Nepal (04) 20070702.2111\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02) 20070620.1990\n.................................................sp/ml/rd/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2055-03-16 00:00:00", "1875-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-09-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tacoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Point Defiance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6697446", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis - USA: (WA) latent, zoo elephant handlers, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6697446", "date": "2019-04-28 10:27:58", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (03): (MICHIGAN) CATTLE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate:Thu 25 Apr 2019\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttps://patch.com/michigan/across-mi/bovine-tb-found-michigan-herd\n\n\nBovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in a small beef herd in Alpena County. This herd, which is the 74th cattle herd to be identified with bovine TB in Michigan since 1998, was identified through routine surveillance testing.\n\nBovine TB, a bacterial disease primarily affecting cattle, is endemic in the free-ranging white-tailed deer population in Michigan's modified accredited zone (MAZ). The MAZ is a U.S. Department of Agriculture designation for Alcona, Alpena, Montmorency and Oscoda counties. In the MAZ, contact with deer can be a potential source of bovine TB infection for cattle. Preventing deer from having access to cattle feed, feed storage, or watering areas is crucial for farmers in this area of Michigan and is a part of the wildlife biosecurity program overseen by the Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development and its partners.\n\nAs part of MDARD's (Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development) standard disease response, an investigation will be conducted to identify and test herds that had an association with the infected herd. In the MAZ, annual surveillance and movement testing are required of cattle producers, which helps detect disease early and prevent it from being moved off the farm.\n\n\"Although a great deal of work is being done by producers in this area of the state, MDARD, the Department of Natural Resources, and partner agencies to prevent bovine TB cases, we do still occasionally see newly infected herds,\" said Michigan's Assistant State Veterinarian Nancy Barr, DVM. \"Responding to them in an effective manner helps prevent further cases and protect the state's TB free status in the remainder of the state. MDARD and the DNR are working with farmers, hunters, and community members to preserve and maintain healthy cattle, healthy deer and healthy communities.\"\n\nAny questions about this herd can be directed to the Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development at 800-292-3939, and more information on bovine TB can be found at http://www.michigan.gov/bovinetb.\n\n[Byline: Jessica Strachan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis is circulating in the cattle herds in Michigan. Cattle and cervids (deer, elk) often have contact with cattle. As the hunting season is upon those in many areas, this should serve as a reminder to be on the lookout for unusual things, such as large lymph nodes or necrotic areas or other abnormalities in your animal when field dressing the animal. It should also serve as a reminder to take along some disposable gloves for use during this process. These gloves are a protective measure for you.\n\n\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\n\"The cooperative federal-state-industry effort to eradicate bovine TB from cattle in the USA has made significant progress since the program's inception in 1917. The disease has nearly been eliminated from the livestock population of the USA. Many consider this one of the great animal- and public-health achievements in the USA. However, our ultimate goal of eradication remains elusive as animal-health officials continue to detect TB sporadically in livestock herds.\n\n\"Signs\n-----\nQ. What is bovine tuberculosis (TB)?\nA. Bovine TB is a contagious, chronic bacterial disease caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_. The infection commonly involves the lungs, but it may spread to other organs. Animals often don't show signs until the infection has reached an advanced stage.\n\nQ. What animals can it affect?\nA. Bovine TB primarily affects cattle, but it can be transmitted to any warm-blooded animal, including people.\n\nQ. What are the clinical signs of bovine TB?\nA. Bovine TB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph nodes may also be enlarged.\n\nQ. What should I do if my animals show these clinical signs?\nA. If you suspect TB in your herd, you should isolate the animal immediately and then call your veterinarian for a proper diagnosis.\n\nQ. How does TB get into cattle herds\nA: TB can be introduced into a herd by infected animals or people. In the USA, the 2 most common methods of introduction are\n\n- the purchase of or exposure to infected cattle; or\n- the exposure to infected free-ranging wildlife.\n\n\"The bacterium that causes bovine TB is found in the saliva of infected animals and spreads through airborne particles from the respiratory tract. The bacteria can also spread through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other bodily discharges (urine, manure) or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as in barns with poor ventilation.\"\n\nExtracted from https://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nMichigan, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (TX) cattle 20190317.6372778\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06): (MI) transmission from deer to humans, 2017", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6696353", "date": "2019-04-28 10:27:58", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (03): (MICHIGAN) CATTLE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate:Thu 25 Apr 2019\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttps://patch.com/michigan/across-mi/bovine-tb-found-michigan-herd\n\n\nBovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in a small beef herd in Alpena County. This herd, which is the 74th cattle herd to be identified with bovine TB in Michigan since 1998, was identified through routine surveillance testing.\n\nBovine TB, a bacterial disease primarily affecting cattle, is endemic in the free-ranging white-tailed deer population in Michigan's modified accredited zone (MAZ). The MAZ is a U.S. Department of Agriculture designation for Alcona, Alpena, Montmorency and Oscoda counties. In the MAZ, contact with deer can be a potential source of bovine TB infection for cattle. Preventing deer from having access to cattle feed, feed storage, or watering areas is crucial for farmers in this area of Michigan and is a part of the wildlife biosecurity program overseen by the Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development and its partners.\n\nAs part of MDARD's (Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development) standard disease response, an investigation will be conducted to identify and test herds that had an association with the infected herd. In the MAZ, annual surveillance and movement testing are required of cattle producers, which helps detect disease early and prevent it from being moved off the farm.\n\n\"Although a great deal of work is being done by producers in this area of the state, MDARD, the Department of Natural Resources, and partner agencies to prevent bovine TB cases, we do still occasionally see newly infected herds,\" said Michigan's Assistant State Veterinarian Nancy Barr, DVM. \"Responding to them in an effective manner helps prevent further cases and protect the state's TB free status in the remainder of the state. MDARD and the DNR are working with farmers, hunters, and community members to preserve and maintain healthy cattle, healthy deer and healthy communities.\"\n\nAny questions about this herd can be directed to the Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development at 800-292-3939, and more information on bovine TB can be found at http://www.michigan.gov/bovinetb.\n\n[Byline: Jessica Strachan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis is circulating in the cattle herds in Michigan. Cattle and cervids (deer, elk) often have contact with cattle. As the hunting season is upon those in many areas, this should serve as a reminder to be on the lookout for unusual things, such as large lymph nodes or necrotic areas or other abnormalities in your animal when field dressing the animal. It should also serve as a reminder to take along some disposable gloves for use during this process. These gloves are a protective measure for you.\n\n\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\n\"The cooperative federal-state-industry effort to eradicate bovine TB from cattle in the USA has made significant progress since the program's inception in 1917. The disease has nearly been eliminated from the livestock population of the USA. Many consider this one of the great animal- and public-health achievements in the USA. However, our ultimate goal of eradication remains elusive as animal-health officials continue to detect TB sporadically in livestock herds.\n\n\"Signs\n-----\nQ. What is bovine tuberculosis (TB)?\nA. Bovine TB is a contagious, chronic bacterial disease caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_. The infection commonly involves the lungs, but it may spread to other organs. Animals often don't show signs until the infection has reached an advanced stage.\n\nQ. What animals can it affect?\nA. Bovine TB primarily affects cattle, but it can be transmitted to any warm-blooded animal, including people.\n\nQ. What are the clinical signs of bovine TB?\nA. Bovine TB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph nodes may also be enlarged.\n\nQ. What should I do if my animals show these clinical signs?\nA. If you suspect TB in your herd, you should isolate the animal immediately and then call your veterinarian for a proper diagnosis.\n\nQ. How does TB get into cattle herds\nA: TB can be introduced into a herd by infected animals or people. In the USA, the 2 most common methods of introduction are\n\n- the purchase of or exposure to infected cattle; or\n- the exposure to infected free-ranging wildlife.\n\n\"The bacterium that causes bovine TB is found in the saliva of infected animals and spreads through airborne particles from the respiratory tract. The bacteria can also spread through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other bodily discharges (urine, manure) or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as in barns with poor ventilation.\"\n\nExtracted from https://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nMichigan, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (TX) cattle 20190317.6372778\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) 20160108.3919034\n2015\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine 20150725.3534951\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) dairy cows 20150426.3323167\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1917-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alpena County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alcona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6603558", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - Germany (02): (BW) school outbreak, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6603558", "date": "2019-04-28 10:27:58", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (03): (MICHIGAN) CATTLE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate:Thu 25 Apr 2019\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttps://patch.com/michigan/across-mi/bovine-tb-found-michigan-herd\n\n\nBovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in a small beef herd in Alpena County. This herd, which is the 74th cattle herd to be identified with bovine TB in Michigan since 1998, was identified through routine surveillance testing.\n\nBovine TB, a bacterial disease primarily affecting cattle, is endemic in the free-ranging white-tailed deer population in Michigan's modified accredited zone (MAZ). The MAZ is a U.S. Department of Agriculture designation for Alcona, Alpena, Montmorency and Oscoda counties. In the MAZ, contact with deer can be a potential source of bovine TB infection for cattle. Preventing deer from having access to cattle feed, feed storage, or watering areas is crucial for farmers in this area of Michigan and is a part of the wildlife biosecurity program overseen by the Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development and its partners.\n\nAs part of MDARD's (Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development) standard disease response, an investigation will be conducted to identify and test herds that had an association with the infected herd. In the MAZ, annual surveillance and movement testing are required of cattle producers, which helps detect disease early and prevent it from being moved off the farm.\n\n\"Although a great deal of work is being done by producers in this area of the state, MDARD, the Department of Natural Resources, and partner agencies to prevent bovine TB cases, we do still occasionally see newly infected herds,\" said Michigan's Assistant State Veterinarian Nancy Barr, DVM. \"Responding to them in an effective manner helps prevent further cases and protect the state's TB free status in the remainder of the state. MDARD and the DNR are working with farmers, hunters, and community members to preserve and maintain healthy cattle, healthy deer and healthy communities.\"\n\nAny questions about this herd can be directed to the Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development at 800-292-3939, and more information on bovine TB can be found at http://www.michigan.gov/bovinetb.\n\n[Byline: Jessica Strachan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis is circulating in the cattle herds in Michigan. Cattle and cervids (deer, elk) often have contact with cattle. As the hunting season is upon those in many areas, this should serve as a reminder to be on the lookout for unusual things, such as large lymph nodes or necrotic areas or other abnormalities in your animal when field dressing the animal. It should also serve as a reminder to take along some disposable gloves for use during this process. These gloves are a protective measure for you.\n\n\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\n\"The cooperative federal-state-industry effort to eradicate bovine TB from cattle in the USA has made significant progress since the program's inception in 1917. The disease has nearly been eliminated from the livestock population of the USA. Many consider this one of the great animal- and public-health achievements in the USA. However, our ultimate goal of eradication remains elusive as animal-health officials continue to detect TB sporadically in livestock herds.\n\n\"Signs\n-----\nQ. What is bovine tuberculosis (TB)?\nA. Bovine TB is a contagious, chronic bacterial disease caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_. The infection commonly involves the lungs, but it may spread to other organs. Animals often don't show signs until the infection has reached an advanced stage.\n\nQ. What animals can it affect?\nA. Bovine TB primarily affects cattle, but it can be transmitted to any warm-blooded animal, including people.\n\nQ. What are the clinical signs of bovine TB?\nA. Bovine TB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph nodes may also be enlarged.\n\nQ. What should I do if my animals show these clinical signs?\nA. If you suspect TB in your herd, you should isolate the animal immediately and then call your veterinarian for a proper diagnosis.\n\nQ. How does TB get into cattle herds\nA: TB can be introduced into a herd by infected animals or people. In the USA, the 2 most common methods of introduction are\n\n- the purchase of or exposure to infected cattle; or\n- the exposure to infected free-ranging wildlife.\n\n\"The bacterium that causes bovine TB is found in the saliva of infected animals and spreads through airborne particles from the respiratory tract. The bacteria can also spread through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other bodily discharges (urine, manure) or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as in barns with poor ventilation.\"\n\nExtracted from https://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nMichigan, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (TX) cattle 20190317.6372778\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (04): (AB) herds quarantined, investigation 20161106.4610944\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (03): (AB) herds quarantined 20161101.4600493\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (MI) new county affected 20161101.4600409\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (02): (AB) herds quarantined 20161031.4598091\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada: (AB) 20161020.4574397\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (IN) wild cervids 20160817.4420929\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) 20160519.4233252\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) 20160108.3919034\n2015\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine 20150725.3534951\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) dairy cows 20150426.3323167\nand other items in the archives\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1917-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alpena County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alcona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6586217", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - These gloves are a protective measure for you.\n\n\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\n\"The cooperative federal-state-industry effort to eradicate bovine TB from cattle in the USA has made significant progress since the program's inception in 1917. The disease has nearly been eliminated from the livestock population of the USA. Many consider this one of the great animal- and public-health achievements in the USA. However, our ultimate goal of eradication remains elusive as animal-health officials continue to detect TB sporadically in livestock herds.\n\n\"Signs\n-----\nQ. What is bovine tuberculosis (TB)?\nA. Bovine TB is a contagious, chronic bacterial disease caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_. The infection commonly involves the lungs, but it may spread to other organs. Animals often don't show signs until the infection has reached an advanced stage.\n\nQ. What animals can it affect?\nA. Bovine TB primarily affects cattle, but it can be transmitted to any warm-blooded animal, including people.\n\nQ. What are the clinical signs of bovine TB?\nA. Bovine TB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph nodes may also be enlarged.\n\nQ. What should I do if my animals show these clinical signs?\nA. If you suspect TB in your herd, you should isolate the animal immediately and then call your veterinarian for a proper diagnosis.\n\nQ. How does TB get into cattle herds\nA: TB can be introduced into a herd by infected animals or people. In the USA, the 2 most common methods of introduction are\n\n- the purchase of or exposure to infected cattle; or\n- the exposure to infected free-ranging wildlife.\n\n\"The bacterium that causes bovine TB is found in the saliva of infected animals and spreads through airborne particles from the respiratory tract. The bacteria can also spread through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other bodily discharges (urine, manure) or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as in barns with poor ventilation.\"\n\nExtracted from https://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nMichigan, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (TX) cattle 20190317.6372778\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (WI) cattle", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6464732", "date": "2019-04-28 10:27:58", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (03): (MICHIGAN) CATTLE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate:Thu 25 Apr 2019\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttps://patch.com/michigan/across-mi/bovine-tb-found-michigan-herd\n\n\nBovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in a small beef herd in Alpena County. This herd, which is the 74th cattle herd to be identified with bovine TB in Michigan since 1998, was identified through routine surveillance testing.\n\nBovine TB, a bacterial disease primarily affecting cattle, is endemic in the free-ranging white-tailed deer population in Michigan's modified accredited zone (MAZ). The MAZ is a U.S. Department of Agriculture designation for Alcona, Alpena, Montmorency and Oscoda counties. In the MAZ, contact with deer can be a potential source of bovine TB infection for cattle. Preventing deer from having access to cattle feed, feed storage, or watering areas is crucial for farmers in this area of Michigan and is a part of the wildlife biosecurity program overseen by the Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development and its partners.\n\nAs part of MDARD's (Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development) standard disease response, an investigation will be conducted to identify and test herds that had an association with the infected herd. In the MAZ, annual surveillance and movement testing are required of cattle producers, which helps detect disease early and prevent it from being moved off the farm.\n\n\"Although a great deal of work is being done by producers in this area of the state, MDARD, the Department of Natural Resources, and partner agencies to prevent bovine TB cases, we do still occasionally see newly infected herds,\" said Michigan's Assistant State Veterinarian Nancy Barr, DVM. \"Responding to them in an effective manner helps prevent further cases and protect the state's TB free status in the remainder of the state. MDARD and the DNR are working with farmers, hunters, and community members to preserve and maintain healthy cattle, healthy deer and healthy communities.\"\n\nAny questions about this herd can be directed to the Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development at 800-292-3939, and more information on bovine TB can be found at http://www.michigan.gov/bovinetb.\n\n[Byline: Jessica Strachan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis is circulating in the cattle herds in Michigan. Cattle and cervids (deer, elk) often have contact with cattle. As the hunting season is upon those in many areas, this should serve as a reminder to be on the lookout for unusual things, such as large lymph nodes or necrotic areas or other abnormalities in your animal when field dressing the animal. It should also serve as a reminder to take along some disposable gloves for use during this process. These gloves are a protective measure for you.\n\n\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\n\"The cooperative federal-state-industry effort to eradicate bovine TB from cattle in the USA has made significant progress since the program's inception in 1917. The disease has nearly been eliminated from the livestock population of the USA. Many consider this one of the great animal- and public-health achievements in the USA. However, our ultimate goal of eradication remains elusive as animal-health officials continue to detect TB sporadically in livestock herds.\n\n\"Signs\n-----\nQ. What is bovine tuberculosis (TB)?\nA. Bovine TB is a contagious, chronic bacterial disease caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_. The infection commonly involves the lungs, but it may spread to other organs. Animals often don't show signs until the infection has reached an advanced stage.\n\nQ. What animals can it affect?\nA. Bovine TB primarily affects cattle, but it can be transmitted to any warm-blooded animal, including people.\n\nQ. What are the clinical signs of bovine TB?\nA. Bovine TB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph nodes may also be enlarged.\n\nQ. What should I do if my animals show these clinical signs?\nA. If you suspect TB in your herd, you should isolate the animal immediately and then call your veterinarian for a proper diagnosis.\n\nQ. How does TB get into cattle herds\nA: TB can be introduced into a herd by infected animals or people. In the USA, the 2 most common methods of introduction are\n\n- the purchase of or exposure to infected cattle; or\n- the exposure to infected free-ranging wildlife.\n\n\"The bacterium that causes bovine TB is found in the saliva of infected animals and spreads through airborne particles from the respiratory tract. The bacteria can also spread through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other bodily discharges (urine, manure) or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as in barns with poor ventilation.\"\n\nExtracted from https://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alpena County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alcona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6402973", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Israel (03): (HZ) cattle, M. bovis, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6402973", "date": "2019-01-10 13:28:39", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA) BOVINE, NEW STRAIN\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 9 Jan 2019\nSource: Manitoba Co-operator [edited]\nhttps://www.manitobacooperator.ca/daily/bovine-tb-strain-in-latest-outbreak-new-to-canada\n\n\nCanada's latest outbreak of bovine tuberculosis in domestic cattle involves a strain of TB bacteria not related to any previously seen in Canadian livestock or wildlife.\n\nCulture testing of bacteria taken from a cow confirmed as TB-positive in November [2018] shows it's \"not related to past cases of bovine TB in Alberta or British Columbia [BC] or anywhere else in Canada,\" the Canadian Food Inspection Agency said on [Wed 9 Jan 2019].\n\nThe agency also said on [Wed 9 Jan 2019] it has now tested the \"majority\" of animals from that infected cow's home herd in BC's southern Interior, and has so far turned up 3 more TB-positive cattle in that herd.\n\nNo part of any of the 4 infected cattle ever entered the food chain, the agency said.\n\nFederal chief veterinary officer Dr. Jaspinder Komal, on a conference call with reporters on [Wed 9 Jan 2019], said the genetic type of the B.C. cow's TB strain also does not match the one seen in Canada's most recent previous bovine TB probe, nor any other isolates found in Canada.\n\nThat previous bovine TB probe -- launched on the September 2016 discovery of a southern Alberta cow with the disease -- also involved a strain never previously seen in Canadian livestock, wildlife or people but which was \"closely related\" to a strain originating from cattle in central Mexico in 1997.\n\nAsked whether the BC cow's strain is connected to any seen in the U.S. or abroad, Komal replied that to CFIA's \"very preliminary\" knowledge, the strain doesn't appear to match any yet seen in Canada or the U.S.\n\nThe infected BC cattle's home premises remain under movement controls, CFIA said, as do 10 other premises in BC, 13 in Alberta and one in Saskatchewan, affecting a total of 18 000 animals. No herds in this probe have yet been released from movement controls.\n\nThe current investigation, run jointly by CFIA and the BC government, began after the 1st infected cow was presented for slaughter at a federally-registered facility on [26 Oct 2018]. Post-mortem examination found lesions in that animal's lymph nodes, lungs and liver; the carcass was then condemned and bovine TB was lab-confirmed on [9 Nov 2018].\n\nA federally reportable livestock disease, bovine TB has been subject to a mandatory nationwide eradication program since 1923.\n\n[Byline: Dave Bedard]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis is a slow insidious disease. Depending on how advanced the lesions are it can be a tough call. The inspectors are to be congratulated. Veterinary inspectors are one of our 1st lines of defense for meat safety. The meat inspectors at the slaughter plant, the front line of detection and prevention will need to be very careful and thorough in their inspections. Inspectors are the front line of preventing diseases such as this from entering the food chain. While we all want cheap, rapid access to quality products, it is very unwise to run a slaughter line so fast the inspectors are not able to do a diligent thorough job, especially when a new strain of disease is prevalent, or any disease needing detecting.\n\nIn November 2018, we were hopeful this was an isolated case, but it takes time to test herds of cattle and do trace-ins and trace-outs (animals moving into or out of a herd) to determine where movements and exposure may have occurred.\n\nNow we know it is not necessarily a single issue but involves more than 1 animal, but hopefully not more than 1 herd. Tracing a new disease back to its origin is one issue, but testing and tracing for a very slow growing disease is quite a longer matter. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBritish Columbia Province, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/264]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (02): (BC) bovine 20181121.6156863\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada: (AB) Mexican strain, tuberculosis - Canada (10): (AB) Mexican strain 20161217.4706014\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (09): (AB) Mexican strain 20161127.4657187\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (08): (AB) Mexican strain 20161119.4640117\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (07): (AB) Mexican strain 20161117.4636107\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (06): (AB, SK) singular genome 20161114.4628497\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (05): (AB,SK) extended 20161110.4620082\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (04): (AB) herds quarantined, investigation 20161106.4610944\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (03): (AB) herds quarantined STRAIN\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 9 Jan 2019\nSource: Manitoba Co-operator [edited]\nhttps://www.manitobacooperator.ca/daily/bovine-tb-strain-in-latest-outbreak-new-to-canada\n\n\nCanada's latest outbreak of bovine tuberculosis in domestic cattle involves a strain of TB bacteria not related to any previously seen in Canadian livestock or wildlife.\n\nCulture testing of bacteria taken from a cow confirmed as TB-positive in November [2018] shows it's \"not related to past cases of bovine TB in Alberta or British Columbia [BC] or anywhere else in Canada,\" the Canadian Food Inspection Agency said on [Wed 9 Jan 2019].\n\nThe agency also said on [Wed 9 Jan 2019] it has now tested the \"majority\" of animals from that infected cow's home herd in BC's southern Interior, and has so far turned up 3 more TB-positive cattle in that herd.\n\nNo part of any of the 4 infected cattle ever entered the food chain, the agency said.\n\nFederal chief veterinary officer Dr. Jaspinder Komal, on a conference call with reporters on [Wed 9 Jan 2019], said the genetic type of the B.C. cow's TB strain also does not match the one seen in Canada's most recent previous bovine TB probe, nor any other isolates found in Canada.\n\nThat previous bovine TB probe -- launched on the September 2016 discovery of a southern Alberta cow with the disease -- also involved a strain never previously seen in Canadian livestock, wildlife or people but which was \"closely related\" to a strain originating from cattle in central Mexico in 1997.\n\nAsked whether the BC cow's strain is connected to any seen in the U.S. or abroad, Komal replied that to CFIA's \"very preliminary\" knowledge, the strain doesn't appear to match any yet seen in Canada or the U.S.\n\nThe infected BC cattle's home premises remain under movement controls, CFIA said, as do 10 other premises in BC, 13 in Alberta and one in Saskatchewan, affecting a total of 18 000 animals. No herds in this probe have yet been released from movement controls.\n\nThe current investigation, run jointly by CFIA and the BC government, began after the 1st infected cow was presented for slaughter at a federally-registered facility on [26 Oct 2018]. Post-mortem examination found lesions in that animal's lymph nodes, lungs and liver; the carcass was then condemned and bovine TB was lab-confirmed on [9 Nov 2018].\n\nA federally reportable livestock disease, bovine TB has been subject to a mandatory nationwide eradication program since 1923.\n\n[Byline: Dave Bedard]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis is a slow insidious disease. Depending on how advanced the lesions are it can be a tough call. The inspectors are to be congratulated. Veterinary inspectors are one of our 1st lines of defense for meat safety. The meat inspectors at the slaughter plant, the front line of detection and prevention will need to be very careful and thorough in their inspections. Inspectors are the front line of preventing diseases such as this from entering the food chain. While we all want cheap, rapid access to quality products, it is very unwise to run a slaughter line so fast the inspectors are not able to do a diligent thorough job, especially when a new strain of disease is prevalent, or any disease needing detecting.\n\nIn November 2018, we were hopeful this was an isolated case, but it takes time to test herds of cattle and do trace-ins and trace-outs (animals moving into or out of a herd) to determine where movements and exposure may have occurred.\n\nNow we know it is not necessarily a single issue but involves more than 1 animal, but hopefully not more than 1 herd. Tracing a new disease back to its origin is one issue, but testing and tracing for a very slow growing disease is quite a longer matter. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBritish 20070915.3068\nTuberculosis, cervids - Canada (MB) 20070914.3060\n.................................................sb/tg/ao/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-01-09 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "1923-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-11-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 "British Columbia Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saskatchewan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6340422", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Fiji: cattle", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6340422", "date": "2019-01-10 13:28:39", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - CANADA: (BRITISH COLUMBIA) BOVINE, NEW STRAIN\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 9 Jan 2019\nSource: Manitoba Co-operator [edited]\nhttps://www.manitobacooperator.ca/daily/bovine-tb-strain-in-latest-outbreak-new-to-canada\n\n\nCanada's latest outbreak of bovine tuberculosis in domestic cattle involves a strain of TB bacteria not related to any previously seen in Canadian livestock or wildlife.\n\nCulture testing of bacteria taken from a cow confirmed as TB-positive in November [2018] shows it's \"not related to past cases of bovine TB in Alberta or British Columbia [BC] or anywhere else in Canada,\" the Canadian Food Inspection Agency said on [Wed 9 Jan 2019].\n\nThe agency also said on [Wed 9 Jan 2019] it has now tested the \"majority\" of animals from that infected cow's home herd in BC's southern Interior, and has so far turned up 3 more TB-positive cattle in that herd.\n\nNo part of any of the 4 infected cattle ever entered the food chain, the agency said.\n\nFederal chief veterinary officer Dr. Jaspinder Komal, on a conference call with reporters on [Wed 9 Jan 2019], said the genetic type of the B.C. cow's TB strain also does not match the one seen in Canada's most recent previous bovine TB probe, nor any other isolates found in Canada.\n\nThat previous bovine TB probe -- launched on the September 2016 discovery of a southern Alberta cow with the disease -- also involved a strain never previously seen in Canadian livestock, wildlife or people but which was \"closely related\" to a strain originating from cattle in central Mexico in 1997.\n\nAsked whether the BC cow's strain is connected to any seen in the U.S. or abroad, Komal replied that to CFIA's \"very preliminary\" knowledge, the strain doesn't appear to match any yet seen in Canada or the U.S.\n\nThe infected BC cattle's home premises remain under movement controls, CFIA said, as do 10 other premises in BC, 13 in Alberta and one in Saskatchewan, affecting a total of 18 000 animals. No herds in this probe have yet been released from movement controls.\n\nThe current investigation, run jointly by CFIA and the BC government, began after the 1st infected cow was presented for slaughter at a federally-registered facility on [26 Oct 2018]. Post-mortem examination found lesions in that animal's lymph nodes, lungs and liver; the carcass was then condemned and bovine TB was lab-confirmed on [9 Nov 2018].\n\nA federally reportable livestock disease, bovine TB has been subject to a mandatory nationwide eradication program since 1923.\n\n[Byline: Dave Bedard]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis is a slow insidious disease. Depending on how advanced the lesions are it can be a tough call. The inspectors are to be congratulated. Veterinary inspectors are one of our 1st lines of defense for meat safety. The meat inspectors at the slaughter plant, the front line of detection and prevention will need to be very careful and thorough in their inspections. Inspectors are the front line of preventing diseases such as this from entering the food chain. While we all want cheap, rapid access to quality products, it is very unwise to run a slaughter line so fast the inspectors are not able to do a diligent thorough job, especially when a new strain of disease is prevalent, or any disease needing detecting.\n\nIn November 2018, we were hopeful this was an isolated case, but it takes time to test herds of cattle and do trace-ins and trace-outs (animals moving into or out of a herd) to determine where movements and exposure may have occurred.\n\nNow we know it is not necessarily a single issue but involves more than 1 animal, but hopefully not more than 1 herd. Tracing a new disease back to its origin is one issue, but testing and tracing for a very slow growing disease is quite a longer matter. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBritish Columbia Province, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/264]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (02): (BC) bovine 20181121.6156863\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada: (AB) Mexican strain, tuberculosis - Canada (10): (AB) Mexican strain 20161217.4706014\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (09): (AB) Mexican strain 20161127.4657187\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (08): (AB) Mexican strain The meat inspectors at the slaughter plant, the front line of detection and prevention will need to be very careful and thorough in their inspections. Inspectors are the front line of preventing diseases such as this from entering the food chain. While we all want cheap, rapid access to quality products, it is very unwise to run a slaughter line so fast the inspectors are not able to do a diligent thorough job, especially when a new strain of disease is prevalent, or any disease needing detecting.\n\nIn November 2018, we were hopeful this was an isolated case, but it takes time to test herds of cattle and do trace-ins and trace-outs (animals moving into or out of a herd) to determine where movements and exposure may have occurred.\n\nNow we know it is not necessarily a single issue but involves more than 1 animal, but hopefully not more than 1 herd. Tracing a new disease back to its origin is one issue, but testing and tracing for a very slow growing disease is quite a longer matter. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBritish Columbia Province, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/264]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (02): (BC) bovine 20181121.6156863\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada: (AB) Mexican strain, 2016 20180502.5780065\n2017\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (02): (AB) Mexican strain 20171119.5452702\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (MB) (03) 20070918.3094\nTuberculosis, cervids - Canada (MB) (02) 20070915.3068\nTuberculosis, cervids - Canada (MB) 20070914.3060\n.................................................sb/tg/ao/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-01-09 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "1923-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-11-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saskatchewan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6170266", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (MI) cervids, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6170266", "date": "2018-08-03 09:15:25", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: (ENGLAND) CANINE, 2016-2017, EPIDEMIOLOGY\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2018\nSource: Transboundary and Emerging Diseases [edited]\nhttps://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/tbed.12969\n\n\nCitation:\nO'Halloran C, Hope JC, Dobromylskyj M, Burr P, McDonald K, Rhodes S, Roberts T et al. An outbreak of tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ infection in a pack of English Foxhounds (2016-2017). Transbound Emerg Dis. 2018; 1-13. First published: 30 Jul 2018. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1111/tbed.12969\n\nAbstract\n--------\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ can cause tuberculosis (TB) in social mammals including lions, cattle, and man, but canine infections are considered rare. In 2016/17 we investigated a _M. bovis_ TB outbreak in a pack of approximately 180 Foxhounds within the bovine TB Edge Area of England. We employed a combination of immunological tests including an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) and a serological assay (DPP VetTB, Chembio). Test\u2010positive hounds were euthanased and subjected to post-mortem examination (PME). Overall, 164 hounds were tested; 97 (59 percent) responded positively to at least one test. 85 (52 percent) of the dogs responded to _M. bovis_ antigens by IGRA, while only 21 (12.9 percent) had detectable serological responses. At PME, 3 hounds (3.1 percent) had visible lesions (VL) due to _M. bovis_ infection, later confirmed by culture. Samples from 24 non\u2010VL hounds were cultured, and _M. bovis_ infection was confirmed in a further 3 hounds (11 percent). This study is the 1st investigation and report of an outbreak of _M. bovis_ TB in a canine species. We establish that, in principle, diagnostic tests used for identifying infected individuals of other species can effectively be used in the dog. Further work is urgently needed to establish the sensitivity and specificity of the testing approach used in this study for future clinical application.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 28 Feb 2017, MFHA (the \"Masters of Foxhounds Association,\" the governing body of foxhunting, representing 176 packs of foxhounds that hunt in England and Wales and a further 10 in Scotland) informed the public about the exceptional bTB event in the Kimblewick Hunt. It was disclosed that \"The Kimblewick and Hunting Office are working closely with officials from DEFRA, Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA), Public Health England, the Royal Dick Veterinary School (Edinburgh), and other vets with specialist expertise in bTB in order to determine the exact position and the best way forward.\" (See 20170308.4886254 and https://www.horseandhound.co.uk/news/bovine-tb-confirmed-kimblewick-hounds-614291).\n\nThe current paper is the outcome of the mentioned collaborative effort by the named parties.\n\nFrom the discussion chapter, the following is copied for subscribers' convenience:\n\n\"Whilst uncertainty exists with regards to the source of infection, it seems likely that contaminated fallen stock carcasses were involved. All cultured positive animals had the same genotype isolated, which has not been frequently detected in the area local to the kennels. This suggests a single introduction with a large dose of infectious material was likely, and that infection then spread between cohabiting hounds. One kennel worker was also diagnosed with latent TB, potentially due to exposure to infected hounds and/or their contaminated feed, though this remains unproven. Though the risk posed by _M. bovis_ infected hounds to other hounds, cattle herds, local wildlife, their environment, and their human keepers is low, this outbreak demonstrates that the risk is plausible and real. Resultantly, to try to prevent such an outbreak from occurring again, the conditions for the collection and use of animal by\u2010products for feeding to dogs in recognized kennels or packs of hounds have now been amended to ban the feeding of offal from fallen stock. Similarly, health surveillance requirements for hounds have been increased by the MFHA. To be successful, these policy changes will need to be aided, however, by the future evaluation of diagnostic test accuracy and test development for canine TB.\"\n\nSubscribers are encouraged to access the full paper (free access). - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nEngland, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279]\nSee Also\n2017\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (England) bovine 20170525.5062625\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) canine, camelid 20170308.4886254\n2016\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine 20160412.4155248\n2015\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine 20150127.3124201\n2014\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): bovine, spread, research 20140705.2589984\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex UK, susp, RFI 20140530.2508847\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: bovine spread, feline 20140410.2395905\n2013\n---\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 2013, domestic cat-to-human transm. 20140327.2361967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20130809.1871322\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20130731.1855759\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - Resultantly, to try to prevent such an outbreak from occurring again, the conditions for the collection and use of animal by\u2010products for feeding to dogs in recognized kennels or packs of hounds have now been amended to ban the feeding of offal from fallen stock. USA (06): (WI) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6132360", "date": "2018-08-03 09:15:25", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: (ENGLAND) CANINE, 2016-2017, EPIDEMIOLOGY\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2018\nSource: Transboundary and Emerging Diseases [edited]\nhttps://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/tbed.12969\n\n\nCitation:\nO'Halloran C, Hope JC, Dobromylskyj M, Burr P, McDonald K, Rhodes S, Roberts T et al. UK: (England) 2013, domestic cat-to-human transm. 20140327.2361967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20130809.1871322\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20130731.1855759\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20130730.1854572\n.................................................sb/arn/tw/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-13 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-02-28 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "English Foxhounds", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6122495", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (WI) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6122495", "date": "2018-08-03 09:15:25", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: (ENGLAND) CANINE, 2016-2017, EPIDEMIOLOGY\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Jul 2018\nSource: Transboundary and Emerging Diseases [edited]\nhttps://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/tbed.12969\n\n\nCitation:\nO'Halloran C, Hope JC, Dobromylskyj M, Burr P, McDonald K, Rhodes S, Roberts T et al. An outbreak of tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ infection in a pack of English Foxhounds (2016-2017). Transbound Emerg Dis. 2018; 1-13. First published: 30 Jul 2018. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1111/tbed.12969\n\nAbstract\n--------\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ can cause tuberculosis (TB) in social mammals including lions, cattle, and man, but canine infections are considered rare. In 2016/17 we investigated a _M. bovis_ TB outbreak in a pack of approximately 180 Foxhounds within the bovine TB Edge Area of England. We employed a combination of immunological tests including an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) and a serological assay (DPP VetTB, Chembio). Test\u2010positive hounds were euthanased and subjected to post-mortem examination (PME). Overall, 164 hounds were tested; 97 (59 percent) responded positively to at least one test. 85 (52 percent) of the dogs responded to _M. bovis_ antigens by IGRA, while only 21 (12.9 percent) had detectable serological responses. At PME, 3 hounds (3.1 percent) had visible lesions (VL) due to _M. bovis_ infection, later confirmed by culture. Samples from 24 non\u2010VL hounds were cultured, and _M. bovis_ infection was confirmed in a further 3 hounds (11 percent). This study is the 1st investigation and report of an outbreak of _M. bovis_ TB in a canine species. We establish that, in principle, diagnostic tests used for identifying infected individuals of other species can effectively be used in the dog. Further work is urgently needed to establish the sensitivity and specificity of the testing approach used in this study for future clinical application.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 28 Feb 2017, MFHA (the \"Masters of Foxhounds Association,\" the governing body of foxhunting, representing 176 packs of foxhounds that hunt in England and Wales and a further 10 in Scotland) informed the public about the exceptional bTB event in the Kimblewick Hunt. It was disclosed that \"The Kimblewick and Hunting Office are working closely with officials from DEFRA, Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA), Public Health England, the Royal Dick Veterinary School (Edinburgh), and other vets with specialist expertise in bTB in order to determine the exact position and the best way forward.\" (See 20170308.4886254 and https://www.horseandhound.co.uk/news/bovine-tb-confirmed-kimblewick-hounds-614291).\n\nThe current paper is the outcome of the mentioned collaborative effort by the named parties.\n\nFrom the discussion chapter, the following is copied for subscribers' convenience:\n\n\"Whilst uncertainty exists with regards to the source of infection, it seems likely that contaminated fallen stock carcasses were involved. All cultured positive animals had the same genotype isolated, which has not been frequently detected in the area local to the kennels. This suggests a single introduction with a large dose of infectious material was likely, and that infection then spread between cohabiting hounds. One kennel worker was also diagnosed with latent TB, potentially due to exposure to infected hounds and/or their contaminated feed, though this remains unproven. Though the risk posed by _M. bovis_ infected hounds to other hounds, cattle herds, local wildlife, their environment, and their human keepers is low, this outbreak demonstrates that the risk is plausible and real. Resultantly, to try to prevent such an outbreak from occurring again, the conditions for the collection and use of animal by\u2010products for feeding to dogs in recognized kennels or packs of hounds have now been amended to ban the feeding of offal from fallen stock. Similarly, health surveillance requirements for hounds have been increased by the MFHA. To be successful, these policy changes will need to be aided, however, by the future evaluation of diagnostic test accuracy and test development for canine TB.\"\n\nSubscribers are encouraged to access the full paper (free access). - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nEngland, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/279]\nSee Also\n2017\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (England) bovine 20170525.5062625\nBovine tuberculosis - All cultured positive animals had the same genotype isolated, which has not been frequently detected in the area local to the kennels. This suggests a single introduction with a large dose of infectious material was likely, and that infection then spread between cohabiting hounds. One kennel worker was also diagnosed with latent TB, potentially due to exposure to infected hounds and/or their contaminated feed, though this remains unproven. Though the risk posed by _M. bovis_ infected hounds to other hounds, cattle herds, local wildlife, their environment, and their human keepers is low, this outbreak demonstrates that the risk is plausible and real. Resultantly, to try to prevent such an outbreak from occurring again, the conditions for the collection and use of animal by\u2010products for feeding to dogs in recognized kennels or packs of hounds have now been amended to ban the feeding of offal from fallen stock. Similarly, health surveillance requirements for hounds have been increased by the MFHA. To be successful, these policy changes will need to be aided, however, by the future evaluation of diagnostic test accuracy and test development for canine TB.\"\n\nSubscribers are encouraged to access the full paper (free access). - An outbreak of tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ infection in a pack of English Foxhounds (2016-2017). Transbound Emerg Dis. 2018; 1-13. First published: 30 Jul 2018. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1111/tbed.12969\n\nAbstract\n--------\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ can cause tuberculosis (TB) in social mammals including lions, cattle, and man, but canine infections are considered rare. In 2016/17 we investigated a _M. bovis_ TB outbreak in a pack of approximately 180 Foxhounds within the bovine TB Edge Area of England. At PME, 3 hounds (3.1 percent) had visible lesions (VL) due to _M. bovis_ infection, later confirmed by culture. Samples from 24 non\u2010VL hounds were cultured, and _M. bovis_ infection was confirmed in a further 3 hounds (11 percent). This study is the 1st investigation and report of an outbreak of _M. bovis_ TB in a canine species. We establish that, in principle, diagnostic tests used for identifying infected individuals of other species can effectively be used in the dog. Further work is urgently needed to establish the sensitivity and specificity of the testing approach used in this study for future clinical application.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[On 28 Feb 2017, MFHA (the \"Masters of Foxhounds Association,\" the governing body of foxhunting, representing 176 packs of foxhounds that hunt in England and Wales and a further 10 in Scotland) informed the public about the exceptional bTB event in the Kimblewick Hunt. It was disclosed that \"The Kimblewick and Hunting Office are working closely with officials from DEFRA, Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA), Public Health England, the Royal Dick Veterinary School (Edinburgh), and other vets with specialist expertise in bTB in order to determine the exact position and the best way forward.\" (See 20170308.4886254 and https://www.horseandhound.co.uk/news/bovine-tb-confirmed-kimblewick-hounds-614291).\n\nThe current paper is the outcome of the mentioned collaborative effort by the named parties.\n\nFrom the discussion chapter, the following is copied for subscribers' convenience:\n\n\"Whilst uncertainty exists with regards to the source of infection, it seems likely that contaminated fallen stock carcasses were involved. All cultured positive animals had the same genotype isolated, which has not been frequently detected in the area local to the kennels. This suggests a single introduction with a large dose of infectious material was likely, and that infection then spread between cohabiting hounds. One kennel worker was also diagnosed with latent TB, potentially due to exposure to infected hounds and/or their contaminated feed, though this remains unproven. Though the risk posed by _M. bovis_ infected hounds to other hounds, cattle herds, local wildlife, their environment, and their human keepers is low, this outbreak demonstrates that the risk is plausible and real. Resultantly, to try to prevent such an outbreak from occurring again, the conditions for the collection and use of animal by\u2010products for feeding to dogs in recognized kennels or packs of hounds have now been amended to ban the feeding of offal from fallen stock. Similarly, health surveillance requirements for hounds have been increased by the MFHA. To be successful, these policy changes will need to be aided, however, by the future evaluation of diagnostic test accuracy and test development for canine TB.\"\n\nSubscribers are encouraged to access the full paper (free access). - UK 20130730.1854572\n.................................................sb/arn/tw/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-13 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-02-28 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "English Foxhounds", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5889976", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - France: red fox", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5889976", "date": "2018-02-12 15:40:08", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - IRELAND (04): (KERRY) PROBABLE BADGER SOURCE\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Feb 2018\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttps://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/deer-not-linked-to-outbreak-of-tb-466988.html\n\n\nThe Department of Agriculture has ruled out any link between the increasing numbers of wild deer in south Kerry and the biggest outbreak of bovine TB in living memory in the area. Dozens of farms are in lockdown and 360 cattle have been removed from slaughter, in an area between Kells and Caherdaniel, on the Iveragh peninsula.\n\nDeer and badgers are suspected. At a recent Kerry County Council meeting in Killorglin, questions about the role of deer in the outbreak were raised and emergency motions demanded a department response.\n\nThe department confirmed that \"evidence to date\" supports the view that badgers have contributed to the spread of the TB. \"Badger-capturing is now taking place to reduce the badger density in this area, which has not experienced this type of outbreak in recent times.\" Badger clans, not subject to a previous capture, were being targeted. \"Where badgers are identified as a possible source, a survey is [being] carried out and badgers captured and removed.\"\n\nThe department said: \"There is no evidence of any deer involvement in this outbreak, at this time. A further contributory factor in the area is the number of (cattle) herd fragments which aid the spread of the disease. \"The department acknowledges the concerns, and fully understands the stress associated with disease events on farms. It continues to work with farmers, and veterinary practitioners, in bringing this outbreak under control.\"\n\nHowever, farmers, and some public representatives, are suspicious of deers, with numbers increasing, due to forestry investment.\n\nThe chairman of Kerry IFA, Pat O'Driscoll, said the problem will not be solved just by testing and removing cattle from the peninsula. He said all contributing sources must be identified. The IFA, he said, had met with National Parks and Wildlife officials and received assurances that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\n\nKerry IFA animal health chairman, Kenneth O'Connell, said the IFA was pursuing, through the National Deer Management Forum, the establishment of a national management programme throughout the country, \"and in particular where deer are associated with TB outbreaks\". The IFA is also seeking changes to both the live-valuation scheme, and the consequential loss schemes, to offset the financial impact of TB breakdowns for farmers, he said.\n\nMeanwhile, the Irish Wild Deer Association's Damian Hannigan, a member of the national forum, said while deer, like any other animal, could contract TB, there were different strains. \"There is no evidence to show there is a link between the spread of TB to cattle and deer,\" he said. \"TB diseases on farms is devastating. But to suggest deer are, in any shape or form, responsible, is to muddy the waters,\" he said. He noted that deer numbers existed only in small pockets around Caherciveen, and while South Kerry, generally, had undergone a lot of clear-felling of forestry, the activities might have disturbed badger sets.\n\n[Byline: Anne Lucey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At this moment we have a \"He said, they said\" situation. The sooner that badgers in the area are confirmed to be infected and with a matching strain of _M. bovis_ the better. Kerry IFA has been assured by the National Parks & Wildlife \"that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\" So it should be possible to selectively (i.e. shoot or dart) suspect deer for testing for bTB infections. In a tense situation like this it is best to test both species. - Mod.MHJ\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nCounty Kerry, Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10087]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland (03): (KY) epidemiological notes 20180124.5581590\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland (02): comment, RFI 20180122.5576698\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland: (KY) spread, control 20180121.5574684\n2016\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Austria: (VO,TR) bovine, M. caprae 20160311.4085658\n2013\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Switzerland: (AR) bovine, M. caprae, Liechtenstein susp 20130930.1975157\nBovine tuberculosis - Germany: (BY) bovine, M. caprae 20130317.1590824\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland: call for cervid control 20141104.2928051\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Caherdaniel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kells", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "tuberculosis - Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5780065", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Canada: (AB) Mexican strain, 2016", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5780065", "date": "2018-02-12 15:40:08", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - IRELAND (04): (KERRY) PROBABLE BADGER SOURCE\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Feb 2018\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttps://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/deer-not-linked-to-outbreak-of-tb-466988.html\n\n\nThe Department of Agriculture has ruled out any link between the increasing numbers of wild deer in south Kerry and the biggest outbreak of bovine TB in living memory in the area. Dozens of farms are in lockdown and 360 cattle have been removed from slaughter, in an area between Kells and Caherdaniel, on the Iveragh peninsula.\n\nDeer and badgers are suspected. At a recent Kerry County Council meeting in Killorglin, questions about the role of deer in the outbreak were raised and emergency motions demanded a department response.\n\nThe department confirmed that \"evidence to date\" supports the view that badgers have contributed to the spread of the TB. \"Badger-capturing is now taking place to reduce the badger density in this area, which has not experienced this type of outbreak in recent times.\" Badger clans, not subject to a previous capture, were being targeted. \"Where badgers are identified as a possible source, a survey is [being] carried out and badgers captured and removed.\"\n\nThe department said: \"There is no evidence of any deer involvement in this outbreak, at this time. A further contributory factor in the area is the number of (cattle) herd fragments which aid the spread of the disease. \"The department acknowledges the concerns, and fully understands the stress associated with disease events on farms. It continues to work with farmers, and veterinary practitioners, in bringing this outbreak under control.\"\n\nHowever, farmers, and some public representatives, are suspicious of deers, with numbers increasing, due to forestry investment.\n\nThe chairman of Kerry IFA, Pat O'Driscoll, said the problem will not be solved just by testing and removing cattle from the peninsula. He said all contributing sources must be identified. The IFA, he said, had met with National Parks and Wildlife officials and received assurances that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\n\nKerry IFA animal health chairman, Kenneth O'Connell, said the IFA was pursuing, through the National Deer Management Forum, the establishment of a national management programme throughout the country, \"and in particular where deer are associated with TB outbreaks\". The IFA is also seeking changes to both the live-valuation scheme, and the consequential loss schemes, to offset the financial impact of TB breakdowns for farmers, he said.\n\nMeanwhile, the Irish Wild Deer Association's Damian Hannigan, a member of the national forum, said while deer, like any other animal, could contract TB, there were different strains. \"There is no evidence to show there is a link between the spread of TB to cattle and deer,\" he said. \"TB diseases on farms is devastating. But to suggest deer are, in any shape or form, responsible, is to muddy the waters,\" he said. He noted that deer numbers existed only in small pockets around Caherciveen, and while South Kerry, generally, had undergone a lot of clear-felling of forestry, the activities might have disturbed badger sets.\n\n[Byline: Anne Lucey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At this moment we have a \"He said, they said\" situation. The sooner that badgers in the area are confirmed to be infected and with a matching strain of _M. bovis_ the better. Kerry IFA has been assured by the National Parks & Wildlife \"that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\" So it should be possible to selectively (i.e. shoot or dart) suspect deer for testing for bTB infections. In a tense situation like this it is best to test both species. - Mod.MHJ\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nCounty Kerry, Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10087]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland (03): (KY) epidemiological notes 20180124.5581590\nBovine tuberculosis -
