IRELAND (04): (KERRY) PROBABLE BADGER SOURCE\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Feb 2018\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttps://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/deer-not-linked-to-outbreak-of-tb-466988.html\n\n\nThe Department of Agriculture has ruled out any link between the increasing numbers of wild deer in south Kerry and the biggest outbreak of bovine TB in living memory in the area. Dozens of farms are in lockdown and 360 cattle have been removed from slaughter, in an area between Kells and Caherdaniel, on the Iveragh peninsula.\n\nDeer and badgers are suspected. At a recent Kerry County Council meeting in Killorglin, questions about the role of deer in the outbreak were raised and emergency motions demanded a department response.\n\nThe department confirmed that \"evidence to date\" supports the view that badgers have contributed to the spread of the TB. \"Badger-capturing is now taking place to reduce the badger density in this area, which has not experienced this type of outbreak in recent times.\" Badger clans, not subject to a previous capture, were being targeted. \"Where badgers are identified as a possible source, a survey is [being] carried out and badgers captured and removed.\"\n\nThe department said: \"There is no evidence of any deer involvement in this outbreak, at this time. A further contributory factor in the area is the number of (cattle) herd fragments which aid the spread of the disease. \"The department acknowledges the concerns, and fully understands the stress associated with disease events on farms. It continues to work with farmers, and veterinary practitioners, in bringing this outbreak under control.\"\n\nHowever, farmers, and some public representatives, are suspicious of deers, with numbers increasing, due to forestry investment.\n\nThe chairman of Kerry IFA, Pat O'Driscoll, said the problem will not be solved just by testing and removing cattle from the peninsula. He said all contributing sources must be identified. The IFA, he said, had met with National Parks and Wildlife officials and received assurances that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\n\nKerry IFA animal health chairman, Kenneth O'Connell, said the IFA was pursuing, through the National Deer Management Forum, the establishment of a national management programme throughout the country, \"and in particular where deer are associated with TB outbreaks\". The IFA is also seeking changes to both the live-valuation scheme, and the consequential loss schemes, to offset the financial impact of TB breakdowns for farmers, he said.\n\nMeanwhile, the Irish Wild Deer Association's Damian Hannigan, a member of the national forum, said while deer, like any other animal, could contract TB, there were different strains. \"There is no evidence to show there is a link between the spread of TB to cattle and deer,\" he said. \"TB diseases on farms is devastating. But to suggest deer are, in any shape or form, responsible, is to muddy the waters,\" he said. He noted that deer numbers existed only in small pockets around Caherciveen, and while South Kerry, generally, had undergone a lot of clear-felling of forestry, the activities might have disturbed badger sets.\n\n[Byline: Anne Lucey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At this moment we have a \"He said, they said\" situation. The sooner that badgers in the area are confirmed to be infected and with a matching strain of _M. bovis_ the better. Kerry IFA has been assured by the National Parks & Wildlife \"that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\" So it should be possible to selectively (i.e. shoot or dart) suspect deer for testing for bTB infections. IRELAND (04): (KERRY) PROBABLE BADGER SOURCE\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Feb 2018\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttps://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/deer-not-linked-to-outbreak-of-tb-466988.html\n\n\nThe Department of Agriculture has ruled out any link between the increasing numbers of wild deer in south Kerry and the biggest outbreak of bovine TB in living memory in the area. Dozens of farms are in lockdown and 360 cattle have been removed from slaughter, in an area between Kells and Caherdaniel, on the Iveragh peninsula.\n\nDeer and badgers are suspected. At a recent Kerry County Council meeting in Killorglin, questions about the role of deer in the outbreak were raised and emergency motions demanded a department response.\n\nThe department confirmed that \"evidence to date\" supports the view that badgers have contributed to the spread of the TB. \"Badger-capturing is now taking place to reduce the badger density in this area, which has not experienced this type of outbreak in recent times.\" Badger clans, not subject to a previous capture, were being targeted. \"Where badgers are identified as a possible source, a survey is [being] carried out and badgers captured and removed.\"\n\nThe department said: \"There is no evidence of any deer involvement in this outbreak, at this time. It continues to work with farmers, and veterinary practitioners, in bringing this outbreak under control.\"\n\nHowever, farmers, and some public representatives, are suspicious of deers, with numbers increasing, due to forestry investment.\n\nThe chairman of Kerry IFA, Pat O'Driscoll, said the problem will not be solved just by testing and removing cattle from the peninsula. He said all contributing sources must be identified. The IFA, he said, had met with National Parks and Wildlife officials and received assurances that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\n\nKerry IFA animal health chairman, Kenneth O'Connell, said the IFA was pursuing, through the National Deer Management Forum, the establishment of a national management programme throughout the country, \"and in particular where deer are associated with TB outbreaks\". The IFA is also seeking changes to both the live-valuation scheme, and the consequential loss schemes, to offset the financial impact of TB breakdowns for farmers, he said.\n\nMeanwhile, the Irish Wild Deer Association's Damian Hannigan, a member of the national forum, said while deer, like any other animal, could contract TB, there were different strains. \"There is no evidence to show there is a link between the spread of TB to cattle and deer,\" he said. \"TB diseases on farms is devastating. But to suggest deer are, in any shape or form, responsible, is to muddy the waters,\" he said. He noted that deer numbers existed only in small pockets around Caherciveen, and while South Kerry, generally, had undergone a lot of clear-felling of forestry, the activities might have disturbed badger sets.\n\n[Byline: Anne Lucey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At this moment we have a \"He said, they said\" situation. The sooner that badgers in the area are confirmed to be infected and with a matching strain of _M. bovis_ the better. Kerry IFA has been assured by the National Parks & Wildlife \"that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\" So it should be possible to selectively (i.e. shoot or dart) suspect deer for testing for bTB infections. In a tense situation like this it is best to test both species. - Mod.MHJ\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nCounty Kerry, Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10087]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland (03): (KY) epidemiological notes 20180124.5581590\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland (02): comment, RFI 20180122.5576698\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland: (KY) spread, control 20180121.5574684\n2016\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Austria: (VO,TR) bovine, M. caprae 20160311.4085658\n2013\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n.................................................sb/ml/mhj/ao/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Killorglin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "tuberculosis - Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Caherdaniel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kells", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "tuberculosis - Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5642891", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5642891", "date": "2018-02-12 15:40:08", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - IRELAND (04): (KERRY) PROBABLE BADGER SOURCE\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Feb 2018\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttps://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/deer-not-linked-to-outbreak-of-tb-466988.html\n\n\nThe Department of Agriculture has ruled out any link between the increasing numbers of wild deer in south Kerry and the biggest outbreak of bovine TB in living memory in the area. Dozens of farms are in lockdown and 360 cattle have been removed from slaughter, in an area between Kells and Caherdaniel, on the Iveragh peninsula.\n\nDeer and badgers are suspected. At a recent Kerry County Council meeting in Killorglin, questions about the role of deer in the outbreak were raised and emergency motions demanded a department response.\n\nThe department confirmed that \"evidence to date\" supports the view that badgers have contributed to the spread of the TB. \"Badger-capturing is now taking place to reduce the badger density in this area, which has not experienced this type of outbreak in recent times.\" Badger clans, not subject to a previous capture, were being targeted. \"Where badgers are identified as a possible source, a survey is [being] carried out and badgers captured and removed.\"\n\nThe department said: \"There is no evidence of any deer involvement in this outbreak, at this time. A further contributory factor in the area is the number of (cattle) herd fragments which aid the spread of the disease. \"The department acknowledges the concerns, and fully understands the stress associated with disease events on farms. It continues to work with farmers, and veterinary practitioners, in bringing this outbreak under control.\"\n\nHowever, farmers, and some public representatives, are suspicious of deers, with numbers increasing, due to forestry investment.\n\nThe chairman of Kerry IFA, Pat O'Driscoll, said the problem will not be solved just by testing and removing cattle from the peninsula. He said all contributing sources must be identified. The IFA, he said, had met with National Parks and Wildlife officials and received assurances that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\n\nKerry IFA animal health chairman, Kenneth O'Connell, said the IFA was pursuing, through the National Deer Management Forum, the establishment of a national management programme throughout the country, \"and in particular where deer are associated with TB outbreaks\". The IFA is also seeking changes to both the live-valuation scheme, and the consequential loss schemes, to offset the financial impact of TB breakdowns for farmers, he said.\n\nMeanwhile, the Irish Wild Deer Association's Damian Hannigan, a member of the national forum, said while deer, like any other animal, could contract TB, there were different strains. \"There is no evidence to show there is a link between the spread of TB to cattle and deer,\" he said. \"TB diseases on farms is devastating. But to suggest deer are, in any shape or form, responsible, is to muddy the waters,\" he said. He noted that deer numbers existed only in small pockets around Caherciveen, and while South Kerry, generally, had undergone a lot of clear-felling of forestry, the activities might have disturbed badger sets.\n\n[Byline: Anne Lucey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At this moment we have a \"He said, they said\" situation. The sooner that badgers in the area are confirmed to be infected and with a matching strain of _M. bovis_ the better. Kerry IFA has been assured by the National Parks & Wildlife \"that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\" So it should be possible to selectively (i.e. shoot or dart) suspect deer for testing for bTB infections. In a tense situation like this it is best to test both species. - Mod.MHJ\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nCounty Kerry, Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10087]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland (03): (KY) epidemiological notes 20180124.5581590\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n.................................................sb/ml/mhj/ao/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Killorglin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "tuberculosis - Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5623365", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Ireland (04): (KY) probable badger source", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5623365", "date": "2018-02-12 15:40:08", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - IRELAND (04): (KERRY) PROBABLE BADGER SOURCE\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Feb 2018\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttps://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/deer-not-linked-to-outbreak-of-tb-466988.html\n\n\nThe Department of Agriculture has ruled out any link between the increasing numbers of wild deer in south Kerry and the biggest outbreak of bovine TB in living memory in the area. Dozens of farms are in lockdown and 360 cattle have been removed from slaughter, in an area between Kells and Caherdaniel, on the Iveragh peninsula.\n\nDeer and badgers are suspected. At a recent Kerry County Council meeting in Killorglin, questions about the role of deer in the outbreak were raised and emergency motions demanded a department response.\n\nThe department confirmed that \"evidence to date\" supports the view that badgers have contributed to the spread of the TB. \"Badger-capturing is now taking place to reduce the badger density in this area, which has not experienced this type of outbreak in recent times.\" Badger clans, not subject to a previous capture, were being targeted. \"Where badgers are identified as a possible source, a survey is [being] carried out and badgers captured and removed.\"\n\nThe department said: \"There is no evidence of any deer involvement in this outbreak, at this time. A further contributory factor in the area is the number of (cattle) herd fragments which aid the spread of the disease. \"The department acknowledges the concerns, and fully understands the stress associated with disease events on farms. It continues to work with farmers, and veterinary practitioners, in bringing this outbreak under control.\"\n\nHowever, farmers, and some public representatives, are suspicious of deers, with numbers increasing, due to forestry investment.\n\nThe chairman of Kerry IFA, Pat O'Driscoll, said the problem will not be solved just by testing and removing cattle from the peninsula. He said all contributing sources must be identified. The IFA, he said, had met with National Parks and Wildlife officials and received assurances that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\n\nKerry IFA animal health chairman, Kenneth O'Connell, said the IFA was pursuing, through the National Deer Management Forum, the establishment of a national management programme throughout the country, \"and in particular where deer are associated with TB outbreaks\". The IFA is also seeking changes to both the live-valuation scheme, and the consequential loss schemes, to offset the financial impact of TB breakdowns for farmers, he said.\n\nMeanwhile, the Irish Wild Deer Association's Damian Hannigan, a member of the national forum, said while deer, like any other animal, could contract TB, there were different strains. \"There is no evidence to show there is a link between the spread of TB to cattle and deer,\" he said. \"TB diseases on farms is devastating. But to suggest deer are, in any shape or form, responsible, is to muddy the waters,\" he said. He noted that deer numbers existed only in small pockets around Caherciveen, and while South Kerry, generally, had undergone a lot of clear-felling of forestry, the activities might have disturbed badger sets.\n\n[Byline: Anne Lucey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At this moment we have a \"He said, they said\" situation. The sooner that badgers in the area are confirmed to be infected and with a matching strain of _M. bovis_ the better. Kerry IFA has been assured by the National Parks & Wildlife \"that farmers would be provided with the relevant licenses to address the problems associated with deer.\" So it should be possible to selectively (i.e. shoot or dart) suspect deer for testing for bTB infections. In a tense situation like this it is best to test both species. - Mod.MHJ\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nCounty Kerry, Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10087]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland (03): (KY) epidemiological notes 20180124.5581590\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n.................................................sb/ml/mhj/ao/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Killorglin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "tuberculosis - Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5613461", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, elephant - Zimbabwe: diagnosis, prevention and control strategies", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5613461", "date": "2018-01-13 23:55:07", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - ISRAEL (02): (HADAROM) BOVINE, HUMAN, CONTROL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? Comment.\n[2] Complementary information on the event\n\n******\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? Comment.\nDate: Sat 13 Jan 2018\nFrom: Daniel Elad <daniel.elad@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nRe: Bovine tuberculosis - Israel: (HD) bovine, OIE 20180112.5555373\n\nUp to 19 cows/heifers on the affected farm were found, with the comparative tuberculin test, positive. Since the worker suspected to be source of the contagion worked only a few months on the farm, it is unlikely that he transmitted _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, being primarily a human adapted pathogen, in such a brief period to so many animals. Thus it may be assumed, pending the final identification, that the pathogen involved is _M. bovis_.\n\n--\nDaniel Elad\nHead, Division of Bacteriological and Mycological Laboratories\nThe Kimron Veterinary Institute\n50250 Bet Dagan,\nIsrael\n<daniel.elad@gmail.com>\n\n[Dr Elad's assumption sounds sensible and is welcomed. We'll have to patiently wait for the final laboratory results.\n\nIn the meantime, all possible contacts of the affected herd since the start of the TB-patient's employment, including animal movements to other farms or locations, should be traced to exclude possible spread of infection. This may become of particular importance in case the agent turns to be _M.bovis_, which, as stated, is more likely to infect cattle elsewhere.\n\nIt would also help to note if all members of the Gal'on dairy farm's personnel have undergone testing. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[2] Complementary information on the event\nDate: Sat 13 Jan 2018\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, head veterinarian's weekly report No 2018/2 [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, summ, edited]\nhttp://www.hachaklait.org.il [subscription required]\n\n\nTuberculosis in Kibbutz Gal'On: About 10 days ago, Uri Koren [\"Hachaklait\" veterinary practitioner attending this dairy farm] reported about one of the plant's employees (a student from Uganda) who was hospitalized in the \"Shmuel HaRofeh\" hospital with active tuberculosis. The said employee has been in Israel since the beginning of September 2017. The information was transferred to the Veterinary Services at the beginning of the week [week of 7-13 Jan 2018] and the entire herd (from the age of 6 months and up) was examined by the comparative tuberculin test. This led to the identification of 19 positive animals, including 17 milking cows, one pregnant heifer and one dry cow [= in nonlactating period], out of a total of 584 tested cattle.\n\nUntill the isolation of the reacting cows, all milk produced in the plant was destroyed. The herd has been put under quarantine.\n\nThe bacterium's species, human or bovine, has not been determined yet; this may take several weeks.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow disease, the positive cows do not pose an immediate risk for further infection. The positive cows will be destroyed at the beginning of the coming week [starting Sun 14 Jan 2018] and an attempt will be made to isolate the bacteria from the lymph nodes. The possible routes of infection from a sick person to animals is by aerosole during coughing or by animals' contact with the patient's sputum or other secretions.\n\nThe herd will enter a routine of tuberculin testing every 60 days and will remain in quarantine until the completion of 2 consecutive negative tests of the entire herd. Weaned calves will be tested at the age of 3 months and will be released for sale provided found negative.\n\nAlthough the dimensions of the infection are unclear, there is no doubt that Uri Koren's early understanding of the significance of the information about the employee's sickness and his initiative to start the chain of alerts have played a central role in preventing further damage to this herd and to the national dairy industry at large.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The described event is a classical case requiring a \"One Health\" approach: the detection of a zoonotic disease, in an animal or a human, deserves to become known to both parties, Public Health and Animal Health agencies alike, as early as possible to allow timely measures undertaken on both sides as deems necessary. According to additional information we received from a reliable source, the patient felt unwell during the last 2 weeks of Dec 2017, initially suspecting flu; eventually he could not continue working: his last working day was [Thu 28 Dec 2017]. He was then hospitalized, TB suspected on [Tue 2 Jan 2018], confirmed next day. This became known to the farm's veterinary practitioner the same day [Wed 3 Jan 2018] and the information was immediately notified, through the main office of his employer (\"Hachaklait\" Veterinary Services, Mutual Society for Clinical Veterinary Services and Livestock Insurance in Israel, catering for about 90 percent of the country's dairy farms) by e-mail to the State veterinary services. The flow of information between the State's Public Health and Animal Health agencies is yet to be visited.\n\nEmployees of food-producing enterprises, in Israel and elsewhere, are traditionally required by law to undergo periodical tests for infectious disease agents, in particular for tuberculosis.\n\nOn 8 Mar 2008, the Ministry of Agriculture published \"Draft business licensing regulations for dairy cattle farming and sheep barns\" for the public's comments. Article 25 (5) of the drafted regulations said, \"A person shall not milk an animal if that person has a contagious disease, a bowel disease, a skin disease or open pustular cuts.\" The approval of the said regulations and their official publication and application afield has not yet been realized.\n\nOn 26 Feb 2015, Israel's Veterinary Services announced the discontinuation of periodic tuberculin testing in cattle, in effect as of 1 Mar 2015. (Hebrew, at http://www.moag.gov.il/vet/Yechidot/VetBasade/Pirsumim/2015/Documents/mivhan__mrt.pdf). Prior to this decision, the tuberculin tests were required to be performed in each farm once in 5 years. The said announcement included, among others, the following articles 3-5:\n\n\"3. Monitoring and surveillance of TB disease is to be moved from the field to the handling by slaughterhouses. The Department of Animal Products Control will publish a monitoring procedure in the coming month.\n\n\"4. The laboratory of bacteriology at the Kimron Veterinary Institute will examine the introduction of modern bTB testing methods.\n\n\"5. The State Veterinary Services will perform risk analysis at least once every 2 years to examine the bTB epidemiological picture and ways of controlling the disease. They will update the Ministry of Health in case any changes are implemented\".\n\nBovine tuberculosis has been eradicated in Israel in 1973, not a single case detected on a dairy farm since. The last case in grazing beef cattle was recorded in 1999. The 1st risk analysis of the bTB situation should have taken place, according to the 2015 decision, the latest 2 year after 1 Mar 2015, namely 10 months ago. In case performed, its summary and conclusions will be useful.\n\nNotably, last week [week of Sun 31 Dec 2017], the Israeli Government published the following decision, included within the Government document \"2019 budget\" (page 8 in https://www.gov.il/BlobFolder/reports/sedergov080118/he/seg080118.pdf):\n\n\"To impose on the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development the establishment of an inter-ministerial team to examine the possibility of selling [!! - Mod.AS] some of the research and laboratory services of the Kimron Veterinary Institute, and accordingly to recommend the outline of the sale. The team will consult \"with advice and legislation\" regarding all aspects related to the legislative powers of the Institute. The composition of the team will be determined in coordination with the Deputy Attorney General (administrative-public law)\" .\n\nThe 2015 expectations from the Kimron Institute's Dep of bacteriology to modernize its bTB techniques (whatever this may mean) are to be weighed against the above government decision.\n\nThe Kimron Veterinary Institute, established 1957, has been instrumental in achieving Israel's satisfactory animal health status in spite of the concerning health situation prevailing in the region, including serious zoonotic diseases (eg RVF). It includes 2 OIE reference laboratories (Brucellosis and rabies).\n\nA map of (HaDarom, Israel): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Israel: (HD) bovine, OIE 20180112.5555373\n2017\n----\nMycobacterium bovis: animal-to-human transmission 20171014.538083\nBovine tuberculosis - Iraq: (WA) international impact 20170730.5214302\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (03): Jul-Dec 2007 20080702.2016\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (02) 20080515.1627\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait 20080504.1526\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\n.................................................arn/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "rabies", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-13 20:18:00", "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "2008-03-08 00:00:00", "2015-02-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kuwait", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HaDarom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "kuwait", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5604991", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Armenia: (ER), zoo, camelid, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5604991", "date": "2018-01-13 23:55:07", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - ISRAEL (02): (HADAROM) BOVINE, HUMAN, CONTROL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? Comment.\n[2] Complementary information on the event\n\n******\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? According to additional information we received from a reliable source, the patient felt unwell during the last 2 weeks of Dec 2017, initially suspecting flu; eventually he could not continue working: his last working day was [Thu 28 Dec 2017]. He was then hospitalized, TB suspected on [Tue 2 Jan 2018], confirmed next day. (Hebrew, at http://www.moag.gov.il/vet/Yechidot/VetBasade/Pirsumim/2015/Documents/mivhan__mrt.pdf). Prior to this decision, the tuberculin tests were required to be performed in each farm once in 5 years. The said announcement included, among others, the following articles 3-5:\n\n\"3. Monitoring and surveillance of TB disease is to be moved from the field to the handling by slaughterhouses. The Department of Animal Products Control will publish a monitoring procedure in the coming month.\n\n\"4. The laboratory of bacteriology at the Kimron Veterinary Institute will examine the introduction of modern bTB testing methods.\n\n\"5. The State Veterinary Services will perform risk analysis at least once every 2 years to examine the bTB epidemiological picture and ways of controlling the disease. They will update the Ministry of Health in case any changes are implemented\".\n\nBovine tuberculosis has been eradicated in Israel in 1973, not a single case detected on a dairy farm since. The last case in grazing beef cattle was recorded in 1999. The 1st risk analysis of the bTB situation should have taken place, according to the 2015 decision, the latest 2 year after 1 Mar 2015, namely 10 months ago. In case performed, its summary and conclusions will be useful.\n\nNotably, last week [week of Sun 31 Dec 2017], the Israeli Government published the following decision, included within the Government document \"2019 budget\" (page 8 in https://www.gov.il/BlobFolder/reports/sedergov080118/he/seg080118.pdf):\n\n\"To impose on the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development the establishment of an inter-ministerial team to examine the possibility of selling [!! - Mod.AS] some of the research and laboratory services of the Kimron Veterinary Institute, and accordingly to recommend the outline of the sale. The team will consult \"with advice and legislation\" regarding all aspects related to the legislative powers of the Institute. The composition of the team will be determined in coordination with the Deputy Attorney General (administrative-public law)\" .\n\nThe 2015 expectations from the Kimron Institute's Dep of bacteriology to modernize its bTB techniques (whatever this may mean) are to be weighed against the above government decision.\n\nThe Kimron Veterinary Institute, established 1957, has been instrumental in achieving Israel's satisfactory animal health status in spite of the concerning health situation prevailing in the region, including serious zoonotic diseases (eg RVF). It includes 2 OIE reference laboratories (Brucellosis and rabies).\n\nA map of (HaDarom, Israel): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Israel: (HD) bovine, OIE 20180112.5555373\n2017\n----\nMycobacterium bovis: animal-to-human transmission 20171014.538083\nBovine tuberculosis - Iraq: (WA) international impact 20170730.5214302\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (03): Jul-Dec 2007 20080702.2016\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (02) 20080515.1627\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait 20080504.1526\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\n.................................................arn/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "rabies", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-13 20:18:00", "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "2008-03-08 00:00:00", "2015-02-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kuwait", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HaDarom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "kuwait", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5604259", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, MDR - Nepal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5604259", "date": "2018-01-13 23:55:07", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - ISRAEL (02): (HADAROM) BOVINE, HUMAN, CONTROL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? Comment.\n[2] Complementary information on the event\n\n******\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? Comment.\nDate: Sat 13 Jan 2018\nFrom: Daniel Elad <daniel.elad@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nRe: Bovine tuberculosis - Israel: (HD) bovine, OIE 20180112.5555373\n\nUp to 19 cows/heifers on the affected farm were found, with the comparative tuberculin test, positive. Since the worker suspected to be source of the contagion worked only a few months on the farm, it is unlikely that he transmitted _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, being primarily a human adapted pathogen, in such a brief period to so many animals. Thus it may be assumed, pending the final identification, that the pathogen involved is _M. bovis_.\n\n--\nDaniel Elad\nHead, Division of Bacteriological and Mycological Laboratories\nThe Kimron Veterinary Institute\n50250 Bet Dagan,\nIsrael\n<daniel.elad@gmail.com>\n\n[Dr Elad's assumption sounds sensible and is welcomed. We'll have to patiently wait for the final laboratory results.\n\nIn the meantime, all possible contacts of the affected herd since the start of the TB-patient's employment, including animal movements to other farms or locations, should be traced to exclude possible spread of infection. This may become of particular importance in case the agent turns to be _M.bovis_, which, as stated, is more likely to infect cattle elsewhere.\n\nIt would also help to note if all members of the Gal'on dairy farm's personnel have undergone testing. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[2] Complementary information on the event\nDate: Sat 13 Jan 2018\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, head veterinarian's weekly report No 2018/2 [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, summ, edited]\nhttp://www.hachaklait.org.il [subscription required]\n\n\nTuberculosis in Kibbutz Gal'On: About 10 days ago, Uri Koren [\"Hachaklait\" veterinary practitioner attending this dairy farm] reported about one of the plant's employees (a student from Uganda) who was hospitalized in the \"Shmuel HaRofeh\" hospital with active tuberculosis. The said employee has been in Israel since the beginning of September 2017. The information was transferred to the Veterinary Services at the beginning of the week [week of 7-13 Jan 2018] and the entire herd (from the age of 6 months and up) was examined by the comparative tuberculin test. This led to the identification of 19 positive animals, including 17 milking cows, one pregnant heifer and one dry cow [= in nonlactating period], out of a total of 584 tested cattle.\n\nUntill the isolation of the reacting cows, all milk produced in the plant was destroyed. The herd has been put under quarantine.\n\nThe bacterium's species, human or bovine, has not been determined yet; this may take several weeks.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow disease, the positive cows do not pose an immediate risk for further infection. The positive cows will be destroyed at the beginning of the coming week [starting Sun 14 Jan 2018] and an attempt will be made to isolate the bacteria from the lymph nodes. The possible routes of infection from a sick person to animals is by aerosole during coughing or by animals' contact with the patient's sputum or other secretions.\n\nThe herd will enter a routine of tuberculin testing every 60 days and will remain in quarantine until the completion of 2 consecutive negative tests of the entire herd. Weaned calves will be tested at the age of 3 months and will be released for sale provided found negative.\n\nAlthough the dimensions of the infection are unclear, there is no doubt that Uri Koren's early understanding of the significance of the information about the employee's sickness and his initiative to start the chain of alerts have played a central role in preventing further damage to this herd and to the national dairy industry at large.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The described event is a classical case requiring a \"One Health\" approach: the detection of a zoonotic disease, in an animal or a human, deserves to become known to both parties, Public Health and Animal Health agencies alike, as early as possible to allow timely measures undertaken on both sides as deems necessary. According to additional information we received from a reliable source, the patient felt unwell during the last 2 weeks of Dec 2017, initially suspecting flu; eventually he could not continue working: his last working day was [Thu 28 Dec 2017]. He was then hospitalized, TB suspected on [Tue 2 Jan 2018], confirmed next day. This became known to the farm's veterinary practitioner the same day [Wed 3 Jan 2018] and the information was immediately notified, through the main office of his employer (\"Hachaklait\" Veterinary Services, Mutual Society for Clinical Veterinary Services and Livestock Insurance in Israel, catering for about 90 percent of the country's dairy farms) by e-mail to the State veterinary services. The flow of information between the State's Public Health and Animal Health agencies is yet to be visited.\n\nEmployees of food-producing enterprises, in Israel and elsewhere, are traditionally required by law to undergo periodical tests for infectious disease agents, in particular for tuberculosis.\n\nOn 8 Mar 2008, the Ministry of Agriculture published \"Draft business licensing regulations for dairy cattle farming and sheep barns\" for the public's comments. Article 25 (5) of the drafted regulations said, \"A person shall not milk an animal if that person has a contagious disease, a bowel disease, a skin disease or open pustular cuts.\" The approval of the said regulations and their official publication and application afield has not yet been realized.\n\nOn 26 Feb 2015, Israel's Veterinary Services announced the discontinuation of periodic tuberculin testing in cattle, in effect as of 1 Mar 2015. (Hebrew, at http://www.moag.gov.il/vet/Yechidot/VetBasade/Pirsumim/2015/Documents/mivhan__mrt.pdf). Prior to this decision, the tuberculin tests were required to be performed in each farm once in 5 years. The said announcement included, among others, the following articles 3-5:\n\n\"3. Monitoring and surveillance of TB disease is to be moved from the field to the handling by slaughterhouses. The Department of Animal Products Control will publish a monitoring procedure in the coming month.\n\n\"4. The laboratory of bacteriology at the Kimron Veterinary Institute will examine the introduction of modern bTB testing methods.\n\n\"5. The State Veterinary Services will perform risk analysis at least once every 2 years to examine the bTB epidemiological picture and ways of controlling the disease. They will update the Ministry of Health in case any changes are implemented\".\n\nBovine tuberculosis has been eradicated in Israel in 1973, not a single case detected on a dairy farm since. The last case in grazing beef cattle was recorded in 1999. The 1st risk analysis of the bTB situation should have taken place, according to the 2015 decision, the latest 2 year after 1 Mar 2015, namely 10 months ago. In case performed, its summary and conclusions will be useful.\n\nNotably, last week [week of Sun 31 Dec 2017], the Israeli Government published the following decision, included within the Government document \"2019 budget\" (page 8 in https://www.gov.il/BlobFolder/reports/sedergov080118/he/seg080118.pdf):\n\n\"To impose on the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development the establishment of an inter-ministerial team to examine the possibility of selling [!! - Mod.AS] some of the research and laboratory services of the Kimron Veterinary Institute, and accordingly to recommend the outline of the sale. The team will consult \"with advice and legislation\" regarding all aspects related to the legislative powers of the Institute. The composition of the team will be determined in coordination with the Deputy Attorney General (administrative-public law)\" .\n\nThe 2015 expectations from the Kimron Institute's Dep of bacteriology to modernize its bTB techniques (whatever this may mean) are to be weighed against the above government decision.\n\nThe Kimron Veterinary Institute, established 1957, has been instrumental in achieving Israel's satisfactory animal health status in spite of the concerning health situation prevailing in the region, including serious zoonotic diseases (eg RVF). It includes 2 OIE reference laboratories (Brucellosis and rabies).\n\nA map of (HaDarom, Israel): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Israel: (HD) bovine, OIE 20180112.5555373\n2017\n----\nMycobacterium bovis: animal-to-human transmission 20171014.538083\nBovine tuberculosis - Iraq: (WA) international impact 20170730.5214302\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (03): Jul-Dec 2007 20080702.2016\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (02) 20080515.1627\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait 20080504.1526\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\n.................................................arn/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "rabies", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-13 20:18:00", "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "2008-03-08 00:00:00", "2015-02-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kuwait", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HaDarom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "kuwait", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5581590", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Ireland (03): (KY) epidemiological notes", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5581590", "date": "2018-01-13 23:55:07", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - ISRAEL (02): (HADAROM) BOVINE, HUMAN, CONTROL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? They will update the Ministry of Health in case any changes are implemented\".\n\nBovine tuberculosis has been eradicated in Israel in 1973, not a single case detected on a dairy farm since. The last case in grazing beef cattle was recorded in 1999. The 1st risk analysis of the bTB situation should have taken place, according to the 2015 decision, the latest 2 year after 1 Mar 2015, namely 10 months ago. In case performed, its summary and conclusions will be useful.\n\nNotably, last week [week of Sun 31 Dec 2017], the Israeli Government published the following decision, included within the Government document \"2019 budget\" (page 8 in https://www.gov.il/BlobFolder/reports/sedergov080118/he/seg080118.pdf):\n\n\"To impose on the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development the establishment of an inter-ministerial team to examine the possibility of selling [!! - Mod.AS] some of the research and laboratory services of the Kimron Veterinary Institute, and accordingly to recommend the outline of the sale. The team will consult \"with advice and legislation\" regarding all aspects related to the legislative powers of the Institute. The composition of the team will be determined in coordination with the Deputy Attorney General (administrative-public law)\" .\n\nThe 2015 expectations from the Kimron Institute's Dep of bacteriology to modernize its bTB techniques (whatever this may mean) are to be weighed against the above government decision.\n\nThe Kimron Veterinary Institute, established 1957, has been instrumental in achieving Israel's satisfactory animal health status in spite of the concerning health situation prevailing in the region, including serious zoonotic diseases (eg RVF). It includes 2 OIE reference laboratories (Brucellosis and rabies).\n\nA map of (HaDarom, Israel): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Israel: (HD) bovine, OIE 20180112.5555373\n2017\n----\nMycobacterium bovis: animal-to-human transmission 20171014.538083\nBovine tuberculosis - Iraq: (WA) international impact 20170730.5214302\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (03): Jul-Dec 2007 20080702.2016\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (02) 20080515.1627\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait 20080504.1526\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\n.................................................arn/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "rabies", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-13 20:18:00", "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "2008-03-08 00:00:00", "2015-02-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kuwait", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HaDarom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "kuwait", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5574684", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Ireland: (KY) spread, control", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5574684", "date": "2018-01-13 23:55:07", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - ISRAEL (02): (HADAROM) BOVINE, HUMAN, CONTROL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? Comment.\n[2] Complementary information on the event\n\n******\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? Comment.\nDate: Sat 13 Jan 2018\nFrom: Daniel Elad <daniel.elad@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nRe: Bovine tuberculosis - Israel: (HD) bovine, OIE 20180112.5555373\n\nUp to 19 cows/heifers on the affected farm were found, with the comparative tuberculin test, positive. Since the worker suspected to be source of the contagion worked only a few months on the farm, it is unlikely that he transmitted _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, being primarily a human adapted pathogen, in such a brief period to so many animals. Thus it may be assumed, pending the final identification, that the pathogen involved is _M. bovis_.\n\n--\nDaniel Elad\nHead, Division of Bacteriological and Mycological Laboratories\nThe Kimron Veterinary Institute\n50250 Bet Dagan,\nIsrael\n<daniel.elad@gmail.com>\n\n[Dr Elad's assumption sounds sensible and is welcomed. We'll have to patiently wait for the final laboratory results.\n\nIn the meantime, all possible contacts of the affected herd since the start of the TB-patient's employment, including animal movements to other farms or locations, should be traced to exclude possible spread of infection. This may become of particular importance in case the agent turns to be _M.bovis_, which, as stated, is more likely to infect cattle elsewhere.\n\nIt would also help to note if all members of the Gal'on dairy farm's personnel have undergone testing. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[2] Complementary information on the event\nDate: Sat 13 Jan 2018\nSource: Hachaklait Clinical Veterinary Services, head veterinarian's weekly report No 2018/2 [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, summ, edited]\nhttp://www.hachaklait.org.il [subscription required]\n\n\nTuberculosis in Kibbutz Gal'On: About 10 days ago, Uri Koren [\"Hachaklait\" veterinary practitioner attending this dairy farm] reported about one of the plant's employees (a student from Uganda) who was hospitalized in the \"Shmuel HaRofeh\" hospital with active tuberculosis. The said employee has been in Israel since the beginning of September 2017. The information was transferred to the Veterinary Services at the beginning of the week [week of 7-13 Jan 2018] and the entire herd (from the age of 6 months and up) was examined by the comparative tuberculin test. This led to the identification of 19 positive animals, including 17 milking cows, one pregnant heifer and one dry cow [= in nonlactating period], out of a total of 584 tested cattle.\n\nUntill the isolation of the reacting cows, all milk produced in the plant was destroyed. The herd has been put under quarantine.\n\nThe bacterium's species, human or bovine, has not been determined yet; this may take several weeks.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow disease, the positive cows do not pose an immediate risk for further infection. The positive cows will be destroyed at the beginning of the coming week [starting Sun 14 Jan 2018] and an attempt will be made to isolate the bacteria from the lymph nodes. The possible routes of infection from a sick person to animals is by aerosole during coughing or by animals' contact with the patient's sputum or other secretions.\n\nThe herd will enter a routine of tuberculin testing every 60 days and will remain in quarantine until the completion of 2 consecutive negative tests of the entire herd. Weaned calves will be tested at the age of 3 months and will be released for sale provided found negative.\n\nAlthough the dimensions of the infection are unclear, there is no doubt that Uri Koren's early understanding of the significance of the information about the employee's sickness and his initiative to start the chain of alerts have played a central role in preventing further damage to this herd and to the national dairy industry at large.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The described event is a classical case requiring a \"One Health\" approach: the detection of a zoonotic disease, in an animal or a human, deserves to become known to both parties, Public Health and Animal Health agencies alike, as early as possible to allow timely measures undertaken on both sides as deems necessary. According to additional information we received from a reliable source, the patient felt unwell during the last 2 weeks of Dec 2017, initially suspecting flu; eventually he could not continue working: his last working day was [Thu 28 Dec 2017]. He was then hospitalized, TB suspected on [Tue 2 Jan 2018], confirmed next day. This became known to the farm's veterinary practitioner the same day [Wed 3 Jan 2018] and the information was immediately notified, through the main office of his employer (\"Hachaklait\" Veterinary Services, Mutual Society for Clinical Veterinary Services and Livestock Insurance in Israel, catering for about 90 percent of the country's dairy farms) by e-mail to the State veterinary services. The flow of information between the State's Public Health and Animal Health agencies is yet to be visited.\n\nEmployees of food-producing enterprises, in Israel and elsewhere, are traditionally required by law to undergo periodical tests for infectious disease agents, in particular for tuberculosis.\n\nOn 8 Mar 2008, the Ministry of Agriculture published \"Draft business licensing regulations for dairy cattle farming and sheep barns\" for the public's comments. Article 25 (5) of the drafted regulations said, \"A person shall not milk an animal if that person has a contagious disease, a bowel disease, a skin disease or open pustular cuts.\" The approval of the said regulations and their official publication and application afield has not yet been realized.\n\nOn 26 Feb 2015, Israel's Veterinary Services announced the discontinuation of periodic tuberculin testing in cattle, in effect as of 1 Mar 2015. (Hebrew, at http://www.moag.gov.il/vet/Yechidot/VetBasade/Pirsumim/2015/Documents/mivhan__mrt.pdf). Prior to this decision, the tuberculin tests were required to be performed in each farm once in 5 years. The said announcement included, among others, the following articles 3-5:\n\n\"3. Monitoring and surveillance of TB disease is to be moved from the field to the handling by slaughterhouses. The Department of Animal Products Control will publish a monitoring procedure in the coming month.\n\n\"4. The laboratory of bacteriology at the Kimron Veterinary Institute will examine the introduction of modern bTB testing methods.\n\n\"5. The State Veterinary Services will perform risk analysis at least once every 2 years to examine the bTB epidemiological picture and ways of controlling the disease. They will update the Ministry of Health in case any changes are implemented\".\n\nBovine tuberculosis has been eradicated in Israel in 1973, not a single case detected on a dairy farm since. The last case in grazing beef cattle was recorded in 1999. The 1st risk analysis of the bTB situation should have taken place, according to the 2015 decision, the latest 2 year after 1 Mar 2015, namely 10 months ago. In case performed, its summary and conclusions will be useful.\n\nNotably, last week [week of Sun 31 Dec 2017], the Israeli Government published the following decision, included within the Government document \"2019 budget\" (page 8 in https://www.gov.il/BlobFolder/reports/sedergov080118/he/seg080118.pdf):\n\n\"To impose on the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development the establishment of an inter-ministerial team to examine the possibility of selling [!! - Mod.AS] some of the research and laboratory services of the Kimron Veterinary Institute, and accordingly to recommend the outline of the sale. The team will consult \"with advice and legislation\" regarding all aspects related to the legislative powers of the Institute. The composition of the team will be determined in coordination with the Deputy Attorney General (administrative-public law)\" .\n\nThe 2015 expectations from the Kimron Institute's Dep of bacteriology to modernize its bTB techniques (whatever this may mean) are to be weighed against the above government decision.\n\nThe Kimron Veterinary Institute, established 1957, has been instrumental in achieving Israel's satisfactory animal health status in spite of the concerning health situation prevailing in the region, including serious zoonotic diseases (eg RVF). It includes 2 OIE reference laboratories (Brucellosis and rabies).\n\nA map of (HaDarom, Israel): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Israel: (HD) bovine, OIE 20180112.5555373\n2017\n----\nMycobacterium bovis: animal-to-human transmission 20171014.538083\nBovine tuberculosis - Iraq: (WA) international impact 20170730.5214302\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (03): Jul-Dec 2007 20080702.2016\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (02) 20080515.1627\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait 20080504.1526\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\n.................................................arn/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "rabies", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-13 20:18:00", "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "2008-03-08 00:00:00", "2015-02-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kuwait", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HaDarom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "kuwait", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5558198", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Israel (02): (HD) bovine, human, control", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5558198", "date": "2018-01-13 23:55:07", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - ISRAEL (02): (HADAROM) BOVINE, HUMAN, CONTROL\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] _M. tuberculosis_ or _M. bovis_? The last case in grazing beef cattle was recorded in 1999. The 1st risk analysis of the bTB situation should have taken place, according to the 2015 decision, the latest 2 year after 1 Mar 2015, namely 10 months ago. In case performed, its summary and conclusions will be useful.\n\nNotably, last week [week of Sun 31 Dec 2017], the Israeli Government published the following decision, included within the Government document \"2019 budget\" (page 8 in https://www.gov.il/BlobFolder/reports/sedergov080118/he/seg080118.pdf):\n\n\"To impose on the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development the establishment of an inter-ministerial team to examine the possibility of selling [!! - Mod.AS] some of the research and laboratory services of the Kimron Veterinary Institute, and accordingly to recommend the outline of the sale. The team will consult \"with advice and legislation\" regarding all aspects related to the legislative powers of the Institute. The composition of the team will be determined in coordination with the Deputy Attorney General (administrative-public law)\" .\n\nThe 2015 expectations from the Kimron Institute's Dep of bacteriology to modernize its bTB techniques (whatever this may mean) are to be weighed against the above government decision.\n\nThe Kimron Veterinary Institute, established 1957, has been instrumental in achieving Israel's satisfactory animal health status in spite of the concerning health situation prevailing in the region, including serious zoonotic diseases (eg RVF). It includes 2 OIE reference laboratories (Brucellosis and rabies).\n\nA map of (HaDarom, Israel): http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Israel: (HD) bovine, OIE 20180112.5555373\n2017\n----\nMycobacterium bovis: animal-to-human transmission 20171014.538083\nBovine tuberculosis - Iraq: (WA) international impact 20170730.5214302\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (03): Jul-Dec 2007 20080702.2016\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (02) 20080515.1627\nTuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait 20080504.1526\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\n.................................................arn/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "rabies", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-13 20:18:00", "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "2017-12-16 00:00:00", "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "2008-03-08 00:00:00", "2015-02-26 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1973-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2019-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1957-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kuwait", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HaDarom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "kuwait", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5540747", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA: (NE) investigation proceeds", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5540747", "date": "2017-11-10 16:49:32", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, ELEPHANT - USA (02): (MISSOURI)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Nov 21 2017\nSource: St. Louis Business Journal [edited]\nhttps://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2017/11/09/saint-louis-zoo-elephant-tests-positive-for.html\n\n\nA 46-year-old Asian elephant at the Saint Louis Zoo, has tested positive for tuberculosis, according to Zoo officials.\n\nVeterinarians and the elephant care team at the Zoo are preparing to start the elephant on an appropriate treatment regimen, they said.\n\nThe Saint Louis Zoo said it has informed the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the Missouri Department of Agriculture and other local agencies about the elephant's test results. Zoo officials said that she does not pose an exposure risk to Zoo visitors.\n\n\"Because the Saint Louis Zoo is dedicated to caring for animals, our established protocols have allowed us to detect this early and take necessary steps for this elephant,\" Dr. Luis Padilla, director of animal health at the Zoo, said in a statement. \"Elephants with tuberculosis can be treated.\"\n\nThe Zoo routinely and proactively tests all of its elephants for tuberculosis as part of its comprehensive health monitoring program, officials said. The elephant was diagnosed through a combination of blood tests and a trunk culture, which is a part of the Zoo's regular veterinary care for elephants, the statement said.\n\nIn 2011 and 2012, the Zoo diagnosed and successfully treated another elephant for tuberculosis.\n\nThe elephant is not showing any symptoms at this time, according to officials. She will begin treatment with antibiotics and will remain with her family for social support.\n\nThroughout her treatment, all of the other elephants in her family will be monitored regularly.\n\nThe elephant 1st came to the Saint Louis Zoo in July 2001, at age 29.\n\n[Byline: Veneta Rizvic]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis (TB) caused by _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ or _Mycobacterium bovis_ has recently re-emerged as an important infectious disease in zoo animals, particularly captive elephants. While TB has been recognized as a disease of elephants for over 20 centuries, increasing numbers of elephant TB cases have been reported in the past 2 decades. It has been reported that about 3 percent of captive elephants in the United States are infected with _M. tuberculosis_.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://cvi.asm.org/content/13/7/722.full. - Mod.PM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephant - USA: (OR) RFI 20170424.4986958\n2016\n----\nTuberculosis, elephant - USA: (OR) CDC update, 2012-2014 20160110.3924828\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis, elephant - USA (02): (MD) 20110413.1165\nTuberculosis, humans, elephant - USA: (TN) 2009 20110219.0546\n.................................................sb/pmb/ec/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5443276", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Malta: (NA) bovine, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5443276", "date": "2017-11-10 16:49:32", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, ELEPHANT - USA (02): (MISSOURI)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Nov 21 2017\nSource: St. Louis Business Journal [edited]\nhttps://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2017/11/09/saint-louis-zoo-elephant-tests-positive-for.html\n\n\nA 46-year-old Asian elephant at the Saint Louis Zoo, has tested positive for tuberculosis, according to Zoo officials.\n\nVeterinarians and the elephant care team at the Zoo are preparing to start the elephant on an appropriate treatment regimen, they said.\n\nThe Saint Louis Zoo said it has informed the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the Missouri Department of Agriculture and other local agencies about the elephant's test results. Zoo officials said that she does not pose an exposure risk to Zoo visitors.\n\n\"Because the Saint Louis Zoo is dedicated to caring for animals, our established protocols have allowed us to detect this early and take necessary steps for this elephant,\" Dr. Luis Padilla, director of animal health at the Zoo, said in a statement. \"Elephants with tuberculosis can be treated.\"\n\nThe Zoo routinely and proactively tests all of its elephants for tuberculosis as part of its comprehensive health monitoring program, officials said. The elephant was diagnosed through a combination of blood tests and a trunk culture, which is a part of the Zoo's regular veterinary care for elephants, the statement said.\n\nIn 2011 and 2012, the Zoo diagnosed and successfully treated another elephant for tuberculosis.\n\nThe elephant is not showing any symptoms at this time, according to officials. She will begin treatment with antibiotics and will remain with her family for social support.\n\nThroughout her treatment, all of the other elephants in her family will be monitored regularly.\n\nThe elephant 1st came to the Saint Louis Zoo in July 2001, at age 29.\n\n[Byline: Veneta Rizvic]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis (TB) caused by _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ or _Mycobacterium bovis_ has recently re-emerged as an important infectious disease in zoo animals, particularly captive elephants. While TB has been recognized as a disease of elephants for over 20 centuries, increasing numbers of elephant TB cases have been reported in the past 2 decades. It has been reported that about 3 percent of captive elephants in the United States are infected with _M. tuberculosis_.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://cvi.asm.org/content/13/7/722.full. - Mod.PM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephant - USA: (OR) RFI 20170424.4986958\n2016\n----\nTuberculosis, elephant - USA: (OR) CDC update, 2012-2014 20160110.3924828\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis, elephant - USA (02): (MD) 20110413.1165\nTuberculosis, humans, elephant - USA: (TN) 2009 20110219.0546\n.................................................sb/pmb/ec/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5436645", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, elephant - USA (02): (MO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5436645", "date": "2017-11-10 16:49:32", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, ELEPHANT - USA (02): (MISSOURI)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Nov 21 2017\nSource: St. Louis Business Journal [edited]\nhttps://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2017/11/09/saint-louis-zoo-elephant-tests-positive-for.html\n\n\nA 46-year-old Asian elephant at the Saint Louis Zoo, has tested positive for tuberculosis, according to Zoo officials.\n\nVeterinarians and the elephant care team at the Zoo are preparing to start the elephant on an appropriate treatment regimen, they said.\n\nThe Saint Louis Zoo said it has informed the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the Missouri Department of Agriculture and other local agencies about the elephant's test results. Zoo officials said that she does not pose an exposure risk to Zoo visitors.\n\n\"Because the Saint Louis Zoo is dedicated to caring for animals, our established protocols have allowed us to detect this early and take necessary steps for this elephant,\" Dr. Luis Padilla, director of animal health at the Zoo, said in a statement. \"Elephants with tuberculosis can be treated.\"\n\nThe Zoo routinely and proactively tests all of its elephants for tuberculosis as part of its comprehensive health monitoring program, officials said. The elephant was diagnosed through a combination of blood tests and a trunk culture, which is a part of the Zoo's regular veterinary care for elephants, the statement said.\n\nIn 2011 and 2012, the Zoo diagnosed and successfully treated another elephant for tuberculosis.\n\nThe elephant is not showing any symptoms at this time, according to officials. She will begin treatment with antibiotics and will remain with her family for social support.\n\nThroughout her treatment, all of the other elephants in her family will be monitored regularly.\n\nThe elephant 1st came to the Saint Louis Zoo in July 2001, at age 29.\n\n[Byline: Veneta Rizvic]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tuberculosis (TB) caused by _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ or _Mycobacterium bovis_ has recently re-emerged as an important infectious disease in zoo animals, particularly captive elephants. While TB has been recognized as a disease of elephants for over 20 centuries, increasing numbers of elephant TB cases have been reported in the past 2 decades. It has been reported that about 3 percent of captive elephants in the United States are infected with _M. tuberculosis_.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://cvi.asm.org/content/13/7/722.full. - Mod.PM\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/227.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephant - USA: (OR) RFI 20170424.4986958\n2016\n----\nTuberculosis, elephant - USA: (OR) CDC update, 2012-2014 20160110.3924828\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis, elephant - Uganda: (MV) boarding school", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5434514", "date": "2017-04-28 11:04:57", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (08): (MICHIGAN)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Apr 2017 2:34 PM EDT\nSource: WZZM [edited]\nhttp://www.wzzm13.com/news/local/michigan/surveillance-area-set-after-lake-county-cow-tests-positive-for-bovine-tb/434309054\n\n\nA Lake County [Michigan]farm and the surrounding area is under specific surveillance after one of its cows tested positive for bovine tuberculosis.\n\nThe farm, which has not been publicly named, was identified amid the discovery of an infected herd in Indiana, according to a Michigan Department of Agriculture news release.\n\nThe identified 3-year-old cow was imported to Michigan in December 2016 from the Indiana herd.\n\n\"Every time a bovine tuberculosis herd is identified, the US Department of Agriculture works to track all animal movements in and out of the infected herd, which can include animals that moved across state boundaries,\" said Rick Smith, DVM, assistant state veterinarian, in the release.\n\nThe surveillance is part of the department's response to the positive bovine TB test, the release states. Other farms within a 3-mile [4.8 km] radius have 6 months to complete bovine TB testing and will be notified by letter.\n\nA meeting to discuss this finding is slated for 7 pm [Mon 8 May 2017], at Reed City High School.\n\nIn March [2017], a Newaygo-area [Michigan] steer tested positive for bovine TB.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Krietz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Michigan can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43881. Lake County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/michigan-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease. Trace outs from other infections always take time and may be revealing of disease not previously known. Likely the officials will be busy doing more traces, those animals having moved into the herd, as well as those having moved out of the herd. It may reveal more disease. This one is tough to root out. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MI,SD) 20170421.4984706\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06): (SD): new strain from Mexico 20170402.4942680\nBovine tuberculosis - Other farms within a 3-mile [4.8 km] radius have 6 months to complete bovine TB testing and will be notified by letter.\n\nA meeting to discuss this finding is slated for 7 pm [Mon 8 May 2017], at Reed City High School.\n\nIn March [2017], a Newaygo-area [Michigan] steer tested positive for bovine TB.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Krietz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Michigan can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43881. Iraq: (WA) international impact", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5214302", "date": "2017-04-28 11:04:57", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (08): (MICHIGAN)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Apr 2017 2:34 PM EDT\nSource: WZZM [edited]\nhttp://www.wzzm13.com/news/local/michigan/surveillance-area-set-after-lake-county-cow-tests-positive-for-bovine-tb/434309054\n\n\nA Lake County [Michigan]farm and the surrounding area is under specific surveillance after one of its cows tested positive for bovine tuberculosis.\n\nThe farm, which has not been publicly named, was identified amid the discovery of an infected herd in Indiana, according to a Michigan Department of Agriculture news release.\n\nThe identified 3-year-old cow was imported to Michigan in December 2016 from the Indiana herd.\n\n\"Every time a bovine tuberculosis herd is identified, the US Department of Agriculture works to track all animal movements in and out of the infected herd, which can include animals that moved across state boundaries,\" said Rick Smith, DVM, assistant state veterinarian, in the release.\n\nThe surveillance is part of the department's response to the positive bovine TB test, the release states. Other farms within a 3-mile [4.8 km] radius have 6 months to complete bovine TB testing and will be notified by letter.\n\nA meeting to discuss this finding is slated for 7 pm [Mon 8 May 2017], at Reed City High School.\n\nIn March [2017], a Newaygo-area [Michigan] steer tested positive for bovine TB.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Krietz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Michigan can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43881. Lake County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/michigan-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease. Trace outs from other infections always take time and may be revealing of disease not previously known. Likely the officials will be busy doing more traces, those animals having moved into the herd, as well as those having moved out of the herd. It may reveal more disease. This one is tough to root out. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MI,SD) 20170421.4984706\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06): (SD): new strain from Mexico 20170402.4942680\nBovine tuberculosis -
