UK (02): (England) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5062625", "date": "2017-04-28 11:04:57", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (08): (MICHIGAN)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Apr 2017 2:34 PM EDT\nSource: WZZM [edited]\nhttp://www.wzzm13.com/news/local/michigan/surveillance-area-set-after-lake-county-cow-tests-positive-for-bovine-tb/434309054\n\n\nA Lake County [Michigan]farm and the surrounding area is under specific surveillance after one of its cows tested positive for bovine tuberculosis.\n\nThe farm, which has not been publicly named, was identified amid the discovery of an infected herd in Indiana, according to a Michigan Department of Agriculture news release.\n\nThe identified 3-year-old cow was imported to Michigan in December 2016 from the Indiana herd.\n\n\"Every time a bovine tuberculosis herd is identified, the US Department of Agriculture works to track all animal movements in and out of the infected herd, which can include animals that moved across state boundaries,\" said Rick Smith, DVM, assistant state veterinarian, in the release.\n\nThe surveillance is part of the department's response to the positive bovine TB test, the release states. Other farms within a 3-mile [4.8 km] radius have 6 months to complete bovine TB testing and will be notified by letter.\n\nA meeting to discuss this finding is slated for 7 pm [Mon 8 May 2017], at Reed City High School.\n\nIn March [2017], a Newaygo-area [Michigan] steer tested positive for bovine TB.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Krietz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Michigan can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43881. Lake County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/michigan-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease. Trace outs from other infections always take time and may be revealing of disease not previously known. Likely the officials will be busy doing more traces, those animals having moved into the herd, as well as those having moved out of the herd. It may reveal more disease. This one is tough to root out. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MI,SD) 20170421.4984706\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06): (SD): new strain from Mexico 20170402.4942680\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (OR) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4986958", "date": "2017-03-05 14:29:11", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (02): (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/cattle-disease-found-in-south-dakota/article_296015f0-0203-5ab7-9fbf-f11958cb32b6.html\n\n\nA rare case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed in a South Dakota beef herd, according to State Veterinarian Dustin Oedekoven.\n\nHe said Thursday [2 Mar 2017] that the suspect animals were identified in February 2017 by meat inspectors during routine slaughter inspection of otherwise healthy-appearing animals. The cattle were traced to a herd in Harding County, northwest of Rapid City. Herd testing and laboratory confirmation has revealed additional infected animals.\n\n\"We are working closely with the affected herd owner and USDA officials and will be working with area veterinarians and other herd owners to evaluate the extent of the disease,\" Oedekoven said in a release.\n\nOedekoven said adjacent herds will be tested and that bovine TB is not a food safety threat, thanks to milk pasteurization and meat inspection programs.\n\nBovine TB is a respiratory disease. Infected animals may be capable of transmitting an infection to other animals even if they appear healthy. The United States has nearly eliminated bovine TB due to a cooperative eradication campaign.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\"\n\nThere is also a nationwide surveillance program in slaughter plants. If lesions consistent with TB appear on a carcass, a sample is sent to APHIS [Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service] National Veterinary Services Laboratories [NVSL] for confirmation. The state officials will likely be tracing the movements of animals into and out of this herd in an effort to find the originating herd or herds.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from the APHIS Bovine Tuberculosis Disease Information webpage https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/animal-disease-information/cattle-disease-information/sa_tuberculosis/ and http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) 20170123.4786644\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) corr 20170102.4737527\n2016\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) 20160108.3919034\n2015\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine 20150725.3534951\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) dairy cows 20150426.3323167\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MI,SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4984706", "date": "2017-03-05 14:29:11", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (02): (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/cattle-disease-found-in-south-dakota/article_296015f0-0203-5ab7-9fbf-f11958cb32b6.html\n\n\nA rare case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed in a South Dakota beef herd, according to State Veterinarian Dustin Oedekoven.\n\nHe said Thursday [2 Mar 2017] that the suspect animals were identified in February 2017 by meat inspectors during routine slaughter inspection of otherwise healthy-appearing animals. The cattle were traced to a herd in Harding County, northwest of Rapid City. Herd testing and laboratory confirmation has revealed additional infected animals.\n\n\"We are working closely with the affected herd owner and USDA officials and will be working with area veterinarians and other herd owners to evaluate the extent of the disease,\" Oedekoven said in a release.\n\nOedekoven said adjacent herds will be tested and that bovine TB is not a food safety threat, thanks to milk pasteurization and meat inspection programs.\n\nBovine TB is a respiratory disease. Infected animals may be capable of transmitting an infection to other animals even if they appear healthy. The United States has nearly eliminated bovine TB due to a cooperative eradication campaign.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\"\n\nThere is also a nationwide surveillance program in slaughter plants. If lesions consistent with TB appear on a carcass, a sample is sent to APHIS [Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service] National Veterinary Services Laboratories [NVSL] for confirmation. The state officials will likely be tracing the movements of animals into and out of this herd in an effort to find the originating herd or herds.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from the APHIS Bovine Tuberculosis Disease Information webpage https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/animal-disease-information/cattle-disease-information/sa_tuberculosis/ and http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - USA (02): (MI) bovine 20120629.1184446\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) cervid 20120218.1045847\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20110416.1196\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20110322.0895\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (07): (MI) 20100909.3246\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20100418.1265\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20100325.0948\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2017-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Harding County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rapid City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4942680", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (06): (SD): new strain from Mexico", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4942680", "date": "2017-03-05 14:29:11", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (02): (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/cattle-disease-found-in-south-dakota/article_296015f0-0203-5ab7-9fbf-f11958cb32b6.html\n\n\nA rare case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed in a South Dakota beef herd, according to State Veterinarian Dustin Oedekoven.\n\nHe said Thursday [2 Mar 2017] that the suspect animals were identified in February 2017 by meat inspectors during routine slaughter inspection of otherwise healthy-appearing animals. The cattle were traced to a herd in Harding County, northwest of Rapid City. Herd testing and laboratory confirmation has revealed additional infected animals.\n\n\"We are working closely with the affected herd owner and USDA officials and will be working with area veterinarians and other herd owners to evaluate the extent of the disease,\" Oedekoven said in a release.\n\nOedekoven said adjacent herds will be tested and that bovine TB is not a food safety threat, thanks to milk pasteurization and meat inspection programs.\n\nBovine TB is a respiratory disease. Infected animals may be capable of transmitting an infection to other animals even if they appear healthy. The United States has nearly eliminated bovine TB due to a cooperative eradication campaign.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\"\n\nThere is also a nationwide surveillance program in slaughter plants. If lesions consistent with TB appear on a carcass, a sample is sent to APHIS [Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service] National Veterinary Services Laboratories [NVSL] for confirmation. The state officials will likely be tracing the movements of animals into and out of this herd in an effort to find the originating herd or herds.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from the APHIS Bovine Tuberculosis Disease Information webpage https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/animal-disease-information/cattle-disease-information/sa_tuberculosis/ and http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) 20170123.4786644\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) corr 20170102.4737527\n2016\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\"\n\nThere is also a nationwide surveillance program in slaughter plants. The cattle were traced to a herd in Harding County, northwest of Rapid City. Herd testing and laboratory confirmation has revealed additional infected animals.\n\n\"We are working closely with the affected herd owner and USDA officials and will be working with area veterinarians and other herd owners to evaluate the extent of the disease,\" Oedekoven said in a release.\n\nOedekoven said adjacent herds will be tested and that bovine TB is not a food safety threat, thanks to milk pasteurization and meat inspection programs.\n\nBovine TB is a respiratory disease. Infected animals may be capable of transmitting an infection to other animals even if they appear healthy. The United States has nearly eliminated bovine TB due to a cooperative eradication campaign.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\"\n\nThere is also a nationwide surveillance program in slaughter plants. If lesions consistent with TB appear on a carcass, a sample is sent to APHIS [Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service] National Veterinary Services Laboratories [NVSL] for confirmation. The state officials will likely be tracing the movements of animals into and out of this herd in an effort to find the originating herd or herds.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from the APHIS Bovine Tuberculosis Disease Information webpage https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/animal-disease-information/cattle-disease-information/sa_tuberculosis/ and http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - UK: (England) canine, camelid", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4886254", "date": "2017-03-05 14:29:11", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (02): (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/cattle-disease-found-in-south-dakota/article_296015f0-0203-5ab7-9fbf-f11958cb32b6.html\n\n\nA rare case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed in a South Dakota beef herd, according to State Veterinarian Dustin Oedekoven.\n\nHe said Thursday [2 Mar 2017] that the suspect animals were identified in February 2017 by meat inspectors during routine slaughter inspection of otherwise healthy-appearing animals. The cattle were traced to a herd in Harding County, northwest of Rapid City. Herd testing and laboratory confirmation has revealed additional infected animals.\n\n\"We are working closely with the affected herd owner and USDA officials and will be working with area veterinarians and other herd owners to evaluate the extent of the disease,\" Oedekoven said in a release.\n\nOedekoven said adjacent herds will be tested and that bovine TB is not a food safety threat, thanks to milk pasteurization and meat inspection programs.\n\nBovine TB is a respiratory disease. Infected animals may be capable of transmitting an infection to other animals even if they appear healthy. The United States has nearly eliminated bovine TB due to a cooperative eradication campaign.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\"\n\nThere is also a nationwide surveillance program in slaughter plants. If lesions consistent with TB appear on a carcass, a sample is sent to APHIS [Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service] National Veterinary Services Laboratories [NVSL] for confirmation. The state officials will likely be tracing the movements of animals into and out of this herd in an effort to find the originating herd or herds.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from the APHIS Bovine Tuberculosis Disease Information webpage https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/animal-disease-information/cattle-disease-information/sa_tuberculosis/ and http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) 20170123.4786644\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) corr 20170102.4737527\n2016\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4880068", "date": "2017-03-05 14:29:11", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (02): (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Mar 2017\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\nhttp://rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/cattle-disease-found-in-south-dakota/article_296015f0-0203-5ab7-9fbf-f11958cb32b6.html\n\n\nA rare case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed in a South Dakota beef herd, according to State Veterinarian Dustin Oedekoven.\n\nHe said Thursday [2 Mar 2017] that the suspect animals were identified in February 2017 by meat inspectors during routine slaughter inspection of otherwise healthy-appearing animals. The cattle were traced to a herd in Harding County, northwest of Rapid City. Herd testing and laboratory confirmation has revealed additional infected animals.\n\n\"We are working closely with the affected herd owner and USDA officials and will be working with area veterinarians and other herd owners to evaluate the extent of the disease,\" Oedekoven said in a release.\n\nOedekoven said adjacent herds will be tested and that bovine TB is not a food safety threat, thanks to milk pasteurization and meat inspection programs.\n\nBovine TB is a respiratory disease. Infected animals may be capable of transmitting an infection to other animals even if they appear healthy. The United States has nearly eliminated bovine TB due to a cooperative eradication campaign.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\"\n\nThere is also a nationwide surveillance program in slaughter plants. If lesions consistent with TB appear on a carcass, a sample is sent to APHIS [Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service] National Veterinary Services Laboratories [NVSL] for confirmation. The state officials will likely be tracing the movements of animals into and out of this herd in an effort to find the originating herd or herds.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from the APHIS Bovine Tuberculosis Disease Information webpage https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/animal-disease-information/cattle-disease-information/sa_tuberculosis/ and http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_health/content/printable_version/faq_bovine_tb_.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) 20170123.4786644\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) corr 20170102.4737527\n2016\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MI) 20100909.3246\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20100418.1265\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20100325.0948\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2017-02-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Harding County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/243", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rapid City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4786644", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4786644", "date": "2016-11-20 11:21:15", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - USA: (OKLAHOMA) HIGH SCHOOL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 17 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story.aspx?story=33734827&catId=112042\n\n\nA 2nd tuberculosis case has been confirmed at Jenks High School [Tulsa, Oklahoma].\n\nIn an email to Jenks school parents on Thursday morning [17 Nov 2016], the district says the student is no longer attending school and is receiving treatment. The district says students who attend class or rode the bus with the affected student will be getting a letter from the Tulsa Health Department offering a free tuberculosis test [tuberculin skin test or interferon gold?].\n\nParents are advised if their child does not receive a letter, a test will not be necessary. Jenks Public Schools stresses the risk of other students getting tuberculosis is extremely low, adding that the disease can only be transmitted through close, prolonged contact.\n\nEarlier this month [November 2016], a Jenks High School student was diagnosed with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMorgan Mueller\nOUHSC\n<Cuevas.morgan@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33686476/no-evidence-of-tuberculosis-exposure-in-jenks-schools\n\n\nJenks Public School officials say they have no evidence of exposure to tuberculosis in classrooms or on the district's school buses. This comes after a high school student was diagnosed with the disease earlier this month [November 2016].\n\nSchool officials say several students did have a positive [tuberculin] skin test, but state health officials say they believe they were likely false positives.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 7 Nov 2016.\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33649536/free-tb-tests-offered-after-jenks-student-diagnosed-with-tuberculosis\n\n\nJenks High School and the Tulsa Health Department are planning free tuberculosis testing for some students who they think may have come in contact with a student diagnosed with TB.\n\nThe Health Department confirmed with the district Monday [7 Nov 2016] morning that one high school student tested positive. The high school student has missed the last 3 weeks of class, and the health department says recovery can take at least 6 months.\n\nRob Loeber with Jenks High School said that since learning about the student with tuberculosis, the school has been in touch with the teen's family. \"We know that the student is okay and hopefully can return to school as quickly as possible,\" he said.\n\nThe Tulsa Health Department says the risk of tuberculosis spreading to anyone at the school is \"extremely low,\" but the infection is serious. Tulsa City-County Health Department [THD] Donna Durant-Macon with THD said: \"Left untreated, it can lead to death.\"\n\nDurant-Macon manages the tuberculosis program with the health department and said anyone who has had close, repeated contact with the affected student needs to take their health seriously. Students who rode the bus or went to class with the affected student are being contacted by the Tulsa Health Department and are encouraged to get tested for TB. \"If the test is positive, then we will offer chest X-rays here at the Tulsa Health Department, and there's no charge for those,\" Duran-Macon said.\n\nThe health department said that so far this year [2016], there have been 61 cases of tuberculosis statewide. Last year [2015], there were 67 cases, 16 in Tulsa County. But Durant-Macon said that it might be more common than people realize. \"I think statistically, about 1/3rd of the population is infected with the dormant infection,\" she said. She added that in some cases, active tuberculosis can take 18 to 24 months to recover from. \"We wish the student well; we wish the family well,\" Loeber said. \"I know it's a trying thing for kids and families to go through.\"\n\nFree testing is available Tuesday [8 Nov 2016] at the high school for students who the health department reached out to.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Morgan Mueller for submission of the news report of an outbreak of tuberculosis (TB) in an Oklahoma high school.\n\nTB is caused by the bacterium _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. TB exists in 2 forms: latent TB infection (LTBI) and clinically active infection (TB disease). Those with recent exposure to a person with contagious TB (e.g., pulmonary or laryngeal TB with positive sputum smear) should be evaluated immediately for LTBI because of the risk for progression to TB disease. Testing for LTBI is done by either a tuberculin skin test (TST) or a blood test known as an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA). If the TST or IGRA result is positive, and there is no evidence of TB disease, they should be treated for LTBI. Those who initially have negative results should be retested in 8-10 weeks after exposure has ended. Medical evaluations for TB disease include a TST or an IGRA, a chest x-ray and physical examination.\n\nTST is the preferred method for testing children under the age of 5 years (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/publications/LTBI/diagnosis.htm) because of limited data on the use of IGRAs in this age group (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5905.pdf). TST will detect _M. tuberculosis_ infection as well as prior exposure to BCG vaccine or non-tuberculous mycobacteria. IGRAs, however, are unaffected by BCG and most non-tuberculous, environmental mycobacteria. IGRAs should be used if there is a question of false positive reaction to TST in the exposed Jenks high school students.\n\nTB in children, either as LTBI or as TB disease, is an indication of recent transmission of _M. tuberculosis_, usually from an adult with active pulmonary or laryngeal tuberculosis, who was in close contact with the children, for example, at school, or in the home. Case finding should identify these sources. In addition, in the U.S., TB due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ continues to be reported, primarily in immigrants who have acquired the infection in countries of origin where _M. bovis_ infection remains endemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of ingesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk from _M. bovis_-infected cows and smuggled across the Mexico-U.S. border (see Levison ME: _Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis Rep 2008, 10(6): 444-6 and Dankner WM, Davis CE: _Mycobacterium bovis_ as a significant cause of tuberculosis in children residing along the United States-Mexico border in the Baja California region. Pediatrics. 2000; 105(6): E79; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10835092).\n\n_M. bovis_ is resistant to the anti-TB drug pyrazinamide (PZA), an essential component of the initial 8-week phase of the 6-month drug treatment regimen for active TB disease. If the initial phase of treatment does not include PZA, treatment must be continued for a total of 9 months, rather than 6 months (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/treatment/tbdisease.htm).\n\nTulsa, with a metropolitan area population of about one million residents, is located in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of Oklahoma (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma). The city is the county seat of Tulsa County, the most densely populated county in Oklahoma. Jenks, the location of Jenks High School, is a suburb of Tulsa in Tulsa County. As of the 2010 census, the Jenks population was 16 924. Oklahoma is located in the South Central region of the U.S. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/238.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - Spain (02): (CL) school, comment 20160529.4252860\nTuberculosis - Spain: (Castilla y Le\u00f3n) school, RFI 20160516.4225012\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - USA (02): (CA) high school students 20140516.2477848\nTuberculosis - USA: children, foreign-born parents 20140212.2273349\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - France: (BD) school, Bejing strain 20130111.1493463\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, school - Sweden (Stockholm) 20051028.3140\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\n.................................................ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Stockholm", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baja", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuberculosis - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States - Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4737527", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) corr", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4737527", "date": "2016-11-20 11:21:15", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - USA: (OKLAHOMA) HIGH SCHOOL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 17 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story.aspx?story=33734827&catId=112042\n\n\nA 2nd tuberculosis case has been confirmed at Jenks High School [Tulsa, Oklahoma].\n\nIn an email to Jenks school parents on Thursday morning [17 Nov 2016], the district says the student is no longer attending school and is receiving treatment. The district says students who attend class or rode the bus with the affected student will be getting a letter from the Tulsa Health Department offering a free tuberculosis test [tuberculin skin test or interferon gold?].\n\nParents are advised if their child does not receive a letter, a test will not be necessary. Jenks Public Schools stresses the risk of other students getting tuberculosis is extremely low, adding that the disease can only be transmitted through close, prolonged contact.\n\nEarlier this month [November 2016], a Jenks High School student was diagnosed with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMorgan Mueller\nOUHSC\n<Cuevas.morgan@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33686476/no-evidence-of-tuberculosis-exposure-in-jenks-schools\n\n\nJenks Public School officials say they have no evidence of exposure to tuberculosis in classrooms or on the district's school buses. This comes after a high school student was diagnosed with the disease earlier this month [November 2016].\n\nSchool officials say several students did have a positive [tuberculin] skin test, but state health officials say they believe they were likely false positives.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 7 Nov 2016.\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33649536/free-tb-tests-offered-after-jenks-student-diagnosed-with-tuberculosis\n\n\nJenks High School and the Tulsa Health Department are planning free tuberculosis testing for some students who they think may have come in contact with a student diagnosed with TB.\n\nThe Health Department confirmed with the district Monday [7 Nov 2016] morning that one high school student tested positive. The high school student has missed the last 3 weeks of class, and the health department says recovery can take at least 6 months.\n\nRob Loeber with Jenks High School said that since learning about the student with tuberculosis, the school has been in touch with the teen's family. \"We know that the student is okay and hopefully can return to school as quickly as possible,\" he said.\n\nThe Tulsa Health Department says the risk of tuberculosis spreading to anyone at the school is \"extremely low,\" but the infection is serious. Tulsa City-County Health Department [THD] Donna Durant-Macon with THD said: \"Left untreated, it can lead to death.\"\n\nDurant-Macon manages the tuberculosis program with the health department and said anyone who has had close, repeated contact with the affected student needs to take their health seriously. Students who rode the bus or went to class with the affected student are being contacted by the Tulsa Health Department and are encouraged to get tested for TB. \"If the test is positive, then we will offer chest X-rays here at the Tulsa Health Department, and there's no charge for those,\" Duran-Macon said.\n\nThe health department said that so far this year [2016], there have been 61 cases of tuberculosis statewide. Last year [2015], there were 67 cases, 16 in Tulsa County. But Durant-Macon said that it might be more common than people realize. \"I think statistically, about 1/3rd of the population is infected with the dormant infection,\" she said. She added that in some cases, active tuberculosis can take 18 to 24 months to recover from. \"We wish the student well; we wish the family well,\" Loeber said. \"I know it's a trying thing for kids and families to go through.\"\n\nFree testing is available Tuesday [8 Nov 2016] at the high school for students who the health department reached out to.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Morgan Mueller for submission of the news report of an outbreak of tuberculosis (TB) in an Oklahoma high school.\n\nTB is caused by the bacterium _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. TB exists in 2 forms: latent TB infection (LTBI) and clinically active infection (TB disease). Those with recent exposure to a person with contagious TB (e.g., pulmonary or laryngeal TB with positive sputum smear) should be evaluated immediately for LTBI because of the risk for progression to TB disease. Testing for LTBI is done by either a tuberculin skin test (TST) or a blood test known as an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA). If the TST or IGRA result is positive, and there is no evidence of TB disease, they should be treated for LTBI. Those who initially have negative results should be retested in 8-10 weeks after exposure has ended. Medical evaluations for TB disease include a TST or an IGRA, a chest x-ray and physical examination.\n\nTST is the preferred method for testing children under the age of 5 years (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/publications/LTBI/diagnosis.htm) because of limited data on the use of IGRAs in this age group (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5905.pdf). TST will detect _M. tuberculosis_ infection as well as prior exposure to BCG vaccine or non-tuberculous mycobacteria. IGRAs, however, are unaffected by BCG and most non-tuberculous, environmental mycobacteria. IGRAs should be used if there is a question of false positive reaction to TST in the exposed Jenks high school students.\n\nTB in children, either as LTBI or as TB disease, is an indication of recent transmission of _M. tuberculosis_, usually from an adult with active pulmonary or laryngeal tuberculosis, who was in close contact with the children, for example, at school, or in the home. Case finding should identify these sources. In addition, in the U.S., TB due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ continues to be reported, primarily in immigrants who have acquired the infection in countries of origin where _M. bovis_ infection remains endemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of ingesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk from _M. bovis_-infected cows and smuggled across the Mexico-U.S. border (see Levison ME: _Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis Rep 2008, 10(6): 444-6 and Dankner WM, Davis CE: _Mycobacterium bovis_ as a significant cause of tuberculosis in children residing along the United States-Mexico border in the Baja California region. Pediatrics. 2000; 105(6): E79; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10835092).\n\n_M. bovis_ is resistant to the anti-TB drug pyrazinamide (PZA), an essential component of the initial 8-week phase of the 6-month drug treatment regimen for active TB disease. If the initial phase of treatment does not include PZA, treatment must be continued for a total of 9 months, rather than 6 months (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/treatment/tbdisease.htm).\n\nTulsa, with a metropolitan area population of about one million residents, is located in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of Oklahoma (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma). The city is the county seat of Tulsa County, the most densely populated county in Oklahoma. Jenks, the location of Jenks High School, is a suburb of Tulsa in Tulsa County. As of the 2010 census, the Jenks population was 16 924. Oklahoma is located in the South Central region of the U.S. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/238.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - Spain (02): (CL) school, comment 20160529.4252860\nTuberculosis - Spain: (Castilla y Le\u00f3n) school, RFI 20160516.4225012\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - USA (02): (CA) high school students 20140516.2477848\nTuberculosis - USA: children, foreign-born parents 20140212.2273349\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - France: (BD) school, Bejing strain 20130111.1493463\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, school - Sweden (Stockholm) 20051028.3140\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\n.................................................ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Stockholm", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baja", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuberculosis - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States - Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4729068", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4729068", "date": "2016-11-20 11:21:15", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - USA: (OKLAHOMA) HIGH SCHOOL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 17 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story.aspx?story=33734827&catId=112042\n\n\nA 2nd tuberculosis case has been confirmed at Jenks High School [Tulsa, Oklahoma].\n\nIn an email to Jenks school parents on Thursday morning [17 Nov 2016], the district says the student is no longer attending school and is receiving treatment. The district says students who attend class or rode the bus with the affected student will be getting a letter from the Tulsa Health Department offering a free tuberculosis test [tuberculin skin test or interferon gold?].\n\nParents are advised if their child does not receive a letter, a test will not be necessary. Jenks Public Schools stresses the risk of other students getting tuberculosis is extremely low, adding that the disease can only be transmitted through close, prolonged contact.\n\nEarlier this month [November 2016], a Jenks High School student was diagnosed with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMorgan Mueller\nOUHSC\n<Cuevas.morgan@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33686476/no-evidence-of-tuberculosis-exposure-in-jenks-schools\n\n\nJenks Public School officials say they have no evidence of exposure to tuberculosis in classrooms or on the district's school buses. This comes after a high school student was diagnosed with the disease earlier this month [November 2016].\n\nSchool officials say several students did have a positive [tuberculin] skin test, but state health officials say they believe they were likely false positives.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 7 Nov 2016.\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33649536/free-tb-tests-offered-after-jenks-student-diagnosed-with-tuberculosis\n\n\nJenks High School and the Tulsa Health Department are planning free tuberculosis testing for some students who they think may have come in contact with a student diagnosed with TB.\n\nThe Health Department confirmed with the district Monday [7 Nov 2016] morning that one high school student tested positive. The high school student has missed the last 3 weeks of class, and the health department says recovery can take at least 6 months.\n\nRob Loeber with Jenks High School said that since learning about the student with tuberculosis, the school has been in touch with the teen's family. \"We know that the student is okay and hopefully can return to school as quickly as possible,\" he said.\n\nThe Tulsa Health Department says the risk of tuberculosis spreading to anyone at the school is \"extremely low,\" but the infection is serious. Tulsa City-County Health Department [THD] Donna Durant-Macon with THD said: \"Left untreated, it can lead to death.\"\n\nDurant-Macon manages the tuberculosis program with the health department and said anyone who has had close, repeated contact with the affected student needs to take their health seriously. Students who rode the bus or went to class with the affected student are being contacted by the Tulsa Health Department and are encouraged to get tested for TB. \"If the test is positive, then we will offer chest X-rays here at the Tulsa Health Department, and there's no charge for those,\" Duran-Macon said.\n\nThe health department said that so far this year [2016], there have been 61 cases of tuberculosis statewide. Last year [2015], there were 67 cases, 16 in Tulsa County. But Durant-Macon said that it might be more common than people realize. \"I think statistically, about 1/3rd of the population is infected with the dormant infection,\" she said. She added that in some cases, active tuberculosis can take 18 to 24 months to recover from. \"We wish the student well; we wish the family well,\" Loeber said. \"I know it's a trying thing for kids and families to go through.\"\n\nFree testing is available Tuesday [8 Nov 2016] at the high school for students who the health department reached out to.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Morgan Mueller for submission of the news report of an outbreak of tuberculosis (TB) in an Oklahoma high school.\n\nTB is caused by the bacterium _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. TB exists in 2 forms: latent TB infection (LTBI) and clinically active infection (TB disease). Those with recent exposure to a person with contagious TB (e.g., pulmonary or laryngeal TB with positive sputum smear) should be evaluated immediately for LTBI because of the risk for progression to TB disease. Testing for LTBI is done by either a tuberculin skin test (TST) or a blood test known as an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA). If the TST or IGRA result is positive, and there is no evidence of TB disease, they should be treated for LTBI. Those who initially have negative results should be retested in 8-10 weeks after exposure has ended. Medical evaluations for TB disease include a TST or an IGRA, a chest x-ray and physical examination.\n\nTST is the preferred method for testing children under the age of 5 years (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/publications/LTBI/diagnosis.htm) because of limited data on the use of IGRAs in this age group (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5905.pdf). TST will detect _M. tuberculosis_ infection as well as prior exposure to BCG vaccine or non-tuberculous mycobacteria. IGRAs, however, are unaffected by BCG and most non-tuberculous, environmental mycobacteria. IGRAs should be used if there is a question of false positive reaction to TST in the exposed Jenks high school students.\n\nTB in children, either as LTBI or as TB disease, is an indication of recent transmission of _M. tuberculosis_, usually from an adult with active pulmonary or laryngeal tuberculosis, who was in close contact with the children, for example, at school, or in the home. Case finding should identify these sources. In addition, in the U.S., TB due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ continues to be reported, primarily in immigrants who have acquired the infection in countries of origin where _M. bovis_ infection remains endemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of ingesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk from _M. bovis_-infected cows and smuggled across the Mexico-U.S. border (see Levison ME: _Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis Rep 2008, 10(6): 444-6 and Dankner WM, Davis CE: _Mycobacterium bovis_ as a significant cause of tuberculosis in children residing along the United States-Mexico border in the Baja California region. Pediatrics. 2000; 105(6): E79; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10835092).\n\n_M. bovis_ is resistant to the anti-TB drug pyrazinamide (PZA), an essential component of the initial 8-week phase of the 6-month drug treatment regimen for active TB disease. If the initial phase of treatment does not include PZA, treatment must be continued for a total of 9 months, rather than 6 months (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/treatment/tbdisease.htm).\n\nTulsa, with a metropolitan area population of about one million residents, is located in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of Oklahoma (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma). The city is the county seat of Tulsa County, the most densely populated county in Oklahoma. Jenks, the location of Jenks High School, is a suburb of Tulsa in Tulsa County. As of the 2010 census, the Jenks population was 16 924. Oklahoma is located in the South Central region of the U.S. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/238.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - Spain (02): (CL) school, comment 20160529.4252860\nTuberculosis - China: (Shanghai) primary, neighborhood outbreaks, 2009-2012", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4702532", "date": "2016-11-20 11:21:15", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - USA: (OKLAHOMA) HIGH SCHOOL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 17 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story.aspx?story=33734827&catId=112042\n\n\nA 2nd tuberculosis case has been confirmed at Jenks High School [Tulsa, Oklahoma].\n\nIn an email to Jenks school parents on Thursday morning [17 Nov 2016], the district says the student is no longer attending school and is receiving treatment. The district says students who attend class or rode the bus with the affected student will be getting a letter from the Tulsa Health Department offering a free tuberculosis test [tuberculin skin test or interferon gold?].\n\nParents are advised if their child does not receive a letter, a test will not be necessary. Jenks Public Schools stresses the risk of other students getting tuberculosis is extremely low, adding that the disease can only be transmitted through close, prolonged contact.\n\nEarlier this month [November 2016], a Jenks High School student was diagnosed with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMorgan Mueller\nOUHSC\n<Cuevas.morgan@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33686476/no-evidence-of-tuberculosis-exposure-in-jenks-schools\n\n\nJenks Public School officials say they have no evidence of exposure to tuberculosis in classrooms or on the district's school buses. This comes after a high school student was diagnosed with the disease earlier this month [November 2016].\n\nSchool officials say several students did have a positive [tuberculin] skin test, but state health officials say they believe they were likely false positives.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 7 Nov 2016.\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33649536/free-tb-tests-offered-after-jenks-student-diagnosed-with-tuberculosis\n\n\nJenks High School and the Tulsa Health Department are planning free tuberculosis testing for some students who they think may have come in contact with a student diagnosed with TB.\n\nThe Health Department confirmed with the district Monday [7 Nov 2016] morning that one high school student tested positive. The high school student has missed the last 3 weeks of class, and the health department says recovery can take at least 6 months.\n\nRob Loeber with Jenks High School said that since learning about the student with tuberculosis, the school has been in touch with the teen's family. \"We know that the student is okay and hopefully can return to school as quickly as possible,\" he said.\n\nThe Tulsa Health Department says the risk of tuberculosis spreading to anyone at the school is \"extremely low,\" but the infection is serious. Tulsa City-County Health Department [THD] Donna Durant-Macon with THD said: \"Left untreated, it can lead to death.\"\n\nDurant-Macon manages the tuberculosis program with the health department and said anyone who has had close, repeated contact with the affected student needs to take their health seriously. Students who rode the bus or went to class with the affected student are being contacted by the Tulsa Health Department and are encouraged to get tested for TB. \"If the test is positive, then we will offer chest X-rays here at the Tulsa Health Department, and there's no charge for those,\" Duran-Macon said.\n\nThe health department said that so far this year [2016], there have been 61 cases of tuberculosis statewide. Last year [2015], there were 67 cases, 16 in Tulsa County. But Durant-Macon said that it might be more common than people realize. \"I think statistically, about 1/3rd of the population is infected with the dormant infection,\" she said. She added that in some cases, active tuberculosis can take 18 to 24 months to recover from. \"We wish the student well; we wish the family well,\" Loeber said. \"I know it's a trying thing for kids and families to go through.\"\n\nFree testing is available Tuesday [8 Nov 2016] at the high school for students who the health department reached out to.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Morgan Mueller for submission of the news report of an outbreak of tuberculosis (TB) in an Oklahoma high school.\n\nTB is caused by the bacterium _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. TB exists in 2 forms: latent TB infection (LTBI) and clinically active infection (TB disease). Those with recent exposure to a person with contagious TB (e.g., pulmonary or laryngeal TB with positive sputum smear) should be evaluated immediately for LTBI because of the risk for progression to TB disease. Testing for LTBI is done by either a tuberculin skin test (TST) or a blood test known as an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA). If the TST or IGRA result is positive, and there is no evidence of TB disease, they should be treated for LTBI. Those who initially have negative results should be retested in 8-10 weeks after exposure has ended. Medical evaluations for TB disease include a TST or an IGRA, a chest x-ray and physical examination.\n\nTST is the preferred method for testing children under the age of 5 years (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/publications/LTBI/diagnosis.htm) because of limited data on the use of IGRAs in this age group (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5905.pdf). TST will detect _M. tuberculosis_ infection as well as prior exposure to BCG vaccine or non-tuberculous mycobacteria. IGRAs, however, are unaffected by BCG and most non-tuberculous, environmental mycobacteria. IGRAs should be used if there is a question of false positive reaction to TST in the exposed Jenks high school students.\n\nTB in children, either as LTBI or as TB disease, is an indication of recent transmission of _M. tuberculosis_, usually from an adult with active pulmonary or laryngeal tuberculosis, who was in close contact with the children, for example, at school, or in the home. Case finding should identify these sources. In addition, in the U.S., TB due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ continues to be reported, primarily in immigrants who have acquired the infection in countries of origin where _M. bovis_ infection remains endemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of ingesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk from _M. bovis_-infected cows and smuggled across the Mexico-U.S. border (see Levison ME: _Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis Rep 2008, 10(6): 444-6 and Dankner WM, Davis CE: _Mycobacterium bovis_ as a significant cause of tuberculosis in children residing along the United States-Mexico border in the Baja California region. Pediatrics. 2000; 105(6): E79; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10835092).\n\n_M. bovis_ is resistant to the anti-TB drug pyrazinamide (PZA), an essential component of the initial 8-week phase of the 6-month drug treatment regimen for active TB disease. If the initial phase of treatment does not include PZA, treatment must be continued for a total of 9 months, rather than 6 months (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/treatment/tbdisease.htm).\n\nTulsa, with a metropolitan area population of about one million residents, is located in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of Oklahoma (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma). The city is the county seat of Tulsa County, the most densely populated county in Oklahoma. Jenks, the location of Jenks High School, is a suburb of Tulsa in Tulsa County. As of the 2010 census, the Jenks population was 16 924. Oklahoma is located in the South Central region of the U.S. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/238.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - Spain (02): (CL) school, comment 20160529.4252860\nTuberculosis - Spain: (Castilla y Le\u00f3n) school, RFI 20160516.4225012\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - USA (02): (CA) high school students 20140516.2477848\nTuberculosis - USA: children, foreign-born parents 20140212.2273349\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - France: (BD) school, Bejing strain 20130111.1493463\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, school - Sweden (Stockholm) 20051028.3140\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\n.................................................ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Stockholm", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Baja", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuberculosis - Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States - Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4688768", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4688768", "date": "2016-11-20 11:21:15", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - USA: (OKLAHOMA) HIGH SCHOOL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 17 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story.aspx?story=33734827&catId=112042\n\n\nA 2nd tuberculosis case has been confirmed at Jenks High School [Tulsa, Oklahoma].\n\nIn an email to Jenks school parents on Thursday morning [17 Nov 2016], the district says the student is no longer attending school and is receiving treatment. The district says students who attend class or rode the bus with the affected student will be getting a letter from the Tulsa Health Department offering a free tuberculosis test [tuberculin skin test or interferon gold?].\n\nParents are advised if their child does not receive a letter, a test will not be necessary. Jenks Public Schools stresses the risk of other students getting tuberculosis is extremely low, adding that the disease can only be transmitted through close, prolonged contact.\n\nEarlier this month [November 2016], a Jenks High School student was diagnosed with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMorgan Mueller\nOUHSC\n<Cuevas.morgan@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33686476/no-evidence-of-tuberculosis-exposure-in-jenks-schools\n\n\nJenks Public School officials say they have no evidence of exposure to tuberculosis in classrooms or on the district's school buses. This comes after a high school student was diagnosed with the disease earlier this month [November 2016].\n\nSchool officials say several students did have a positive [tuberculin] skin test, but state health officials say they believe they were likely false positives.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 7 Nov 2016.\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33649536/free-tb-tests-offered-after-jenks-student-diagnosed-with-tuberculosis\n\n\nJenks High School and the Tulsa Health Department are planning free tuberculosis testing for some students who they think may have come in contact with a student diagnosed with TB.\n\nThe Health Department confirmed with the district Monday [7 Nov 2016] morning that one high school student tested positive. The high school student has missed the last 3 weeks of class, and the health department says recovery can take at least 6 months.\n\nRob Loeber with Jenks High School said that since learning about the student with tuberculosis, the school has been in touch with the teen's family. \"We know that the student is okay and hopefully can return to school as quickly as possible,\" he said.\n\nThe Tulsa Health Department says the risk of tuberculosis spreading to anyone at the school is \"extremely low,\" but the infection is serious. Tulsa City-County Health Department [THD] Donna Durant-Macon with THD said: \"Left untreated, it can lead to death.\"\n\nDurant-Macon manages the tuberculosis program with the health department and said anyone who has had close, repeated contact with the affected student needs to take their health seriously. Students who rode the bus or went to class with the affected student are being contacted by the Tulsa Health Department and are encouraged to get tested for TB. \"If the test is positive, then we will offer chest X-rays here at the Tulsa Health Department, and there's no charge for those,\" Duran-Macon said.\n\nThe health department said that so far this year [2016], there have been 61 cases of tuberculosis statewide. Last year [2015], there were 67 cases, 16 in Tulsa County. But Durant-Macon said that it might be more common than people realize. \"I think statistically, about 1/3rd of the population is infected with the dormant infection,\" she said. She added that in some cases, active tuberculosis can take 18 to 24 months to recover from. \"We wish the student well; we wish the family well,\" Loeber said. \"I know it's a trying thing for kids and families to go through.\"\n\nFree testing is available Tuesday [8 Nov 2016] at the high school for students who the health department reached out to.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Morgan Mueller for submission of the news report of an outbreak of tuberculosis (TB) in an Oklahoma high school.\n\nTB is caused by the bacterium _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. TB exists in 2 forms: latent TB infection (LTBI) and clinically active infection (TB disease). Those with recent exposure to a person with contagious TB (e.g., pulmonary or laryngeal TB with positive sputum smear) should be evaluated immediately for LTBI because of the risk for progression to TB disease. Testing for LTBI is done by either a tuberculin skin test (TST) or a blood test known as an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA). If the TST or IGRA result is positive, and there is no evidence of TB disease, they should be treated for LTBI. Those who initially have negative results should be retested in 8-10 weeks after exposure has ended. Medical evaluations for TB disease include a TST or an IGRA, a chest x-ray and physical examination.\n\nTST is the preferred method for testing children under the age of 5 years (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/publications/LTBI/diagnosis.htm) because of limited data on the use of IGRAs in this age group (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5905.pdf). TST will detect _M. tuberculosis_ infection as well as prior exposure to BCG vaccine or non-tuberculous mycobacteria. IGRAs, however, are unaffected by BCG and most non-tuberculous, environmental mycobacteria. IGRAs should be used if there is a question of false positive reaction to TST in the exposed Jenks high school students.\n\nTB in children, either as LTBI or as TB disease, is an indication of recent transmission of _M. tuberculosis_, usually from an adult with active pulmonary or laryngeal tuberculosis, who was in close contact with the children, for example, at school, or in the home. Case finding should identify these sources. In addition, in the U.S., TB due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ continues to be reported, primarily in immigrants who have acquired the infection in countries of origin where _M. bovis_ infection remains endemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of ingesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk from _M. bovis_-infected cows and smuggled across the Mexico-U.S. border (see Levison ME: _Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis Rep 2008, 10(6): 444-6 and Dankner WM, Davis CE: _Mycobacterium bovis_ as a significant cause of tuberculosis in children residing along the United States-Mexico border in the Baja California region. Pediatrics. 2000; 105(6): E79; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10835092).\n\n_M. bovis_ is resistant to the anti-TB drug pyrazinamide (PZA), an essential component of the initial 8-week phase of the 6-month drug treatment regimen for active TB disease. If the initial phase of treatment does not include PZA, treatment must be continued for a total of 9 months, rather than 6 months (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/treatment/tbdisease.htm).\n\nTulsa, with a metropolitan area population of about one million residents, is located in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of Oklahoma (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma). The city is the county seat of Tulsa County, the most densely populated county in Oklahoma. Jenks, the location of Jenks High School, is a suburb of Tulsa in Tulsa County. As of the 2010 census, the Jenks population was 16 924. Oklahoma is located in the South Central region of the U.S. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/238.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - Spain (02): (CL) school, comment 20160529.4252860\nTuberculosis - France: (BD) school, Bejing strain 20130111.1493463\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, school - Sweden (Stockholm) 20051028.3140\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\n.................................................ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Stockholm", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa City -
