USA: (OK) high school", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4642052", "date": "2016-11-20 11:21:15", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - USA: (OKLAHOMA) HIGH SCHOOL\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 17 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story.aspx?story=33734827&catId=112042\n\n\nA 2nd tuberculosis case has been confirmed at Jenks High School [Tulsa, Oklahoma].\n\nIn an email to Jenks school parents on Thursday morning [17 Nov 2016], the district says the student is no longer attending school and is receiving treatment. The district says students who attend class or rode the bus with the affected student will be getting a letter from the Tulsa Health Department offering a free tuberculosis test [tuberculin skin test or interferon gold?].\n\nParents are advised if their child does not receive a letter, a test will not be necessary. Jenks Public Schools stresses the risk of other students getting tuberculosis is extremely low, adding that the disease can only be transmitted through close, prolonged contact.\n\nEarlier this month [November 2016], a Jenks High School student was diagnosed with the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMorgan Mueller\nOUHSC\n<Cuevas.morgan@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 11 Nov 2016\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33686476/no-evidence-of-tuberculosis-exposure-in-jenks-schools\n\n\nJenks Public School officials say they have no evidence of exposure to tuberculosis in classrooms or on the district's school buses. This comes after a high school student was diagnosed with the disease earlier this month [November 2016].\n\nSchool officials say several students did have a positive [tuberculin] skin test, but state health officials say they believe they were likely false positives.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Mon 7 Nov 2016.\nSource: Newson6 [edited]\nhttp://m.newson6.com/story/33649536/free-tb-tests-offered-after-jenks-student-diagnosed-with-tuberculosis\n\n\nJenks High School and the Tulsa Health Department are planning free tuberculosis testing for some students who they think may have come in contact with a student diagnosed with TB.\n\nThe Health Department confirmed with the district Monday [7 Nov 2016] morning that one high school student tested positive. The high school student has missed the last 3 weeks of class, and the health department says recovery can take at least 6 months.\n\nRob Loeber with Jenks High School said that since learning about the student with tuberculosis, the school has been in touch with the teen's family. \"We know that the student is okay and hopefully can return to school as quickly as possible,\" he said.\n\nThe Tulsa Health Department says the risk of tuberculosis spreading to anyone at the school is \"extremely low,\" but the infection is serious. Tulsa City-County Health Department [THD] Donna Durant-Macon with THD said: \"Left untreated, it can lead to death.\"\n\nDurant-Macon manages the tuberculosis program with the health department and said anyone who has had close, repeated contact with the affected student needs to take their health seriously. Students who rode the bus or went to class with the affected student are being contacted by the Tulsa Health Department and are encouraged to get tested for TB. \"If the test is positive, then we will offer chest X-rays here at the Tulsa Health Department, and there's no charge for those,\" Duran-Macon said.\n\nThe health department said that so far this year [2016], there have been 61 cases of tuberculosis statewide. Last year [2015], there were 67 cases, 16 in Tulsa County. But Durant-Macon said that it might be more common than people realize. \"I think statistically, about 1/3rd of the population is infected with the dormant infection,\" she said. She added that in some cases, active tuberculosis can take 18 to 24 months to recover from. \"We wish the student well; we wish the family well,\" Loeber said. \"I know it's a trying thing for kids and families to go through.\"\n\nFree testing is available Tuesday [8 Nov 2016] at the high school for students who the health department reached out to.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Morgan Mueller for submission of the news report of an outbreak of tuberculosis (TB) in an Oklahoma high school.\n\nTB is caused by the bacterium _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. TB exists in 2 forms: latent TB infection (LTBI) and clinically active infection (TB disease). Those with recent exposure to a person with contagious TB (e.g., pulmonary or laryngeal TB with positive sputum smear) should be evaluated immediately for LTBI because of the risk for progression to TB disease. Testing for LTBI is done by either a tuberculin skin test (TST) or a blood test known as an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA). If the TST or IGRA result is positive, and there is no evidence of TB disease, they should be treated for LTBI. Those who initially have negative results should be retested in 8-10 weeks after exposure has ended. Medical evaluations for TB disease include a TST or an IGRA, a chest x-ray and physical examination.\n\nTST is the preferred method for testing children under the age of 5 years (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/publications/LTBI/diagnosis.htm) because of limited data on the use of IGRAs in this age group (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5905.pdf). TST will detect _M. tuberculosis_ infection as well as prior exposure to BCG vaccine or non-tuberculous mycobacteria. IGRAs, however, are unaffected by BCG and most non-tuberculous, environmental mycobacteria. IGRAs should be used if there is a question of false positive reaction to TST in the exposed Jenks high school students.\n\nTB in children, either as LTBI or as TB disease, is an indication of recent transmission of _M. tuberculosis_, usually from an adult with active pulmonary or laryngeal tuberculosis, who was in close contact with the children, for example, at school, or in the home. Case finding should identify these sources. In addition, in the U.S., TB due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ continues to be reported, primarily in immigrants who have acquired the infection in countries of origin where _M. bovis_ infection remains endemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of ingesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk from _M. bovis_-infected cows and smuggled across the Mexico-U.S. border (see Levison ME: _Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis Rep 2008, 10(6): 444-6 and Dankner WM, Davis CE: _Mycobacterium bovis_ as a significant cause of tuberculosis in children residing along the United States-Mexico border in the Baja California region. Pediatrics. 2000; 105(6): E79; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10835092).\n\n_M. bovis_ is resistant to the anti-TB drug pyrazinamide (PZA), an essential component of the initial 8-week phase of the 6-month drug treatment regimen for active TB disease. If the initial phase of treatment does not include PZA, treatment must be continued for a total of 9 months, rather than 6 months (http://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/treatment/tbdisease.htm).\n\nTulsa, with a metropolitan area population of about one million residents, is located in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of Oklahoma (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma). The city is the county seat of Tulsa County, the most densely populated county in Oklahoma. Jenks, the location of Jenks High School, is a suburb of Tulsa in Tulsa County. As of the 2010 census, the Jenks population was 16 924. Oklahoma is located in the South Central region of the U.S. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/238.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - Spain (02): (CL) school, comment 20160529.4252860\nTuberculosis - Spain: (Castilla y Le\u00f3n) school, RFI 20160516.4225012\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - USA (02): (CA) high school students 20140516.2477848\nTuberculosis - USA: children, foreign-born parents 20140212.2273349\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - France: (BD) school, Bejing strain 20130111.1493463\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, school - Sweden (Stockholm) 20051028.3140\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\n.................................................ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Stockholm", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa City - Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulsa County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4640117", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Canada (08): (AB) Mexican strain", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4640117", "date": "2016-11-01 17:16:01", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (05): (MICHIGAN) NEW COUNTY AFFECTED\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 31 Oct 2016, 12:00 PM\nSource: M Live Michigan [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/flint/index.ssf/2016/10/bovine_tb_found_in_steer_in_hu.html\n\n\nBovine tuberculosis was found in a 2-year-old steer [from] the state's thumb region, according to state officials.\n\nUnited States Department of Agriculture's food safety inspection service identified the Huron County steer as possibly diseased during inspection [presumably of the carcass] and removed the animal from the human food chain, according to a statement from Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. After the steer was removed, it tested positive for bovine TB, the statement said.\n\nState agriculture officials identified the farm in Huron County that sent the steer to slaughter, along with 2 prior farms in Presque Isle County where the animal had been kept. Each farm will be tested to ensure the disease is not present, the statement said. A 3-mi [approx 4.8 km] surveillance area around the Huron County farm has been established and all farms within that zone will have 6 months to complete bovine tuberculosis testing.\n\nThere will be a meeting to discuss the finding of bovine TB and the surveillance area at 7 pm, on 14 Nov [2016] at the Holiday Inn Express & Suites, 55 Rapson Lane West in Bad Axe.\n\n\"Cattle properly identified with (radio frequency identification) can be traced in minutes,\" Dr. Rick Smith, assistant state veterinarian said in a statement. \"Not only can we find the most recent owner, we can successfully track where the animal has moved, allowing us to stamp out disease before it spreads.\"\n\nThe name of the farm that the steer came from and city it was located in was not released under Public Act 466 that bars making that information public, according to Jennifer Holton, spokeswoman for the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. \"This did not go into the food chain,\" Holton said of the steer. \"This shows that what is supposed to be happening did happen to make sure that consumer public health, food safety is protected.\"\n\nBovine TB primarily affects cattle, but can be spread between other mammals, including humans. The [bacterial pathogen] primarily affects the respiratory system of infected animals, but can spread to other parts of the body. In the U.S., [infection of] humans with bovine TB from animals is rare, according to state officials, and bovine TB can be effectively treated in exposed humans.\n\n[Byline: Dominic Adams]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development website of 31 Oct 2016: \"Bovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in samples taken from a 2-year old steer from Huron County. The animal was identified as possibly diseased and removed from the human food chain by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, Food Safety Inspection Service, who inspects each animal during processing.\" i.e., at post-mortem inspection of the carcass http://www.michigan.gov/mdard/0,4610,7-125-1660-396745--,00.html.\n\nTo review the Current Bovine TB Issues in Michigan, members should refer to http://www.michigan.gov/emergingdiseases/0,1607,7-186-25804---,00.html. The disease is not proving easy to eradicate in the state.\n\nFor a map of Michigan go to: http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/michigan_90.jpg. Huron County is the \"thumb\" county on the eastern side of the state. - Mod.MHJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada (06): (AB, SK) singular genome", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4628497", "date": "2016-11-01 17:16:01", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (05): (MICHIGAN) NEW COUNTY AFFECTED\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 31 Oct 2016, 12:00 PM\nSource: M Live Michigan [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/flint/index.ssf/2016/10/bovine_tb_found_in_steer_in_hu.html\n\n\nBovine tuberculosis was found in a 2-year-old steer [from] the state's thumb region, according to state officials.\n\nUnited States Department of Agriculture's food safety inspection service identified the Huron County steer as possibly diseased during inspection [presumably of the carcass] and removed the animal from the human food chain, according to a statement from Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. After the steer was removed, it tested positive for bovine TB, the statement said.\n\nState agriculture officials identified the farm in Huron County that sent the steer to slaughter, along with 2 prior farms in Presque Isle County where the animal had been kept. Each farm will be tested to ensure the disease is not present, the statement said. A 3-mi [approx 4.8 km] surveillance area around the Huron County farm has been established and all farms within that zone will have 6 months to complete bovine tuberculosis testing.\n\nThere will be a meeting to discuss the finding of bovine TB and the surveillance area at 7 pm, on 14 Nov [2016] at the Holiday Inn Express & Suites, 55 Rapson Lane West in Bad Axe.\n\n\"Cattle properly identified with (radio frequency identification) can be traced in minutes,\" Dr. Rick Smith, assistant state veterinarian said in a statement. \"Not only can we find the most recent owner, we can successfully track where the animal has moved, allowing us to stamp out disease before it spreads.\"\n\nThe name of the farm that the steer came from and city it was located in was not released under Public Act 466 that bars making that information public, according to Jennifer Holton, spokeswoman for the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. \"This did not go into the food chain,\" Holton said of the steer. \"This shows that what is supposed to be happening did happen to make sure that consumer public health, food safety is protected.\"\n\nBovine TB primarily affects cattle, but can be spread between other mammals, including humans. The [bacterial pathogen] primarily affects the respiratory system of infected animals, but can spread to other parts of the body. In the U.S., [infection of] humans with bovine TB from animals is rare, according to state officials, and bovine TB can be effectively treated in exposed humans.\n\n[Byline: Dominic Adams]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development website of 31 Oct 2016: \"Bovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in samples taken from a 2-year old steer from Huron County. Canada (05): (AB,SK) extended", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4620082", "date": "2016-11-01 17:16:01", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (05): (MICHIGAN) NEW COUNTY AFFECTED\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 31 Oct 2016, 12:00 PM\nSource: M Live Michigan [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/flint/index.ssf/2016/10/bovine_tb_found_in_steer_in_hu.html\n\n\nBovine tuberculosis was found in a 2-year-old steer [from] the state's thumb region, according to state officials.\n\nUnited States Department of Agriculture's food safety inspection service identified the Huron County steer as possibly diseased during inspection [presumably of the carcass] and removed the animal from the human food chain, according to a statement from Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. After the steer was removed, it tested positive for bovine TB, the statement said.\n\nState agriculture officials identified the farm in Huron County that sent the steer to slaughter, along with 2 prior farms in Presque Isle County where the animal had been kept. Each farm will be tested to ensure the disease is not present, the statement said. A 3-mi [approx 4.8 km] surveillance area around the Huron County farm has been established and all farms within that zone will have 6 months to complete bovine tuberculosis testing.\n\nThere will be a meeting to discuss the finding of bovine TB and the surveillance area at 7 pm, on 14 Nov [2016] at the Holiday Inn Express & Suites, 55 Rapson Lane West in Bad Axe.\n\n\"Cattle properly identified with (radio frequency identification) can be traced in minutes,\" Dr. Rick Smith, assistant state veterinarian said in a statement. \"Not only can we find the most recent owner, we can successfully track where the animal has moved, allowing us to stamp out disease before it spreads.\"\n\nThe name of the farm that the steer came from and city it was located in was not released under Public Act 466 that bars making that information public, according to Jennifer Holton, spokeswoman for the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. \"This did not go into the food chain,\" Holton said of the steer. \"This shows that what is supposed to be happening did happen to make sure that consumer public health, food safety is protected.\"\n\nBovine TB primarily affects cattle, but can be spread between other mammals, including humans. The [bacterial pathogen] primarily affects the respiratory system of infected animals, but can spread to other parts of the body. In the U.S., [infection of] humans with bovine TB from animals is rare, according to state officials, and bovine TB can be effectively treated in exposed humans.\n\n[Byline: Dominic Adams]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development website of 31 Oct 2016: \"Bovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in samples taken from a 2-year old steer from Huron County. The animal was identified as possibly diseased and removed from the human food chain by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, Food Safety Inspection Service, who inspects each animal during processing.\" i.e., at post-mortem inspection of the carcass http://www.michigan.gov/mdard/0,4610,7-125-1660-396745--,00.html.\n\nTo review the Current Bovine TB Issues in Michigan, members should refer to http://www.michigan.gov/emergingdiseases/0,1607,7-186-25804---,00.html. The disease is not proving easy to eradicate in the state.\n\nFor a map of Michigan go to: http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/michigan_90.jpg. Huron County is the \"thumb\" county on the eastern side of the state. - Mod.MHJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/225.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - After the steer was removed, it tested positive for bovine TB, the statement said.\n\nState agriculture officials identified the farm in Huron County that sent the steer to slaughter, along with 2 prior farms in Presque Isle County where the animal had been kept. Each farm will be tested to ensure the disease is not present, the statement said. A 3-mi [approx 4.8 km] surveillance area around the Huron County farm has been established and all farms within that zone will have 6 months to complete bovine tuberculosis testing.\n\nThere will be a meeting to discuss the finding of bovine TB and the surveillance area at 7 pm, on 14 Nov [2016] at the Holiday Inn Express & Suites, 55 Rapson Lane West in Bad Axe.\n\n\"Cattle properly identified with (radio frequency identification) can be traced in minutes,\" Dr. Rick Smith, assistant state veterinarian said in a statement. \"Not only can we find the most recent owner, we can successfully track where the animal has moved, allowing us to stamp out disease before it spreads.\"\n\nThe name of the farm that the steer came from and city it was located in was not released under Public Act 466 that bars making that information public, according to Jennifer Holton, spokeswoman for the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. \"This did not go into the food chain,\" Holton said of the steer. \"This shows that what is supposed to be happening did happen to make sure that consumer public health, food safety is protected.\"\n\nBovine TB primarily affects cattle, but can be spread between other mammals, including humans. The [bacterial pathogen] primarily affects the respiratory system of infected animals, but can spread to other parts of the body. In the U.S., [infection of] humans with bovine TB from animals is rare, according to state officials, and bovine TB can be effectively treated in exposed humans.\n\n[Byline: Dominic Adams]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development website of 31 Oct 2016: \"Bovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in samples taken from a 2-year old steer from Huron County. Canada (03): (AB) herds quarantined", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4600493", "date": "2016-11-01 17:16:01", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (05): (MICHIGAN) NEW COUNTY AFFECTED\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 31 Oct 2016, 12:00 PM\nSource: M Live Michigan [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/flint/index.ssf/2016/10/bovine_tb_found_in_steer_in_hu.html\n\n\nBovine tuberculosis was found in a 2-year-old steer [from] the state's thumb region, according to state officials.\n\nUnited States Department of Agriculture's food safety inspection service identified the Huron County steer as possibly diseased during inspection [presumably of the carcass] and removed the animal from the human food chain, according to a statement from Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. After the steer was removed, it tested positive for bovine TB, the statement said.\n\nState agriculture officials identified the farm in Huron County that sent the steer to slaughter, along with 2 prior farms in Presque Isle County where the animal had been kept. Each farm will be tested to ensure the disease is not present, the statement said. A 3-mi [approx 4.8 km] surveillance area around the Huron County farm has been established and all farms within that zone will have 6 months to complete bovine tuberculosis testing.\n\nThere will be a meeting to discuss the finding of bovine TB and the surveillance area at 7 pm, on 14 Nov [2016] at the Holiday Inn Express & Suites, 55 Rapson Lane West in Bad Axe.\n\n\"Cattle properly identified with (radio frequency identification) can be traced in minutes,\" Dr. Rick Smith, assistant state veterinarian said in a statement. \"Not only can we find the most recent owner, we can successfully track where the animal has moved, allowing us to stamp out disease before it spreads.\"\n\nThe name of the farm that the steer came from and city it was located in was not released under Public Act 466 that bars making that information public, according to Jennifer Holton, spokeswoman for the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. \"This did not go into the food chain,\" Holton said of the steer. \"This shows that what is supposed to be happening did happen to make sure that consumer public health, food safety is protected.\"\n\nBovine TB primarily affects cattle, but can be spread between other mammals, including humans. The [bacterial pathogen] primarily affects the respiratory system of infected animals, but can spread to other parts of the body. In the U.S., [infection of] humans with bovine TB from animals is rare, according to state officials, and bovine TB can be effectively treated in exposed humans.\n\n[Byline: Dominic Adams]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development website of 31 Oct 2016: \"Bovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in samples taken from a 2-year old steer from Huron County. USA (05): (MI) new county affected", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4600409", "date": "2016-11-01 17:16:01", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (05): (MICHIGAN) NEW COUNTY AFFECTED\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 31 Oct 2016, 12:00 PM\nSource: M Live Michigan [edited]\nhttp://www.mlive.com/news/flint/index.ssf/2016/10/bovine_tb_found_in_steer_in_hu.html\n\n\nBovine tuberculosis was found in a 2-year-old steer [from] the state's thumb region, according to state officials.\n\nUnited States Department of Agriculture's food safety inspection service identified the Huron County steer as possibly diseased during inspection [presumably of the carcass] and removed the animal from the human food chain, according to a statement from Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. After the steer was removed, it tested positive for bovine TB, the statement said.\n\nState agriculture officials identified the farm in Huron County that sent the steer to slaughter, along with 2 prior farms in Presque Isle County where the animal had been kept. Each farm will be tested to ensure the disease is not present, the statement said. A 3-mi [approx 4.8 km] surveillance area around the Huron County farm has been established and all farms within that zone will have 6 months to complete bovine tuberculosis testing.\n\nThere will be a meeting to discuss the finding of bovine TB and the surveillance area at 7 pm, on 14 Nov [2016] at the Holiday Inn Express & Suites, 55 Rapson Lane West in Bad Axe.\n\n\"Cattle properly identified with (radio frequency identification) can be traced in minutes,\" Dr. Rick Smith, assistant state veterinarian said in a statement. \"Not only can we find the most recent owner, we can successfully track where the animal has moved, allowing us to stamp out disease before it spreads.\"\n\nThe name of the farm that the steer came from and city it was located in was not released under Public Act 466 that bars making that information public, according to Jennifer Holton, spokeswoman for the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development. \"This did not go into the food chain,\" Holton said of the steer. \"This shows that what is supposed to be happening did happen to make sure that consumer public health, food safety is protected.\"\n\nBovine TB primarily affects cattle, but can be spread between other mammals, including humans. The [bacterial pathogen] primarily affects the respiratory system of infected animals, but can spread to other parts of the body. In the U.S., [infection of] humans with bovine TB from animals is rare, according to state officials, and bovine TB can be effectively treated in exposed humans.\n\n[Byline: Dominic Adams]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the Michigan Department of Agriculture & Rural Development website of 31 Oct 2016: \"Bovine tuberculosis was recently confirmed in samples taken from a 2-year old steer from Huron County. Canada (02): (AB) herds quarantined", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4598091", "date": "2016-07-18 12:11:32", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - INDIA (04): (SIKKIM, MAHARASHTRA) BEIJING STRAIN\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Jul 2016 01:44 IST\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\nhttp://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/beijing-strain-tb-in-mumbai-is-drugresistant/article8860635.ece\n\n\nThe virulent Beijing strain that was found in most multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) cases in Sikkim is a concern in Mumbai as well. Not only has the strain been identified in tuberculosis patients in Mumbai over the past decade, but in most cases it was also found to be drug-resistant. \"We have collected strains from tuberculosis patients in the last one year in Mumbai, and found that almost 95 percent are drug resistant,\" said Dr Nerges Mistry, director, Foundation for Medical Research, referring to a study that is still under way.\n\nThe Hindu on [14 Jul 2016] reported the growing concern of MDR-TB in Sikkim, which is recording almost the same proportion of drug-resistant cases as Mumbai, India's TB capital. [See ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates 20160716.4350079.] The ICMR's [Indian Council of Medical Research] institute in Dibrugarh had over the last year studied 120 MDR-TB strains in patients from Sikkim and identified 70 percent of them as Beijing strains.\n\nDr Mistry said that the genome sequencing of the strains found in TB patients in Mumbai has shown a lot of drug mutation, making the cases more difficult to treat. However, there are no data yet on the strain's prevalence and Dr Mistry said there was a need for surveillance to map the numbers.\n\nThe reason why tuberculosis experts are worried is because the drug-resistant Beijing strain has an enhanced fitness \"in terms of their ability to grow as compared to the drug-sensitive strains,\" noted a study co-authored by Dr Mistry and published by the Elsevier. It further noted that the Beijing genotype was known to be associated with several outbreaks across the world \"implying mechanisms which permit its predominance even in the presence of other competing strains.\"\n\n\"This highlights the virulent nature of the strain and its high transmission efficiency across different continents and thus its inherent ability to multiply faster in the presence of several strain types,\" the study says.\n\nStudies published over the years have recorded the presence of the Beijing strain in Mumbai [1]. About a decade ago, doctors at PD Hinduja Hospital had reported a high frequency (35 percent) of the Beijing genotype among the MDR-TB [multidrug resistant tuberculosis] cases in a study published in Clinical Infectious Diseases journal. The high figure was, however, attributed to the hospital being a tertiary care facility that largely gets cases not responding to the treatment.\n\n[Byline: Roli Srivastava]\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Mistry NF, Iyer AM, D'souza DTB, et al: Spoligotyping of _Mycobacterium tuberculosi_ isolates from multiple-drug-resistant tuberculosis patients from Bombay, India. J Clin Microbiol. 2002; 40(7): 2677-80; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC120599/]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of 120 multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) strains from patients in Sikkim over the past year (2015-2016) 70 percent were reported to be 'Beijing strains' (ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates 20160716.4350079). Beijing strains were first identified in 1995 in the Far East, mainly in Beijing province of China, on the basis of genotyping (http://jcm.asm.org/content/33/12/3234.long). Beijing strains are related on the basis of genotyping to a multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ strain, known as \"W\", that caused large institutional outbreaks of tuberculosis (TB) and many deaths in New York City in the 1990's (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00020788.htm). Strains of the Beijing/W genotype family of _M. tuberculosis_ have subsequently been found to have caused tuberculosis worldwide, predominating in some geographic areas, especially in Asia. Beijing strains represent about 50 percent of strains in East Asia and at least 13 percent of strains worldwide (http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(09)70330-5/abstract).\n\nBeijing strains are frequently associated with multidrug resistance (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/8/8/02-0002_article) and outbreaks, which suggest increased transmissibility (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22865872). Beijing strains have also been found to exhibit increased virulence in animal models, being better able to withstand tuberculosis treatment, even in the absence of drug resistance (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/201/4/553.full). - Mod.ML\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - USA ex India 20080103.0019\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mumbai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bombay", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4574397", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Canada: (AB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4574397", "date": "2016-07-18 12:11:32", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - INDIA (04): (SIKKIM, MAHARASHTRA) BEIJING STRAIN\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Jul 2016 01:44 IST\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\nhttp://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/beijing-strain-tb-in-mumbai-is-drugresistant/article8860635.ece\n\n\nThe virulent Beijing strain that was found in most multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) cases in Sikkim is a concern in Mumbai as well. Not only has the strain been identified in tuberculosis patients in Mumbai over the past decade, but in most cases it was also found to be drug-resistant. \"We have collected strains from tuberculosis patients in the last one year in Mumbai, and found that almost 95 percent are drug resistant,\" said Dr Nerges Mistry, director, Foundation for Medical Research, referring to a study that is still under way.\n\nThe Hindu on [14 Jul 2016] reported the growing concern of MDR-TB in Sikkim, which is recording almost the same proportion of drug-resistant cases as Mumbai, India's TB capital. [See ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates 20160716.4350079.] The ICMR's [Indian Council of Medical Research] institute in Dibrugarh had over the last year studied 120 MDR-TB strains in patients from Sikkim and identified 70 percent of them as Beijing strains.\n\nDr Mistry said that the genome sequencing of the strains found in TB patients in Mumbai has shown a lot of drug mutation, making the cases more difficult to treat. However, there are no data yet on the strain's prevalence and Dr Mistry said there was a need for surveillance to map the numbers.\n\nThe reason why tuberculosis experts are worried is because the drug-resistant Beijing strain has an enhanced fitness \"in terms of their ability to grow as compared to the drug-sensitive strains,\" noted a study co-authored by Dr Mistry and published by the Elsevier. It further noted that the Beijing genotype was known to be associated with several outbreaks across the world \"implying mechanisms which permit its predominance even in the presence of other competing strains.\"\n\n\"This highlights the virulent nature of the strain and its high transmission efficiency across different continents and thus its inherent ability to multiply faster in the presence of several strain types,\" the study says.\n\nStudies published over the years have recorded the presence of the Beijing strain in Mumbai [1]. About a decade ago, doctors at PD Hinduja Hospital had reported a high frequency (35 percent) of the Beijing genotype among the MDR-TB [multidrug resistant tuberculosis] cases in a study published in Clinical Infectious Diseases journal. The high figure was, however, attributed to the hospital being a tertiary care facility that largely gets cases not responding to the treatment.\n\n[Byline: Roli Srivastava]\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Mistry NF, Iyer AM, D'souza DTB, et al: Spoligotyping of _Mycobacterium tuberculosi_ isolates from multiple-drug-resistant tuberculosis patients from Bombay, India. J Clin Microbiol. 2002; 40(7): 2677-80; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC120599/]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of 120 multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) strains from patients in Sikkim over the past year (2015-2016) 70 percent were reported to be 'Beijing strains' (ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates 20160716.4350079). Beijing strains were first identified in 1995 in the Far East, mainly in Beijing province of China, on the basis of genotyping (http://jcm.asm.org/content/33/12/3234.long). Beijing strains are related on the basis of genotyping to a multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ strain, known as \"W\", that caused large institutional outbreaks of tuberculosis (TB) and many deaths in New York City in the 1990's (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00020788.htm). Strains of the Beijing/W genotype family of _M. tuberculosis_ have subsequently been found to have caused tuberculosis worldwide, predominating in some geographic areas, especially in Asia. Beijing strains represent about 50 percent of strains in East Asia and at least 13 percent of strains worldwide (http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(09)70330-5/abstract).\n\nBeijing strains are frequently associated with multidrug resistance (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/8/8/02-0002_article) and outbreaks, which suggest increased transmissibility (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22865872). Beijing strains have also been found to exhibit increased virulence in animal models, being better able to withstand tuberculosis treatment, even in the absence of drug resistance (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/201/4/553.full). - Mod.ML\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - [See ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates 20160716.4350079.] The ICMR's [Indian Council of Medical Research] institute in Dibrugarh had over the last year studied 120 MDR-TB strains in patients from Sikkim and identified 70 percent of them as Beijing strains.\n\nDr Mistry said that the genome sequencing of the strains found in TB patients in Mumbai has shown a lot of drug mutation, making the cases more difficult to treat. However, there are no data yet on the strain's prevalence and Dr Mistry said there was a need for surveillance to map the numbers.\n\nThe reason why tuberculosis experts are worried is because the drug-resistant Beijing strain has an enhanced fitness \"in terms of their ability to grow as compared to the drug-sensitive strains,\" noted a study co-authored by Dr Mistry and published by the Elsevier. It further noted that the Beijing genotype was known to be associated with several outbreaks across the world \"implying mechanisms which permit its predominance even in the presence of other competing strains.\"\n\n\"This highlights the virulent nature of the strain and its high transmission efficiency across different continents and thus its inherent ability to multiply faster in the presence of several strain types,\" the study says.\n\nStudies published over the years have recorded the presence of the Beijing strain in Mumbai [1]. About a decade ago, doctors at PD Hinduja Hospital had reported a high frequency (35 percent) of the Beijing genotype among the MDR-TB [multidrug resistant tuberculosis] cases in a study published in Clinical Infectious Diseases journal. The high figure was, however, attributed to the hospital being a tertiary care facility that largely gets cases not responding to the treatment.\n\n[Byline: Roli Srivastava]\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Mistry NF, Iyer AM, D'souza DTB, et al: Spoligotyping of _Mycobacterium tuberculosi_ isolates from multiple-drug-resistant tuberculosis patients from Bombay, India. J Clin Microbiol. 2002; 40(7): 2677-80; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC120599/]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of 120 multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) strains from patients in Sikkim over the past year (2015-2016) 70 percent were reported to be 'Beijing strains' (ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates 20160716.4350079). Beijing strains were first identified in 1995 in the Far East, mainly in Beijing province of China, on the basis of genotyping (http://jcm.asm.org/content/33/12/3234.long). Beijing strains are related on the basis of genotyping to a multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ strain, known as \"W\", that caused large institutional outbreaks of tuberculosis (TB) and many deaths in New York City in the 1990's (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00020788.htm). Strains of the Beijing/W genotype family of _M. tuberculosis_ have subsequently been found to have caused tuberculosis worldwide, predominating in some geographic areas, especially in Asia. Beijing strains represent about 50 percent of strains in East Asia and at least 13 percent of strains worldwide (http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(09)70330-5/abstract).\n\nBeijing strains are frequently associated with multidrug resistance (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/8/8/02-0002_article) and outbreaks, which suggest increased transmissibility (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22865872). Beijing strains have also been found to exhibit increased virulence in animal models, being better able to withstand tuberculosis treatment, even in the absence of drug resistance (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/201/4/553.full). - Mod.ML\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - India (04): (MH) nosocomial, MDR 20151014.3714117\nTuberculosis - India: (PB) MDR 20150106.3074389\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - India (03): MDR, 2013 20141129.2998315\nTuberculosis - India (02): (MH) MDR 20140328.2364314\nTuberculosis - USA (04): (IN) wild cervids", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4420929", "date": "2016-07-18 12:11:32", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - INDIA (04): (SIKKIM, MAHARASHTRA) BEIJING STRAIN\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Jul 2016 01:44 IST\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\nhttp://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/mumbai/beijing-strain-tb-in-mumbai-is-drugresistant/article8860635.ece\n\n\nThe virulent Beijing strain that was found in most multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) cases in Sikkim is a concern in Mumbai as well. Not only has the strain been identified in tuberculosis patients in Mumbai over the past decade, but in most cases it was also found to be drug-resistant. \"We have collected strains from tuberculosis patients in the last one year in Mumbai, and found that almost 95 percent are drug resistant,\" said Dr Nerges Mistry, director, Foundation for Medical Research, referring to a study that is still under way.\n\nThe Hindu on [14 Jul 2016] reported the growing concern of MDR-TB in Sikkim, which is recording almost the same proportion of drug-resistant cases as Mumbai, India's TB capital. [See ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates 20160716.4350079.] The ICMR's [Indian Council of Medical Research] institute in Dibrugarh had over the last year studied 120 MDR-TB strains in patients from Sikkim and identified 70 percent of them as Beijing strains.\n\nDr Mistry said that the genome sequencing of the strains found in TB patients in Mumbai has shown a lot of drug mutation, making the cases more difficult to treat. However, there are no data yet on the strain's prevalence and Dr Mistry said there was a need for surveillance to map the numbers.\n\nThe reason why tuberculosis experts are worried is because the drug-resistant Beijing strain has an enhanced fitness \"in terms of their ability to grow as compared to the drug-sensitive strains,\" noted a study co-authored by Dr Mistry and published by the Elsevier. It further noted that the Beijing genotype was known to be associated with several outbreaks across the world \"implying mechanisms which permit its predominance even in the presence of other competing strains.\"\n\n\"This highlights the virulent nature of the strain and its high transmission efficiency across different continents and thus its inherent ability to multiply faster in the presence of several strain types,\" the study says.\n\nStudies published over the years have recorded the presence of the Beijing strain in Mumbai [1]. About a decade ago, doctors at PD Hinduja Hospital had reported a high frequency (35 percent) of the Beijing genotype among the MDR-TB [multidrug resistant tuberculosis] cases in a study published in Clinical Infectious Diseases journal. The high figure was, however, attributed to the hospital being a tertiary care facility that largely gets cases not responding to the treatment.\n\n[Byline: Roli Srivastava]\n\n[Reference\n----------\n1. Mistry NF, Iyer AM, D'souza DTB, et al: Spoligotyping of _Mycobacterium tuberculosi_ isolates from multiple-drug-resistant tuberculosis patients from Bombay, India. J Clin Microbiol. 2002; 40(7): 2677-80; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC120599/]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Of 120 multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) strains from patients in Sikkim over the past year (2015-2016) 70 percent were reported to be 'Beijing strains' (ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates 20160716.4350079). Beijing strains were first identified in 1995 in the Far East, mainly in Beijing province of China, on the basis of genotyping (http://jcm.asm.org/content/33/12/3234.long). Beijing strains are related on the basis of genotyping to a multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ strain, known as \"W\", that caused large institutional outbreaks of tuberculosis (TB) and many deaths in New York City in the 1990's (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00020788.htm). Strains of the Beijing/W genotype family of _M. tuberculosis_ have subsequently been found to have caused tuberculosis worldwide, predominating in some geographic areas, especially in Asia. Beijing strains represent about 50 percent of strains in East Asia and at least 13 percent of strains worldwide (http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(09)70330-5/abstract).\n\nBeijing strains are frequently associated with multidrug resistance (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/8/8/02-0002_article) and outbreaks, which suggest increased transmissibility (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22865872). Beijing strains have also been found to exhibit increased virulence in animal models, being better able to withstand tuberculosis treatment, even in the absence of drug resistance (http://jid.oxfordjournals.org/content/201/4/553.full). - India (03): (SK) intro. of GeneXpert system, high MDR rates", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4350079", "date": "2016-05-02 19:24:10", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND: CATTLE, DEER, POSSUMS\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 2 May 2016\nSource: NZ Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/the-country/news/article.cfm?c_id=16&objectid=11632206\n\n\nA ferret survey is being undertaken in the Mt Cargill area, near Dunedin, after last year's [2015] bovine Tb outbreak.\n\nFour herds of cattle and deer were identified as infected with Tb. In a recent update, TB free southern South Island programme manager Brent Rohloff said work had been progressing well.\n\nOSPRI [Operational Solutions for Primary Industries] was using a combination of herd Tb testing, controls on animal movement for infected herds, and survey and control of wild animals to eradicate Tb from the area.\n\nAs Tb had been found in 6 possums and one ferret, further surveillance work was needed to determine the extent of the infection in local wildlife.\n\nThe ferret survey, undertaken by a TB free contractor, was expected to be finished by the end of this month [May 2016].\n\nFerrets scavenged Tb-infected possums and could become infected with the disease, which made them \"extremely important'' indicators of whether Tb was present in an area. Trapping was being used for the survey, and carcasses would be sent for postmortem examination.\n\nFurther possum control and surveys would be done during this year and next year [2016-17].\n\nThe infected herds were subject to an ongoing intensive Tb testing programme until they were free of the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The situation with possums in New Zealand is similar to the situation with badgers in the UK. These animals are resident reservoirs of TB.\n\nAs New Zealand seeks to control the TB population, looking at the prevalence and spread through other susceptible populations may be a good approach to understanding how far the disease has spread in certain areas. It may provide a tool to predict which farms of bovines may soon be seen suffering from the disease.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (TB) is a slow, insidious disease that can have a nasty grip on a herd before it is ever located.\n\nTuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacterial aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\n\nAlthough the disease (TB) is transmissible from animals to humans, the risk of infection is likely to be small. The responsible bacterium, _Mycobacterium bovis_, can be transmitted by close contact with the animals. Practically speaking, the producer and family, the veterinarian, the cattle dealers and slaughterhouse workers are most at risk. A consumer can become infected just by drinking raw milk or eating cheese made from raw milk. Most milk is pasteurized (heated) in a process that the bacteria will not survive.\n\nAlso, most places have a meat inspection process to prevent diseased or suspect diseased animals from entering the human food chain.\n\nUsing possums and ferrets to understand disease dissemination seems reasonable, but the deer component seems a more complicated factor. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - New Zealand 20151205.3843019\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway (02): ex Canada, comment 20150831.3614443\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex Canada, RFI 20150829.3610821\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium (02): (LI) update 20150819.3587763\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium: (LI) 20150808.3566504\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine 20150725.3534951\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) dairy cows 20150426.3323167\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine 20150127.3124201\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX) dairy cattle 20150115.3093307\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Fiji: (CE) 20141114.2954055\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland: call for cervid control 20141104.2928051\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (SM) 20140728.2641321\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): bovine, spread, research 20140705.2589984\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex UK, susp, RFI 20140530.2508847\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (MI) 20140413.2400796\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: bovine spread, feline 20140410.2395905\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): tuberculin shortage 20140330.2367001\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-05-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4302632", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, MDR - Singapore: (AMK) neighborhood outbreak, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4294856", "date": "2016-05-02 19:24:10", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND: CATTLE, DEER, POSSUMS\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 2 May 2016\nSource: NZ Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/the-country/news/article.cfm?c_id=16&objectid=11632206\n\n\nA ferret survey is being undertaken in the Mt Cargill area, near Dunedin, after last year's [2015] bovine Tb outbreak.\n\nFour herds of cattle and deer were identified as infected with Tb. In a recent update, TB free southern South Island programme manager Brent Rohloff said work had been progressing well.\n\nOSPRI [Operational Solutions for Primary Industries] was using a combination of herd Tb testing, controls on animal movement for infected herds, and survey and control of wild animals to eradicate Tb from the area.\n\nAs Tb had been found in 6 possums and one ferret, further surveillance work was needed to determine the extent of the infection in local wildlife.\n\nThe ferret survey, undertaken by a TB free contractor, was expected to be finished by the end of this month [May 2016].\n\nFerrets scavenged Tb-infected possums and could become infected with the disease, which made them \"extremely important'' indicators of whether Tb was present in an area. Trapping was being used for the survey, and carcasses would be sent for postmortem examination.\n\nFurther possum control and surveys would be done during this year and next year [2016-17].\n\nThe infected herds were subject to an ongoing intensive Tb testing programme until they were free of the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The situation with possums in New Zealand is similar to the situation with badgers in the UK. These animals are resident reservoirs of TB.\n\nAs New Zealand seeks to control the TB population, looking at the prevalence and spread through other susceptible populations may be a good approach to understanding how far the disease has spread in certain areas. It may provide a tool to predict which farms of bovines may soon be seen suffering from the disease.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (TB) is a slow, insidious disease that can have a nasty grip on a herd before it is ever located.\n\nTuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacterial aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\n\nAlthough the disease (TB) is transmissible from animals to humans, the risk of infection is likely to be small. The responsible bacterium, _Mycobacterium bovis_, can be transmitted by close contact with the animals. Practically speaking, the producer and family, the veterinarian, the cattle dealers and slaughterhouse workers are most at risk. A consumer can become infected just by drinking raw milk or eating cheese made from raw milk. Most milk is pasteurized (heated) in a process that the bacteria will not survive.\n\nAlso, most places have a meat inspection process to prevent diseased or suspect diseased animals from entering the human food chain.\n\nUsing possums and ferrets to understand disease dissemination seems reasonable, but the deer component seems a more complicated factor. - Spain (02): (CL) school, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4252860", "date": "2016-05-02 19:24:10", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND: CATTLE, DEER, POSSUMS\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 2 May 2016\nSource: NZ Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/the-country/news/article.cfm?c_id=16&objectid=11632206\n\n\nA ferret survey is being undertaken in the Mt Cargill area, near Dunedin, after last year's [2015] bovine Tb outbreak.\n\nFour herds of cattle and deer were identified as infected with Tb. In a recent update, TB free southern South Island programme manager Brent Rohloff said work had been progressing well.\n\nOSPRI [Operational Solutions for Primary Industries] was using a combination of herd Tb testing, controls on animal movement for infected herds, and survey and control of wild animals to eradicate Tb from the area.\n\nAs Tb had been found in 6 possums and one ferret, further surveillance work was needed to determine the extent of the infection in local wildlife.\n\nThe ferret survey, undertaken by a TB free contractor, was expected to be finished by the end of this month [May 2016].\n\nFerrets scavenged Tb-infected possums and could become infected with the disease, which made them \"extremely important'' indicators of whether Tb was present in an area. Trapping was being used for the survey, and carcasses would be sent for postmortem examination.\n\nFurther possum control and surveys would be done during this year and next year [2016-17].\n\nThe infected herds were subject to an ongoing intensive Tb testing programme until they were free of the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The situation with possums in New Zealand is similar to the situation with badgers in the UK. These animals are resident reservoirs of TB.\n\nAs New Zealand seeks to control the TB population, looking at the prevalence and spread through other susceptible populations may be a good approach to understanding how far the disease has spread in certain areas. It may provide a tool to predict which farms of bovines may soon be seen suffering from the disease.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (TB) is a slow, insidious disease that can have a nasty grip on a herd before it is ever located.\n\nTuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacterial aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\n\nAlthough the disease (TB) is transmissible from animals to humans, the risk of infection is likely to be small. The responsible bacterium, _Mycobacterium bovis_, can be transmitted by close contact with the animals. Practically speaking, the producer and family, the veterinarian, the cattle dealers and slaughterhouse workers are most at risk. A consumer can become infected just by drinking raw milk or eating cheese made from raw milk. Most milk is pasteurized (heated) in a process that the bacteria will not survive.\n\nAlso, most places have a meat inspection process to prevent diseased or suspect diseased animals from entering the human food chain.\n\nUsing possums and ferrets to understand disease dissemination seems reasonable, but the deer component seems a more complicated factor. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - New Zealand 20151205.3843019\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway (02): ex Canada, comment 20150831.3614443\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex Canada, RFI 20150829.3610821\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium (02): (LI) update 20150819.3587763\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium: (LI) 20150808.3566504\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine 20150725.3534951\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) dairy cows 20150426.3323167\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine 20150127.3124201\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX) dairy cattle 20150115.3093307\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Norway: ex UK, susp, RFI 20140530.2508847\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (MI) 20140413.2400796\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: bovine spread, feline 20140410.2395905\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): tuberculin shortage 20140330.2367001\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-05-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4233252", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4233252", "date": "2016-05-02 19:24:10", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND: CATTLE, DEER, POSSUMS\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 2 May 2016\nSource: NZ Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/the-country/news/article.cfm?c_id=16&objectid=11632206\n\n\nA ferret survey is being undertaken in the Mt Cargill area, near Dunedin, after last year's [2015] bovine Tb outbreak.\n\nFour herds of cattle and deer were identified as infected with Tb. In a recent update, TB free southern South Island programme manager Brent Rohloff said work had been progressing well.\n\nOSPRI [Operational Solutions for Primary Industries] was using a combination of herd Tb testing, controls on animal movement for infected herds, and survey and control of wild animals to eradicate Tb from the area.\n\nAs Tb had been found in 6 possums and one ferret, further surveillance work was needed to determine the extent of the infection in local wildlife.\n\nThe ferret survey, undertaken by a TB free contractor, was expected to be finished by the end of this month [May 2016].\n\nFerrets scavenged Tb-infected possums and could become infected with the disease, which made them \"extremely important'' indicators of whether Tb was present in an area. Trapping was being used for the survey, and carcasses would be sent for postmortem examination.\n\nFurther possum control and surveys would be done during this year and next year [2016-17].\n\nThe infected herds were subject to an ongoing intensive Tb testing programme until they were free of the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The situation with possums in New Zealand is similar to the situation with badgers in the UK. New Zealand: cattle, deer, possums", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4197692", "date": "2016-05-02 19:24:10", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND: CATTLE, DEER, POSSUMS\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 2 May 2016\nSource: NZ Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.nzherald.co.nz/the-country/news/article.cfm?c_id=16&objectid=11632206\n\n\nA ferret survey is being undertaken in the Mt Cargill area, near Dunedin, after last year's [2015] bovine Tb outbreak.\n\nFour herds of cattle and deer were identified as infected with Tb. In a recent update, TB free southern South Island programme manager Brent Rohloff said work had been progressing well.\n\nOSPRI [Operational Solutions for Primary Industries] was using a combination of herd Tb testing, controls on animal movement for infected herds, and survey and control of wild animals to eradicate Tb from the area.\n\nAs Tb had been found in 6 possums and one ferret, further surveillance work was needed to determine the extent of the infection in local wildlife.\n\nThe ferret survey, undertaken by a TB free contractor, was expected to be finished by the end of this month [May 2016].\n\nFerrets scavenged Tb-infected possums and could become infected with the disease, which made them \"extremely important'' indicators of whether Tb was present in an area. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacterial aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone.
