USA (02): (IN, PA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4197585", "date": "2016-03-03 10:28:40", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, MDR - PAPUA NEW GUINEA: (WESTERN PROVINCE)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Feb 2016\nSource: EMTV News [edited]\nhttp://www.emtv.com.pg/article.aspx?slug=TB-Cases-Increase&subcategory=Top-Stories\n\n\nExtra-pulmonary cases of tuberculosis have been detected in Daru, Western Province [Papua New Guinea]. According to Daru General Hospital Chief Executive Officer, Sister Orpah Tugo, 478 cases have been detected. \"The extra-pulmonary TB cases are [almost 3 times] the [number of] new pulmonary TB cases of 174. Total cases are 652, detected from October 2015 to January 2016,\" she said. The number of patients accessing treatment has increased to 227 and, according to the hospital's Chief Executive Officer, this is because of the preventative health awareness being carried out in the area. \"[The] number of patients diagnosed has increased to January 2016 and we have run out of bed space. Most patients are out in the community under the treatment support program,\" Sister Tugo said.\n\nThose diagnosed with multidrug resistance TB now stands at 161. Sister Tugo says it's expected that by 2018, there should be a decline on the TB epidemic in Daru, Western province.\n\n[Byline: Fabian Hakalits]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Papua New Guinea (PNG), with a population of over 7 million people, gained its independence from Australia in 1975 and is now a Commonwealth with Queen Elizabeth II as its Sovereign and Head of State (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea). It occupies the eastern half of the island of New Guinea and its offshore islands in Melanesia in the southwestern Pacific Ocean north of Australia.\n\nDaru, located on an island located near the mouth of the Fly River with a population of 13 000, is the capital of the Western Province of Papua New Guinea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daru). Daru is just north of Torres Strait and Far North Queensland, the northernmost part of the state of Queensland, Australia.\n\nThe Torres Strait Islands Treaty signed by Australia and PNG allows for free movement of people (without passports or visas) between the Torres Strait Islands and PNG for traditional activities. The Torres Strait Islanders, who are culturally akin to the coastal peoples of PNG, became citizens of Queensland, Australia in 1967 with full access to health and social services and freedom to travel and work in Australia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torres_Strait_Islanders). Many thousands of Torres Strait Islanders are said to live in Queensland today and patients from PNG with MDR TB have migrated across the border into Far North Queensland (Tuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289).\n\nIn a prior ProMED-mail post (Tuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545) we reported that, of 60 patients living in the Western Province of PNG who sought treatment between 2000 and 2006 in the Torres Strait Islands because of limited access to health care in the Western Province of PNG, 15 (25 percent) were found to have multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) (https://www.mja.com.au/journal/2008/188/3/evidence-primary-transmission-multidrug-resistant-tuberculosis-western-province).\n\nThe prior ProMED-mail post also reported that 39 percent of MDR TB in the Western Province was said to be primary, that is, the result of person-to-person transmission, rather than a consequence of treatment with an inappropriate drug regimen that is not effective at eliminating the particular strain of TB causing the infection and that Daru was the epicenter of primary MDR TB. Primary drug resistance indicates a need for better TB control to interrupt transmission, whereas acquired drug resistance indicates a need for better patient management to prevent the evolution of antimicrobial resistance. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14673.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824\nTuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289\n2012\n----\nTuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea 20121020.1355085\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-02-29 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Commonwealth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Melanesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "XDR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daru , Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4155248", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4155248", "date": "2016-03-03 10:28:40", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, MDR - PAPUA NEW GUINEA: (WESTERN PROVINCE)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Feb 2016\nSource: EMTV News [edited]\nhttp://www.emtv.com.pg/article.aspx?slug=TB-Cases-Increase&subcategory=Top-Stories\n\n\nExtra-pulmonary cases of tuberculosis have been detected in Daru, Western Province [Papua New Guinea]. According to Daru General Hospital Chief Executive Officer, Sister Orpah Tugo, 478 cases have been detected. \"The extra-pulmonary TB cases are [almost 3 times] the [number of] new pulmonary TB cases of 174. Total cases are 652, detected from October 2015 to January 2016,\" she said. The number of patients accessing treatment has increased to 227 and, according to the hospital's Chief Executive Officer, this is because of the preventative health awareness being carried out in the area. \"[The] number of patients diagnosed has increased to January 2016 and we have run out of bed space. Most patients are out in the community under the treatment support program,\" Sister Tugo said.\n\nThose diagnosed with multidrug resistance TB now stands at 161. Sister Tugo says it's expected that by 2018, there should be a decline on the TB epidemic in Daru, Western province.\n\n[Byline: Fabian Hakalits]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Papua New Guinea (PNG), with a population of over 7 million people, gained its independence from Australia in 1975 and is now a Commonwealth with Queen Elizabeth II as its Sovereign and Head of State (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea). It occupies the eastern half of the island of New Guinea and its offshore islands in Melanesia in the southwestern Pacific Ocean north of Australia.\n\nDaru, located on an island located near the mouth of the Fly River with a population of 13 000, is the capital of the Western Province of Papua New Guinea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daru). Daru is just north of Torres Strait and Far North Queensland, the northernmost part of the state of Queensland, Australia.\n\nThe Torres Strait Islands Treaty signed by Australia and PNG allows for free movement of people (without passports or visas) between the Torres Strait Islands and PNG for traditional activities. The Torres Strait Islanders, who are culturally akin to the coastal peoples of PNG, became citizens of Queensland, Australia in 1967 with full access to health and social services and freedom to travel and work in Australia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torres_Strait_Islanders). Many thousands of Torres Strait Islanders are said to live in Queensland today and patients from PNG with MDR TB have migrated across the border into Far North Queensland (Tuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289).\n\nIn a prior ProMED-mail post (Tuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545) we reported that, of 60 patients living in the Western Province of PNG who sought treatment between 2000 and 2006 in the Torres Strait Islands because of limited access to health care in the Western Province of PNG, 15 (25 percent) were found to have multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) (https://www.mja.com.au/journal/2008/188/3/evidence-primary-transmission-multidrug-resistant-tuberculosis-western-province).\n\nThe prior ProMED-mail post also reported that 39 percent of MDR TB in the Western Province was said to be primary, that is, the result of person-to-person transmission, rather than a consequence of treatment with an inappropriate drug regimen that is not effective at eliminating the particular strain of TB causing the infection and that Daru was the epicenter of primary MDR TB. Primary drug resistance indicates a need for better TB control to interrupt transmission, whereas acquired drug resistance indicates a need for better patient management to prevent the evolution of antimicrobial resistance. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14673.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - Nepal: 1st report", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4131298", "date": "2016-03-03 10:28:40", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, MDR - PAPUA NEW GUINEA: (WESTERN PROVINCE)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Feb 2016\nSource: EMTV News [edited]\nhttp://www.emtv.com.pg/article.aspx?slug=TB-Cases-Increase&subcategory=Top-Stories\n\n\nExtra-pulmonary cases of tuberculosis have been detected in Daru, Western Province [Papua New Guinea]. According to Daru General Hospital Chief Executive Officer, Sister Orpah Tugo, 478 cases have been detected. \"The extra-pulmonary TB cases are [almost 3 times] the [number of] new pulmonary TB cases of 174. Total cases are 652, detected from October 2015 to January 2016,\" she said. The number of patients accessing treatment has increased to 227 and, according to the hospital's Chief Executive Officer, this is because of the preventative health awareness being carried out in the area. \"[The] number of patients diagnosed has increased to January 2016 and we have run out of bed space. Most patients are out in the community under the treatment support program,\" Sister Tugo said.\n\nThose diagnosed with multidrug resistance TB now stands at 161. Sister Tugo says it's expected that by 2018, there should be a decline on the TB epidemic in Daru, Western province.\n\n[Byline: Fabian Hakalits]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Papua New Guinea (PNG), with a population of over 7 million people, gained its independence from Australia in 1975 and is now a Commonwealth with Queen Elizabeth II as its Sovereign and Head of State (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea). It occupies the eastern half of the island of New Guinea and its offshore islands in Melanesia in the southwestern Pacific Ocean north of Australia.\n\nDaru, located on an island located near the mouth of the Fly River with a population of 13 000, is the capital of the Western Province of Papua New Guinea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daru). Daru is just north of Torres Strait and Far North Queensland, the northernmost part of the state of Queensland, Australia.\n\nThe Torres Strait Islands Treaty signed by Australia and PNG allows for free movement of people (without passports or visas) between the Torres Strait Islands and PNG for traditional activities. The Torres Strait Islanders, who are culturally akin to the coastal peoples of PNG, became citizens of Queensland, Australia in 1967 with full access to health and social services and freedom to travel and work in Australia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torres_Strait_Islanders). Many thousands of Torres Strait Islanders are said to live in Queensland today and patients from PNG with MDR TB have migrated across the border into Far North Queensland (Tuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289).\n\nIn a prior ProMED-mail post (Tuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545) we reported that, of 60 patients living in the Western Province of PNG who sought treatment between 2000 and 2006 in the Torres Strait Islands because of limited access to health care in the Western Province of PNG, 15 (25 percent) were found to have multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) (https://www.mja.com.au/journal/2008/188/3/evidence-primary-transmission-multidrug-resistant-tuberculosis-western-province).\n\nThe prior ProMED-mail post also reported that 39 percent of MDR TB in the Western Province was said to be primary, that is, the result of person-to-person transmission, rather than a consequence of treatment with an inappropriate drug regimen that is not effective at eliminating the particular strain of TB causing the infection and that Daru was the epicenter of primary MDR TB. Primary drug resistance indicates a need for better TB control to interrupt transmission, whereas acquired drug resistance indicates a need for better patient management to prevent the evolution of antimicrobial resistance. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14673.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - According to Daru General Hospital Chief Executive Officer, Sister Orpah Tugo, 478 cases have been detected. \"The extra-pulmonary TB cases are [almost 3 times] the [number of] new pulmonary TB cases of 174. Total cases are 652, detected from October 2015 to January 2016,\" she said. The number of patients accessing treatment has increased to 227 and, according to the hospital's Chief Executive Officer, this is because of the preventative health awareness being carried out in the area. \"[The] number of patients diagnosed has increased to January 2016 and we have run out of bed space. Most patients are out in the community under the treatment support program,\" Sister Tugo said.\n\nThose diagnosed with multidrug resistance TB now stands at 161. It occupies the eastern half of the island of New Guinea and its offshore islands in Melanesia in the southwestern Pacific Ocean north of Australia.\n\nDaru, located on an island located near the mouth of the Fly River with a population of 13 000, is the capital of the Western Province of Papua New Guinea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daru). Daru is just north of Torres Strait and Far North Queensland, the northernmost part of the state of Queensland, Australia.\n\nThe Torres Strait Islands Treaty signed by Australia and PNG allows for free movement of people (without passports or visas) between the Torres Strait Islands and PNG for traditional activities. The Torres Strait Islanders, who are culturally akin to the coastal peoples of PNG, became citizens of Queensland, Australia in 1967 with full access to health and social services and freedom to travel and work in Australia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torres_Strait_Islanders). Many thousands of Torres Strait Islanders are said to live in Queensland today and patients from PNG with MDR TB have migrated across the border into Far North Queensland (Tuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289).\n\nIn a prior ProMED-mail post (Tuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545) we reported that, of 60 patients living in the Western Province of PNG who sought treatment between 2000 and 2006 in the Torres Strait Islands because of limited access to health care in the Western Province of PNG, 15 (25 percent) were found to have multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) (https://www.mja.com.au/journal/2008/188/3/evidence-primary-transmission-multidrug-resistant-tuberculosis-western-province).\n\nThe prior ProMED-mail post also reported that 39 percent of MDR TB in the Western Province was said to be primary, that is, the result of person-to-person transmission, rather than a consequence of treatment with an inappropriate drug regimen that is not effective at eliminating the particular strain of TB causing the infection and that Daru was the epicenter of primary MDR TB. Primary drug resistance indicates a need for better TB control to interrupt transmission, whereas acquired drug resistance indicates a need for better patient management to prevent the evolution of antimicrobial resistance. - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824\nTuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289\n2012\n----\nTuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea 20121020.1355085\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-02-29 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Commonwealth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Melanesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "XDR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daru , Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4075832", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea (02): (WE) comment, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4075832", "date": "2016-03-03 10:28:40", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, MDR - PAPUA NEW GUINEA: (WESTERN PROVINCE)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Feb 2016\nSource: EMTV News [edited]\nhttp://www.emtv.com.pg/article.aspx?slug=TB-Cases-Increase&subcategory=Top-Stories\n\n\nExtra-pulmonary cases of tuberculosis have been detected in Daru, Western Province [Papua New Guinea]. According to Daru General Hospital Chief Executive Officer, Sister Orpah Tugo, 478 cases have been detected. \"The extra-pulmonary TB cases are [almost 3 times] the [number of] new pulmonary TB cases of 174. Total cases are 652, detected from October 2015 to January 2016,\" she said. The number of patients accessing treatment has increased to 227 and, according to the hospital's Chief Executive Officer, this is because of the preventative health awareness being carried out in the area. \"[The] number of patients diagnosed has increased to January 2016 and we have run out of bed space. Most patients are out in the community under the treatment support program,\" Sister Tugo said.\n\nThose diagnosed with multidrug resistance TB now stands at 161. Sister Tugo says it's expected that by 2018, there should be a decline on the TB epidemic in Daru, Western province.\n\n[Byline: Fabian Hakalits]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Papua New Guinea (PNG), with a population of over 7 million people, gained its independence from Australia in 1975 and is now a Commonwealth with Queen Elizabeth II as its Sovereign and Head of State (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea). It occupies the eastern half of the island of New Guinea and its offshore islands in Melanesia in the southwestern Pacific Ocean north of Australia.\n\nDaru, located on an island located near the mouth of the Fly River with a population of 13 000, is the capital of the Western Province of Papua New Guinea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daru). Daru is just north of Torres Strait and Far North Queensland, the northernmost part of the state of Queensland, Australia.\n\nThe Torres Strait Islands Treaty signed by Australia and PNG allows for free movement of people (without passports or visas) between the Torres Strait Islands and PNG for traditional activities. The Torres Strait Islanders, who are culturally akin to the coastal peoples of PNG, became citizens of Queensland, Australia in 1967 with full access to health and social services and freedom to travel and work in Australia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torres_Strait_Islanders). Many thousands of Torres Strait Islanders are said to live in Queensland today and patients from PNG with MDR TB have migrated across the border into Far North Queensland (Tuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289).\n\nIn a prior ProMED-mail post (Tuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545) we reported that, of 60 patients living in the Western Province of PNG who sought treatment between 2000 and 2006 in the Torres Strait Islands because of limited access to health care in the Western Province of PNG, 15 (25 percent) were found to have multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) (https://www.mja.com.au/journal/2008/188/3/evidence-primary-transmission-multidrug-resistant-tuberculosis-western-province).\n\nThe prior ProMED-mail post also reported that 39 percent of MDR TB in the Western Province was said to be primary, that is, the result of person-to-person transmission, rather than a consequence of treatment with an inappropriate drug regimen that is not effective at eliminating the particular strain of TB causing the infection and that Daru was the epicenter of primary MDR TB. Primary drug resistance indicates a need for better TB control to interrupt transmission, whereas acquired drug resistance indicates a need for better patient management to prevent the evolution of antimicrobial resistance. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14673.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824\nTuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289\n2012\n----\nTuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea 20121020.1355085\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-02-29 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Commonwealth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Melanesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "XDR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daru , Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4065389", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea: (WE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4065389", "date": "2016-03-03 10:28:40", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, MDR - PAPUA NEW GUINEA: (WESTERN PROVINCE)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 29 Feb 2016\nSource: EMTV News [edited]\nhttp://www.emtv.com.pg/article.aspx?slug=TB-Cases-Increase&subcategory=Top-Stories\n\n\nExtra-pulmonary cases of tuberculosis have been detected in Daru, Western Province [Papua New Guinea]. According to Daru General Hospital Chief Executive Officer, Sister Orpah Tugo, 478 cases have been detected. \"The extra-pulmonary TB cases are [almost 3 times] the [number of] new pulmonary TB cases of 174. Total cases are 652, detected from October 2015 to January 2016,\" she said. The number of patients accessing treatment has increased to 227 and, according to the hospital's Chief Executive Officer, this is because of the preventative health awareness being carried out in the area. \"[The] number of patients diagnosed has increased to January 2016 and we have run out of bed space. Most patients are out in the community under the treatment support program,\" Sister Tugo said.\n\nThose diagnosed with multidrug resistance TB now stands at 161. Sister Tugo says it's expected that by 2018, there should be a decline on the TB epidemic in Daru, Western province.\n\n[Byline: Fabian Hakalits]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Papua New Guinea (PNG), with a population of over 7 million people, gained its independence from Australia in 1975 and is now a Commonwealth with Queen Elizabeth II as its Sovereign and Head of State (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea). It occupies the eastern half of the island of New Guinea and its offshore islands in Melanesia in the southwestern Pacific Ocean north of Australia.\n\nDaru, located on an island located near the mouth of the Fly River with a population of 13 000, is the capital of the Western Province of Papua New Guinea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daru). Daru is just north of Torres Strait and Far North Queensland, the northernmost part of the state of Queensland, Australia.\n\nThe Torres Strait Islands Treaty signed by Australia and PNG allows for free movement of people (without passports or visas) between the Torres Strait Islands and PNG for traditional activities. The Torres Strait Islanders, who are culturally akin to the coastal peoples of PNG, became citizens of Queensland, Australia in 1967 with full access to health and social services and freedom to travel and work in Australia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torres_Strait_Islanders). Many thousands of Torres Strait Islanders are said to live in Queensland today and patients from PNG with MDR TB have migrated across the border into Far North Queensland (Tuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289).\n\nIn a prior ProMED-mail post (Tuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545) we reported that, of 60 patients living in the Western Province of PNG who sought treatment between 2000 and 2006 in the Torres Strait Islands because of limited access to health care in the Western Province of PNG, 15 (25 percent) were found to have multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) (https://www.mja.com.au/journal/2008/188/3/evidence-primary-transmission-multidrug-resistant-tuberculosis-western-province).\n\nThe prior ProMED-mail post also reported that 39 percent of MDR TB in the Western Province was said to be primary, that is, the result of person-to-person transmission, rather than a consequence of treatment with an inappropriate drug regimen that is not effective at eliminating the particular strain of TB causing the infection and that Daru was the epicenter of primary MDR TB. Primary drug resistance indicates a need for better TB control to interrupt transmission, whereas acquired drug resistance indicates a need for better patient management to prevent the evolution of antimicrobial resistance. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14673.]\nSee Also\n2015\n----\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20151120.3806545\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824\nTuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal 20130318.1591289\n2012\n----\nTuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea 20121020.1355085\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-02-29 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "1975-03-16 00:00:00", "1967-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Commonwealth", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Melanesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "XDR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Daru , Western Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3987571", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - India (02): (PB) MDR, more labs, more cases anticipated", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3987571", "date": "2015-12-05 22:51:31", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2015\nSource: Otago Daily Times [edited]\nhttp://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/365857/bovine-tb-found-three-mt-cargill-herds\n\n\nAn investigation is under way to find the cause of a \"disappointing\" bovine TB outbreak in 3 herds at Mt Cargill, on the outskirts of Dunedin.\n\nEarlier [in 2015], the number of infected cattle herds in Otago was officially zero, although there were 2 infected deer herds in Central Otago.\n\nYesterday [4 Dec 2015], Ospri South Island relationships manager Danny Templeman said all possible sources of the infectious disease were being explored and measures introduced to reduce the risk to cattle and deer herds in the area.\n\nSlaughter and routine TB testing identified the 3 herds, which were understood to comprise both cattle and deer.\n\nPossums and ferrets were the main carriers of the disease.\n\nAs well as investigating the source of the infection, Ospri was taking \"immediate action\" to manage and control the disease on the properties, Mr Templeman said.\n\nAn initial possum control operation was due to begin next week and the public were asked to heed warning signs if they were in the area. Possum carcasses would be recovered and autopsies performed to help determine the source of the disease. It was important to get the possum surveillance completed quickly to provide information to herd owners in the area.\n\nMr Templeman would not comment on the specific details of the herds. Further information on the herds was being gathered and on the disease status of wildlife surrounding the properties.\n\nSince the disease hit high levels in the 1990s, a huge effort has been put into controlling it, with about USD 1.2 billion spent over the past 15 years.\n\nIn 1998, there were 306 infected herds in Otago and 1700 nationally. The national infected herds figure earlier [in 2015] was 41.\n\nMr Templeman said the potential for TB infection was not unexpected, although the latest confirmation of the disease was \"certainly disappointing.\".\n\nOspri's TBfree programme would be doing its best to control the outbreak and make sure infected herd numbers were reduced. It was probably a good reminder the disease was still present and everyone needed to remain vigilant, he said.\n\nTBfree Otago committee chairman Ross Wilson, of Omakau, said an infected herd placed stress on the owner, with financial costs and disruptions to farm-management routines, often for a year or more while the disease was eliminated from the herd.\n\n\"It is never pleasant to find TB in your herd and this case is a reminder that the disease still poses a threat to farmed cattle and deer in the region,\" Mr Wilson said.\n\nThere was always the likelihood that it could be found and it was disappointing that it was in \"one little area,\" he said.\n\nWhere the risk of TB infection was particularly high, movement-control areas were in place to ensure certain conditions, such as pre-movement testing, were met before stock is moved.\n\nThe latest infected herds were found just outside a movement-control area, he said.\n\n[Byline: Sally Rae]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Indeed it is always sad for the owner, and even for those officials charged with regulating the disease.\n\nThe possum in New Zealand is a resident carrier of the disease, as is the badger in the UK.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (TB) is a slow insidious disease that can have a nasty grip on a herd before it is ever located.\n\nTuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\n\nAlthough the disease (TB) is transmissible from animals to humans, the risk of infection is likely small. The responsible bacterium, _Mycobacterium bovis_, can be transmitted by close contact with the animals. Practically speaking, the producer and family, the veterinarian, the cattle dealers and slaughterhouse workers are most at risk. A consumer can become infected just by drinking raw milk or eating cheese made from raw milk. Most milk is pasteurized (heated) in a process that the bacteria will not survive.\n\nAlso most places have a meat inspection process to prevent diseased or suspect diseased animals from entering the human food chain.\n\nThe investigation will likely involve tracing where animals have come from to be in the herd, or where animals may have gone if any have been sold, as well as testing the herd. This investigation likely has a wildlife component to it as well. Testing of the possums and the deer will also be involved. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway (02): ex Canada, comment 20150831.3614443\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex Canada, RFI 20150829.3610821\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium (02): (LI) update 20150819.3587763\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium: (LI) 20150808.3566504\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine 20150725.3534951\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) dairy cows 20150426.3323167\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine 20150127.3124201\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX) dairy cattle 20150115.3093307\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Fiji: (CE) 20141114.2954055\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland: call for cervid control 20141104.2928051\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (SM) 20140728.2641321\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): bovine, spread, research 20140705.2589984\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex UK, susp, RFI 20140530.2508847\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (MI) 20140413.2400796\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: bovine spread, feline 20140410.2395905\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): tuberculin shortage 20140330.2367001\nAnd others in the archives.\n.................................................sb/tg/pg/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1700-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2041-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otago", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3952031", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - India: (MH) XDR, more cases, more labs", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3952031", "date": "2015-12-05 22:51:31", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2015\nSource: Otago Daily Times [edited]\nhttp://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/365857/bovine-tb-found-three-mt-cargill-herds\n\n\nAn investigation is under way to find the cause of a \"disappointing\" bovine TB outbreak in 3 herds at Mt Cargill, on the outskirts of Dunedin.\n\nEarlier [in 2015], the number of infected cattle herds in Otago was officially zero, although there were 2 infected deer herds in Central Otago.\n\nYesterday [4 Dec 2015], Ospri South Island relationships manager Danny Templeman said all possible sources of the infectious disease were being explored and measures introduced to reduce the risk to cattle and deer herds in the area.\n\nSlaughter and routine TB testing identified the 3 herds, which were understood to comprise both cattle and deer.\n\nPossums and ferrets were the main carriers of the disease.\n\nAs well as investigating the source of the infection, Ospri was taking \"immediate action\" to manage and control the disease on the properties, Mr Templeman said.\n\nAn initial possum control operation was due to begin next week and the public were asked to heed warning signs if they were in the area. Possum carcasses would be recovered and autopsies performed to help determine the source of the disease. The national infected herds figure earlier [in 2015] was 41.\n\nMr Templeman said the potential for TB infection was not unexpected, although the latest confirmation of the disease was \"certainly disappointing.\".\n\nOspri's TBfree programme would be doing its best to control the outbreak and make sure infected herd numbers were reduced. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. Norway: ex UK, susp, RFI 20140530.2508847\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (MI) 20140413.2400796\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: bovine spread, feline 20140410.2395905\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): tuberculin shortage 20140330.2367001\nAnd others in the archives.\n.................................................sb/tg/pg/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1700-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2041-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otago", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3941739", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, elephant - USA (02): (OR) CDC update, 2012-2014, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3941739", "date": "2015-12-05 22:51:31", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2015\nSource: Otago Daily Times [edited]\nhttp://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/365857/bovine-tb-found-three-mt-cargill-herds\n\n\nAn investigation is under way to find the cause of a \"disappointing\" bovine TB outbreak in 3 herds at Mt Cargill, on the outskirts of Dunedin.\n\nEarlier [in 2015], the number of infected cattle herds in Otago was officially zero, although there were 2 infected deer herds in Central Otago.\n\nYesterday [4 Dec 2015], Ospri South Island relationships manager Danny Templeman said all possible sources of the infectious disease were being explored and measures introduced to reduce the risk to cattle and deer herds in the area.\n\nSlaughter and routine TB testing identified the 3 herds, which were understood to comprise both cattle and deer.\n\nPossums and ferrets were the main carriers of the disease.\n\nAs well as investigating the source of the infection, Ospri was taking \"immediate action\" to manage and control the disease on the properties, Mr Templeman said.\n\nAn initial possum control operation was due to begin next week and the public were asked to heed warning signs if they were in the area. Possum carcasses would be recovered and autopsies performed to help determine the source of the disease. It was important to get the possum surveillance completed quickly to provide information to herd owners in the area.\n\nMr Templeman would not comment on the specific details of the herds. Further information on the herds was being gathered and on the disease status of wildlife surrounding the properties.\n\nSince the disease hit high levels in the 1990s, a huge effort has been put into controlling it, with about USD 1.2 billion spent over the past 15 years.\n\nIn 1998, there were 306 infected herds in Otago and 1700 nationally. The national infected herds figure earlier [in 2015] was 41.\n\nMr Templeman said the potential for TB infection was not unexpected, although the latest confirmation of the disease was \"certainly disappointing.\".\n\nOspri's TBfree programme would be doing its best to control the outbreak and make sure infected herd numbers were reduced. It was probably a good reminder the disease was still present and everyone needed to remain vigilant, he said.\n\nTBfree Otago committee chairman Ross Wilson, of Omakau, said an infected herd placed stress on the owner, with financial costs and disruptions to farm-management routines, often for a year or more while the disease was eliminated from the herd.\n\n\"It is never pleasant to find TB in your herd and this case is a reminder that the disease still poses a threat to farmed cattle and deer in the region,\" Mr Wilson said.\n\nThere was always the likelihood that it could be found and it was disappointing that it was in \"one little area,\" he said.\n\nWhere the risk of TB infection was particularly high, movement-control areas were in place to ensure certain conditions, such as pre-movement testing, were met before stock is moved.\n\nThe latest infected herds were found just outside a movement-control area, he said.\n\n[Byline: Sally Rae]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Indeed it is always sad for the owner, and even for those officials charged with regulating the disease.\n\nThe possum in New Zealand is a resident carrier of the disease, as is the badger in the UK.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (TB) is a slow insidious disease that can have a nasty grip on a herd before it is ever located.\n\nTuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\n\nAlthough the disease (TB) is transmissible from animals to humans, the risk of infection is likely small. The responsible bacterium, _Mycobacterium bovis_, can be transmitted by close contact with the animals. Practically speaking, the producer and family, the veterinarian, the cattle dealers and slaughterhouse workers are most at risk. A consumer can become infected just by drinking raw milk or eating cheese made from raw milk. Most milk is pasteurized (heated) in a process that the bacteria will not survive.\n\nAlso most places have a meat inspection process to prevent diseased or suspect diseased animals from entering the human food chain.\n\nThe investigation will likely involve tracing where animals have come from to be in the herd, or where animals may have gone if any have been sold, as well as testing the herd. This investigation likely has a wildlife component to it as well. Testing of the possums and the deer will also be involved. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway (02): ex Canada, comment 20150831.3614443\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex Canada, RFI 20150829.3610821\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium (02): (LI) update 20150819.3587763\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium: (LI) 20150808.3566504\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine 20150725.3534951\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) dairy cows 20150426.3323167\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine 20150127.3124201\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX) dairy cattle 20150115.3093307\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Fiji: (CE) 20141114.2954055\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland: call for cervid control 20141104.2928051\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (SM) 20140728.2641321\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): bovine, spread, research 20140705.2589984\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex UK, susp, RFI 20140530.2508847\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (MI) 20140413.2400796\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: bovine spread, feline 20140410.2395905\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): tuberculin shortage 20140330.2367001\nAnd others in the archives.\n.................................................sb/tg/pg/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1700-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2041-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otago", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3924828", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, elephant - USA: (OR) CDC update, 2012-2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3924828", "date": "2015-12-05 22:51:31", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2015\nSource: Otago Daily Times [edited]\nhttp://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/365857/bovine-tb-found-three-mt-cargill-herds\n\n\nAn investigation is under way to find the cause of a \"disappointing\" bovine TB outbreak in 3 herds at Mt Cargill, on the outskirts of Dunedin.\n\nEarlier [in 2015], the number of infected cattle herds in Otago was officially zero, although there were 2 infected deer herds in Central Otago.\n\nYesterday [4 Dec 2015], Ospri South Island relationships manager Danny Templeman said all possible sources of the infectious disease were being explored and measures introduced to reduce the risk to cattle and deer herds in the area.\n\nSlaughter and routine TB testing identified the 3 herds, which were understood to comprise both cattle and deer.\n\nPossums and ferrets were the main carriers of the disease.\n\nAs well as investigating the source of the infection, Ospri was taking \"immediate action\" to manage and control the disease on the properties, Mr Templeman said.\n\nAn initial possum control operation was due to begin next week and the public were asked to heed warning signs if they were in the area. Possum carcasses would be recovered and autopsies performed to help determine the source of the disease. It was important to get the possum surveillance completed quickly to provide information to herd owners in the area.\n\nMr Templeman would not comment on the specific details of the herds. Further information on the herds was being gathered and on the disease status of wildlife surrounding the properties.\n\nSince the disease hit high levels in the 1990s, a huge effort has been put into controlling it, with about USD 1.2 billion spent over the past 15 years.\n\nIn 1998, there were 306 infected herds in Otago and 1700 nationally. The national infected herds figure earlier [in 2015] was 41.\n\nMr Templeman said the potential for TB infection was not unexpected, although the latest confirmation of the disease was \"certainly disappointing.\".\n\nOspri's TBfree programme would be doing its best to control the outbreak and make sure infected herd numbers were reduced. It was probably a good reminder the disease was still present and everyone needed to remain vigilant, he said.\n\nTBfree Otago committee chairman Ross Wilson, of Omakau, said an infected herd placed stress on the owner, with financial costs and disruptions to farm-management routines, often for a year or more while the disease was eliminated from the herd.\n\n\"It is never pleasant to find TB in your herd and this case is a reminder that the disease still poses a threat to farmed cattle and deer in the region,\" Mr Wilson said.\n\nThere was always the likelihood that it could be found and it was disappointing that it was in \"one little area,\" he said.\n\nWhere the risk of TB infection was particularly high, movement-control areas were in place to ensure certain conditions, such as pre-movement testing, were met before stock is moved.\n\nThe latest infected herds were found just outside a movement-control area, he said.\n\n[Byline: Sally Rae]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Indeed it is always sad for the owner, and even for those officials charged with regulating the disease.\n\nThe possum in New Zealand is a resident carrier of the disease, as is the badger in the UK.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (TB) is a slow insidious disease that can have a nasty grip on a herd before it is ever located.\n\nTuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\n\nAlthough the disease (TB) is transmissible from animals to humans, the risk of infection is likely small. The responsible bacterium, _Mycobacterium bovis_, can be transmitted by close contact with the animals. Practically speaking, the producer and family, the veterinarian, the cattle dealers and slaughterhouse workers are most at risk. A consumer can become infected just by drinking raw milk or eating cheese made from raw milk. Most milk is pasteurized (heated) in a process that the bacteria will not survive.\n\nAlso most places have a meat inspection process to prevent diseased or suspect diseased animals from entering the human food chain.\n\nThe investigation will likely involve tracing where animals have come from to be in the herd, or where animals may have gone if any have been sold, as well as testing the herd. Testing of the possums and the deer will also be involved. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway (02): ex Canada, comment 20150831.3614443\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. NEW ZEALAND\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2015\nSource: Otago Daily Times [edited]\nhttp://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/365857/bovine-tb-found-three-mt-cargill-herds\n\n\nAn investigation is under way to find the cause of a \"disappointing\" bovine TB outbreak in 3 herds at Mt Cargill, on the outskirts of Dunedin.\n\nEarlier [in 2015], the number of infected cattle herds in Otago was officially zero, although there were 2 infected deer herds in Central Otago.\n\nYesterday [4 Dec 2015], Ospri South Island relationships manager Danny Templeman said all possible sources of the infectious disease were being explored and measures introduced to reduce the risk to cattle and deer herds in the area.\n\nSlaughter and routine TB testing identified the 3 herds, which were understood to comprise both cattle and deer.\n\nPossums and ferrets were the main carriers of the disease.\n\nAs well as investigating the source of the infection, Ospri was taking \"immediate action\" to manage and control the disease on the properties, Mr Templeman said.\n\nAn initial possum control operation was due to begin next week and the public were asked to heed warning signs if they were in the area. Possum carcasses would be recovered and autopsies performed to help determine the source of the disease. It was important to get the possum surveillance completed quickly to provide information to herd owners in the area.\n\nMr Templeman would not comment on the specific details of the herds. Further information on the herds was being gathered and on the disease status of wildlife surrounding the properties.\n\nSince the disease hit high levels in the 1990s, a huge effort has been put into controlling it, with about USD 1.2 billion spent over the past 15 years.\n\nIn 1998, there were 306 infected herds in Otago and 1700 nationally. The national infected herds figure earlier [in 2015] was 41.\n\nMr Templeman said the potential for TB infection was not unexpected, although the latest confirmation of the disease was \"certainly disappointing.\".\n\nOspri's TBfree programme would be doing its best to control the outbreak and make sure infected herd numbers were reduced. It was probably a good reminder the disease was still present and everyone needed to remain vigilant, he said.\n\nTBfree Otago committee chairman Ross Wilson, of Omakau, said an infected herd placed stress on the owner, with financial costs and disruptions to farm-management routines, often for a year or more while the disease was eliminated from the herd.\n\n\"It is never pleasant to find TB in your herd and this case is a reminder that the disease still poses a threat to farmed cattle and deer in the region,\" Mr Wilson said.\n\nThere was always the likelihood that it could be found and it was disappointing that it was in \"one little area,\" he said.\n\nWhere the risk of TB infection was particularly high, movement-control areas were in place to ensure certain conditions, such as pre-movement testing, were met before stock is moved.\n\nThe latest infected herds were found just outside a movement-control area, he said.\n\n[Byline: Sally Rae]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Indeed it is always sad for the owner, and even for those officials charged with regulating the disease.\n\nThe possum in New Zealand is a resident carrier of the disease, as is the badger in the UK.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (TB) is a slow insidious disease that can have a nasty grip on a herd before it is ever located.\n\nTuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\n\nAlthough the disease (TB) is transmissible from animals to humans, the risk of infection is likely small. The responsible bacterium, _Mycobacterium bovis_, can be transmitted by close contact with the animals. Practically speaking, the producer and family, the veterinarian, the cattle dealers and slaughterhouse workers are most at risk. A consumer can become infected just by drinking raw milk or eating cheese made from raw milk. Most milk is pasteurized (heated) in a process that the bacteria will not survive.\n\nAlso most places have a meat inspection process to prevent diseased or suspect diseased animals from entering the human food chain.\n\nThe investigation will likely involve tracing where animals have come from to be in the herd, or where animals may have gone if any have been sold, as well as testing the herd. This investigation likely has a wildlife component to it as well. Testing of the possums and the deer will also be involved. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway (02): ex Canada, comment 20150831.3614443\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex Canada, RFI 20150829.3610821\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium (02): (LI) update 20150819.3587763\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium: (LI) 20150808.3566504\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine 20150725.3534951\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) dairy cows 20150426.3323167\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine 20150127.3124201\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX) dairy cattle 20150115.3093307\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Fiji: (CE) 20141114.2954055\nBovine tuberculosis - Ireland: call for cervid control 20141104.2928051\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (SM) 20140728.2641321\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): bovine, spread, research 20140705.2589984\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex UK, susp, RFI 20140530.2508847\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (MI) 20140413.2400796\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: bovine spread, feline 20140410.2395905\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): tuberculin shortage 20140330.2367001\nAnd others in the archives.\n.................................................sb/tg/pg/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1700-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2041-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otago", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3856460", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Leprosy & tuberculosis - India: (TN) case finding, management", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3856460", "date": "2015-12-05 22:51:31", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - NEW ZEALAND\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2015\nSource: Otago Daily Times [edited]\nhttp://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/365857/bovine-tb-found-three-mt-cargill-herds\n\n\nAn investigation is under way to find the cause of a \"disappointing\" bovine TB outbreak in 3 herds at Mt Cargill, on the outskirts of Dunedin.\n\nEarlier [in 2015], the number of infected cattle herds in Otago was officially zero, although there were 2 infected deer herds in Central Otago.\n\nYesterday [4 Dec 2015], Ospri South Island relationships manager Danny Templeman said all possible sources of the infectious disease were being explored and measures introduced to reduce the risk to cattle and deer herds in the area.\n\nSlaughter and routine TB testing identified the 3 herds, which were understood to comprise both cattle and deer.\n\nPossums and ferrets were the main carriers of the disease.\n\nAs well as investigating the source of the infection, Ospri was taking \"immediate action\" to manage and control the disease on the properties, Mr Templeman said.\n\nAn initial possum control operation was due to begin next week and the public were asked to heed warning signs if they were in the area. Possum carcasses would be recovered and autopsies performed to help determine the source of the disease. It was important to get the possum surveillance completed quickly to provide information to herd owners in the area.\n\nMr Templeman would not comment on the specific details of the herds. Further information on the herds was being gathered and on the disease status of wildlife surrounding the properties.\n\nSince the disease hit high levels in the 1990s, a huge effort has been put into controlling it, with about USD 1.2 billion spent over the past 15 years.\n\nIn 1998, there were 306 infected herds in Otago and 1700 nationally. The national infected herds figure earlier [in 2015] was 41.\n\nMr Templeman said the potential for TB infection was not unexpected, although the latest confirmation of the disease was \"certainly disappointing.\".\n\nOspri's TBfree programme would be doing its best to control the outbreak and make sure infected herd numbers were reduced. It was probably a good reminder the disease was still present and everyone needed to remain vigilant, he said.\n\nTBfree Otago committee chairman Ross Wilson, of Omakau, said an infected herd placed stress on the owner, with financial costs and disruptions to farm-management routines, often for a year or more while the disease was eliminated from the herd.\n\n\"It is never pleasant to find TB in your herd and this case is a reminder that the disease still poses a threat to farmed cattle and deer in the region,\" Mr Wilson said.\n\nThere was always the likelihood that it could be found and it was disappointing that it was in \"one little area,\" he said.\n\nWhere the risk of TB infection was particularly high, movement-control areas were in place to ensure certain conditions, such as pre-movement testing, were met before stock is moved.\n\nThe latest infected herds were found just outside a movement-control area, he said.\n\n[Byline: Sally Rae]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Indeed it is always sad for the owner, and even for those officials charged with regulating the disease.\n\nThe possum in New Zealand is a resident carrier of the disease, as is the badger in the UK.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (TB) is a slow insidious disease that can have a nasty grip on a herd before it is ever located.\n\nTuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease of both animals and humans. It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. In the early stages of TB, clinical signs are not visible. In later stages, clinical signs may include: emaciation, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, low-grade fever, and pneumonia with a chronic, moist cough. Lymph node enlargement may also be present.\n\nAlthough the disease (TB) is transmissible from animals to humans, the risk of infection is likely small. The responsible bacterium, _Mycobacterium bovis_, can be transmitted by close contact with the animals. Practically speaking, the producer and family, the veterinarian, the cattle dealers and slaughterhouse workers are most at risk. A consumer can become infected just by drinking raw milk or eating cheese made from raw milk. Most milk is pasteurized (heated) in a process that the bacteria will not survive.\n\nAlso most places have a meat inspection process to prevent diseased or suspect diseased animals from entering the human food chain.\n\nThe investigation will likely involve tracing where animals have come from to be in the herd, or where animals may have gone if any have been sold, as well as testing the herd. This investigation likely has a wildlife component to it as well. Testing of the possums and the deer will also be involved. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/164.]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway (02): ex Canada, comment 20150831.3614443\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex Canada, RFI 20150829.3610821\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium (02): (LI) update 20150819.3587763\nBovine tuberculosis - Belgium: (LI) 20150808.3566504\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine 20150725.3534951\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) dairy cows 20150426.3323167\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine 20150127.3124201\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX) dairy cattle 20150115.3093307\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Norway: ex UK, susp, RFI 20140530.2508847\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (MI) 20140413.2400796\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: bovine spread, feline 20140410.2395905\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): tuberculin shortage 20140330.2367001\nAnd others in the archives.\n.................................................sb/tg/pg/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1700-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2041-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Otago", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3843019", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - It is caused by 3 specific types of bacteria that are part of the _Mycobacterium_ group: _M. bovis_, _M. avium_, and _M. tuberculosis_. Bovine TB, caused by _M. bovis_, can be transmitted from livestock to humans and other animals.\n\nTB can be passed to a herd by infected cattle, cervids, swine, and humans. It is spread through the inhalation of TB bacteria aerosols, through feed or watering sites contaminated with saliva and other discharges, or by drinking raw, unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The risk of exposure is greatest in enclosed areas, such as barns with poor ventilation.\n\nTB is difficult to diagnose with clinical signs alone. Papua New Guinea", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3806545", "date": "2015-08-29 19:17:44", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, ALPACA - NORWAY: ex CANADA, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Aug 2015\nSource: The Sheep Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thesheepsite.com/news/1393/alpacas-test-positive-for-bovine-tb-in-norway/\n\n\n2 alpacas imported from Canada into Norway have tested positive for bovine tuberculosis (bTB).\n\nAntibodies against bovine tuberculosis were found in 2 alpacas, which are currently in solitary confinement on a farm in Hedmark. The 2 positive animals were imported from Canada along with 19 other alpacas in summer.\n\nCamelids imported to Norway are tested for a number of animal diseases of which Norway is free, and the animals are kept isolated from other animals for half a year while testing is in progress.\n\nBlood samples from the alpacas must be positive in 2 different serological methods performed by the Animal and Plant Health Agency as well as other tests before there is a strong suspicion of bovine tuberculosis.\n\nBovine tuberculosis is prevalent in many parts of the world, but as a result of testing cattle, it has been possible to limit the spread.\n\nThe disease can infect a variety of animal species and the authorities are therefore acting to prevent the introduction of this disease into Norway. The last time bovine tuberculosis was detected in Norway was in 1986.\n\nThe alpacas will be subjected to further tests before decisions are taken on what to do with the animals.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The last occurrence of _Bov. tuberculosis_ (bTB) in Norway dates back to 1986. In Canada, the last case was reported in Manitoba province during May 2014.\n\nThe 1st general test of all areas of Canada for bTB was complete by 1961 when the national prevalence was reduced from over 4 percent in 1923 to approximately 0.1 percent. The classification of provinces/areas based on their TB status has been an effective approach in the latter stages of Canada's eradication effort. In 2009, bTB, carried by wild elk, was reported to increasingly threaten Manitoba cattle herds, causing farmers to call for a cull of the elk (see ProMED-mail post 20091023.3641).\n\nInformation on the tests which the Canadian-sourced alpacas underwent prior to their export to Norway will be helpful. - Mod.AS\n\nA ProMED-mail map showing Canada is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12; and Hedmark county, Norway, at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34770.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - India (05): MDR, children", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3803835", "date": "2015-08-29 19:17:44", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, ALPACA - NORWAY: ex CANADA, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Aug 2015\nSource: The Sheep Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thesheepsite.com/news/1393/alpacas-test-positive-for-bovine-tb-in-norway/\n\n\n2 alpacas imported from Canada into Norway have tested positive for bovine tuberculosis (bTB).\n\nAntibodies against bovine tuberculosis were found in 2 alpacas, which are currently in solitary confinement on a farm in Hedmark. The 2 positive animals were imported from Canada along with 19 other alpacas in summer.\n\nCamelids imported to Norway are tested for a number of animal diseases of which Norway is free, and the animals are kept isolated from other animals for half a year while testing is in progress.\n\nBlood samples from the alpacas must be positive in 2 different serological methods performed by the Animal and Plant Health Agency as well as other tests before there is a strong suspicion of bovine tuberculosis.\n\nBovine tuberculosis is prevalent in many parts of the world, but as a result of testing cattle, it has been possible to limit the spread.\n\nThe disease can infect a variety of animal species and the authorities are therefore acting to prevent the introduction of this disease into Norway. The last time bovine tuberculosis was detected in Norway was in 1986.\n\nThe alpacas will be subjected to further tests before decisions are taken on what to do with the animals.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The last occurrence of _Bov. tuberculosis_ (bTB) in Norway dates back to 1986. In Canada, the last case was reported in Manitoba province during May 2014.\n\nThe 1st general test of all areas of Canada for bTB was complete by 1961 when the national prevalence was reduced from over 4 percent in 1923 to approximately 0.1 percent. The classification of provinces/areas based on their TB status has been an effective approach in the latter stages of Canada's eradication effort. In 2009, bTB, carried by wild elk, was reported to increasingly threaten Manitoba cattle herds, causing farmers to call for a cull of the elk (see ProMED-mail post 20091023.3641).\n\nInformation on the tests which the Canadian-sourced alpacas underwent prior to their export to Norway will be helpful. -
