USA ex Canada 19980415.0694\n.................................................sb/arn/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1986-03-16 00:00:00", "1986-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-05-16 00:00:00", "1961-03-16 00:00:00", "1923-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hedmark county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hedmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3802924", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - Kenya: MDR, increasing incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3802924", "date": "2015-08-29 19:17:44", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, ALPACA - NORWAY: ex CANADA, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Aug 2015\nSource: The Sheep Site [edited]\nhttp://www.thesheepsite.com/news/1393/alpacas-test-positive-for-bovine-tb-in-norway/\n\n\n2 alpacas imported from Canada into Norway have tested positive for bovine tuberculosis (bTB).\n\nAntibodies against bovine tuberculosis were found in 2 alpacas, which are currently in solitary confinement on a farm in Hedmark. The 2 positive animals were imported from Canada along with 19 other alpacas in summer.\n\nCamelids imported to Norway are tested for a number of animal diseases of which Norway is free, and the animals are kept isolated from other animals for half a year while testing is in progress.\n\nBlood samples from the alpacas must be positive in 2 different serological methods performed by the Animal and Plant Health Agency as well as other tests before there is a strong suspicion of bovine tuberculosis.\n\nBovine tuberculosis is prevalent in many parts of the world, but as a result of testing cattle, it has been possible to limit the spread.\n\nThe disease can infect a variety of animal species and the authorities are therefore acting to prevent the introduction of this disease into Norway. The last time bovine tuberculosis was detected in Norway was in 1986.\n\nThe alpacas will be subjected to further tests before decisions are taken on what to do with the animals.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The last occurrence of _Bov. tuberculosis_ (bTB) in Norway dates back to 1986. In Canada, the last case was reported in Manitoba province during May 2014.\n\nThe 1st general test of all areas of Canada for bTB was complete by 1961 when the national prevalence was reduced from over 4 percent in 1923 to approximately 0.1 percent. The classification of provinces/areas based on their TB status has been an effective approach in the latter stages of Canada's eradication effort. In 2009, bTB, carried by wild elk, was reported to increasingly threaten Manitoba cattle herds, causing farmers to call for a cull of the elk (see ProMED-mail post 20091023.3641).\n\nInformation on the tests which the Canadian-sourced alpacas underwent prior to their export to Norway will be helpful. - Mod.AS\n\nA ProMED-mail map showing Canada is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12; and Hedmark county, Norway, at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34770.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - The 2 positive animals were imported from Canada along with 19 other alpacas in summer.\n\nCamelids imported to Norway are tested for a number of animal diseases of which Norway is free, and the animals are kept isolated from other animals for half a year while testing is in progress.\n\nBlood samples from the alpacas must be positive in 2 different serological methods performed by the Animal and Plant Health Agency as well as other tests before there is a strong suspicion of bovine tuberculosis.\n\nBovine tuberculosis is prevalent in many parts of the world, but as a result of testing cattle, it has been possible to limit the spread.\n\nThe disease can infect a variety of animal species and the authorities are therefore acting to prevent the introduction of this disease into Norway. The last time bovine tuberculosis was detected in Norway was in 1986.\n\nThe alpacas will be subjected to further tests before decisions are taken on what to do with the animals.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The last occurrence of _Bov. tuberculosis_ (bTB) in Norway dates back to 1986. In Canada, the last case was reported in Manitoba province during May 2014.\n\nThe 1st general test of all areas of Canada for bTB was complete by 1961 when the national prevalence was reduced from over 4 percent in 1923 to approximately 0.1 percent. The classification of provinces/areas based on their TB status has been an effective approach in the latter stages of Canada's eradication effort. In 2009, bTB, carried by wild elk, was reported to increasingly threaten Manitoba cattle herds, causing farmers to call for a cull of the elk (see ProMED-mail post 20091023.3641).\n\nInformation on the tests which the Canadian-sourced alpacas underwent prior to their export to Norway will be helpful. - Mod.AS\n\nA ProMED-mail map showing Canada is available at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12; and Hedmark county, Norway, at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34770.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - Norway: ex UK, susp, RFI 20140530.2508847\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20110626.1959\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - Canada: (MB) cervid 20091023.3641\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (02): (BC, AB) 20071202.3884\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada: (BC, AB) 20071111.3664\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (MB) 20060925.2738\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (MN) 20060925.2738\n2004\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Man.) 20040324.0819\n2003\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (04) 20031208.3018\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (03) 20031207.3007\nTuberculosis, bovine, elk - Canada (Manitoba) (02) 20030724.1808\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) 20030206.0317\n1998\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, wood bison - Canada (WBNP)(02) 19980809.1561\nTuberculosis, bovine, wood bison - Canada (WBNP) 19980730.1441\nBovine tuberculosis, imported - USA ex Canada 19980415.0694\n.................................................sb/arn/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1986-03-16 00:00:00", "1986-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-05-16 00:00:00", "1961-03-16 00:00:00", "1923-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hedmark county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CANADA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hedmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3587763", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Belgium (02): (LI) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3587763", "date": "2015-03-19 22:02:05", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - EUROPE: REPORT, EUROPEAN CENTRE FOR DISEASE PREVENTION AND CONTROL, WHO, 2015\n********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 18 Mar 2015\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/1000-cases-a-day-as-resistant-tb-ravages-europe-319075.html\n\n\nEvery day 1000 people throughout Europe develop tuberculosis, with one expert claiming that multi-drug resistant TB continues to \"ravage\" the region.\n\nWith World TB Day falling next Tuesday -- 24 Mar 2015 -- new data from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDPC) and the World Health Organisation (WHO) for Europe shows that cases fell by 6 percent between 2012 and 2013. About 360 000 Europeans developed TB in 2013 but, even with an annual 6-percent decline, Europe will not be TB-free until the next century.\n\nThere has been a sustained decline in cases over the last decade but rates of multi-drug resistant TB remains at very high levels. WHO regional director for Europe, Zsuzsanna Jakab, said only 50 percent of an estimated 75 000 multi-drug resistant TB patients were found in 2013 and just half were successfully cured.\n\n\"Multi-drug resistant TB is still ravaging the European region, making it the most affected area of the entire world,\" he said. ECDC director, Marc Sprenger, said the EU countries were not all progressing in the same way and faced significant challenges in their TB control efforts. \"In most low-incident countries, rates are stable or going down only very slowly and the majority of patients are of foreign origin,\" he said.\n\nThere were 328 cases of TB reported in Ireland last year -- 7.1 per 100 000 -- the lowest notification rate recorded since surveillance began in 1998. The number of TB cases reported in Ireland has declined since the 1990s with 604 cases reported in 1992. The decline has been even more considerable since the early 1950s, when 7000 cases of TB were notified annually. Ireland is among the low-incidence countries in the EU and European Economic Area.\n\nHowever, there is concern that multi-drug resistant TB continues to be most prevalent in the 3 Baltic countries -- Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania.\n\nAlso, TB is one of the diseases that kills most people with HIV and this deadly combination is increasing in Europe. The prevalence of HIV among TB cases throughout Europe increased from 3.4 percent in 2008 to 7.8 percent in 2013.\n\nOf the 60 296 TB cases notified in 2012 where there was a treatment outcome, 44 318 (73.5 percent) were treated successfully and 4571 died (7.6 percent). Of 1386 multi-drug resistant cases notified in 2011 where there was a treatment outcome, 524 (37.8 percent) were treated successfully and 235 (17 percent) died.\n\nA national TB surveillance report from the Health Protection Surveillance Centre [HPSC] [Ireland] for [2014] found that 40 percent of the 328 cases it was made aware of last year were foreign born. Men accounted for 54 percent of all cases. The HPSC was notified of 2 cases of multi-drug resistant TB and both were foreign-born and had no previous history of TB. There were 11 deaths, with TB reported as the cause in 3 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to: Tuberculosis surveillance and monitoring in Europe 2015, published jointly by the WHO Regional Office for Europe and ECDC. Below is a summary; the full report is available at: http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/tuberculosis-surveillance-monitoring-Europe-2015.pdf.\n\n\"Executive Summary\n--------------------------\nThis is the 7th report launched jointly by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and the WHO Regional Office for Europe following on from reports under the EuroTB project, established in 1996.\n\nThe WHO European Region\n-----------------------------------\nDespite notable progress in the past decade, tuberculosis (TB) is still a public health concern in most of the countries within the WHO European Region.\n\nIn 2013, an estimated 360 000 incident TB cases (range 340 000-370 000) occurred in the WHO European Region, equivalent to an average of 39 cases (38-41) per 100 000 population. 85 percent of incident TB cases in the Region occur in the 18 high-priority countries. In 2013, the absolute number of incident TB cases fell by 20 000 compared to the previous year, corresponding to 5.6 percent decline. Since 2001, TB incidence has been falling at an average rate of 4.3 percent per year.\n\nIn 2013, there were an estimated 460 000 prevalent TB cases (range 350 000-590 000), which is equivalent to 51 (39-65) cases per 100 000 population. Considering the downward trend observed during last decade, it seems feasible that the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) target of a 50 percent reduction by 2015 against a baseline of 1990 will not be reached.\n\nThere were an estimated 38 000 TB deaths in 2013 among HIV-negative people in the European Region, equivalent to 4.1 deaths per 100 000 population (range 4.0-4.2). Yet, despite a constant decline in estimated mortality observed over the past 12 years, the MDG target will not be achieved in the Region.\n\nDuring the period 2004-2013, TB notification rates decreased by almost 20 percent, from 40.3 to 32.8 cases per 100 000 population. This trend reflects a true reduction in the spread of the disease, strongly influenced by the 17.7 percent decrease in notification rates throughout the Region's 18 high-priority countries (from 77.8 to 64.0 per 100 000 population).\n\nIn 2013, the 25-44 year age group was predominant (44 percent) among new TB cases registered in the European Region. The percentage of new TB patients under 15 years in the Region is around 4 percent.\n\nIn 2013, 17 096 (81.4 percent) TB cases with HIV co-infection were detected from approximately 21 000 cases in the European Region, based on an estimated prevalence of HIV infection among incident TB patients of 5.8 percent. Due to low HIV testing coverage (68 percent) the status was only known for 219 095 TB cases, 17 096 of which were determined to have HIV-co-infection. Moreover, there was a notable decrease in anti-retroviral therapy (ART) coverage among HIV-positive TB patients (from 62.3 percent in 2012 to 53.8 percent in 2013).\n\nOverall, 6.4 percent of the burden of new TB cases in the Region originated from prisons. In EU and EEA countries the proportion of TB cases detected in prisons was only 1.6 percent of all new TB cases detected in the country, while the corresponding proportion in non-EU countries was 7.4 percent. Overall, the notification rate of new TB cases in prisons within the WHO European Region was 893 per 100 000 population, indicating that the risk of developing TB in prisons was, on average, around 23 times higher than in the general population.\n\nOf an estimated 75 000 multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB cases in the European Region in 2013, 34 941 (46.6 percent) were detected. The prevalence of MDR among new pulmonary TB cases in the Region amounted to 16.9 percent and was 48.0 percent among previously treated cases. Information relating to second-line drug susceptibility testing (SLD DST) remains limited as only a few countries provided data, altogether accounting for 12 percent of all notified MDR TB cases. Coverage of SLD DST among the reporting countries was 56.4 percent. In total, 532 extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB cases were detected, equivalent to 12.7 percent XDR prevalence among MDR TB patients.\n\nCoverage of 2nd-line TB treatment continued to improve in 2013. In total, 46 710 TB patients were enrolled into MDR treatment, 45 147 of whom had confirmed MDR TB. In 2013, the proportion of patients starting MDR treatment out of the total notified cases of MDR TB was 116.7 percent, or 110.7 percent including rifampicin-resistant TB (RR TB). In some countries the number of patients enrolled exceeded the total notified because prevalent MDR cases detected in previous years were still enrolled in treatment.\n\nTreatment success among new and relapse TB cases was 75.6 percent. Among previously treated cases (excluding relapses) it was 57.1 percent. The treatment success rate in the MDR TB cohort was 46.0 percent, which is lower than in 2012.\n\nGiven all of the above, and the fact that the vast majority of the TB burden occurs in the 18 high-priority countries of the European Region (85 percent of TB incidence, 86 percent of prevalence, 90 percent of the mortality caused by TB, 90 percent of TB/HIV co-infections and 99.5 percent of the MDR TB), the main efforts to combat and prevent TB in the Region still need to be focused there.\n\nIn collaboration with national and international partners and civil society organisations, WHO Regional Office for Europe has been implementing the Consolidated Action Plan to Prevent and Combat Multidrug- and Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis, 2011-2015 at regional level and helping Member States to adopt evidence-based interventions in order to improve TB and M/XDR TB prevention and control. The WHO Regional Office for Europe has also established the European Green Light Committee and the European Laboratory Initiative to help countries develop and/or adjust their national plans in response to the M/ XDR-TB threat. Now that implementation of the Consolidated Action Plan is in its final year, and with the endorsement of the post-2015 global End TB Strategy by the 67th session of the World Health Assembly, Member States, WHO and partners are currently developing a new TB Action Plan for the WHO European Region, 2016-2020.\" - Mod.ML]\n\n[The Executive Summary ends with a section on European Union and European Economic Area countries. - Mod.JW]]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - Ukraine: anti-TB drug shortage, RFI 20141222.3047464\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR 20130818.1886543\nTuberculosis - France: (BD) school, Bejing strain 20130111.1493463\n2012\n---\nTuberculosis - UK: increasing drug resistance 20120709.1194280\nTuberculosis, MDR - worldwide: rates 20120206.1034331\n2011\n---\nTuberculosis - Ireland: (LN) prison, hospital 20111024.3165\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2010\n---\nTuberculosis - UK: resurgence 20101223.4522\n.................................................sb/ml/pg/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "4571-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lithuania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Member States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "non - The WHO Regional Office for Europe has also established the European Green Light Committee and the European Laboratory Initiative to help countries develop and/or adjust their national plans in response to the M/ XDR-TB threat. eu", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3534951", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (MI) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3534951", "date": "2015-03-19 22:02:05", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - EUROPE: REPORT, EUROPEAN CENTRE FOR DISEASE PREVENTION AND CONTROL, WHO, 2015\n********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 18 Mar 2015\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/1000-cases-a-day-as-resistant-tb-ravages-europe-319075.html\n\n\nEvery day 1000 people throughout Europe develop tuberculosis, with one expert claiming that multi-drug resistant TB continues to \"ravage\" the region.\n\nWith World TB Day falling next Tuesday -- 24 Mar 2015 -- new data from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDPC) and the World Health Organisation (WHO) for Europe shows that cases fell by 6 percent between 2012 and 2013. About 360 000 Europeans developed TB in 2013 but, even with an annual 6-percent decline, Europe will not be TB-free until the next century.\n\nThere has been a sustained decline in cases over the last decade but rates of multi-drug resistant TB remains at very high levels. WHO regional director for Europe, Zsuzsanna Jakab, said only 50 percent of an estimated 75 000 multi-drug resistant TB patients were found in 2013 and just half were successfully cured.\n\n\"Multi-drug resistant TB is still ravaging the European region, making it the most affected area of the entire world,\" he said. ECDC director, Marc Sprenger, said the EU countries were not all progressing in the same way and faced significant challenges in their TB control efforts. \"In most low-incident countries, rates are stable or going down only very slowly and the majority of patients are of foreign origin,\" he said.\n\nThere were 328 cases of TB reported in Ireland last year -- 7.1 per 100 000 -- the lowest notification rate recorded since surveillance began in 1998. The number of TB cases reported in Ireland has declined since the 1990s with 604 cases reported in 1992. The decline has been even more considerable since the early 1950s, when 7000 cases of TB were notified annually. Ireland is among the low-incidence countries in the EU and European Economic Area.\n\nHowever, there is concern that multi-drug resistant TB continues to be most prevalent in the 3 Baltic countries -- Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania.\n\nAlso, TB is one of the diseases that kills most people with HIV and this deadly combination is increasing in Europe. The prevalence of HIV among TB cases throughout Europe increased from 3.4 percent in 2008 to 7.8 percent in 2013.\n\nOf the 60 296 TB cases notified in 2012 where there was a treatment outcome, 44 318 (73.5 percent) were treated successfully and 4571 died (7.6 percent). Of 1386 multi-drug resistant cases notified in 2011 where there was a treatment outcome, 524 (37.8 percent) were treated successfully and 235 (17 percent) died.\n\nA national TB surveillance report from the Health Protection Surveillance Centre [HPSC] [Ireland] for [2014] found that 40 percent of the 328 cases it was made aware of last year were foreign born. Men accounted for 54 percent of all cases. The HPSC was notified of 2 cases of multi-drug resistant TB and both were foreign-born and had no previous history of TB. There were 11 deaths, with TB reported as the cause in 3 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to: Tuberculosis surveillance and monitoring in Europe 2015, published jointly by the WHO Regional Office for Europe and ECDC. Below is a summary; the full report is available at: http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/tuberculosis-surveillance-monitoring-Europe-2015.pdf.\n\n\"Executive Summary\n--------------------------\nThis is the 7th report launched jointly by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and the WHO Regional Office for Europe following on from reports under the EuroTB project, established in 1996.\n\nThe WHO European Region\n-----------------------------------\nDespite notable progress in the past decade, tuberculosis (TB) is still a public health concern in most of the countries within the WHO European Region.\n\nIn 2013, an estimated 360 000 incident TB cases (range 340 000-370 000) occurred in the WHO European Region, equivalent to an average of 39 cases (38-41) per 100 000 population. 85 percent of incident TB cases in the Region occur in the 18 high-priority countries. In 2013, the absolute number of incident TB cases fell by 20 000 compared to the previous year, corresponding to 5.6 percent decline. Since 2001, TB incidence has been falling at an average rate of 4.3 percent per year.\n\nIn 2013, there were an estimated 460 000 prevalent TB cases (range 350 000-590 000), which is equivalent to 51 (39-65) cases per 100 000 population. Considering the downward trend observed during last decade, it seems feasible that the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) target of a 50 percent reduction by 2015 against a baseline of 1990 will not be reached.\n\nThere were an estimated 38 000 TB deaths in 2013 among HIV-negative people in the European Region, equivalent to 4.1 deaths per 100 000 population (range 4.0-4.2). Yet, despite a constant decline in estimated mortality observed over the past 12 years, the MDG target will not be achieved in the Region.\n\nDuring the period 2004-2013, TB notification rates decreased by almost 20 percent, from 40.3 to 32.8 cases per 100 000 population. This trend reflects a true reduction in the spread of the disease, strongly influenced by the 17.7 percent decrease in notification rates throughout the Region's 18 high-priority countries (from 77.8 to 64.0 per 100 000 population).\n\nIn 2013, the 25-44 year age group was predominant (44 percent) among new TB cases registered in the European Region. The percentage of new TB patients under 15 years in the Region is around 4 percent.\n\nIn 2013, 17 096 (81.4 percent) TB cases with HIV co-infection were detected from approximately 21 000 cases in the European Region, based on an estimated prevalence of HIV infection among incident TB patients of 5.8 percent. Due to low HIV testing coverage (68 percent) the status was only known for 219 095 TB cases, 17 096 of which were determined to have HIV-co-infection. Moreover, there was a notable decrease in anti-retroviral therapy (ART) coverage among HIV-positive TB patients (from 62.3 percent in 2012 to 53.8 percent in 2013).\n\nOverall, 6.4 percent of the burden of new TB cases in the Region originated from prisons. In EU and EEA countries the proportion of TB cases detected in prisons was only 1.6 percent of all new TB cases detected in the country, while the corresponding proportion in non-EU countries was 7.4 percent. Overall, the notification rate of new TB cases in prisons within the WHO European Region was 893 per 100 000 population, indicating that the risk of developing TB in prisons was, on average, around 23 times higher than in the general population.\n\nOf an estimated 75 000 multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB cases in the European Region in 2013, 34 941 (46.6 percent) were detected. The prevalence of MDR among new pulmonary TB cases in the Region amounted to 16.9 percent and was 48.0 percent among previously treated cases. Information relating to second-line drug susceptibility testing (SLD DST) remains limited as only a few countries provided data, altogether accounting for 12 percent of all notified MDR TB cases. Coverage of SLD DST among the reporting countries was 56.4 percent. In total, 532 extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB cases were detected, equivalent to 12.7 percent XDR prevalence among MDR TB patients.\n\nCoverage of 2nd-line TB treatment continued to improve in 2013. In total, 46 710 TB patients were enrolled into MDR treatment, 45 147 of whom had confirmed MDR TB. In 2013, the proportion of patients starting MDR treatment out of the total notified cases of MDR TB was 116.7 percent, or 110.7 percent including rifampicin-resistant TB (RR TB). In some countries the number of patients enrolled exceeded the total notified because prevalent MDR cases detected in previous years were still enrolled in treatment.\n\nTreatment success among new and relapse TB cases was 75.6 percent. Among previously treated cases (excluding relapses) it was 57.1 percent. The treatment success rate in the MDR TB cohort was 46.0 percent, which is lower than in 2012.\n\nGiven all of the above, and the fact that the vast majority of the TB burden occurs in the 18 high-priority countries of the European Region (85 percent of TB incidence, 86 percent of prevalence, 90 percent of the mortality caused by TB, 90 percent of TB/HIV co-infections and 99.5 percent of the MDR TB), the main efforts to combat and prevent TB in the Region still need to be focused there.\n\nIn collaboration with national and international partners and civil society organisations, WHO Regional Office for Europe has been implementing the Consolidated Action Plan to Prevent and Combat Multidrug- and Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis, 2011-2015 at regional level and helping Member States to adopt evidence-based interventions in order to improve TB and M/XDR TB prevention and control. The WHO Regional Office for Europe has also established the European Green Light Committee and the European Laboratory Initiative to help countries develop and/or adjust their national plans in response to the M/ XDR-TB threat. Now that implementation of the Consolidated Action Plan is in its final year, and with the endorsement of the post-2015 global End TB Strategy by the 67th session of the World Health Assembly, Member States, WHO and partners are currently developing a new TB Action Plan for the WHO European Region, 2016-2020.\" - Mod.ML]\n\n[The Executive Summary ends with a section on European Union and European Economic Area countries. - Mod.JW]]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - Ukraine: anti-TB drug shortage, RFI 20141222.3047464\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - worldwide: rates 20120206.1034331\n2011\n---\nTuberculosis - Ireland: (LN) prison, hospital 20111024.3165\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2010\n---\nTuberculosis - UK: resurgence 20101223.4522\n.................................................sb/ml/pg/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "4571-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lithuania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Member States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "non - eu", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3502593", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - India (03): national TB control program assessed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3502593", "date": "2015-03-19 22:02:05", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - EUROPE: REPORT, EUROPEAN CENTRE FOR DISEASE PREVENTION AND CONTROL, WHO, 2015\n********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 18 Mar 2015\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/1000-cases-a-day-as-resistant-tb-ravages-europe-319075.html\n\n\nEvery day 1000 people throughout Europe develop tuberculosis, with one expert claiming that multi-drug resistant TB continues to \"ravage\" the region.\n\nWith World TB Day falling next Tuesday -- 24 Mar 2015 -- new data from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDPC) and the World Health Organisation (WHO) for Europe shows that cases fell by 6 percent between 2012 and 2013. About 360 000 Europeans developed TB in 2013 but, even with an annual 6-percent decline, Europe will not be TB-free until the next century.\n\nThere has been a sustained decline in cases over the last decade but rates of multi-drug resistant TB remains at very high levels. WHO regional director for Europe, Zsuzsanna Jakab, said only 50 percent of an estimated 75 000 multi-drug resistant TB patients were found in 2013 and just half were successfully cured.\n\n\"Multi-drug resistant TB is still ravaging the European region, making it the most affected area of the entire world,\" he said. ECDC director, Marc Sprenger, said the EU countries were not all progressing in the same way and faced significant challenges in their TB control efforts. \"In most low-incident countries, rates are stable or going down only very slowly and the majority of patients are of foreign origin,\" he said.\n\nThere were 328 cases of TB reported in Ireland last year -- 7.1 per 100 000 -- the lowest notification rate recorded since surveillance began in 1998. The number of TB cases reported in Ireland has declined since the 1990s with 604 cases reported in 1992. The decline has been even more considerable since the early 1950s, when 7000 cases of TB were notified annually. Ireland is among the low-incidence countries in the EU and European Economic Area.\n\nHowever, there is concern that multi-drug resistant TB continues to be most prevalent in the 3 Baltic countries -- Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania.\n\nAlso, TB is one of the diseases that kills most people with HIV and this deadly combination is increasing in Europe. The prevalence of HIV among TB cases throughout Europe increased from 3.4 percent in 2008 to 7.8 percent in 2013.\n\nOf the 60 296 TB cases notified in 2012 where there was a treatment outcome, 44 318 (73.5 percent) were treated successfully and 4571 died (7.6 percent). Of 1386 multi-drug resistant cases notified in 2011 where there was a treatment outcome, 524 (37.8 percent) were treated successfully and 235 (17 percent) died.\n\nA national TB surveillance report from the Health Protection Surveillance Centre [HPSC] [Ireland] for [2014] found that 40 percent of the 328 cases it was made aware of last year were foreign born. Men accounted for 54 percent of all cases. The HPSC was notified of 2 cases of multi-drug resistant TB and both were foreign-born and had no previous history of TB. There were 11 deaths, with TB reported as the cause in 3 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to: Tuberculosis surveillance and monitoring in Europe 2015, published jointly by the WHO Regional Office for Europe and ECDC. Below is a summary; the full report is available at: http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/tuberculosis-surveillance-monitoring-Europe-2015.pdf.\n\n\"Executive Summary\n--------------------------\nThis is the 7th report launched jointly by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and the WHO Regional Office for Europe following on from reports under the EuroTB project, established in 1996.\n\nThe WHO European Region\n-----------------------------------\nDespite notable progress in the past decade, tuberculosis (TB) is still a public health concern in most of the countries within the WHO European Region.\n\nIn 2013, an estimated 360 000 incident TB cases (range 340 000-370 000) occurred in the WHO European Region, equivalent to an average of 39 cases (38-41) per 100 000 population. 85 percent of incident TB cases in the Region occur in the 18 high-priority countries. In 2013, the absolute number of incident TB cases fell by 20 000 compared to the previous year, corresponding to 5.6 percent decline. Since 2001, TB incidence has been falling at an average rate of 4.3 percent per year.\n\nIn 2013, there were an estimated 460 000 prevalent TB cases (range 350 000-590 000), which is equivalent to 51 (39-65) cases per 100 000 population. Considering the downward trend observed during last decade, it seems feasible that the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) target of a 50 percent reduction by 2015 against a baseline of 1990 will not be reached.\n\nThere were an estimated 38 000 TB deaths in 2013 among HIV-negative people in the European Region, equivalent to 4.1 deaths per 100 000 population (range 4.0-4.2). Yet, despite a constant decline in estimated mortality observed over the past 12 years, the MDG target will not be achieved in the Region.\n\nDuring the period 2004-2013, TB notification rates decreased by almost 20 percent, from 40.3 to 32.8 cases per 100 000 population. This trend reflects a true reduction in the spread of the disease, strongly influenced by the 17.7 percent decrease in notification rates throughout the Region's 18 high-priority countries (from 77.8 to 64.0 per 100 000 population).\n\nIn 2013, the 25-44 year age group was predominant (44 percent) among new TB cases registered in the European Region. The percentage of new TB patients under 15 years in the Region is around 4 percent.\n\nIn 2013, 17 096 (81.4 percent) TB cases with HIV co-infection were detected from approximately 21 000 cases in the European Region, based on an estimated prevalence of HIV infection among incident TB patients of 5.8 percent. Due to low HIV testing coverage (68 percent) the status was only known for 219 095 TB cases, 17 096 of which were determined to have HIV-co-infection. Moreover, there was a notable decrease in anti-retroviral therapy (ART) coverage among HIV-positive TB patients (from 62.3 percent in 2012 to 53.8 percent in 2013).\n\nOverall, 6.4 percent of the burden of new TB cases in the Region originated from prisons. In EU and EEA countries the proportion of TB cases detected in prisons was only 1.6 percent of all new TB cases detected in the country, while the corresponding proportion in non-EU countries was 7.4 percent. Overall, the notification rate of new TB cases in prisons within the WHO European Region was 893 per 100 000 population, indicating that the risk of developing TB in prisons was, on average, around 23 times higher than in the general population.\n\nOf an estimated 75 000 multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB cases in the European Region in 2013, 34 941 (46.6 percent) were detected. The prevalence of MDR among new pulmonary TB cases in the Region amounted to 16.9 percent and was 48.0 percent among previously treated cases. Information relating to second-line drug susceptibility testing (SLD DST) remains limited as only a few countries provided data, altogether accounting for 12 percent of all notified MDR TB cases. Coverage of SLD DST among the reporting countries was 56.4 percent. In total, 532 extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB cases were detected, equivalent to 12.7 percent XDR prevalence among MDR TB patients.\n\nCoverage of 2nd-line TB treatment continued to improve in 2013. In total, 46 710 TB patients were enrolled into MDR treatment, 45 147 of whom had confirmed MDR TB. In 2013, the proportion of patients starting MDR treatment out of the total notified cases of MDR TB was 116.7 percent, or 110.7 percent including rifampicin-resistant TB (RR TB). In some countries the number of patients enrolled exceeded the total notified because prevalent MDR cases detected in previous years were still enrolled in treatment.\n\nTreatment success among new and relapse TB cases was 75.6 percent. Among previously treated cases (excluding relapses) it was 57.1 percent. The treatment success rate in the MDR TB cohort was 46.0 percent, which is lower than in 2012.\n\nGiven all of the above, and the fact that the vast majority of the TB burden occurs in the 18 high-priority countries of the European Region (85 percent of TB incidence, 86 percent of prevalence, 90 percent of the mortality caused by TB, 90 percent of TB/HIV co-infections and 99.5 percent of the MDR TB), the main efforts to combat and prevent TB in the Region still need to be focused there.\n\nIn collaboration with national and international partners and civil society organisations, WHO Regional Office for Europe has been implementing the Consolidated Action Plan to Prevent and Combat Multidrug- and Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis, 2011-2015 at regional level and helping Member States to adopt evidence-based interventions in order to improve TB and M/XDR TB prevention and control. The WHO Regional Office for Europe has also established the European Green Light Committee and the European Laboratory Initiative to help countries develop and/or adjust their national plans in response to the M/ XDR-TB threat. Now that implementation of the Consolidated Action Plan is in its final year, and with the endorsement of the post-2015 global End TB Strategy by the 67th session of the World Health Assembly, Member States, WHO and partners are currently developing a new TB Action Plan for the WHO European Region, 2016-2020.\" - Mod.ML]\n\n[The Executive Summary ends with a section on European Union and European Economic Area countries. - Mod.JW]]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - Ukraine: anti-TB drug shortage, RFI 20141222.3047464\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR 20130818.1886543\nTuberculosis - France: (BD) school, Bejing strain 20130111.1493463\n2012\n---\nTuberculosis - UK: increasing drug resistance 20120709.1194280\nTuberculosis, MDR - worldwide: rates 20120206.1034331\n2011\n---\nTuberculosis - Ireland: (LN) prison, hospital 20111024.3165\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2010\n---\nTuberculosis - UK: resurgence 20101223.4522\n.................................................sb/ml/pg/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "4571-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lithuania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Member States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "non - eu", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3408645", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - worldwide: children, isoniazid resistance", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3408645", "date": "2015-03-19 22:02:05", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - EUROPE: REPORT, EUROPEAN CENTRE FOR DISEASE PREVENTION AND CONTROL, WHO, 2015\n********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 18 Mar 2015\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/1000-cases-a-day-as-resistant-tb-ravages-europe-319075.html\n\n\nEvery day 1000 people throughout Europe develop tuberculosis, with one expert claiming that multi-drug resistant TB continues to \"ravage\" the region.\n\nWith World TB Day falling next Tuesday -- 24 Mar 2015 -- new data from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDPC) and the World Health Organisation (WHO) for Europe shows that cases fell by 6 percent between 2012 and 2013. About 360 000 Europeans developed TB in 2013 but, even with an annual 6-percent decline, Europe will not be TB-free until the next century.\n\nThere has been a sustained decline in cases over the last decade but rates of multi-drug resistant TB remains at very high levels. WHO regional director for Europe, Zsuzsanna Jakab, said only 50 percent of an estimated 75 000 multi-drug resistant TB patients were found in 2013 and just half were successfully cured.\n\n\"Multi-drug resistant TB is still ravaging the European region, making it the most affected area of the entire world,\" he said. ECDC director, Marc Sprenger, said the EU countries were not all progressing in the same way and faced significant challenges in their TB control efforts. \"In most low-incident countries, rates are stable or going down only very slowly and the majority of patients are of foreign origin,\" he said.\n\nThere were 328 cases of TB reported in Ireland last year -- 7.1 per 100 000 -- the lowest notification rate recorded since surveillance began in 1998. The number of TB cases reported in Ireland has declined since the 1990s with 604 cases reported in 1992. The decline has been even more considerable since the early 1950s, when 7000 cases of TB were notified annually. Ireland is among the low-incidence countries in the EU and European Economic Area.\n\nHowever, there is concern that multi-drug resistant TB continues to be most prevalent in the 3 Baltic countries -- Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania.\n\nAlso, TB is one of the diseases that kills most people with HIV and this deadly combination is increasing in Europe. The prevalence of HIV among TB cases throughout Europe increased from 3.4 percent in 2008 to 7.8 percent in 2013.\n\nOf the 60 296 TB cases notified in 2012 where there was a treatment outcome, 44 318 (73.5 percent) were treated successfully and 4571 died (7.6 percent). Of 1386 multi-drug resistant cases notified in 2011 where there was a treatment outcome, 524 (37.8 percent) were treated successfully and 235 (17 percent) died.\n\nA national TB surveillance report from the Health Protection Surveillance Centre [HPSC] [Ireland] for [2014] found that 40 percent of the 328 cases it was made aware of last year were foreign born. Men accounted for 54 percent of all cases. The HPSC was notified of 2 cases of multi-drug resistant TB and both were foreign-born and had no previous history of TB. There were 11 deaths, with TB reported as the cause in 3 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to: Tuberculosis surveillance and monitoring in Europe 2015, published jointly by the WHO Regional Office for Europe and ECDC. Below is a summary; the full report is available at: http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/tuberculosis-surveillance-monitoring-Europe-2015.pdf.\n\n\"Executive Summary\n--------------------------\nThis is the 7th report launched jointly by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and the WHO Regional Office for Europe following on from reports under the EuroTB project, established in 1996.\n\nThe WHO European Region\n-----------------------------------\nDespite notable progress in the past decade, tuberculosis (TB) is still a public health concern in most of the countries within the WHO European Region.\n\nIn 2013, an estimated 360 000 incident TB cases (range 340 000-370 000) occurred in the WHO European Region, equivalent to an average of 39 cases (38-41) per 100 000 population. 85 percent of incident TB cases in the Region occur in the 18 high-priority countries. In 2013, the absolute number of incident TB cases fell by 20 000 compared to the previous year, corresponding to 5.6 percent decline. Since 2001, TB incidence has been falling at an average rate of 4.3 percent per year.\n\nIn 2013, there were an estimated 460 000 prevalent TB cases (range 350 000-590 000), which is equivalent to 51 (39-65) cases per 100 000 population. Considering the downward trend observed during last decade, it seems feasible that the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) target of a 50 percent reduction by 2015 against a baseline of 1990 will not be reached.\n\nThere were an estimated 38 000 TB deaths in 2013 among HIV-negative people in the European Region, equivalent to 4.1 deaths per 100 000 population (range 4.0-4.2). Yet, despite a constant decline in estimated mortality observed over the past 12 years, the MDG target will not be achieved in the Region.\n\nDuring the period 2004-2013, TB notification rates decreased by almost 20 percent, from 40.3 to 32.8 cases per 100 000 population. This trend reflects a true reduction in the spread of the disease, strongly influenced by the 17.7 percent decrease in notification rates throughout the Region's 18 high-priority countries (from 77.8 to 64.0 per 100 000 population).\n\nIn 2013, the 25-44 year age group was predominant (44 percent) among new TB cases registered in the European Region. The percentage of new TB patients under 15 years in the Region is around 4 percent.\n\nIn 2013, 17 096 (81.4 percent) TB cases with HIV co-infection were detected from approximately 21 000 cases in the European Region, based on an estimated prevalence of HIV infection among incident TB patients of 5.8 percent. Due to low HIV testing coverage (68 percent) the status was only known for 219 095 TB cases, 17 096 of which were determined to have HIV-co-infection. Moreover, there was a notable decrease in anti-retroviral therapy (ART) coverage among HIV-positive TB patients (from 62.3 percent in 2012 to 53.8 percent in 2013).\n\nOverall, 6.4 percent of the burden of new TB cases in the Region originated from prisons. In EU and EEA countries the proportion of TB cases detected in prisons was only 1.6 percent of all new TB cases detected in the country, while the corresponding proportion in non-EU countries was 7.4 percent. Overall, the notification rate of new TB cases in prisons within the WHO European Region was 893 per 100 000 population, indicating that the risk of developing TB in prisons was, on average, around 23 times higher than in the general population.\n\nOf an estimated 75 000 multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB cases in the European Region in 2013, 34 941 (46.6 percent) were detected. The prevalence of MDR among new pulmonary TB cases in the Region amounted to 16.9 percent and was 48.0 percent among previously treated cases. Information relating to second-line drug susceptibility testing (SLD DST) remains limited as only a few countries provided data, altogether accounting for 12 percent of all notified MDR TB cases. Coverage of SLD DST among the reporting countries was 56.4 percent. In total, 532 extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB cases were detected, equivalent to 12.7 percent XDR prevalence among MDR TB patients.\n\nCoverage of 2nd-line TB treatment continued to improve in 2013. In total, 46 710 TB patients were enrolled into MDR treatment, 45 147 of whom had confirmed MDR TB. In 2013, the proportion of patients starting MDR treatment out of the total notified cases of MDR TB was 116.7 percent, or 110.7 percent including rifampicin-resistant TB (RR TB). In some countries the number of patients enrolled exceeded the total notified because prevalent MDR cases detected in previous years were still enrolled in treatment.\n\nTreatment success among new and relapse TB cases was 75.6 percent. Among previously treated cases (excluding relapses) it was 57.1 percent. The treatment success rate in the MDR TB cohort was 46.0 percent, which is lower than in 2012.\n\nGiven all of the above, and the fact that the vast majority of the TB burden occurs in the 18 high-priority countries of the European Region (85 percent of TB incidence, 86 percent of prevalence, 90 percent of the mortality caused by TB, 90 percent of TB/HIV co-infections and 99.5 percent of the MDR TB), the main efforts to combat and prevent TB in the Region still need to be focused there.\n\nIn collaboration with national and international partners and civil society organisations, WHO Regional Office for Europe has been implementing the Consolidated Action Plan to Prevent and Combat Multidrug- and Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis, 2011-2015 at regional level and helping Member States to adopt evidence-based interventions in order to improve TB and M/XDR TB prevention and control. The WHO Regional Office for Europe has also established the European Green Light Committee and the European Laboratory Initiative to help countries develop and/or adjust their national plans in response to the M/ XDR-TB threat. Now that implementation of the Consolidated Action Plan is in its final year, and with the endorsement of the post-2015 global End TB Strategy by the 67th session of the World Health Assembly, Member States, WHO and partners are currently developing a new TB Action Plan for the WHO European Region, 2016-2020.\" - Mod.ML]\n\n[The Executive Summary ends with a section on European Union and European Economic Area countries. - Mod.JW]]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - Ukraine: anti-TB drug shortage, RFI 20141222.3047464\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - worldwide: rates 20120206.1034331\n2011\n---\nTuberculosis - Ireland: (LN) prison, hospital 20111024.3165\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2010\n---\nTuberculosis - UK: resurgence 20101223.4522\n.................................................sb/ml/pg/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "4571-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lithuania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Member States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "non - EUROPE: REPORT, EUROPEAN CENTRE FOR DISEASE PREVENTION AND CONTROL, WHO, 2015\n********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 18 Mar 2015\nSource: Irish Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/1000-cases-a-day-as-resistant-tb-ravages-europe-319075.html\n\n\nEvery day 1000 people throughout Europe develop tuberculosis, with one expert claiming that multi-drug resistant TB continues to \"ravage\" the region.\n\nWith World TB Day falling next Tuesday -- 24 Mar 2015 -- new data from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDPC) and the World Health Organisation (WHO) for Europe shows that cases fell by 6 percent between 2012 and 2013. There were 11 deaths, with TB reported as the cause in 3 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above refers to: Tuberculosis surveillance and monitoring in Europe 2015, published jointly by the WHO Regional Office for Europe and ECDC. Below is a summary; the full report is available at: http://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications/Publications/tuberculosis-surveillance-monitoring-Europe-2015.pdf.\n\n\"Executive Summary\n--------------------------\nThis is the 7th report launched jointly by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and the WHO Regional Office for Europe following on from reports under the EuroTB project, established in 1996.\n\nThe WHO European Region\n-----------------------------------\nDespite notable progress in the past decade, tuberculosis (TB) is still a public health concern in most of the countries within the WHO European Region.\n\nIn 2013, an estimated 360 000 incident TB cases (range 340 000-370 000) occurred in the WHO European Region, equivalent to an average of 39 cases (38-41) per 100 000 population. 85 percent of incident TB cases in the Region occur in the 18 high-priority countries. In 2013, the absolute number of incident TB cases fell by 20 000 compared to the previous year, corresponding to 5.6 percent decline. Since 2001, TB incidence has been falling at an average rate of 4.3 percent per year.\n\nIn 2013, there were an estimated 460 000 prevalent TB cases (range 350 000-590 000), which is equivalent to 51 (39-65) cases per 100 000 population. Considering the downward trend observed during last decade, it seems feasible that the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) target of a 50 percent reduction by 2015 against a baseline of 1990 will not be reached.\n\nThere were an estimated 38 000 TB deaths in 2013 among HIV-negative people in the European Region, equivalent to 4.1 deaths per 100 000 population (range 4.0-4.2). Yet, despite a constant decline in estimated mortality observed over the past 12 years, the MDG target will not be achieved in the Region.\n\nDuring the period 2004-2013, TB notification rates decreased by almost 20 percent, from 40.3 to 32.8 cases per 100 000 population. This trend reflects a true reduction in the spread of the disease, strongly influenced by the 17.7 percent decrease in notification rates throughout the Region's 18 high-priority countries (from 77.8 to 64.0 per 100 000 population).\n\nIn 2013, the 25-44 year age group was predominant (44 percent) among new TB cases registered in the European Region. The percentage of new TB patients under 15 years in the Region is around 4 percent.\n\nIn 2013, 17 096 (81.4 percent) TB cases with HIV co-infection were detected from approximately 21 000 cases in the European Region, based on an estimated prevalence of HIV infection among incident TB patients of 5.8 percent. Due to low HIV testing coverage (68 percent) the status was only known for 219 095 TB cases, 17 096 of which were determined to have HIV-co-infection. Moreover, there was a notable decrease in anti-retroviral therapy (ART) coverage among HIV-positive TB patients (from 62.3 percent in 2012 to 53.8 percent in 2013).\n\nOverall, 6.4 percent of the burden of new TB cases in the Region originated from prisons. In EU and EEA countries the proportion of TB cases detected in prisons was only 1.6 percent of all new TB cases detected in the country, while the corresponding proportion in non-EU countries was 7.4 percent. Overall, the notification rate of new TB cases in prisons within the WHO European Region was 893 per 100 000 population, indicating that the risk of developing TB in prisons was, on average, around 23 times higher than in the general population.\n\nOf an estimated 75 000 multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB cases in the European Region in 2013, 34 941 (46.6 percent) were detected. The prevalence of MDR among new pulmonary TB cases in the Region amounted to 16.9 percent and was 48.0 percent among previously treated cases. Information relating to second-line drug susceptibility testing (SLD DST) remains limited as only a few countries provided data, altogether accounting for 12 percent of all notified MDR TB cases. Coverage of SLD DST among the reporting countries was 56.4 percent. In total, 532 extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB cases were detected, equivalent to 12.7 percent XDR prevalence among MDR TB patients.\n\nCoverage of 2nd-line TB treatment continued to improve in 2013. In total, 46 710 TB patients were enrolled into MDR treatment, 45 147 of whom had confirmed MDR TB. In 2013, the proportion of patients starting MDR treatment out of the total notified cases of MDR TB was 116.7 percent, or 110.7 percent including rifampicin-resistant TB (RR TB). In some countries the number of patients enrolled exceeded the total notified because prevalent MDR cases detected in previous years were still enrolled in treatment.\n\nTreatment success among new and relapse TB cases was 75.6 percent. Among previously treated cases (excluding relapses) it was 57.1 percent. The treatment success rate in the MDR TB cohort was 46.0 percent, which is lower than in 2012.\n\nGiven all of the above, and the fact that the vast majority of the TB burden occurs in the 18 high-priority countries of the European Region (85 percent of TB incidence, 86 percent of prevalence, 90 percent of the mortality caused by TB, 90 percent of TB/HIV co-infections and 99.5 percent of the MDR TB), the main efforts to combat and prevent TB in the Region still need to be focused there.\n\nIn collaboration with national and international partners and civil society organisations, WHO Regional Office for Europe has been implementing the Consolidated Action Plan to Prevent and Combat Multidrug- and Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis, 2011-2015 at regional level and helping Member States to adopt evidence-based interventions in order to improve TB and M/XDR TB prevention and control. The WHO Regional Office for Europe has also established the European Green Light Committee and the European Laboratory Initiative to help countries develop and/or adjust their national plans in response to the M/ XDR-TB threat. Now that implementation of the Consolidated Action Plan is in its final year, and with the endorsement of the post-2015 global End TB Strategy by the 67th session of the World Health Assembly, Member States, WHO and partners are currently developing a new TB Action Plan for the WHO European Region, 2016-2020.\" - Mod.ML]\n\n[The Executive Summary ends with a section on European Union and European Economic Area countries. - Mod.JW]]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nTuberculosis - Ukraine: anti-TB drug shortage, RFI 20141222.3047464\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - worldwide: rates 20120206.1034331\n2011\n---\nTuberculosis - Ireland: (LN) prison, hospital 20111024.3165\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2010\n---\nTuberculosis - UK: resurgence 20101223.4522\n.................................................sb/ml/pg/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "4571-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Estonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lithuania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Member States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "non - eu", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3124201", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3124201", "date": "2014-11-04 10:43:26", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - IRELAND: CALL FOR CERVID CONTROL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 1 Nov 2014\nSource: Wicklow People [edited]\nhttp://www.independent.ie/regionals/wicklowpeople/news/calls-for-deer-cull-in-wicklow-as-cases-of-bovine-tb-increase-30698191.html\n\n\nThe levels of bovine TB [tuberculosis] occurring across County Wicklow are having a devastating effect on the farming community, with many dairy and beef farmers suffering drastic losses in income when infected animals have to be put down.\n\nAccording to Aughrim-based farmer and President of Wicklow ICMSA [Irish Creamery Milk Suppliers Association] Shane O'Loughlin, 'TB is rife' in Wicklow at present.\n\n'At the moment we are looking at TB levels at 3.5 times the national average per 1000 population. This is a huge concern for farmers who have had herds devastated by the disease. We are not just hearing of 1 or 2 reactors in a herd but sometimes in the dozens,' said Shane.\n\nOnce a reactor is detected in a herd, it is removed and the remaining cattle must pass 2 tests at 60 and 120 days post reactor before they are deemed fit for sale.\n\n'You cannot sell stock without this clearance and during this time the farmer's income is gone or vastly diminished. They have no way of making an income and the bills keep coming in.'\n\nShane explained that, in the past, cattle to cattle and badger to cattle transfer of TB were the main causes for concern but today, rising levels of deer is the suspected reason for the increase.\n\n'I see deer tracks in my yard almost every morning. At our AGM [Annual General Meeting] we had farmers in Castletown, 2 miles [3.2 km] outside of Arklow, who saw deer on land where they never were before. We have no idea of the numbers of deer out there.'\n\nAs a result of the increasing bovine TB levels, Shane said that Wicklow farmers are seeking a deer cull to get the matter under control.\n\n'A cull is most definitely required and the farming community is getting very frustrated by the lack of progress. It's not good for the cattle or the deer. If the disease is rampant amongst the deer then they are dying a slow and painful death. We want to see a healthy, sustainable deer stock as well.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ has one of the widest host ranges of all the _M. tuberculosis_ complex (MTC) and can readily spill over into a variety of domestic and wild mammals, including humans.\n\nIt is surprising that the call for culling is only based on perceived deer abundance. Even if there are good estimates of deer population dynamics, a culling effort should at least be based on surveys that provide data on the prevalence in deer, a careful analysis of how much culling would be needed to have the expected result, and whether such efforts are feasible.\n\nSurveillance efforts in deer and other susceptible wildlife species can provide an early warning of risk of transmission to livestock and also to produce crucial data to better understand the eco-epidemiology of the disease.\n\nMaps of Ireland can be accessed at https://www.uni-due.de/IERC/Ireland_FullSize.JPG and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42391. - Mod.PMB]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) cervids 20140324.2352510\n2013\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06): (TX) cervid surveillance 20131217.2120834\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) bovine 20131201.2084248\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090711.2480\n.................................................sb/pmb/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Castletown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wicklow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aughrim", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3093307", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX) dairy cattle", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3093307", "date": "2014-11-04 10:43:26", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - IRELAND: CALL FOR CERVID CONTROL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 1 Nov 2014\nSource: Wicklow People [edited]\nhttp://www.independent.ie/regionals/wicklowpeople/news/calls-for-deer-cull-in-wicklow-as-cases-of-bovine-tb-increase-30698191.html\n\n\nThe levels of bovine TB [tuberculosis] occurring across County Wicklow are having a devastating effect on the farming community, with many dairy and beef farmers suffering drastic losses in income when infected animals have to be put down.\n\nAccording to Aughrim-based farmer and President of Wicklow ICMSA [Irish Creamery Milk Suppliers Association] Shane O'Loughlin, 'TB is rife' in Wicklow at present.\n\n'At the moment we are looking at TB levels at 3.5 times the national average per 1000 population. This is a huge concern for farmers who have had herds devastated by the disease. We are not just hearing of 1 or 2 reactors in a herd but sometimes in the dozens,' said Shane.\n\nOnce a reactor is detected in a herd, it is removed and the remaining cattle must pass 2 tests at 60 and 120 days post reactor before they are deemed fit for sale.\n\n'You cannot sell stock without this clearance and during this time the farmer's income is gone or vastly diminished. They have no way of making an income and the bills keep coming in.'\n\nShane explained that, in the past, cattle to cattle and badger to cattle transfer of TB were the main causes for concern but today, rising levels of deer is the suspected reason for the increase.\n\n'I see deer tracks in my yard almost every morning. At our AGM [Annual General Meeting] we had farmers in Castletown, 2 miles [3.2 km] outside of Arklow, who saw deer on land where they never were before. We have no idea of the numbers of deer out there.'\n\nAs a result of the increasing bovine TB levels, Shane said that Wicklow farmers are seeking a deer cull to get the matter under control.\n\n'A cull is most definitely required and the farming community is getting very frustrated by the lack of progress. It's not good for the cattle or the deer. If the disease is rampant amongst the deer then they are dying a slow and painful death. We want to see a healthy, sustainable deer stock as well.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ has one of the widest host ranges of all the _M. tuberculosis_ complex (MTC) and can readily spill over into a variety of domestic and wild mammals, including humans.\n\nIt is surprising that the call for culling is only based on perceived deer abundance. Even if there are good estimates of deer population dynamics, a culling effort should at least be based on surveys that provide data on the prevalence in deer, a careful analysis of how much culling would be needed to have the expected result, and whether such efforts are feasible.\n\nSurveillance efforts in deer and other susceptible wildlife species can provide an early warning of risk of transmission to livestock and also to produce crucial data to better understand the eco-epidemiology of the disease.\n\nMaps of Ireland can be accessed at https://www.uni-due.de/IERC/Ireland_FullSize.JPG and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42391. - India (02): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3077424", "date": "2014-11-04 10:43:26", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - IRELAND: CALL FOR CERVID CONTROL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 1 Nov 2014\nSource: Wicklow People [edited]\nhttp://www.independent.ie/regionals/wicklowpeople/news/calls-for-deer-cull-in-wicklow-as-cases-of-bovine-tb-increase-30698191.html\n\n\nThe levels of bovine TB [tuberculosis] occurring across County Wicklow are having a devastating effect on the farming community, with many dairy and beef farmers suffering drastic losses in income when infected animals have to be put down.\n\nAccording to Aughrim-based farmer and President of Wicklow ICMSA [Irish Creamery Milk Suppliers Association] Shane O'Loughlin, 'TB is rife' in Wicklow at present.\n\n'At the moment we are looking at TB levels at 3.5 times the national average per 1000 population. This is a huge concern for farmers who have had herds devastated by the disease. We are not just hearing of 1 or 2 reactors in a herd but sometimes in the dozens,' said Shane.\n\nOnce a reactor is detected in a herd, it is removed and the remaining cattle must pass 2 tests at 60 and 120 days post reactor before they are deemed fit for sale.\n\n'You cannot sell stock without this clearance and during this time the farmer's income is gone or vastly diminished. They have no way of making an income and the bills keep coming in.'\n\nShane explained that, in the past, cattle to cattle and badger to cattle transfer of TB were the main causes for concern but today, rising levels of deer is the suspected reason for the increase.\n\n'I see deer tracks in my yard almost every morning. At our AGM [Annual General Meeting] we had farmers in Castletown, 2 miles [3.2 km] outside of Arklow, who saw deer on land where they never were before. We have no idea of the numbers of deer out there.'\n\nAs a result of the increasing bovine TB levels, Shane said that Wicklow farmers are seeking a deer cull to get the matter under control.\n\n'A cull is most definitely required and the farming community is getting very frustrated by the lack of progress. It's not good for the cattle or the deer. If the disease is rampant amongst the deer then they are dying a slow and painful death. We want to see a healthy, sustainable deer stock as well.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ has one of the widest host ranges of all the _M. tuberculosis_ complex (MTC) and can readily spill over into a variety of domestic and wild mammals, including humans.\n\nIt is surprising that the call for culling is only based on perceived deer abundance. Even if there are good estimates of deer population dynamics, a culling effort should at least be based on surveys that provide data on the prevalence in deer, a careful analysis of how much culling would be needed to have the expected result, and whether such efforts are feasible.\n\nSurveillance efforts in deer and other susceptible wildlife species can provide an early warning of risk of transmission to livestock and also to produce crucial data to better understand the eco-epidemiology of the disease.\n\nMaps of Ireland can be accessed at https://www.uni-due.de/IERC/Ireland_FullSize.JPG and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42391. - This is a huge concern for farmers who have had herds devastated by the disease. We are not just hearing of 1 or 2 reactors in a herd but sometimes in the dozens,' said Shane.\n\nOnce a reactor is detected in a herd, it is removed and the remaining cattle must pass 2 tests at 60 and 120 days post reactor before they are deemed fit for sale.\n\n'You cannot sell stock without this clearance and during this time the farmer's income is gone or vastly diminished. It's not good for the cattle or the deer. If the disease is rampant amongst the deer then they are dying a slow and painful death. We want to see a healthy, sustainable deer stock as well.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ has one of the widest host ranges of all the _M. tuberculosis_ complex (MTC) and can readily spill over into a variety of domestic and wild mammals, including humans.\n\nIt is surprising that the call for culling is only based on perceived deer abundance. Even if there are good estimates of deer population dynamics, a culling effort should at least be based on surveys that provide data on the prevalence in deer, a careful analysis of how much culling would be needed to have the expected result, and whether such efforts are feasible.\n\nSurveillance efforts in deer and other susceptible wildlife species can provide an early warning of risk of transmission to livestock and also to produce crucial data to better understand the eco-epidemiology of the disease.\n\nMaps of Ireland can be accessed at https://www.uni-due.de/IERC/Ireland_FullSize.JPG and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42391. -
