USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090711.2480\n.................................................sb/pmb/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Castletown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wicklow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aughrim", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3047464", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - Ukraine: anti-TB drug shortage, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3047464", "date": "2014-11-04 10:43:26", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - IRELAND: CALL FOR CERVID CONTROL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 1 Nov 2014\nSource: Wicklow People [edited]\nhttp://www.independent.ie/regionals/wicklowpeople/news/calls-for-deer-cull-in-wicklow-as-cases-of-bovine-tb-increase-30698191.html\n\n\nThe levels of bovine TB [tuberculosis] occurring across County Wicklow are having a devastating effect on the farming community, with many dairy and beef farmers suffering drastic losses in income when infected animals have to be put down.\n\nAccording to Aughrim-based farmer and President of Wicklow ICMSA [Irish Creamery Milk Suppliers Association] Shane O'Loughlin, 'TB is rife' in Wicklow at present.\n\n'At the moment we are looking at TB levels at 3.5 times the national average per 1000 population. This is a huge concern for farmers who have had herds devastated by the disease. We are not just hearing of 1 or 2 reactors in a herd but sometimes in the dozens,' said Shane.\n\nOnce a reactor is detected in a herd, it is removed and the remaining cattle must pass 2 tests at 60 and 120 days post reactor before they are deemed fit for sale.\n\n'You cannot sell stock without this clearance and during this time the farmer's income is gone or vastly diminished. They have no way of making an income and the bills keep coming in.'\n\nShane explained that, in the past, cattle to cattle and badger to cattle transfer of TB were the main causes for concern but today, rising levels of deer is the suspected reason for the increase.\n\n'I see deer tracks in my yard almost every morning. At our AGM [Annual General Meeting] we had farmers in Castletown, 2 miles [3.2 km] outside of Arklow, who saw deer on land where they never were before. We have no idea of the numbers of deer out there.'\n\nAs a result of the increasing bovine TB levels, Shane said that Wicklow farmers are seeking a deer cull to get the matter under control.\n\n'A cull is most definitely required and the farming community is getting very frustrated by the lack of progress. It's not good for the cattle or the deer. If the disease is rampant amongst the deer then they are dying a slow and painful death. We want to see a healthy, sustainable deer stock as well.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ has one of the widest host ranges of all the _M. tuberculosis_ complex (MTC) and can readily spill over into a variety of domestic and wild mammals, including humans.\n\nIt is surprising that the call for culling is only based on perceived deer abundance. Even if there are good estimates of deer population dynamics, a culling effort should at least be based on surveys that provide data on the prevalence in deer, a careful analysis of how much culling would be needed to have the expected result, and whether such efforts are feasible.\n\nSurveillance efforts in deer and other susceptible wildlife species can provide an early warning of risk of transmission to livestock and also to produce crucial data to better understand the eco-epidemiology of the disease.\n\nMaps of Ireland can be accessed at https://www.uni-due.de/IERC/Ireland_FullSize.JPG and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42391. - USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090711.2480\n.................................................sb/pmb/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Castletown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wicklow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aughrim", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2998315", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - India (03): MDR, 2013", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2998315", "date": "2014-11-04 10:43:26", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - IRELAND: CALL FOR CERVID CONTROL\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 1 Nov 2014\nSource: Wicklow People [edited]\nhttp://www.independent.ie/regionals/wicklowpeople/news/calls-for-deer-cull-in-wicklow-as-cases-of-bovine-tb-increase-30698191.html\n\n\nThe levels of bovine TB [tuberculosis] occurring across County Wicklow are having a devastating effect on the farming community, with many dairy and beef farmers suffering drastic losses in income when infected animals have to be put down.\n\nAccording to Aughrim-based farmer and President of Wicklow ICMSA [Irish Creamery Milk Suppliers Association] Shane O'Loughlin, 'TB is rife' in Wicklow at present.\n\n'At the moment we are looking at TB levels at 3.5 times the national average per 1000 population. This is a huge concern for farmers who have had herds devastated by the disease. We are not just hearing of 1 or 2 reactors in a herd but sometimes in the dozens,' said Shane.\n\nOnce a reactor is detected in a herd, it is removed and the remaining cattle must pass 2 tests at 60 and 120 days post reactor before they are deemed fit for sale.\n\n'You cannot sell stock without this clearance and during this time the farmer's income is gone or vastly diminished. They have no way of making an income and the bills keep coming in.'\n\nShane explained that, in the past, cattle to cattle and badger to cattle transfer of TB were the main causes for concern but today, rising levels of deer is the suspected reason for the increase.\n\n'I see deer tracks in my yard almost every morning. At our AGM [Annual General Meeting] we had farmers in Castletown, 2 miles [3.2 km] outside of Arklow, who saw deer on land where they never were before. We have no idea of the numbers of deer out there.'\n\nAs a result of the increasing bovine TB levels, Shane said that Wicklow farmers are seeking a deer cull to get the matter under control.\n\n'A cull is most definitely required and the farming community is getting very frustrated by the lack of progress. It's not good for the cattle or the deer. If the disease is rampant amongst the deer then they are dying a slow and painful death. We want to see a healthy, sustainable deer stock as well.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ has one of the widest host ranges of all the _M. tuberculosis_ complex (MTC) and can readily spill over into a variety of domestic and wild mammals, including humans.\n\nIt is surprising that the call for culling is only based on perceived deer abundance. Even if there are good estimates of deer population dynamics, a culling effort should at least be based on surveys that provide data on the prevalence in deer, a careful analysis of how much culling would be needed to have the expected result, and whether such efforts are feasible.\n\nSurveillance efforts in deer and other susceptible wildlife species can provide an early warning of risk of transmission to livestock and also to produce crucial data to better understand the eco-epidemiology of the disease.\n\nMaps of Ireland can be accessed at https://www.uni-due.de/IERC/Ireland_FullSize.JPG and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42391. - This is a huge concern for farmers who have had herds devastated by the disease. We are not just hearing of 1 or 2 reactors in a herd but sometimes in the dozens,' said Shane.\n\nOnce a reactor is detected in a herd, it is removed and the remaining cattle must pass 2 tests at 60 and 120 days post reactor before they are deemed fit for sale.\n\n'You cannot sell stock without this clearance and during this time the farmer's income is gone or vastly diminished. They have no way of making an income and the bills keep coming in.'\n\nShane explained that, in the past, cattle to cattle and badger to cattle transfer of TB were the main causes for concern but today, rising levels of deer is the suspected reason for the increase.\n\n'I see deer tracks in my yard almost every morning. At our AGM [Annual General Meeting] we had farmers in Castletown, 2 miles [3.2 km] outside of Arklow, who saw deer on land where they never were before. We have no idea of the numbers of deer out there.'\n\nAs a result of the increasing bovine TB levels, Shane said that Wicklow farmers are seeking a deer cull to get the matter under control.\n\n'A cull is most definitely required and the farming community is getting very frustrated by the lack of progress. It's not good for the cattle or the deer. If the disease is rampant amongst the deer then they are dying a slow and painful death. We want to see a healthy, sustainable deer stock as well.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ has one of the widest host ranges of all the _M. tuberculosis_ complex (MTC) and can readily spill over into a variety of domestic and wild mammals, including humans.\n\nIt is surprising that the call for culling is only based on perceived deer abundance. Even if there are good estimates of deer population dynamics, a culling effort should at least be based on surveys that provide data on the prevalence in deer, a careful analysis of how much culling would be needed to have the expected result, and whether such efforts are feasible.\n\nSurveillance efforts in deer and other susceptible wildlife species can provide an early warning of risk of transmission to livestock and also to produce crucial data to better understand the eco-epidemiology of the disease.\n\nMaps of Ireland can be accessed at https://www.uni-due.de/IERC/Ireland_FullSize.JPG and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42391. - This is a huge concern for farmers who have had herds devastated by the disease. We are not just hearing of 1 or 2 reactors in a herd but sometimes in the dozens,' said Shane.\n\nOnce a reactor is detected in a herd, it is removed and the remaining cattle must pass 2 tests at 60 and 120 days post reactor before they are deemed fit for sale.\n\n'You cannot sell stock without this clearance and during this time the farmer's income is gone or vastly diminished. They have no way of making an income and the bills keep coming in.'\n\nShane explained that, in the past, cattle to cattle and badger to cattle transfer of TB were the main causes for concern but today, rising levels of deer is the suspected reason for the increase.\n\n'I see deer tracks in my yard almost every morning. At our AGM [Annual General Meeting] we had farmers in Castletown, 2 miles [3.2 km] outside of Arklow, who saw deer on land where they never were before. We have no idea of the numbers of deer out there.'\n\nAs a result of the increasing bovine TB levels, Shane said that Wicklow farmers are seeking a deer cull to get the matter under control.\n\n'A cull is most definitely required and the farming community is getting very frustrated by the lack of progress. It's not good for the cattle or the deer. If the disease is rampant amongst the deer then they are dying a slow and painful death. We want to see a healthy, sustainable deer stock as well.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis due to _Mycobacterium bovis_ has one of the widest host ranges of all the _M. tuberculosis_ complex (MTC) and can readily spill over into a variety of domestic and wild mammals, including humans.\n\nIt is surprising that the call for culling is only based on perceived deer abundance. Even if there are good estimates of deer population dynamics, a culling effort should at least be based on surveys that provide data on the prevalence in deer, a careful analysis of how much culling would be needed to have the expected result, and whether such efforts are feasible.\n\nSurveillance efforts in deer and other susceptible wildlife species can provide an early warning of risk of transmission to livestock and also to produce crucial data to better understand the eco-epidemiology of the disease.\n\nMaps of Ireland can be accessed at https://www.uni-due.de/IERC/Ireland_FullSize.JPG and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42391. - France: (SM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2641321", "date": "2014-05-17 12:28:38", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - USA (03): (GEORGIA) HOMELESS PERSONS\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 May 2014\nSource: WABE/NPR [edited]\nhttp://wabe.org/post/tb-outbreak-reported-atlanta-homeless-shelters\n\n\nOver the past 3 years, Fulton County [Georgia] had the lowest number of tuberculosis [TB] cases in the nation. That has changed. Since the start of 2014, county health officials say 16 cases were reported in 3 homeless shelters in Atlanta. They are the Central Night Shelter, the Atlanta Union Mission and the Task Force for the Homeless.\n\nOfficials say it's easy for diseases to thrive in homeless shelters. \"The bacteria take advantage of their situation, the congregate settings in which they live. The difficult situations stress their immune system and it activates. And it circulates on an ongoing basis,\" says Fulton County Medical Director Dr. Matthew McKenna.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says homeless people are nearly 10-times more likely to get TB compared to the general population. While there has been an outbreak in the homeless shelters, the DPH stresses there is no threat to the general public. \"Infection with TB requires prolonged.... at least 6 hours of sharing air in an enclosed space, of course, with an infected person,\" says Dr. Patrice Harris, the District Health Director for the Fulton County Department of Health and Wellness.\n\nHarris says all of the people who have the disease have been taken out of the shelters and are being treated. The same goes for the workers and volunteers at the homeless shelters. \"We're all going to be tested, in fact we routinely send people to get tested every day, so let's hang tight,\" says Task Force for the Homeless executive director Anita Beaty.\n\nThe Fulton County Department of Health and Wellness says a report on this outbreak will be released once its investigation is complete.\n\n[Byline: John Lorinc]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of tuberculosis in homeless people, please see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - USA: (CA) fatal, homeless persons 20130224.1556939.\n\nAtlanta is the capital and most populous city in the US state of Georgia, with an estimated 2012 population of 443 775 in the city and 5 457 831 in the Atlanta metropolitan area (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta). Atlanta is the county seat of Fulton County; 90 percent of the city of Atlanta is within Fulton County and the other 10 percent lies within DeKalb County (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fulton_County,_Georgia). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/213.]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - USA: (CA) fatal, homeless persons 20130224.1556939\n2012\n----\nTuberculosis - USA: (FL) fatal, homeless shelter 20120710.1196037\n2011\n----\nTuberculosis - Ireland: (LN) prison, hospital 20111024.3165\n.................................................ml/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fulton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DeKalb County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2592267", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, elephant - USA (05): (OR), background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2592267", "date": "2014-05-17 12:28:38", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - USA (03): (GEORGIA) HOMELESS PERSONS\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 May 2014\nSource: WABE/NPR [edited]\nhttp://wabe.org/post/tb-outbreak-reported-atlanta-homeless-shelters\n\n\nOver the past 3 years, Fulton County [Georgia] had the lowest number of tuberculosis [TB] cases in the nation. That has changed. Since the start of 2014, county health officials say 16 cases were reported in 3 homeless shelters in Atlanta. They are the Central Night Shelter, the Atlanta Union Mission and the Task Force for the Homeless.\n\nOfficials say it's easy for diseases to thrive in homeless shelters. \"The bacteria take advantage of their situation, the congregate settings in which they live. The difficult situations stress their immune system and it activates. And it circulates on an ongoing basis,\" says Fulton County Medical Director Dr. Matthew McKenna.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says homeless people are nearly 10-times more likely to get TB compared to the general population. While there has been an outbreak in the homeless shelters, the DPH stresses there is no threat to the general public. \"Infection with TB requires prolonged.... at least 6 hours of sharing air in an enclosed space, of course, with an infected person,\" says Dr. Patrice Harris, the District Health Director for the Fulton County Department of Health and Wellness.\n\nHarris says all of the people who have the disease have been taken out of the shelters and are being treated. The same goes for the workers and volunteers at the homeless shelters. \"We're all going to be tested, in fact we routinely send people to get tested every day, so let's hang tight,\" says Task Force for the Homeless executive director Anita Beaty.\n\nThe Fulton County Department of Health and Wellness says a report on this outbreak will be released once its investigation is complete.\n\n[Byline: John Lorinc]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For a discussion of tuberculosis in homeless people, please see moderator ML's comments in ProMED-mail post Tuberculosis - USA: (CA) fatal, homeless persons 20130224.1556939.\n\nAtlanta is the capital and most populous city in the US state of Georgia, with an estimated 2012 population of 443 775 in the city and 5 457 831 in the Atlanta metropolitan area (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta). Atlanta is the county seat of Fulton County; 90 percent of the city of Atlanta is within Fulton County and the other 10 percent lies within DeKalb County (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fulton_County,_Georgia). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/213.]\nSee Also\n2013\n----\nTuberculosis - USA: (CA) fatal, homeless persons 20130224.1556939\n2012\n----\nTuberculosis - USA: (FL) fatal, homeless shelter 20120710.1196037\n2011\n----\nTuberculosis - Ireland: (LN) prison, hospital 20111024.3165\n.................................................ml/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fulton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DeKalb County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2589984", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - UK (02): bovine, spread, research", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2589984", "date": "2014-05-17 12:28:38", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - USA (03): (GEORGIA) HOMELESS PERSONS\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 May 2014\nSource: WABE/NPR [edited]\nhttp://wabe.org/post/tb-outbreak-reported-atlanta-homeless-shelters\n\n\nOver the past 3 years, Fulton County [Georgia] had the lowest number of tuberculosis [TB] cases in the nation. That has changed. Since the start of 2014, county health officials say 16 cases were reported in 3 homeless shelters in Atlanta. They are the Central Night Shelter, the Atlanta Union Mission and the Task Force for the Homeless.\n\nOfficials say it's easy for diseases to thrive in homeless shelters. \"The bacteria take advantage of their situation, the congregate settings in which they live. The difficult situations stress their immune system and it activates. And it circulates on an ongoing basis,\" says Fulton County Medical Director Dr. Matthew McKenna.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says homeless people are nearly 10-times more likely to get TB compared to the general population. As a result, Wisconsin is unable to procure as much of the product as possibly needed. This shortage could potentially impact animal movement and herd accreditation plans for bovines and cervids.\n\nIf you or your clients have animal movement plans, prepare for the delays caused by the shortage.\n\nThe USDA is actively working to acquire a supply.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is huge news as it can impact the cost a producer incurs for the extra time (Days? Weeks? Months?) prior to being able to move animals. In some cases this may affect breeding dates and times, and may affect transport to some shows as well.\n\nSo how did the USDA find itself in a \"shortage situation\" of such a critical part of the tuberculosis control program? When do they anticipate having an adequate supply to meet the needs of the producers? Has the USDA taken any steps to help the producer?\n\nGenerally movement to harvest (slaughter) is not affected by such testing. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) cervids 20140324.2352510\n2013\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (OR) update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2411578", "date": "2014-03-27 11:07:04", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - USA (02): TUBERCULIN SHORTAGE\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 21 Mar 2014\nSource: Agri-View [edited]\nhttp://www.agriview.com/briefs/livestock/tuberculin-shortage/article_f28f635b-7ede-501b-9b97-632bdc5954b8.html\n\n\nLivestock producers should be aware that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) is currently experiencing a nationwide shortage of tuberculin, the product that is used for tuberculosis testing. As a result, Wisconsin is unable to procure as much of the product as possibly needed. This shortage could potentially impact animal movement and herd accreditation plans for bovines and cervids.\n\nIf you or your clients have animal movement plans, prepare for the delays caused by the shortage.\n\nThe USDA is actively working to acquire a supply.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is huge news as it can impact the cost a producer incurs for the extra time (Days? Weeks? Months?) prior to being able to move animals. In some cases this may affect breeding dates and times, and may affect transport to some shows as well.\n\nSo how did the USDA find itself in a \"shortage situation\" of such a critical part of the tuberculosis control program? When do they anticipate having an adequate supply to meet the needs of the producers? Has the USDA taken any steps to help the producer?\n\nGenerally movement to harvest (slaughter) is not affected by such testing. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI) cervids 20140324.2352510\n2013\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - As a result, Wisconsin is unable to procure as much of the product as possibly needed. This shortage could potentially impact animal movement and herd accreditation plans for bovines and cervids.\n\nIf you or your clients have animal movement plans, prepare for the delays caused by the shortage.\n\nThe USDA is actively working to acquire a supply.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is huge news as it can impact the cost a producer incurs for the extra time (Days? Weeks? Months?) prior to being able to move animals. USA: (MI) cervids", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2352510", "date": "2013-12-04 09:53:18", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - FRANCE (03): (ARDENNES)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Dec 2013\nSource: France 3 Champagne-Ardenne [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://champagne-ardenne.france3.fr/2013/12/03/nouveau-cas-de-tuberculose-bovine-diagnostique-dans-les-ardennes-370091.html\n\n\nA new outbreak of tuberculosis was confirmed by the prefecture of the Ardennes. It is located in a cattle farm in the town of Semide (Canton Machault [Champagne- Ardenne region]) following the discovery of suspicious lesions at slaughter.\n\nAccording to the statement issued by the prefecture, the test results revealed the DNA of _Mycobacterium bovis_, the bacterium responsible for bovine tuberculosis. Analyses are underway to determine the strain implicated. This is the 2nd outbreak of bovine tuberculosis in the municipality of Semide, the 1st of which was discovered in June 2012.\n\nThe fate of the suckler herd, composed of 109 calves, will have to be determined soon in line with the Ministry of Agriculture's ordinance.\n\nAccording to the prefecture of the Ardennes, this is the 6th case of bovine tuberculosis diagnosed in the Ardennes.\n\n[Byline: Lionel Gonzalez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the 25 Nov 2013 (most recent) update of EU's Animal Disease Notification System (ADNS), 9 EU countries have reported, so far, a total of 183 outbreaks of bovine tuberculosis (bTB) in cattle, as follows (in brackets: date of last report, number of outbreaks):\nAustria (21 Feb 2013, 2),\nBelgium (27 Sep 2013, 9)\nFrance (24 Oct 2013, 100)\nGermany (18 Apr 2013, 24)\nItaly (24 Sep 2013, 15)\nNetherlands (09 Jul 2013, 4)\nPoland (18 Oct 2013, 11)\nSwitzerland (14 Nov 2013, 13)\nUK (30 Sep 2013, 5).\n\nFor the above and additional details, see http://ec.europa.eu/food/animal/diseases/adns/adns_outbreaks_per_disease_en.pdf.\n\nFrance maintains -- since Dec 2000 -- the status of country \"officially bTB free\" according to international criteria (\"at least 99.8 percent of the herds free\"). Herd surveillance has been applied in areas with historical background and in herds with high potential for spread (such as raw milk dairy farms).\n\nThree potential wild bTB reservoirs are suspected in France -- wild boar, red deer, and badger. During the previous outbreak in Semide, preliminarily badgers were named as suspected. A recent study provides useful information on the bTB reservoir issue in France, including maps and suggested venues for further studies:\n\nRichomme C, Boadella M, Courcoul A, Durand B, Drapeau A, et al: Exposure of Wild Boar to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ Complex in France since 2000 Is Consistent with the Distribution of Bovine Tuberculosis Outbreaks in Cattle. PLoS ONE 2013; 8(10): e77842. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0077842; available at http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0077842. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/7S8K. - USA (06): (TX) cervid surveillance", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2120834", "date": "2013-12-04 09:53:18", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - FRANCE (03): (ARDENNES)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Dec 2013\nSource: France 3 Champagne-Ardenne [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://champagne-ardenne.france3.fr/2013/12/03/nouveau-cas-de-tuberculose-bovine-diagnostique-dans-les-ardennes-370091.html\n\n\nA new outbreak of tuberculosis was confirmed by the prefecture of the Ardennes. It is located in a cattle farm in the town of Semide (Canton Machault [Champagne- Ardenne region]) following the discovery of suspicious lesions at slaughter.\n\nAccording to the statement issued by the prefecture, the test results revealed the DNA of _Mycobacterium bovis_, the bacterium responsible for bovine tuberculosis. Analyses are underway to determine the strain implicated. This is the 2nd outbreak of bovine tuberculosis in the municipality of Semide, the 1st of which was discovered in June 2012.\n\nThe fate of the suckler herd, composed of 109 calves, will have to be determined soon in line with the Ministry of Agriculture's ordinance.\n\nAccording to the prefecture of the Ardennes, this is the 6th case of bovine tuberculosis diagnosed in the Ardennes.\n\n[Byline: Lionel Gonzalez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the 25 Nov 2013 (most recent) update of EU's Animal Disease Notification System (ADNS), 9 EU countries have reported, so far, a total of 183 outbreaks of bovine tuberculosis (bTB) in cattle, as follows (in brackets: date of last report, number of outbreaks):\nAustria (21 Feb 2013, 2),\nBelgium (27 Sep 2013, 9)\nFrance (24 Oct 2013, 100)\nGermany (18 Apr 2013, 24)\nItaly (24 Sep 2013, 15)\nNetherlands (09 Jul 2013, 4)\nPoland (18 Oct 2013, 11)\nSwitzerland (14 Nov 2013, 13)\nUK (30 Sep 2013, 5).\n\nFor the above and additional details, see http://ec.europa.eu/food/animal/diseases/adns/adns_outbreaks_per_disease_en.pdf.\n\nFrance maintains -- since Dec 2000 -- the status of country \"officially bTB free\" according to international criteria (\"at least 99.8 percent of the herds free\"). Herd surveillance has been applied in areas with historical background and in herds with high potential for spread (such as raw milk dairy farms).\n\nThree potential wild bTB reservoirs are suspected in France -- wild boar, red deer, and badger. During the previous outbreak in Semide, preliminarily badgers were named as suspected. A recent study provides useful information on the bTB reservoir issue in France, including maps and suggested venues for further studies:\n\nRichomme C, Boadella M, Courcoul A, Durand B, Drapeau A, et al: Exposure of Wild Boar to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ Complex in France since 2000 Is Consistent with the Distribution of Bovine Tuberculosis Outbreaks in Cattle. PLoS ONE 2013; 8(10): e77842. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0077842; available at http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0077842. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/7S8K. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - France (02): (AN) 20130802.1861207\n2012\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MY, AN) 20121122.1420616\n.................................................sb/arn/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2012-06-16 00:00:00", "2013-02-21 00:00:00", "2013-09-27 00:00:00", "2013-10-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2013-09-24 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-14 00:00:00", "2013-09-30 00:00:00", "2000-12-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Semide", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2091061", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, bovine - France (03): (AN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2091061", "date": "2013-12-04 09:53:18", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - FRANCE (03): (ARDENNES)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Dec 2013\nSource: France 3 Champagne-Ardenne [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://champagne-ardenne.france3.fr/2013/12/03/nouveau-cas-de-tuberculose-bovine-diagnostique-dans-les-ardennes-370091.html\n\n\nA new outbreak of tuberculosis was confirmed by the prefecture of the Ardennes. It is located in a cattle farm in the town of Semide (Canton Machault [Champagne- Ardenne region]) following the discovery of suspicious lesions at slaughter.\n\nAccording to the statement issued by the prefecture, the test results revealed the DNA of _Mycobacterium bovis_, the bacterium responsible for bovine tuberculosis. Analyses are underway to determine the strain implicated. This is the 2nd outbreak of bovine tuberculosis in the municipality of Semide, the 1st of which was discovered in June 2012.\n\nThe fate of the suckler herd, composed of 109 calves, will have to be determined soon in line with the Ministry of Agriculture's ordinance.\n\nAccording to the prefecture of the Ardennes, this is the 6th case of bovine tuberculosis diagnosed in the Ardennes.\n\n[Byline: Lionel Gonzalez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the 25 Nov 2013 (most recent) update of EU's Animal Disease Notification System (ADNS), 9 EU countries have reported, so far, a total of 183 outbreaks of bovine tuberculosis (bTB) in cattle, as follows (in brackets: date of last report, number of outbreaks):\nAustria (21 Feb 2013, 2),\nBelgium (27 Sep 2013, 9)\nFrance (24 Oct 2013, 100)\nGermany (18 Apr 2013, 24)\nItaly (24 Sep 2013, 15)\nNetherlands (09 Jul 2013, 4)\nPoland (18 Oct 2013, 11)\nSwitzerland (14 Nov 2013, 13)\nUK (30 Sep 2013, 5).\n\nFor the above and additional details, see http://ec.europa.eu/food/animal/diseases/adns/adns_outbreaks_per_disease_en.pdf.\n\nFrance maintains -- since Dec 2000 -- the status of country \"officially bTB free\" according to international criteria (\"at least 99.8 percent of the herds free\"). Herd surveillance has been applied in areas with historical background and in herds with high potential for spread (such as raw milk dairy farms).\n\nThree potential wild bTB reservoirs are suspected in France -- wild boar, red deer, and badger. During the previous outbreak in Semide, preliminarily badgers were named as suspected. A recent study provides useful information on the bTB reservoir issue in France, including maps and suggested venues for further studies:\n\nRichomme C, Boadella M, Courcoul A, Durand B, Drapeau A, et al: Exposure of Wild Boar to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ Complex in France since 2000 Is Consistent with the Distribution of Bovine Tuberculosis Outbreaks in Cattle. PLoS ONE 2013; 8(10): e77842. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0077842; available at http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0077842. - Mod.AS\n\nMaps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/7S8K. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - France (02): (AN) 20130802.1861207\n2012\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MY, AN) 20121122.1420616\n.................................................sb/arn/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2012-06-16 00:00:00", "2013-02-21 00:00:00", "2013-09-27 00:00:00", "2013-10-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2013-09-24 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-11-14 00:00:00", "2013-09-30 00:00:00", "2000-12-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Semide", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2084248", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2084248", "date": "2013-08-22 12:21:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - JORDAN: INCIDENCE, COMMENT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Aug 2013 [accessed]\nSource: OIE's World Animal Health Information Database (WAHID) Interface, zoonoses in humans, Jordan, 2011-2012 [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Zoonoses\n\n\nAccording to the above source, Jordan reported to the OIE the following numbers of human cases of 'bovine tuberculosis' (TB) for the years 2011 and 2012:\n\n2011: 312 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 4.8 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (136) and brucellosis (119).\n2012: 234 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 3.6 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (103) and brucellosis (96).\n\nFor the years 2009 and 2010, bovine tuberculosis was not named among the 4 top ranking zoonoses in humans. Ranks 1, 2 were leishmaniasis and brucellosis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following media report in The Jordan Times dated Sat 30 Mar 2013 may serve as\nbackground information on the current status of human tuberculosis in Jordan:\n\nhttp://jordantimes.com/ministry-to-halt-implementation-of-plan-to-eliminate-tb\n\"The [Jordanian] Ministry of Health is planning to put its strategy to eliminate tuberculosis (TB) on hold, according to its secretary general. Deifallah Lozi said the Kingdom is facing new challenges with the discovery of 50 TB [tuberculosis] cases among Syrian refugees, noting that this will affect Jordan's efforts to completely eliminate the disease.\n\n\"Speaking late on Thursday [28 Mar 2013] at a ceremony to mark the annual 24 March World TB Day, the secretary general explained that Jordan is one of the few countries worldwide that has met the World Health Organisation's benchmark to reduce the global TB burden ahead of the 2015 target year. The Kingdom achieved this goal in 2010, when TB prevalence in Jordan was 6 cases per 100 000 people, a drop of over 50 per cent from 1995, when it was 14 cases per 100 000.\n\n\"However, with the high prevalence of the disease among Syrian refugees, the Kingdom's plans to eliminate it will stop, according to Lozi, who called on the international community to support Jordan in providing healthcare services for Syrian refugees. According to official figures, 330 TB cases were discovered among Jordanians in 2012 [5.1 per 100 000], and 69 cases among non-Jordanians residing in the country.\n\n\"In addition, 50 cases -- 5 of them are multi-drug resistant -- were discovered among Syrians in Jordan.\n\n\"Also at Thursday's [28 Mar 2013] ceremony, the Jordan Tuberculosis Association announced that it will establish a specialised centre for the treatment of TB patients. Currently, there is only one healthcare centre specialised in treating TB patients, and it is located in Mafraq Governorate, 80 km [49.7 km] northeast of Amman, according to Khaled Abu Rumman, director of the National Programme to Stop TB.\n\n\"In 2011, 233 TB cases were detected among Jordanians [3.6 per 100 000], compared with 232 in 2010 and 272 in 2009.\"\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ can be transmitted from infected animals to humans by either ingestion of unpasteurized milk or milk products or inhalation of infectious aerosols from infected animals. Although rare, person-to-person transmission of _M. bovis_ can also occur. Following ingestion of _M. bovis_-contaminated food, _M. bovis_ most commonly localizes in cervical lymph nodes (scrofula) or the gastrointestinal tract and related lymph nodes with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the lungs and other organs. These forms of _M. bovis_ infection occur commonly in children and were common in developed countries during the pre-pasteurization era. Following inhalation of infectious aerosols of _M. bovis_, primary pulmonary _M. bovis_ infection develops with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the lungs and other organs.\n\nReactivation of latent _M. bovis_ pulmonary infection can occur in later life and can clinically resemble disease due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Differentiation of pulmonary infection due to _M. bovis_ from that due to _M. tuberculosis_ requires special microbiologic laboratory tests that are not done routinely.\n\nFrom the WAHID database, Jordan is said to have 312 and 234 human cases of bovine tuberculosis reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. However, we are not told how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans in Jordan was confirmed. Routine microbiologic methods allow only identification of \"Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex\", which includes _M. tuberculosis_, as well as _M. bovis_. To distinguish _M. bovis_ from _M. tuberculosis_, spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions are done. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of _M. bovis_ infection might otherwise be missed.\n\nThe numbers of human cases of bovine tuberculosis in the WAHID site do not correspond to numbers given by The Jordan Times for 2011 and 2012. According to the Jordan Times news release above, the official numbers of cases of tuberculosis were 233 and 330 reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. We are not told if these were cases of tuberculosis due to _M. tuberculosis_ alone or were a total of cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ plus cases due to _M. tuberculosis_. These numbers also differ from those reported by WHO for 2011 (312 new cases) for Jordan at https://extranet.who.int/sree/Reports?op=Replet&name=%2FWHO_HQ_Reports%2FG2%2FPROD%2FEXT%2FTBCountryProfile&ISO2=JO&LAN=EN&outtype=html.\n\nClarification of the numbers of new cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ and that due to _M. tuberculosis_ in Jordan for 2011 and 2012 would be appreciated, as well as how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans was confirmed for the cases reported in the WAHID database.\n\nFor a discussion of cross-border spread of tuberculosis, including multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR TB), see prior ProMED-mail posts: Tuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR 20130818.1886543;\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935; Tuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824; Tuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387; Tuberculosis - USA (02): (WI) MDR 20130721.183665; and Tuberculosis, XDR - USA: Texas ex Nepal 20130304.1570707.\n- Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1CMW.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR 20130818.1886543\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20130809.1871322\nTuberculosis - USA (02): (WI) MDR 20130721.183665\nTuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824\nTuberculosis, XDR - USA: Texas ex Nepal 20130304.1570707\n2012\n----\nLeishmaniasis, tuberculosis - Syria 20121226.1470184\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (02): (England) ex alpaca 20120510.1128707\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) ex alpaca 20120427.1116358\n2011\n----\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2009\n----\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI) 20050112.0102\n2004\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) (02) 20040716.1930\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\n.................................................arn/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mafraq Governorate", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amman", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "XDR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2066039", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - India (03): (MH) MDR", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2066039", "date": "2013-08-22 12:21:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - JORDAN: INCIDENCE, COMMENT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Aug 2013 [accessed]\nSource: OIE's World Animal Health Information Database (WAHID) Interface, zoonoses in humans, Jordan, 2011-2012 [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Zoonoses\n\n\nAccording to the above source, Jordan reported to the OIE the following numbers of human cases of 'bovine tuberculosis' (TB) for the years 2011 and 2012:\n\n2011: 312 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 4.8 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (136) and brucellosis (119).\n2012: 234 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 3.6 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (103) and brucellosis (96).\n\nFor the years 2009 and 2010, bovine tuberculosis was not named among the 4 top ranking zoonoses in humans. USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387; Tuberculosis - USA (02): (WI) MDR 20130721.183665; and Tuberculosis, XDR - USA: Texas ex Nepal 20130304.1570707.\n- Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1CMW.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - UK (Gloucestershire) (02) 20040716.1930\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\n.................................................arn/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mafraq Governorate", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amman", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "XDR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1996441", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, human - USA (02): (NV) nosocomial spread, fatal, query", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1996441", "date": "2013-08-22 12:21:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - JORDAN: INCIDENCE, COMMENT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Aug 2013 [accessed]\nSource: OIE's World Animal Health Information Database (WAHID) Interface, zoonoses in humans, Jordan, 2011-2012 [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Zoonoses\n\n\nAccording to the above source, Jordan reported to the OIE the following numbers of human cases of 'bovine tuberculosis' (TB) for the years 2011 and 2012:\n\n2011: 312 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 4.8 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (136) and brucellosis (119).\n2012: 234 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 3.6 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (103) and brucellosis (96).\n\nFor the years 2009 and 2010, bovine tuberculosis was not named among the 4 top ranking zoonoses in humans. Ranks 1, 2 were leishmaniasis and brucellosis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following media report in The Jordan Times dated Sat 30 Mar 2013 may serve as\nbackground information on the current status of human tuberculosis in Jordan:\n\nhttp://jordantimes.com/ministry-to-halt-implementation-of-plan-to-eliminate-tb\n\"The [Jordanian] Ministry of Health is planning to put its strategy to eliminate tuberculosis (TB) on hold, according to its secretary general. Deifallah Lozi said the Kingdom is facing new challenges with the discovery of 50 TB [tuberculosis] cases among Syrian refugees, noting that this will affect Jordan's efforts to completely eliminate the disease.\n\n\"Speaking late on Thursday [28 Mar 2013] at a ceremony to mark the annual 24 March World TB Day, the secretary general explained that Jordan is one of the few countries worldwide that has met the World Health Organisation's benchmark to reduce the global TB burden ahead of the 2015 target year. The Kingdom achieved this goal in 2010, when TB prevalence in Jordan was 6 cases per 100 000 people, a drop of over 50 per cent from 1995, when it was 14 cases per 100 000.\n\n\"However, with the high prevalence of the disease among Syrian refugees, the Kingdom's plans to eliminate it will stop, according to Lozi, who called on the international community to support Jordan in providing healthcare services for Syrian refugees. According to official figures, 330 TB cases were discovered among Jordanians in 2012 [5.1 per 100 000], and 69 cases among non-Jordanians residing in the country.\n\n\"In addition, 50 cases -- 5 of them are multi-drug resistant -- were discovered among Syrians in Jordan.\n\n\"Also at Thursday's [28 Mar 2013] ceremony, the Jordan Tuberculosis Association announced that it will establish a specialised centre for the treatment of TB patients. Currently, there is only one healthcare centre specialised in treating TB patients, and it is located in Mafraq Governorate, 80 km [49.7 km] northeast of Amman, according to Khaled Abu Rumman, director of the National Programme to Stop TB.\n\n\"In 2011, 233 TB cases were detected among Jordanians [3.6 per 100 000], compared with 232 in 2010 and 272 in 2009.\"\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ can be transmitted from infected animals to humans by either ingestion of unpasteurized milk or milk products or inhalation of infectious aerosols from infected animals. Although rare, person-to-person transmission of _M. bovis_ can also occur. Following ingestion of _M. bovis_-contaminated food, _M. bovis_ most commonly localizes in cervical lymph nodes (scrofula) or the gastrointestinal tract and related lymph nodes with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the lungs and other organs. These forms of _M. bovis_ infection occur commonly in children and were common in developed countries during the pre-pasteurization era. Following inhalation of infectious aerosols of _M. bovis_, primary pulmonary _M. bovis_ infection develops with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the lungs and other organs.\n\nReactivation of latent _M. bovis_ pulmonary infection can occur in later life and can clinically resemble disease due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Differentiation of pulmonary infection due to _M. bovis_ from that due to _M. tuberculosis_ requires special microbiologic laboratory tests that are not done routinely.\n\nFrom the WAHID database, Jordan is said to have 312 and 234 human cases of bovine tuberculosis reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. However, we are not told how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans in Jordan was confirmed. Routine microbiologic methods allow only identification of \"Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex\", which includes _M. tuberculosis_, as well as _M. bovis_. To distinguish _M. bovis_ from _M. tuberculosis_, spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions are done. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of _M. bovis_ infection might otherwise be missed.\n\nThe numbers of human cases of bovine tuberculosis in the WAHID site do not correspond to numbers given by The Jordan Times for 2011 and 2012. According to the Jordan Times news release above, the official numbers of cases of tuberculosis were 233 and 330 reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. We are not told if these were cases of tuberculosis due to _M. tuberculosis_ alone or were a total of cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ plus cases due to _M. tuberculosis_. These numbers also differ from those reported by WHO for 2011 (312 new cases) for Jordan at https://extranet.who.int/sree/Reports?op=Replet&name=%2FWHO_HQ_Reports%2FG2%2FPROD%2FEXT%2FTBCountryProfile&ISO2=JO&LAN=EN&outtype=html.\n\nClarification of the numbers of new cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ and that due to _M. tuberculosis_ in Jordan for 2011 and 2012 would be appreciated, as well as how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans was confirmed for the cases reported in the WAHID database.\n\nFor a discussion of cross-border spread of tuberculosis, including multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR TB), see prior ProMED-mail posts: Tuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR 20130818.1886543;\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935; Tuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824; Tuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387; Tuberculosis - USA (02): (WI) MDR 20130721.183665; and Tuberculosis, XDR - USA: Texas ex Nepal 20130304.1570707.\n- Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1CMW.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR 20130818.1886543\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20130809.1871322\nTuberculosis - USA (02): (WI) MDR 20130721.183665\nTuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824\nTuberculosis, XDR - USA: Texas ex Nepal 20130304.1570707\n2012\n----\nLeishmaniasis, tuberculosis - Syria 20121226.1470184\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (02): (England) ex alpaca 20120510.1128707\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) ex alpaca 20120427.1116358\n2011\n----\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2009\n----\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI) 20050112.0102\n2004\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) (02) 20040716.1930\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\n.................................................arn/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mafraq Governorate", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amman", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "XDR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1993861", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, human - Switzerland: (AR) bovine, M. caprae, Liechtenstein susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1975157", "date": "2013-08-22 12:21:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - JORDAN: INCIDENCE, COMMENT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Aug 2013 [accessed]\nSource: OIE's World Animal Health Information Database (WAHID) Interface, zoonoses in humans, Jordan, 2011-2012 [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Zoonoses\n\n\nAccording to the above source, Jordan reported to the OIE the following numbers of human cases of 'bovine tuberculosis' (TB) for the years 2011 and 2012:\n\n2011: 312 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 4.8 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (136) and brucellosis (119).\n2012: 234 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 3.6 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (103) and brucellosis (96).\n\nFor the years 2009 and 2010, bovine tuberculosis was not named among the 4 top ranking zoonoses in humans. Ranks 1, 2 were leishmaniasis and brucellosis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following media report in The Jordan Times dated Sat 30 Mar 2013 may serve as\nbackground information on the current status of human tuberculosis in Jordan:\n\nhttp://jordantimes.com/ministry-to-halt-implementation-of-plan-to-eliminate-tb\n\"The [Jordanian] Ministry of Health is planning to put its strategy to eliminate tuberculosis (TB) on hold, according to its secretary general. Deifallah Lozi said the Kingdom is facing new challenges with the discovery of 50 TB [tuberculosis] cases among Syrian refugees, noting that this will affect Jordan's efforts to completely eliminate the disease.\n\n\"Speaking late on Thursday [28 Mar 2013] at a ceremony to mark the annual 24 March World TB Day, the secretary general explained that Jordan is one of the few countries worldwide that has met the World Health Organisation's benchmark to reduce the global TB burden ahead of the 2015 target year. The Kingdom achieved this goal in 2010, when TB prevalence in Jordan was 6 cases per 100 000 people, a drop of over 50 per cent from 1995, when it was 14 cases per 100 000.\n\n\"However, with the high prevalence of the disease among Syrian refugees, the Kingdom's plans to eliminate it will stop, according to Lozi, who called on the international community to support Jordan in providing healthcare services for Syrian refugees. According to official figures, 330 TB cases were discovered among Jordanians in 2012 [5.1 per 100 000], and 69 cases among non-Jordanians residing in the country.\n\n\"In addition, 50 cases -- 5 of them are multi-drug resistant -- were discovered among Syrians in Jordan.\n\n\"Also at Thursday's [28 Mar 2013] ceremony, the Jordan Tuberculosis Association announced that it will establish a specialised centre for the treatment of TB patients. Currently, there is only one healthcare centre specialised in treating TB patients, and it is located in Mafraq Governorate, 80 km [49.7 km] northeast of Amman, according to Khaled Abu Rumman, director of the National Programme to Stop TB.\n\n\"In 2011, 233 TB cases were detected among Jordanians [3.6 per 100 000], compared with 232 in 2010 and 272 in 2009.\"\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ can be transmitted from infected animals to humans by either ingestion of unpasteurized milk or milk products or inhalation of infectious aerosols from infected animals. Differentiation of pulmonary infection due to _M. bovis_ from that due to _M. tuberculosis_ requires special microbiologic laboratory tests that are not done routinely.\n\nFrom the WAHID database, Jordan is said to have 312 and 234 human cases of bovine tuberculosis reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. However, we are not told how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans in Jordan was confirmed. Routine microbiologic methods allow only identification of \"Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex\", which includes _M. tuberculosis_, as well as _M. bovis_. To distinguish _M. bovis_ from _M. tuberculosis_, spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions are done. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of _M. bovis_ infection might otherwise be missed.\n\nThe numbers of human cases of bovine tuberculosis in the WAHID site do not correspond to numbers given by The Jordan Times for 2011 and 2012. According to the Jordan Times news release above, the official numbers of cases of tuberculosis were 233 and 330 reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. We are not told if these were cases of tuberculosis due to _M. tuberculosis_ alone or were a total of cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ plus cases due to _M. tuberculosis_. These numbers also differ from those reported by WHO for 2011 (312 new cases) for Jordan at https://extranet.who.int/sree/Reports?op=Replet&name=%2FWHO_HQ_Reports%2FG2%2FPROD%2FEXT%2FTBCountryProfile&ISO2=JO&LAN=EN&outtype=html.\n\nClarification of the numbers of new cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ and that due to _M. tuberculosis_ in Jordan for 2011 and 2012 would be appreciated, as well as how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans was confirmed for the cases reported in the WAHID database.\n\nFor a discussion of cross-border spread of tuberculosis, including multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR TB), see prior ProMED-mail posts: Tuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR 20130818.1886543;\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935; Tuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824; Tuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387; Tuberculosis - USA (02): (WI) MDR 20130721.183665; and Tuberculosis, XDR - USA: Texas ex Nepal 20130304.1570707.\n- Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1CMW.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - UK (Gloucestershire) (02) 20040716.1930\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\n.................................................arn/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mafraq Governorate", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amman", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "XDR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1936137", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine tuberculosis - Honduras: bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1936137", "date": "2013-08-22 12:21:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - JORDAN: INCIDENCE, COMMENT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Aug 2013 [accessed]\nSource: OIE's World Animal Health Information Database (WAHID) Interface, zoonoses in humans, Jordan, 2011-2012 [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Zoonoses\n\n\nAccording to the above source, Jordan reported to the OIE the following numbers of human cases of 'bovine tuberculosis' (TB) for the years 2011 and 2012:\n\n2011: 312 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 4.8 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (136) and brucellosis (119).\n2012: 234 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 3.6 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (103) and brucellosis (96).\n\nFor the years 2009 and 2010, bovine tuberculosis was not named among the 4 top ranking zoonoses in humans. Ranks 1, 2 were leishmaniasis and brucellosis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following media report in The Jordan Times dated Sat 30 Mar 2013 may serve as\nbackground information on the current status of human tuberculosis in Jordan:\n\nhttp://jordantimes.com/ministry-to-halt-implementation-of-plan-to-eliminate-tb\n\"The [Jordanian] Ministry of Health is planning to put its strategy to eliminate tuberculosis (TB) on hold, according to its secretary general. Deifallah Lozi said the Kingdom is facing new challenges with the discovery of 50 TB [tuberculosis] cases among Syrian refugees, noting that this will affect Jordan's efforts to completely eliminate the disease.\n\n\"Speaking late on Thursday [28 Mar 2013] at a ceremony to mark the annual 24 March World TB Day, the secretary general explained that Jordan is one of the few countries worldwide that has met the World Health Organisation's benchmark to reduce the global TB burden ahead of the 2015 target year. The Kingdom achieved this goal in 2010, when TB prevalence in Jordan was 6 cases per 100 000 people, a drop of over 50 per cent from 1995, when it was 14 cases per 100 000.\n\n\"However, with the high prevalence of the disease among Syrian refugees, the Kingdom's plans to eliminate it will stop, according to Lozi, who called on the international community to support Jordan in providing healthcare services for Syrian refugees. According to official figures, 330 TB cases were discovered among Jordanians in 2012 [5.1 per 100 000], and 69 cases among non-Jordanians residing in the country.\n\n\"In addition, 50 cases -- 5 of them are multi-drug resistant -- were discovered among Syrians in Jordan.\n\n\"Also at Thursday's [28 Mar 2013] ceremony, the Jordan Tuberculosis Association announced that it will establish a specialised centre for the treatment of TB patients. Currently, there is only one healthcare centre specialised in treating TB patients, and it is located in Mafraq Governorate, 80 km [49.7 km] northeast of Amman, according to Khaled Abu Rumman, director of the National Programme to Stop TB.\n\n\"In 2011, 233 TB cases were detected among Jordanians [3.6 per 100 000], compared with 232 in 2010 and 272 in 2009.\"\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ can be transmitted from infected animals to humans by either ingestion of unpasteurized milk or milk products or inhalation of infectious aerosols from infected animals. Although rare, person-to-person transmission of _M. bovis_ can also occur. Following ingestion of _M. bovis_-contaminated food, _M. bovis_ most commonly localizes in cervical lymph nodes (scrofula) or the gastrointestinal tract and related lymph nodes with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the lungs and other organs. These forms of _M. bovis_ infection occur commonly in children and were common in developed countries during the pre-pasteurization era. Following inhalation of infectious aerosols of _M. bovis_, primary pulmonary _M. bovis_ infection develops with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the lungs and other organs.\n\nReactivation of latent _M. bovis_ pulmonary infection can occur in later life and can clinically resemble disease due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Differentiation of pulmonary infection due to _M. bovis_ from that due to _M. tuberculosis_ requires special microbiologic laboratory tests that are not done routinely.\n\nFrom the WAHID database, Jordan is said to have 312 and 234 human cases of bovine tuberculosis reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. However, we are not told how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans in Jordan was confirmed. Routine microbiologic methods allow only identification of \"Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex\", which includes _M. tuberculosis_, as well as _M. bovis_. To distinguish _M. bovis_ from _M. tuberculosis_, spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions are done. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of _M. bovis_ infection might otherwise be missed.\n\nThe numbers of human cases of bovine tuberculosis in the WAHID site do not correspond to numbers given by The Jordan Times for 2011 and 2012. According to the Jordan Times news release above, the official numbers of cases of tuberculosis were 233 and 330 reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. We are not told if these were cases of tuberculosis due to _M. tuberculosis_ alone or were a total of cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ plus cases due to _M. tuberculosis_. These numbers also differ from those reported by WHO for 2011 (312 new cases) for Jordan at https://extranet.who.int/sree/Reports?op=Replet&name=%2FWHO_HQ_Reports%2FG2%2FPROD%2FEXT%2FTBCountryProfile&ISO2=JO&LAN=EN&outtype=html.\n\nClarification of the numbers of new cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ and that due to _M. tuberculosis_ in Jordan for 2011 and 2012 would be appreciated, as well as how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans was confirmed for the cases reported in the WAHID database.\n\nFor a discussion of cross-border spread of tuberculosis, including multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR TB), see prior ProMED-mail posts: Tuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR 20130818.1886543;\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935; Tuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824; Tuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387; Tuberculosis - USA (02): (WI) MDR 20130721.183665; and Tuberculosis, XDR - USA: Texas ex Nepal 20130304.1570707.\n- Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1CMW.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - USA: Texas ex Nepal 20130304.1570707\n2012\n----\nLeishmaniasis, tuberculosis - Syria 20121226.1470184\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (02): (England) ex alpaca 20120510.1128707\nBovine tuberculosis, human -
