Jordan: incidence, comment, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1892434", "date": "2013-08-22 12:21:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - JORDAN: INCIDENCE, COMMENT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 Aug 2013 [accessed]\nSource: OIE's World Animal Health Information Database (WAHID) Interface, zoonoses in humans, Jordan, 2011-2012 [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Zoonoses\n\n\nAccording to the above source, Jordan reported to the OIE the following numbers of human cases of 'bovine tuberculosis' (TB) for the years 2011 and 2012:\n\n2011: 312 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 4.8 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (136) and brucellosis (119).\n2012: 234 cases of bovine tuberculosis, [with an incidence rate of 3.6 per 100 000], ranking 1 among zoonoses, followed by leishmaniasis (103) and brucellosis (96).\n\nFor the years 2009 and 2010, bovine tuberculosis was not named among the 4 top ranking zoonoses in humans. Ranks 1, 2 were leishmaniasis and brucellosis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following media report in The Jordan Times dated Sat 30 Mar 2013 may serve as\nbackground information on the current status of human tuberculosis in Jordan:\n\nhttp://jordantimes.com/ministry-to-halt-implementation-of-plan-to-eliminate-tb\n\"The [Jordanian] Ministry of Health is planning to put its strategy to eliminate tuberculosis (TB) on hold, according to its secretary general. Deifallah Lozi said the Kingdom is facing new challenges with the discovery of 50 TB [tuberculosis] cases among Syrian refugees, noting that this will affect Jordan's efforts to completely eliminate the disease.\n\n\"Speaking late on Thursday [28 Mar 2013] at a ceremony to mark the annual 24 March World TB Day, the secretary general explained that Jordan is one of the few countries worldwide that has met the World Health Organisation's benchmark to reduce the global TB burden ahead of the 2015 target year. The Kingdom achieved this goal in 2010, when TB prevalence in Jordan was 6 cases per 100 000 people, a drop of over 50 per cent from 1995, when it was 14 cases per 100 000.\n\n\"However, with the high prevalence of the disease among Syrian refugees, the Kingdom's plans to eliminate it will stop, according to Lozi, who called on the international community to support Jordan in providing healthcare services for Syrian refugees. According to official figures, 330 TB cases were discovered among Jordanians in 2012 [5.1 per 100 000], and 69 cases among non-Jordanians residing in the country.\n\n\"In addition, 50 cases -- 5 of them are multi-drug resistant -- were discovered among Syrians in Jordan.\n\n\"Also at Thursday's [28 Mar 2013] ceremony, the Jordan Tuberculosis Association announced that it will establish a specialised centre for the treatment of TB patients. Currently, there is only one healthcare centre specialised in treating TB patients, and it is located in Mafraq Governorate, 80 km [49.7 km] northeast of Amman, according to Khaled Abu Rumman, director of the National Programme to Stop TB.\n\n\"In 2011, 233 TB cases were detected among Jordanians [3.6 per 100 000], compared with 232 in 2010 and 272 in 2009.\"\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ can be transmitted from infected animals to humans by either ingestion of unpasteurized milk or milk products or inhalation of infectious aerosols from infected animals. Although rare, person-to-person transmission of _M. bovis_ can also occur. Following ingestion of _M. bovis_-contaminated food, _M. bovis_ most commonly localizes in cervical lymph nodes (scrofula) or the gastrointestinal tract and related lymph nodes with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the lungs and other organs. These forms of _M. bovis_ infection occur commonly in children and were common in developed countries during the pre-pasteurization era. Following inhalation of infectious aerosols of _M. bovis_, primary pulmonary _M. bovis_ infection develops with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the lungs and other organs.\n\nReactivation of latent _M. bovis_ pulmonary infection can occur in later life and can clinically resemble disease due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Differentiation of pulmonary infection due to _M. bovis_ from that due to _M. tuberculosis_ requires special microbiologic laboratory tests that are not done routinely.\n\nFrom the WAHID database, Jordan is said to have 312 and 234 human cases of bovine tuberculosis reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. However, we are not told how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans in Jordan was confirmed. Routine microbiologic methods allow only identification of \"Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex\", which includes _M. tuberculosis_, as well as _M. bovis_. To distinguish _M. bovis_ from _M. tuberculosis_, spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions are done. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of _M. bovis_ infection might otherwise be missed.\n\nThe numbers of human cases of bovine tuberculosis in the WAHID site do not correspond to numbers given by The Jordan Times for 2011 and 2012. According to the Jordan Times news release above, the official numbers of cases of tuberculosis were 233 and 330 reported in 2011 and 2012, respectively. We are not told if these were cases of tuberculosis due to _M. tuberculosis_ alone or were a total of cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ plus cases due to _M. tuberculosis_. These numbers also differ from those reported by WHO for 2011 (312 new cases) for Jordan at https://extranet.who.int/sree/Reports?op=Replet&name=%2FWHO_HQ_Reports%2FG2%2FPROD%2FEXT%2FTBCountryProfile&ISO2=JO&LAN=EN&outtype=html.\n\nClarification of the numbers of new cases of tuberculosis due to _M. bovis_ and that due to _M. tuberculosis_ in Jordan for 2011 and 2012 would be appreciated, as well as how the diagnosis of bovine tuberculosis in humans was confirmed for the cases reported in the WAHID database.\n\nFor a discussion of cross-border spread of tuberculosis, including multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR TB), see prior ProMED-mail posts: Tuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR 20130818.1886543;\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935; Tuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI 20130524.1735824; Tuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387; Tuberculosis - USA (02): (WI) MDR 20130721.183665; and Tuberculosis, XDR - USA: Texas ex Nepal 20130304.1570707.\n- Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1CMW.]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis - UK (Gloucestershire) (02) 20040716.1930\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\n.................................................arn/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mafraq Governorate", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amman", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "XDR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1886543", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - France (02): ex former Soviet Union, MDR", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1886543", "date": "2013-07-21 16:11:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK (04): (ENGLAND) UPDATE, CONTROL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Jul 2013\nSource: Farmers Weekly [edited]\nhttp://www.fwi.co.uk/articles/17/07/2013/140057/bovine-tb-results-in-slaughter-of-96-cattle-a-day.htm\n\n\nA total of 96 cattle animals a day were slaughtered because of bovine TB during the 1st 4 months of 2013, according to DEFRA [Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]'s latest statistics.\n\nThere were 12 006 cattle killed in Great Britain between January and April 2013 as a result of the disease.\n\nThe bulk of these were in England, which saw 9503 cattle slaughtered either as reactors or direct contacts.\n\nThe figures show a small drop on the same period in 2012, which saw 12 279 animals slaughtered.\n\nHowever, DEFRA has pointed out that the TB incidence rate -- defined as the percentage of tests on officially TB-free herds that resulted in the TB-free status being withdrawn -- went up from 3.8 percent in April 2012 to 4.1 percent in April 2013.\n\nDEFRA farm minister David Heath said: \"Once again these figures show the very real need to stop TB from its relentless march across the countryside.\n\n\"Every month thousands of animals infected with TB are sent to the slaughterhouse at huge cost to the farming industry and the taxpayer.\n\n\"That is why we have launched our TB eradication strategy, setting out our plan to make England TB-free within 25 years. Bovine TB is the most pressing animal health problem in the UK, threatening cattle farmers' livelihoods, our farming industry as well as the health of wildlife and livestock and we must do all we can to get on top of it.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The UK's government draft strategy for achieving \"Officially Bovine Tuberculosis-Free\" Status for England has been recently published for the public's consultation which runs from 4 Jul 2013 to 26 Sep 2013. The call for consultation is available at https://www.gov.uk/government/news/bovine-tb-strategy-launched-to-make-england-disease-free-within-25-years. Panama: (CC) OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1881848", "date": "2013-07-21 16:11:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK (04): (ENGLAND) UPDATE, CONTROL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Jul 2013\nSource: Farmers Weekly [edited]\nhttp://www.fwi.co.uk/articles/17/07/2013/140057/bovine-tb-results-in-slaughter-of-96-cattle-a-day.htm\n\n\nA total of 96 cattle animals a day were slaughtered because of bovine TB during the 1st 4 months of 2013, according to DEFRA [Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]'s latest statistics.\n\nThere were 12 006 cattle killed in Great Britain between January and April 2013 as a result of the disease.\n\nThe bulk of these were in England, which saw 9503 cattle slaughtered either as reactors or direct contacts.\n\nThe figures show a small drop on the same period in 2012, which saw 12 279 animals slaughtered.\n\nHowever, DEFRA has pointed out that the TB incidence rate -- defined as the percentage of tests on officially TB-free herds that resulted in the TB-free status being withdrawn -- went up from 3.8 percent in April 2012 to 4.1 percent in April 2013.\n\nDEFRA farm minister David Heath said: \"Once again these figures show the very real need to stop TB from its relentless march across the countryside.\n\n\"Every month thousands of animals infected with TB are sent to the slaughterhouse at huge cost to the farming industry and the taxpayer.\n\n\"That is why we have launched our TB eradication strategy, setting out our plan to make England TB-free within 25 years. Bovine TB is the most pressing animal health problem in the UK, threatening cattle farmers' livelihoods, our farming industry as well as the health of wildlife and livestock and we must do all we can to get on top of it.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The UK's government draft strategy for achieving \"Officially Bovine Tuberculosis-Free\" Status for England has been recently published for the public's consultation which runs from 4 Jul 2013 to 26 Sep 2013. UK: (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1871322", "date": "2013-07-21 16:11:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK (04): (ENGLAND) UPDATE, CONTROL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Jul 2013\nSource: Farmers Weekly [edited]\nhttp://www.fwi.co.uk/articles/17/07/2013/140057/bovine-tb-results-in-slaughter-of-96-cattle-a-day.htm\n\n\nA total of 96 cattle animals a day were slaughtered because of bovine TB during the 1st 4 months of 2013, according to DEFRA [Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]'s latest statistics.\n\nThere were 12 006 cattle killed in Great Britain between January and April 2013 as a result of the disease.\n\nThe bulk of these were in England, which saw 9503 cattle slaughtered either as reactors or direct contacts.\n\nThe figures show a small drop on the same period in 2012, which saw 12 279 animals slaughtered.\n\nHowever, DEFRA has pointed out that the TB incidence rate -- defined as the percentage of tests on officially TB-free herds that resulted in the TB-free status being withdrawn -- went up from 3.8 percent in April 2012 to 4.1 percent in April 2013.\n\nDEFRA farm minister David Heath said: \"Once again these figures show the very real need to stop TB from its relentless march across the countryside.\n\n\"Every month thousands of animals infected with TB are sent to the slaughterhouse at huge cost to the farming industry and the taxpayer.\n\n\"That is why we have launched our TB eradication strategy, setting out our plan to make England TB-free within 25 years. Bovine TB is the most pressing animal health problem in the UK, threatening cattle farmers' livelihoods, our farming industry as well as the health of wildlife and livestock and we must do all we can to get on top of it.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The UK's government draft strategy for achieving \"Officially Bovine Tuberculosis-Free\" Status for England has been recently published for the public's consultation which runs from 4 Jul 2013 to 26 Sep 2013. UK (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1855759", "date": "2013-07-21 16:11:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK (04): (ENGLAND) UPDATE, CONTROL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Jul 2013\nSource: Farmers Weekly [edited]\nhttp://www.fwi.co.uk/articles/17/07/2013/140057/bovine-tb-results-in-slaughter-of-96-cattle-a-day.htm\n\n\nA total of 96 cattle animals a day were slaughtered because of bovine TB during the 1st 4 months of 2013, according to DEFRA [Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]'s latest statistics.\n\nThere were 12 006 cattle killed in Great Britain between January and April 2013 as a result of the disease.\n\nThe bulk of these were in England, which saw 9503 cattle slaughtered either as reactors or direct contacts.\n\nThe figures show a small drop on the same period in 2012, which saw 12 279 animals slaughtered.\n\nHowever, DEFRA has pointed out that the TB incidence rate -- defined as the percentage of tests on officially TB-free herds that resulted in the TB-free status being withdrawn -- went up from 3.8 percent in April 2012 to 4.1 percent in April 2013.\n\nDEFRA farm minister David Heath said: \"Once again these figures show the very real need to stop TB from its relentless march across the countryside.\n\n\"Every month thousands of animals infected with TB are sent to the slaughterhouse at huge cost to the farming industry and the taxpayer.\n\n\"That is why we have launched our TB eradication strategy, setting out our plan to make England TB-free within 25 years. Bovine TB is the most pressing animal health problem in the UK, threatening cattle farmers' livelihoods, our farming industry as well as the health of wildlife and livestock and we must do all we can to get on top of it.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The UK's government draft strategy for achieving \"Officially Bovine Tuberculosis-Free\" Status for England has been recently published for the public's consultation which runs from 4 Jul 2013 to 26 Sep 2013. UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1854572", "date": "2013-07-21 16:11:24", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK (04): (ENGLAND) UPDATE, CONTROL\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Jul 2013\nSource: Farmers Weekly [edited]\nhttp://www.fwi.co.uk/articles/17/07/2013/140057/bovine-tb-results-in-slaughter-of-96-cattle-a-day.htm\n\n\nA total of 96 cattle animals a day were slaughtered because of bovine TB during the 1st 4 months of 2013, according to DEFRA [Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]'s latest statistics.\n\nThere were 12 006 cattle killed in Great Britain between January and April 2013 as a result of the disease.\n\nThe bulk of these were in England, which saw 9503 cattle slaughtered either as reactors or direct contacts.\n\nThe figures show a small drop on the same period in 2012, which saw 12 279 animals slaughtered.\n\nHowever, DEFRA has pointed out that the TB incidence rate -- defined as the percentage of tests on officially TB-free herds that resulted in the TB-free status being withdrawn -- went up from 3.8 percent in April 2012 to 4.1 percent in April 2013.\n\nDEFRA farm minister David Heath said: \"Once again these figures show the very real need to stop TB from its relentless march across the countryside.\n\n\"Every month thousands of animals infected with TB are sent to the slaughterhouse at huge cost to the farming industry and the taxpayer.\n\n\"That is why we have launched our TB eradication strategy, setting out our plan to make England TB-free within 25 years. Bovine TB is the most pressing animal health problem in the UK, threatening cattle farmers' livelihoods, our farming industry as well as the health of wildlife and livestock and we must do all we can to get on top of it.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The UK's government draft strategy for achieving \"Officially Bovine Tuberculosis-Free\" Status for England has been recently published for the public's consultation which runs from 4 Jul 2013 to 26 Sep 2013. UK: resurgence 20101223.4522\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): badger vaccination 20101110.4082\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): new control program 20100921.3396\n.................................................arn/je/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "9503-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-04-16 00:00:00", "2013-04-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Great Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1836650", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - USA (02): (WI) MDR", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1836650", "date": "2013-05-11 23:08:29", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NEW ZEALAND\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 9 May 2013\nSource: Stuff.co.nz [edited]\nhttp://www.stuff.co.nz/taranaki-daily-news/lifestyle/8650750/TB-outbreak-investigation\n\n\nTaranaki's 6th case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed. The Animal Health Board (AHB) said last week that a herd near Inglewood was suspected of having the disease.\n\nThe confirmation this week of the infection brings to 4 the number of herds near Inglewood with the disease. Two herds near Opunake also have it.\n\nThe new infection near Inglewood related to movements of animals between the infected herds, and there was also a direct movement relationship between the 2 Opunake herds, AHB regional coordinator Frank Pavitt, of Hamilton, said. \"So we know why these herds have been infected.\"\n\nHe hoped that the Taranaki outbreak, in which the 1st case was detected in January 2013, would be confined to the 6 herds already identified.\n\n\"We hope we're coming to the end of our investigation and that we've identified all the infections that are present. But it's still a work in progress. It's a dynamic investigation, so we don't know when it will be fully completed.\"\n\nPavitt said movements from the herd where the infection had just been confirmed would now have to be examined.\n\nThe AHB is holding meetings for farmers within a 10-km radius of the infected herds in the Opunake and Inglewood areas on 21 May 2013.\n\nPavitt said it was contacting all farmers in the 2 areas about the meetings. They were being sent factsheets about the infections in their area and about the new annual testing regime for cattle and deer over 12 months of age that will now be set in place.\n\n[Byline: Sue O'dowd]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The primary cause of tuberculosis in cattle is the bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. This bacterium is in the same family as bacteria that cause Johne's disease and leprosy. Adult cattle are usually infected by inhaling invisible droplets containing the bacteria into their lungs, while pre-weaned calves are more often infected by drinking contaminated milk. The route of entry will ultimately determine the clinical signs of the disease.\n\nSince the bacteria are usually inhaled into the lungs in adult cows, the commonest clinical signs are related to pulmonary tuberculosis. Once the bacteria enter the lungs, they begin to multiply and generally spread to the lymph nodes near the lungs. At this primary site of infection, the lesions can remain quietly inactive or develop further depending on the ability of the cow to fight off the infection. When the immune system of the cow is fully activated, the infection may remain limited to the lungs and could go undetected for the productive life of the cow. If the infection over-powers the body defenses, the bacteria may be carried to other locations in the body in the lymph or blood circulation. New areas of infection often occur in the lungs, kidneys, liver, spleen, and the lymph nodes associated with these organs. In cases allowed to progress over an extended period of time, lesions may be present in the uterus or mammary gland.\n\nWhen calves are exposed to the tuberculosis bacteria in the milk, the commonest lesions are noted in the lymph nodes at the junction of the neck and head around the throat. The main sign may be swelling of these nodes. The primary lesions in calves, however, are most frequently located in the lymph nodes along the intestinal tract.\n\nOther species of _Mycobacterium_ may complicate the diagnosis of tuberculosis in cattle caused by _M. bovis_, but cattle are resistant to these infections, and they rarely cause infections with clinical signs. _M. avium_, causing infection by ingestion and lesions in the intestinal tract of adult cows, and _M. tuberculosis_, the main cause of human tuberculosis, are 2 of these species. They cause the cattle to be sensitive to tuberculin testing and give false positive reactions when tests are being conducted to find cows with _M. bovis_ infections. These other bacteria are more important as causes of infection in swine, sheep, goats, and humans.\n\nLive, infected cattle are diagnosed as being infected with _M. bovis_ with the tuberculin test. The appropriate tuberculin is purified protein derivative (PPD), as it is specific and not costly to produce. In the US, the tuberculin is injected into the caudal fold of the tail near the tail head by a federally accredited veterinarian. A 0.1 ml dose of PPD is injected intradermally. Infected cows will have an allergic type reaction to the PPD at the injection site. The test is read in 72 hours by palpating the injection site for the allergic swelling. When sufficient swelling is found to indicate infection with mycobacteria, follow-up testing is usually performed by state officials to determine that the swelling is due to _M. bovis_ and not a different type of mycobacterium.\n\nNationwide, there is active surveillance at slaughter plants. State and federal meat inspectors check the lymph glands and other organs of each cow for signs of tuberculosis. When any signs suspicious of tuberculosis are found, tissues are collected and sent to the National Veterinary Services Laboratories for confirmation. If bovine tuberculosis is confirmed, trace-back studies are performed to find the herd of origin. The most effective means of control in a tuberculosis herd is to depopulate the entire herd and compensate the owners. Otherwise, the herd will be quarantined and tested repeatedly until all evidence of infection is eliminated.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease that can lurk for quite a while before rearing its head. Unfortunately, the best tests, as noted above, do not always detect this disease in its earliest stages.\n\nScience has been hard at work trying to develop a better test for this disease but has not yet succeeded.\n\nWildlife reservoirs, such as the brush-tailed opossums tend to be part of the problem with this disease. In brush-tailed opossums, bovine tuberculosis is usually a fulminating pulmonary disease that typically lasts 2 to 6 months. In the final stage of the disease, animals become disoriented, cannot climb, and may be seen wandering about in daylight.\n\nOnce this strain has been genotyped, it will be clearer how these herds became infected. I have not seen a report of the genotype of the situation.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/vetext/INF-DA/Tuberculosis.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - New Zealand (02): possum reservoir 20111130.3490\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: badger vaccination 20111014.3087\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (06): (IN) 20110924.2891\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (IN) 20110918.2839\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: alpaca, mastitis, implications 20110825.2588\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (04): England 20110723.2219\nBovine tuberculosis, porcine - UK: Wales 20110717.2170\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20110626.1959\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (AZ) ex Mexico 20110612.1793\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (03): England 20110430.1341\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (02): England 20110430.1332\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (CA) 20110429.1328\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - New Zealand 20110417.1202\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20110416.1196\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (Wales) badger control 20110328.0969\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20110322.0895\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (IN) 20110301.0670\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/tg/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-01-16 00:00:00", "2013-05-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taranaki", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opunake", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pavitt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1811709", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - UK (03): (England) control", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1811709", "date": "2013-05-11 23:08:29", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NEW ZEALAND\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 9 May 2013\nSource: Stuff.co.nz [edited]\nhttp://www.stuff.co.nz/taranaki-daily-news/lifestyle/8650750/TB-outbreak-investigation\n\n\nTaranaki's 6th case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed. The Animal Health Board (AHB) said last week that a herd near Inglewood was suspected of having the disease.\n\nThe confirmation this week of the infection brings to 4 the number of herds near Inglewood with the disease. Two herds near Opunake also have it.\n\nThe new infection near Inglewood related to movements of animals between the infected herds, and there was also a direct movement relationship between the 2 Opunake herds, AHB regional coordinator Frank Pavitt, of Hamilton, said. \"So we know why these herds have been infected.\"\n\nHe hoped that the Taranaki outbreak, in which the 1st case was detected in January 2013, would be confined to the 6 herds already identified.\n\n\"We hope we're coming to the end of our investigation and that we've identified all the infections that are present. But it's still a work in progress. It's a dynamic investigation, so we don't know when it will be fully completed.\"\n\nPavitt said movements from the herd where the infection had just been confirmed would now have to be examined.\n\nThe AHB is holding meetings for farmers within a 10-km radius of the infected herds in the Opunake and Inglewood areas on 21 May 2013.\n\nPavitt said it was contacting all farmers in the 2 areas about the meetings. They were being sent factsheets about the infections in their area and about the new annual testing regime for cattle and deer over 12 months of age that will now be set in place.\n\n[Byline: Sue O'dowd]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The primary cause of tuberculosis in cattle is the bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. This bacterium is in the same family as bacteria that cause Johne's disease and leprosy. Adult cattle are usually infected by inhaling invisible droplets containing the bacteria into their lungs, while pre-weaned calves are more often infected by drinking contaminated milk. The route of entry will ultimately determine the clinical signs of the disease.\n\nSince the bacteria are usually inhaled into the lungs in adult cows, the commonest clinical signs are related to pulmonary tuberculosis. Once the bacteria enter the lungs, they begin to multiply and generally spread to the lymph nodes near the lungs. At this primary site of infection, the lesions can remain quietly inactive or develop further depending on the ability of the cow to fight off the infection. When the immune system of the cow is fully activated, the infection may remain limited to the lungs and could go undetected for the productive life of the cow. If the infection over-powers the body defenses, the bacteria may be carried to other locations in the body in the lymph or blood circulation. New areas of infection often occur in the lungs, kidneys, liver, spleen, and the lymph nodes associated with these organs. In cases allowed to progress over an extended period of time, lesions may be present in the uterus or mammary gland.\n\nWhen calves are exposed to the tuberculosis bacteria in the milk, the commonest lesions are noted in the lymph nodes at the junction of the neck and head around the throat. The main sign may be swelling of these nodes. The primary lesions in calves, however, are most frequently located in the lymph nodes along the intestinal tract.\n\nOther species of _Mycobacterium_ may complicate the diagnosis of tuberculosis in cattle caused by _M. bovis_, but cattle are resistant to these infections, and they rarely cause infections with clinical signs. _M. avium_, causing infection by ingestion and lesions in the intestinal tract of adult cows, and _M. tuberculosis_, the main cause of human tuberculosis, are 2 of these species. They cause the cattle to be sensitive to tuberculin testing and give false positive reactions when tests are being conducted to find cows with _M. bovis_ infections. These other bacteria are more important as causes of infection in swine, sheep, goats, and humans.\n\nLive, infected cattle are diagnosed as being infected with _M. bovis_ with the tuberculin test. The appropriate tuberculin is purified protein derivative (PPD), as it is specific and not costly to produce. In the US, the tuberculin is injected into the caudal fold of the tail near the tail head by a federally accredited veterinarian. A 0.1 ml dose of PPD is injected intradermally. Infected cows will have an allergic type reaction to the PPD at the injection site. The test is read in 72 hours by palpating the injection site for the allergic swelling. When sufficient swelling is found to indicate infection with mycobacteria, follow-up testing is usually performed by state officials to determine that the swelling is due to _M. bovis_ and not a different type of mycobacterium.\n\nNationwide, there is active surveillance at slaughter plants. State and federal meat inspectors check the lymph glands and other organs of each cow for signs of tuberculosis. When any signs suspicious of tuberculosis are found, tissues are collected and sent to the National Veterinary Services Laboratories for confirmation. If bovine tuberculosis is confirmed, trace-back studies are performed to find the herd of origin. The most effective means of control in a tuberculosis herd is to depopulate the entire herd and compensate the owners. Otherwise, the herd will be quarantined and tested repeatedly until all evidence of infection is eliminated.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease that can lurk for quite a while before rearing its head. Unfortunately, the best tests, as noted above, do not always detect this disease in its earliest stages.\n\nScience has been hard at work trying to develop a better test for this disease but has not yet succeeded.\n\nWildlife reservoirs, such as the brush-tailed opossums tend to be part of the problem with this disease. In brush-tailed opossums, bovine tuberculosis is usually a fulminating pulmonary disease that typically lasts 2 to 6 months. In the final stage of the disease, animals become disoriented, cannot climb, and may be seen wandering about in daylight.\n\nOnce this strain has been genotyped, it will be clearer how these herds became infected. I have not seen a report of the genotype of the situation.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/vetext/INF-DA/Tuberculosis.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - New Zealand (02): possum reservoir 20111130.3490\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: badger vaccination 20111014.3087\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (06): (IN) 20110924.2891\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (IN) 20110918.2839\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: alpaca, mastitis, implications 20110825.2588\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (04): England 20110723.2219\nBovine tuberculosis, porcine - UK: Wales 20110717.2170\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20110626.1959\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (AZ) ex Mexico 20110612.1793\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (03): England 20110430.1341\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (02): England 20110430.1332\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (CA) 20110429.1328\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - New Zealand 20110417.1202\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20110416.1196\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (Wales) badger control 20110328.0969\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20110322.0895\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (IN) 20110301.0670\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/tg/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-01-16 00:00:00", "2013-05-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taranaki", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opunake", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pavitt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1797812", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (England) seal, 1st rep", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1797812", "date": "2013-05-11 23:08:29", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NEW ZEALAND\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 9 May 2013\nSource: Stuff.co.nz [edited]\nhttp://www.stuff.co.nz/taranaki-daily-news/lifestyle/8650750/TB-outbreak-investigation\n\n\nTaranaki's 6th case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed. The Animal Health Board (AHB) said last week that a herd near Inglewood was suspected of having the disease.\n\nThe confirmation this week of the infection brings to 4 the number of herds near Inglewood with the disease. Two herds near Opunake also have it.\n\nThe new infection near Inglewood related to movements of animals between the infected herds, and there was also a direct movement relationship between the 2 Opunake herds, AHB regional coordinator Frank Pavitt, of Hamilton, said. \"So we know why these herds have been infected.\"\n\nHe hoped that the Taranaki outbreak, in which the 1st case was detected in January 2013, would be confined to the 6 herds already identified.\n\n\"We hope we're coming to the end of our investigation and that we've identified all the infections that are present. But it's still a work in progress. It's a dynamic investigation, so we don't know when it will be fully completed.\"\n\nPavitt said movements from the herd where the infection had just been confirmed would now have to be examined.\n\nThe AHB is holding meetings for farmers within a 10-km radius of the infected herds in the Opunake and Inglewood areas on 21 May 2013.\n\nPavitt said it was contacting all farmers in the 2 areas about the meetings. They were being sent factsheets about the infections in their area and about the new annual testing regime for cattle and deer over 12 months of age that will now be set in place.\n\n[Byline: Sue O'dowd]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The primary cause of tuberculosis in cattle is the bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. This bacterium is in the same family as bacteria that cause Johne's disease and leprosy. Adult cattle are usually infected by inhaling invisible droplets containing the bacteria into their lungs, while pre-weaned calves are more often infected by drinking contaminated milk. The route of entry will ultimately determine the clinical signs of the disease.\n\nSince the bacteria are usually inhaled into the lungs in adult cows, the commonest clinical signs are related to pulmonary tuberculosis. Once the bacteria enter the lungs, they begin to multiply and generally spread to the lymph nodes near the lungs. At this primary site of infection, the lesions can remain quietly inactive or develop further depending on the ability of the cow to fight off the infection. When the immune system of the cow is fully activated, the infection may remain limited to the lungs and could go undetected for the productive life of the cow. If the infection over-powers the body defenses, the bacteria may be carried to other locations in the body in the lymph or blood circulation. New areas of infection often occur in the lungs, kidneys, liver, spleen, and the lymph nodes associated with these organs. In cases allowed to progress over an extended period of time, lesions may be present in the uterus or mammary gland.\n\nWhen calves are exposed to the tuberculosis bacteria in the milk, the commonest lesions are noted in the lymph nodes at the junction of the neck and head around the throat. The main sign may be swelling of these nodes. The primary lesions in calves, however, are most frequently located in the lymph nodes along the intestinal tract.\n\nOther species of _Mycobacterium_ may complicate the diagnosis of tuberculosis in cattle caused by _M. bovis_, but cattle are resistant to these infections, and they rarely cause infections with clinical signs. _M. avium_, causing infection by ingestion and lesions in the intestinal tract of adult cows, and _M. tuberculosis_, the main cause of human tuberculosis, are 2 of these species. They cause the cattle to be sensitive to tuberculin testing and give false positive reactions when tests are being conducted to find cows with _M. bovis_ infections. These other bacteria are more important as causes of infection in swine, sheep, goats, and humans.\n\nLive, infected cattle are diagnosed as being infected with _M. bovis_ with the tuberculin test. The appropriate tuberculin is purified protein derivative (PPD), as it is specific and not costly to produce. In the US, the tuberculin is injected into the caudal fold of the tail near the tail head by a federally accredited veterinarian. A 0.1 ml dose of PPD is injected intradermally. Infected cows will have an allergic type reaction to the PPD at the injection site. The test is read in 72 hours by palpating the injection site for the allergic swelling. When sufficient swelling is found to indicate infection with mycobacteria, follow-up testing is usually performed by state officials to determine that the swelling is due to _M. bovis_ and not a different type of mycobacterium.\n\nNationwide, there is active surveillance at slaughter plants. State and federal meat inspectors check the lymph glands and other organs of each cow for signs of tuberculosis. When any signs suspicious of tuberculosis are found, tissues are collected and sent to the National Veterinary Services Laboratories for confirmation. If bovine tuberculosis is confirmed, trace-back studies are performed to find the herd of origin. The most effective means of control in a tuberculosis herd is to depopulate the entire herd and compensate the owners. Otherwise, the herd will be quarantined and tested repeatedly until all evidence of infection is eliminated.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease that can lurk for quite a while before rearing its head. Unfortunately, the best tests, as noted above, do not always detect this disease in its earliest stages.\n\nScience has been hard at work trying to develop a better test for this disease but has not yet succeeded.\n\nWildlife reservoirs, such as the brush-tailed opossums tend to be part of the problem with this disease. In brush-tailed opossums, bovine tuberculosis is usually a fulminating pulmonary disease that typically lasts 2 to 6 months. In the final stage of the disease, animals become disoriented, cannot climb, and may be seen wandering about in daylight.\n\nOnce this strain has been genotyped, it will be clearer how these herds became infected. I have not seen a report of the genotype of the situation.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/vetext/INF-DA/Tuberculosis.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - The Animal Health Board (AHB) said last week that a herd near Inglewood was suspected of having the disease.\n\nThe confirmation this week of the infection brings to 4 the number of herds near Inglewood with the disease. Two herds near Opunake also have it.\n\nThe new infection near Inglewood related to movements of animals between the infected herds, and there was also a direct movement relationship between the 2 Opunake herds, AHB regional coordinator Frank Pavitt, of Hamilton, said. \"So we know why these herds have been infected.\"\n\nHe hoped that the Taranaki outbreak, in which the 1st case was detected in January 2013, would be confined to the 6 herds already identified.\n\n\"We hope we're coming to the end of our investigation and that we've identified all the infections that are present. But it's still a work in progress. It's a dynamic investigation, so we don't know when it will be fully completed.\"\n\nPavitt said movements from the herd where the infection had just been confirmed would now have to be examined.\n\nThe AHB is holding meetings for farmers within a 10-km radius of the infected herds in the Opunake and Inglewood areas on 21 May 2013.\n\nPavitt said it was contacting all farmers in the 2 areas about the meetings. They were being sent factsheets about the infections in their area and about the new annual testing regime for cattle and deer over 12 months of age that will now be set in place.\n\n[Byline: Sue O'dowd]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The primary cause of tuberculosis in cattle is the bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. This bacterium is in the same family as bacteria that cause Johne's disease and leprosy. Adult cattle are usually infected by inhaling invisible droplets containing the bacteria into their lungs, while pre-weaned calves are more often infected by drinking contaminated milk. The route of entry will ultimately determine the clinical signs of the disease.\n\nSince the bacteria are usually inhaled into the lungs in adult cows, the commonest clinical signs are related to pulmonary tuberculosis. Once the bacteria enter the lungs, they begin to multiply and generally spread to the lymph nodes near the lungs. At this primary site of infection, the lesions can remain quietly inactive or develop further depending on the ability of the cow to fight off the infection. When the immune system of the cow is fully activated, the infection may remain limited to the lungs and could go undetected for the productive life of the cow. If the infection over-powers the body defenses, the bacteria may be carried to other locations in the body in the lymph or blood circulation. New areas of infection often occur in the lungs, kidneys, liver, spleen, and the lymph nodes associated with these organs. In cases allowed to progress over an extended period of time, lesions may be present in the uterus or mammary gland.\n\nWhen calves are exposed to the tuberculosis bacteria in the milk, the commonest lesions are noted in the lymph nodes at the junction of the neck and head around the throat. The main sign may be swelling of these nodes. The primary lesions in calves, however, are most frequently located in the lymph nodes along the intestinal tract.\n\nOther species of _Mycobacterium_ may complicate the diagnosis of tuberculosis in cattle caused by _M. bovis_, but cattle are resistant to these infections, and they rarely cause infections with clinical signs. _M. avium_, causing infection by ingestion and lesions in the intestinal tract of adult cows, and _M. tuberculosis_, the main cause of human tuberculosis, are 2 of these species. They cause the cattle to be sensitive to tuberculin testing and give false positive reactions when tests are being conducted to find cows with _M. bovis_ infections. These other bacteria are more important as causes of infection in swine, sheep, goats, and humans.\n\nLive, infected cattle are diagnosed as being infected with _M. bovis_ with the tuberculin test. The appropriate tuberculin is purified protein derivative (PPD), as it is specific and not costly to produce. In the US, the tuberculin is injected into the caudal fold of the tail near the tail head by a federally accredited veterinarian. A 0.1 ml dose of PPD is injected intradermally. Infected cows will have an allergic type reaction to the PPD at the injection site. The test is read in 72 hours by palpating the injection site for the allergic swelling. When sufficient swelling is found to indicate infection with mycobacteria, follow-up testing is usually performed by state officials to determine that the swelling is due to _M. bovis_ and not a different type of mycobacterium.\n\nNationwide, there is active surveillance at slaughter plants. State and federal meat inspectors check the lymph glands and other organs of each cow for signs of tuberculosis. When any signs suspicious of tuberculosis are found, tissues are collected and sent to the National Veterinary Services Laboratories for confirmation. If bovine tuberculosis is confirmed, trace-back studies are performed to find the herd of origin. The most effective means of control in a tuberculosis herd is to depopulate the entire herd and compensate the owners. Otherwise, the herd will be quarantined and tested repeatedly until all evidence of infection is eliminated.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease that can lurk for quite a while before rearing its head. Unfortunately, the best tests, as noted above, do not always detect this disease in its earliest stages.\n\nScience has been hard at work trying to develop a better test for this disease but has not yet succeeded.\n\nWildlife reservoirs, such as the brush-tailed opossums tend to be part of the problem with this disease. In brush-tailed opossums, bovine tuberculosis is usually a fulminating pulmonary disease that typically lasts 2 to 6 months. In the final stage of the disease, animals become disoriented, cannot climb, and may be seen wandering about in daylight.\n\nOnce this strain has been genotyped, it will be clearer how these herds became infected. I have not seen a report of the genotype of the situation.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/vetext/INF-DA/Tuberculosis.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (ND) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1775410", "date": "2013-05-11 23:08:29", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NEW ZEALAND\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 9 May 2013\nSource: Stuff.co.nz [edited]\nhttp://www.stuff.co.nz/taranaki-daily-news/lifestyle/8650750/TB-outbreak-investigation\n\n\nTaranaki's 6th case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed. The Animal Health Board (AHB) said last week that a herd near Inglewood was suspected of having the disease.\n\nThe confirmation this week of the infection brings to 4 the number of herds near Inglewood with the disease. Two herds near Opunake also have it.\n\nThe new infection near Inglewood related to movements of animals between the infected herds, and there was also a direct movement relationship between the 2 Opunake herds, AHB regional coordinator Frank Pavitt, of Hamilton, said. \"So we know why these herds have been infected.\"\n\nHe hoped that the Taranaki outbreak, in which the 1st case was detected in January 2013, would be confined to the 6 herds already identified.\n\n\"We hope we're coming to the end of our investigation and that we've identified all the infections that are present. But it's still a work in progress. It's a dynamic investigation, so we don't know when it will be fully completed.\"\n\nPavitt said movements from the herd where the infection had just been confirmed would now have to be examined.\n\nThe AHB is holding meetings for farmers within a 10-km radius of the infected herds in the Opunake and Inglewood areas on 21 May 2013.\n\nPavitt said it was contacting all farmers in the 2 areas about the meetings. They were being sent factsheets about the infections in their area and about the new annual testing regime for cattle and deer over 12 months of age that will now be set in place.\n\n[Byline: Sue O'dowd]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The primary cause of tuberculosis in cattle is the bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. This bacterium is in the same family as bacteria that cause Johne's disease and leprosy. Adult cattle are usually infected by inhaling invisible droplets containing the bacteria into their lungs, while pre-weaned calves are more often infected by drinking contaminated milk. The route of entry will ultimately determine the clinical signs of the disease.\n\nSince the bacteria are usually inhaled into the lungs in adult cows, the commonest clinical signs are related to pulmonary tuberculosis. Once the bacteria enter the lungs, they begin to multiply and generally spread to the lymph nodes near the lungs. At this primary site of infection, the lesions can remain quietly inactive or develop further depending on the ability of the cow to fight off the infection. When the immune system of the cow is fully activated, the infection may remain limited to the lungs and could go undetected for the productive life of the cow. If the infection over-powers the body defenses, the bacteria may be carried to other locations in the body in the lymph or blood circulation. New areas of infection often occur in the lungs, kidneys, liver, spleen, and the lymph nodes associated with these organs. In cases allowed to progress over an extended period of time, lesions may be present in the uterus or mammary gland.\n\nWhen calves are exposed to the tuberculosis bacteria in the milk, the commonest lesions are noted in the lymph nodes at the junction of the neck and head around the throat. The main sign may be swelling of these nodes. The primary lesions in calves, however, are most frequently located in the lymph nodes along the intestinal tract.\n\nOther species of _Mycobacterium_ may complicate the diagnosis of tuberculosis in cattle caused by _M. bovis_, but cattle are resistant to these infections, and they rarely cause infections with clinical signs. _M. avium_, causing infection by ingestion and lesions in the intestinal tract of adult cows, and _M. tuberculosis_, the main cause of human tuberculosis, are 2 of these species. They cause the cattle to be sensitive to tuberculin testing and give false positive reactions when tests are being conducted to find cows with _M. bovis_ infections. These other bacteria are more important as causes of infection in swine, sheep, goats, and humans.\n\nLive, infected cattle are diagnosed as being infected with _M. bovis_ with the tuberculin test. The appropriate tuberculin is purified protein derivative (PPD), as it is specific and not costly to produce. In the US, the tuberculin is injected into the caudal fold of the tail near the tail head by a federally accredited veterinarian. A 0.1 ml dose of PPD is injected intradermally. Infected cows will have an allergic type reaction to the PPD at the injection site. The test is read in 72 hours by palpating the injection site for the allergic swelling. When sufficient swelling is found to indicate infection with mycobacteria, follow-up testing is usually performed by state officials to determine that the swelling is due to _M. bovis_ and not a different type of mycobacterium.\n\nNationwide, there is active surveillance at slaughter plants. State and federal meat inspectors check the lymph glands and other organs of each cow for signs of tuberculosis. When any signs suspicious of tuberculosis are found, tissues are collected and sent to the National Veterinary Services Laboratories for confirmation. If bovine tuberculosis is confirmed, trace-back studies are performed to find the herd of origin. The most effective means of control in a tuberculosis herd is to depopulate the entire herd and compensate the owners. Otherwise, the herd will be quarantined and tested repeatedly until all evidence of infection is eliminated.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease that can lurk for quite a while before rearing its head. Unfortunately, the best tests, as noted above, do not always detect this disease in its earliest stages.\n\nScience has been hard at work trying to develop a better test for this disease but has not yet succeeded.\n\nWildlife reservoirs, such as the brush-tailed opossums tend to be part of the problem with this disease. In brush-tailed opossums, bovine tuberculosis is usually a fulminating pulmonary disease that typically lasts 2 to 6 months. In the final stage of the disease, animals become disoriented, cannot climb, and may be seen wandering about in daylight.\n\nOnce this strain has been genotyped, it will be clearer how these herds became infected. I have not seen a report of the genotype of the situation.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/vetext/INF-DA/Tuberculosis.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - New Zealand (02): possum reservoir 20111130.3490\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: badger vaccination 20111014.3087\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (06): (IN) 20110924.2891\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (IN) 20110918.2839\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: alpaca, mastitis, implications 20110825.2588\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (04): England 20110723.2219\nBovine tuberculosis, porcine - UK: Wales 20110717.2170\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20110626.1959\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (AZ) ex Mexico 20110612.1793\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (03): England 20110430.1341\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (02): England 20110430.1332\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (CA) 20110429.1328\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - New Zealand 20110417.1202\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20110416.1196\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (Wales) badger control 20110328.0969\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20110322.0895\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (IN) 20110301.0670\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/tg/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-01-16 00:00:00", "2013-05-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taranaki", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opunake", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pavitt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1735824", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - Australia (02): (QL) ex Papua New Guinea, XDR, fatal, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1735824", "date": "2013-05-11 23:08:29", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NEW ZEALAND\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 9 May 2013\nSource: Stuff.co.nz [edited]\nhttp://www.stuff.co.nz/taranaki-daily-news/lifestyle/8650750/TB-outbreak-investigation\n\n\nTaranaki's 6th case of bovine tuberculosis has been confirmed. The Animal Health Board (AHB) said last week that a herd near Inglewood was suspected of having the disease.\n\nThe confirmation this week of the infection brings to 4 the number of herds near Inglewood with the disease. Two herds near Opunake also have it.\n\nThe new infection near Inglewood related to movements of animals between the infected herds, and there was also a direct movement relationship between the 2 Opunake herds, AHB regional coordinator Frank Pavitt, of Hamilton, said. \"So we know why these herds have been infected.\"\n\nHe hoped that the Taranaki outbreak, in which the 1st case was detected in January 2013, would be confined to the 6 herds already identified.\n\n\"We hope we're coming to the end of our investigation and that we've identified all the infections that are present. But it's still a work in progress. It's a dynamic investigation, so we don't know when it will be fully completed.\"\n\nPavitt said movements from the herd where the infection had just been confirmed would now have to be examined.\n\nThe AHB is holding meetings for farmers within a 10-km radius of the infected herds in the Opunake and Inglewood areas on 21 May 2013.\n\nPavitt said it was contacting all farmers in the 2 areas about the meetings. They were being sent factsheets about the infections in their area and about the new annual testing regime for cattle and deer over 12 months of age that will now be set in place.\n\n[Byline: Sue O'dowd]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The primary cause of tuberculosis in cattle is the bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. This bacterium is in the same family as bacteria that cause Johne's disease and leprosy. Adult cattle are usually infected by inhaling invisible droplets containing the bacteria into their lungs, while pre-weaned calves are more often infected by drinking contaminated milk. The route of entry will ultimately determine the clinical signs of the disease.\n\nSince the bacteria are usually inhaled into the lungs in adult cows, the commonest clinical signs are related to pulmonary tuberculosis. Once the bacteria enter the lungs, they begin to multiply and generally spread to the lymph nodes near the lungs. At this primary site of infection, the lesions can remain quietly inactive or develop further depending on the ability of the cow to fight off the infection. When the immune system of the cow is fully activated, the infection may remain limited to the lungs and could go undetected for the productive life of the cow. If the infection over-powers the body defenses, the bacteria may be carried to other locations in the body in the lymph or blood circulation. New areas of infection often occur in the lungs, kidneys, liver, spleen, and the lymph nodes associated with these organs. In cases allowed to progress over an extended period of time, lesions may be present in the uterus or mammary gland.\n\nWhen calves are exposed to the tuberculosis bacteria in the milk, the commonest lesions are noted in the lymph nodes at the junction of the neck and head around the throat. The main sign may be swelling of these nodes. The primary lesions in calves, however, are most frequently located in the lymph nodes along the intestinal tract.\n\nOther species of _Mycobacterium_ may complicate the diagnosis of tuberculosis in cattle caused by _M. bovis_, but cattle are resistant to these infections, and they rarely cause infections with clinical signs. _M. avium_, causing infection by ingestion and lesions in the intestinal tract of adult cows, and _M. tuberculosis_, the main cause of human tuberculosis, are 2 of these species. They cause the cattle to be sensitive to tuberculin testing and give false positive reactions when tests are being conducted to find cows with _M. bovis_ infections. These other bacteria are more important as causes of infection in swine, sheep, goats, and humans.\n\nLive, infected cattle are diagnosed as being infected with _M. bovis_ with the tuberculin test. The appropriate tuberculin is purified protein derivative (PPD), as it is specific and not costly to produce. In the US, the tuberculin is injected into the caudal fold of the tail near the tail head by a federally accredited veterinarian. A 0.1 ml dose of PPD is injected intradermally. Infected cows will have an allergic type reaction to the PPD at the injection site. The test is read in 72 hours by palpating the injection site for the allergic swelling. When sufficient swelling is found to indicate infection with mycobacteria, follow-up testing is usually performed by state officials to determine that the swelling is due to _M. bovis_ and not a different type of mycobacterium.\n\nNationwide, there is active surveillance at slaughter plants. State and federal meat inspectors check the lymph glands and other organs of each cow for signs of tuberculosis. When any signs suspicious of tuberculosis are found, tissues are collected and sent to the National Veterinary Services Laboratories for confirmation. If bovine tuberculosis is confirmed, trace-back studies are performed to find the herd of origin. The most effective means of control in a tuberculosis herd is to depopulate the entire herd and compensate the owners. Otherwise, the herd will be quarantined and tested repeatedly until all evidence of infection is eliminated.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease that can lurk for quite a while before rearing its head. Unfortunately, the best tests, as noted above, do not always detect this disease in its earliest stages.\n\nScience has been hard at work trying to develop a better test for this disease but has not yet succeeded.\n\nWildlife reservoirs, such as the brush-tailed opossums tend to be part of the problem with this disease. In brush-tailed opossums, bovine tuberculosis is usually a fulminating pulmonary disease that typically lasts 2 to 6 months. In the final stage of the disease, animals become disoriented, cannot climb, and may be seen wandering about in daylight.\n\nOnce this strain has been genotyped, it will be clearer how these herds became infected. I have not seen a report of the genotype of the situation.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.vetmed.ucdavis.edu/vetext/INF-DA/Tuberculosis.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiF.]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - This bacterium is in the same family as bacteria that cause Johne's disease and leprosy. Adult cattle are usually infected by inhaling invisible droplets containing the bacteria into their lungs, while pre-weaned calves are more often infected by drinking contaminated milk. The route of entry will ultimately determine the clinical signs of the disease.\n\nSince the bacteria are usually inhaled into the lungs in adult cows, the commonest clinical signs are related to pulmonary tuberculosis. Once the bacteria enter the lungs, they begin to multiply and generally spread to the lymph nodes near the lungs. At this primary site of infection, the lesions can remain quietly inactive or develop further depending on the ability of the cow to fight off the infection. When the immune system of the cow is fully activated, the infection may remain limited to the lungs and could go undetected for the productive life of the cow. If the infection over-powers the body defenses, the bacteria may be carried to other locations in the body in the lymph or blood circulation. New areas of infection often occur in the lungs, kidneys, liver, spleen, and the lymph nodes associated with these organs. In cases allowed to progress over an extended period of time, lesions may be present in the uterus or mammary gland.\n\nWhen calves are exposed to the tuberculosis bacteria in the milk, the commonest lesions are noted in the lymph nodes at the junction of the neck and head around the throat. The main sign may be swelling of these nodes. The primary lesions in calves, however, are most frequently located in the lymph nodes along the intestinal tract.\n\nOther species of _Mycobacterium_ may complicate the diagnosis of tuberculosis in cattle caused by _M. bovis_, but cattle are resistant to these infections, and they rarely cause infections with clinical signs. _M. avium_, causing infection by ingestion and lesions in the intestinal tract of adult cows, and _M. tuberculosis_, the main cause of human tuberculosis, are 2 of these species. They cause the cattle to be sensitive to tuberculin testing and give false positive reactions when tests are being conducted to find cows with _M. bovis_ infections. These other bacteria are more important as causes of infection in swine, sheep, goats, and humans.\n\nLive, infected cattle are diagnosed as being infected with _M. bovis_ with the tuberculin test. The appropriate tuberculin is purified protein derivative (PPD), as it is specific and not costly to produce. In the US, the tuberculin is injected into the caudal fold of the tail near the tail head by a federally accredited veterinarian. A 0.1 ml dose of PPD is injected intradermally. Infected cows will have an allergic type reaction to the PPD at the injection site. The test is read in 72 hours by palpating the injection site for the allergic swelling. When sufficient swelling is found to indicate infection with mycobacteria, follow-up testing is usually performed by state officials to determine that the swelling is due to _M. bovis_ and not a different type of mycobacterium.\n\nNationwide, there is active surveillance at slaughter plants. State and federal meat inspectors check the lymph glands and other organs of each cow for signs of tuberculosis. When any signs suspicious of tuberculosis are found, tissues are collected and sent to the National Veterinary Services Laboratories for confirmation. If bovine tuberculosis is confirmed, trace-back studies are performed to find the herd of origin. The most effective means of control in a tuberculosis herd is to depopulate the entire herd and compensate the owners. Otherwise, the herd will be quarantined and tested repeatedly until all evidence of infection is eliminated.\n\nTuberculosis is a slow, insidious disease that can lurk for quite a while before rearing its head. Unfortunately, the best tests, as noted above, do not always detect this disease in its earliest stages.\n\nScience has been hard at work trying to develop a better test for this disease but has not yet succeeded.\n\nWildlife reservoirs, such as the brush-tailed opossums tend to be part of the problem with this disease. In brush-tailed opossums, bovine tuberculosis is usually a fulminating pulmonary disease that typically lasts 2 to 6 months. In the final stage of the disease, animals become disoriented, cannot climb, and may be seen wandering about in daylight.\n\nOnce this strain has been genotyped, it will be clearer how these herds became infected.
