As in this report, most cases of TB today are caused by organisms which are not drug-resistant and which can be cured using a standard treatment with combination of anti-TB drugs for at least 6 months [12]. Patients on treatment only require isolation until they are no longer infectious. Given that Beijing strains are particularly transmissible and often exhibit multi-drug resistance, France and other European countries are concerned with Beijing strain family of _M. tuberculosis_ [13]. Schools should be integrated in nation-wide surveillance systems for TB in France.\n\n[References are available in the URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPro-MED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[When a person with pulmonary, especially cavitary, or laryngeal tuberculosis (TB) coughs, sneezes, speaks, or sings, droplet nuclei containing _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ can become airborne. Depending on the environment, these tiny particles (1-5 microns in diameter) can remain suspended for hours, and can be carried by air currents. If another person inhales these droplet nuclei, transmission may occur.\n\nThe probability that TB will be transmitted depends on the infectiousness of the person with TB (the number of organisms expelled into the air), the immune competence of the person exposed, the environment in which exposure occurred, the duration of exposure, and the virulence of the organism. Persons at highest risk for becoming infected with _M. tuberculosis_ are those having prolonged, frequent, or intense contact with a person with infectious TB. Close contacts include family members, roommates, friends, coworkers, or others.\n\nPatients with laryngeal tuberculosis, an uncommon complication of pulmonary tuberculosis, are thought to be particularly contagious; although it is possible that concomitant far-advance pulmonary tuberculosis in these patients contributes to their infectivity (Braden CR, et al. Infectiousness of a University Student with Laryngeal and Cavitary Tuberculosis. Clin Infect Dis 1995; 21: 565-70).\n\nMolecular typing of _M. tuberculosis_ strains in recent years has shown that a group of strains known as \"Beijing,\" which have a similar genotype, are most prevalent in Asia but have been found worldwide; these strains predominate in some geographic areas, and have caused large outbreaks of tuberculosis, sometimes involving multidrug resistance in some regions (Glynn JR, Whiteley J, Bifani PJ, Kremer K, van Soolingen D. Worldwide Occurrence of Beijing/W Strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis: A Systematic Review. Emerg Infect Dis. 2002 August; 8(8): 843-49. Available at: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2732522/). One multidrug-resistant strain, designated \"W,\" belonging to the Beijing group, was found in New York City in the early 1990s and caused large institutional outbreaks of tuberculosis in the United States (Bifani PJ, Mathema B, Liu Z, Moghazeh SL, Shopsin B, Tempalski B, et al. Identification of a W variant outbreak of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ via population-based molecular epidemiology. JAMA. 1999;282:2321-7. Available at: http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=192231).\n\nNumerous outbreaks of tuberculosis have been reported in schools. Just a brief Internet search disclosed 9 relatively recent reports of school outbreaks:\n(http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/1258456.stm,\nhttp://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/tuberculosis-outbreaks-at-palm-beach-county-scho-1/nL7f4/,\nhttp://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/education/tuberculosis-hits-a-second-school-delray-elementar/nL7cw/,\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-36016/Doctors-fight-major-TB-outbreak-school.html,\nhttp://www.bakkentoday.com/event/article/id/249411/publisher_ID/40/,\nhttp://health.usnews.com/health-news/managing-your-healthcare/treatment/articles/2011/10/14/tb-outbreaks-in-texas-schools-show-disease-still-a-threat,\nhttp://www.independent.ie/national-news/pupils-tested-after-tb-outbreak-at-school-3113099.html,\nhttp://www.nbcdfw.com/news/health/State-Health-Officials-Meet-With-Families-Over-Tuberculosis-Outbreak-130746098.html, and\nhttp://vaccinenewsdaily.com/united-states/321007-tb-cases-reported-at-two-san-diego-county-schools/).\n\nTransmission rates in classrooms have varied from 10 to 83 percent (Braden CR, et al.\nInfectiousness of a University Student with Laryngeal and Cavitary Tuberculosis\nClin Infect Dis 1995; 21: 565-70). High rates of transmission have been reported to occur following even minimal exposure to an infectious patient or in an environment thought not to be conducive to transmission of tuberculosis (Braden CR, Investigative Team. Infectiousness of a university student with laryngeal and cavitary tuberculosis. Clin Infect Dis 1995;21:565-70; and Hoge CW, Fisher L, Donnell HD Jr, et al. Risk factors for transmission of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ in a primary school outbreak: lack of racial difference in susceptibility to infection. Am J Epidemiol 1994;139:520-30). As in the above Eurosurveillance report, some investigators have postulated that the strains involved in such outbreaks may be especially virulent (Valnay SE, Sanchez MPC, Shinnick TS, et al. An outbreak involving extensive transmission of a virulent strain of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. New Engl J Med 1998; 338:633-9. Available at:\nhttp://www.hawaii.edu/hivandaids/Outbreak%20Involving%20Extensive%20Transmission%20of%20a%20Virulent%20Strain%20of%20Mycobacterium%20TB.pdf).\n\nIn 1965, we described a large outbreak of tuberculosis that started in the fall of 1962 among medical students (11 cases) and employees of the medical school (11 cases) and medical college hospital (5 cases) (Alpert ME, Levison ME. An epidemic of tuberculosis in a medical school. N Engl J Med 1965;272:7l8-21). In the medical school classes in which cases of tuberculosis occurred, the tuberculin skin test reactivity rose from 16 percent on average among medical students at admission to medical school to 69-90 percent among those students that had not been vaccinated with BCG on admission. No one source was identified in this medical school out, but school outbreaks should serve as a reminder that students, especially young children, serve as indicators of recent transmission that warrants prompt investigation for a source with active tuberculosis in their environment so that further transmission can be rapidly interrupted.\n\nMarseille, located on the southeast Mediterranean coast of France, is the 2nd largest city in France, after Paris, with a population of 852 395 within its administrative limits (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marseille). Marseille is the capital of the Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur region, as well as the capital of the Bouches-du-Rhone department.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of France can be seen at http://healthmap.org/r/12KJ. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nTuberculosis - Canada: (ON) exposure, nosocomial, infants 20120806.1230363\nTuberculosis - USA: (FL) fatal, homeless shelter 20120710.1196037\n2011\n----\nTuberculosis - Ireland: (LN) prison, hospital 20111024.3165\nTuberculosis, latent, nosocomial, infants - Italy (03): (Rome) 20110901.2677\nTuberculosis, latent, nosocomial, infants - Italy (02): (Rome) 20110830.2668\nTuberculosis, latent, nosocomial, infants - Italy: (Rome) 20110825.2587\n2010\n----\nTuberculosis - Canada: (NU), Inuit 20101008.3659\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\n2009\n----\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA: (IL) susp. 20090412.1398\nTuberculosis, airplane exposure - USA ex Germany 20090317.1081\n.................................................mpp/ml/ejp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-01-10 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1972-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Marseille", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rome", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brignatz J", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1487921", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Netherlands: (GE) bovine, susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1487921", "date": "2012-11-22 18:07:09", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (MAYENNE, ARDENNES)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Mayenne\n[2] Ardennes\n\n******\n[1] Mayenne\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: Ouest-France [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/d5oeh9r\n\n\nAn outbreak of bovine tuberculosis has been identified and confirmed by laboratory test in a cattle farm located in the municipality of Asse-le-Beranger, in the canton of Evron, Mayenne department.\n\nThe same farm was found infected during a previous outbreak, detected on the farm in 2006. This led to the slaughter of the entire stock, as well as cleaning and disinfection measures according to regulations, said the prefecture of Mayenne.\n\nThe whole herd, consisting of 180 cattle, has been declared as infected by the prefecture and was placed under quarantine on 4 Oct 2012. All animals were slaughtered between 13-16 Nov 2012, following their evaluation. The premises will be subject to double disinfection procedures prior to allowing for repopulation.\n\nCompensation for the slaughtered animals and the costs of disinfection will be fully covered by the State. Epidemiological investigations have identified farms in contact with this new focus; they are being monitored.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (_Mycobacterium bovis_ infection) is potentially transmissible to man. It is reminded that, on the national level, the percentage of TB cases in humans due infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ is minimal [out of the total TB cases). Theses cases involve people in close contact with confined excretory animals or consumption of raw [unpasteurized] milk from animal shedders.\n\nThe vast majority of cases of human tuberculosis is due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the specific TB bacterium of human and primates. The health authorities in charge of human health (Health Region Pays de la Loire) will carry out investigation and tests to exclude infection of the breeder concerned and his family.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ardennes\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: L'union L'Ardennais [in French, machine trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/ardennes/la-tuberculose-bovine-frappe-les-ardennes\n\n\nTwo cases of bovine tuberculosis [BovTB] were detected in Semide and Chehery, Ardennes department. This led to the slaughter of about 400 cattle. France is approaching the threshold which, if crossed, will challenge its status of country officially declared \"free\" of the disease [see commentary below]. It is true that we touch on a very sensitive subject because of the economic impact at the national level.\n\nThe 1st warning was recorded in June [2012], in Semide, resulting in the regulatory slaughter of the entire herd of 40 heads. The 2nd, one month later, in Chehery, where 350 cattle were sent to the slaughterhouse. Since then, fingers are crossed that the veterinary services detectives will discover the source of infection.\n\n\"Bovine TB has existed for decades,\" says Arthur Tirado, veterinarian and director of training DDCSPP (Departmental directorate of social cohesion and the protection of people, under the direction of veterinary services, DFS), \"but the fight against this disease has borne fruit since the early 2000s, when France was recognized as BovTB free. This means that despite a few cases, at least 99.9 percent of the French herds are not infected. For now, in the Ardennes, our main concern is to identify the origin of the disease\".\n\nTo this end, DFS conducted a survey of all animals sold or introduced into each of 2 herds concerned. No result yet. \"What we know so far is that 2 different strains were found in the Ardennes; thus there has been no contamination between the 2 herds. The studies are continuing to discover the source of infection\".\n\nThe owners of the slaughtered herds were compensated on the real value of their stock determined by 2 experts from a list, chosen by the breeder.\n\n[Byline: JC Roussel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[According to a recently published referenced paper (Ref 1; thanks to Susan Baekeland for bringing this to our attention), France has been experiencing a resurgence of BovTB since 2004. The rate of herd prevalence increased from 0.02 percent in 2004 to 0.07 percent in 2010. This increase, if continuing, could jeopardize the free status of France.\n\nMoreover, the distribution of the disease on French territory is heterogeneous, with 4 geographic regions infected (Cote-d'Or, Dordogne, Camargue, and Pyrenees-Atlantiques) and uncertainty as to the situation in other areas.\n\nIn addition, the authors indicate that the discovery of infected wild animals in several areas where bovine infection is present, raises the question of suspected reservoirs in wildlife, leading to the maintenance of the epidemiological cycle.\n\nSubscribers are referred to commentary in ProMED-mail posting 20111228.3695, which included the following information: on BovTB in wildlife in France.\n\nRegarding France's BovTB status, subscribers are referred to article 11.6.2. of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.11.6.htm. According to said article, to qualify as free from bovine tuberculosis, a country or zone should satisfy the following requirements:\n1. _M. bovis_ infection in domestic (permanently captive and owned free-range) bovines including cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison is a notifiable disease in the country;\n2. an on-going awareness programme should be in place to encourage reporting of all cases suggestive of bovine tuberculosis;\n3. regular and periodic testing of all cattle, water buffalo, and wood bison herds demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes and wood bison in the country or zone for 3 consecutive years;\n4. a surveillance programme should be in place to detect bovine tuberculosis in the country or zone through ante- and post-mortem inspection;\n5. if the surveillance programme described in points 3 and 4 above demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison in the country or zone for 5 consecutive years, surveillance may be maintained through ante- and post-mortem inspection.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. S Gorecki, D Calavas, A Fediaevsky, et al: Evaluation du dispositif national de surveillance epidemiologique de la tuberculose bovine en France a l'aide de la methode OASIS [Evaluation of the bovine tuberculosis national surveillance system in France using the OASIS method]. Bulletin epidemiologique, sante animale et alimentation, no 51, 13 Sep 2012 [in French, abstract in English], available at http://www.anses.fr/bulletin-epidemiologique/Documents/BEP-mg-BE51-art4.pdf. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/4aV5. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (IV) RFI 20111228.3695\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................sb/arn/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Evron", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Semide", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camargue", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chehery", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mayenne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1482604", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA: (MI), bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1482604", "date": "2012-11-22 18:07:09", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (MAYENNE, ARDENNES)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Mayenne\n[2] Ardennes\n\n******\n[1] Mayenne\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: Ouest-France [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/d5oeh9r\n\n\nAn outbreak of bovine tuberculosis has been identified and confirmed by laboratory test in a cattle farm located in the municipality of Asse-le-Beranger, in the canton of Evron, Mayenne department.\n\nThe same farm was found infected during a previous outbreak, detected on the farm in 2006. This led to the slaughter of the entire stock, as well as cleaning and disinfection measures according to regulations, said the prefecture of Mayenne.\n\nThe whole herd, consisting of 180 cattle, has been declared as infected by the prefecture and was placed under quarantine on 4 Oct 2012. All animals were slaughtered between 13-16 Nov 2012, following their evaluation. The premises will be subject to double disinfection procedures prior to allowing for repopulation.\n\nCompensation for the slaughtered animals and the costs of disinfection will be fully covered by the State. Epidemiological investigations have identified farms in contact with this new focus; they are being monitored.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (_Mycobacterium bovis_ infection) is potentially transmissible to man. It is reminded that, on the national level, the percentage of TB cases in humans due infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ is minimal [out of the total TB cases). Theses cases involve people in close contact with confined excretory animals or consumption of raw [unpasteurized] milk from animal shedders.\n\nThe vast majority of cases of human tuberculosis is due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the specific TB bacterium of human and primates. The health authorities in charge of human health (Health Region Pays de la Loire) will carry out investigation and tests to exclude infection of the breeder concerned and his family.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ardennes\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: L'union L'Ardennais [in French, machine trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/ardennes/la-tuberculose-bovine-frappe-les-ardennes\n\n\nTwo cases of bovine tuberculosis [BovTB] were detected in Semide and Chehery, Ardennes department. This led to the slaughter of about 400 cattle. France is approaching the threshold which, if crossed, will challenge its status of country officially declared \"free\" of the disease [see commentary below]. It is true that we touch on a very sensitive subject because of the economic impact at the national level.\n\nThe 1st warning was recorded in June [2012], in Semide, resulting in the regulatory slaughter of the entire herd of 40 heads. The 2nd, one month later, in Chehery, where 350 cattle were sent to the slaughterhouse. Since then, fingers are crossed that the veterinary services detectives will discover the source of infection.\n\n\"Bovine TB has existed for decades,\" says Arthur Tirado, veterinarian and director of training DDCSPP (Departmental directorate of social cohesion and the protection of people, under the direction of veterinary services, DFS), \"but the fight against this disease has borne fruit since the early 2000s, when France was recognized as BovTB free. This means that despite a few cases, at least 99.9 percent of the French herds are not infected. For now, in the Ardennes, our main concern is to identify the origin of the disease\".\n\nTo this end, DFS conducted a survey of all animals sold or introduced into each of 2 herds concerned. No result yet. \"What we know so far is that 2 different strains were found in the Ardennes; thus there has been no contamination between the 2 herds. The studies are continuing to discover the source of infection\".\n\nThe owners of the slaughtered herds were compensated on the real value of their stock determined by 2 experts from a list, chosen by the breeder.\n\n[Byline: JC Roussel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[According to a recently published referenced paper (Ref 1; thanks to Susan Baekeland for bringing this to our attention), France has been experiencing a resurgence of BovTB since 2004. The rate of herd prevalence increased from 0.02 percent in 2004 to 0.07 percent in 2010. This increase, if continuing, could jeopardize the free status of France.\n\nMoreover, the distribution of the disease on French territory is heterogeneous, with 4 geographic regions infected (Cote-d'Or, Dordogne, Camargue, and Pyrenees-Atlantiques) and uncertainty as to the situation in other areas.\n\nIn addition, the authors indicate that the discovery of infected wild animals in several areas where bovine infection is present, raises the question of suspected reservoirs in wildlife, leading to the maintenance of the epidemiological cycle.\n\nSubscribers are referred to commentary in ProMED-mail posting 20111228.3695, which included the following information: on BovTB in wildlife in France.\n\nRegarding France's BovTB status, subscribers are referred to article 11.6.2. of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.11.6.htm. According to said article, to qualify as free from bovine tuberculosis, a country or zone should satisfy the following requirements:\n1. _M. bovis_ infection in domestic (permanently captive and owned free-range) bovines including cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison is a notifiable disease in the country;\n2. an on-going awareness programme should be in place to encourage reporting of all cases suggestive of bovine tuberculosis;\n3. regular and periodic testing of all cattle, water buffalo, and wood bison herds demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes and wood bison in the country or zone for 3 consecutive years;\n4. a surveillance programme should be in place to detect bovine tuberculosis in the country or zone through ante- and post-mortem inspection;\n5. if the surveillance programme described in points 3 and 4 above demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison in the country or zone for 5 consecutive years, surveillance may be maintained through ante- and post-mortem inspection.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. S Gorecki, D Calavas, A Fediaevsky, et al: Evaluation du dispositif national de surveillance epidemiologique de la tuberculose bovine en France a l'aide de la methode OASIS [Evaluation of the bovine tuberculosis national surveillance system in France using the OASIS method]. Bulletin epidemiologique, sante animale et alimentation, no 51, 13 Sep 2012 [in French, abstract in English], available at http://www.anses.fr/bulletin-epidemiologique/Documents/BEP-mg-BE51-art4.pdf. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/4aV5. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (IV) RFI 20111228.3695\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................sb/arn/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Evron", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Semide", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camargue", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chehery", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mayenne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1471041", "headline": "PRO/AH> Leishmaniasis, tuberculosis - Syria (02): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1471041", "date": "2012-11-22 18:07:09", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (MAYENNE, ARDENNES)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Mayenne\n[2] Ardennes\n\n******\n[1] Mayenne\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: Ouest-France [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/d5oeh9r\n\n\nAn outbreak of bovine tuberculosis has been identified and confirmed by laboratory test in a cattle farm located in the municipality of Asse-le-Beranger, in the canton of Evron, Mayenne department.\n\nThe same farm was found infected during a previous outbreak, detected on the farm in 2006. This led to the slaughter of the entire stock, as well as cleaning and disinfection measures according to regulations, said the prefecture of Mayenne.\n\nThe whole herd, consisting of 180 cattle, has been declared as infected by the prefecture and was placed under quarantine on 4 Oct 2012. All animals were slaughtered between 13-16 Nov 2012, following their evaluation. The premises will be subject to double disinfection procedures prior to allowing for repopulation.\n\nCompensation for the slaughtered animals and the costs of disinfection will be fully covered by the State. Epidemiological investigations have identified farms in contact with this new focus; they are being monitored.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (_Mycobacterium bovis_ infection) is potentially transmissible to man. It is reminded that, on the national level, the percentage of TB cases in humans due infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ is minimal [out of the total TB cases). Theses cases involve people in close contact with confined excretory animals or consumption of raw [unpasteurized] milk from animal shedders.\n\nThe vast majority of cases of human tuberculosis is due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the specific TB bacterium of human and primates. The health authorities in charge of human health (Health Region Pays de la Loire) will carry out investigation and tests to exclude infection of the breeder concerned and his family.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ardennes\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: L'union L'Ardennais [in French, machine trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/ardennes/la-tuberculose-bovine-frappe-les-ardennes\n\n\nTwo cases of bovine tuberculosis [BovTB] were detected in Semide and Chehery, Ardennes department. This led to the slaughter of about 400 cattle. France is approaching the threshold which, if crossed, will challenge its status of country officially declared \"free\" of the disease [see commentary below]. It is true that we touch on a very sensitive subject because of the economic impact at the national level.\n\nThe 1st warning was recorded in June [2012], in Semide, resulting in the regulatory slaughter of the entire herd of 40 heads. The 2nd, one month later, in Chehery, where 350 cattle were sent to the slaughterhouse. Since then, fingers are crossed that the veterinary services detectives will discover the source of infection.\n\n\"Bovine TB has existed for decades,\" says Arthur Tirado, veterinarian and director of training DDCSPP (Departmental directorate of social cohesion and the protection of people, under the direction of veterinary services, DFS), \"but the fight against this disease has borne fruit since the early 2000s, when France was recognized as BovTB free. This means that despite a few cases, at least 99.9 percent of the French herds are not infected. For now, in the Ardennes, our main concern is to identify the origin of the disease\".\n\nTo this end, DFS conducted a survey of all animals sold or introduced into each of 2 herds concerned. No result yet. \"What we know so far is that 2 different strains were found in the Ardennes; thus there has been no contamination between the 2 herds. The studies are continuing to discover the source of infection\".\n\nThe owners of the slaughtered herds were compensated on the real value of their stock determined by 2 experts from a list, chosen by the breeder.\n\n[Byline: JC Roussel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[According to a recently published referenced paper (Ref 1; thanks to Susan Baekeland for bringing this to our attention), France has been experiencing a resurgence of BovTB since 2004. The rate of herd prevalence increased from 0.02 percent in 2004 to 0.07 percent in 2010. This increase, if continuing, could jeopardize the free status of France.\n\nMoreover, the distribution of the disease on French territory is heterogeneous, with 4 geographic regions infected (Cote-d'Or, Dordogne, Camargue, and Pyrenees-Atlantiques) and uncertainty as to the situation in other areas.\n\nIn addition, the authors indicate that the discovery of infected wild animals in several areas where bovine infection is present, raises the question of suspected reservoirs in wildlife, leading to the maintenance of the epidemiological cycle.\n\nSubscribers are referred to commentary in ProMED-mail posting 20111228.3695, which included the following information: on BovTB in wildlife in France.\n\nRegarding France's BovTB status, subscribers are referred to article 11.6.2. of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.11.6.htm. According to said article, to qualify as free from bovine tuberculosis, a country or zone should satisfy the following requirements:\n1. _M. bovis_ infection in domestic (permanently captive and owned free-range) bovines including cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison is a notifiable disease in the country;\n2. an on-going awareness programme should be in place to encourage reporting of all cases suggestive of bovine tuberculosis;\n3. regular and periodic testing of all cattle, water buffalo, and wood bison herds demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes and wood bison in the country or zone for 3 consecutive years;\n4. a surveillance programme should be in place to detect bovine tuberculosis in the country or zone through ante- and post-mortem inspection;\n5. if the surveillance programme described in points 3 and 4 above demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison in the country or zone for 5 consecutive years, surveillance may be maintained through ante- and post-mortem inspection.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. S Gorecki, D Calavas, A Fediaevsky, et al: Evaluation du dispositif national de surveillance epidemiologique de la tuberculose bovine en France a l'aide de la methode OASIS [Evaluation of the bovine tuberculosis national surveillance system in France using the OASIS method]. Bulletin epidemiologique, sante animale et alimentation, no 51, 13 Sep 2012 [in French, abstract in English], available at http://www.anses.fr/bulletin-epidemiologique/Documents/BEP-mg-BE51-art4.pdf. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/4aV5. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (IV) RFI 20111228.3695\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................sb/arn/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Evron", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Semide", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camargue", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chehery", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mayenne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1470184", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Leishmaniasis, tuberculosis - Syria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1470184", "date": "2012-11-22 18:07:09", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (MAYENNE, ARDENNES)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Mayenne\n[2] Ardennes\n\n******\n[1] Mayenne\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: Ouest-France [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/d5oeh9r\n\n\nAn outbreak of bovine tuberculosis has been identified and confirmed by laboratory test in a cattle farm located in the municipality of Asse-le-Beranger, in the canton of Evron, Mayenne department.\n\nThe same farm was found infected during a previous outbreak, detected on the farm in 2006. This led to the slaughter of the entire stock, as well as cleaning and disinfection measures according to regulations, said the prefecture of Mayenne.\n\nThe whole herd, consisting of 180 cattle, has been declared as infected by the prefecture and was placed under quarantine on 4 Oct 2012. All animals were slaughtered between 13-16 Nov 2012, following their evaluation. The premises will be subject to double disinfection procedures prior to allowing for repopulation.\n\nCompensation for the slaughtered animals and the costs of disinfection will be fully covered by the State. Epidemiological investigations have identified farms in contact with this new focus; they are being monitored.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (_Mycobacterium bovis_ infection) is potentially transmissible to man. It is reminded that, on the national level, the percentage of TB cases in humans due infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ is minimal [out of the total TB cases). Theses cases involve people in close contact with confined excretory animals or consumption of raw [unpasteurized] milk from animal shedders.\n\nThe vast majority of cases of human tuberculosis is due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the specific TB bacterium of human and primates. The health authorities in charge of human health (Health Region Pays de la Loire) will carry out investigation and tests to exclude infection of the breeder concerned and his family.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ardennes\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: L'union L'Ardennais [in French, machine trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/ardennes/la-tuberculose-bovine-frappe-les-ardennes\n\n\nTwo cases of bovine tuberculosis [BovTB] were detected in Semide and Chehery, Ardennes department. This led to the slaughter of about 400 cattle. France is approaching the threshold which, if crossed, will challenge its status of country officially declared \"free\" of the disease [see commentary below]. It is true that we touch on a very sensitive subject because of the economic impact at the national level.\n\nThe 1st warning was recorded in June [2012], in Semide, resulting in the regulatory slaughter of the entire herd of 40 heads. The 2nd, one month later, in Chehery, where 350 cattle were sent to the slaughterhouse. Since then, fingers are crossed that the veterinary services detectives will discover the source of infection.\n\n\"Bovine TB has existed for decades,\" says Arthur Tirado, veterinarian and director of training DDCSPP (Departmental directorate of social cohesion and the protection of people, under the direction of veterinary services, DFS), \"but the fight against this disease has borne fruit since the early 2000s, when France was recognized as BovTB free. This means that despite a few cases, at least 99.9 percent of the French herds are not infected. For now, in the Ardennes, our main concern is to identify the origin of the disease\".\n\nTo this end, DFS conducted a survey of all animals sold or introduced into each of 2 herds concerned. No result yet. \"What we know so far is that 2 different strains were found in the Ardennes; thus there has been no contamination between the 2 herds. The studies are continuing to discover the source of infection\".\n\nThe owners of the slaughtered herds were compensated on the real value of their stock determined by 2 experts from a list, chosen by the breeder.\n\n[Byline: JC Roussel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[According to a recently published referenced paper (Ref 1; thanks to Susan Baekeland for bringing this to our attention), France has been experiencing a resurgence of BovTB since 2004. The rate of herd prevalence increased from 0.02 percent in 2004 to 0.07 percent in 2010. This increase, if continuing, could jeopardize the free status of France.\n\nMoreover, the distribution of the disease on French territory is heterogeneous, with 4 geographic regions infected (Cote-d'Or, Dordogne, Camargue, and Pyrenees-Atlantiques) and uncertainty as to the situation in other areas.\n\nIn addition, the authors indicate that the discovery of infected wild animals in several areas where bovine infection is present, raises the question of suspected reservoirs in wildlife, leading to the maintenance of the epidemiological cycle.\n\nSubscribers are referred to commentary in ProMED-mail posting 20111228.3695, which included the following information: on BovTB in wildlife in France.\n\nRegarding France's BovTB status, subscribers are referred to article 11.6.2. of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.11.6.htm. According to said article, to qualify as free from bovine tuberculosis, a country or zone should satisfy the following requirements:\n1. _M. bovis_ infection in domestic (permanently captive and owned free-range) bovines including cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison is a notifiable disease in the country;\n2. an on-going awareness programme should be in place to encourage reporting of all cases suggestive of bovine tuberculosis;\n3. regular and periodic testing of all cattle, water buffalo, and wood bison herds demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes and wood bison in the country or zone for 3 consecutive years;\n4. a surveillance programme should be in place to detect bovine tuberculosis in the country or zone through ante- and post-mortem inspection;\n5. if the surveillance programme described in points 3 and 4 above demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison in the country or zone for 5 consecutive years, surveillance may be maintained through ante- and post-mortem inspection.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. S Gorecki, D Calavas, A Fediaevsky, et al: Evaluation du dispositif national de surveillance epidemiologique de la tuberculose bovine en France a l'aide de la methode OASIS [Evaluation of the bovine tuberculosis national surveillance system in France using the OASIS method]. Bulletin epidemiologique, sante animale et alimentation, no 51, 13 Sep 2012 [in French, abstract in English], available at http://www.anses.fr/bulletin-epidemiologique/Documents/BEP-mg-BE51-art4.pdf. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/4aV5. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (IV) RFI 20111228.3695\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): (WAL, NIR) badger vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1432082", "date": "2012-11-22 18:07:09", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (MAYENNE, ARDENNES)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Mayenne\n[2] Ardennes\n\n******\n[1] Mayenne\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: Ouest-France [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/d5oeh9r\n\n\nAn outbreak of bovine tuberculosis has been identified and confirmed by laboratory test in a cattle farm located in the municipality of Asse-le-Beranger, in the canton of Evron, Mayenne department.\n\nThe same farm was found infected during a previous outbreak, detected on the farm in 2006. This led to the slaughter of the entire stock, as well as cleaning and disinfection measures according to regulations, said the prefecture of Mayenne.\n\nThe whole herd, consisting of 180 cattle, has been declared as infected by the prefecture and was placed under quarantine on 4 Oct 2012. All animals were slaughtered between 13-16 Nov 2012, following their evaluation. The premises will be subject to double disinfection procedures prior to allowing for repopulation.\n\nCompensation for the slaughtered animals and the costs of disinfection will be fully covered by the State. Epidemiological investigations have identified farms in contact with this new focus; they are being monitored.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (_Mycobacterium bovis_ infection) is potentially transmissible to man. It is reminded that, on the national level, the percentage of TB cases in humans due infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ is minimal [out of the total TB cases). Theses cases involve people in close contact with confined excretory animals or consumption of raw [unpasteurized] milk from animal shedders.\n\nThe vast majority of cases of human tuberculosis is due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the specific TB bacterium of human and primates. The health authorities in charge of human health (Health Region Pays de la Loire) will carry out investigation and tests to exclude infection of the breeder concerned and his family.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ardennes\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: L'union L'Ardennais [in French, machine trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/ardennes/la-tuberculose-bovine-frappe-les-ardennes\n\n\nTwo cases of bovine tuberculosis [BovTB] were detected in Semide and Chehery, Ardennes department. This led to the slaughter of about 400 cattle. France is approaching the threshold which, if crossed, will challenge its status of country officially declared \"free\" of the disease [see commentary below]. It is true that we touch on a very sensitive subject because of the economic impact at the national level.\n\nThe 1st warning was recorded in June [2012], in Semide, resulting in the regulatory slaughter of the entire herd of 40 heads. The 2nd, one month later, in Chehery, where 350 cattle were sent to the slaughterhouse. Since then, fingers are crossed that the veterinary services detectives will discover the source of infection.\n\n\"Bovine TB has existed for decades,\" says Arthur Tirado, veterinarian and director of training DDCSPP (Departmental directorate of social cohesion and the protection of people, under the direction of veterinary services, DFS), \"but the fight against this disease has borne fruit since the early 2000s, when France was recognized as BovTB free. This means that despite a few cases, at least 99.9 percent of the French herds are not infected. For now, in the Ardennes, our main concern is to identify the origin of the disease\".\n\nTo this end, DFS conducted a survey of all animals sold or introduced into each of 2 herds concerned. No result yet. \"What we know so far is that 2 different strains were found in the Ardennes; thus there has been no contamination between the 2 herds. The studies are continuing to discover the source of infection\".\n\nThe owners of the slaughtered herds were compensated on the real value of their stock determined by 2 experts from a list, chosen by the breeder.\n\n[Byline: JC Roussel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[According to a recently published referenced paper (Ref 1; thanks to Susan Baekeland for bringing this to our attention), France has been experiencing a resurgence of BovTB since 2004. The rate of herd prevalence increased from 0.02 percent in 2004 to 0.07 percent in 2010. This increase, if continuing, could jeopardize the free status of France.\n\nMoreover, the distribution of the disease on French territory is heterogeneous, with 4 geographic regions infected (Cote-d'Or, Dordogne, Camargue, and Pyrenees-Atlantiques) and uncertainty as to the situation in other areas.\n\nIn addition, the authors indicate that the discovery of infected wild animals in several areas where bovine infection is present, raises the question of suspected reservoirs in wildlife, leading to the maintenance of the epidemiological cycle.\n\nSubscribers are referred to commentary in ProMED-mail posting 20111228.3695, which included the following information: on BovTB in wildlife in France.\n\nRegarding France's BovTB status, subscribers are referred to article 11.6.2. of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.11.6.htm. According to said article, to qualify as free from bovine tuberculosis, a country or zone should satisfy the following requirements:\n1. _M. bovis_ infection in domestic (permanently captive and owned free-range) bovines including cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison is a notifiable disease in the country;\n2. an on-going awareness programme should be in place to encourage reporting of all cases suggestive of bovine tuberculosis;\n3. regular and periodic testing of all cattle, water buffalo, and wood bison herds demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes and wood bison in the country or zone for 3 consecutive years;\n4. a surveillance programme should be in place to detect bovine tuberculosis in the country or zone through ante- and post-mortem inspection;\n5. if the surveillance programme described in points 3 and 4 above demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison in the country or zone for 5 consecutive years, surveillance may be maintained through ante- and post-mortem inspection.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. S Gorecki, D Calavas, A Fediaevsky, et al: Evaluation du dispositif national de surveillance epidemiologique de la tuberculose bovine en France a l'aide de la methode OASIS [Evaluation of the bovine tuberculosis national surveillance system in France using the OASIS method].
