Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/4aV5. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (IV) RFI 20111228.3695\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................sb/arn/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Evron", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Semide", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camargue", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chehery", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mayenne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1423321", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Austria: (TR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1423321", "date": "2012-11-22 18:07:09", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (MAYENNE, ARDENNES)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Mayenne\n[2] Ardennes\n\n******\n[1] Mayenne\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: Ouest-France [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/d5oeh9r\n\n\nAn outbreak of bovine tuberculosis has been identified and confirmed by laboratory test in a cattle farm located in the municipality of Asse-le-Beranger, in the canton of Evron, Mayenne department.\n\nThe same farm was found infected during a previous outbreak, detected on the farm in 2006. This led to the slaughter of the entire stock, as well as cleaning and disinfection measures according to regulations, said the prefecture of Mayenne.\n\nThe whole herd, consisting of 180 cattle, has been declared as infected by the prefecture and was placed under quarantine on 4 Oct 2012. All animals were slaughtered between 13-16 Nov 2012, following their evaluation. The premises will be subject to double disinfection procedures prior to allowing for repopulation.\n\nCompensation for the slaughtered animals and the costs of disinfection will be fully covered by the State. Epidemiological investigations have identified farms in contact with this new focus; they are being monitored.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (_Mycobacterium bovis_ infection) is potentially transmissible to man. It is reminded that, on the national level, the percentage of TB cases in humans due infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ is minimal [out of the total TB cases). Theses cases involve people in close contact with confined excretory animals or consumption of raw [unpasteurized] milk from animal shedders.\n\nThe vast majority of cases of human tuberculosis is due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the specific TB bacterium of human and primates. The health authorities in charge of human health (Health Region Pays de la Loire) will carry out investigation and tests to exclude infection of the breeder concerned and his family.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ardennes\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: L'union L'Ardennais [in French, machine trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/ardennes/la-tuberculose-bovine-frappe-les-ardennes\n\n\nTwo cases of bovine tuberculosis [BovTB] were detected in Semide and Chehery, Ardennes department. This led to the slaughter of about 400 cattle. France is approaching the threshold which, if crossed, will challenge its status of country officially declared \"free\" of the disease [see commentary below]. It is true that we touch on a very sensitive subject because of the economic impact at the national level.\n\nThe 1st warning was recorded in June [2012], in Semide, resulting in the regulatory slaughter of the entire herd of 40 heads. The 2nd, one month later, in Chehery, where 350 cattle were sent to the slaughterhouse. Since then, fingers are crossed that the veterinary services detectives will discover the source of infection.\n\n\"Bovine TB has existed for decades,\" says Arthur Tirado, veterinarian and director of training DDCSPP (Departmental directorate of social cohesion and the protection of people, under the direction of veterinary services, DFS), \"but the fight against this disease has borne fruit since the early 2000s, when France was recognized as BovTB free. This means that despite a few cases, at least 99.9 percent of the French herds are not infected. For now, in the Ardennes, our main concern is to identify the origin of the disease\".\n\nTo this end, DFS conducted a survey of all animals sold or introduced into each of 2 herds concerned. No result yet. \"What we know so far is that 2 different strains were found in the Ardennes; thus there has been no contamination between the 2 herds. The studies are continuing to discover the source of infection\".\n\nThe owners of the slaughtered herds were compensated on the real value of their stock determined by 2 experts from a list, chosen by the breeder.\n\n[Byline: JC Roussel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[According to a recently published referenced paper (Ref 1; thanks to Susan Baekeland for bringing this to our attention), France has been experiencing a resurgence of BovTB since 2004. The rate of herd prevalence increased from 0.02 percent in 2004 to 0.07 percent in 2010. This increase, if continuing, could jeopardize the free status of France.\n\nMoreover, the distribution of the disease on French territory is heterogeneous, with 4 geographic regions infected (Cote-d'Or, Dordogne, Camargue, and Pyrenees-Atlantiques) and uncertainty as to the situation in other areas.\n\nIn addition, the authors indicate that the discovery of infected wild animals in several areas where bovine infection is present, raises the question of suspected reservoirs in wildlife, leading to the maintenance of the epidemiological cycle.\n\nSubscribers are referred to commentary in ProMED-mail posting 20111228.3695, which included the following information: on BovTB in wildlife in France.\n\nRegarding France's BovTB status, subscribers are referred to article 11.6.2. of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.11.6.htm. According to said article, to qualify as free from bovine tuberculosis, a country or zone should satisfy the following requirements:\n1. _M. bovis_ infection in domestic (permanently captive and owned free-range) bovines including cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison is a notifiable disease in the country;\n2. an on-going awareness programme should be in place to encourage reporting of all cases suggestive of bovine tuberculosis;\n3. regular and periodic testing of all cattle, water buffalo, and wood bison herds demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes and wood bison in the country or zone for 3 consecutive years;\n4. a surveillance programme should be in place to detect bovine tuberculosis in the country or zone through ante- and post-mortem inspection;\n5. if the surveillance programme described in points 3 and 4 above demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison in the country or zone for 5 consecutive years, surveillance may be maintained through ante- and post-mortem inspection.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. S Gorecki, D Calavas, A Fediaevsky, et al: Evaluation du dispositif national de surveillance epidemiologique de la tuberculose bovine en France a l'aide de la methode OASIS [Evaluation of the bovine tuberculosis national surveillance system in France using the OASIS method]. Bulletin epidemiologique, sante animale et alimentation, no 51, 13 Sep 2012 [in French, abstract in English], available at http://www.anses.fr/bulletin-epidemiologique/Documents/BEP-mg-BE51-art4.pdf. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/4aV5. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (IV) RFI 20111228.3695\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................sb/arn/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Evron", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Semide", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camargue", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chehery", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mayenne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1420616", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - France: (MY, AN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1420616", "date": "2012-11-22 18:07:09", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (MAYENNE, ARDENNES)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Mayenne\n[2] Ardennes\n\n******\n[1] Mayenne\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: Ouest-France [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/d5oeh9r\n\n\nAn outbreak of bovine tuberculosis has been identified and confirmed by laboratory test in a cattle farm located in the municipality of Asse-le-Beranger, in the canton of Evron, Mayenne department.\n\nThe same farm was found infected during a previous outbreak, detected on the farm in 2006. This led to the slaughter of the entire stock, as well as cleaning and disinfection measures according to regulations, said the prefecture of Mayenne.\n\nThe whole herd, consisting of 180 cattle, has been declared as infected by the prefecture and was placed under quarantine on 4 Oct 2012. All animals were slaughtered between 13-16 Nov 2012, following their evaluation. The premises will be subject to double disinfection procedures prior to allowing for repopulation.\n\nCompensation for the slaughtered animals and the costs of disinfection will be fully covered by the State. Epidemiological investigations have identified farms in contact with this new focus; they are being monitored.\n\nBovine tuberculosis (_Mycobacterium bovis_ infection) is potentially transmissible to man. It is reminded that, on the national level, the percentage of TB cases in humans due infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ is minimal [out of the total TB cases). Theses cases involve people in close contact with confined excretory animals or consumption of raw [unpasteurized] milk from animal shedders.\n\nThe vast majority of cases of human tuberculosis is due to _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the specific TB bacterium of human and primates. The health authorities in charge of human health (Health Region Pays de la Loire) will carry out investigation and tests to exclude infection of the breeder concerned and his family.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Ardennes\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nSource: L'union L'Ardennais [in French, machine trans. & summ., edited]\nhttp://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/ardennes/la-tuberculose-bovine-frappe-les-ardennes\n\n\nTwo cases of bovine tuberculosis [BovTB] were detected in Semide and Chehery, Ardennes department. This led to the slaughter of about 400 cattle. France is approaching the threshold which, if crossed, will challenge its status of country officially declared \"free\" of the disease [see commentary below]. It is true that we touch on a very sensitive subject because of the economic impact at the national level.\n\nThe 1st warning was recorded in June [2012], in Semide, resulting in the regulatory slaughter of the entire herd of 40 heads. The 2nd, one month later, in Chehery, where 350 cattle were sent to the slaughterhouse. Since then, fingers are crossed that the veterinary services detectives will discover the source of infection.\n\n\"Bovine TB has existed for decades,\" says Arthur Tirado, veterinarian and director of training DDCSPP (Departmental directorate of social cohesion and the protection of people, under the direction of veterinary services, DFS), \"but the fight against this disease has borne fruit since the early 2000s, when France was recognized as BovTB free. This means that despite a few cases, at least 99.9 percent of the French herds are not infected. For now, in the Ardennes, our main concern is to identify the origin of the disease\".\n\nTo this end, DFS conducted a survey of all animals sold or introduced into each of 2 herds concerned. No result yet. \"What we know so far is that 2 different strains were found in the Ardennes; thus there has been no contamination between the 2 herds. The studies are continuing to discover the source of infection\".\n\nThe owners of the slaughtered herds were compensated on the real value of their stock determined by 2 experts from a list, chosen by the breeder.\n\n[Byline: JC Roussel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[According to a recently published referenced paper (Ref 1; thanks to Susan Baekeland for bringing this to our attention), France has been experiencing a resurgence of BovTB since 2004. The rate of herd prevalence increased from 0.02 percent in 2004 to 0.07 percent in 2010. This increase, if continuing, could jeopardize the free status of France.\n\nMoreover, the distribution of the disease on French territory is heterogeneous, with 4 geographic regions infected (Cote-d'Or, Dordogne, Camargue, and Pyrenees-Atlantiques) and uncertainty as to the situation in other areas.\n\nIn addition, the authors indicate that the discovery of infected wild animals in several areas where bovine infection is present, raises the question of suspected reservoirs in wildlife, leading to the maintenance of the epidemiological cycle.\n\nSubscribers are referred to commentary in ProMED-mail posting 20111228.3695, which included the following information: on BovTB in wildlife in France.\n\nRegarding France's BovTB status, subscribers are referred to article 11.6.2. of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.11.6.htm. According to said article, to qualify as free from bovine tuberculosis, a country or zone should satisfy the following requirements:\n1. _M. bovis_ infection in domestic (permanently captive and owned free-range) bovines including cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison is a notifiable disease in the country;\n2. an on-going awareness programme should be in place to encourage reporting of all cases suggestive of bovine tuberculosis;\n3. regular and periodic testing of all cattle, water buffalo, and wood bison herds demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes and wood bison in the country or zone for 3 consecutive years;\n4. a surveillance programme should be in place to detect bovine tuberculosis in the country or zone through ante- and post-mortem inspection;\n5. if the surveillance programme described in points 3 and 4 above demonstrated that _M. bovis_ infection was not present in at least 99.8 percent of the herds and 99.9 percent of the cattle, water buffaloes, and wood bison in the country or zone for 5 consecutive years, surveillance may be maintained through ante- and post-mortem inspection.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. S Gorecki, D Calavas, A Fediaevsky, et al: Evaluation du dispositif national de surveillance epidemiologique de la tuberculose bovine en France a l'aide de la methode OASIS [Evaluation of the bovine tuberculosis national surveillance system in France using the OASIS method]. Bulletin epidemiologique, sante animale et alimentation, no 51, 13 Sep 2012 [in French, abstract in English], available at http://www.anses.fr/bulletin-epidemiologique/Documents/BEP-mg-BE51-art4.pdf. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Maps of France can be seen at http://www.trussel.com/maig/image/frdeptb.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/4aV5. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (IV) RFI 20111228.3695\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................sb/arn/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Evron", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Semide", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Camargue", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chehery", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mayenne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1355085", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - Australia: (QL) ex Papua New Guinea", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1355085", "date": "2012-05-10 13:45:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - UK (02): (ENGLAND) ex ALPACA\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 9 May 2012\nFrom: Finn Twomey <Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Bovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Following the recent bovine tuberculosis case in a UK Alpaca breeder, we have approached Dr DF Twomey, Animal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency-Exeter, Devon, UK, requesting his view of the case and some background. The following response, kindly forwarded by him, is gratefully acknowledged and much appreciated. - Mod.AS]\n\nI have been involved with several investigations into TB in camelids but didn't have any direct involvement with the recently reported case of TB in a person who had contact with an infected alpaca. The following link provides further details, presumably about the same case: http://www.alpacatb.com/news.html.\n\nThis person was at an unusually high risk of exposure to _Mycobacterium bovis_ by virtue of her work with infected alpacas. All animals infected with _M. bovis_ constitute a potential source of the bacterium for humans and tuberculous alpacas are no exception. 'Native' cases of zoonotic TB infection, although very rare in developed countries, can happen occasionally. This particular case does not alter the fact that there is a very low risk of zoonotic TB infection in the UK.\n\nAlthough _M. bovis_ was first diagnosed in camelids in GB in 1999, this is only the 2nd documented case of human infection associated with contact with tuberculous llamas or alpacas since then. The other incident was also attributed to occupational exposure to an infected alpaca in GB and occurred in 2004-05 after a veterinary surgeon treating and sampling an alpaca that died of TB subsequently contracted a cutaneous form of _M. bovis_ infection. The case was later published: Twomey DF, Higgins RJ, Worth DR, et al: Cutaneous TB caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_ in a veterinary surgeon following exposure to a tuberculous alpaca (_Vicugna pacos_). Vet Rec 2010. 166(6): 175-7 [abstract available at http://veterinaryrecord.bmj.com/content/166/6/175.extract].\n\n--\nDF Twomey\nVeterinary Laboratories Agency\nStaplake Mount, Starcross, Exeter, Devon\nUK\n<Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk>\n\n[According to a 2006 review (see reference below), in the period 1990-2003, between 17 and 50 new cases of human _M. bovis_ infection were confirmed every year in the UK. This represented between 0.5 and 1.5 percent of all the culture-confirmed TB cases, a proportion similar to that of other industrialized countries. Most cases of zoonotic TB diagnosed in the UK were, at that point in time, attributed to (i) reactivation of long-standing latent infections acquired before widespread adoption of milk pasteurization, or (ii) _M. bovis_ infections contracted abroad. Throughout the said 14-year period, only one case was documented in the UK of confirmed, indigenous human _M. bovis_ infection recently acquired from an animal source.\n\nIn view of the increased incidence of bovine TB in cattle and other animals, the number of human cases is expected to rise.\n\nThe reviewer concluded:\n\"A significant risk of _M. bovis_ infection remains in certain segments of the UK population in the form of (i) continuing on-farm consumption of unpasteurized cows' milk, (ii) retail sales by approved establishments of unpasteurized milk and dairy products, and (iii) occupational exposure to infectious aerosols from tuberculous animals and their carcases.\"\n\n\"Physicians and other public health professionals must remember that zoonotic TB is not just a disease of the past.\"\n\nReference\n---------\nde la Rua-Domenech R: Human _Mycobacterium bovis_ infection in the United Kingdom: Incidence, risks, control measures and review of the zoonotic aspects of bovine tuberculosis. Tuberculosis (Edinb). 2006; 86(2): 77-10; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16257579. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Conventional microbiologic diagnosis of human tuberculosis relies on methods that allow only identification of \u201cMycobacterium tuberculosis complex\u201d. \u201cM. tuberculosis complex\u201d is composed of _ Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ (Mtb), as well as _Mycobacterium bovis_ (Mb) and several other genetically closely related species: the BCG bacillus, _M. africanum_, _M. caprae_, _M. microti_, and M. canetti. Mb is inherently resistant to pyrazinamide (PZA), a drug that is an essential component of the standard multidrug short-course regimen to treat human tuberculosis due to drug-susceptible Mtb. Differentiation of Mb from Mtb is therefore important clinically as well as epidemiologically. To distinguish Mb from these other species, special tests would have to be done, such as spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of Mb infection might be missed and the patient treated inappropriately. - ModML]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) ex Alpaca 20120427.1116358\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: alpaca, mastitis, implications 20110825.2588\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\n.................................................mhj/arn/mj/ml/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Worth DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom : incidence", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1296946", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis - UK (03): (England) badger control", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1296946", "date": "2012-05-10 13:45:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - UK (02): (ENGLAND) ex ALPACA\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 9 May 2012\nFrom: Finn Twomey <Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Bovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Following the recent bovine tuberculosis case in a UK Alpaca breeder, we have approached Dr DF Twomey, Animal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency-Exeter, Devon, UK, requesting his view of the case and some background. The following response, kindly forwarded by him, is gratefully acknowledged and much appreciated. - Mod.AS]\n\nI have been involved with several investigations into TB in camelids but didn't have any direct involvement with the recently reported case of TB in a person who had contact with an infected alpaca. The following link provides further details, presumably about the same case: http://www.alpacatb.com/news.html.\n\nThis person was at an unusually high risk of exposure to _Mycobacterium bovis_ by virtue of her work with infected alpacas. All animals infected with _M. bovis_ constitute a potential source of the bacterium for humans and tuberculous alpacas are no exception. 'Native' cases of zoonotic TB infection, although very rare in developed countries, can happen occasionally. This particular case does not alter the fact that there is a very low risk of zoonotic TB infection in the UK.\n\nAlthough _M. bovis_ was first diagnosed in camelids in GB in 1999, this is only the 2nd documented case of human infection associated with contact with tuberculous llamas or alpacas since then. The other incident was also attributed to occupational exposure to an infected alpaca in GB and occurred in 2004-05 after a veterinary surgeon treating and sampling an alpaca that died of TB subsequently contracted a cutaneous form of _M. bovis_ infection. The case was later published: Twomey DF, Higgins RJ, Worth DR, et al: Cutaneous TB caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_ in a veterinary surgeon following exposure to a tuberculous alpaca (_Vicugna pacos_). Vet Rec 2010. 166(6): 175-7 [abstract available at http://veterinaryrecord.bmj.com/content/166/6/175.extract].\n\n--\nDF Twomey\nVeterinary Laboratories Agency\nStaplake Mount, Starcross, Exeter, Devon\nUK\n<Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk>\n\n[According to a 2006 review (see reference below), in the period 1990-2003, between 17 and 50 new cases of human _M. bovis_ infection were confirmed every year in the UK. This represented between 0.5 and 1.5 percent of all the culture-confirmed TB cases, a proportion similar to that of other industrialized countries. Most cases of zoonotic TB diagnosed in the UK were, at that point in time, attributed to (i) reactivation of long-standing latent infections acquired before widespread adoption of milk pasteurization, or (ii) _M. bovis_ infections contracted abroad. Throughout the said 14-year period, only one case was documented in the UK of confirmed, indigenous human _M. bovis_ infection recently acquired from an animal source.\n\nIn view of the increased incidence of bovine TB in cattle and other animals, the number of human cases is expected to rise.\n\nThe reviewer concluded:\n\"A significant risk of _M. bovis_ infection remains in certain segments of the UK population in the form of (i) continuing on-farm consumption of unpasteurized cows' milk, (ii) retail sales by approved establishments of unpasteurized milk and dairy products, and (iii) occupational exposure to infectious aerosols from tuberculous animals and their carcases.\"\n\n\"Physicians and other public health professionals must remember that zoonotic TB is not just a disease of the past.\"\n\nReference\n---------\nde la Rua-Domenech R: Human _Mycobacterium bovis_ infection in the United Kingdom: Incidence, risks, control measures and review of the zoonotic aspects of bovine tuberculosis. Tuberculosis (Edinb). 2006; 86(2): 77-10; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16257579. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Conventional microbiologic diagnosis of human tuberculosis relies on methods that allow only identification of \u201cMycobacterium tuberculosis complex\u201d. \u201cM. tuberculosis complex\u201d is composed of _ Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ (Mtb), as well as _Mycobacterium bovis_ (Mb) and several other genetically closely related species: the BCG bacillus, _M. africanum_, _M. caprae_, _M. microti_, and M. canetti. Mb is inherently resistant to pyrazinamide (PZA), a drug that is an essential component of the standard multidrug short-course regimen to treat human tuberculosis due to drug-susceptible Mtb. Differentiation of Mb from Mtb is therefore important clinically as well as epidemiologically. To distinguish Mb from these other species, special tests would have to be done, such as spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of Mb infection might be missed and the patient treated inappropriately. - ModML]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) ex Alpaca 20120427.1116358\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: alpaca, mastitis, implications 20110825.2588\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\n.................................................mhj/arn/mj/ml/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Worth DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom : incidence", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1262053", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Mexico: (GR) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1262053", "date": "2012-05-10 13:45:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - UK (02): (ENGLAND) ex ALPACA\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 9 May 2012\nFrom: Finn Twomey <Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Bovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Following the recent bovine tuberculosis case in a UK Alpaca breeder, we have approached Dr DF Twomey, Animal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency-Exeter, Devon, UK, requesting his view of the case and some background. The following response, kindly forwarded by him, is gratefully acknowledged and much appreciated. - Mod.AS]\n\nI have been involved with several investigations into TB in camelids but didn't have any direct involvement with the recently reported case of TB in a person who had contact with an infected alpaca. The following link provides further details, presumably about the same case: http://www.alpacatb.com/news.html.\n\nThis person was at an unusually high risk of exposure to _Mycobacterium bovis_ by virtue of her work with infected alpacas. All animals infected with _M. bovis_ constitute a potential source of the bacterium for humans and tuberculous alpacas are no exception. 'Native' cases of zoonotic TB infection, although very rare in developed countries, can happen occasionally. This particular case does not alter the fact that there is a very low risk of zoonotic TB infection in the UK.\n\nAlthough _M. bovis_ was first diagnosed in camelids in GB in 1999, this is only the 2nd documented case of human infection associated with contact with tuberculous llamas or alpacas since then. The other incident was also attributed to occupational exposure to an infected alpaca in GB and occurred in 2004-05 after a veterinary surgeon treating and sampling an alpaca that died of TB subsequently contracted a cutaneous form of _M. bovis_ infection. The case was later published: Twomey DF, Higgins RJ, Worth DR, et al: Cutaneous TB caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_ in a veterinary surgeon following exposure to a tuberculous alpaca (_Vicugna pacos_). Vet Rec 2010. 166(6): 175-7 [abstract available at http://veterinaryrecord.bmj.com/content/166/6/175.extract].\n\n--\nDF Twomey\nVeterinary Laboratories Agency\nStaplake Mount, Starcross, Exeter, Devon\nUK\n<Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk>\n\n[According to a 2006 review (see reference below), in the period 1990-2003, between 17 and 50 new cases of human _M. bovis_ infection were confirmed every year in the UK. This represented between 0.5 and 1.5 percent of all the culture-confirmed TB cases, a proportion similar to that of other industrialized countries. Most cases of zoonotic TB diagnosed in the UK were, at that point in time, attributed to (i) reactivation of long-standing latent infections acquired before widespread adoption of milk pasteurization, or (ii) _M. bovis_ infections contracted abroad. Throughout the said 14-year period, only one case was documented in the UK of confirmed, indigenous human _M. bovis_ infection recently acquired from an animal source.\n\nIn view of the increased incidence of bovine TB in cattle and other animals, the number of human cases is expected to rise.\n\nThe reviewer concluded:\n\"A significant risk of _M. bovis_ infection remains in certain segments of the UK population in the form of (i) continuing on-farm consumption of unpasteurized cows' milk, (ii) retail sales by approved establishments of unpasteurized milk and dairy products, and (iii) occupational exposure to infectious aerosols from tuberculous animals and their carcases.\"\n\n\"Physicians and other public health professionals must remember that zoonotic TB is not just a disease of the past.\"\n\nReference\n---------\nde la Rua-Domenech R: Human _Mycobacterium bovis_ infection in the United Kingdom: Incidence, risks, control measures and review of the zoonotic aspects of bovine tuberculosis. Tuberculosis (Edinb). 2006; 86(2): 77-10; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16257579. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Conventional microbiologic diagnosis of human tuberculosis relies on methods that allow only identification of \u201cMycobacterium tuberculosis complex\u201d. \u201cM. tuberculosis complex\u201d is composed of _ Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ (Mtb), as well as _Mycobacterium bovis_ (Mb) and several other genetically closely related species: the BCG bacillus, _M. africanum_, _M. caprae_, _M. microti_, and M. canetti. Mb is inherently resistant to pyrazinamide (PZA), a drug that is an essential component of the standard multidrug short-course regimen to treat human tuberculosis due to drug-susceptible Mtb. Differentiation of Mb from Mtb is therefore important clinically as well as epidemiologically. To distinguish Mb from these other species, special tests would have to be done, such as spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of Mb infection might be missed and the patient treated inappropriately. - ModML]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) ex Alpaca 20120427.1116358\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: alpaca, mastitis, implications 20110825.2588\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\n.................................................mhj/arn/mj/ml/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Worth DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom : incidence", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1230363", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - USA (02): (MI) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1184446", "date": "2012-05-10 13:45:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - UK (02): (ENGLAND) ex ALPACA\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 9 May 2012\nFrom: Finn Twomey <Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Bovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Following the recent bovine tuberculosis case in a UK Alpaca breeder, we have approached Dr DF Twomey, Animal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency-Exeter, Devon, UK, requesting his view of the case and some background. The following response, kindly forwarded by him, is gratefully acknowledged and much appreciated. - Mod.AS]\n\nI have been involved with several investigations into TB in camelids but didn't have any direct involvement with the recently reported case of TB in a person who had contact with an infected alpaca. The following link provides further details, presumably about the same case: http://www.alpacatb.com/news.html.\n\nThis person was at an unusually high risk of exposure to _Mycobacterium bovis_ by virtue of her work with infected alpacas. All animals infected with _M. bovis_ constitute a potential source of the bacterium for humans and tuberculous alpacas are no exception. 'Native' cases of zoonotic TB infection, although very rare in developed countries, can happen occasionally. This particular case does not alter the fact that there is a very low risk of zoonotic TB infection in the UK.\n\nAlthough _M. bovis_ was first diagnosed in camelids in GB in 1999, this is only the 2nd documented case of human infection associated with contact with tuberculous llamas or alpacas since then. The other incident was also attributed to occupational exposure to an infected alpaca in GB and occurred in 2004-05 after a veterinary surgeon treating and sampling an alpaca that died of TB subsequently contracted a cutaneous form of _M. bovis_ infection. The case was later published: Twomey DF, Higgins RJ, Worth DR, et al: Cutaneous TB caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_ in a veterinary surgeon following exposure to a tuberculous alpaca (_Vicugna pacos_). Vet Rec 2010. 166(6): 175-7 [abstract available at http://veterinaryrecord.bmj.com/content/166/6/175.extract].\n\n--\nDF Twomey\nVeterinary Laboratories Agency\nStaplake Mount, Starcross, Exeter, Devon\nUK\n<Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk>\n\n[According to a 2006 review (see reference below), in the period 1990-2003, between 17 and 50 new cases of human _M. bovis_ infection were confirmed every year in the UK. This represented between 0.5 and 1.5 percent of all the culture-confirmed TB cases, a proportion similar to that of other industrialized countries. Most cases of zoonotic TB diagnosed in the UK were, at that point in time, attributed to (i) reactivation of long-standing latent infections acquired before widespread adoption of milk pasteurization, or (ii) _M. bovis_ infections contracted abroad. Throughout the said 14-year period, only one case was documented in the UK of confirmed, indigenous human _M. bovis_ infection recently acquired from an animal source.\n\nIn view of the increased incidence of bovine TB in cattle and other animals, the number of human cases is expected to rise.\n\nThe reviewer concluded:\n\"A significant risk of _M. bovis_ infection remains in certain segments of the UK population in the form of (i) continuing on-farm consumption of unpasteurized cows' milk, (ii) retail sales by approved establishments of unpasteurized milk and dairy products, and (iii) occupational exposure to infectious aerosols from tuberculous animals and their carcases.\"\n\n\"Physicians and other public health professionals must remember that zoonotic TB is not just a disease of the past.\"\n\nReference\n---------\nde la Rua-Domenech R: Human _Mycobacterium bovis_ infection in the United Kingdom: Incidence, risks, control measures and review of the zoonotic aspects of bovine tuberculosis. Tuberculosis (Edinb). 2006; 86(2): 77-10; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16257579. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Conventional microbiologic diagnosis of human tuberculosis relies on methods that allow only identification of \u201cMycobacterium tuberculosis complex\u201d. \u201cM. tuberculosis complex\u201d is composed of _ Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ (Mtb), as well as _Mycobacterium bovis_ (Mb) and several other genetically closely related species: the BCG bacillus, _M. africanum_, _M. caprae_, _M. microti_, and M. canetti. Mb is inherently resistant to pyrazinamide (PZA), a drug that is an essential component of the standard multidrug short-course regimen to treat human tuberculosis due to drug-susceptible Mtb. Differentiation of Mb from Mtb is therefore important clinically as well as epidemiologically. To distinguish Mb from these other species, special tests would have to be done, such as spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of Mb infection might be missed and the patient treated inappropriately. - ModML]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) ex Alpaca 20120427.1116358\n2011\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: alpaca, mastitis, implications 20110825.2588\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\n.................................................mhj/arn/mj/ml/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Worth DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom : incidence", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1128707", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, human - UK (02): (England) ex alpaca", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1128707", "date": "2012-05-10 13:45:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - UK (02): (ENGLAND) ex ALPACA\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 9 May 2012\nFrom: Finn Twomey <Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Bovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Following the recent bovine tuberculosis case in a UK Alpaca breeder, we have approached Dr DF Twomey, Animal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency-Exeter, Devon, UK, requesting his view of the case and some background. The following response, kindly forwarded by him, is gratefully acknowledged and much appreciated. - Mod.AS]\n\nI have been involved with several investigations into TB in camelids but didn't have any direct involvement with the recently reported case of TB in a person who had contact with an infected alpaca. The following link provides further details, presumably about the same case: http://www.alpacatb.com/news.html.\n\nThis person was at an unusually high risk of exposure to _Mycobacterium bovis_ by virtue of her work with infected alpacas. All animals infected with _M. bovis_ constitute a potential source of the bacterium for humans and tuberculous alpacas are no exception. 'Native' cases of zoonotic TB infection, although very rare in developed countries, can happen occasionally. This particular case does not alter the fact that there is a very low risk of zoonotic TB infection in the UK.\n\nAlthough _M. bovis_ was first diagnosed in camelids in GB in 1999, this is only the 2nd documented case of human infection associated with contact with tuberculous llamas or alpacas since then. The other incident was also attributed to occupational exposure to an infected alpaca in GB and occurred in 2004-05 after a veterinary surgeon treating and sampling an alpaca that died of TB subsequently contracted a cutaneous form of _M. bovis_ infection. The case was later published: Twomey DF, Higgins RJ, Worth DR, et al: Cutaneous TB caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_ in a veterinary surgeon following exposure to a tuberculous alpaca (_Vicugna pacos_). Vet Rec 2010. 166(6): 175-7 [abstract available at http://veterinaryrecord.bmj.com/content/166/6/175.extract].\n\n--\nDF Twomey\nVeterinary Laboratories Agency\nStaplake Mount, Starcross, Exeter, Devon\nUK\n<Finn.Twomey@ahvla.gsi.gov.uk>\n\n[According to a 2006 review (see reference below), in the period 1990-2003, between 17 and 50 new cases of human _M. bovis_ infection were confirmed every year in the UK. This represented between 0.5 and 1.5 percent of all the culture-confirmed TB cases, a proportion similar to that of other industrialized countries. Most cases of zoonotic TB diagnosed in the UK were, at that point in time, attributed to (i) reactivation of long-standing latent infections acquired before widespread adoption of milk pasteurization, or (ii) _M. bovis_ infections contracted abroad. Throughout the said 14-year period, only one case was documented in the UK of confirmed, indigenous human _M. bovis_ infection recently acquired from an animal source.\n\nIn view of the increased incidence of bovine TB in cattle and other animals, the number of human cases is expected to rise.\n\nThe reviewer concluded:\n\"A significant risk of _M. bovis_ infection remains in certain segments of the UK population in the form of (i) continuing on-farm consumption of unpasteurized cows' milk, (ii) retail sales by approved establishments of unpasteurized milk and dairy products, and (iii) occupational exposure to infectious aerosols from tuberculous animals and their carcases.\"\n\n\"Physicians and other public health professionals must remember that zoonotic TB is not just a disease of the past.\"\n\nReference\n---------\nde la Rua-Domenech R: Human _Mycobacterium bovis_ infection in the United Kingdom: Incidence, risks, control measures and review of the zoonotic aspects of bovine tuberculosis. Tuberculosis (Edinb). 2006; 86(2): 77-10; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16257579. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Conventional microbiologic diagnosis of human tuberculosis relies on methods that allow only identification of \u201cMycobacterium tuberculosis complex\u201d. \u201cM. tuberculosis complex\u201d is composed of _ Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ (Mtb), as well as _Mycobacterium bovis_ (Mb) and several other genetically closely related species: the BCG bacillus, _M. africanum_, _M. caprae_, _M. microti_, and M. canetti. Mb is inherently resistant to pyrazinamide (PZA), a drug that is an essential component of the standard multidrug short-course regimen to treat human tuberculosis due to drug-susceptible Mtb. Differentiation of Mb from Mtb is therefore important clinically as well as epidemiologically. To distinguish Mb from these other species, special tests would have to be done, such as spoligotyping (spacer oligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based amplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome, or growth in selective media and specific biochemical reactions. If these special tests are not done, the diagnosis of Mb infection might be missed and the patient treated inappropriately. - ModML]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, alpaca - UK: immune system, RFI 20120430.1118567\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\n.................................................mhj/arn/mj/ml/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Worth DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom : incidence", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1119816", "headline": "PRO> Tuberculosis, TDR - India (05): (MH) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1119816", "date": "2012-02-18 16:34:53", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS \u2013 USA: (MICHIGAN) CERVID\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 15 Feb 2012\nSource: USA Today\nhttp://www.hometownlife.com/usatoday/article/38586015?odyssey=mod%7Cnewswell%7Ctext%7CLivonia%7Cs\n\n\nBovine TB tests ordered for Presque Isle cattle\n-----------------------------------------------\nROGERS CITY, Michigan: State officials are ordering tests for cattle in parts of Michigan's north eastern Lower Peninsula after 3 wild deer were found to have bovine tuberculosis.\n\nThe Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development said on Wednesday that the tests are required for cattle within a 10 mile radius of where each infected deer was killed during last year's hunting season in Presque Isle County, whose county seat is Rogers City.\n\nExperts recently confirmed the deer carried the potentially fatal disease. Federal officials have designated most of the Lower Peninsula as free of bovine TB. A high risk zone remains in Alcona, Alpena, Montmorency, and Oscoda counties. Presque Isle is among 7 counties in a mid-level zone. State veterinarian Dr Steven Halstead says the testing will help Presque Isle avoid being moved to the high risk group.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the various TB regions of Michigan may be found at http://www.michigan.gov/documents/MDA_TB_ZoneSplitStateMap_87803_7.pdf.\n\nMichigan may be found on the interactive HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1nDW.\n\nBovine tuberculosis has plagued the northern region of the lower peninsula of Michigan for some time. The surveillance on TB has included cervids for quite some time. Surveillance and risk involves both deer and cattle in trying to rid the state of this disease. \u2013 Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2011\n---\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (06): (IN) 20110924.2891\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (02): (Scotland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1101180", "date": "2012-02-18 16:34:53", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS \u2013 USA: (MICHIGAN) CERVID\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 15 Feb 2012\nSource: USA Today\nhttp://www.hometownlife.com/usatoday/article/38586015?odyssey=mod%7Cnewswell%7Ctext%7CLivonia%7Cs\n\n\nBovine TB tests ordered for Presque Isle cattle\n-----------------------------------------------\nROGERS CITY, Michigan: State officials are ordering tests for cattle in parts of Michigan's north eastern Lower Peninsula after 3 wild deer were found to have bovine tuberculosis.\n\nThe Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development said on Wednesday that the tests are required for cattle within a 10 mile radius of where each infected deer was killed during last year's hunting season in Presque Isle County, whose county seat is Rogers City.\n\nExperts recently confirmed the deer carried the potentially fatal disease. Federal officials have designated most of the Lower Peninsula as free of bovine TB. A high risk zone remains in Alcona, Alpena, Montmorency, and Oscoda counties. Presque Isle is among 7 counties in a mid-level zone. State veterinarian Dr Steven Halstead says the testing will help Presque Isle avoid being moved to the high risk group.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the various TB regions of Michigan may be found at http://www.michigan.gov/documents/MDA_TB_ZoneSplitStateMap_87803_7.pdf.\n\nMichigan may be found on the interactive HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1nDW.\n\nBovine tuberculosis has plagued the northern region of the lower peninsula of Michigan for some time. The surveillance on TB has included cervids for quite some time. Surveillance and risk involves both deer and cattle in trying to rid the state of this disease. \u2013 Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2011\n---\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (06): (IN) 20110924.2891\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - Federal officials have designated most of the Lower Peninsula as free of bovine TB. A high risk zone remains in Alcona, Alpena, Montmorency, and Oscoda counties. Presque Isle is among 7 counties in a mid-level zone. State veterinarian Dr Steven Halstead says the testing will help Presque Isle avoid being moved to the high risk group.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the various TB regions of Michigan may be found at http://www.michigan.gov/documents/MDA_TB_ZoneSplitStateMap_87803_7.pdf.\n\nMichigan may be found on the interactive HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1nDW.\n\nBovine tuberculosis has plagued the northern region of the lower peninsula of Michigan for some time. The surveillance on TB has included cervids for quite some time. Federal officials have designated most of the Lower Peninsula as free of bovine TB. A high risk zone remains in Alcona, Alpena, Montmorency, and Oscoda counties. Presque Isle is among 7 counties in a mid-level zone. State veterinarian Dr Steven Halstead says the testing will help Presque Isle avoid being moved to the high risk group.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the various TB regions of Michigan may be found at http://www.michigan.gov/documents/MDA_TB_ZoneSplitStateMap_87803_7.pdf.\n\nMichigan may be found on the interactive HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1nDW.\n\nBovine tuberculosis has plagued the northern region of the lower peninsula of Michigan for some time.
