USA: (MI) 20110322.0895\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (IN) 20110301.0670\n.................................................sb/tg/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-02-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Presque Isle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alcona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rogers City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Presque Isle County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1045228", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis, cervid - UK: (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1045228", "date": "2011-12-28 18:15:40", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (ILLE-ET-VILAINE), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Dec 2011\nFrom: Susan Baekeland <susan.baekeland@sfr.fr> [edited]\n\n\nA farmer in Saint George de Reintembault, La Mayenne who is a raiser\nof the beef-breed Bleu Belge (a well-built, large bovine with\nsilver-grey fur), sold one of his pedigree stock to a farmer in Izier,\njust southeast of Dijon in the Cote d'Or. The animal had a reaction to\na bovine tuberculosis test and was confirmed positive. The farmer at\nSaint George (about 25 km from me) has had his herd tested and\nconfirmed infected with bovine TB. The whole herd of some 300 pedigree\nanimals has been slaughtered, including even the farm dog.\n\nThis report has been confirmed by Dr Claude Gras, Cattle Vet at the\nCabinet Veteriniares, Rue de la Liberation, Saint James, 50240,\nNormandy, France.\n\nNo one knows how this herd became infected. There is a lot of forest\naround here, and we have boar, roe deer, foxes and the odd badger.\n\n--\nSusan Baekeland\nProMED-mail Correspondent\nCarnet\nLower Normandy\nFrance\n<susan.baekeland@sfr.fr>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a notifiable, contagious disease in the\nEuropean Union (EU). Several member states, including France, have\nattained, officially, tuberculosis-free (OTF) status (over 99.9\npercent of herds found free from bTB).\n\nSaint-Georges-de-Reintembault is a commune in the Ille-et-Vilaine\ndepartment in Bretagne in northwestern France. The slaughter of all\nbovines on the affected farm seems to be in line with France's bTB\ncontrol policy. It will be interesting to note whether the organs of\nthe culled animals have been examined, how many of them may have been\nfound affected, and how old were the lesions. The final results of the\nepidemiological investigation into the origin of infection is\nanticipated with interest; it may include the examinations of other\nspecies on the affected premises, such as the mentioned dog, as well\nas in the surroundings.\n\nIt addition, information on previous outbreaks in domestic cattle and\ncases in wildlife (specifying their species) recorded in this\ndepartment since the official declaration of France as OTF in 2000,\nwill be helpful. At that time (2000), there was no indication of a\nwildlife reservoir.\n\nIn recent years, bTB has been recorded in several parts of France in\nwildlife; this included red deer (_Cervus elaphus_), wild boar (_Sus\nscrofa_), roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_ and [the occasional] red fox\n(_Vulpes vulpes_). There has also been some recurrence of bTB on\ncattle farms. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Photo of Blanc-Bleu Belge cattle:\nhttp://farm1.staticflickr.com/49/134440993_a8191b1c62_z.jpg\nLocation map on ProMED-HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aq_\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................arn/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Normandy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint George de Reintembault", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint James", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1034331", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, MDR - worldwide: rates", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1034331", "date": "2011-12-28 18:15:40", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (ILLE-ET-VILAINE), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Dec 2011\nFrom: Susan Baekeland <susan.baekeland@sfr.fr> [edited]\n\n\nA farmer in Saint George de Reintembault, La Mayenne who is a raiser\nof the beef-breed Bleu Belge (a well-built, large bovine with\nsilver-grey fur), sold one of his pedigree stock to a farmer in Izier,\njust southeast of Dijon in the Cote d'Or. The animal had a reaction to\na bovine tuberculosis test and was confirmed positive. The farmer at\nSaint George (about 25 km from me) has had his herd tested and\nconfirmed infected with bovine TB. The whole herd of some 300 pedigree\nanimals has been slaughtered, including even the farm dog.\n\nThis report has been confirmed by Dr Claude Gras, Cattle Vet at the\nCabinet Veteriniares, Rue de la Liberation, Saint James, 50240,\nNormandy, France.\n\nNo one knows how this herd became infected. There is a lot of forest\naround here, and we have boar, roe deer, foxes and the odd badger.\n\n--\nSusan Baekeland\nProMED-mail Correspondent\nCarnet\nLower Normandy\nFrance\n<susan.baekeland@sfr.fr>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a notifiable, contagious disease in the\nEuropean Union (EU). Several member states, including France, have\nattained, officially, tuberculosis-free (OTF) status (over 99.9\npercent of herds found free from bTB).\n\nSaint-Georges-de-Reintembault is a commune in the Ille-et-Vilaine\ndepartment in Bretagne in northwestern France. The slaughter of all\nbovines on the affected farm seems to be in line with France's bTB\ncontrol policy. It will be interesting to note whether the organs of\nthe culled animals have been examined, how many of them may have been\nfound affected, and how old were the lesions. The final results of the\nepidemiological investigation into the origin of infection is\nanticipated with interest; it may include the examinations of other\nspecies on the affected premises, such as the mentioned dog, as well\nas in the surroundings.\n\nIt addition, information on previous outbreaks in domestic cattle and\ncases in wildlife (specifying their species) recorded in this\ndepartment since the official declaration of France as OTF in 2000,\nwill be helpful. At that time (2000), there was no indication of a\nwildlife reservoir.\n\nIn recent years, bTB has been recorded in several parts of France in\nwildlife; this included red deer (_Cervus elaphus_), wild boar (_Sus\nscrofa_), roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_ and [the occasional] red fox\n(_Vulpes vulpes_). There has also been some recurrence of bTB on\ncattle farms. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Photo of Blanc-Bleu Belge cattle:\nhttp://farm1.staticflickr.com/49/134440993_a8191b1c62_z.jpg\nLocation map on ProMED-HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aq_\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................arn/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Normandy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint George de Reintembault", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint James", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1017815", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis - UK: (England) badger control", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1017815", "date": "2011-12-28 18:15:40", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (ILLE-ET-VILAINE), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Dec 2011\nFrom: Susan Baekeland <susan.baekeland@sfr.fr> [edited]\n\n\nA farmer in Saint George de Reintembault, La Mayenne who is a raiser\nof the beef-breed Bleu Belge (a well-built, large bovine with\nsilver-grey fur), sold one of his pedigree stock to a farmer in Izier,\njust southeast of Dijon in the Cote d'Or. The animal had a reaction to\na bovine tuberculosis test and was confirmed positive. The farmer at\nSaint George (about 25 km from me) has had his herd tested and\nconfirmed infected with bovine TB. The whole herd of some 300 pedigree\nanimals has been slaughtered, including even the farm dog.\n\nThis report has been confirmed by Dr Claude Gras, Cattle Vet at the\nCabinet Veteriniares, Rue de la Liberation, Saint James, 50240,\nNormandy, France.\n\nNo one knows how this herd became infected. There is a lot of forest\naround here, and we have boar, roe deer, foxes and the odd badger.\n\n--\nSusan Baekeland\nProMED-mail Correspondent\nCarnet\nLower Normandy\nFrance\n<susan.baekeland@sfr.fr>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a notifiable, contagious disease in the\nEuropean Union (EU). Several member states, including France, have\nattained, officially, tuberculosis-free (OTF) status (over 99.9\npercent of herds found free from bTB).\n\nSaint-Georges-de-Reintembault is a commune in the Ille-et-Vilaine\ndepartment in Bretagne in northwestern France. The slaughter of all\nbovines on the affected farm seems to be in line with France's bTB\ncontrol policy. It will be interesting to note whether the organs of\nthe culled animals have been examined, how many of them may have been\nfound affected, and how old were the lesions. The final results of the\nepidemiological investigation into the origin of infection is\nanticipated with interest; it may include the examinations of other\nspecies on the affected premises, such as the mentioned dog, as well\nas in the surroundings.\n\nIt addition, information on previous outbreaks in domestic cattle and\ncases in wildlife (specifying their species) recorded in this\ndepartment since the official declaration of France as OTF in 2000,\nwill be helpful. At that time (2000), there was no indication of a\nwildlife reservoir.\n\nIn recent years, bTB has been recorded in several parts of France in\nwildlife; this included red deer (_Cervus elaphus_), wild boar (_Sus\nscrofa_), roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_ and [the occasional] red fox\n(_Vulpes vulpes_). There has also been some recurrence of bTB on\ncattle farms. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Photo of Blanc-Bleu Belge cattle:\nhttp://farm1.staticflickr.com/49/134440993_a8191b1c62_z.jpg\nLocation map on ProMED-HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aq_\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................arn/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Normandy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint George de Reintembault", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint James", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1015543", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, TDR - India (04): (MH) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1015543", "date": "2011-12-28 18:15:40", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (ILLE-ET-VILAINE), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Dec 2011\nFrom: Susan Baekeland <susan.baekeland@sfr.fr> [edited]\n\n\nA farmer in Saint George de Reintembault, La Mayenne who is a raiser\nof the beef-breed Bleu Belge (a well-built, large bovine with\nsilver-grey fur), sold one of his pedigree stock to a farmer in Izier,\njust southeast of Dijon in the Cote d'Or. The animal had a reaction to\na bovine tuberculosis test and was confirmed positive. The farmer at\nSaint George (about 25 km from me) has had his herd tested and\nconfirmed infected with bovine TB. The whole herd of some 300 pedigree\nanimals has been slaughtered, including even the farm dog.\n\nThis report has been confirmed by Dr Claude Gras, Cattle Vet at the\nCabinet Veteriniares, Rue de la Liberation, Saint James, 50240,\nNormandy, France.\n\nNo one knows how this herd became infected. There is a lot of forest\naround here, and we have boar, roe deer, foxes and the odd badger.\n\n--\nSusan Baekeland\nProMED-mail Correspondent\nCarnet\nLower Normandy\nFrance\n<susan.baekeland@sfr.fr>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a notifiable, contagious disease in the\nEuropean Union (EU). Several member states, including France, have\nattained, officially, tuberculosis-free (OTF) status (over 99.9\npercent of herds found free from bTB).\n\nSaint-Georges-de-Reintembault is a commune in the Ille-et-Vilaine\ndepartment in Bretagne in northwestern France. The slaughter of all\nbovines on the affected farm seems to be in line with France's bTB\ncontrol policy. It will be interesting to note whether the organs of\nthe culled animals have been examined, how many of them may have been\nfound affected, and how old were the lesions. The final results of the\nepidemiological investigation into the origin of infection is\nanticipated with interest; it may include the examinations of other\nspecies on the affected premises, such as the mentioned dog, as well\nas in the surroundings.\n\nIt addition, information on previous outbreaks in domestic cattle and\ncases in wildlife (specifying their species) recorded in this\ndepartment since the official declaration of France as OTF in 2000,\nwill be helpful. At that time (2000), there was no indication of a\nwildlife reservoir.\n\nIn recent years, bTB has been recorded in several parts of France in\nwildlife; this included red deer (_Cervus elaphus_), wild boar (_Sus\nscrofa_), roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_ and [the occasional] red fox\n(_Vulpes vulpes_). There has also been some recurrence of bTB on\ncattle farms. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Photo of Blanc-Bleu Belge cattle:\nhttp://farm1.staticflickr.com/49/134440993_a8191b1c62_z.jpg\nLocation map on ProMED-HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aq_\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................arn/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Normandy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint George de Reintembault", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint James", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1012906", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, TDR - India (03): (MH) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1012906", "date": "2011-12-28 18:15:40", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (ILLE-ET-VILAINE), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Dec 2011\nFrom: Susan Baekeland <susan.baekeland@sfr.fr> [edited]\n\n\nA farmer in Saint George de Reintembault, La Mayenne who is a raiser\nof the beef-breed Bleu Belge (a well-built, large bovine with\nsilver-grey fur), sold one of his pedigree stock to a farmer in Izier,\njust southeast of Dijon in the Cote d'Or. The animal had a reaction to\na bovine tuberculosis test and was confirmed positive. The farmer at\nSaint George (about 25 km from me) has had his herd tested and\nconfirmed infected with bovine TB. The whole herd of some 300 pedigree\nanimals has been slaughtered, including even the farm dog.\n\nThis report has been confirmed by Dr Claude Gras, Cattle Vet at the\nCabinet Veteriniares, Rue de la Liberation, Saint James, 50240,\nNormandy, France.\n\nNo one knows how this herd became infected. There is a lot of forest\naround here, and we have boar, roe deer, foxes and the odd badger.\n\n--\nSusan Baekeland\nProMED-mail Correspondent\nCarnet\nLower Normandy\nFrance\n<susan.baekeland@sfr.fr>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a notifiable, contagious disease in the\nEuropean Union (EU). Several member states, including France, have\nattained, officially, tuberculosis-free (OTF) status (over 99.9\npercent of herds found free from bTB).\n\nSaint-Georges-de-Reintembault is a commune in the Ille-et-Vilaine\ndepartment in Bretagne in northwestern France. The slaughter of all\nbovines on the affected farm seems to be in line with France's bTB\ncontrol policy. It will be interesting to note whether the organs of\nthe culled animals have been examined, how many of them may have been\nfound affected, and how old were the lesions. The final results of the\nepidemiological investigation into the origin of infection is\nanticipated with interest; it may include the examinations of other\nspecies on the affected premises, such as the mentioned dog, as well\nas in the surroundings.\n\nIt addition, information on previous outbreaks in domestic cattle and\ncases in wildlife (specifying their species) recorded in this\ndepartment since the official declaration of France as OTF in 2000,\nwill be helpful. At that time (2000), there was no indication of a\nwildlife reservoir.\n\nIn recent years, bTB has been recorded in several parts of France in\nwildlife; this included red deer (_Cervus elaphus_), wild boar (_Sus\nscrofa_), roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_ and [the occasional] red fox\n(_Vulpes vulpes_). There has also been some recurrence of bTB on\ncattle farms. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Photo of Blanc-Bleu Belge cattle:\nhttp://farm1.staticflickr.com/49/134440993_a8191b1c62_z.jpg\nLocation map on ProMED-HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aq_\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................arn/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Normandy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint George de Reintembault", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint James", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1009005", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, TDR - India (02): (KA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1009005", "date": "2011-12-28 18:15:40", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (ILLE-ET-VILAINE), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Dec 2011\nFrom: Susan Baekeland <susan.baekeland@sfr.fr> [edited]\n\n\nA farmer in Saint George de Reintembault, La Mayenne who is a raiser\nof the beef-breed Bleu Belge (a well-built, large bovine with\nsilver-grey fur), sold one of his pedigree stock to a farmer in Izier,\njust southeast of Dijon in the Cote d'Or. The animal had a reaction to\na bovine tuberculosis test and was confirmed positive. The farmer at\nSaint George (about 25 km from me) has had his herd tested and\nconfirmed infected with bovine TB. The whole herd of some 300 pedigree\nanimals has been slaughtered, including even the farm dog.\n\nThis report has been confirmed by Dr Claude Gras, Cattle Vet at the\nCabinet Veteriniares, Rue de la Liberation, Saint James, 50240,\nNormandy, France.\n\nNo one knows how this herd became infected. There is a lot of forest\naround here, and we have boar, roe deer, foxes and the odd badger.\n\n--\nSusan Baekeland\nProMED-mail Correspondent\nCarnet\nLower Normandy\nFrance\n<susan.baekeland@sfr.fr>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a notifiable, contagious disease in the\nEuropean Union (EU). Several member states, including France, have\nattained, officially, tuberculosis-free (OTF) status (over 99.9\npercent of herds found free from bTB).\n\nSaint-Georges-de-Reintembault is a commune in the Ille-et-Vilaine\ndepartment in Bretagne in northwestern France. The slaughter of all\nbovines on the affected farm seems to be in line with France's bTB\ncontrol policy. It will be interesting to note whether the organs of\nthe culled animals have been examined, how many of them may have been\nfound affected, and how old were the lesions. The final results of the\nepidemiological investigation into the origin of infection is\nanticipated with interest; it may include the examinations of other\nspecies on the affected premises, such as the mentioned dog, as well\nas in the surroundings.\n\nIt addition, information on previous outbreaks in domestic cattle and\ncases in wildlife (specifying their species) recorded in this\ndepartment since the official declaration of France as OTF in 2000,\nwill be helpful. At that time (2000), there was no indication of a\nwildlife reservoir.\n\nIn recent years, bTB has been recorded in several parts of France in\nwildlife; this included red deer (_Cervus elaphus_), wild boar (_Sus\nscrofa_), roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_ and [the occasional] red fox\n(_Vulpes vulpes_). There has also been some recurrence of bTB on\ncattle farms. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Photo of Blanc-Bleu Belge cattle:\nhttp://farm1.staticflickr.com/49/134440993_a8191b1c62_z.jpg\nLocation map on ProMED-HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aq_\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................arn/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Normandy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint George de Reintembault", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint James", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1005663", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, TDR - India: (MH, KA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1005663", "date": "2011-12-28 18:15:40", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (ILLE-ET-VILAINE), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Dec 2011\nFrom: Susan Baekeland <susan.baekeland@sfr.fr> [edited]\n\n\nA farmer in Saint George de Reintembault, La Mayenne who is a raiser\nof the beef-breed Bleu Belge (a well-built, large bovine with\nsilver-grey fur), sold one of his pedigree stock to a farmer in Izier,\njust southeast of Dijon in the Cote d'Or. The animal had a reaction to\na bovine tuberculosis test and was confirmed positive. The farmer at\nSaint George (about 25 km from me) has had his herd tested and\nconfirmed infected with bovine TB. The whole herd of some 300 pedigree\nanimals has been slaughtered, including even the farm dog.\n\nThis report has been confirmed by Dr Claude Gras, Cattle Vet at the\nCabinet Veteriniares, Rue de la Liberation, Saint James, 50240,\nNormandy, France.\n\nNo one knows how this herd became infected. There is a lot of forest\naround here, and we have boar, roe deer, foxes and the odd badger.\n\n--\nSusan Baekeland\nProMED-mail Correspondent\nCarnet\nLower Normandy\nFrance\n<susan.baekeland@sfr.fr>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a notifiable, contagious disease in the\nEuropean Union (EU). Several member states, including France, have\nattained, officially, tuberculosis-free (OTF) status (over 99.9\npercent of herds found free from bTB).\n\nSaint-Georges-de-Reintembault is a commune in the Ille-et-Vilaine\ndepartment in Bretagne in northwestern France. The slaughter of all\nbovines on the affected farm seems to be in line with France's bTB\ncontrol policy. It will be interesting to note whether the organs of\nthe culled animals have been examined, how many of them may have been\nfound affected, and how old were the lesions. The final results of the\nepidemiological investigation into the origin of infection is\nanticipated with interest; it may include the examinations of other\nspecies on the affected premises, such as the mentioned dog, as well\nas in the surroundings.\n\nIt addition, information on previous outbreaks in domestic cattle and\ncases in wildlife (specifying their species) recorded in this\ndepartment since the official declaration of France as OTF in 2000,\nwill be helpful. At that time (2000), there was no indication of a\nwildlife reservoir.\n\nIn recent years, bTB has been recorded in several parts of France in\nwildlife; this included red deer (_Cervus elaphus_), wild boar (_Sus\nscrofa_), roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_ and [the occasional] red fox\n(_Vulpes vulpes_). There has also been some recurrence of bTB on\ncattle farms. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Photo of Blanc-Bleu Belge cattle:\nhttp://farm1.staticflickr.com/49/134440993_a8191b1c62_z.jpg\nLocation map on ProMED-HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aq_\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................arn/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Normandy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint George de Reintembault", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint James", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "993030", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - France: (IV) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=993030", "date": "2011-12-28 18:15:40", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - FRANCE: (ILLE-ET-VILAINE), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Dec 2011\nFrom: Susan Baekeland <susan.baekeland@sfr.fr> [edited]\n\n\nA farmer in Saint George de Reintembault, La Mayenne who is a raiser\nof the beef-breed Bleu Belge (a well-built, large bovine with\nsilver-grey fur), sold one of his pedigree stock to a farmer in Izier,\njust southeast of Dijon in the Cote d'Or. The animal had a reaction to\na bovine tuberculosis test and was confirmed positive. The farmer at\nSaint George (about 25 km from me) has had his herd tested and\nconfirmed infected with bovine TB. The whole herd of some 300 pedigree\nanimals has been slaughtered, including even the farm dog.\n\nThis report has been confirmed by Dr Claude Gras, Cattle Vet at the\nCabinet Veteriniares, Rue de la Liberation, Saint James, 50240,\nNormandy, France.\n\nNo one knows how this herd became infected. There is a lot of forest\naround here, and we have boar, roe deer, foxes and the odd badger.\n\n--\nSusan Baekeland\nProMED-mail Correspondent\nCarnet\nLower Normandy\nFrance\n<susan.baekeland@sfr.fr>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a notifiable, contagious disease in the\nEuropean Union (EU). Several member states, including France, have\nattained, officially, tuberculosis-free (OTF) status (over 99.9\npercent of herds found free from bTB).\n\nSaint-Georges-de-Reintembault is a commune in the Ille-et-Vilaine\ndepartment in Bretagne in northwestern France. The slaughter of all\nbovines on the affected farm seems to be in line with France's bTB\ncontrol policy. It will be interesting to note whether the organs of\nthe culled animals have been examined, how many of them may have been\nfound affected, and how old were the lesions. The final results of the\nepidemiological investigation into the origin of infection is\nanticipated with interest; it may include the examinations of other\nspecies on the affected premises, such as the mentioned dog, as well\nas in the surroundings.\n\nIt addition, information on previous outbreaks in domestic cattle and\ncases in wildlife (specifying their species) recorded in this\ndepartment since the official declaration of France as OTF in 2000,\nwill be helpful. At that time (2000), there was no indication of a\nwildlife reservoir.\n\nIn recent years, bTB has been recorded in several parts of France in\nwildlife; this included red deer (_Cervus elaphus_), wild boar (_Sus\nscrofa_), roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_ and [the occasional] red fox\n(_Vulpes vulpes_). There has also been some recurrence of bTB on\ncattle farms. - Mod.AS]\n\n[Photo of Blanc-Bleu Belge cattle:\nhttp://farm1.staticflickr.com/49/134440993_a8191b1c62_z.jpg\nLocation map on ProMED-HealthMap at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aq_\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France: (MP) 20100831.3096\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - France (Brittany) 20081006.3160\n.................................................arn/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Normandy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint George de Reintembault", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint James", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "964257", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, bovine - New Zealand (02): possum reservoir", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=964257", "date": "2011-10-14 19:13:16", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: BADGER VACCINATION\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 12 Oct 2011\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-15273307\n\n\nBadger vaccine project generates 'delight'\n------------------------------------------\nThe UK's 1st independent badger vaccination project has proved that\nthe technique is \"viable and affordable,\" according to the charity\nrunning it. The Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust vaccinated 35 badgers\nduring the summer against the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB)\nin cattle.\n\nThe government wants to fight cattle TB in England through culling,\nbut animal groups see vaccination as preferable. The trial did not\nlook for any impact on disease in badgers or cattle. Instead, the idea\nwas to see how feasible it would be to train staff and vaccinate the\nanimals, and how much it might cost.\n\n\"We are delighted with the results (which prove) that there is an\naffordable alternative to the proposed cull,\" said Gordon McGlone, the\ntrust's chief executive. Bovine TB is a big problem, but local culling\nof one of our much-loved native animals is not the answer. Scientists\nhave spent the last 12 years investigating whether killing badgers\nwill halt this serious disease in cattle, and the answer they are\ngetting is that it could well make the problem worse.\"\n\nThe UK's so-called \"Krebs Trial,\" the largest investigation of badger\nculling undertaken in any country, found that culling can reduce the\nincidence of bovine TB in the target area. But if it is not done\nthoroughly and consistently over a large area, it can actually\nincrease the disease burden, as badgers roam further from their setts\nwhen others die, taking bacteria to other farms. Conservation groups\nargue that vaccination does not carry this risk.\n\nBut the Gloucestershire experience suggests it might be more expensive\nthan culling, with the wildlife trust reporting an average cost of BP\n51 per hectare. The true cost of culling will not be known unless and\nuntil it happens, but farmers' leaders believe it may be in the region\nof BP 20 per hectare.\n\nThe Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust hopes it will never happen. They,\nand other conservation groups, argue that a combination of tighter\nrestrictions on farmers and vaccination will be more effective, and\nthat in any case, badgers should not be killed as a matter of\nprinciple.\n\nThe National Trust has also begun an implementation trial, at its\nproperty at Killerton in Devon. Other wildlife trusts are expected to\nbegin similar projects now that the Gloucestershire group has reported\nits positive experience.\n\nThe UK government, meanwhile, is midway through a 2nd consultation\nperiod on its culling proposals for England. It is not against\nvaccination, but believes the approach will have much more success\nwhen an edible formulation becomes available to supplant the existing\ninjectable dose, which could take another 4 to 5 years.\n\nIn Wales, plans are on hold following the election in May 2011 of a\nLabour government.\n\n[Byline: Richard Black]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An effective baited oral vaccine, if/when available, will be a\nsignificant step forward.\n\nSee another article, kindly forwarded by Sabine Zentis, at\nhttp://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/13/10/2011/129571/Clash-over-bovine-TB-controls.htm.\n- Mod.AS]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for England is available at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1fj0 - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: alpaca, mastitis, implications\n20110825.2588\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - UK (04): England 20110723.2219\nBovine tuberculosis, porcine - UK: Wales 20110717.2170\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: (Wales) badger control 20110328.0969\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): badger vaccination 20101110.4082\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): new control program 20100921.3396\n.................................................mhj/arn/ejp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "957944", "headline": "PRO> Tuberculosis, drug resistance - North Korea (03): comment, BCG coverage", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=957944", "date": "2011-10-14 19:13:16", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: BADGER VACCINATION\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 12 Oct 2011\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-15273307\n\n\nBadger vaccine project generates 'delight'\n------------------------------------------\nThe UK's 1st independent badger vaccination project has proved that\nthe technique is \"viable and affordable,\" according to the charity\nrunning it. The Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust vaccinated 35 badgers\nduring the summer against the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB)\nin cattle.\n\nThe government wants to fight cattle TB in England through culling,\nbut animal groups see vaccination as preferable. The trial did not\nlook for any impact on disease in badgers or cattle. Instead, the idea\nwas to see how feasible it would be to train staff and vaccinate the\nanimals, and how much it might cost.\n\n\"We are delighted with the results (which prove) that there is an\naffordable alternative to the proposed cull,\" said Gordon McGlone, the\ntrust's chief executive. Bovine TB is a big problem, but local culling\nof one of our much-loved native animals is not the answer. Scientists\nhave spent the last 12 years investigating whether killing badgers\nwill halt this serious disease in cattle, and the answer they are\ngetting is that it could well make the problem worse.\"\n\nThe UK's so-called \"Krebs Trial,\" the largest investigation of badger\nculling undertaken in any country, found that culling can reduce the\nincidence of bovine TB in the target area. But if it is not done\nthoroughly and consistently over a large area, it can actually\nincrease the disease burden, as badgers roam further from their setts\nwhen others die, taking bacteria to other farms. Conservation groups\nargue that vaccination does not carry this risk.\n\nBut the Gloucestershire experience suggests it might be more expensive\nthan culling, with the wildlife trust reporting an average cost of BP\n51 per hectare. The true cost of culling will not be known unless and\nuntil it happens, but farmers' leaders believe it may be in the region\nof BP 20 per hectare.\n\nThe Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust hopes it will never happen. They,\nand other conservation groups, argue that a combination of tighter\nrestrictions on farmers and vaccination will be more effective, and\nthat in any case, badgers should not be killed as a matter of\nprinciple.\n\nThe National Trust has also begun an implementation trial, at its\nproperty at Killerton in Devon. Other wildlife trusts are expected to\nbegin similar projects now that the Gloucestershire group has reported\nits positive experience.\n\nThe UK government, meanwhile, is midway through a 2nd consultation\nperiod on its culling proposals for England. It is not against\nvaccination, but believes the approach will have much more success\nwhen an edible formulation becomes available to supplant the existing\ninjectable dose, which could take another 4 to 5 years.\n\nIn Wales, plans are on hold following the election in May 2011 of a\nLabour government.\n\n[Byline: Richard Black]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An effective baited oral vaccine, if/when available, will be a\nsignificant step forward.\n\nSee another article, kindly forwarded by Sabine Zentis, at\nhttp://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/13/10/2011/129571/Clash-over-bovine-TB-controls.htm.\n- Mod.AS]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for England is available at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1fj0 - UK: (Wales) badger control 20110328.0969\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): badger vaccination 20101110.4082\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): new control program 20100921.3396\n.................................................mhj/arn/ejp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-05-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "950247", "headline": "PRO> Tuberculosis, drug resistance - North Korea (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=950247", "date": "2011-10-14 19:13:16", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: BADGER VACCINATION\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 12 Oct 2011\nSource: BBC News [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-15273307\n\n\nBadger vaccine project generates 'delight'\n------------------------------------------\nThe UK's 1st independent badger vaccination project has proved that\nthe technique is \"viable and affordable,\" according to the charity\nrunning it. The Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust vaccinated 35 badgers\nduring the summer against the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB)\nin cattle.\n\nThe government wants to fight cattle TB in England through culling,\nbut animal groups see vaccination as preferable. The trial did not\nlook for any impact on disease in badgers or cattle. Instead, the idea\nwas to see how feasible it would be to train staff and vaccinate the\nanimals, and how much it might cost.\n\n\"We are delighted with the results (which prove) that there is an\naffordable alternative to the proposed cull,\" said Gordon McGlone, the\ntrust's chief executive. Bovine TB is a big problem, but local culling\nof one of our much-loved native animals is not the answer. Scientists\nhave spent the last 12 years investigating whether killing badgers\nwill halt this serious disease in cattle, and the answer they are\ngetting is that it could well make the problem worse.\"\n\nThe UK's so-called \"Krebs Trial,\" the largest investigation of badger\nculling undertaken in any country, found that culling can reduce the\nincidence of bovine TB in the target area. But if it is not done\nthoroughly and consistently over a large area, it can actually\nincrease the disease burden, as badgers roam further from their setts\nwhen others die, taking bacteria to other farms. Conservation groups\nargue that vaccination does not carry this risk.\n\nBut the Gloucestershire experience suggests it might be more expensive\nthan culling, with the wildlife trust reporting an average cost of BP\n51 per hectare. The true cost of culling will not be known unless and\nuntil it happens, but farmers' leaders believe it may be in the region\nof BP 20 per hectare.\n\nThe Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust hopes it will never happen. They,\nand other conservation groups, argue that a combination of tighter\nrestrictions on farmers and vaccination will be more effective, and\nthat in any case, badgers should not be killed as a matter of\nprinciple.\n\nThe National Trust has also begun an implementation trial, at its\nproperty at Killerton in Devon. Other wildlife trusts are expected to\nbegin similar projects now that the Gloucestershire group has reported\nits positive experience.\n\nThe UK government, meanwhile, is midway through a 2nd consultation\nperiod on its culling proposals for England. It is not against\nvaccination, but believes the approach will have much more success\nwhen an edible formulation becomes available to supplant the existing\ninjectable dose, which could take another 4 to 5 years.\n\nIn Wales, plans are on hold following the election in May 2011 of a\nLabour government.\n\n[Byline: Richard Black]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An effective baited oral vaccine, if/when available, will be a\nsignificant step forward.\n\nSee another article, kindly forwarded by Sabine Zentis, at\nhttp://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/13/10/2011/129571/Clash-over-bovine-TB-controls.htm.\n- Mod.AS]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for England is available at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1fj0 - The Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust vaccinated 35 badgers\nduring the summer against the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB)\nin cattle.\n\nThe government wants to fight cattle TB in England through culling,\nbut animal groups see vaccination as preferable. The trial did not\nlook for any impact on disease in badgers or cattle. Instead, the idea\nwas to see how feasible it would be to train staff and vaccinate the\nanimals, and how much it might cost.\n\n\"We are delighted with the results (which prove) that there is an\naffordable alternative to the proposed cull,\" said Gordon McGlone, the\ntrust's chief executive. Bovine TB is a big problem, but local culling\nof one of our much-loved native animals is not the answer. Scientists\nhave spent the last 12 years investigating whether killing badgers\nwill halt this serious disease in cattle, and the answer they are\ngetting is that it could well make the problem worse.\"\n\nThe UK's so-called \"Krebs Trial,\" the largest investigation of badger\nculling undertaken in any country, found that culling can reduce the\nincidence of bovine TB in the target area. But if it is not done\nthoroughly and consistently over a large area, it can actually\nincrease the disease burden, as badgers roam further from their setts\nwhen others die, taking bacteria to other farms. Conservation groups\nargue that vaccination does not carry this risk.\n\nBut the Gloucestershire experience suggests it might be more expensive\nthan culling, with the wildlife trust reporting an average cost of BP\n51 per hectare. The true cost of culling will not be known unless and\nuntil it happens, but farmers' leaders believe it may be in the region\nof BP 20 per hectare.\n\nThe Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust hopes it will never happen. They,\nand other conservation groups, argue that a combination of tighter\nrestrictions on farmers and vaccination will be more effective, and\nthat in any case, badgers should not be killed as a matter of\nprinciple.\n\nThe National Trust has also begun an implementation trial, at its\nproperty at Killerton in Devon. Other wildlife trusts are expected to\nbegin similar projects now that the Gloucestershire group has reported\nits positive experience.\n\nThe UK government, meanwhile, is midway through a 2nd consultation\nperiod on its culling proposals for England. It is not against\nvaccination, but believes the approach will have much more success\nwhen an edible formulation becomes available to supplant the existing\ninjectable dose, which could take another 4 to 5 years.\n\nIn Wales, plans are on hold following the election in May 2011 of a\nLabour government.\n\n[Byline: Richard Black]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An effective baited oral vaccine, if/when available, will be a\nsignificant step forward.\n\nSee another article, kindly forwarded by Sabine Zentis, at\nhttp://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/13/10/2011/129571/Clash-over-bovine-TB-controls.htm.\n- Mod.AS]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for England is available at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1fj0 - Instead, the idea\nwas to see how feasible it would be to train staff and vaccinate the\nanimals, and how much it might cost.\n\n\"We are delighted with the results (which prove) that there is an\naffordable alternative to the proposed cull,\" said Gordon McGlone, the\ntrust's chief executive. USA (06): (IN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=884409", "date": "2011-07-26 12:53:26", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, INACCURATE BLOOD TESTS, WHO STATEMENT (03)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 25 Jul 2011\nFrom: John P Maher <jmaher@chesco.org> [edited]\n\n\nre: ProMED-mail Tuberculosis, inaccurate blood tests, WHO statement\n(02) 20110724.2233\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nConcerning the moderator's comments about BCG causing false positives:\nwe have been told by CDC representatives on several occasions in the\npast that a positive TST [tuberculin skin test] after 18 months\npost-BCG vaccination is to be considered evidence of LTBI [latent TB\ninfection] and that chemoprophylaxis should be offered.\n\n--\nJohn P Maher, MD, MPH\nPublic Health Physician\nChester County (PA) Health Department\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n[BCG, or bacille Calmette-Guerin, is a vaccine used in many countries\nwith a high prevalence of TB to prevent childhood tuberculous\nmeningitis and miliary disease. BCG may cause a reaction to the\ntuberculin skin test (TST). The effect of BCG vaccination on TST\nreactivity is dependent on strain and dose of BCG used, the method of\nvaccine administration, the number of BCG vaccinations administered,\nthe age, weight, and nutritional status of the individual at the time\nof vaccination, genetic factors, and the time since vaccination (1).\nHowever, the BCG effect on the tuberculin skin test declines in both\nfrequency and size of the reaction over time. Studies have shown that\na TST applied several years after neonatal BCG vaccination usually\nproduces a reaction of less than 10 mm; TST reactions larger than 10\nmm are unlikely to occur in the absence of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection (2,3). Certainly neonatal BCG vaccination has\na minimal effect on the TST as an adolescent or adult; in a review of\n24 studies involving 240 203 subjects BCG-vaccinated as infants,\noverall 20 406 (8.5 percent) had a TST reaction of 10 mm or larger\nattributable to BCG, but only 56/5639 (1 percent) were TST-positive\n(10 mm or larger) if tested 10 years or more after BCG (4). Indeed,\nthe US CDC recommends that a history of BCG vaccination be disregarded\nwhen interpreting a TST (5).\n\nInterferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs), which use antigens that are\nspecific for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, do not cause cross\nreactions with BCG, and therefore do not cause false-positive\nreactions in BCG recipients (6). A history of BCG vaccination should\nthus be an indication for use of an IGRA when screening for LTBI to\neliminate any confusion over interpretation of TST reactivity that\ncould complicate decisions about prescribing chemoprophylactic therapy\nfor LTBI.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Burl S, Adetifa UJ, Cox M, et al: The tuberculin skin test (TST) is\naffected by recent BCG vaccination but not by exposure to\nnon-tuberculosis mycobacteria (NTM) during early life. PLoS ONE. 2010;\n5(8): e12287. Available at\nhttp://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0012287#pone.0012287-MiretCuadras1.\n2. Santiago EM, Lawson E, Gillenwater K, et al: A prospective study of\nbacillus Calmette-Guerin scar formation and tuberculin skin test\nreactivity in infants in Lima, Peru. Pediatrics. 2003; 112(4): e298.\nAvailable at\nhttp://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/112/4/e298.long.\n3. Chan PC, Chang LY, Wu YC, et al: Age-specific cut-offs for the\ntuberculin skin test to detect latent tuberculosis in BCG-vaccinated\nchildren. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis. 2008; 12(12): 1401-6. Available at\n63724459.1/iuatld/ijtld/2008/00000012/00000012/art00012/005ED3EEC7920A1C1311696632AFC7D0F75E0BAEDB.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">http://docstore.ingenta.com/cgi-bin/ds_deliver/1/u/d/ISIS/ 63724459.1/iuatld/ijtld/2008/00000012/00000012/art00012/005ED3EEC7920A1C1311696632AFC7D0F75E0BAEDB.pdf\n4. Farhat M, Greenaway C, Pai M, Menzies D: False-positive tuberculin\nskin tests: what is the absolute effect of BCG and non-tuberculous\nmycobacteria? Int J Tuberc Lung Dis. 2006; 10(11): 1192-204. Available\nat\n63724490.1/iuatld/ijtld/2006/00000010/00000011/art00003/85B7D92AE2463EB013116967791F438205CC451CCF.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">http://docstore.ingenta.com/cgi-bin/ds_deliver/1/u/d/ISIS/ 63724490.1/iuatld/ijtld/2006/00000010/00000011/art00003/85B7D92AE2463EB013116967791F438205CC451CCF.pdf\n5. CDC: Tuberculosis: testing and diagnosis. Available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/testing/default.htm.\n6. CDC: latent tuberculosis infection: a guide for primary health care\nproviders. Available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/tb/publications/LTBI/diagnosis.htm. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, inaccurate blood tests, WHO statement 20110723.2217\nTuberculosis - Pakistan: increased incidence 20110618.1866\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2010\n----\nTuberculosis - UK: resurgence 20101223.4522\nTuberculosis - Canada: (NU), Inuit 20101008.3659\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Marshall Islands: RFI 20100131.0335\n2009\n----\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nTuberculosis, MDR - China 20090114.0151\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, XDR - Austria ex Romania 20080803.2373\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Peru 20080412.1337\nTuberculosis, XDR - Namibia 20080403.1231\nTuberculosis, XDR - UK (Scotland) ex Somalia 20080322.1094\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - South Africa 20080208.0521\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\nTuberculosis, XDR - Botswana, South Africa 20080118.0222\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, XDR, MDR: genome sequences 20071122.3780\nTuberculosis - Uganda (02): MDR, susp. BCG may cause a reaction to the\ntuberculin skin test (TST). The effect of BCG vaccination on TST\nreactivity is dependent on strain and dose of BCG used, the method of\nvaccine administration, the number of BCG vaccinations administered,\nthe age, weight, and nutritional status of the individual at the time\nof vaccination, genetic factors, and the time since vaccination (1).\nHowever, the BCG effect on the tuberculin skin test declines in both\nfrequency and size of the reaction over time. Certainly neonatal BCG vaccination has\na minimal effect on the TST as an adolescent or adult; in a review of\n24 studies involving 240 203 subjects BCG-vaccinated as infants,\noverall 20 406 (8.5 percent) had a TST reaction of 10 mm or larger\nattributable to BCG, but only 56/5639 (1 percent) were TST-positive\n(10 mm or larger) if tested 10 years or more after BCG (4). A history of BCG vaccination should\nthus be an indication for use of an IGRA when screening for LTBI to\neliminate any confusion over interpretation of TST reactivity that\ncould complicate decisions about prescribing chemoprophylactic therapy\nfor LTBI.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Italy (03): (Rome)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=852903", "date": "2011-07-26 12:53:26", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, INACCURATE BLOOD TESTS, WHO STATEMENT (03)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 25 Jul 2011\nFrom: John P Maher <jmaher@chesco.org> [edited]\n\n\nre: ProMED-mail Tuberculosis, inaccurate blood tests, WHO statement\n(02) 20110724.2233\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nConcerning the moderator's comments about BCG causing false positives:\nwe have been told by CDC representatives on several occasions in the\npast that a positive TST [tuberculin skin test] after 18 months\npost-BCG vaccination is to be considered evidence of LTBI [latent TB\ninfection] and that chemoprophylaxis should be offered.\n\n--\nJohn P Maher, MD, MPH\nPublic Health Physician\nChester County (PA) Health Department\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n[BCG, or bacille Calmette-Guerin, is a vaccine used in many countries\nwith a high prevalence of TB to prevent childhood tuberculous\nmeningitis and miliary disease. BCG may cause a reaction to the\ntuberculin skin test (TST). The effect of BCG vaccination on TST\nreactivity is dependent on strain and dose of BCG used, the method of\nvaccine administration, the number of BCG vaccinations administered,\nthe age, weight, and nutritional status of the individual at the time\nof vaccination, genetic factors, and the time since vaccination (1).\nHowever, the BCG effect on the tuberculin skin test declines in both\nfrequency and size of the reaction over time. Studies have shown that\na TST applied several years after neonatal BCG vaccination usually\nproduces a reaction of less than 10 mm; TST reactions larger than 10\nmm are unlikely to occur in the absence of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection (2,3). Certainly neonatal BCG vaccination has\na minimal effect on the TST as an adolescent or adult; in a review of\n24 studies involving 240 203 subjects BCG-vaccinated as infants,\noverall 20 406 (8.5 percent) had a TST reaction of 10 mm or larger\nattributable to BCG, but only 56/5639 (1 percent) were TST-positive\n(10 mm or larger) if tested 10 years or more after BCG (4). Indeed,\nthe US CDC recommends that a history of BCG vaccination be disregarded\nwhen interpreting a TST (5).\n\nInterferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs), which use antigens that are\nspecific for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, do not cause cross\nreactions with BCG, and therefore do not cause false-positive\nreactions in BCG recipients (6). A history of BCG vaccination should\nthus be an indication for use of an IGRA when screening for LTBI to\neliminate any confusion over interpretation of TST reactivity that\ncould complicate decisions about prescribing chemoprophylactic therapy\nfor LTBI.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\n.................................................ml/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1401-06-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chester County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lima", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Botswana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "848587", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, latent, nosocomial, infants - Italy (02): (Rome)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=848587", "date": "2011-07-26 12:53:26", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, INACCURATE BLOOD TESTS, WHO STATEMENT (03)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 25 Jul 2011\nFrom: John P Maher <jmaher@chesco.org> [edited]\n\n\nre: ProMED-mail Tuberculosis, inaccurate blood tests, WHO statement\n(02) 20110724.2233\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nConcerning the moderator's comments about BCG causing false positives:\nwe have been told by CDC representatives on several occasions in the\npast that a positive TST [tuberculin skin test] after 18 months\npost-BCG vaccination is to be considered evidence of LTBI [latent TB\ninfection] and that chemoprophylaxis should be offered.\n\n--\nJohn P Maher, MD, MPH\nPublic Health Physician\nChester County (PA) Health Department\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n[BCG, or bacille Calmette-Guerin, is a vaccine used in many countries\nwith a high prevalence of TB to prevent childhood tuberculous\nmeningitis and miliary disease. BCG may cause a reaction to the\ntuberculin skin test (TST). The effect of BCG vaccination on TST\nreactivity is dependent on strain and dose of BCG used, the method of\nvaccine administration, the number of BCG vaccinations administered,\nthe age, weight, and nutritional status of the individual at the time\nof vaccination, genetic factors, and the time since vaccination (1).\nHowever, the BCG effect on the tuberculin skin test declines in both\nfrequency and size of the reaction over time. Studies have shown that\na TST applied several years after neonatal BCG vaccination usually\nproduces a reaction of less than 10 mm; TST reactions larger than 10\nmm are unlikely to occur in the absence of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection (2,3). Certainly neonatal BCG vaccination has\na minimal effect on the TST as an adolescent or adult; in a review of\n24 studies involving 240 203 subjects BCG-vaccinated as infants,\noverall 20 406 (8.5 percent) had a TST reaction of 10 mm or larger\nattributable to BCG, but only 56/5639 (1 percent) were TST-positive\n(10 mm or larger) if tested 10 years or more after BCG (4). Indeed,\nthe US CDC recommends that a history of BCG vaccination be disregarded\nwhen interpreting a TST (5).\n\nInterferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs), which use antigens that are\nspecific for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, do not cause cross\nreactions with BCG, and therefore do not cause false-positive\nreactions in BCG recipients (6). A history of BCG vaccination should\nthus be an indication for use of an IGRA when screening for LTBI to\neliminate any confusion over interpretation of TST reactivity that\ncould complicate decisions about prescribing chemoprophylactic therapy\nfor LTBI.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Burl S, Adetifa UJ, Cox M, et al: The tuberculin skin test (TST) is\naffected by recent BCG vaccination but not by exposure to\nnon-tuberculosis mycobacteria (NTM) during early life. PLoS ONE. 2010;\n5(8): e12287. Available at\nhttp://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0012287#pone.0012287-MiretCuadras1.\n2. Santiago EM, Lawson E, Gillenwater K, et al: A prospective study of\nbacillus Calmette-Guerin scar formation and tuberculin skin test\nreactivity in infants in Lima, Peru. Pediatrics. 2003; 112(4): e298.\nAvailable at\nhttp://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/112/4/e298.long.\n3. Chan PC, Chang LY, Wu YC, et al: Age-specific cut-offs for the\ntuberculin skin test to detect latent tuberculosis in BCG-vaccinated\nchildren. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis. 2008; 12(12): 1401-6. Available at\n63724459.1/iuatld/ijtld/2008/00000012/00000012/art00012/005ED3EEC7920A1C1311696632AFC7D0F75E0BAEDB.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">http://docstore.ingenta.com/cgi-bin/ds_deliver/1/u/d/ISIS/ 63724459.1/iuatld/ijtld/2008/00000012/00000012/art00012/005ED3EEC7920A1C1311696632AFC7D0F75E0BAEDB.pdf\n4. Farhat M, Greenaway C, Pai M, Menzies D: False-positive tuberculin\nskin tests: what is the absolute effect of BCG and non-tuberculous\nmycobacteria? Int J Tuberc Lung Dis. 2006; 10(11): 1192-204. Available\nat\n63724490.1/iuatld/ijtld/2006/00000010/00000011/art00003/85B7D92AE2463EB013116967791F438205CC451CCF.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">http://docstore.ingenta.com/cgi-bin/ds_deliver/1/u/d/ISIS/ 63724490.1/iuatld/ijtld/2006/00000010/00000011/art00003/85B7D92AE2463EB013116967791F438205CC451CCF.pdf\n5. CDC: Tuberculosis: testing and diagnosis. Available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/testing/default.htm.\n6. CDC: latent tuberculosis infection: a guide for primary health care\nproviders. Available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/tb/publications/LTBI/diagnosis.htm. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, inaccurate blood tests, WHO statement 20110723.2217\nTuberculosis - Pakistan: increased incidence 20110618.1866\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2010\n----\nTuberculosis - UK: resurgence 20101223.4522\nTuberculosis - Canada: (NU), Inuit 20101008.3659\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Marshall Islands: RFI 20100131.0335\n2009\n----\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nTuberculosis, MDR - China 20090114.0151\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, XDR - Austria ex Romania 20080803.2373\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Peru 20080412.1337\nTuberculosis, XDR - Namibia 20080403.1231\nTuberculosis, XDR - UK (Scotland) ex Somalia 20080322.1094\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - South Africa 20080208.0521\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\nTuberculosis, XDR - Botswana, South Africa 20080118.0222\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, XDR, MDR: genome sequences 20071122.3780\nTuberculosis - Uganda (02): MDR, susp. UK: alpaca, mastitis, implications", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=835265", "date": "2011-07-26 12:53:26", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, INACCURATE BLOOD TESTS, WHO STATEMENT (03)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 25 Jul 2011\nFrom: John P Maher <jmaher@chesco.org> [edited]\n\n\nre: ProMED-mail Tuberculosis, inaccurate blood tests, WHO statement\n(02) 20110724.2233\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nConcerning the moderator's comments about BCG causing false positives:\nwe have been told by CDC representatives on several occasions in the\npast that a positive TST [tuberculin skin test] after 18 months\npost-BCG vaccination is to be considered evidence of LTBI [latent TB\ninfection] and that chemoprophylaxis should be offered.\n\n--\nJohn P Maher, MD, MPH\nPublic Health Physician\nChester County (PA) Health Department\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n[BCG, or bacille Calmette-Guerin, is a vaccine used in many countries\nwith a high prevalence of TB to prevent childhood tuberculous\nmeningitis and miliary disease. BCG may cause a reaction to the\ntuberculin skin test (TST). The effect of BCG vaccination on TST\nreactivity is dependent on strain and dose of BCG used, the method of\nvaccine administration, the number of BCG vaccinations administered,\nthe age, weight, and nutritional status of the individual at the time\nof vaccination, genetic factors, and the time since vaccination (1).\nHowever, the BCG effect on the tuberculin skin test declines in both\nfrequency and size of the reaction over time. Studies have shown that\na TST applied several years after neonatal BCG vaccination usually\nproduces a reaction of less than 10 mm; TST reactions larger than 10\nmm are unlikely to occur in the absence of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection (2,3). Certainly neonatal BCG vaccination has\na minimal effect on the TST as an adolescent or adult; in a review of\n24 studies involving 240 203 subjects BCG-vaccinated as infants,\noverall 20 406 (8.5 percent) had a TST reaction of 10 mm or larger\nattributable to BCG, but only 56/5639 (1 percent) were TST-positive\n(10 mm or larger) if tested 10 years or more after BCG (4). Indeed,\nthe US CDC recommends that a history of BCG vaccination be disregarded\nwhen interpreting a TST (5).\n\nInterferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs), which use antigens that are\nspecific for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, do not cause cross\nreactions with BCG, and therefore do not cause false-positive\nreactions in BCG recipients (6). A history of BCG vaccination should\nthus be an indication for use of an IGRA when screening for LTBI to\neliminate any confusion over interpretation of TST reactivity that\ncould complicate decisions about prescribing chemoprophylactic therapy\nfor LTBI.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\n.................................................ml/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1401-06-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chester County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lima", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Botswana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "835264", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, latent, nosocomial, infants - Italy: (Rome)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=835264", "date": "2011-07-26 12:53:26", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, INACCURATE BLOOD TESTS, WHO STATEMENT (03)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 25 Jul 2011\nFrom: John P Maher <jmaher@chesco.org> [edited]\n\n\nre: ProMED-mail Tuberculosis, inaccurate blood tests, WHO statement\n(02) 20110724.2233\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nConcerning the moderator's comments about BCG causing false positives:\nwe have been told by CDC representatives on several occasions in the\npast that a positive TST [tuberculin skin test] after 18 months\npost-BCG vaccination is to be considered evidence of LTBI [latent TB\ninfection] and that chemoprophylaxis should be offered.\n\n--\nJohn P Maher, MD, MPH\nPublic Health Physician\nChester County (PA) Health Department\n<jmaher@chesco.org>\n\n[BCG, or bacille Calmette-Guerin, is a vaccine used in many countries\nwith a high prevalence of TB to prevent childhood tuberculous\nmeningitis and miliary disease. BCG may cause a reaction to the\ntuberculin skin test (TST). The effect of BCG vaccination on TST\nreactivity is dependent on strain and dose of BCG used, the method of\nvaccine administration, the number of BCG vaccinations administered,\nthe age, weight, and nutritional status of the individual at the time\nof vaccination, genetic factors, and the time since vaccination (1).\nHowever, the BCG effect on the tuberculin skin test declines in both\nfrequency and size of the reaction over time. Studies have shown that\na TST applied several years after neonatal BCG vaccination usually\nproduces a reaction of less than 10 mm; TST reactions larger than 10\nmm are unlikely to occur in the absence of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection (2,3). Certainly neonatal BCG vaccination has\na minimal effect on the TST as an adolescent or adult; in a review of\n24 studies involving 240 203 subjects BCG-vaccinated as infants,\noverall 20 406 (8.5 percent) had a TST reaction of 10 mm or larger\nattributable to BCG, but only 56/5639 (1 percent) were TST-positive\n(10 mm or larger) if tested 10 years or more after BCG (4). Indeed,\nthe US CDC recommends that a history of BCG vaccination be disregarded\nwhen interpreting a TST (5).\n\nInterferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs), which use antigens that are\nspecific for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, do not cause cross\nreactions with BCG, and therefore do not cause false-positive\nreactions in BCG recipients (6). A history of BCG vaccination should\nthus be an indication for use of an IGRA when screening for LTBI to\neliminate any confusion over interpretation of TST reactivity that\ncould complicate decisions about prescribing chemoprophylactic therapy\nfor LTBI.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Burl S, Adetifa UJ, Cox M, et al: The tuberculin skin test (TST) is\naffected by recent BCG vaccination but not by exposure to\nnon-tuberculosis mycobacteria (NTM) during early life. PLoS ONE. 2010;\n5(8): e12287. Available at\nhttp://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0012287#pone.0012287-MiretCuadras1.\n2. Santiago EM, Lawson E, Gillenwater K, et al: A prospective study of\nbacillus Calmette-Guerin scar formation and tuberculin skin test\nreactivity in infants in Lima, Peru. Pediatrics. 2003; 112(4): e298.\nAvailable at\nhttp://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/112/4/e298.long.\n3. Chan PC, Chang LY, Wu YC, et al: Age-specific cut-offs for the\ntuberculin skin test to detect latent tuberculosis in BCG-vaccinated\nchildren. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis. 2008; 12(12): 1401-6. Available at\n63724459.1/iuatld/ijtld/2008/00000012/00000012/art00012/005ED3EEC7920A1C1311696632AFC7D0F75E0BAEDB.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">http://docstore.ingenta.com/cgi-bin/ds_deliver/1/u/d/ISIS/ 63724459.1/iuatld/ijtld/2008/00000012/00000012/art00012/005ED3EEC7920A1C1311696632AFC7D0F75E0BAEDB.pdf\n4. Farhat M, Greenaway C, Pai M, Menzies D: False-positive tuberculin\nskin tests: what is the absolute effect of BCG and non-tuberculous\nmycobacteria? Int J Tuberc Lung Dis. 2006; 10(11): 1192-204. Available\nat\n63724490.1/iuatld/ijtld/2006/00000010/00000011/art00003/85B7D92AE2463EB013116967791F438205CC451CCF.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">http://docstore.ingenta.com/cgi-bin/ds_deliver/1/u/d/ISIS/ 63724490.1/iuatld/ijtld/2006/00000010/00000011/art00003/85B7D92AE2463EB013116967791F438205CC451CCF.pdf\n5. CDC: Tuberculosis: testing and diagnosis. Available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/testing/default.htm.\n6. CDC: latent tuberculosis infection: a guide for primary health care\nproviders. Available at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/tb/publications/LTBI/diagnosis.htm. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, inaccurate blood tests, WHO statement 20110723.2217\nTuberculosis - Pakistan: increased incidence 20110618.1866\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Finland: (SK) 20110324.0935\n2010\n----\nTuberculosis - UK: resurgence 20101223.4522\nTuberculosis - Canada: (NU), Inuit 20101008.3659\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\nTuberculosis, drug resistance - Marshall Islands: RFI 20100131.0335\n2009\n----\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nTuberculosis, MDR - China 20090114.0151\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, XDR - Austria ex Romania 20080803.2373\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Peru 20080412.1337\nTuberculosis, XDR - Namibia 20080403.1231\nTuberculosis, XDR - UK (Scotland) ex Somalia 20080322.1094\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - South Africa 20080208.0521\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\nTuberculosis, XDR - Botswana, South Africa 20080118.0222\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, XDR, MDR: genome sequences 20071122.3780\nTuberculosis - Uganda (02): MDR, susp. South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\n.................................................ml/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1401-06-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chester County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lima", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Botswana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "796448", "headline": "PRO> Tuberculosis, inaccurate blood tests, WHO statement (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=796448", "date": "2011-06-12 19:56:22", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA (04): (ARIZONA) ex MEXICO\n***********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 10 Jun 2011\nSource: Western Farm Press [edited]\nhttp://westernfarmpress.com/management/steer-tests-positive-arizona-bovine-tuberculosis\n\n\nThe Arizona Department of Agriculture (ADA) has announced [that] a\nsingle steer in a Pinal County rodeo stock operation tested positive\nfor bovine tuberculosis (bovine TB). The event cattle operation has\nbeen placed under quarantine. The affected steer was recently imported\ninto the state of Arizona from Mexico and tested negative for bovine\nTB at the time of importation. The positive diagnosis was determined\nwhen the steer was retested to meet another state's entry\nrequirement.\n\n\"This diagnosis is a reminder of how important it is to keep high\nrisk imported steers and spayed heifers separate from domestic beef\nand dairy breeding cattle,\" stated Acting State Veterinarian John\nHunt. Hunt says since there is no treatment for cattle infected with\nbovine tuberculosis, exposed cattle must be either tested or\ndepopulated. Given that the time from an animal's exposure to a\npositive test can be several months, it can take months of testing to\nensure the disease is eradicated from a herd.\n\nArizona has been declared free of bovine tuberculosis since 1978.\n\"Free status\" was temporarily suspended due to an incident in 1979 but\nwas reinstated in 1981 after prompt elimination of the disease.\n\nThe State Veterinarian and the ADA veterinary staff are working\nclosely with USDA officials to implement the best course of action to\neliminate the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis is a chronic problem in Mexico, albeit mainly in\nthe states away from the US border. It would probably be fruitful to\nrecheck other Mexican steers intended for US rodeos that crossed the\nborder in the same week as this steer but which went to other\ndestinations. If there was a shedder somewhere along the route, either\nwithin Mexico or the US, there will be other infected steers beginning\nto reveal themselves, if retested. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (CA) 20110429.1328\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20110416.1196\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20110322.0895\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (IN) 20110301.0670\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (07): (MI) 20100909.3246\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (06): (OH) 20100715.2362\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (CO) 20100614.1989\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (KY) 20100528.1768\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid -
