UK (04): England", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=795920", "date": "2011-06-12 19:56:22", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA (04): (ARIZONA) ex MEXICO\n***********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 10 Jun 2011\nSource: Western Farm Press [edited]\nhttp://westernfarmpress.com/management/steer-tests-positive-arizona-bovine-tuberculosis\n\n\nThe Arizona Department of Agriculture (ADA) has announced [that] a\nsingle steer in a Pinal County rodeo stock operation tested positive\nfor bovine tuberculosis (bovine TB). The event cattle operation has\nbeen placed under quarantine. The affected steer was recently imported\ninto the state of Arizona from Mexico and tested negative for bovine\nTB at the time of importation. The positive diagnosis was determined\nwhen the steer was retested to meet another state's entry\nrequirement.\n\n\"This diagnosis is a reminder of how important it is to keep high\nrisk imported steers and spayed heifers separate from domestic beef\nand dairy breeding cattle,\" stated Acting State Veterinarian John\nHunt. Hunt says since there is no treatment for cattle infected with\nbovine tuberculosis, exposed cattle must be either tested or\ndepopulated. Given that the time from an animal's exposure to a\npositive test can be several months, it can take months of testing to\nensure the disease is eradicated from a herd.\n\nArizona has been declared free of bovine tuberculosis since 1978.\n\"Free status\" was temporarily suspended due to an incident in 1979 but\nwas reinstated in 1981 after prompt elimination of the disease.\n\nThe State Veterinarian and the ADA veterinary staff are working\nclosely with USDA officials to implement the best course of action to\neliminate the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis is a chronic problem in Mexico, albeit mainly in\nthe states away from the US border. It would probably be fruitful to\nrecheck other Mexican steers intended for US rodeos that crossed the\nborder in the same week as this steer but which went to other\ndestinations. If there was a shedder somewhere along the route, either\nwithin Mexico or the US, there will be other infected steers beginning\nto reveal themselves, if retested. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (ARIZONA) ex MEXICO\n***********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 10 Jun 2011\nSource: Western Farm Press [edited]\nhttp://westernfarmpress.com/management/steer-tests-positive-arizona-bovine-tuberculosis\n\n\nThe Arizona Department of Agriculture (ADA) has announced [that] a\nsingle steer in a Pinal County rodeo stock operation tested positive\nfor bovine tuberculosis (bovine TB). The event cattle operation has\nbeen placed under quarantine. The affected steer was recently imported\ninto the state of Arizona from Mexico and tested negative for bovine\nTB at the time of importation. The positive diagnosis was determined\nwhen the steer was retested to meet another state's entry\nrequirement.\n\n\"This diagnosis is a reminder of how important it is to keep high\nrisk imported steers and spayed heifers separate from domestic beef\nand dairy breeding cattle,\" stated Acting State Veterinarian John\nHunt. Hunt says since there is no treatment for cattle infected with\nbovine tuberculosis, exposed cattle must be either tested or\ndepopulated. Given that the time from an animal's exposure to a\npositive test can be several months, it can take months of testing to\nensure the disease is eradicated from a herd.\n\nArizona has been declared free of bovine tuberculosis since 1978.\n\"Free status\" was temporarily suspended due to an incident in 1979 but\nwas reinstated in 1981 after prompt elimination of the disease.\n\nThe State Veterinarian and the ADA veterinary staff are working\nclosely with USDA officials to implement the best course of action to\neliminate the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis is a chronic problem in Mexico, albeit mainly in\nthe states away from the US border. The affected steer was recently imported\ninto the state of Arizona from Mexico and tested negative for bovine\nTB at the time of importation. The positive diagnosis was determined\nwhen the steer was retested to meet another state's entry\nrequirement.\n\n\"This diagnosis is a reminder of how important it is to keep high\nrisk imported steers and spayed heifers separate from domestic beef\nand dairy breeding cattle,\" stated Acting State Veterinarian John\nHunt. The affected steer was recently imported\ninto the state of Arizona from Mexico and tested negative for bovine\nTB at the time of importation. The positive diagnosis was determined\nwhen the steer was retested to meet another state's entry\nrequirement.\n\n\"This diagnosis is a reminder of how important it is to keep high\nrisk imported steers and spayed heifers separate from domestic beef\nand dairy breeding cattle,\" stated Acting State Veterinarian John\nHunt. The event cattle operation has\nbeen placed under quarantine. The affected steer was recently imported\ninto the state of Arizona from Mexico and tested negative for bovine\nTB at the time of importation. The positive diagnosis was determined\nwhen the steer was retested to meet another state's entry\nrequirement.\n\n\"This diagnosis is a reminder of how important it is to keep high\nrisk imported steers and spayed heifers separate from domestic beef\nand dairy breeding cattle,\" stated Acting State Veterinarian John\nHunt. Hunt says since there is no treatment for cattle infected with\nbovine tuberculosis, exposed cattle must be either tested or\ndepopulated. Given that the time from an animal's exposure to a\npositive test can be several months, it can take months of testing to\nensure the disease is eradicated from a herd.\n\nArizona has been declared free of bovine tuberculosis since 1978.\n\"Free status\" was temporarily suspended due to an incident in 1979 but\nwas reinstated in 1981 after prompt elimination of the disease.\n\nThe State Veterinarian and the ADA veterinary staff are working\nclosely with USDA officials to implement the best course of action to\neliminate the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis is a chronic problem in Mexico, albeit mainly in\nthe states away from the US border. UK (03): England", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=711365", "date": "2011-06-12 19:56:22", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA (04): (ARIZONA) ex MEXICO\n***********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 10 Jun 2011\nSource: Western Farm Press [edited]\nhttp://westernfarmpress.com/management/steer-tests-positive-arizona-bovine-tuberculosis\n\n\nThe Arizona Department of Agriculture (ADA) has announced [that] a\nsingle steer in a Pinal County rodeo stock operation tested positive\nfor bovine tuberculosis (bovine TB). The event cattle operation has\nbeen placed under quarantine. The affected steer was recently imported\ninto the state of Arizona from Mexico and tested negative for bovine\nTB at the time of importation. The positive diagnosis was determined\nwhen the steer was retested to meet another state's entry\nrequirement.\n\n\"This diagnosis is a reminder of how important it is to keep high\nrisk imported steers and spayed heifers separate from domestic beef\nand dairy breeding cattle,\" stated Acting State Veterinarian John\nHunt. Hunt says since there is no treatment for cattle infected with\nbovine tuberculosis, exposed cattle must be either tested or\ndepopulated. Given that the time from an animal's exposure to a\npositive test can be several months, it can take months of testing to\nensure the disease is eradicated from a herd.\n\nArizona has been declared free of bovine tuberculosis since 1978.\n\"Free status\" was temporarily suspended due to an incident in 1979 but\nwas reinstated in 1981 after prompt elimination of the disease.\n\nThe State Veterinarian and the ADA veterinary staff are working\nclosely with USDA officials to implement the best course of action to\neliminate the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis is a chronic problem in Mexico, albeit mainly in\nthe states away from the US border. It would probably be fruitful to\nrecheck other Mexican steers intended for US rodeos that crossed the\nborder in the same week as this steer but which went to other\ndestinations. If there was a shedder somewhere along the route, either\nwithin Mexico or the US, there will be other infected steers beginning\nto reveal themselves, if retested. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - Cheboygan County can\nbe seen on the map at\n<http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/michigan.shtml>.\n\nThis county is currently outside of the zone where Michigan is trying\nto eradicate TB. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (IN) 20110301.0670\n2010\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (07): (MI) 20100909.3246\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20100418.1265\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20100325.0948\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, cervid - USA (MI) 20080304.0897\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI )20050112.0102\n2003\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MI) (02) 20030606.1392\n2000\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Michigan) 20001001.1695\nTuberculosis, deer - USA (Michigan) 20000515.0761\nTuberculosis, bovine, deer - USA (Michigan) 20000426.0630\n1999\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Michigan) (02) 19990522.0840\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Michigan) (02) 19990519.0822\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Michigan) 19990517.0803\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Michigan) 19990110.0033\n1998\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Michigan) 19980923.1899\nTuberculosis, deer/cattle transfer - USA (Michigan) 19980625.1179\nTuberculosis, deer - USA (Michigan) (02) 19980405.0627\nTuberculosis, deer - USA (Michigan) 19980316.0487\n.................................................sb/tg/lm/mj\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cheboygan County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "665287", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> PRO/GREEN>Bovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (IN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=665287", "date": "2010-10-08 15:00:09", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - CANADA: (NUNAVUT), INUIT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 4 Oct 2010\nSource: Northern News Services Online [edited]\n<http://nnsl.com/northern-news-services/stories/papers/oct4_10tb.html>\n\n\nThe [Nunavut] territory is seeing its worst tuberculosis [TB]\noutbreak in more than a decade, with 87 cases diagnosed so far this\nyear [2010]. From 1 Jan to 30 Sep 2010, 87 TB cases were diagnosed in\nNunavut, with 92 per cent of them [80 cases] in the Baffin region,\nsaid Elaine Randell, communicable disease consultant with Nunavut's\nDepartment of Health and Social Services. She added 40 of those cases\nwere in Iqaluit, 27 in Cape Dorset, and the rest in other\ncommunities. Randell also said 15 to 24-year-olds were hit the hardest.\n\nThe outbreak peaked in May [2010]. Only 3 TB cases were diagnosed in\nthe territory in September. \"There seems to be a downward trend,\nalthough with TB, it's probably too early to tell but we're hoping\nthat this is the beginning of a downward trend,\" she said. \"It would\nappear that Iqaluit and Cape Dorset both have their own strains. The\noutbreaks don't seem to be related.\"\n\nThis year's [2010] surge in cases already surpasses the previous\nrecord set in 2008, when 58 people were diagnosed with TB, an\ninfectious and potentially deadly disease that often attacks the\nlungs. \"Nunavut has all the elements for a perfect storm when it\ncomes to TB,\" she said. \"You have a high rate of infection among the\nInuit, which makes all the communities sort of at risk for outbreaks.\nYou also have the social determinants for health -- the poverty,\n[lack of] access to healthy foods, crowded housing conditions, those\nsorts of things.\" Those factors make the territory \"ripe for this\ntype of outbreak,\" she said.\n\nShe added they have traced anyone who might have been in contact with\nan infected person, sought other cases, and added staff to the\nbusiest areas. Randell said they are also revising the TB manual for\nhealth care workers and developing a communications strategy. She\nsaid they have even offered taxi vouchers as incentives for people to\ncome for treatment. \"For the most part, most of the clients have been\nvery co-operative in helping us,\" she said. In Cape Dorset, mayor\nCary Merritt, as the general manager of the local co-op, has provided\nfood vouchers to the co-op's restaurant as an incentive for people to\nfollow their treatment. \"It's helping making sure people come in to\nget their treatments on time,\" he said.\n\n\"We're not so worried because we have a really good nurse in place\nright now. She's been very proactive with making sure people come in\nand get their treatment. I believe she is really doing a good job\nbringing down the cases now and with the level of treatment, she's\nensuring it's happening. I think we will see a drastic reduction now.\"\n\n[Byline: Jeanne Gagnon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, the largest federal territory of Canada, is the size of\nWestern Europe; it comprises a major portion of Northern Canada, and\nhas an estimated population in 2010 of about 33 000, mostly Inuit\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut>). The territorial capital\nIqaluit, which had a population in 2006 of 6184, is on Baffin Island,\nwhich had a population of 11 000 in 2007. Cape Dorset is a town\nlocated on Dorset Island at the southern tip of Baffin Island with a\npopulation in 2006 of 1236.\n\nThe TB incidence rate for the first 9 months of 2010 is thus 727 per\n100 000 in the Baffin region with 80 cases, 647 per 100 000 in\nIqaluit with 40 cases, and 2184 per 100 000 in Cape Dorset with 27\ncases, whereas the annual incidence rate for Canada as a whole has\nbeen reported to be less than 5 per 100 000\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/tbpc-latb/itir-eng.php>).\n\nAboriginal peoples in Canada comprise the Inuit, First Nations, and\nMetis (indigenous First People of Canada who trace their descent to\nmixed European and First Nations parentage)\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aboriginal_peoples_in_Canada>). The\n2006 census counted a total Canadian Aboriginal population of 1 172\n790 (3.75 percent of the population), which includes 698 025 First\nNations (2.23 percent), 389 785 Metis (1.25 percent), and 50 480\nInuit (0.16 percent) (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Canada>).\n\nSince the 1st contact with Europeans, the Canadian Aboriginals have\nhad a disproportionately high burden of TB disease. For example, high\nincidence rates for TB have been reported among Aboriginals, mainly\nFirst Nations, in Northern Manitoba: specifically 48.4 per 100 000\noverall, with rates as high as 496.3 per 100 000 in select\ncommunities (<http://www.skylarkmedicalclinic.com/TubercuosisinManitoba.htm>).\n\nIn 2002, the Public Health Agency of Canada\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/tbcbap-tbpac/special_report-eng.php>)\nreported that from 1991-1999, of 17 590 new active and relapsed TB\ncases, 3013 (17 percent) occurred among Canadian-born Aboriginals\n(which constitute only 3.75 percent of the population). Of the\nremaining cases, 4201 (24 percent) occurred in Canadian-born\nnon-Aboriginals and 10 281 (58 percent) occurred in foreign-born\nindividuals. Aboriginals with TB were younger (median 27 years) than\nforeign-born (median 39 years) and non-Aboriginals (median 59 years).\nIn this report, drug resistant strains of TB had not yet emerged as a\nsignificant problem in this population. Less than 2 percent of\nreported cases were resistant to one or more drugs. The extent of HIV\nco-infection could not be estimated using data from this surveillance\nsystem. (HIV status was known for only 2 percent of reported\nAboriginal cases.) In the 1990's, Aboriginal people were said to have\nan overall TB rate almost 4 times higher than the Canada-wide rate.\n\nMore recently, the situation has apparently worsened. In a news\nrelease in March 2010, the Inuit were reported to be \"the most at\nrisk of tuberculosis infection with a rate that is 186 times higher\nthan the non-aboriginal average. This is double what it was just 4\nyears ago\"\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\nThe high rates for TB in the Canadian Aboriginal population have been\nattributed to limited access to healthcare in remote regions,\nsubstandard housing, with whole families living in a single room,\nwidespread poverty, and malnutrition\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\n\nThe TB control plan described in the news release above seems\ninadequate for the situation. For example, the treatment plan in\nNunavut relies on the patients self-administering medication. Because\nof the frequency of non-adherence to TB treatment regimens in all\npopulations, directly observed therapy (DOTS) is the internationally\nrecommended strategy for TB case management. DOTS requires an\nindependent observer watching patients swallow each dose of their\nanti-TB therapy. The independent observer is not necessarily a\nhealthcare worker; the person could be, for example, a tribal elder\nor similar senior person within that community. Because drug\nresistance and HIV co-infection may require modification of the TB\ntreatment regimens (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5211.pdf>), HIV\nstatus and drug resistance should be determined in each case, if not\ndone already, in the current outbreak in Nunavut.\n\nA program to prevent latent from becoming active disease should\naccompany early detection of cases of active tuberculosis and its\nprompt and complete treatment. Most cases of progression from latent\nTB to active tuberculosis occur within 2 to 12 months of initial\ninfection. Children and adolescents are especially at high risk for\nprogression to tuberculosis disease (with potential for disseminated\ndisease). Most children with latent TB have been recently infected\n(especially those younger than age 5 years), usually from exposure to\na person with active TB in their immediate environment, usually the\nhousehold. Children exposed to active TB must be evaluated and\ntreated for latent TB. TB control requires government commitment of\nfunds and personnel more than a single nurse in the field for such a\nlarge and remote region, even though she may be \"a really good nurse\".\n\nA map of Nunavut, Baffin Island, and the towns of Cape Dorset and\nIqaluit can be found at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/reference/provincesterritories/nunavut/referencemap_image_view>.\nNunavut can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nof Canada at <http://healthmap.org/r/0ccp>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\n...................................ml/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nDonate to ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-09-30 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Iqaluit", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Dorset", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin Island", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "657631", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, humans, elephant - USA: (TN) 2009", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=657631", "date": "2010-10-08 15:00:09", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - CANADA: (NUNAVUT), INUIT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 4 Oct 2010\nSource: Northern News Services Online [edited]\n<http://nnsl.com/northern-news-services/stories/papers/oct4_10tb.html>\n\n\nThe [Nunavut] territory is seeing its worst tuberculosis [TB]\noutbreak in more than a decade, with 87 cases diagnosed so far this\nyear [2010]. From 1 Jan to 30 Sep 2010, 87 TB cases were diagnosed in\nNunavut, with 92 per cent of them [80 cases] in the Baffin region,\nsaid Elaine Randell, communicable disease consultant with Nunavut's\nDepartment of Health and Social Services. She added 40 of those cases\nwere in Iqaluit, 27 in Cape Dorset, and the rest in other\ncommunities. Randell also said 15 to 24-year-olds were hit the hardest.\n\nThe outbreak peaked in May [2010]. Only 3 TB cases were diagnosed in\nthe territory in September. \"There seems to be a downward trend,\nalthough with TB, it's probably too early to tell but we're hoping\nthat this is the beginning of a downward trend,\" she said. \"It would\nappear that Iqaluit and Cape Dorset both have their own strains. The\noutbreaks don't seem to be related.\"\n\nThis year's [2010] surge in cases already surpasses the previous\nrecord set in 2008, when 58 people were diagnosed with TB, an\ninfectious and potentially deadly disease that often attacks the\nlungs. \"Nunavut has all the elements for a perfect storm when it\ncomes to TB,\" she said. \"You have a high rate of infection among the\nInuit, which makes all the communities sort of at risk for outbreaks.\nYou also have the social determinants for health -- the poverty,\n[lack of] access to healthy foods, crowded housing conditions, those\nsorts of things.\" Those factors make the territory \"ripe for this\ntype of outbreak,\" she said.\n\nShe added they have traced anyone who might have been in contact with\nan infected person, sought other cases, and added staff to the\nbusiest areas. Randell said they are also revising the TB manual for\nhealth care workers and developing a communications strategy. She\nsaid they have even offered taxi vouchers as incentives for people to\ncome for treatment. \"For the most part, most of the clients have been\nvery co-operative in helping us,\" she said. In Cape Dorset, mayor\nCary Merritt, as the general manager of the local co-op, has provided\nfood vouchers to the co-op's restaurant as an incentive for people to\nfollow their treatment. \"It's helping making sure people come in to\nget their treatments on time,\" he said.\n\n\"We're not so worried because we have a really good nurse in place\nright now. She's been very proactive with making sure people come in\nand get their treatment. I believe she is really doing a good job\nbringing down the cases now and with the level of treatment, she's\nensuring it's happening. I think we will see a drastic reduction now.\"\n\n[Byline: Jeanne Gagnon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, the largest federal territory of Canada, is the size of\nWestern Europe; it comprises a major portion of Northern Canada, and\nhas an estimated population in 2010 of about 33 000, mostly Inuit\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut>). The territorial capital\nIqaluit, which had a population in 2006 of 6184, is on Baffin Island,\nwhich had a population of 11 000 in 2007. Cape Dorset is a town\nlocated on Dorset Island at the southern tip of Baffin Island with a\npopulation in 2006 of 1236.\n\nThe TB incidence rate for the first 9 months of 2010 is thus 727 per\n100 000 in the Baffin region with 80 cases, 647 per 100 000 in\nIqaluit with 40 cases, and 2184 per 100 000 in Cape Dorset with 27\ncases, whereas the annual incidence rate for Canada as a whole has\nbeen reported to be less than 5 per 100 000\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/tbpc-latb/itir-eng.php>).\n\nAboriginal peoples in Canada comprise the Inuit, First Nations, and\nMetis (indigenous First People of Canada who trace their descent to\nmixed European and First Nations parentage)\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aboriginal_peoples_in_Canada>). The\n2006 census counted a total Canadian Aboriginal population of 1 172\n790 (3.75 percent of the population), which includes 698 025 First\nNations (2.23 percent), 389 785 Metis (1.25 percent), and 50 480\nInuit (0.16 percent) (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Canada>).\n\nSince the 1st contact with Europeans, the Canadian Aboriginals have\nhad a disproportionately high burden of TB disease. For example, high\nincidence rates for TB have been reported among Aboriginals, mainly\nFirst Nations, in Northern Manitoba: specifically 48.4 per 100 000\noverall, with rates as high as 496.3 per 100 000 in select\ncommunities (<http://www.skylarkmedicalclinic.com/TubercuosisinManitoba.htm>).\n\nIn 2002, the Public Health Agency of Canada\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/tbcbap-tbpac/special_report-eng.php>)\nreported that from 1991-1999, of 17 590 new active and relapsed TB\ncases, 3013 (17 percent) occurred among Canadian-born Aboriginals\n(which constitute only 3.75 percent of the population). Of the\nremaining cases, 4201 (24 percent) occurred in Canadian-born\nnon-Aboriginals and 10 281 (58 percent) occurred in foreign-born\nindividuals. Aboriginals with TB were younger (median 27 years) than\nforeign-born (median 39 years) and non-Aboriginals (median 59 years).\nIn this report, drug resistant strains of TB had not yet emerged as a\nsignificant problem in this population. Less than 2 percent of\nreported cases were resistant to one or more drugs. The extent of HIV\nco-infection could not be estimated using data from this surveillance\nsystem. (HIV status was known for only 2 percent of reported\nAboriginal cases.) In the 1990's, Aboriginal people were said to have\nan overall TB rate almost 4 times higher than the Canada-wide rate.\n\nMore recently, the situation has apparently worsened. In a news\nrelease in March 2010, the Inuit were reported to be \"the most at\nrisk of tuberculosis infection with a rate that is 186 times higher\nthan the non-aboriginal average. This is double what it was just 4\nyears ago\"\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\nThe high rates for TB in the Canadian Aboriginal population have been\nattributed to limited access to healthcare in remote regions,\nsubstandard housing, with whole families living in a single room,\nwidespread poverty, and malnutrition\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\n\nThe TB control plan described in the news release above seems\ninadequate for the situation. For example, the treatment plan in\nNunavut relies on the patients self-administering medication. Because\nof the frequency of non-adherence to TB treatment regimens in all\npopulations, directly observed therapy (DOTS) is the internationally\nrecommended strategy for TB case management. DOTS requires an\nindependent observer watching patients swallow each dose of their\nanti-TB therapy. The independent observer is not necessarily a\nhealthcare worker; the person could be, for example, a tribal elder\nor similar senior person within that community. Because drug\nresistance and HIV co-infection may require modification of the TB\ntreatment regimens (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5211.pdf>), HIV\nstatus and drug resistance should be determined in each case, if not\ndone already, in the current outbreak in Nunavut.\n\nA program to prevent latent from becoming active disease should\naccompany early detection of cases of active tuberculosis and its\nprompt and complete treatment. Most cases of progression from latent\nTB to active tuberculosis occur within 2 to 12 months of initial\ninfection. Children and adolescents are especially at high risk for\nprogression to tuberculosis disease (with potential for disseminated\ndisease). Most children with latent TB have been recently infected\n(especially those younger than age 5 years), usually from exposure to\na person with active TB in their immediate environment, usually the\nhousehold. Children exposed to active TB must be evaluated and\ntreated for latent TB. TB control requires government commitment of\nfunds and personnel more than a single nurse in the field for such a\nlarge and remote region, even though she may be \"a really good nurse\".\n\nA map of Nunavut, Baffin Island, and the towns of Cape Dorset and\nIqaluit can be found at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/reference/provincesterritories/nunavut/referencemap_image_view>.\nNunavut can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nof Canada at <http://healthmap.org/r/0ccp>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\n...................................ml/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-09-30 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Iqaluit", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Dorset", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin Island", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "657181", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, elephants - France: (Rhone)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=657181", "date": "2010-10-08 15:00:09", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - CANADA: (NUNAVUT), INUIT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 4 Oct 2010\nSource: Northern News Services Online [edited]\n<http://nnsl.com/northern-news-services/stories/papers/oct4_10tb.html>\n\n\nThe [Nunavut] territory is seeing its worst tuberculosis [TB]\noutbreak in more than a decade, with 87 cases diagnosed so far this\nyear [2010]. She's been very proactive with making sure people come in\nand get their treatment. I believe she is really doing a good job\nbringing down the cases now and with the level of treatment, she's\nensuring it's happening. I think we will see a drastic reduction now.\"\n\n[Byline: Jeanne Gagnon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, the largest federal territory of Canada, is the size of\nWestern Europe; it comprises a major portion of Northern Canada, and\nhas an estimated population in 2010 of about 33 000, mostly Inuit\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut>). In the 1990's, Aboriginal people were said to have\nan overall TB rate almost 4 times higher than the Canada-wide rate.\n\nMore recently, the situation has apparently worsened. In a news\nrelease in March 2010, the Inuit were reported to be \"the most at\nrisk of tuberculosis infection with a rate that is 186 times higher\nthan the non-aboriginal average. This is double what it was just 4\nyears ago\"\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\nThe high rates for TB in the Canadian Aboriginal population have been\nattributed to limited access to healthcare in remote regions,\nsubstandard housing, with whole families living in a single room,\nwidespread poverty, and malnutrition\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\n\nThe TB control plan described in the news release above seems\ninadequate for the situation. For example, the treatment plan in\nNunavut relies on the patients self-administering medication. Because\nof the frequency of non-adherence to TB treatment regimens in all\npopulations, directly observed therapy (DOTS) is the internationally\nrecommended strategy for TB case management. DOTS requires an\nindependent observer watching patients swallow each dose of their\nanti-TB therapy. The independent observer is not necessarily a\nhealthcare worker; the person could be, for example, a tribal elder\nor similar senior person within that community. Because drug\nresistance and HIV co-infection may require modification of the TB\ntreatment regimens (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5211.pdf>), HIV\nstatus and drug resistance should be determined in each case, if not\ndone already, in the current outbreak in Nunavut.\n\nA program to prevent latent from becoming active disease should\naccompany early detection of cases of active tuberculosis and its\nprompt and complete treatment. Most cases of progression from latent\nTB to active tuberculosis occur within 2 to 12 months of initial\ninfection. Children and adolescents are especially at high risk for\nprogression to tuberculosis disease (with potential for disseminated\ndisease). Most children with latent TB have been recently infected\n(especially those younger than age 5 years), usually from exposure to\na person with active TB in their immediate environment, usually the\nhousehold. Children exposed to active TB must be evaluated and\ntreated for latent TB. TB control requires government commitment of\nfunds and personnel more than a single nurse in the field for such a\nlarge and remote region, even though she may be \"a really good nurse\".\n\nA map of Nunavut, Baffin Island, and the towns of Cape Dorset and\nIqaluit can be found at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/reference/provincesterritories/nunavut/referencemap_image_view>.\nNunavut can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nof Canada at <http://healthmap.org/r/0ccp>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\n...................................ml/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. From 1 Jan to 30 Sep 2010, 87 TB cases were diagnosed in\nNunavut, with 92 per cent of them [80 cases] in the Baffin region,\nsaid Elaine Randell, communicable disease consultant with Nunavut's\nDepartment of Health and Social Services. She added 40 of those cases\nwere in Iqaluit, 27 in Cape Dorset, and the rest in other\ncommunities. Randell also said 15 to 24-year-olds were hit the hardest.\n\nThe outbreak peaked in May [2010]. Only 3 TB cases were diagnosed in\nthe territory in September. \"There seems to be a downward trend,\nalthough with TB, it's probably too early to tell but we're hoping\nthat this is the beginning of a downward trend,\" she said. \"It would\nappear that Iqaluit and Cape Dorset both have their own strains. The\noutbreaks don't seem to be related.\"\n\nThis year's [2010] surge in cases already surpasses the previous\nrecord set in 2008, when 58 people were diagnosed with TB, an\ninfectious and potentially deadly disease that often attacks the\nlungs. \"Nunavut has all the elements for a perfect storm when it\ncomes to TB,\" she said. \"You have a high rate of infection among the\nInuit, which makes all the communities sort of at risk for outbreaks.\nYou also have the social determinants for health -- the poverty,\n[lack of] access to healthy foods, crowded housing conditions, those\nsorts of things.\" Those factors make the territory \"ripe for this\ntype of outbreak,\" she said.\n\nShe added they have traced anyone who might have been in contact with\nan infected person, sought other cases, and added staff to the\nbusiest areas. Randell said they are also revising the TB manual for\nhealth care workers and developing a communications strategy. She\nsaid they have even offered taxi vouchers as incentives for people to\ncome for treatment. \"For the most part, most of the clients have been\nvery co-operative in helping us,\" she said. In Cape Dorset, mayor\nCary Merritt, as the general manager of the local co-op, has provided\nfood vouchers to the co-op's restaurant as an incentive for people to\nfollow their treatment. \"It's helping making sure people come in to\nget their treatments on time,\" he said.\n\n\"We're not so worried because we have a really good nurse in place\nright now. She's been very proactive with making sure people come in\nand get their treatment. I believe she is really doing a good job\nbringing down the cases now and with the level of treatment, she's\nensuring it's happening. I think we will see a drastic reduction now.\"\n\n[Byline: Jeanne Gagnon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, the largest federal territory of Canada, is the size of\nWestern Europe; it comprises a major portion of Northern Canada, and\nhas an estimated population in 2010 of about 33 000, mostly Inuit\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut>). The territorial capital\nIqaluit, which had a population in 2006 of 6184, is on Baffin Island,\nwhich had a population of 11 000 in 2007. Cape Dorset is a town\nlocated on Dorset Island at the southern tip of Baffin Island with a\npopulation in 2006 of 1236.\n\nThe TB incidence rate for the first 9 months of 2010 is thus 727 per\n100 000 in the Baffin region with 80 cases, 647 per 100 000 in\nIqaluit with 40 cases, and 2184 per 100 000 in Cape Dorset with 27\ncases, whereas the annual incidence rate for Canada as a whole has\nbeen reported to be less than 5 per 100 000\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/tbpc-latb/itir-eng.php>).\n\nAboriginal peoples in Canada comprise the Inuit, First Nations, and\nMetis (indigenous First People of Canada who trace their descent to\nmixed European and First Nations parentage)\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aboriginal_peoples_in_Canada>). The\n2006 census counted a total Canadian Aboriginal population of 1 172\n790 (3.75 percent of the population), which includes 698 025 First\nNations (2.23 percent), 389 785 Metis (1.25 percent), and 50 480\nInuit (0.16 percent) (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Canada>).\n\nSince the 1st contact with Europeans, the Canadian Aboriginals have\nhad a disproportionately high burden of TB disease. For example, high\nincidence rates for TB have been reported among Aboriginals, mainly\nFirst Nations, in Northern Manitoba: specifically 48.4 per 100 000\noverall, with rates as high as 496.3 per 100 000 in select\ncommunities (<http://www.skylarkmedicalclinic.com/TubercuosisinManitoba.htm>).\n\nIn 2002, the Public Health Agency of Canada\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/tbcbap-tbpac/special_report-eng.php>)\nreported that from 1991-1999, of 17 590 new active and relapsed TB\ncases, 3013 (17 percent) occurred among Canadian-born Aboriginals\n(which constitute only 3.75 percent of the population). Of the\nremaining cases, 4201 (24 percent) occurred in Canadian-born\nnon-Aboriginals and 10 281 (58 percent) occurred in foreign-born\nindividuals. Aboriginals with TB were younger (median 27 years) than\nforeign-born (median 39 years) and non-Aboriginals (median 59 years).\nIn this report, drug resistant strains of TB had not yet emerged as a\nsignificant problem in this population. Less than 2 percent of\nreported cases were resistant to one or more drugs. The extent of HIV\nco-infection could not be estimated using data from this surveillance\nsystem. (HIV status was known for only 2 percent of reported\nAboriginal cases.) In the 1990's, Aboriginal people were said to have\nan overall TB rate almost 4 times higher than the Canada-wide rate.\n\nMore recently, the situation has apparently worsened. In a news\nrelease in March 2010, the Inuit were reported to be \"the most at\nrisk of tuberculosis infection with a rate that is 186 times higher\nthan the non-aboriginal average. This is double what it was just 4\nyears ago\"\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\nThe high rates for TB in the Canadian Aboriginal population have been\nattributed to limited access to healthcare in remote regions,\nsubstandard housing, with whole families living in a single room,\nwidespread poverty, and malnutrition\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\n\nThe TB control plan described in the news release above seems\ninadequate for the situation. For example, the treatment plan in\nNunavut relies on the patients self-administering medication. Because\nof the frequency of non-adherence to TB treatment regimens in all\npopulations, directly observed therapy (DOTS) is the internationally\nrecommended strategy for TB case management. DOTS requires an\nindependent observer watching patients swallow each dose of their\nanti-TB therapy. The independent observer is not necessarily a\nhealthcare worker; the person could be, for example, a tribal elder\nor similar senior person within that community. Because drug\nresistance and HIV co-infection may require modification of the TB\ntreatment regimens (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5211.pdf>), HIV\nstatus and drug resistance should be determined in each case, if not\ndone already, in the current outbreak in Nunavut.\n\nA program to prevent latent from becoming active disease should\naccompany early detection of cases of active tuberculosis and its\nprompt and complete treatment. Most cases of progression from latent\nTB to active tuberculosis occur within 2 to 12 months of initial\ninfection. Children and adolescents are especially at high risk for\nprogression to tuberculosis disease (with potential for disseminated\ndisease). Most children with latent TB have been recently infected\n(especially those younger than age 5 years), usually from exposure to\na person with active TB in their immediate environment, usually the\nhousehold. Children exposed to active TB must be evaluated and\ntreated for latent TB. TB control requires government commitment of\nfunds and personnel more than a single nurse in the field for such a\nlarge and remote region, even though she may be \"a really good nurse\".\n\nA map of Nunavut, Baffin Island, and the towns of Cape Dorset and\nIqaluit can be found at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/reference/provincesterritories/nunavut/referencemap_image_view>.\nNunavut can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nof Canada at <http://healthmap.org/r/0ccp>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\n...................................ml/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-09-30 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Iqaluit", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Dorset", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin Island", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "647981", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, elephant - Australia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=647981", "date": "2010-10-08 15:00:09", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - CANADA: (NUNAVUT), INUIT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 4 Oct 2010\nSource: Northern News Services Online [edited]\n<http://nnsl.com/northern-news-services/stories/papers/oct4_10tb.html>\n\n\nThe [Nunavut] territory is seeing its worst tuberculosis [TB]\noutbreak in more than a decade, with 87 cases diagnosed so far this\nyear [2010]. From 1 Jan to 30 Sep 2010, 87 TB cases were diagnosed in\nNunavut, with 92 per cent of them [80 cases] in the Baffin region,\nsaid Elaine Randell, communicable disease consultant with Nunavut's\nDepartment of Health and Social Services. She added 40 of those cases\nwere in Iqaluit, 27 in Cape Dorset, and the rest in other\ncommunities. Randell also said 15 to 24-year-olds were hit the hardest.\n\nThe outbreak peaked in May [2010]. Only 3 TB cases were diagnosed in\nthe territory in September. \"There seems to be a downward trend,\nalthough with TB, it's probably too early to tell but we're hoping\nthat this is the beginning of a downward trend,\" she said. \"It would\nappear that Iqaluit and Cape Dorset both have their own strains. The\noutbreaks don't seem to be related.\"\n\nThis year's [2010] surge in cases already surpasses the previous\nrecord set in 2008, when 58 people were diagnosed with TB, an\ninfectious and potentially deadly disease that often attacks the\nlungs. \"Nunavut has all the elements for a perfect storm when it\ncomes to TB,\" she said. \"You have a high rate of infection among the\nInuit, which makes all the communities sort of at risk for outbreaks.\nYou also have the social determinants for health -- the poverty,\n[lack of] access to healthy foods, crowded housing conditions, those\nsorts of things.\" Those factors make the territory \"ripe for this\ntype of outbreak,\" she said.\n\nShe added they have traced anyone who might have been in contact with\nan infected person, sought other cases, and added staff to the\nbusiest areas. Randell said they are also revising the TB manual for\nhealth care workers and developing a communications strategy. She\nsaid they have even offered taxi vouchers as incentives for people to\ncome for treatment. \"For the most part, most of the clients have been\nvery co-operative in helping us,\" she said. In Cape Dorset, mayor\nCary Merritt, as the general manager of the local co-op, has provided\nfood vouchers to the co-op's restaurant as an incentive for people to\nfollow their treatment. \"It's helping making sure people come in to\nget their treatments on time,\" he said.\n\n\"We're not so worried because we have a really good nurse in place\nright now. She's been very proactive with making sure people come in\nand get their treatment. I believe she is really doing a good job\nbringing down the cases now and with the level of treatment, she's\nensuring it's happening. I think we will see a drastic reduction now.\"\n\n[Byline: Jeanne Gagnon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, the largest federal territory of Canada, is the size of\nWestern Europe; it comprises a major portion of Northern Canada, and\nhas an estimated population in 2010 of about 33 000, mostly Inuit\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut>). The territorial capital\nIqaluit, which had a population in 2006 of 6184, is on Baffin Island,\nwhich had a population of 11 000 in 2007. Cape Dorset is a town\nlocated on Dorset Island at the southern tip of Baffin Island with a\npopulation in 2006 of 1236.\n\nThe TB incidence rate for the first 9 months of 2010 is thus 727 per\n100 000 in the Baffin region with 80 cases, 647 per 100 000 in\nIqaluit with 40 cases, and 2184 per 100 000 in Cape Dorset with 27\ncases, whereas the annual incidence rate for Canada as a whole has\nbeen reported to be less than 5 per 100 000\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/tbpc-latb/itir-eng.php>).\n\nAboriginal peoples in Canada comprise the Inuit, First Nations, and\nMetis (indigenous First People of Canada who trace their descent to\nmixed European and First Nations parentage)\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aboriginal_peoples_in_Canada>). The\n2006 census counted a total Canadian Aboriginal population of 1 172\n790 (3.75 percent of the population), which includes 698 025 First\nNations (2.23 percent), 389 785 Metis (1.25 percent), and 50 480\nInuit (0.16 percent) (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Canada>).\n\nSince the 1st contact with Europeans, the Canadian Aboriginals have\nhad a disproportionately high burden of TB disease. For example, high\nincidence rates for TB have been reported among Aboriginals, mainly\nFirst Nations, in Northern Manitoba: specifically 48.4 per 100 000\noverall, with rates as high as 496.3 per 100 000 in select\ncommunities (<http://www.skylarkmedicalclinic.com/TubercuosisinManitoba.htm>).\n\nIn 2002, the Public Health Agency of Canada\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/tbcbap-tbpac/special_report-eng.php>)\nreported that from 1991-1999, of 17 590 new active and relapsed TB\ncases, 3013 (17 percent) occurred among Canadian-born Aboriginals\n(which constitute only 3.75 percent of the population). Of the\nremaining cases, 4201 (24 percent) occurred in Canadian-born\nnon-Aboriginals and 10 281 (58 percent) occurred in foreign-born\nindividuals. Aboriginals with TB were younger (median 27 years) than\nforeign-born (median 39 years) and non-Aboriginals (median 59 years).\nIn this report, drug resistant strains of TB had not yet emerged as a\nsignificant problem in this population. Less than 2 percent of\nreported cases were resistant to one or more drugs. The extent of HIV\nco-infection could not be estimated using data from this surveillance\nsystem. (HIV status was known for only 2 percent of reported\nAboriginal cases.) In the 1990's, Aboriginal people were said to have\nan overall TB rate almost 4 times higher than the Canada-wide rate.\n\nMore recently, the situation has apparently worsened. In a news\nrelease in March 2010, the Inuit were reported to be \"the most at\nrisk of tuberculosis infection with a rate that is 186 times higher\nthan the non-aboriginal average. This is double what it was just 4\nyears ago\"\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\nThe high rates for TB in the Canadian Aboriginal population have been\nattributed to limited access to healthcare in remote regions,\nsubstandard housing, with whole families living in a single room,\nwidespread poverty, and malnutrition\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\n\nThe TB control plan described in the news release above seems\ninadequate for the situation. For example, the treatment plan in\nNunavut relies on the patients self-administering medication. Because\nof the frequency of non-adherence to TB treatment regimens in all\npopulations, directly observed therapy (DOTS) is the internationally\nrecommended strategy for TB case management. DOTS requires an\nindependent observer watching patients swallow each dose of their\nanti-TB therapy. The independent observer is not necessarily a\nhealthcare worker; the person could be, for example, a tribal elder\nor similar senior person within that community. Because drug\nresistance and HIV co-infection may require modification of the TB\ntreatment regimens (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5211.pdf>), HIV\nstatus and drug resistance should be determined in each case, if not\ndone already, in the current outbreak in Nunavut.\n\nA program to prevent latent from becoming active disease should\naccompany early detection of cases of active tuberculosis and its\nprompt and complete treatment. Most cases of progression from latent\nTB to active tuberculosis occur within 2 to 12 months of initial\ninfection. Children and adolescents are especially at high risk for\nprogression to tuberculosis disease (with potential for disseminated\ndisease). Most children with latent TB have been recently infected\n(especially those younger than age 5 years), usually from exposure to\na person with active TB in their immediate environment, usually the\nhousehold. Children exposed to active TB must be evaluated and\ntreated for latent TB. TB control requires government commitment of\nfunds and personnel more than a single nurse in the field for such a\nlarge and remote region, even though she may be \"a really good nurse\".\n\nA map of Nunavut, Baffin Island, and the towns of Cape Dorset and\nIqaluit can be found at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/reference/provincesterritories/nunavut/referencemap_image_view>.\nNunavut can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nof Canada at <http://healthmap.org/r/0ccp>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\n...................................ml/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. From 1 Jan to 30 Sep 2010, 87 TB cases were diagnosed in\nNunavut, with 92 per cent of them [80 cases] in the Baffin region,\nsaid Elaine Randell, communicable disease consultant with Nunavut's\nDepartment of Health and Social Services. She added 40 of those cases\nwere in Iqaluit, 27 in Cape Dorset, and the rest in other\ncommunities. Randell also said 15 to 24-year-olds were hit the hardest.\n\nThe outbreak peaked in May [2010]. Only 3 TB cases were diagnosed in\nthe territory in September. \"There seems to be a downward trend,\nalthough with TB, it's probably too early to tell but we're hoping\nthat this is the beginning of a downward trend,\" she said. \"It would\nappear that Iqaluit and Cape Dorset both have their own strains. The\noutbreaks don't seem to be related.\"\n\nThis year's [2010] surge in cases already surpasses the previous\nrecord set in 2008, when 58 people were diagnosed with TB, an\ninfectious and potentially deadly disease that often attacks the\nlungs. \"Nunavut has all the elements for a perfect storm when it\ncomes to TB,\" she said. \"You have a high rate of infection among the\nInuit, which makes all the communities sort of at risk for outbreaks.\nYou also have the social determinants for health -- the poverty,\n[lack of] access to healthy foods, crowded housing conditions, those\nsorts of things.\" Those factors make the territory \"ripe for this\ntype of outbreak,\" she said.\n\nShe added they have traced anyone who might have been in contact with\nan infected person, sought other cases, and added staff to the\nbusiest areas. Randell said they are also revising the TB manual for\nhealth care workers and developing a communications strategy. She\nsaid they have even offered taxi vouchers as incentives for people to\ncome for treatment. \"For the most part, most of the clients have been\nvery co-operative in helping us,\" she said. She's been very proactive with making sure people come in\nand get their treatment. I believe she is really doing a good job\nbringing down the cases now and with the level of treatment, she's\nensuring it's happening. I think we will see a drastic reduction now.\"\n\n[Byline: Jeanne Gagnon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, the largest federal territory of Canada, is the size of\nWestern Europe; it comprises a major portion of Northern Canada, and\nhas an estimated population in 2010 of about 33 000, mostly Inuit\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut>). In a news\nrelease in March 2010, the Inuit were reported to be \"the most at\nrisk of tuberculosis infection with a rate that is 186 times higher\nthan the non-aboriginal average. This is double what it was just 4\nyears ago\"\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\nThe high rates for TB in the Canadian Aboriginal population have been\nattributed to limited access to healthcare in remote regions,\nsubstandard housing, with whole families living in a single room,\nwidespread poverty, and malnutrition\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\n\nThe TB control plan described in the news release above seems\ninadequate for the situation. For example, the treatment plan in\nNunavut relies on the patients self-administering medication. Because\nof the frequency of non-adherence to TB treatment regimens in all\npopulations, directly observed therapy (DOTS) is the internationally\nrecommended strategy for TB case management. DOTS requires an\nindependent observer watching patients swallow each dose of their\nanti-TB therapy. The independent observer is not necessarily a\nhealthcare worker; the person could be, for example, a tribal elder\nor similar senior person within that community. Because drug\nresistance and HIV co-infection may require modification of the TB\ntreatment regimens (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5211.pdf>), HIV\nstatus and drug resistance should be determined in each case, if not\ndone already, in the current outbreak in Nunavut.\n\nA program to prevent latent from becoming active disease should\naccompany early detection of cases of active tuberculosis and its\nprompt and complete treatment. Most cases of progression from latent\nTB to active tuberculosis occur within 2 to 12 months of initial\ninfection. Children and adolescents are especially at high risk for\nprogression to tuberculosis disease (with potential for disseminated\ndisease). Most children with latent TB have been recently infected\n(especially those younger than age 5 years), usually from exposure to\na person with active TB in their immediate environment, usually the\nhousehold. Children exposed to active TB must be evaluated and\ntreated for latent TB. TB control requires government commitment of\nfunds and personnel more than a single nurse in the field for such a\nlarge and remote region, even though she may be \"a really good nurse\".\n\nA map of Nunavut, Baffin Island, and the towns of Cape Dorset and\nIqaluit can be found at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/reference/provincesterritories/nunavut/referencemap_image_view>.\nNunavut can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nof Canada at <http://healthmap.org/r/0ccp>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\n...................................ml/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-09-30 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Iqaluit", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Dorset", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin Island", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "575408", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis - UK (05): badger vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=575408", "date": "2010-10-08 15:00:09", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS - CANADA: (NUNAVUT), INUIT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 4 Oct 2010\nSource: Northern News Services Online [edited]\n<http://nnsl.com/northern-news-services/stories/papers/oct4_10tb.html>\n\n\nThe [Nunavut] territory is seeing its worst tuberculosis [TB]\noutbreak in more than a decade, with 87 cases diagnosed so far this\nyear [2010]. From 1 Jan to 30 Sep 2010, 87 TB cases were diagnosed in\nNunavut, with 92 per cent of them [80 cases] in the Baffin region,\nsaid Elaine Randell, communicable disease consultant with Nunavut's\nDepartment of Health and Social Services. She added 40 of those cases\nwere in Iqaluit, 27 in Cape Dorset, and the rest in other\ncommunities. Randell also said 15 to 24-year-olds were hit the hardest.\n\nThe outbreak peaked in May [2010]. Only 3 TB cases were diagnosed in\nthe territory in September. \"There seems to be a downward trend,\nalthough with TB, it's probably too early to tell but we're hoping\nthat this is the beginning of a downward trend,\" she said. \"It would\nappear that Iqaluit and Cape Dorset both have their own strains. The\noutbreaks don't seem to be related.\"\n\nThis year's [2010] surge in cases already surpasses the previous\nrecord set in 2008, when 58 people were diagnosed with TB, an\ninfectious and potentially deadly disease that often attacks the\nlungs. \"Nunavut has all the elements for a perfect storm when it\ncomes to TB,\" she said. \"You have a high rate of infection among the\nInuit, which makes all the communities sort of at risk for outbreaks.\nYou also have the social determinants for health -- the poverty,\n[lack of] access to healthy foods, crowded housing conditions, those\nsorts of things.\" Those factors make the territory \"ripe for this\ntype of outbreak,\" she said.\n\nShe added they have traced anyone who might have been in contact with\nan infected person, sought other cases, and added staff to the\nbusiest areas. Randell said they are also revising the TB manual for\nhealth care workers and developing a communications strategy. She\nsaid they have even offered taxi vouchers as incentives for people to\ncome for treatment. \"For the most part, most of the clients have been\nvery co-operative in helping us,\" she said. In Cape Dorset, mayor\nCary Merritt, as the general manager of the local co-op, has provided\nfood vouchers to the co-op's restaurant as an incentive for people to\nfollow their treatment. \"It's helping making sure people come in to\nget their treatments on time,\" he said.\n\n\"We're not so worried because we have a really good nurse in place\nright now. She's been very proactive with making sure people come in\nand get their treatment. I believe she is really doing a good job\nbringing down the cases now and with the level of treatment, she's\nensuring it's happening. I think we will see a drastic reduction now.\"\n\n[Byline: Jeanne Gagnon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, the largest federal territory of Canada, is the size of\nWestern Europe; it comprises a major portion of Northern Canada, and\nhas an estimated population in 2010 of about 33 000, mostly Inuit\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut>). The territorial capital\nIqaluit, which had a population in 2006 of 6184, is on Baffin Island,\nwhich had a population of 11 000 in 2007. Cape Dorset is a town\nlocated on Dorset Island at the southern tip of Baffin Island with a\npopulation in 2006 of 1236.\n\nThe TB incidence rate for the first 9 months of 2010 is thus 727 per\n100 000 in the Baffin region with 80 cases, 647 per 100 000 in\nIqaluit with 40 cases, and 2184 per 100 000 in Cape Dorset with 27\ncases, whereas the annual incidence rate for Canada as a whole has\nbeen reported to be less than 5 per 100 000\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/tbpc-latb/itir-eng.php>).\n\nAboriginal peoples in Canada comprise the Inuit, First Nations, and\nMetis (indigenous First People of Canada who trace their descent to\nmixed European and First Nations parentage)\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aboriginal_peoples_in_Canada>). The\n2006 census counted a total Canadian Aboriginal population of 1 172\n790 (3.75 percent of the population), which includes 698 025 First\nNations (2.23 percent), 389 785 Metis (1.25 percent), and 50 480\nInuit (0.16 percent) (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Canada>).\n\nSince the 1st contact with Europeans, the Canadian Aboriginals have\nhad a disproportionately high burden of TB disease. For example, high\nincidence rates for TB have been reported among Aboriginals, mainly\nFirst Nations, in Northern Manitoba: specifically 48.4 per 100 000\noverall, with rates as high as 496.3 per 100 000 in select\ncommunities (<http://www.skylarkmedicalclinic.com/TubercuosisinManitoba.htm>).\n\nIn 2002, the Public Health Agency of Canada\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/tbcbap-tbpac/special_report-eng.php>)\nreported that from 1991-1999, of 17 590 new active and relapsed TB\ncases, 3013 (17 percent) occurred among Canadian-born Aboriginals\n(which constitute only 3.75 percent of the population). Of the\nremaining cases, 4201 (24 percent) occurred in Canadian-born\nnon-Aboriginals and 10 281 (58 percent) occurred in foreign-born\nindividuals. Aboriginals with TB were younger (median 27 years) than\nforeign-born (median 39 years) and non-Aboriginals (median 59 years).\nIn this report, drug resistant strains of TB had not yet emerged as a\nsignificant problem in this population. Less than 2 percent of\nreported cases were resistant to one or more drugs. The extent of HIV\nco-infection could not be estimated using data from this surveillance\nsystem. (HIV status was known for only 2 percent of reported\nAboriginal cases.) In the 1990's, Aboriginal people were said to have\nan overall TB rate almost 4 times higher than the Canada-wide rate.\n\nMore recently, the situation has apparently worsened. In a news\nrelease in March 2010, the Inuit were reported to be \"the most at\nrisk of tuberculosis infection with a rate that is 186 times higher\nthan the non-aboriginal average. This is double what it was just 4\nyears ago\"\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\nThe high rates for TB in the Canadian Aboriginal population have been\nattributed to limited access to healthcare in remote regions,\nsubstandard housing, with whole families living in a single room,\nwidespread poverty, and malnutrition\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\n\nThe TB control plan described in the news release above seems\ninadequate for the situation. For example, the treatment plan in\nNunavut relies on the patients self-administering medication. Because\nof the frequency of non-adherence to TB treatment regimens in all\npopulations, directly observed therapy (DOTS) is the internationally\nrecommended strategy for TB case management. DOTS requires an\nindependent observer watching patients swallow each dose of their\nanti-TB therapy. The independent observer is not necessarily a\nhealthcare worker; the person could be, for example, a tribal elder\nor similar senior person within that community. Because drug\nresistance and HIV co-infection may require modification of the TB\ntreatment regimens (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5211.pdf>), HIV\nstatus and drug resistance should be determined in each case, if not\ndone already, in the current outbreak in Nunavut.\n\nA program to prevent latent from becoming active disease should\naccompany early detection of cases of active tuberculosis and its\nprompt and complete treatment. Most cases of progression from latent\nTB to active tuberculosis occur within 2 to 12 months of initial\ninfection. Children and adolescents are especially at high risk for\nprogression to tuberculosis disease (with potential for disseminated\ndisease). Most children with latent TB have been recently infected\n(especially those younger than age 5 years), usually from exposure to\na person with active TB in their immediate environment, usually the\nhousehold. Children exposed to active TB must be evaluated and\ntreated for latent TB. TB control requires government commitment of\nfunds and personnel more than a single nurse in the field for such a\nlarge and remote region, even though she may be \"a really good nurse\".\n\nA map of Nunavut, Baffin Island, and the towns of Cape Dorset and\nIqaluit can be found at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/reference/provincesterritories/nunavut/referencemap_image_view>.\nNunavut can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nof Canada at <http://healthmap.org/r/0ccp>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\n...................................ml/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
