From 1 Jan to 30 Sep 2010, 87 TB cases were diagnosed in\nNunavut, with 92 per cent of them [80 cases] in the Baffin region,\nsaid Elaine Randell, communicable disease consultant with Nunavut's\nDepartment of Health and Social Services. She added 40 of those cases\nwere in Iqaluit, 27 in Cape Dorset, and the rest in other\ncommunities. Randell also said 15 to 24-year-olds were hit the hardest.\n\nThe outbreak peaked in May [2010]. Only 3 TB cases were diagnosed in\nthe territory in September. \"There seems to be a downward trend,\nalthough with TB, it's probably too early to tell but we're hoping\nthat this is the beginning of a downward trend,\" she said. \"It would\nappear that Iqaluit and Cape Dorset both have their own strains. The\noutbreaks don't seem to be related.\"\n\nThis year's [2010] surge in cases already surpasses the previous\nrecord set in 2008, when 58 people were diagnosed with TB, an\ninfectious and potentially deadly disease that often attacks the\nlungs. \"Nunavut has all the elements for a perfect storm when it\ncomes to TB,\" she said. \"You have a high rate of infection among the\nInuit, which makes all the communities sort of at risk for outbreaks.\nYou also have the social determinants for health -- the poverty,\n[lack of] access to healthy foods, crowded housing conditions, those\nsorts of things.\" Those factors make the territory \"ripe for this\ntype of outbreak,\" she said.\n\nShe added they have traced anyone who might have been in contact with\nan infected person, sought other cases, and added staff to the\nbusiest areas. Randell said they are also revising the TB manual for\nhealth care workers and developing a communications strategy. She\nsaid they have even offered taxi vouchers as incentives for people to\ncome for treatment. \"For the most part, most of the clients have been\nvery co-operative in helping us,\" she said. In Cape Dorset, mayor\nCary Merritt, as the general manager of the local co-op, has provided\nfood vouchers to the co-op's restaurant as an incentive for people to\nfollow their treatment. \"It's helping making sure people come in to\nget their treatments on time,\" he said.\n\n\"We're not so worried because we have a really good nurse in place\nright now. She's been very proactive with making sure people come in\nand get their treatment. I believe she is really doing a good job\nbringing down the cases now and with the level of treatment, she's\nensuring it's happening. I think we will see a drastic reduction now.\"\n\n[Byline: Jeanne Gagnon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Nunavut, the largest federal territory of Canada, is the size of\nWestern Europe; it comprises a major portion of Northern Canada, and\nhas an estimated population in 2010 of about 33 000, mostly Inuit\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nunavut>). The territorial capital\nIqaluit, which had a population in 2006 of 6184, is on Baffin Island,\nwhich had a population of 11 000 in 2007. Cape Dorset is a town\nlocated on Dorset Island at the southern tip of Baffin Island with a\npopulation in 2006 of 1236.\n\nThe TB incidence rate for the first 9 months of 2010 is thus 727 per\n100 000 in the Baffin region with 80 cases, 647 per 100 000 in\nIqaluit with 40 cases, and 2184 per 100 000 in Cape Dorset with 27\ncases, whereas the annual incidence rate for Canada as a whole has\nbeen reported to be less than 5 per 100 000\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/tbpc-latb/itir-eng.php>).\n\nAboriginal peoples in Canada comprise the Inuit, First Nations, and\nMetis (indigenous First People of Canada who trace their descent to\nmixed European and First Nations parentage)\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aboriginal_peoples_in_Canada>). The\n2006 census counted a total Canadian Aboriginal population of 1 172\n790 (3.75 percent of the population), which includes 698 025 First\nNations (2.23 percent), 389 785 Metis (1.25 percent), and 50 480\nInuit (0.16 percent) (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Canada>).\n\nSince the 1st contact with Europeans, the Canadian Aboriginals have\nhad a disproportionately high burden of TB disease. For example, high\nincidence rates for TB have been reported among Aboriginals, mainly\nFirst Nations, in Northern Manitoba: specifically 48.4 per 100 000\noverall, with rates as high as 496.3 per 100 000 in select\ncommunities (<http://www.skylarkmedicalclinic.com/TubercuosisinManitoba.htm>).\n\nIn 2002, the Public Health Agency of Canada\n(<http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/publicat/tbcbap-tbpac/special_report-eng.php>)\nreported that from 1991-1999, of 17 590 new active and relapsed TB\ncases, 3013 (17 percent) occurred among Canadian-born Aboriginals\n(which constitute only 3.75 percent of the population). Of the\nremaining cases, 4201 (24 percent) occurred in Canadian-born\nnon-Aboriginals and 10 281 (58 percent) occurred in foreign-born\nindividuals. Aboriginals with TB were younger (median 27 years) than\nforeign-born (median 39 years) and non-Aboriginals (median 59 years).\nIn this report, drug resistant strains of TB had not yet emerged as a\nsignificant problem in this population. Less than 2 percent of\nreported cases were resistant to one or more drugs. The extent of HIV\nco-infection could not be estimated using data from this surveillance\nsystem. (HIV status was known for only 2 percent of reported\nAboriginal cases.) In the 1990's, Aboriginal people were said to have\nan overall TB rate almost 4 times higher than the Canada-wide rate.\n\nMore recently, the situation has apparently worsened. In a news\nrelease in March 2010, the Inuit were reported to be \"the most at\nrisk of tuberculosis infection with a rate that is 186 times higher\nthan the non-aboriginal average. This is double what it was just 4\nyears ago\"\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\nThe high rates for TB in the Canadian Aboriginal population have been\nattributed to limited access to healthcare in remote regions,\nsubstandard housing, with whole families living in a single room,\nwidespread poverty, and malnutrition\n(<http://www.suite101.com/content/tb-epidemic-among-canadas-native-people-a211908#ixzz11jIy6OW1>).\n\nThe TB control plan described in the news release above seems\ninadequate for the situation. For example, the treatment plan in\nNunavut relies on the patients self-administering medication. Because\nof the frequency of non-adherence to TB treatment regimens in all\npopulations, directly observed therapy (DOTS) is the internationally\nrecommended strategy for TB case management. DOTS requires an\nindependent observer watching patients swallow each dose of their\nanti-TB therapy. The independent observer is not necessarily a\nhealthcare worker; the person could be, for example, a tribal elder\nor similar senior person within that community. Because drug\nresistance and HIV co-infection may require modification of the TB\ntreatment regimens (<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/PDF/rr/rr5211.pdf>), HIV\nstatus and drug resistance should be determined in each case, if not\ndone already, in the current outbreak in Nunavut.\n\nA program to prevent latent from becoming active disease should\naccompany early detection of cases of active tuberculosis and its\nprompt and complete treatment. Most cases of progression from latent\nTB to active tuberculosis occur within 2 to 12 months of initial\ninfection. Children and adolescents are especially at high risk for\nprogression to tuberculosis disease (with potential for disseminated\ndisease). Most children with latent TB have been recently infected\n(especially those younger than age 5 years), usually from exposure to\na person with active TB in their immediate environment, usually the\nhousehold. Children exposed to active TB must be evaluated and\ntreated for latent TB. TB control requires government commitment of\nfunds and personnel more than a single nurse in the field for such a\nlarge and remote region, even though she may be \"a really good nurse\".\n\nA map of Nunavut, Baffin Island, and the towns of Cape Dorset and\nIqaluit can be found at\n<http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/auth/english/maps/reference/provincesterritories/nunavut/referencemap_image_view>.\nNunavut can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nof Canada at <http://healthmap.org/r/0ccp>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, children - UK: use of BCG vaccine 20100717.2386\n...................................ml/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-09-30 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-09-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Iqaluit", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Dorset", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Baffin Island", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "534780", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - UK (04): new control program", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=534780", "date": "2010-07-15 10:00:04", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA (06): (OHIO)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Jul 2010\nSource: Dairy Herd [edited]\n<http://www.dairyherd.com/directories.asp?pgID=675&ed_id=11820>\n\n\nOhio Department of Agriculture director Robert Boggs announced\nWednesday [7 Jul 2010] that preliminary tests performed by the\ndepartment's Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory revealed a positive\nresult for bovine tuberculosis in a Paulding County dairy herd. There\nis no known human illness associated with this occurrence.\n\nThe herd was found positive after routine tuberculosis testing by the\ndepartment. The herd was depopulated, and the department is currently\nconducting a trace-in and trace-out investigation to determine if\nother livestock may be affected.\n\n\"We are currently working with our state and federal partners on this\nmatter to take the necessary steps to identify the origin of the\naffected cattle,\" said Boggs. \"This is yet another example of how the\nOhio Department of Agriculture works daily to assure the safety of\nOhio consumers and livestock.\"\n\nTuberculosis is a disease caused by bacteria which affect the\nrespiratory system. Bovine tuberculosis, also known as cattle TB, is\nan infectious form of tuberculosis as it infects most warm-blooded\nanimals, including humans. It can manifest in livestock as a chronic,\ndebilitating disease, and it may take years to develop bovine\ntuberculosis lesions in the lungs.\n\nAirborne exposure from coughing and sneezing is considered to be the\nmost frequent way in which bovine tuberculosis is spread, but it can\nalso occur through consumption of contaminated water, feed, or\nunpasteurized milk.\n\nFor more information about the Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory, visit\n<http://www.agri.ohio.gov>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (TB) is caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_. While\nthere are other _Mycobacterium_ spp, _M. bovis_ and _M. tuberculosis_\nare among the most important, as these tend to move between animals and people.\n\nDisease caused by mycobacteria often develop very slowly and may take\nmonths to years to develop. These bacteria grow very slowly and only\nreplicate every 12-20 hours. While the pathogenic species (those\nwhich can cause disease) such as _M. tuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ can\ninfect a human or an animal, often the individual does not know that\nhe has been infected. In humans, those infected but without active\ndisease can be treated to prevent disease from occurring. To prevent\nother animals from being infected, a diseased animal must be culled\nfrom the herd.\n\nThe disease primarily affects the respiratory tract but can also\nspread to other parts of the body. The primary route of transmission\nis the exchange of respiratory secretions between infected and\nuninfected animals. This can be achieved through nose-to-nose contact\nor by the inhalation of aerosol droplets that have been exhaled by an\ninfected animal. Animals may also become infected with _M. bovis_ by\ningesting the bacteria. This could occur by ingesting feeds that have\nbeen contaminated with _M. bovis_ by other infected animals.\nCarnivores may become infected with bovine TB by eating infected carcasses.\n\nVarious factors affect the efficiency in which _M. bovis_ is spread\nwithin a cattle herd. The number of infected animals shedding the\norganism, as well as the number of susceptible animals present within\na herd can have an impact on the transmission of the bacteria. For\nexample, the more animals within a herd shedding _M. bovis_, the\ngreater the chance of an uninfected animal coming into contact with\nan infected animal. The animal density of a herd also influences the\nefficiency of _M. bovis_ transmission. Transmission of _M. bovis_\namong animals housed in confinement facilities may be greater because\nof close contact. Cattle infected with bovine TB may shed bacteria in\ntheir feces, urine, and milk, but these are felt to be a minor source\nof bacterial transmission.\n\nEnvironmental contamination with _M. bovis_ may play a role in the\nspread of bovine TB. Survival of _M. bovis_ in the environment is\nprimarily affected by exposure to sunlight. Reports on the length of\nsurvival of _M. bovis_ vary from 18-332 days at temperatures ranging\nfrom 54-75 deg F (12-24 deg C). Under laboratory conditions, _M.\nbovis_ has been isolated for up to 8 weeks from various feeds kept at\n75 deg F (24 deg C) and 14 weeks from various feeds kept at 32 deg F\n(0 deg C). Under field conditions, however, it is difficult to\nisolate _M. bovis_ from pastures grazed by animals known to be\ninfected with bovine TB.\n\nSadly, this disease still keeps popping up in the animal herds.\nResearchers need to find a more reliable test. While the Bovigam [an\nin vitro laboratory test for the diagnosis of bovine TB in cattle,\nsheep, goats, buffalo, bison, and other bovidae] has promise, it is\nnot an end-all to testing.\n\nParts of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.michigan.gov/emergingdiseases/0,1607,7-186-25804-75601--,00.html>.\n- Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at <http://healthmap.org/r/01Ja>. Paulding County can be located on the\nmap at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paulding_County,_Ohio>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (CO) 20100614.1989\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (KY) 20100528.1768\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20100418.1265\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (NE) 20100409.1144\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20100325.0948\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (SD) 20100107.0065\n2009\n---\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (12): (MN), cervid 20091222.4315\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (11): (IN) cervid 20090804.2742\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (10): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090714.2508\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090711.2480\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090628.2343\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MN) cervid 20090625.2307\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\nTuberculosis, captive wildlife - USA: (NE) 20090414.1423\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA: (IL) susp. 20090412.1398\n...................................sb/tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paulding County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "531338", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, porcine - New Zealand", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=531338", "date": "2010-07-15 10:00:04", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA (06): (OHIO)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Jul 2010\nSource: Dairy Herd [edited]\n<http://www.dairyherd.com/directories.asp?pgID=675&ed_id=11820>\n\n\nOhio Department of Agriculture director Robert Boggs announced\nWednesday [7 Jul 2010] that preliminary tests performed by the\ndepartment's Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory revealed a positive\nresult for bovine tuberculosis in a Paulding County dairy herd. There\nis no known human illness associated with this occurrence.\n\nThe herd was found positive after routine tuberculosis testing by the\ndepartment. The herd was depopulated, and the department is currently\nconducting a trace-in and trace-out investigation to determine if\nother livestock may be affected.\n\n\"We are currently working with our state and federal partners on this\nmatter to take the necessary steps to identify the origin of the\naffected cattle,\" said Boggs. \"This is yet another example of how the\nOhio Department of Agriculture works daily to assure the safety of\nOhio consumers and livestock.\"\n\nTuberculosis is a disease caused by bacteria which affect the\nrespiratory system. Bovine tuberculosis, also known as cattle TB, is\nan infectious form of tuberculosis as it infects most warm-blooded\nanimals, including humans. It can manifest in livestock as a chronic,\ndebilitating disease, and it may take years to develop bovine\ntuberculosis lesions in the lungs.\n\nAirborne exposure from coughing and sneezing is considered to be the\nmost frequent way in which bovine tuberculosis is spread, but it can\nalso occur through consumption of contaminated water, feed, or\nunpasteurized milk.\n\nFor more information about the Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory, visit\n<http://www.agri.ohio.gov>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (TB) is caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_. While\nthere are other _Mycobacterium_ spp, _M. bovis_ and _M. tuberculosis_\nare among the most important, as these tend to move between animals and people.\n\nDisease caused by mycobacteria often develop very slowly and may take\nmonths to years to develop. These bacteria grow very slowly and only\nreplicate every 12-20 hours. While the pathogenic species (those\nwhich can cause disease) such as _M. tuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ can\ninfect a human or an animal, often the individual does not know that\nhe has been infected. In humans, those infected but without active\ndisease can be treated to prevent disease from occurring. To prevent\nother animals from being infected, a diseased animal must be culled\nfrom the herd.\n\nThe disease primarily affects the respiratory tract but can also\nspread to other parts of the body. The primary route of transmission\nis the exchange of respiratory secretions between infected and\nuninfected animals. This can be achieved through nose-to-nose contact\nor by the inhalation of aerosol droplets that have been exhaled by an\ninfected animal. Animals may also become infected with _M. bovis_ by\ningesting the bacteria. This could occur by ingesting feeds that have\nbeen contaminated with _M. bovis_ by other infected animals.\nCarnivores may become infected with bovine TB by eating infected carcasses.\n\nVarious factors affect the efficiency in which _M. bovis_ is spread\nwithin a cattle herd. The number of infected animals shedding the\norganism, as well as the number of susceptible animals present within\na herd can have an impact on the transmission of the bacteria. For\nexample, the more animals within a herd shedding _M. bovis_, the\ngreater the chance of an uninfected animal coming into contact with\nan infected animal. The animal density of a herd also influences the\nefficiency of _M. bovis_ transmission. Transmission of _M. bovis_\namong animals housed in confinement facilities may be greater because\nof close contact. Cattle infected with bovine TB may shed bacteria in\ntheir feces, urine, and milk, but these are felt to be a minor source\nof bacterial transmission.\n\nEnvironmental contamination with _M. bovis_ may play a role in the\nspread of bovine TB. Survival of _M. bovis_ in the environment is\nprimarily affected by exposure to sunlight. Reports on the length of\nsurvival of _M. bovis_ vary from 18-332 days at temperatures ranging\nfrom 54-75 deg F (12-24 deg C). Under laboratory conditions, _M.\nbovis_ has been isolated for up to 8 weeks from various feeds kept at\n75 deg F (24 deg C) and 14 weeks from various feeds kept at 32 deg F\n(0 deg C). Under field conditions, however, it is difficult to\nisolate _M. bovis_ from pastures grazed by animals known to be\ninfected with bovine TB.\n\nSadly, this disease still keeps popping up in the animal herds.\nResearchers need to find a more reliable test. While the Bovigam [an\nin vitro laboratory test for the diagnosis of bovine TB in cattle,\nsheep, goats, buffalo, bison, and other bovidae] has promise, it is\nnot an end-all to testing.\n\nParts of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.michigan.gov/emergingdiseases/0,1607,7-186-25804-75601--,00.html>.\n- Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at <http://healthmap.org/r/01Ja>. Paulding County can be located on the\nmap at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paulding_County,_Ohio>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (CO) 20100614.1989\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (KY) 20100528.1768\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20100418.1265\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (NE) 20100409.1144\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20100325.0948\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (SD) 20100107.0065\n2009\n---\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (12): (MN), cervid 20091222.4315\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (11): (IN) cervid 20090804.2742\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (10): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090714.2508\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090711.2480\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090628.2343\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MN) cervid 20090625.2307\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\nTuberculosis, captive wildlife - USA: (NE) 20090414.1423\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA: (IL) susp. 20090412.1398\n...................................sb/tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Under field conditions, however, it is difficult to\nisolate _M. bovis_ from pastures grazed by animals known to be\ninfected with bovine TB.\n\nSadly, this disease still keeps popping up in the animal herds.\nResearchers need to find a more reliable test. While the Bovigam [an\nin vitro laboratory test for the diagnosis of bovine TB in cattle,\nsheep, goats, buffalo, bison, and other bovidae] has promise, it is\nnot an end-all to testing.\n\nParts of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.michigan.gov/emergingdiseases/0,1607,7-186-25804-75601--,00.html>.\n- Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at <http://healthmap.org/r/01Ja>. Paulding County can be located on the\nmap at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paulding_County,_Ohio>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (CO) 20100614.1989\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (KY) 20100528.1768\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20100418.1265\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (NE) 20100409.1144\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20100325.0948\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (SD) 20100107.0065\n2009\n---\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (12): (MN), cervid 20091222.4315\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (11): (IN) cervid 20090804.2742\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (10): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090714.2508\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090711.2480\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090628.2343\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MN) cervid 20090625.2307\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\nTuberculosis, captive wildlife - USA: (NE) 20090414.1423\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA: (IL) susp. 20090412.1398\n...................................sb/tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paulding County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "511931", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - France: (MP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=511931", "date": "2010-07-15 10:00:04", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA (06): (OHIO)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Jul 2010\nSource: Dairy Herd [edited]\n<http://www.dairyherd.com/directories.asp?pgID=675&ed_id=11820>\n\n\nOhio Department of Agriculture director Robert Boggs announced\nWednesday [7 Jul 2010] that preliminary tests performed by the\ndepartment's Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory revealed a positive\nresult for bovine tuberculosis in a Paulding County dairy herd. There\nis no known human illness associated with this occurrence.\n\nThe herd was found positive after routine tuberculosis testing by the\ndepartment. The herd was depopulated, and the department is currently\nconducting a trace-in and trace-out investigation to determine if\nother livestock may be affected.\n\n\"We are currently working with our state and federal partners on this\nmatter to take the necessary steps to identify the origin of the\naffected cattle,\" said Boggs. \"This is yet another example of how the\nOhio Department of Agriculture works daily to assure the safety of\nOhio consumers and livestock.\"\n\nTuberculosis is a disease caused by bacteria which affect the\nrespiratory system. Bovine tuberculosis, also known as cattle TB, is\nan infectious form of tuberculosis as it infects most warm-blooded\nanimals, including humans. It can manifest in livestock as a chronic,\ndebilitating disease, and it may take years to develop bovine\ntuberculosis lesions in the lungs.\n\nAirborne exposure from coughing and sneezing is considered to be the\nmost frequent way in which bovine tuberculosis is spread, but it can\nalso occur through consumption of contaminated water, feed, or\nunpasteurized milk.\n\nFor more information about the Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory, visit\n<http://www.agri.ohio.gov>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (TB) is caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_. While\nthere are other _Mycobacterium_ spp, _M. bovis_ and _M. tuberculosis_\nare among the most important, as these tend to move between animals and people.\n\nDisease caused by mycobacteria often develop very slowly and may take\nmonths to years to develop. These bacteria grow very slowly and only\nreplicate every 12-20 hours. While the pathogenic species (those\nwhich can cause disease) such as _M. tuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ can\ninfect a human or an animal, often the individual does not know that\nhe has been infected. In humans, those infected but without active\ndisease can be treated to prevent disease from occurring. To prevent\nother animals from being infected, a diseased animal must be culled\nfrom the herd.\n\nThe disease primarily affects the respiratory tract but can also\nspread to other parts of the body. The primary route of transmission\nis the exchange of respiratory secretions between infected and\nuninfected animals. This can be achieved through nose-to-nose contact\nor by the inhalation of aerosol droplets that have been exhaled by an\ninfected animal. Animals may also become infected with _M. bovis_ by\ningesting the bacteria. This could occur by ingesting feeds that have\nbeen contaminated with _M. bovis_ by other infected animals.\nCarnivores may become infected with bovine TB by eating infected carcasses.\n\nVarious factors affect the efficiency in which _M. bovis_ is spread\nwithin a cattle herd. The number of infected animals shedding the\norganism, as well as the number of susceptible animals present within\na herd can have an impact on the transmission of the bacteria. For\nexample, the more animals within a herd shedding _M. bovis_, the\ngreater the chance of an uninfected animal coming into contact with\nan infected animal. The animal density of a herd also influences the\nefficiency of _M. bovis_ transmission. Transmission of _M. bovis_\namong animals housed in confinement facilities may be greater because\nof close contact. Cattle infected with bovine TB may shed bacteria in\ntheir feces, urine, and milk, but these are felt to be a minor source\nof bacterial transmission.\n\nEnvironmental contamination with _M. bovis_ may play a role in the\nspread of bovine TB. Survival of _M. bovis_ in the environment is\nprimarily affected by exposure to sunlight. Reports on the length of\nsurvival of _M. bovis_ vary from 18-332 days at temperatures ranging\nfrom 54-75 deg F (12-24 deg C). Under laboratory conditions, _M.\nbovis_ has been isolated for up to 8 weeks from various feeds kept at\n75 deg F (24 deg C) and 14 weeks from various feeds kept at 32 deg F\n(0 deg C). Under field conditions, however, it is difficult to\nisolate _M. bovis_ from pastures grazed by animals known to be\ninfected with bovine TB.\n\nSadly, this disease still keeps popping up in the animal herds.\nResearchers need to find a more reliable test. While the Bovigam [an\nin vitro laboratory test for the diagnosis of bovine TB in cattle,\nsheep, goats, buffalo, bison, and other bovidae] has promise, it is\nnot an end-all to testing.\n\nParts of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.michigan.gov/emergingdiseases/0,1607,7-186-25804-75601--,00.html>.\n- Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at <http://healthmap.org/r/01Ja>. Paulding County can be located on the\nmap at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paulding_County,_Ohio>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (CO) 20100614.1989\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (KY) 20100528.1768\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20100418.1265\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (NE) 20100409.1144\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20100325.0948\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (SD) 20100107.0065\n2009\n---\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (12): (MN), cervid 20091222.4315\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (11): (IN) cervid 20090804.2742\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (10): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090714.2508\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090711.2480\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090628.2343\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MN) cervid 20090625.2307\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\nTuberculosis, captive wildlife - USA: (NE) 20090414.1423\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA: (IL) susp. 20090412.1398\n...................................sb/tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. There\nis no known human illness associated with this occurrence.\n\nThe herd was found positive after routine tuberculosis testing by the\ndepartment. The herd was depopulated, and the department is currently\nconducting a trace-in and trace-out investigation to determine if\nother livestock may be affected.\n\n\"We are currently working with our state and federal partners on this\nmatter to take the necessary steps to identify the origin of the\naffected cattle,\" said Boggs. \"This is yet another example of how the\nOhio Department of Agriculture works daily to assure the safety of\nOhio consumers and livestock.\"\n\nTuberculosis is a disease caused by bacteria which affect the\nrespiratory system. Under field conditions, however, it is difficult to\nisolate _M. bovis_ from pastures grazed by animals known to be\ninfected with bovine TB.\n\nSadly, this disease still keeps popping up in the animal herds.\nResearchers need to find a more reliable test. While the Bovigam [an\nin vitro laboratory test for the diagnosis of bovine TB in cattle,\nsheep, goats, buffalo, bison, and other bovidae] has promise, it is\nnot an end-all to testing.\n\nParts of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.michigan.gov/emergingdiseases/0,1607,7-186-25804-75601--,00.html>.\n- Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at <http://healthmap.org/r/01Ja>. Paulding County can be located on the\nmap at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paulding_County,_Ohio>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (CO) 20100614.1989\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (KY) 20100528.1768\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20100418.1265\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (NE) 20100409.1144\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20100325.0948\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (SD) 20100107.0065\n2009\n---\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (12): (MN), cervid 20091222.4315\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (11): (IN) cervid 20090804.2742\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (10): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090714.2508\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090711.2480\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090628.2343\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MN) cervid 20090625.2307\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\nTuberculosis, captive wildlife - USA: (NE) 20090414.1423\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA: (IL) susp. 20090412.1398\n...................................sb/tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paulding County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "466926", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (06): (OH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=466926", "date": "2010-07-15 10:00:04", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA (06): (OHIO)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Jul 2010\nSource: Dairy Herd [edited]\n<http://www.dairyherd.com/directories.asp?pgID=675&ed_id=11820>\n\n\nOhio Department of Agriculture director Robert Boggs announced\nWednesday [7 Jul 2010] that preliminary tests performed by the\ndepartment's Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory revealed a positive\nresult for bovine tuberculosis in a Paulding County dairy herd. There\nis no known human illness associated with this occurrence.\n\nThe herd was found positive after routine tuberculosis testing by the\ndepartment. The herd was depopulated, and the department is currently\nconducting a trace-in and trace-out investigation to determine if\nother livestock may be affected.\n\n\"We are currently working with our state and federal partners on this\nmatter to take the necessary steps to identify the origin of the\naffected cattle,\" said Boggs. \"This is yet another example of how the\nOhio Department of Agriculture works daily to assure the safety of\nOhio consumers and livestock.\"\n\nTuberculosis is a disease caused by bacteria which affect the\nrespiratory system. Bovine tuberculosis, also known as cattle TB, is\nan infectious form of tuberculosis as it infects most warm-blooded\nanimals, including humans. It can manifest in livestock as a chronic,\ndebilitating disease, and it may take years to develop bovine\ntuberculosis lesions in the lungs.\n\nAirborne exposure from coughing and sneezing is considered to be the\nmost frequent way in which bovine tuberculosis is spread, but it can\nalso occur through consumption of contaminated water, feed, or\nunpasteurized milk.\n\nFor more information about the Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory, visit\n<http://www.agri.ohio.gov>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine tuberculosis (TB) is caused by _Mycobacterium bovis_. While\nthere are other _Mycobacterium_ spp, _M. bovis_ and _M. tuberculosis_\nare among the most important, as these tend to move between animals and people.\n\nDisease caused by mycobacteria often develop very slowly and may take\nmonths to years to develop. These bacteria grow very slowly and only\nreplicate every 12-20 hours. While the pathogenic species (those\nwhich can cause disease) such as _M. tuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ can\ninfect a human or an animal, often the individual does not know that\nhe has been infected. In humans, those infected but without active\ndisease can be treated to prevent disease from occurring. To prevent\nother animals from being infected, a diseased animal must be culled\nfrom the herd.\n\nThe disease primarily affects the respiratory tract but can also\nspread to other parts of the body. The primary route of transmission\nis the exchange of respiratory secretions between infected and\nuninfected animals. This can be achieved through nose-to-nose contact\nor by the inhalation of aerosol droplets that have been exhaled by an\ninfected animal. Animals may also become infected with _M. bovis_ by\ningesting the bacteria. This could occur by ingesting feeds that have\nbeen contaminated with _M. bovis_ by other infected animals.\nCarnivores may become infected with bovine TB by eating infected carcasses.\n\nVarious factors affect the efficiency in which _M. bovis_ is spread\nwithin a cattle herd. The number of infected animals shedding the\norganism, as well as the number of susceptible animals present within\na herd can have an impact on the transmission of the bacteria. For\nexample, the more animals within a herd shedding _M. bovis_, the\ngreater the chance of an uninfected animal coming into contact with\nan infected animal. The animal density of a herd also influences the\nefficiency of _M. bovis_ transmission. Transmission of _M. bovis_\namong animals housed in confinement facilities may be greater because\nof close contact. Cattle infected with bovine TB may shed bacteria in\ntheir feces, urine, and milk, but these are felt to be a minor source\nof bacterial transmission.\n\nEnvironmental contamination with _M. bovis_ may play a role in the\nspread of bovine TB. Survival of _M. bovis_ in the environment is\nprimarily affected by exposure to sunlight. Reports on the length of\nsurvival of _M. bovis_ vary from 18-332 days at temperatures ranging\nfrom 54-75 deg F (12-24 deg C). Under laboratory conditions, _M.\nbovis_ has been isolated for up to 8 weeks from various feeds kept at\n75 deg F (24 deg C) and 14 weeks from various feeds kept at 32 deg F\n(0 deg C). Under field conditions, however, it is difficult to\nisolate _M. bovis_ from pastures grazed by animals known to be\ninfected with bovine TB.\n\nSadly, this disease still keeps popping up in the animal herds.\nResearchers need to find a more reliable test. While the Bovigam [an\nin vitro laboratory test for the diagnosis of bovine TB in cattle,\nsheep, goats, buffalo, bison, and other bovidae] has promise, it is\nnot an end-all to testing.\n\nParts of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.michigan.gov/emergingdiseases/0,1607,7-186-25804-75601--,00.html>.\n- Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of Ohio can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at <http://healthmap.org/r/01Ja>. Paulding County can be located on the\nmap at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paulding_County,_Ohio>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (CO) 20100614.1989\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (KY) 20100528.1768\nBovine tuberculosis, cervid - USA: (MI) 20100418.1265\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (NE) 20100409.1144\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI) 20100325.0948\nBovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (SD) 20100107.0065\n2009\n---\nTuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru 20091230.4387\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (12): (MN), cervid 20091222.4315\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (11): (IN) cervid 20090804.2742\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (10): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090714.2508\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090711.2480\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) cervid, bovine 20090628.2343\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (07): (MN) cervid 20090625.2307\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\nTuberculosis, captive wildlife - USA: (NE) 20090414.1423\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA: (IL) susp. 20090412.1398\n...................................sb/tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paulding County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "446105", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (05): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=446105", "date": "2010-03-19 16:00:02", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: (ENGLAND) SHEEP\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Mar 2010\nSource: Farmers Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.farmersguardian.com/home/livestock/livestock-news/bovine-tb-found-in-sheep-and-wild-boar/30961.article>\n\n\nBovine TB found in sheep and wild boar\n--------------------------------------\nConcerns that bTB [bovine tuberculosis] is becoming increasingly\nprevalent in species other than cattle and badgers have been\nheightened by the discovery of the disease in sheep and wild boar.\n\nIt has emerged that a flock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire has\nbeen placed under TB restriction.\n\nVets were alerted by chronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one\nram. Postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10, the predominant strain in\nlocal cattle herds and wildlife, was subsequently isolated. Lesions\nin these 3 sheep were 'extensive', a letter in the Veterinary Record reports.\n\nA Defra spokesman said the movement restrictions would only be lifted\nwhen Animal Health was confident that the flock is free from TB. He\nsaid _M. bovis_ in sheep was 'considered rare'.\n\nThe Department has also revealed that 'lesions consistent with TB'\nhave been identified in a feral wild boar in the Ross-on-Wye area\nduring post-mortem examination by the Veterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA).\n\nDefra figures show there were over 140 bTB cases identified in\nindividual animals other than cattle in 2009, including in 68\nalpacas, 26 cats, 23 pigs, and 5 sheep. The true numbers are almost\ncertainly much higher as there is no active surveillance in non-bovine species.\n\nDefra said most other species 'generally act only as spillover hosts'\nfrom cattle and badgers with disease not sustained within populations\nwithout an external source of infection.\n\nNational Sheep Association chief executive Peter Morris said cases in\nsheep were 'not unexpected' and that the industry was not required to\ntake additional actions.\n\n[Byline: Alistair Driver]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In view of the rarity of clinical bTB in sheep and differential\ndiagnostic considerations, it has been found worthwhile to reproduce\nthe full text of the letter published in the Veterinary Record of 6\nMar 2010 (166:306):\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ causing clinical disease in adult sheep\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nI would like to report an outbreak of clinical tuberculosis (TB) in a\nflock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire.\n\nChronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one ram was investigated by\nthe flock's private veterinary surgeon. Field postmortem examinations\nof 2 ewes revealed enlarged, abscessed, mediastinal lymph nodes, but\nroutine cultures remained sterile. Serological follow-up did not\nreveal any evidence of caseous lymphadenitis (CLA) [a rather common\novine infection caused by _Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis_. -\nMod.AS] The absence of a diagnosis prompted the submission of 6 sheep\nthat had shown chronic weight loss to the Veterinary Laboratories\nAgency (VLA) for postmortem examination.\n\nGross postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10 (the predominant strain of\nthe bacterium in local cattle herds and wildlife) was subsequently\nisolated. Lesions in these 3 sheep were extensive and affected the\nlungs, lymph nodes, and viscera.\n\nClinical signs and postmortem findings of TB in sheep may resemble\nlesions of visceral CLA. Failure to demonstrate serological or\nbacteriological evidence in cases of suspect CLA should trigger a\nsuspicion of possible TB. Colleagues are reminded that suspect cases\nof TB detected in farm animals are notifiable to Animal Health. The\nsmall number of previous incidents of _M. bovis_ infection in sheep\nin Great Britain have been incidental findings at slaughter or at\npostmortem examination, but have not been associated with clinical\nsigns. The VLA plans to provide more details of this incident in the\nnear future.\n\nGuda van der Burgt\nVLA - Luddington\nLuddington, Stratford upon Avon\nWarwickshire CV37 9SJ\nUK\n<g.vanderburgt@vla.defra.gsi.gov.uk>\n\nbTB can obviously infect also dairy sheep. It will be interesting to\nnote the response of public health authorities and the Food Standards\nAgency in Britain to the described development and the continued\nspread of _M. bovis_ within the UK animal domain. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the UK is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01aS>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): badger vaccination 20090707.2443\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (Wales) 20090323.1143\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (Wales) 20090107.0066\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\n...................................arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Great Britain", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Gloucestershire", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lleyn", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Veterinary Record of", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "435935", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (KY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=435935", "date": "2010-03-19 16:00:02", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: (ENGLAND) SHEEP\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Mar 2010\nSource: Farmers Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.farmersguardian.com/home/livestock/livestock-news/bovine-tb-found-in-sheep-and-wild-boar/30961.article>\n\n\nBovine TB found in sheep and wild boar\n--------------------------------------\nConcerns that bTB [bovine tuberculosis] is becoming increasingly\nprevalent in species other than cattle and badgers have been\nheightened by the discovery of the disease in sheep and wild boar.\n\nIt has emerged that a flock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire has\nbeen placed under TB restriction.\n\nVets were alerted by chronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one\nram. Postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10, the predominant strain in\nlocal cattle herds and wildlife, was subsequently isolated. Lesions\nin these 3 sheep were 'extensive', a letter in the Veterinary Record reports.\n\nA Defra spokesman said the movement restrictions would only be lifted\nwhen Animal Health was confident that the flock is free from TB. He\nsaid _M. bovis_ in sheep was 'considered rare'.\n\nThe Department has also revealed that 'lesions consistent with TB'\nhave been identified in a feral wild boar in the Ross-on-Wye area\nduring post-mortem examination by the Veterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA).\n\nDefra figures show there were over 140 bTB cases identified in\nindividual animals other than cattle in 2009, including in 68\nalpacas, 26 cats, 23 pigs, and 5 sheep. The true numbers are almost\ncertainly much higher as there is no active surveillance in non-bovine species.\n\nDefra said most other species 'generally act only as spillover hosts'\nfrom cattle and badgers with disease not sustained within populations\nwithout an external source of infection.\n\nNational Sheep Association chief executive Peter Morris said cases in\nsheep were 'not unexpected' and that the industry was not required to\ntake additional actions.\n\n[Byline: Alistair Driver]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In view of the rarity of clinical bTB in sheep and differential\ndiagnostic considerations, it has been found worthwhile to reproduce\nthe full text of the letter published in the Veterinary Record of 6\nMar 2010 (166:306):\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ causing clinical disease in adult sheep\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nI would like to report an outbreak of clinical tuberculosis (TB) in a\nflock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire.\n\nChronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one ram was investigated by\nthe flock's private veterinary surgeon. Field postmortem examinations\nof 2 ewes revealed enlarged, abscessed, mediastinal lymph nodes, but\nroutine cultures remained sterile. Serological follow-up did not\nreveal any evidence of caseous lymphadenitis (CLA) [a rather common\novine infection caused by _Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis_. -\nMod.AS] The absence of a diagnosis prompted the submission of 6 sheep\nthat had shown chronic weight loss to the Veterinary Laboratories\nAgency (VLA) for postmortem examination.\n\nGross postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10 (the predominant strain of\nthe bacterium in local cattle herds and wildlife) was subsequently\nisolated. Lesions in these 3 sheep were extensive and affected the\nlungs, lymph nodes, and viscera.\n\nClinical signs and postmortem findings of TB in sheep may resemble\nlesions of visceral CLA. Failure to demonstrate serological or\nbacteriological evidence in cases of suspect CLA should trigger a\nsuspicion of possible TB. Colleagues are reminded that suspect cases\nof TB detected in farm animals are notifiable to Animal Health. The\nsmall number of previous incidents of _M. bovis_ infection in sheep\nin Great Britain have been incidental findings at slaughter or at\npostmortem examination, but have not been associated with clinical\nsigns. The VLA plans to provide more details of this incident in the\nnear future.\n\nGuda van der Burgt\nVLA - Luddington\nLuddington, Stratford upon Avon\nWarwickshire CV37 9SJ\nUK\n<g.vanderburgt@vla.defra.gsi.gov.uk>\n\nbTB can obviously infect also dairy sheep. It will be interesting to\nnote the response of public health authorities and the Food Standards\nAgency in Britain to the described development and the continued\nspread of _M. bovis_ within the UK animal domain. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the UK is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01aS>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): badger vaccination 20090707.2443\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (Wales) 20090323.1143\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (Wales) 20090107.0066\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\n...................................arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Great Britain", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Gloucestershire", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lleyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Veterinary Record of", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "432402", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - UK: (England), wild boar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=432402", "date": "2010-03-19 16:00:02", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: (ENGLAND) SHEEP\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Mar 2010\nSource: Farmers Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.farmersguardian.com/home/livestock/livestock-news/bovine-tb-found-in-sheep-and-wild-boar/30961.article>\n\n\nBovine TB found in sheep and wild boar\n--------------------------------------\nConcerns that bTB [bovine tuberculosis] is becoming increasingly\nprevalent in species other than cattle and badgers have been\nheightened by the discovery of the disease in sheep and wild boar.\n\nIt has emerged that a flock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire has\nbeen placed under TB restriction.\n\nVets were alerted by chronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one\nram. Postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10, the predominant strain in\nlocal cattle herds and wildlife, was subsequently isolated. Lesions\nin these 3 sheep were 'extensive', a letter in the Veterinary Record reports.\n\nA Defra spokesman said the movement restrictions would only be lifted\nwhen Animal Health was confident that the flock is free from TB. He\nsaid _M. bovis_ in sheep was 'considered rare'.\n\nThe Department has also revealed that 'lesions consistent with TB'\nhave been identified in a feral wild boar in the Ross-on-Wye area\nduring post-mortem examination by the Veterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA).\n\nDefra figures show there were over 140 bTB cases identified in\nindividual animals other than cattle in 2009, including in 68\nalpacas, 26 cats, 23 pigs, and 5 sheep. The true numbers are almost\ncertainly much higher as there is no active surveillance in non-bovine species.\n\nDefra said most other species 'generally act only as spillover hosts'\nfrom cattle and badgers with disease not sustained within populations\nwithout an external source of infection.\n\nNational Sheep Association chief executive Peter Morris said cases in\nsheep were 'not unexpected' and that the industry was not required to\ntake additional actions.\n\n[Byline: Alistair Driver]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In view of the rarity of clinical bTB in sheep and differential\ndiagnostic considerations, it has been found worthwhile to reproduce\nthe full text of the letter published in the Veterinary Record of 6\nMar 2010 (166:306):\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ causing clinical disease in adult sheep\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nI would like to report an outbreak of clinical tuberculosis (TB) in a\nflock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire.\n\nChronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one ram was investigated by\nthe flock's private veterinary surgeon. Field postmortem examinations\nof 2 ewes revealed enlarged, abscessed, mediastinal lymph nodes, but\nroutine cultures remained sterile. Serological follow-up did not\nreveal any evidence of caseous lymphadenitis (CLA) [a rather common\novine infection caused by _Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis_. -\nMod.AS] The absence of a diagnosis prompted the submission of 6 sheep\nthat had shown chronic weight loss to the Veterinary Laboratories\nAgency (VLA) for postmortem examination.\n\nGross postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10 (the predominant strain of\nthe bacterium in local cattle herds and wildlife) was subsequently\nisolated. Lesions in these 3 sheep were extensive and affected the\nlungs, lymph nodes, and viscera.\n\nClinical signs and postmortem findings of TB in sheep may resemble\nlesions of visceral CLA. Failure to demonstrate serological or\nbacteriological evidence in cases of suspect CLA should trigger a\nsuspicion of possible TB. Colleagues are reminded that suspect cases\nof TB detected in farm animals are notifiable to Animal Health. The\nsmall number of previous incidents of _M. bovis_ infection in sheep\nin Great Britain have been incidental findings at slaughter or at\npostmortem examination, but have not been associated with clinical\nsigns. The VLA plans to provide more details of this incident in the\nnear future.\n\nGuda van der Burgt\nVLA - Luddington\nLuddington, Stratford upon Avon\nWarwickshire CV37 9SJ\nUK\n<g.vanderburgt@vla.defra.gsi.gov.uk>\n\nbTB can obviously infect also dairy sheep. It will be interesting to\nnote the response of public health authorities and the Food Standards\nAgency in Britain to the described development and the continued\nspread of _M. bovis_ within the UK animal domain. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the UK is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01aS>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): badger vaccination 20090707.2443\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (Wales) 20090323.1143\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (Wales) 20090107.0066\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\n...................................arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10, the predominant strain in\nlocal cattle herds and wildlife, was subsequently isolated. Lesions\nin these 3 sheep were 'extensive', a letter in the Veterinary Record reports.\n\nA Defra spokesman said the movement restrictions would only be lifted\nwhen Animal Health was confident that the flock is free from TB. He\nsaid _M. bovis_ in sheep was 'considered rare'.\n\nThe Department has also revealed that 'lesions consistent with TB'\nhave been identified in a feral wild boar in the Ross-on-Wye area\nduring post-mortem examination by the Veterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA).\n\nDefra figures show there were over 140 bTB cases identified in\nindividual animals other than cattle in 2009, including in 68\nalpacas, 26 cats, 23 pigs, and 5 sheep. The true numbers are almost\ncertainly much higher as there is no active surveillance in non-bovine species.\n\nDefra said most other species 'generally act only as spillover hosts'\nfrom cattle and badgers with disease not sustained within populations\nwithout an external source of infection.\n\nNational Sheep Association chief executive Peter Morris said cases in\nsheep were 'not unexpected' and that the industry was not required to\ntake additional actions.\n\n[Byline: Alistair Driver]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In view of the rarity of clinical bTB in sheep and differential\ndiagnostic considerations, it has been found worthwhile to reproduce\nthe full text of the letter published in the Veterinary Record of 6\nMar 2010 (166:306):\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ causing clinical disease in adult sheep\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nI would like to report an outbreak of clinical tuberculosis (TB) in a\nflock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire.\n\nChronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one ram was investigated by\nthe flock's private veterinary surgeon. Field postmortem examinations\nof 2 ewes revealed enlarged, abscessed, mediastinal lymph nodes, but\nroutine cultures remained sterile. Serological follow-up did not\nreveal any evidence of caseous lymphadenitis (CLA) [a rather common\novine infection caused by _Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis_. -\nMod.AS] The absence of a diagnosis prompted the submission of 6 sheep\nthat had shown chronic weight loss to the Veterinary Laboratories\nAgency (VLA) for postmortem examination.\n\nGross postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10 (the predominant strain of\nthe bacterium in local cattle herds and wildlife) was subsequently\nisolated. Lesions in these 3 sheep were extensive and affected the\nlungs, lymph nodes, and viscera.\n\nClinical signs and postmortem findings of TB in sheep may resemble\nlesions of visceral CLA. Failure to demonstrate serological or\nbacteriological evidence in cases of suspect CLA should trigger a\nsuspicion of possible TB. Colleagues are reminded that suspect cases\nof TB detected in farm animals are notifiable to Animal Health. The\nsmall number of previous incidents of _M. bovis_ infection in sheep\nin Great Britain have been incidental findings at slaughter or at\npostmortem examination, but have not been associated with clinical\nsigns. The VLA plans to provide more details of this incident in the\nnear future.\n\nGuda van der Burgt\nVLA - Luddington\nLuddington, Stratford upon Avon\nWarwickshire CV37 9SJ\nUK\n<g.vanderburgt@vla.defra.gsi.gov.uk>\n\nbTB can obviously infect also dairy sheep. It will be interesting to\nnote the response of public health authorities and the Food Standards\nAgency in Britain to the described development and the continued\nspread of _M. bovis_ within the UK animal domain. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the UK is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01aS>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): badger vaccination 20090707.2443\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (Wales) 20090323.1143\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (Wales) 20090107.0066\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\n...................................arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
