For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Great Britain", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Gloucestershire", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lleyn", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Veterinary Record of", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "407606", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=407606", "date": "2010-03-19 16:00:02", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: (ENGLAND) SHEEP\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Mar 2010\nSource: Farmers Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.farmersguardian.com/home/livestock/livestock-news/bovine-tb-found-in-sheep-and-wild-boar/30961.article>\n\n\nBovine TB found in sheep and wild boar\n--------------------------------------\nConcerns that bTB [bovine tuberculosis] is becoming increasingly\nprevalent in species other than cattle and badgers have been\nheightened by the discovery of the disease in sheep and wild boar.\n\nIt has emerged that a flock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire has\nbeen placed under TB restriction.\n\nVets were alerted by chronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one\nram. Postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10, the predominant strain in\nlocal cattle herds and wildlife, was subsequently isolated. Lesions\nin these 3 sheep were 'extensive', a letter in the Veterinary Record reports.\n\nA Defra spokesman said the movement restrictions would only be lifted\nwhen Animal Health was confident that the flock is free from TB. He\nsaid _M. bovis_ in sheep was 'considered rare'.\n\nThe Department has also revealed that 'lesions consistent with TB'\nhave been identified in a feral wild boar in the Ross-on-Wye area\nduring post-mortem examination by the Veterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA).\n\nDefra figures show there were over 140 bTB cases identified in\nindividual animals other than cattle in 2009, including in 68\nalpacas, 26 cats, 23 pigs, and 5 sheep. The true numbers are almost\ncertainly much higher as there is no active surveillance in non-bovine species.\n\nDefra said most other species 'generally act only as spillover hosts'\nfrom cattle and badgers with disease not sustained within populations\nwithout an external source of infection.\n\nNational Sheep Association chief executive Peter Morris said cases in\nsheep were 'not unexpected' and that the industry was not required to\ntake additional actions.\n\n[Byline: Alistair Driver]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In view of the rarity of clinical bTB in sheep and differential\ndiagnostic considerations, it has been found worthwhile to reproduce\nthe full text of the letter published in the Veterinary Record of 6\nMar 2010 (166:306):\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ causing clinical disease in adult sheep\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nI would like to report an outbreak of clinical tuberculosis (TB) in a\nflock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire.\n\nChronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one ram was investigated by\nthe flock's private veterinary surgeon. Field postmortem examinations\nof 2 ewes revealed enlarged, abscessed, mediastinal lymph nodes, but\nroutine cultures remained sterile. Serological follow-up did not\nreveal any evidence of caseous lymphadenitis (CLA) [a rather common\novine infection caused by _Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis_. -\nMod.AS] The absence of a diagnosis prompted the submission of 6 sheep\nthat had shown chronic weight loss to the Veterinary Laboratories\nAgency (VLA) for postmortem examination.\n\nGross postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10 (the predominant strain of\nthe bacterium in local cattle herds and wildlife) was subsequently\nisolated. Lesions in these 3 sheep were extensive and affected the\nlungs, lymph nodes, and viscera.\n\nClinical signs and postmortem findings of TB in sheep may resemble\nlesions of visceral CLA. Failure to demonstrate serological or\nbacteriological evidence in cases of suspect CLA should trigger a\nsuspicion of possible TB. Colleagues are reminded that suspect cases\nof TB detected in farm animals are notifiable to Animal Health. The\nsmall number of previous incidents of _M. bovis_ infection in sheep\nin Great Britain have been incidental findings at slaughter or at\npostmortem examination, but have not been associated with clinical\nsigns. The VLA plans to provide more details of this incident in the\nnear future.\n\nGuda van der Burgt\nVLA - Luddington\nLuddington, Stratford upon Avon\nWarwickshire CV37 9SJ\nUK\n<g.vanderburgt@vla.defra.gsi.gov.uk>\n\nbTB can obviously infect also dairy sheep. It will be interesting to\nnote the response of public health authorities and the Food Standards\nAgency in Britain to the described development and the continued\nspread of _M. bovis_ within the UK animal domain. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the UK is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01aS>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): badger vaccination 20090707.2443\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (Wales) 20090323.1143\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (Wales) 20090107.0066\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\n...................................arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Great Britain", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Gloucestershire", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lleyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Veterinary Record of", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "401184", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=401184", "date": "2010-03-19 16:00:02", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS - UK: (ENGLAND) SHEEP\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Mar 2010\nSource: Farmers Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.farmersguardian.com/home/livestock/livestock-news/bovine-tb-found-in-sheep-and-wild-boar/30961.article>\n\n\nBovine TB found in sheep and wild boar\n--------------------------------------\nConcerns that bTB [bovine tuberculosis] is becoming increasingly\nprevalent in species other than cattle and badgers have been\nheightened by the discovery of the disease in sheep and wild boar.\n\nIt has emerged that a flock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire has\nbeen placed under TB restriction.\n\nVets were alerted by chronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one\nram. Postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10, the predominant strain in\nlocal cattle herds and wildlife, was subsequently isolated. Lesions\nin these 3 sheep were 'extensive', a letter in the Veterinary Record reports.\n\nA Defra spokesman said the movement restrictions would only be lifted\nwhen Animal Health was confident that the flock is free from TB. He\nsaid _M. bovis_ in sheep was 'considered rare'.\n\nThe Department has also revealed that 'lesions consistent with TB'\nhave been identified in a feral wild boar in the Ross-on-Wye area\nduring post-mortem examination by the Veterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA).\n\nDefra figures show there were over 140 bTB cases identified in\nindividual animals other than cattle in 2009, including in 68\nalpacas, 26 cats, 23 pigs, and 5 sheep. The true numbers are almost\ncertainly much higher as there is no active surveillance in non-bovine species.\n\nDefra said most other species 'generally act only as spillover hosts'\nfrom cattle and badgers with disease not sustained within populations\nwithout an external source of infection.\n\nNational Sheep Association chief executive Peter Morris said cases in\nsheep were 'not unexpected' and that the industry was not required to\ntake additional actions.\n\n[Byline: Alistair Driver]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[In view of the rarity of clinical bTB in sheep and differential\ndiagnostic considerations, it has been found worthwhile to reproduce\nthe full text of the letter published in the Veterinary Record of 6\nMar 2010 (166:306):\n\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ causing clinical disease in adult sheep\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nI would like to report an outbreak of clinical tuberculosis (TB) in a\nflock of Lleyn sheep in Gloucestershire.\n\nChronic weight loss in 20 of 220 ewes and one ram was investigated by\nthe flock's private veterinary surgeon. Field postmortem examinations\nof 2 ewes revealed enlarged, abscessed, mediastinal lymph nodes, but\nroutine cultures remained sterile. Serological follow-up did not\nreveal any evidence of caseous lymphadenitis (CLA) [a rather common\novine infection caused by _Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis_. -\nMod.AS] The absence of a diagnosis prompted the submission of 6 sheep\nthat had shown chronic weight loss to the Veterinary Laboratories\nAgency (VLA) for postmortem examination.\n\nGross postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10 (the predominant strain of\nthe bacterium in local cattle herds and wildlife) was subsequently\nisolated. Lesions in these 3 sheep were extensive and affected the\nlungs, lymph nodes, and viscera.\n\nClinical signs and postmortem findings of TB in sheep may resemble\nlesions of visceral CLA. Failure to demonstrate serological or\nbacteriological evidence in cases of suspect CLA should trigger a\nsuspicion of possible TB. Colleagues are reminded that suspect cases\nof TB detected in farm animals are notifiable to Animal Health. The\nsmall number of previous incidents of _M. bovis_ infection in sheep\nin Great Britain have been incidental findings at slaughter or at\npostmortem examination, but have not been associated with clinical\nsigns. The VLA plans to provide more details of this incident in the\nnear future.\n\nGuda van der Burgt\nVLA - Luddington\nLuddington, Stratford upon Avon\nWarwickshire CV37 9SJ\nUK\n<g.vanderburgt@vla.defra.gsi.gov.uk>\n\nbTB can obviously infect also dairy sheep. It will be interesting to\nnote the response of public health authorities and the Food Standards\nAgency in Britain to the described development and the continued\nspread of _M. bovis_ within the UK animal domain. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the UK is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01aS>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK: (England) 20090808.2815\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (05): (England) alpaca 20090730.2667\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): badger vaccination 20090707.2443\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (Wales) 20090323.1143\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (Wales) 20090107.0066\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\n...................................arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. He\nsaid _M. bovis_ in sheep was 'considered rare'.\n\nThe Department has also revealed that 'lesions consistent with TB'\nhave been identified in a feral wild boar in the Ross-on-Wye area\nduring post-mortem examination by the Veterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA).\n\nDefra figures show there were over 140 bTB cases identified in\nindividual animals other than cattle in 2009, including in 68\nalpacas, 26 cats, 23 pigs, and 5 sheep. Field postmortem examinations\nof 2 ewes revealed enlarged, abscessed, mediastinal lymph nodes, but\nroutine cultures remained sterile. Serological follow-up did not\nreveal any evidence of caseous lymphadenitis (CLA) [a rather common\novine infection caused by _Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis_. -\nMod.AS] The absence of a diagnosis prompted the submission of 6 sheep\nthat had shown chronic weight loss to the Veterinary Laboratories\nAgency (VLA) for postmortem examination.\n\nGross postmortem findings in 3 of the 6 sheep were consistent with TB\nand _Mycobacterium bovis_ spoligotype 10 (the predominant strain of\nthe bacterium in local cattle herds and wildlife) was subsequently\nisolated. The\nsmall number of previous incidents of _M. bovis_ infection in sheep\nin Great Britain have been incidental findings at slaughter or at\npostmortem examination, but have not been associated with clinical\nsigns. Around 30 staff at the\nFood and Environment Research Agency (FERA) in Gloucestershire are\nalso being tested for the disease.\n\nThe staff are all involved in looking into the spread of bovine TB\nfor DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs). Dr\nAlison Wilson, head of executive support at FERA, confirmed the\nhealth of a member of staff was under investigation. She said: \"We\ncan confirm that a member of staff is being investigated for a\nsuspected mycobacterial infection. Some of FERA's staff work on\nlong-term wildlife research projects looking at the relationship\nbetween badgers and cattle in the spread of bovine TB. FERA is\ntherefore treating the case seriously, as it may represent infection\nby _Mycobacterium bovis_, the organism which causes bovine TB.\" She\nalso confirmed 30 staff were being tested for the disease.\n\nDr Wilson said: \"This is the 1st instance of suspected bovine TB\namong staff at the agency, which has been working in this research\narea for more than 30 years. \"The risk of contracting the disease\nfrom this type of work remains very low. The risk to the health of\nthe public remains very low.\" Last year [2008] a former veterinary\nnurse, from Cornwall, and her dog contracted bTB [bovine\ntuberculosis] [see ProMED-mail post Bovine tuberculosis, human,\ncanine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054]. A paper on the case,\npublished in medical journal Thorax, concluded that the woman could\nhave been infected by cattle while working as a veterinary nurse or\nbadgers 'both on her property and as part of her previous work.' The\npaper warned of a 'low, but ongoing, public health risk' where bTB is\nprevalent in cattle and badgers.\n\nAccording to DEFRA the number of cases of human infection with bTB\nwas 'low and stable' and accounted for less than 1 percent of all\nconfirmed cases of TB in humans.\n\n[Byline: William Surman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nH Jones and Sons\n<ajones@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n\n[_Mycobacterium bovis_ (Mb) is a member of the \"_Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ complex,\" along with other genetically closely related\nspecies: _ Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ (Mtb), the BCG bacillus, _M.\nafricanum_, _M. caprae_, _M. microti_, and M. canetti. Mtb is the\nusual cause of tuberculosis in humans and Mb is the usual cause of\nbovine tuberculosis. Although the disease caused by Mb is commonly\ncalled bovine tuberculosis, Mb has a broad host range that includes\nhumans, cattle, pigs, goats, cats, dogs, badgers, foxes, marsupials,\nrabbits, sheep, horses, and deer. BCG is the attenuated bacillus\nCalmette-Guerin vaccine strain derived from a virulent Mb strain that\nhas been used as a vaccine against tuberculosis and increasingly as\ncancer immunotherapy. _M. microti_ has been reported to infect small\nrodents like voles and more recently also humans. _M. canettii_ and\n_M. africanum_ both cause human tuberculosis, mainly in Africa.\n\nHumans are generally infected with Mb by eating or drinking\ncontaminated, unpasteurized (raw) milk products from areas where Mb\nis present in cattle. Mb can also be spread through the air when a\nperson with the disease in their lungs coughs or sneezes. Mb is\ninherently resistant to pyrazinamide (PZA), a drug that is an\nessential component of the standard multidrug short-course regimen to\ntreat human tuberculosis due to drug-susceptible Mtb. Differentiation\nof Mb from Mtb is therefore important clinically as well as\nepidemiologically. The standard gene probe used in clinical\nmicrobiology labs just identifies the \"_M. tuberculosis_ complex\". Mb\ncan be distinguished rapidly from Mtb by spoligotyping (spacer\noligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based\namplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome. Other tests,\nsuch as growth in selective media, specific biochemical reactions,\nand resistance to pyrazinamide, are more time consuming.\n\nHuman infection caused by Mb has been mostly, but not completely,\neradicated in the developed world by the use of pasteurization of\nmilk and culling of cattle shown positive on skin testing, which was\nstarted in about 1917 in the USA. Mb infection in humans continues to\nbe reported in the USA, primarily in immigrants who acquired the\ninfection in their countries of origin where Mb infection remains\nendemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of\ningesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk of Mb-infected\ncows and smuggled across the Mexico-US border (see Levison ME.\n_Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis\nRep 2008, 10:444-446). In the U.K. in recent years, bovine TB in\ncattle has been on the rise, a trend that some blame on badgers\nspreading the infection.\n\nAs stated in the news release above, last year a woman from Cornwall,\nEngland was believed to have developed pulmonary tuberculosis due to\nMb that was acquired either from cattle while working as a veterinary\nnurse or from badgers in her garden; her dog was also infected with\nMb [see ProMED-mail post Bovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK:\n(England) (02) 20080927.3054]. To cause her pulmonary tuberculosis,\nshe would have had to inhale an infectious aerosol of Mb. As stated\nin the ProMED moderator's comments at the time, of the 3 possible\nsources -- cattle, her dog, or the badgers in her garden -- the\nbadgers would seem to be the least likely source, unless grass or\nsoil contaminated by the badgers was aersolized, for example, by\nmowing. It is doubtful that she \"inhaled\" aerosolized urine from\ninfected badgers after touching grass or soil. It seems she more\nlikely had exposure to aerosolized respiratory secretions of infected\ncattle she may have taken care of or her dog. How the government lab\nworker acquired bovine TB from an infected badger is not specified in\nthe above news release.\n\nA map of British counties can be found at:\n<http://badc.nerc.ac.uk/search/midas_stations/traditional_counties_map.gif>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): badger vaccination 20090707.2443\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, New Zealand: vaccination 20090325.1160\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (Wales) 20090323.1143\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (02) 20090320.1121\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (Wales) 20090107.0066\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (03): 2005-2006 20081114.3594\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK 20080718.2186\nTuberculosis, bovine - Netherlands ex UK: EU consultation 20080909.2813\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (02) 20061011.2915\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\n2004\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England): wildlife 20040717.1941\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20040216.0513\n2003\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20031105.2745\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20031021.2647\n....................ml/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thorax", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cornwall", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.K.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mtb", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "373797", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, drug resistance - Marshall Islands: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=373797", "date": "2009-08-08 20:00:06", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - UK: (England)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 August 2009\nSource: Farmers Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.farmersguardian.com/dozens-of-btb-researchers-tested-for-disease/27105.article>\n\n\nA government lab worker is suspected of having contracted bovine\ntuberculosis (TB) from an infected badger. Around 30 staff at the\nFood and Environment Research Agency (FERA) in Gloucestershire are\nalso being tested for the disease.\n\nThe staff are all involved in looking into the spread of bovine TB\nfor DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs). Dr\nAlison Wilson, head of executive support at FERA, confirmed the\nhealth of a member of staff was under investigation. She said: \"We\ncan confirm that a member of staff is being investigated for a\nsuspected mycobacterial infection. Some of FERA's staff work on\nlong-term wildlife research projects looking at the relationship\nbetween badgers and cattle in the spread of bovine TB. FERA is\ntherefore treating the case seriously, as it may represent infection\nby _Mycobacterium bovis_, the organism which causes bovine TB.\" She\nalso confirmed 30 staff were being tested for the disease.\n\nDr Wilson said: \"This is the 1st instance of suspected bovine TB\namong staff at the agency, which has been working in this research\narea for more than 30 years. \"The risk of contracting the disease\nfrom this type of work remains very low. The risk to the health of\nthe public remains very low.\" Last year [2008] a former veterinary\nnurse, from Cornwall, and her dog contracted bTB [bovine\ntuberculosis] [see ProMED-mail post Bovine tuberculosis, human,\ncanine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054]. A paper on the case,\npublished in medical journal Thorax, concluded that the woman could\nhave been infected by cattle while working as a veterinary nurse or\nbadgers 'both on her property and as part of her previous work.' The standard gene probe used in clinical\nmicrobiology labs just identifies the \"_M. tuberculosis_ complex\". Mb\ncan be distinguished rapidly from Mtb by spoligotyping (spacer\noligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based\namplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome. Other tests,\nsuch as growth in selective media, specific biochemical reactions,\nand resistance to pyrazinamide, are more time consuming.\n\nHuman infection caused by Mb has been mostly, but not completely,\neradicated in the developed world by the use of pasteurization of\nmilk and culling of cattle shown positive on skin testing, which was\nstarted in about 1917 in the USA. To cause her pulmonary tuberculosis,\nshe would have had to inhale an infectious aerosol of Mb. As stated\nin the ProMED moderator's comments at the time, of the 3 possible\nsources -- cattle, her dog, or the badgers in her garden -- the\nbadgers would seem to be the least likely source, unless grass or\nsoil contaminated by the badgers was aersolized, for example, by\nmowing. It is doubtful that she \"inhaled\" aerosolized urine from\ninfected badgers after touching grass or soil. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thorax", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cornwall", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.K.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mtb", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "358009", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XXDR - USA: FL ex Peru", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=358009", "date": "2009-08-08 20:00:06", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - UK: (England)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 August 2009\nSource: Farmers Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.farmersguardian.com/dozens-of-btb-researchers-tested-for-disease/27105.article>\n\n\nA government lab worker is suspected of having contracted bovine\ntuberculosis (TB) from an infected badger. Around 30 staff at the\nFood and Environment Research Agency (FERA) in Gloucestershire are\nalso being tested for the disease.\n\nThe staff are all involved in looking into the spread of bovine TB\nfor DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs). Dr\nAlison Wilson, head of executive support at FERA, confirmed the\nhealth of a member of staff was under investigation. She said: \"We\ncan confirm that a member of staff is being investigated for a\nsuspected mycobacterial infection. Some of FERA's staff work on\nlong-term wildlife research projects looking at the relationship\nbetween badgers and cattle in the spread of bovine TB. FERA is\ntherefore treating the case seriously, as it may represent infection\nby _Mycobacterium bovis_, the organism which causes bovine TB.\" She\nalso confirmed 30 staff were being tested for the disease.\n\nDr Wilson said: \"This is the 1st instance of suspected bovine TB\namong staff at the agency, which has been working in this research\narea for more than 30 years. \"The risk of contracting the disease\nfrom this type of work remains very low. The risk to the health of\nthe public remains very low.\" Last year [2008] a former veterinary\nnurse, from Cornwall, and her dog contracted bTB [bovine\ntuberculosis] [see ProMED-mail post Bovine tuberculosis, human,\ncanine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054]. A paper on the case,\npublished in medical journal Thorax, concluded that the woman could\nhave been infected by cattle while working as a veterinary nurse or\nbadgers 'both on her property and as part of her previous work.' The\npaper warned of a 'low, but ongoing, public health risk' where bTB is\nprevalent in cattle and badgers.\n\nAccording to DEFRA the number of cases of human infection with bTB\nwas 'low and stable' and accounted for less than 1 percent of all\nconfirmed cases of TB in humans.\n\n[Byline: William Surman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nH Jones and Sons\n<ajones@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n\n[_Mycobacterium bovis_ (Mb) is a member of the \"_Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ complex,\" along with other genetically closely related\nspecies: _ Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ (Mtb), the BCG bacillus, _M.\nafricanum_, _M. caprae_, _M. microti_, and M. canetti. Mtb is the\nusual cause of tuberculosis in humans and Mb is the usual cause of\nbovine tuberculosis. Although the disease caused by Mb is commonly\ncalled bovine tuberculosis, Mb has a broad host range that includes\nhumans, cattle, pigs, goats, cats, dogs, badgers, foxes, marsupials,\nrabbits, sheep, horses, and deer. BCG is the attenuated bacillus\nCalmette-Guerin vaccine strain derived from a virulent Mb strain that\nhas been used as a vaccine against tuberculosis and increasingly as\ncancer immunotherapy. _M. microti_ has been reported to infect small\nrodents like voles and more recently also humans. _M. canettii_ and\n_M. africanum_ both cause human tuberculosis, mainly in Africa.\n\nHumans are generally infected with Mb by eating or drinking\ncontaminated, unpasteurized (raw) milk products from areas where Mb\nis present in cattle. Mb can also be spread through the air when a\nperson with the disease in their lungs coughs or sneezes. Mb is\ninherently resistant to pyrazinamide (PZA), a drug that is an\nessential component of the standard multidrug short-course regimen to\ntreat human tuberculosis due to drug-susceptible Mtb. Differentiation\nof Mb from Mtb is therefore important clinically as well as\nepidemiologically. The standard gene probe used in clinical\nmicrobiology labs just identifies the \"_M. tuberculosis_ complex\". Mb\ncan be distinguished rapidly from Mtb by spoligotyping (spacer\noligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based\namplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome. Other tests,\nsuch as growth in selective media, specific biochemical reactions,\nand resistance to pyrazinamide, are more time consuming.\n\nHuman infection caused by Mb has been mostly, but not completely,\neradicated in the developed world by the use of pasteurization of\nmilk and culling of cattle shown positive on skin testing, which was\nstarted in about 1917 in the USA. Mb infection in humans continues to\nbe reported in the USA, primarily in immigrants who acquired the\ninfection in their countries of origin where Mb infection remains\nendemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of\ningesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk of Mb-infected\ncows and smuggled across the Mexico-US border (see Levison ME.\n_Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis\nRep 2008, 10:444-446). In the U.K. in recent years, bovine TB in\ncattle has been on the rise, a trend that some blame on badgers\nspreading the infection.\n\nAs stated in the news release above, last year a woman from Cornwall,\nEngland was believed to have developed pulmonary tuberculosis due to\nMb that was acquired either from cattle while working as a veterinary\nnurse or from badgers in her garden; her dog was also infected with\nMb [see ProMED-mail post Bovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK:\n(England) (02) 20080927.3054]. To cause her pulmonary tuberculosis,\nshe would have had to inhale an infectious aerosol of Mb. As stated\nin the ProMED moderator's comments at the time, of the 3 possible\nsources -- cattle, her dog, or the badgers in her garden -- the\nbadgers would seem to be the least likely source, unless grass or\nsoil contaminated by the badgers was aersolized, for example, by\nmowing. It is doubtful that she \"inhaled\" aerosolized urine from\ninfected badgers after touching grass or soil. It seems she more\nlikely had exposure to aerosolized respiratory secretions of infected\ncattle she may have taken care of or her dog. How the government lab\nworker acquired bovine TB from an infected badger is not specified in\nthe above news release.\n\nA map of British counties can be found at:\n<http://badc.nerc.ac.uk/search/midas_stations/traditional_counties_map.gif>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): badger vaccination 20090707.2443\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, New Zealand: vaccination 20090325.1160\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (Wales) 20090323.1143\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (02) 20090320.1121\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (Wales) 20090107.0066\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (03): 2005-2006 20081114.3594\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK 20080718.2186\nTuberculosis, bovine - Netherlands ex UK: EU consultation 20080909.2813\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (02) 20061011.2915\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\n2004\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England): wildlife 20040717.1941\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20040216.0513\n2003\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20031105.2745\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20031021.2647\n....................ml/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Around 30 staff at the\nFood and Environment Research Agency (FERA) in Gloucestershire are\nalso being tested for the disease.\n\nThe staff are all involved in looking into the spread of bovine TB\nfor DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs). Mb infection in humans continues to\nbe reported in the USA, primarily in immigrants who acquired the\ninfection in their countries of origin where Mb infection remains\nendemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of\ningesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk of Mb-infected\ncows and smuggled across the Mexico-US border (see Levison ME.\n_Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis\nRep 2008, 10:444-446). In the U.K. in recent years, bovine TB in\ncattle has been on the rise, a trend that some blame on badgers\nspreading the infection.\n\nAs stated in the news release above, last year a woman from Cornwall,\nEngland was believed to have developed pulmonary tuberculosis due to\nMb that was acquired either from cattle while working as a veterinary\nnurse or from badgers in her garden; her dog was also infected with\nMb [see ProMED-mail post Bovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK:\n(England) (02) 20080927.3054]. To cause her pulmonary tuberculosis,\nshe would have had to inhale an infectious aerosol of Mb. As stated\nin the ProMED moderator's comments at the time, of the 3 possible\nsources -- cattle, her dog, or the badgers in her garden -- the\nbadgers would seem to be the least likely source, unless grass or\nsoil contaminated by the badgers was aersolized, for example, by\nmowing. It is doubtful that she \"inhaled\" aerosolized urine from\ninfected badgers after touching grass or soil. It seems she more\nlikely had exposure to aerosolized respiratory secretions of infected\ncattle she may have taken care of or her dog. How the government lab\nworker acquired bovine TB from an infected badger is not specified in\nthe above news release.\n\nA map of British counties can be found at:\n<http://badc.nerc.ac.uk/search/midas_stations/traditional_counties_map.gif>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (04): badger vaccination 20090707.2443\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, New Zealand: vaccination 20090325.1160\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (02): (Wales) 20090323.1143\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (02) 20090320.1121\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: (Wales) 20090107.0066\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (03): 2005-2006 20081114.3594\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK 20080718.2186\nTuberculosis, bovine - Netherlands ex UK: EU consultation 20080909.2813\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thorax", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cornwall", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.K.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mtb", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "314904", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - Canada: (MB) cervid", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=314904", "date": "2009-08-08 20:00:06", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, HUMAN - UK: (England)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 August 2009\nSource: Farmers Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.farmersguardian.com/dozens-of-btb-researchers-tested-for-disease/27105.article>\n\n\nA government lab worker is suspected of having contracted bovine\ntuberculosis (TB) from an infected badger. Around 30 staff at the\nFood and Environment Research Agency (FERA) in Gloucestershire are\nalso being tested for the disease.\n\nThe staff are all involved in looking into the spread of bovine TB\nfor DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs). Dr\nAlison Wilson, head of executive support at FERA, confirmed the\nhealth of a member of staff was under investigation. She said: \"We\ncan confirm that a member of staff is being investigated for a\nsuspected mycobacterial infection. Some of FERA's staff work on\nlong-term wildlife research projects looking at the relationship\nbetween badgers and cattle in the spread of bovine TB. FERA is\ntherefore treating the case seriously, as it may represent infection\nby _Mycobacterium bovis_, the organism which causes bovine TB.\" She\nalso confirmed 30 staff were being tested for the disease.\n\nDr Wilson said: \"This is the 1st instance of suspected bovine TB\namong staff at the agency, which has been working in this research\narea for more than 30 years. \"The risk of contracting the disease\nfrom this type of work remains very low. The risk to the health of\nthe public remains very low.\" Last year [2008] a former veterinary\nnurse, from Cornwall, and her dog contracted bTB [bovine\ntuberculosis] [see ProMED-mail post Bovine tuberculosis, human,\ncanine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054]. A paper on the case,\npublished in medical journal Thorax, concluded that the woman could\nhave been infected by cattle while working as a veterinary nurse or\nbadgers 'both on her property and as part of her previous work.' The\npaper warned of a 'low, but ongoing, public health risk' where bTB is\nprevalent in cattle and badgers.\n\nAccording to DEFRA the number of cases of human infection with bTB\nwas 'low and stable' and accounted for less than 1 percent of all\nconfirmed cases of TB in humans.\n\n[Byline: William Surman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nH Jones and Sons\n<ajones@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n\n[_Mycobacterium bovis_ (Mb) is a member of the \"_Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ complex,\" along with other genetically closely related\nspecies: _ Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ (Mtb), the BCG bacillus, _M.\nafricanum_, _M. caprae_, _M. microti_, and M. canetti. Mtb is the\nusual cause of tuberculosis in humans and Mb is the usual cause of\nbovine tuberculosis. Although the disease caused by Mb is commonly\ncalled bovine tuberculosis, Mb has a broad host range that includes\nhumans, cattle, pigs, goats, cats, dogs, badgers, foxes, marsupials,\nrabbits, sheep, horses, and deer. BCG is the attenuated bacillus\nCalmette-Guerin vaccine strain derived from a virulent Mb strain that\nhas been used as a vaccine against tuberculosis and increasingly as\ncancer immunotherapy. _M. microti_ has been reported to infect small\nrodents like voles and more recently also humans. _M. canettii_ and\n_M. africanum_ both cause human tuberculosis, mainly in Africa.\n\nHumans are generally infected with Mb by eating or drinking\ncontaminated, unpasteurized (raw) milk products from areas where Mb\nis present in cattle. Mb can also be spread through the air when a\nperson with the disease in their lungs coughs or sneezes. Mb is\ninherently resistant to pyrazinamide (PZA), a drug that is an\nessential component of the standard multidrug short-course regimen to\ntreat human tuberculosis due to drug-susceptible Mtb. Differentiation\nof Mb from Mtb is therefore important clinically as well as\nepidemiologically. The standard gene probe used in clinical\nmicrobiology labs just identifies the \"_M. tuberculosis_ complex\". Mb\ncan be distinguished rapidly from Mtb by spoligotyping (spacer\noligonucleotide typing), which is a polymerase chain reaction-based\namplification of a region of the mycobacterial genome. Other tests,\nsuch as growth in selective media, specific biochemical reactions,\nand resistance to pyrazinamide, are more time consuming.\n\nHuman infection caused by Mb has been mostly, but not completely,\neradicated in the developed world by the use of pasteurization of\nmilk and culling of cattle shown positive on skin testing, which was\nstarted in about 1917 in the USA. Mb infection in humans continues to\nbe reported in the USA, primarily in immigrants who acquired the\ninfection in their countries of origin where Mb infection remains\nendemic, or in persons of Hispanic ethnicity as a consequence of\ningesting dairy foods made from unpasteurized milk of Mb-infected\ncows and smuggled across the Mexico-US border (see Levison ME.\n_Mycobacterium bovis_: An Underappreciated Pathogen. Curr Infect Dis\nRep 2008, 10:444-446). In the U.K. in recent years, bovine TB in\ncattle has been on the rise, a trend that some blame on badgers\nspreading the infection.\n\nAs stated in the news release above, last year a woman from Cornwall,\nEngland was believed to have developed pulmonary tuberculosis due to\nMb that was acquired either from cattle while working as a veterinary\nnurse or from badgers in her garden; her dog was also infected with\nMb [see ProMED-mail post Bovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK:\n(England) (02) 20080927.3054]. To cause her pulmonary tuberculosis,\nshe would have had to inhale an infectious aerosol of Mb. As stated\nin the ProMED moderator's comments at the time, of the 3 possible\nsources -- cattle, her dog, or the badgers in her garden -- the\nbadgers would seem to be the least likely source, unless grass or\nsoil contaminated by the badgers was aersolized, for example, by\nmowing. It is doubtful that she \"inhaled\" aerosolized urine from\ninfected badgers after touching grass or soil. It seems she more\nlikely had exposure to aerosolized respiratory secretions of infected\ncattle she may have taken care of or her dog. How the government lab\nworker acquired bovine TB from an infected badger is not specified in\nthe above news release.\n\nA map of British counties can be found at:\n<http://badc.nerc.ac.uk/search/midas_stations/traditional_counties_map.gif>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thorax", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cornwall", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.K.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mtb", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "259568", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (11): (IN) cervid", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=259568", "date": "2009-06-25 11:00:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, CERVIDS - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 23 Jun 2009\nSource: Bemidji Pioneer [edited]\n<http://www.bemidjipioneer.com/event/article/id/24892/>\n\n\nThe discovery of a whitetail deer with bovine tuberculosis [TB] in\nnorthwest Beltrami County doesn't concern state agriculture\nofficials. \"It was kind of expected, and is the reason why we need to\ncontinue monitoring to be sure there's not something out there,\"\nRobin Kinney, Minnesota assistant agriculture commissioner, said in a\nrecent interview.\n\nThe TB-positive deer was a 6-year-old male, and showed clinical signs\nof bovine TB, which later was confirmed by laboratory analysis. No\nother deer removed this winter [2008-09] showed similar signs of\ninfection. \"We fully expected that the deer population was carrying\nsome of this, so to find one is a good sign,\" Kinney said.\n\nThe older deer makes state officials believe that bovine TB among\ndeer may be confined to a certain age class, since the infected deer\nfound since testing began in 2005 have been born in 2005 or earlier.\n\n\"It was an older deer that was found,\" Kinney said. \"That's great,\nand it means that we need to continue that diligence to seek it out.\nI don't expect we're going to have any problems, but that's why we're\nstaying on high alert on it.\"\n\nLast year [208], the US Department of Agriculture allowed Minnesota a\nsplit-state status, meaning that outside a bovine TB management area\nin northwest Beltrami County and Roseau County, the state remains TB-free.\n\nCattle sold within the bovine TB management area must undergo strict\ntesting regimes before being sold or transported across state lines.\n\nCattle are believed to contract bovine TB from infected free-ranging\ndeer, so the DNR [Department of Natural Resources] has been working\nwith USDA sharpshooters during the winter to cull the deer herd in that area.\n\nThe DNR has also conducted surveillance for TB in hunter-harvested\ndeer within a 15-mile [24 km] radius of the once-infected farms every\nfall since 2005. To date, more than 6000 deer taken by hunters and\nsharp-shooters have been tested.\n\n\"The older ages of infected deer, the lack of infection in younger\ndeer, and the close proximity of infected deer suggest the disease is\nnot efficiently spreading in the deer population,\" Michelle\nCarstensen, DNR wildlife health program coordinator, said last month\n[May 2009].\n\nDNR sampled 1246 deer taken in the bovine TB surveillance zone during\nthe fall 2008 hunt. Spring sharp-shooting efforts, that began in\nMarch and concluded 30 Apr [2009], have resulted in an additional 738\ndeer being removed near previously infected cattle operations inside\nthe management zone.\n\nDNR will continue monitoring for the disease through sampling of\nhunter-harvested deer, Carstensen said. Hunter-harvested surveillance\nwill be conducted within the larger bovine TB surveillance zone in\nfall 2009, with a sampling goal of 1800 deer. Surveillance will\ncontinue every year until no positive animals are detected for 5\nconsecutive years, she said.\n\nThe 2008 Legislature, led by Sen. Rod Skoe, DFL-Clearbrook, put in\nplace the bovine TB management zone and provided buyouts of herds\nthat may be infected and ordered fencing around remaining herds to\nkeep out deer.\n\nThe Agriculture Department's bovine TB czar is Joe Martin, appointed\nby Gov. Tim Pawlenty. \"He's done just a great job shepherding this\nthrough and being sure that producers are being taken care of,\" said\nKinney. \"Funding-wise, we've had a great partnership, especially with\nthe legislative folks up here. They understand the issue, they've\nbeen working very closely hand-in-hand with Joe and the DNR to be\nsure we've got that balance.\"\n\n\"This should not delay Minnesota's goal of regaining TB-Free Status,\"\nMartin said last month [May 2009] of the new deer discovery. \"We have\nbeen in contact with USDA and they have assured us this finding in\nthe deer will not impact cattle movements or the state's TB status.\"\n\nThe state's status is only impacted by finding additional TB-positive\ncattle herds. The last known infected herd was depopulated earlier\nthis year [2009] as part of the state's buyout program. There are no\nother active cattle investigations ongoing at this time, Martin said.\n\nThe buyout of herds is complete, Kinney said. \"Money-wise this coming\nyear it's going to be continuing to provide some education and\nmanagement opportunities for as long as these folks are going to need\nto be out, be sure that we're monitoring that deer population so that\nwe can get the status back as quickly as we can.\"\n\nThe issue continues to be a priority of the Minnesota Farm Bureau\nFederation, which lobbied last year [2008] for the special management\nzone and funding for cattle buyouts. \"Bovine TB is still a priority\nfor us in Farm Bureau,\" Minnesota Farm Bureau President Kevin Paap\nsaid in a recent interview. \"We need to do everything and anything we\ncan to eradicate that, both in the cattle and the deer herds. So\nwe'll watch that very closely.\"\n\nMinnesota state agencies and USDA have entered into a productive\npartnership in an effort to eradicate bovine TB, Kinney said. \"We\nhave a very good partnership, and I have say that's to the fact that\nCommissioner (Gene) Hugoson has served so long in a leadership role,\"\nshe said. \"That consistency has been extremely important, not only\nfor Minnesota but for APHIS and the other divisions. He is recognized\nnationally as a leader and has great insight.\" USDA's Animal and\nPublic Health Information System establishes threat levels for animal\ndiseases, and determines levels of bovine TB classifications.\n\nKinney also credited US House Agriculture Chairman Collin Peterson,\nDFL-7th District, in whose district the bovine TB management zone\nlies. \"He just does a tremendous job as an advocate for agriculture,\nand his role as chairman of the House Ag Committee certainly helped\nMinnesota come forward,\" Kinney said. \"We've got great dialogue with him.\"\n\n[Byline: Brad Swenson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[Minnesota has had a long battle with tuberculosis, both in bovines\nand in cervids. They have made gallant strides in getting this\ndisease under control. Their surveillance here is a minor triumph in\nbeing able to predict what the age of expected animals with the\ndisease. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The Midwestern state of Minnesota can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00uq>.\nBeltrami County can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beltrami_County,_Minnesota>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (MN) status downgrade 20080408.1296\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20071029.3509\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03)20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)(02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)20050716.2030\n...................................tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. There are no\nother active cattle investigations ongoing at this time, Martin said.\n\nThe buyout of herds is complete, Kinney said. \"Money-wise this coming\nyear it's going to be continuing to provide some education and\nmanagement opportunities for as long as these folks are going to need\nto be out, be sure that we're monitoring that deer population so that\nwe can get the status back as quickly as we can.\"\n\nThe issue continues to be a priority of the Minnesota Farm Bureau\nFederation, which lobbied last year [2008] for the special management\nzone and funding for cattle buyouts. \"Bovine TB is still a priority\nfor us in Farm Bureau,\" Minnesota Farm Bureau President Kevin Paap\nsaid in a recent interview. \"We need to do everything and anything we\ncan to eradicate that, both in the cattle and the deer herds. So\nwe'll watch that very closely.\"\n\nMinnesota state agencies and USDA have entered into a productive\npartnership in an effort to eradicate bovine TB, Kinney said. \"We\nhave a very good partnership, and I have say that's to the fact that\nCommissioner (Gene) Hugoson has served so long in a leadership role,\"\nshe said. \"That consistency has been extremely important, not only\nfor Minnesota but for APHIS and the other divisions. He is recognized\nnationally as a leader and has great insight.\" USDA's Animal and\nPublic Health Information System establishes threat levels for animal\ndiseases, and determines levels of bovine TB classifications.\n\nKinney also credited US House Agriculture Chairman Collin Peterson,\nDFL-7th District, in whose district the bovine TB management zone\nlies. \"He just does a tremendous job as an advocate for agriculture,\nand his role as chairman of the House Ag Committee certainly helped\nMinnesota come forward,\" Kinney said. \"We've got great dialogue with him.\"\n\n[Byline: Brad Swenson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[Minnesota has had a long battle with tuberculosis, both in bovines\nand in cervids. USA (10): (IN) cervid, bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=241190", "date": "2009-06-25 11:00:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, CERVIDS - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 23 Jun 2009\nSource: Bemidji Pioneer [edited]\n<http://www.bemidjipioneer.com/event/article/id/24892/>\n\n\nThe discovery of a whitetail deer with bovine tuberculosis [TB] in\nnorthwest Beltrami County doesn't concern state agriculture\nofficials. \"It was kind of expected, and is the reason why we need to\ncontinue monitoring to be sure there's not something out there,\"\nRobin Kinney, Minnesota assistant agriculture commissioner, said in a\nrecent interview.\n\nThe TB-positive deer was a 6-year-old male, and showed clinical signs\nof bovine TB, which later was confirmed by laboratory analysis. No\nother deer removed this winter [2008-09] showed similar signs of\ninfection. \"We fully expected that the deer population was carrying\nsome of this, so to find one is a good sign,\" Kinney said.\n\nThe older deer makes state officials believe that bovine TB among\ndeer may be confined to a certain age class, since the infected deer\nfound since testing began in 2005 have been born in 2005 or earlier.\n\n\"It was an older deer that was found,\" Kinney said. \"That's great,\nand it means that we need to continue that diligence to seek it out.\nI don't expect we're going to have any problems, but that's why we're\nstaying on high alert on it.\"\n\nLast year [208], the US Department of Agriculture allowed Minnesota a\nsplit-state status, meaning that outside a bovine TB management area\nin northwest Beltrami County and Roseau County, the state remains TB-free.\n\nCattle sold within the bovine TB management area must undergo strict\ntesting regimes before being sold or transported across state lines.\n\nCattle are believed to contract bovine TB from infected free-ranging\ndeer, so the DNR [Department of Natural Resources] has been working\nwith USDA sharpshooters during the winter to cull the deer herd in that area.\n\nThe DNR has also conducted surveillance for TB in hunter-harvested\ndeer within a 15-mile [24 km] radius of the once-infected farms every\nfall since 2005. To date, more than 6000 deer taken by hunters and\nsharp-shooters have been tested.\n\n\"The older ages of infected deer, the lack of infection in younger\ndeer, and the close proximity of infected deer suggest the disease is\nnot efficiently spreading in the deer population,\" Michelle\nCarstensen, DNR wildlife health program coordinator, said last month\n[May 2009].\n\nDNR sampled 1246 deer taken in the bovine TB surveillance zone during\nthe fall 2008 hunt. Spring sharp-shooting efforts, that began in\nMarch and concluded 30 Apr [2009], have resulted in an additional 738\ndeer being removed near previously infected cattle operations inside\nthe management zone.\n\nDNR will continue monitoring for the disease through sampling of\nhunter-harvested deer, Carstensen said. Hunter-harvested surveillance\nwill be conducted within the larger bovine TB surveillance zone in\nfall 2009, with a sampling goal of 1800 deer. Surveillance will\ncontinue every year until no positive animals are detected for 5\nconsecutive years, she said.\n\nThe 2008 Legislature, led by Sen. Rod Skoe, DFL-Clearbrook, put in\nplace the bovine TB management zone and provided buyouts of herds\nthat may be infected and ordered fencing around remaining herds to\nkeep out deer.\n\nThe Agriculture Department's bovine TB czar is Joe Martin, appointed\nby Gov. Tim Pawlenty. \"He's done just a great job shepherding this\nthrough and being sure that producers are being taken care of,\" said\nKinney. \"Funding-wise, we've had a great partnership, especially with\nthe legislative folks up here. They understand the issue, they've\nbeen working very closely hand-in-hand with Joe and the DNR to be\nsure we've got that balance.\"\n\n\"This should not delay Minnesota's goal of regaining TB-Free Status,\"\nMartin said last month [May 2009] of the new deer discovery. \"We have\nbeen in contact with USDA and they have assured us this finding in\nthe deer will not impact cattle movements or the state's TB status.\"\n\nThe state's status is only impacted by finding additional TB-positive\ncattle herds. The last known infected herd was depopulated earlier\nthis year [2009] as part of the state's buyout program. There are no\nother active cattle investigations ongoing at this time, Martin said.\n\nThe buyout of herds is complete, Kinney said. \"Money-wise this coming\nyear it's going to be continuing to provide some education and\nmanagement opportunities for as long as these folks are going to need\nto be out, be sure that we're monitoring that deer population so that\nwe can get the status back as quickly as we can.\"\n\nThe issue continues to be a priority of the Minnesota Farm Bureau\nFederation, which lobbied last year [2008] for the special management\nzone and funding for cattle buyouts. \"Bovine TB is still a priority\nfor us in Farm Bureau,\" Minnesota Farm Bureau President Kevin Paap\nsaid in a recent interview. \"We need to do everything and anything we\ncan to eradicate that, both in the cattle and the deer herds. So\nwe'll watch that very closely.\"\n\nMinnesota state agencies and USDA have entered into a productive\npartnership in an effort to eradicate bovine TB, Kinney said. \"We\nhave a very good partnership, and I have say that's to the fact that\nCommissioner (Gene) Hugoson has served so long in a leadership role,\"\nshe said. \"That consistency has been extremely important, not only\nfor Minnesota but for APHIS and the other divisions. He is recognized\nnationally as a leader and has great insight.\" USDA's Animal and\nPublic Health Information System establishes threat levels for animal\ndiseases, and determines levels of bovine TB classifications.\n\nKinney also credited US House Agriculture Chairman Collin Peterson,\nDFL-7th District, in whose district the bovine TB management zone\nlies. \"He just does a tremendous job as an advocate for agriculture,\nand his role as chairman of the House Ag Committee certainly helped\nMinnesota come forward,\" Kinney said. \"We've got great dialogue with him.\"\n\n[Byline: Brad Swenson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[Minnesota has had a long battle with tuberculosis, both in bovines\nand in cervids. They have made gallant strides in getting this\ndisease under control. Their surveillance here is a minor triumph in\nbeing able to predict what the age of expected animals with the\ndisease. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The Midwestern state of Minnesota can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00uq>.\nBeltrami County can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beltrami_County,_Minnesota>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (MN) status downgrade 20080408.1296\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20071029.3509\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03)20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)(02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)20050716.2030\n...................................tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
