ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-05-16 00:00:00", "1246-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-05-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beltrami County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Roseau County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DFL-7th District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "241216", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (09): (IN) cervid, bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=241216", "date": "2009-06-25 11:00:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, CERVIDS - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 23 Jun 2009\nSource: Bemidji Pioneer [edited]\n<http://www.bemidjipioneer.com/event/article/id/24892/>\n\n\nThe discovery of a whitetail deer with bovine tuberculosis [TB] in\nnorthwest Beltrami County doesn't concern state agriculture\nofficials. \"It was kind of expected, and is the reason why we need to\ncontinue monitoring to be sure there's not something out there,\"\nRobin Kinney, Minnesota assistant agriculture commissioner, said in a\nrecent interview.\n\nThe TB-positive deer was a 6-year-old male, and showed clinical signs\nof bovine TB, which later was confirmed by laboratory analysis. No\nother deer removed this winter [2008-09] showed similar signs of\ninfection. \"We fully expected that the deer population was carrying\nsome of this, so to find one is a good sign,\" Kinney said.\n\nThe older deer makes state officials believe that bovine TB among\ndeer may be confined to a certain age class, since the infected deer\nfound since testing began in 2005 have been born in 2005 or earlier.\n\n\"It was an older deer that was found,\" Kinney said. \"That's great,\nand it means that we need to continue that diligence to seek it out.\nI don't expect we're going to have any problems, but that's why we're\nstaying on high alert on it.\"\n\nLast year [208], the US Department of Agriculture allowed Minnesota a\nsplit-state status, meaning that outside a bovine TB management area\nin northwest Beltrami County and Roseau County, the state remains TB-free.\n\nCattle sold within the bovine TB management area must undergo strict\ntesting regimes before being sold or transported across state lines.\n\nCattle are believed to contract bovine TB from infected free-ranging\ndeer, so the DNR [Department of Natural Resources] has been working\nwith USDA sharpshooters during the winter to cull the deer herd in that area.\n\nThe DNR has also conducted surveillance for TB in hunter-harvested\ndeer within a 15-mile [24 km] radius of the once-infected farms every\nfall since 2005. To date, more than 6000 deer taken by hunters and\nsharp-shooters have been tested.\n\n\"The older ages of infected deer, the lack of infection in younger\ndeer, and the close proximity of infected deer suggest the disease is\nnot efficiently spreading in the deer population,\" Michelle\nCarstensen, DNR wildlife health program coordinator, said last month\n[May 2009].\n\nDNR sampled 1246 deer taken in the bovine TB surveillance zone during\nthe fall 2008 hunt. Spring sharp-shooting efforts, that began in\nMarch and concluded 30 Apr [2009], have resulted in an additional 738\ndeer being removed near previously infected cattle operations inside\nthe management zone.\n\nDNR will continue monitoring for the disease through sampling of\nhunter-harvested deer, Carstensen said. Hunter-harvested surveillance\nwill be conducted within the larger bovine TB surveillance zone in\nfall 2009, with a sampling goal of 1800 deer. Surveillance will\ncontinue every year until no positive animals are detected for 5\nconsecutive years, she said.\n\nThe 2008 Legislature, led by Sen. Rod Skoe, DFL-Clearbrook, put in\nplace the bovine TB management zone and provided buyouts of herds\nthat may be infected and ordered fencing around remaining herds to\nkeep out deer.\n\nThe Agriculture Department's bovine TB czar is Joe Martin, appointed\nby Gov. Tim Pawlenty. \"He's done just a great job shepherding this\nthrough and being sure that producers are being taken care of,\" said\nKinney. \"Funding-wise, we've had a great partnership, especially with\nthe legislative folks up here. They understand the issue, they've\nbeen working very closely hand-in-hand with Joe and the DNR to be\nsure we've got that balance.\"\n\n\"This should not delay Minnesota's goal of regaining TB-Free Status,\"\nMartin said last month [May 2009] of the new deer discovery. \"We have\nbeen in contact with USDA and they have assured us this finding in\nthe deer will not impact cattle movements or the state's TB status.\"\n\nThe state's status is only impacted by finding additional TB-positive\ncattle herds. The last known infected herd was depopulated earlier\nthis year [2009] as part of the state's buyout program. There are no\nother active cattle investigations ongoing at this time, Martin said.\n\nThe buyout of herds is complete, Kinney said. \"Money-wise this coming\nyear it's going to be continuing to provide some education and\nmanagement opportunities for as long as these folks are going to need\nto be out, be sure that we're monitoring that deer population so that\nwe can get the status back as quickly as we can.\"\n\nThe issue continues to be a priority of the Minnesota Farm Bureau\nFederation, which lobbied last year [2008] for the special management\nzone and funding for cattle buyouts. \"Bovine TB is still a priority\nfor us in Farm Bureau,\" Minnesota Farm Bureau President Kevin Paap\nsaid in a recent interview. \"We need to do everything and anything we\ncan to eradicate that, both in the cattle and the deer herds. So\nwe'll watch that very closely.\"\n\nMinnesota state agencies and USDA have entered into a productive\npartnership in an effort to eradicate bovine TB, Kinney said. \"We\nhave a very good partnership, and I have say that's to the fact that\nCommissioner (Gene) Hugoson has served so long in a leadership role,\"\nshe said. \"That consistency has been extremely important, not only\nfor Minnesota but for APHIS and the other divisions. He is recognized\nnationally as a leader and has great insight.\" USDA's Animal and\nPublic Health Information System establishes threat levels for animal\ndiseases, and determines levels of bovine TB classifications.\n\nKinney also credited US House Agriculture Chairman Collin Peterson,\nDFL-7th District, in whose district the bovine TB management zone\nlies. \"He just does a tremendous job as an advocate for agriculture,\nand his role as chairman of the House Ag Committee certainly helped\nMinnesota come forward,\" Kinney said. \"We've got great dialogue with him.\"\n\n[Byline: Brad Swenson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[Minnesota has had a long battle with tuberculosis, both in bovines\nand in cervids. They have made gallant strides in getting this\ndisease under control. Their surveillance here is a minor triumph in\nbeing able to predict what the age of expected animals with the\ndisease. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The Midwestern state of Minnesota can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00uq>.\nBeltrami County can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beltrami_County,_Minnesota>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (MN) status downgrade 20080408.1296\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20071029.3509\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03)20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)(02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)20050716.2030\n...................................tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. UK (04): badger vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=235958", "date": "2009-06-25 11:00:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, CERVIDS - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 23 Jun 2009\nSource: Bemidji Pioneer [edited]\n<http://www.bemidjipioneer.com/event/article/id/24892/>\n\n\nThe discovery of a whitetail deer with bovine tuberculosis [TB] in\nnorthwest Beltrami County doesn't concern state agriculture\nofficials. \"It was kind of expected, and is the reason why we need to\ncontinue monitoring to be sure there's not something out there,\"\nRobin Kinney, Minnesota assistant agriculture commissioner, said in a\nrecent interview.\n\nThe TB-positive deer was a 6-year-old male, and showed clinical signs\nof bovine TB, which later was confirmed by laboratory analysis. No\nother deer removed this winter [2008-09] showed similar signs of\ninfection. \"We fully expected that the deer population was carrying\nsome of this, so to find one is a good sign,\" Kinney said.\n\nThe older deer makes state officials believe that bovine TB among\ndeer may be confined to a certain age class, since the infected deer\nfound since testing began in 2005 have been born in 2005 or earlier.\n\n\"It was an older deer that was found,\" Kinney said. \"That's great,\nand it means that we need to continue that diligence to seek it out.\nI don't expect we're going to have any problems, but that's why we're\nstaying on high alert on it.\"\n\nLast year [208], the US Department of Agriculture allowed Minnesota a\nsplit-state status, meaning that outside a bovine TB management area\nin northwest Beltrami County and Roseau County, the state remains TB-free.\n\nCattle sold within the bovine TB management area must undergo strict\ntesting regimes before being sold or transported across state lines.\n\nCattle are believed to contract bovine TB from infected free-ranging\ndeer, so the DNR [Department of Natural Resources] has been working\nwith USDA sharpshooters during the winter to cull the deer herd in that area.\n\nThe DNR has also conducted surveillance for TB in hunter-harvested\ndeer within a 15-mile [24 km] radius of the once-infected farms every\nfall since 2005. To date, more than 6000 deer taken by hunters and\nsharp-shooters have been tested.\n\n\"The older ages of infected deer, the lack of infection in younger\ndeer, and the close proximity of infected deer suggest the disease is\nnot efficiently spreading in the deer population,\" Michelle\nCarstensen, DNR wildlife health program coordinator, said last month\n[May 2009].\n\nDNR sampled 1246 deer taken in the bovine TB surveillance zone during\nthe fall 2008 hunt. Spring sharp-shooting efforts, that began in\nMarch and concluded 30 Apr [2009], have resulted in an additional 738\ndeer being removed near previously infected cattle operations inside\nthe management zone.\n\nDNR will continue monitoring for the disease through sampling of\nhunter-harvested deer, Carstensen said. Hunter-harvested surveillance\nwill be conducted within the larger bovine TB surveillance zone in\nfall 2009, with a sampling goal of 1800 deer. Surveillance will\ncontinue every year until no positive animals are detected for 5\nconsecutive years, she said.\n\nThe 2008 Legislature, led by Sen. Rod Skoe, DFL-Clearbrook, put in\nplace the bovine TB management zone and provided buyouts of herds\nthat may be infected and ordered fencing around remaining herds to\nkeep out deer.\n\nThe Agriculture Department's bovine TB czar is Joe Martin, appointed\nby Gov. Tim Pawlenty. \"He's done just a great job shepherding this\nthrough and being sure that producers are being taken care of,\" said\nKinney. \"Funding-wise, we've had a great partnership, especially with\nthe legislative folks up here. They understand the issue, they've\nbeen working very closely hand-in-hand with Joe and the DNR to be\nsure we've got that balance.\"\n\n\"This should not delay Minnesota's goal of regaining TB-Free Status,\"\nMartin said last month [May 2009] of the new deer discovery. \"We have\nbeen in contact with USDA and they have assured us this finding in\nthe deer will not impact cattle movements or the state's TB status.\"\n\nThe state's status is only impacted by finding additional TB-positive\ncattle herds. The last known infected herd was depopulated earlier\nthis year [2009] as part of the state's buyout program. There are no\nother active cattle investigations ongoing at this time, Martin said.\n\nThe buyout of herds is complete, Kinney said. \"Money-wise this coming\nyear it's going to be continuing to provide some education and\nmanagement opportunities for as long as these folks are going to need\nto be out, be sure that we're monitoring that deer population so that\nwe can get the status back as quickly as we can.\"\n\nThe issue continues to be a priority of the Minnesota Farm Bureau\nFederation, which lobbied last year [2008] for the special management\nzone and funding for cattle buyouts. \"Bovine TB is still a priority\nfor us in Farm Bureau,\" Minnesota Farm Bureau President Kevin Paap\nsaid in a recent interview. \"We need to do everything and anything we\ncan to eradicate that, both in the cattle and the deer herds. So\nwe'll watch that very closely.\"\n\nMinnesota state agencies and USDA have entered into a productive\npartnership in an effort to eradicate bovine TB, Kinney said. \"We\nhave a very good partnership, and I have say that's to the fact that\nCommissioner (Gene) Hugoson has served so long in a leadership role,\"\nshe said. \"That consistency has been extremely important, not only\nfor Minnesota but for APHIS and the other divisions. He is recognized\nnationally as a leader and has great insight.\" USDA's Animal and\nPublic Health Information System establishes threat levels for animal\ndiseases, and determines levels of bovine TB classifications.\n\nKinney also credited US House Agriculture Chairman Collin Peterson,\nDFL-7th District, in whose district the bovine TB management zone\nlies. \"He just does a tremendous job as an advocate for agriculture,\nand his role as chairman of the House Ag Committee certainly helped\nMinnesota come forward,\" Kinney said. \"We've got great dialogue with him.\"\n\n[Byline: Brad Swenson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[Minnesota has had a long battle with tuberculosis, both in bovines\nand in cervids. They have made gallant strides in getting this\ndisease under control. Their surveillance here is a minor triumph in\nbeing able to predict what the age of expected animals with the\ndisease. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The Midwestern state of Minnesota can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00uq>.\nBeltrami County can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beltrami_County,_Minnesota>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (MN) status downgrade 20080408.1296\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20071029.3509\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03)20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)(02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)20050716.2030\n...................................tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-05-16 00:00:00", "1246-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-05-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beltrami County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Roseau County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DFL-7th District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "229298", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (08): (IN) cervid, bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=229298", "date": "2009-06-25 11:00:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, CERVIDS - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 23 Jun 2009\nSource: Bemidji Pioneer [edited]\n<http://www.bemidjipioneer.com/event/article/id/24892/>\n\n\nThe discovery of a whitetail deer with bovine tuberculosis [TB] in\nnorthwest Beltrami County doesn't concern state agriculture\nofficials. \"It was kind of expected, and is the reason why we need to\ncontinue monitoring to be sure there's not something out there,\"\nRobin Kinney, Minnesota assistant agriculture commissioner, said in a\nrecent interview.\n\nThe TB-positive deer was a 6-year-old male, and showed clinical signs\nof bovine TB, which later was confirmed by laboratory analysis. No\nother deer removed this winter [2008-09] showed similar signs of\ninfection. \"We fully expected that the deer population was carrying\nsome of this, so to find one is a good sign,\" Kinney said.\n\nThe older deer makes state officials believe that bovine TB among\ndeer may be confined to a certain age class, since the infected deer\nfound since testing began in 2005 have been born in 2005 or earlier.\n\n\"It was an older deer that was found,\" Kinney said. \"That's great,\nand it means that we need to continue that diligence to seek it out.\nI don't expect we're going to have any problems, but that's why we're\nstaying on high alert on it.\"\n\nLast year [208], the US Department of Agriculture allowed Minnesota a\nsplit-state status, meaning that outside a bovine TB management area\nin northwest Beltrami County and Roseau County, the state remains TB-free.\n\nCattle sold within the bovine TB management area must undergo strict\ntesting regimes before being sold or transported across state lines.\n\nCattle are believed to contract bovine TB from infected free-ranging\ndeer, so the DNR [Department of Natural Resources] has been working\nwith USDA sharpshooters during the winter to cull the deer herd in that area.\n\nThe DNR has also conducted surveillance for TB in hunter-harvested\ndeer within a 15-mile [24 km] radius of the once-infected farms every\nfall since 2005. To date, more than 6000 deer taken by hunters and\nsharp-shooters have been tested.\n\n\"The older ages of infected deer, the lack of infection in younger\ndeer, and the close proximity of infected deer suggest the disease is\nnot efficiently spreading in the deer population,\" Michelle\nCarstensen, DNR wildlife health program coordinator, said last month\n[May 2009].\n\nDNR sampled 1246 deer taken in the bovine TB surveillance zone during\nthe fall 2008 hunt. Spring sharp-shooting efforts, that began in\nMarch and concluded 30 Apr [2009], have resulted in an additional 738\ndeer being removed near previously infected cattle operations inside\nthe management zone.\n\nDNR will continue monitoring for the disease through sampling of\nhunter-harvested deer, Carstensen said. Hunter-harvested surveillance\nwill be conducted within the larger bovine TB surveillance zone in\nfall 2009, with a sampling goal of 1800 deer. Surveillance will\ncontinue every year until no positive animals are detected for 5\nconsecutive years, she said.\n\nThe 2008 Legislature, led by Sen. Rod Skoe, DFL-Clearbrook, put in\nplace the bovine TB management zone and provided buyouts of herds\nthat may be infected and ordered fencing around remaining herds to\nkeep out deer.\n\nThe Agriculture Department's bovine TB czar is Joe Martin, appointed\nby Gov. Tim Pawlenty. \"He's done just a great job shepherding this\nthrough and being sure that producers are being taken care of,\" said\nKinney. \"Funding-wise, we've had a great partnership, especially with\nthe legislative folks up here. They understand the issue, they've\nbeen working very closely hand-in-hand with Joe and the DNR to be\nsure we've got that balance.\"\n\n\"This should not delay Minnesota's goal of regaining TB-Free Status,\"\nMartin said last month [May 2009] of the new deer discovery. \"We have\nbeen in contact with USDA and they have assured us this finding in\nthe deer will not impact cattle movements or the state's TB status.\"\n\nThe state's status is only impacted by finding additional TB-positive\ncattle herds. The last known infected herd was depopulated earlier\nthis year [2009] as part of the state's buyout program. There are no\nother active cattle investigations ongoing at this time, Martin said.\n\nThe buyout of herds is complete, Kinney said. \"Money-wise this coming\nyear it's going to be continuing to provide some education and\nmanagement opportunities for as long as these folks are going to need\nto be out, be sure that we're monitoring that deer population so that\nwe can get the status back as quickly as we can.\"\n\nThe issue continues to be a priority of the Minnesota Farm Bureau\nFederation, which lobbied last year [2008] for the special management\nzone and funding for cattle buyouts. \"Bovine TB is still a priority\nfor us in Farm Bureau,\" Minnesota Farm Bureau President Kevin Paap\nsaid in a recent interview. \"We need to do everything and anything we\ncan to eradicate that, both in the cattle and the deer herds. So\nwe'll watch that very closely.\"\n\nMinnesota state agencies and USDA have entered into a productive\npartnership in an effort to eradicate bovine TB, Kinney said. \"We\nhave a very good partnership, and I have say that's to the fact that\nCommissioner (Gene) Hugoson has served so long in a leadership role,\"\nshe said. \"That consistency has been extremely important, not only\nfor Minnesota but for APHIS and the other divisions. He is recognized\nnationally as a leader and has great insight.\" USDA's Animal and\nPublic Health Information System establishes threat levels for animal\ndiseases, and determines levels of bovine TB classifications.\n\nKinney also credited US House Agriculture Chairman Collin Peterson,\nDFL-7th District, in whose district the bovine TB management zone\nlies. \"He just does a tremendous job as an advocate for agriculture,\nand his role as chairman of the House Ag Committee certainly helped\nMinnesota come forward,\" Kinney said. \"We've got great dialogue with him.\"\n\n[Byline: Brad Swenson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[Minnesota has had a long battle with tuberculosis, both in bovines\nand in cervids. They have made gallant strides in getting this\ndisease under control. Their surveillance here is a minor triumph in\nbeing able to predict what the age of expected animals with the\ndisease. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The Midwestern state of Minnesota can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00uq>.\nBeltrami County can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beltrami_County,_Minnesota>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (MN) status downgrade 20080408.1296\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20071029.3509\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03)20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)(02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)20050716.2030\n...................................tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA: (MN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=227538", "date": "2009-06-25 11:00:13", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, CERVIDS - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 23 Jun 2009\nSource: Bemidji Pioneer [edited]\n<http://www.bemidjipioneer.com/event/article/id/24892/>\n\n\nThe discovery of a whitetail deer with bovine tuberculosis [TB] in\nnorthwest Beltrami County doesn't concern state agriculture\nofficials. \"It was kind of expected, and is the reason why we need to\ncontinue monitoring to be sure there's not something out there,\"\nRobin Kinney, Minnesota assistant agriculture commissioner, said in a\nrecent interview.\n\nThe TB-positive deer was a 6-year-old male, and showed clinical signs\nof bovine TB, which later was confirmed by laboratory analysis. No\nother deer removed this winter [2008-09] showed similar signs of\ninfection. \"We fully expected that the deer population was carrying\nsome of this, so to find one is a good sign,\" Kinney said.\n\nThe older deer makes state officials believe that bovine TB among\ndeer may be confined to a certain age class, since the infected deer\nfound since testing began in 2005 have been born in 2005 or earlier.\n\n\"It was an older deer that was found,\" Kinney said. \"That's great,\nand it means that we need to continue that diligence to seek it out.\nI don't expect we're going to have any problems, but that's why we're\nstaying on high alert on it.\"\n\nLast year [208], the US Department of Agriculture allowed Minnesota a\nsplit-state status, meaning that outside a bovine TB management area\nin northwest Beltrami County and Roseau County, the state remains TB-free.\n\nCattle sold within the bovine TB management area must undergo strict\ntesting regimes before being sold or transported across state lines.\n\nCattle are believed to contract bovine TB from infected free-ranging\ndeer, so the DNR [Department of Natural Resources] has been working\nwith USDA sharpshooters during the winter to cull the deer herd in that area.\n\nThe DNR has also conducted surveillance for TB in hunter-harvested\ndeer within a 15-mile [24 km] radius of the once-infected farms every\nfall since 2005. To date, more than 6000 deer taken by hunters and\nsharp-shooters have been tested.\n\n\"The older ages of infected deer, the lack of infection in younger\ndeer, and the close proximity of infected deer suggest the disease is\nnot efficiently spreading in the deer population,\" Michelle\nCarstensen, DNR wildlife health program coordinator, said last month\n[May 2009].\n\nDNR sampled 1246 deer taken in the bovine TB surveillance zone during\nthe fall 2008 hunt. Hunter-harvested surveillance\nwill be conducted within the larger bovine TB surveillance zone in\nfall 2009, with a sampling goal of 1800 deer. Surveillance will\ncontinue every year until no positive animals are detected for 5\nconsecutive years, she said.\n\nThe 2008 Legislature, led by Sen. Tim Pawlenty. \"He's done just a great job shepherding this\nthrough and being sure that producers are being taken care of,\" said\nKinney. \"Funding-wise, we've had a great partnership, especially with\nthe legislative folks up here. They understand the issue, they've\nbeen working very closely hand-in-hand with Joe and the DNR to be\nsure we've got that balance.\"\n\n\"This should not delay Minnesota's goal of regaining TB-Free Status,\"\nMartin said last month [May 2009] of the new deer discovery. \"We have\nbeen in contact with USDA and they have assured us this finding in\nthe deer will not impact cattle movements or the state's TB status.\"\n\nThe state's status is only impacted by finding additional TB-positive\ncattle herds. The last known infected herd was depopulated earlier\nthis year [2009] as part of the state's buyout program. There are no\nother active cattle investigations ongoing at this time, Martin said.\n\nThe buyout of herds is complete, Kinney said. \"Money-wise this coming\nyear it's going to be continuing to provide some education and\nmanagement opportunities for as long as these folks are going to need\nto be out, be sure that we're monitoring that deer population so that\nwe can get the status back as quickly as we can.\"\n\nThe issue continues to be a priority of the Minnesota Farm Bureau\nFederation, which lobbied last year [2008] for the special management\nzone and funding for cattle buyouts. \"Bovine TB is still a priority\nfor us in Farm Bureau,\" Minnesota Farm Bureau President Kevin Paap\nsaid in a recent interview. \"We need to do everything and anything we\ncan to eradicate that, both in the cattle and the deer herds. So\nwe'll watch that very closely.\"\n\nMinnesota state agencies and USDA have entered into a productive\npartnership in an effort to eradicate bovine TB, Kinney said. \"We\nhave a very good partnership, and I have say that's to the fact that\nCommissioner (Gene) Hugoson has served so long in a leadership role,\"\nshe said. \"That consistency has been extremely important, not only\nfor Minnesota but for APHIS and the other divisions. He is recognized\nnationally as a leader and has great insight.\" USDA's Animal and\nPublic Health Information System establishes threat levels for animal\ndiseases, and determines levels of bovine TB classifications.\n\nKinney also credited US House Agriculture Chairman Collin Peterson,\nDFL-7th District, in whose district the bovine TB management zone\nlies. \"He just does a tremendous job as an advocate for agriculture,\nand his role as chairman of the House Ag Committee certainly helped\nMinnesota come forward,\" Kinney said. \"We've got great dialogue with him.\"\n\n[Byline: Brad Swenson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[Minnesota has had a long battle with tuberculosis, both in bovines\nand in cervids. They have made gallant strides in getting this\ndisease under control. Their surveillance here is a minor triumph in\nbeing able to predict what the age of expected animals with the\ndisease. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The Midwestern state of Minnesota can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00uq>.\nBeltrami County can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beltrami_County,_Minnesota>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02) 20090620.2270\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (05): (NE) 20090613.2198\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (04): (TX) conf. 20090613.2195\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (03): (NE) cattle, elk 20090603.2060\nBovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND) 20090514.1811\nBovine tuberculosis - UK (03): increased incidence 20090514.1809\nBovine tuberculosis - USA: (TX), susp 20090423.1536\n2008\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (04): (MN) status downgrade 20080408.1296\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n2007\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20071029.3509\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03)20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)(02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN)20050716.2030\n...................................tg/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-05-16 00:00:00", "1246-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-05-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beltrami County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Roseau County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DFL-7th District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "224101", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (06) (NE) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=224101", "date": "2009-04-23 19:00:54", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA: (TEXAS), SUSPECTED\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 23 Apr 2009\nSource: Texas Animal Health Commission [edited]\n<http://www.tahc.state.tx.us/news/pr/2009/2009Apr_PreliminaryTbTestsInTexasDairy.pdf>\n\n\nPreliminary test results indicate that a dairy in west Texas is infected\nwith cattle tuberculosis (TB). Cattle TB is caused by the _Mycobacterium\nbovis_ bacteria and can cause internal lesions in animals. Milk from\ncommercial dairies is pasteurized, killing bacteria with heat, so there is\nnot public health concern from this herd detection.\n\n\"Animals from the 2600-head dairy were being prepared for sale, and some\nreacted to TB skin tests. The follow-up blood tests on these animals also\nwere positive,\" said Dr Bob Hillman, Texas state veterinarian and executive\ndirector of the Texas Animal Health Commission, the state's livestock and\npoultry health regulatory agency. \"Samples were collected from 2 of the\ncattle slaughtered for examination, and the tissues were submitted to the\nNational Veterinary Services Laboratory in Ames, Iowa for additional\ntesting. The lesions are microscopically compatible with TB, and polymerase\nchain reaction (PCR) tests on the tissues have detected the DNA, or the\nbasic genetic material of the disease. The final confirmation is based on a\nculture, which may take several weeks. It involves identifying bacterial\ngrowth from the tissue samples as _Mycobacterium bovis_.\"\n\n\"We will be determining the dispensation of the herd in the next few days,\"\nsaid Dr Hillman. \"An epidemiological investigation has been launched to\ndetermine the source or possible spread of the disease.\"\n\nTexas regained cattle TB-free status in fall 2006 after losing the coveted\nstatus in spring 2002. Dr Hillman noted that one TB-infected herd would not\naffect the state's status, but 2 infected herds within a 48-month period\nwould result in a loss of TB-free status. Texas' most recent TB-infected\nherd was a dairy, detected in 2004 and depopulated. California lost its\nTB-free status in September 2008, and Minnesota, Michigan and New Mexico\nare split states, meaning areas within these states have different TB\nstatuses. All other states currently are TB-free.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The loss of a \"free\" status for this disease places an extra burden on any\nproducers selling or shipping animals. There is a cost to testing the\nanimals, and it certainly requires advance planning to allow a minimum of 3\n-- and more likely 5 -- days ahead of when the animals need to be shipped.\nThe producer can no longer make arrangements and proceed to ship the\nanimals but rather must test in advance.\n\nIt seems likely this will be a positive case. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (10): (CA) 20081218.3981\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (09): (ND) 20081208.3856\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (07): (IN) 20081205.3826\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20080202.0429\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n\n..................tg/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cattle TB is caused by the _Mycobacterium\nbovis_ bacteria and can cause internal lesions in animals. Milk from\ncommercial dairies is pasteurized, killing bacteria with heat, so there is\nnot public health concern from this herd detection.\n\n\"Animals from the 2600-head dairy were being prepared for sale, and some\nreacted to TB skin tests. The follow-up blood tests on these animals also\nwere positive,\" said Dr Bob Hillman, Texas state veterinarian and executive\ndirector of the Texas Animal Health Commission, the state's livestock and\npoultry health regulatory agency. \"Samples were collected from 2 of the\ncattle slaughtered for examination, and the tissues were submitted to the\nNational Veterinary Services Laboratory in Ames, Iowa for additional\ntesting. The lesions are microscopically compatible with TB, and polymerase\nchain reaction (PCR) tests on the tissues have detected the DNA, or the\nbasic genetic material of the disease. The final confirmation is based on a\nculture, which may take several weeks. It involves identifying bacterial\ngrowth from the tissue samples as _Mycobacterium bovis_.\"\n\n\"We will be determining the dispensation of the herd in the next few days,\"\nsaid Dr Hillman. \"An epidemiological investigation has been launched to\ndetermine the source or possible spread of the disease.\"\n\nTexas regained cattle TB-free status in fall 2006 after losing the coveted\nstatus in spring 2002. Dr Hillman noted that one TB-infected herd would not\naffect the state's status, but 2 infected herds within a 48-month period\nwould result in a loss of TB-free status. Texas' most recent TB-infected\nherd was a dairy, detected in 2004 and depopulated. California lost its\nTB-free status in September 2008, and Minnesota, Michigan and New Mexico\nare split states, meaning areas within these states have different TB\nstatuses. All other states currently are TB-free.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The loss of a \"free\" status for this disease places an extra burden on any\nproducers selling or shipping animals. There is a cost to testing the\nanimals, and it certainly requires advance planning to allow a minimum of 3\n-- and more likely 5 -- days ahead of when the animals need to be shipped.\nThe producer can no longer make arrangements and proceed to ship the\nanimals but rather must test in advance.\n\nIt seems likely this will be a positive case. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (10): (CA) 20081218.3981\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (09): (ND) 20081208.3856\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (07): (IN) 20081205.3826\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20080202.0429\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n\n..................tg/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cattle TB is caused by the _Mycobacterium\nbovis_ bacteria and can cause internal lesions in animals. Milk from\ncommercial dairies is pasteurized, killing bacteria with heat, so there is\nnot public health concern from this herd detection.\n\n\"Animals from the 2600-head dairy were being prepared for sale, and some\nreacted to TB skin tests. The final confirmation is based on a\nculture, which may take several weeks. It involves identifying bacterial\ngrowth from the tissue samples as _Mycobacterium bovis_.\"\n\n\"We will be determining the dispensation of the herd in the next few days,\"\nsaid Dr Hillman. \"An epidemiological investigation has been launched to\ndetermine the source or possible spread of the disease.\"\n\nTexas regained cattle TB-free status in fall 2006 after losing the coveted\nstatus in spring 2002. Dr Hillman noted that one TB-infected herd would not\naffect the state's status, but 2 infected herds within a 48-month period\nwould result in a loss of TB-free status. Texas' most recent TB-infected\nherd was a dairy, detected in 2004 and depopulated. California lost its\nTB-free status in September 2008, and Minnesota, Michigan and New Mexico\nare split states, meaning areas within these states have different TB\nstatuses. There is a cost to testing the\nanimals, and it certainly requires advance planning to allow a minimum of 3\n-- and more likely 5 -- days ahead of when the animals need to be shipped.\nThe producer can no longer make arrangements and proceed to ship the\nanimals but rather must test in advance.\n\nIt seems likely this will be a positive case. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (10): (CA) 20081218.3981\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (09): (ND) 20081208.3856\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (07): (IN) 20081205.3826\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20080202.0429\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n\n..................tg/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2600-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "197302", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis - USA (02): (ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=197302", "date": "2009-04-23 19:00:54", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA: (TEXAS), SUSPECTED\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 23 Apr 2009\nSource: Texas Animal Health Commission [edited]\n<http://www.tahc.state.tx.us/news/pr/2009/2009Apr_PreliminaryTbTestsInTexasDairy.pdf>\n\n\nPreliminary test results indicate that a dairy in west Texas is infected\nwith cattle tuberculosis (TB). Cattle TB is caused by the _Mycobacterium\nbovis_ bacteria and can cause internal lesions in animals. Milk from\ncommercial dairies is pasteurized, killing bacteria with heat, so there is\nnot public health concern from this herd detection.\n\n\"Animals from the 2600-head dairy were being prepared for sale, and some\nreacted to TB skin tests. The follow-up blood tests on these animals also\nwere positive,\" said Dr Bob Hillman, Texas state veterinarian and executive\ndirector of the Texas Animal Health Commission, the state's livestock and\npoultry health regulatory agency. \"Samples were collected from 2 of the\ncattle slaughtered for examination, and the tissues were submitted to the\nNational Veterinary Services Laboratory in Ames, Iowa for additional\ntesting. The lesions are microscopically compatible with TB, and polymerase\nchain reaction (PCR) tests on the tissues have detected the DNA, or the\nbasic genetic material of the disease. The final confirmation is based on a\nculture, which may take several weeks. It involves identifying bacterial\ngrowth from the tissue samples as _Mycobacterium bovis_.\"\n\n\"We will be determining the dispensation of the herd in the next few days,\"\nsaid Dr Hillman. \"An epidemiological investigation has been launched to\ndetermine the source or possible spread of the disease.\"\n\nTexas regained cattle TB-free status in fall 2006 after losing the coveted\nstatus in spring 2002. Dr Hillman noted that one TB-infected herd would not\naffect the state's status, but 2 infected herds within a 48-month period\nwould result in a loss of TB-free status. Texas' most recent TB-infected\nherd was a dairy, detected in 2004 and depopulated. California lost its\nTB-free status in September 2008, and Minnesota, Michigan and New Mexico\nare split states, meaning areas within these states have different TB\nstatuses. All other states currently are TB-free.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The loss of a \"free\" status for this disease places an extra burden on any\nproducers selling or shipping animals. There is a cost to testing the\nanimals, and it certainly requires advance planning to allow a minimum of 3\n-- and more likely 5 -- days ahead of when the animals need to be shipped.\nThe producer can no longer make arrangements and proceed to ship the\nanimals but rather must test in advance.\n\nIt seems likely this will be a positive case. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (10): (CA) 20081218.3981\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (09): (ND) 20081208.3856\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (07): (IN) 20081205.3826\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20080202.0429\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n\n..................tg/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cattle TB is caused by the _Mycobacterium\nbovis_ bacteria and can cause internal lesions in animals. Milk from\ncommercial dairies is pasteurized, killing bacteria with heat, so there is\nnot public health concern from this herd detection.\n\n\"Animals from the 2600-head dairy were being prepared for sale, and some\nreacted to TB skin tests. The follow-up blood tests on these animals also\nwere positive,\" said Dr Bob Hillman, Texas state veterinarian and executive\ndirector of the Texas Animal Health Commission, the state's livestock and\npoultry health regulatory agency. \"Samples were collected from 2 of the\ncattle slaughtered for examination, and the tissues were submitted to the\nNational Veterinary Services Laboratory in Ames, Iowa for additional\ntesting. The lesions are microscopically compatible with TB, and polymerase\nchain reaction (PCR) tests on the tissues have detected the DNA, or the\nbasic genetic material of the disease. The final confirmation is based on a\nculture, which may take several weeks. It involves identifying bacterial\ngrowth from the tissue samples as _Mycobacterium bovis_.\"\n\n\"We will be determining the dispensation of the herd in the next few days,\"\nsaid Dr Hillman. \"An epidemiological investigation has been launched to\ndetermine the source or possible spread of the disease.\"\n\nTexas regained cattle TB-free status in fall 2006 after losing the coveted\nstatus in spring 2002. Dr Hillman noted that one TB-infected herd would not\naffect the state's status, but 2 infected herds within a 48-month period\nwould result in a loss of TB-free status. Texas' most recent TB-infected\nherd was a dairy, detected in 2004 and depopulated. California lost its\nTB-free status in September 2008, and Minnesota, Michigan and New Mexico\nare split states, meaning areas within these states have different TB\nstatuses. All other states currently are TB-free.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The loss of a \"free\" status for this disease places an extra burden on any\nproducers selling or shipping animals. There is a cost to testing the\nanimals, and it certainly requires advance planning to allow a minimum of 3\n-- and more likely 5 -- days ahead of when the animals need to be shipped.\nThe producer can no longer make arrangements and proceed to ship the\nanimals but rather must test in advance.\n\nIt seems likely this will be a positive case. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2008\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (10): (CA) 20081218.3981\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (09): (ND) 20081208.3856\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (08): (MN) 20081207.3839\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (07): (IN) 20081205.3826\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (03): (MN) 20080222.0718\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (02): (MN) 20080205.0472\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20080202.0429\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN) 20080123.0285\n\n..................tg/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Some 230 youngstock have\nalready been culled.\n\nThe family-run business, which makes the Daioni range of organic\nflavored milk, has insisted production levels will not be affected.\nIt has also stressed the TB outbreak poses no health risk to\nconsumers, as all its milk is pasteurized.\n\nTrioni's founder and managing director Laurence Harris said: \"We\nwould like to emphasize that business will continue as normal, as we\nhave always sourced milk from other OMSCO farms (organic milk\nsuppliers co-operative) in Pembrokeshire as well as our own.\"\n\nThe company is working with the State Veterinary Service and Assembly\nGovernment to control the outbreak. Culling of dairy cows will start\ntomorrow [7 Jan 2009].\n\nMr. Harris admitted it was \"without doubt\" a stressful time for\nstaff, but he thanked people for their support. He added: \"We are\ndeeply saddened for this to be happening to our farming business. In\ntime, we will look to rebuild our herd but will never be able to\nreplace them, as 3 generations of hard work have gone into building\nthe Ffosyficer herd.\"\n\nTrioni developed its Daioni (\"goodness\" in Welsh) range of organic\nmilk drinks as an alternative to the fizzy sugary drinks generally\navailable for children and launched them in 2003.\n\nThe multi award-winning business has expanded its customer base to\ninclude the Welsh Rugby Union and a number of Premiership football\nteams. It also exports to several countries.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Forgrave]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[DEFRA's provisional bovine TB statistics for Great Britain (England,\nWales and Scotland) from 1 Jan 2008 to 30 Sep 2008, as updated on 1\nDec 2008, are available in 6 pdf tables (Great Britain, West Region,\nNorth Region, East Region, Wales, and Scotland), which are accessible at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/latest.htm>.\n\nAccording to the said tables, the total current number of cattle\nherds registered in Great Britain is 87 258, of which 5399 herds\n(6.19 percent) were under TB2 restrictions because of a TB incident\nat some time during the said period. This is an unusually high\nincidence for a west-European country.\n\nThe detailed Bovine TB Statistics for Wales pertaining to the said\nperiod are available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/08/sept08wales.pdf>.\nThe number of cattle herds registered in Wales is 13 875, of which\n1610 (11.6 percent!!) were under TB2 restrictions. The situation in\nWales deteriorated during 2008: During the entire year in 2007, there\nwere 447 confirmed new TB incidents, compared to 406 such incidents\n(temporary data) during January-September 2008.\n\nThe deplorably deteriorated bTB situation in the UK has already been\nreflected in the introduction of infected animals into importing\nfarms elsewhere (see postings 20080718.2186 and 20080909.2813). - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (03): 2005-2006 20081114.3594\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-01-06 00:00:00", "2009-01-07 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-01 00:00:00", "5399-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Great Britain", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "East Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "173696", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA: (IL) susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=173696", "date": "2009-01-07 21:00:40", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK: (WALES)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 6 Jan 2009\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\n<http://www.dailypost.co.uk/farming-north-wales/farming-news/2009/01/06/tb-disaster-rocks-welsh-milk-firm-55578-22616269/>\n\n\nAward-winning milk firm Trioni, a Welsh farming success story, has\nsuffered a devastating setback after its dairy herd was hit by bovine TB.\n\nSome 335 cows from its dairy herd of 390 are to be slaughtered in an\nattempt to stop the disease in its tracks. Some 230 youngstock have\nalready been culled.\n\nThe family-run business, which makes the Daioni range of organic\nflavored milk, has insisted production levels will not be affected.\nIt has also stressed the TB outbreak poses no health risk to\nconsumers, as all its milk is pasteurized.\n\nTrioni's founder and managing director Laurence Harris said: \"We\nwould like to emphasize that business will continue as normal, as we\nhave always sourced milk from other OMSCO farms (organic milk\nsuppliers co-operative) in Pembrokeshire as well as our own.\"\n\nThe company is working with the State Veterinary Service and Assembly\nGovernment to control the outbreak. Culling of dairy cows will start\ntomorrow [7 Jan 2009].\n\nMr. Harris admitted it was \"without doubt\" a stressful time for\nstaff, but he thanked people for their support. He added: \"We are\ndeeply saddened for this to be happening to our farming business. In\ntime, we will look to rebuild our herd but will never be able to\nreplace them, as 3 generations of hard work have gone into building\nthe Ffosyficer herd.\"\n\nTrioni developed its Daioni (\"goodness\" in Welsh) range of organic\nmilk drinks as an alternative to the fizzy sugary drinks generally\navailable for children and launched them in 2003.\n\nThe multi award-winning business has expanded its customer base to\ninclude the Welsh Rugby Union and a number of Premiership football\nteams. It also exports to several countries.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Forgrave]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[DEFRA's provisional bovine TB statistics for Great Britain (England,\nWales and Scotland) from 1 Jan 2008 to 30 Sep 2008, as updated on 1\nDec 2008, are available in 6 pdf tables (Great Britain, West Region,\nNorth Region, East Region, Wales, and Scotland), which are accessible at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/latest.htm>.\n\nAccording to the said tables, the total current number of cattle\nherds registered in Great Britain is 87 258, of which 5399 herds\n(6.19 percent) were under TB2 restrictions because of a TB incident\nat some time during the said period. This is an unusually high\nincidence for a west-European country.\n\nThe detailed Bovine TB Statistics for Wales pertaining to the said\nperiod are available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/08/sept08wales.pdf>.\nThe number of cattle herds registered in Wales is 13 875, of which\n1610 (11.6 percent!!) were under TB2 restrictions. The situation in\nWales deteriorated during 2008: During the entire year in 2007, there\nwere 447 confirmed new TB incidents, compared to 406 such incidents\n(temporary data) during January-September 2008.\n\nThe deplorably deteriorated bTB situation in the UK has already been\nreflected in the introduction of infected animals into importing\nfarms elsewhere (see postings 20080718.2186 and 20080909.2813). - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (03): 2005-2006 20081114.3594\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-01-06 00:00:00", "2009-01-07 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-01 00:00:00", "5399-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Great Britain", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "East Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "168073", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis - UK, New Zealand: vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=168073", "date": "2009-01-07 21:00:40", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK: (WALES)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 6 Jan 2009\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\n<http://www.dailypost.co.uk/farming-north-wales/farming-news/2009/01/06/tb-disaster-rocks-welsh-milk-firm-55578-22616269/>\n\n\nAward-winning milk firm Trioni, a Welsh farming success story, has\nsuffered a devastating setback after its dairy herd was hit by bovine TB.\n\nSome 335 cows from its dairy herd of 390 are to be slaughtered in an\nattempt to stop the disease in its tracks. Some 230 youngstock have\nalready been culled.\n\nThe family-run business, which makes the Daioni range of organic\nflavored milk, has insisted production levels will not be affected.\nIt has also stressed the TB outbreak poses no health risk to\nconsumers, as all its milk is pasteurized.\n\nTrioni's founder and managing director Laurence Harris said: \"We\nwould like to emphasize that business will continue as normal, as we\nhave always sourced milk from other OMSCO farms (organic milk\nsuppliers co-operative) in Pembrokeshire as well as our own.\"\n\nThe company is working with the State Veterinary Service and Assembly\nGovernment to control the outbreak. Culling of dairy cows will start\ntomorrow [7 Jan 2009].\n\nMr. Harris admitted it was \"without doubt\" a stressful time for\nstaff, but he thanked people for their support. He added: \"We are\ndeeply saddened for this to be happening to our farming business. In\ntime, we will look to rebuild our herd but will never be able to\nreplace them, as 3 generations of hard work have gone into building\nthe Ffosyficer herd.\"\n\nTrioni developed its Daioni (\"goodness\" in Welsh) range of organic\nmilk drinks as an alternative to the fizzy sugary drinks generally\navailable for children and launched them in 2003.\n\nThe multi award-winning business has expanded its customer base to\ninclude the Welsh Rugby Union and a number of Premiership football\nteams. It also exports to several countries.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Forgrave]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[DEFRA's provisional bovine TB statistics for Great Britain (England,\nWales and Scotland) from 1 Jan 2008 to 30 Sep 2008, as updated on 1\nDec 2008, are available in 6 pdf tables (Great Britain, West Region,\nNorth Region, East Region, Wales, and Scotland), which are accessible at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/latest.htm>.\n\nAccording to the said tables, the total current number of cattle\nherds registered in Great Britain is 87 258, of which 5399 herds\n(6.19 percent) were under TB2 restrictions because of a TB incident\nat some time during the said period. This is an unusually high\nincidence for a west-European country.\n\nThe detailed Bovine TB Statistics for Wales pertaining to the said\nperiod are available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/08/sept08wales.pdf>.\nThe number of cattle herds registered in Wales is 13 875, of which\n1610 (11.6 percent!!) were under TB2 restrictions. The situation in\nWales deteriorated during 2008: During the entire year in 2007, there\nwere 447 confirmed new TB incidents, compared to 406 such incidents\n(temporary data) during January-September 2008.\n\nThe deplorably deteriorated bTB situation in the UK has already been\nreflected in the introduction of infected animals into importing\nfarms elsewhere (see postings 20080718.2186 and 20080909.2813). - Some 230 youngstock have\nalready been culled.\n\nThe family-run business, which makes the Daioni range of organic\nflavored milk, has insisted production levels will not be affected.\nIt has also stressed the TB outbreak poses no health risk to\nconsumers, as all its milk is pasteurized.\n\nTrioni's founder and managing director Laurence Harris said: \"We\nwould like to emphasize that business will continue as normal, as we\nhave always sourced milk from other OMSCO farms (organic milk\nsuppliers co-operative) in Pembrokeshire as well as our own.\"\n\nThe company is working with the State Veterinary Service and Assembly\nGovernment to control the outbreak. Culling of dairy cows will start\ntomorrow [7 Jan 2009].\n\nMr. Harris admitted it was \"without doubt\" a stressful time for\nstaff, but he thanked people for their support. He added: \"We are\ndeeply saddened for this to be happening to our farming business. In\ntime, we will look to rebuild our herd but will never be able to\nreplace them, as 3 generations of hard work have gone into building\nthe Ffosyficer herd.\"\n\nTrioni developed its Daioni (\"goodness\" in Welsh) range of organic\nmilk drinks as an alternative to the fizzy sugary drinks generally\navailable for children and launched them in 2003.\n\nThe multi award-winning business has expanded its customer base to\ninclude the Welsh Rugby Union and a number of Premiership football\nteams. It also exports to several countries.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Forgrave]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[DEFRA's provisional bovine TB statistics for Great Britain (England,\nWales and Scotland) from 1 Jan 2008 to 30 Sep 2008, as updated on 1\nDec 2008, are available in 6 pdf tables (Great Britain, West Region,\nNorth Region, East Region, Wales, and Scotland), which are accessible at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/latest.htm>.\n\nAccording to the said tables, the total current number of cattle\nherds registered in Great Britain is 87 258, of which 5399 herds\n(6.19 percent) were under TB2 restrictions because of a TB incident\nat some time during the said period. This is an unusually high\nincidence for a west-European country.\n\nThe detailed Bovine TB Statistics for Wales pertaining to the said\nperiod are available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/08/sept08wales.pdf>.\nThe number of cattle herds registered in Wales is 13 875, of which\n1610 (11.6 percent!!) were under TB2 restrictions. The situation in\nWales deteriorated during 2008: During the entire year in 2007, there\nwere 447 confirmed new TB incidents, compared to 406 such incidents\n(temporary data) during January-September 2008.\n\nThe deplorably deteriorated bTB situation in the UK has already been\nreflected in the introduction of infected animals into importing\nfarms elsewhere (see postings 20080718.2186 and 20080909.2813). - Some 230 youngstock have\nalready been culled.\n\nThe family-run business, which makes the Daioni range of organic\nflavored milk, has insisted production levels will not be affected.\nIt has also stressed the TB outbreak poses no health risk to\nconsumers, as all its milk is pasteurized.\n\nTrioni's founder and managing director Laurence Harris said: \"We\nwould like to emphasize that business will continue as normal, as we\nhave always sourced milk from other OMSCO farms (organic milk\nsuppliers co-operative) in Pembrokeshire as well as our own.\"\n\nThe company is working with the State Veterinary Service and Assembly\nGovernment to control the outbreak. Culling of dairy cows will start\ntomorrow [7 Jan 2009].\n\nMr. Harris admitted it was \"without doubt\" a stressful time for\nstaff, but he thanked people for their support. He added: \"We are\ndeeply saddened for this to be happening to our farming business. In\ntime, we will look to rebuild our herd but will never be able to\nreplace them, as 3 generations of hard work have gone into building\nthe Ffosyficer herd.\"\n\nTrioni developed its Daioni (\"goodness\" in Welsh) range of organic\nmilk drinks as an alternative to the fizzy sugary drinks generally\navailable for children and launched them in 2003.\n\nThe multi award-winning business has expanded its customer base to\ninclude the Welsh Rugby Union and a number of Premiership football\nteams. It also exports to several countries.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Forgrave]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[DEFRA's provisional bovine TB statistics for Great Britain (England,\nWales and Scotland) from 1 Jan 2008 to 30 Sep 2008, as updated on 1\nDec 2008, are available in 6 pdf tables (Great Britain, West Region,\nNorth Region, East Region, Wales, and Scotland), which are accessible at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/latest.htm>.\n\nAccording to the said tables, the total current number of cattle\nherds registered in Great Britain is 87 258, of which 5399 herds\n(6.19 percent) were under TB2 restrictions because of a TB incident\nat some time during the said period. This is an unusually high\nincidence for a west-European country.\n\nThe detailed Bovine TB Statistics for Wales pertaining to the said\nperiod are available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/08/sept08wales.pdf>.\nThe number of cattle herds registered in Wales is 13 875, of which\n1610 (11.6 percent!!) were under TB2 restrictions. The situation in\nWales deteriorated during 2008: During the entire year in 2007, there\nwere 447 confirmed new TB incidents, compared to 406 such incidents\n(temporary data) during January-September 2008.\n\nThe deplorably deteriorated bTB situation in the UK has already been\nreflected in the introduction of infected animals into importing\nfarms elsewhere (see postings 20080718.2186 and 20080909.2813). - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (03): 2005-2006 20081114.3594\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK 20081005.3141\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) (02) 20080927.3054\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-01-06 00:00:00", "2009-01-07 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-01 00:00:00", "5399-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Great Britain", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "East Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "165646", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, airplane exposure - USA ex Germany", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=165646", "date": "2009-01-07 21:00:40", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK: (WALES)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 6 Jan 2009\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\n<http://www.dailypost.co.uk/farming-north-wales/farming-news/2009/01/06/tb-disaster-rocks-welsh-milk-firm-55578-22616269/>\n\n\nAward-winning milk firm Trioni, a Welsh farming success story, has\nsuffered a devastating setback after its dairy herd was hit by bovine TB.\n\nSome 335 cows from its dairy herd of 390 are to be slaughtered in an\nattempt to stop the disease in its tracks. Some 230 youngstock have\nalready been culled.\n\nThe family-run business, which makes the Daioni range of organic\nflavored milk, has insisted production levels will not be affected.\nIt has also stressed the TB outbreak poses no health risk to\nconsumers, as all its milk is pasteurized.\n\nTrioni's founder and managing director Laurence Harris said: \"We\nwould like to emphasize that business will continue as normal, as we\nhave always sourced milk from other OMSCO farms (organic milk\nsuppliers co-operative) in Pembrokeshire as well as our own.\"\n\nThe company is working with the State Veterinary Service and Assembly\nGovernment to control the outbreak. Culling of dairy cows will start\ntomorrow [7 Jan 2009].\n\nMr. Harris admitted it was \"without doubt\" a stressful time for\nstaff, but he thanked people for their support. He added: \"We are\ndeeply saddened for this to be happening to our farming business. In\ntime, we will look to rebuild our herd but will never be able to\nreplace them, as 3 generations of hard work have gone into building\nthe Ffosyficer herd.\"\n\nTrioni developed its Daioni (\"goodness\" in Welsh) range of organic\nmilk drinks as an alternative to the fizzy sugary drinks generally\navailable for children and launched them in 2003.\n\nThe multi award-winning business has expanded its customer base to\ninclude the Welsh Rugby Union and a number of Premiership football\nteams. It also exports to several countries.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Forgrave]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[DEFRA's provisional bovine TB statistics for Great Britain (England,\nWales and Scotland) from 1 Jan 2008 to 30 Sep 2008, as updated on 1\nDec 2008, are available in 6 pdf tables (Great Britain, West Region,\nNorth Region, East Region, Wales, and Scotland), which are accessible at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/latest.htm>.\n\nAccording to the said tables, the total current number of cattle\nherds registered in Great Britain is 87 258, of which 5399 herds\n(6.19 percent) were under TB2 restrictions because of a TB incident\nat some time during the said period. This is an unusually high\nincidence for a west-European country.\n\nThe detailed Bovine TB Statistics for Wales pertaining to the said\nperiod are available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/08/sept08wales.pdf>.\nThe number of cattle herds registered in Wales is 13 875, of which\n1610 (11.6 percent!!) were under TB2 restrictions. The situation in\nWales deteriorated during 2008: During the entire year in 2007, there\nwere 447 confirmed new TB incidents, compared to 406 such incidents\n(temporary data) during January-September 2008.\n\nThe deplorably deteriorated bTB situation in the UK has already been\nreflected in the introduction of infected animals into importing\nfarms elsewhere (see postings 20080718.2186 and 20080909.2813). - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2008\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, feline - UK (02) 20081126.3722\nBovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence 20081123.3696\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (03): 2005-2006 20081114.3594\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals -
