Some 230 youngstock have\nalready been culled.\n\nThe family-run business, which makes the Daioni range of organic\nflavored milk, has insisted production levels will not be affected.\nIt has also stressed the TB outbreak poses no health risk to\nconsumers, as all its milk is pasteurized.\n\nTrioni's founder and managing director Laurence Harris said: \"We\nwould like to emphasize that business will continue as normal, as we\nhave always sourced milk from other OMSCO farms (organic milk\nsuppliers co-operative) in Pembrokeshire as well as our own.\"\n\nThe company is working with the State Veterinary Service and Assembly\nGovernment to control the outbreak. Culling of dairy cows will start\ntomorrow [7 Jan 2009].\n\nMr. Harris admitted it was \"without doubt\" a stressful time for\nstaff, but he thanked people for their support. He added: \"We are\ndeeply saddened for this to be happening to our farming business. In\ntime, we will look to rebuild our herd but will never be able to\nreplace them, as 3 generations of hard work have gone into building\nthe Ffosyficer herd.\"\n\nTrioni developed its Daioni (\"goodness\" in Welsh) range of organic\nmilk drinks as an alternative to the fizzy sugary drinks generally\navailable for children and launched them in 2003.\n\nThe multi award-winning business has expanded its customer base to\ninclude the Welsh Rugby Union and a number of Premiership football\nteams. It also exports to several countries.\n\n[Byline: Andrew Forgrave]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[DEFRA's provisional bovine TB statistics for Great Britain (England,\nWales and Scotland) from 1 Jan 2008 to 30 Sep 2008, as updated on 1\nDec 2008, are available in 6 pdf tables (Great Britain, West Region,\nNorth Region, East Region, Wales, and Scotland), which are accessible at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/latest.htm>.\n\nAccording to the said tables, the total current number of cattle\nherds registered in Great Britain is 87 258, of which 5399 herds\n(6.19 percent) were under TB2 restrictions because of a TB incident\nat some time during the said period. This is an unusually high\nincidence for a west-European country.\n\nThe detailed Bovine TB Statistics for Wales pertaining to the said\nperiod are available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/stats/08/sept08wales.pdf>.\nThe number of cattle herds registered in Wales is 13 875, of which\n1610 (11.6 percent!!) were under TB2 restrictions. The situation in\nWales deteriorated during 2008: During the entire year in 2007, there\nwere 447 confirmed new TB incidents, compared to 406 such incidents\n(temporary data) during January-September 2008.\n\nThe deplorably deteriorated bTB situation in the UK has already been\nreflected in the introduction of infected animals into importing\nfarms elsewhere (see postings 20080718.2186 and 20080909.2813). - USA (10): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=137900", "date": "2008-11-14 17:00:36", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, DOMESTIC ANIMALS - UK (03): 2005-2006\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 9 Oct 2008 [added/updated]\nSource: The Human Animal Infections and Risk Surveillance (HAIRS)\nGroup First Report 2004-2007 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/web/HPAwebFile/HPAweb_C/1223534078963>\n\n\nTuberculosis in cats and ferrets [2005 and 2006] (page 18)\n----------------------------------------------------------\nIncident\n--------\nin early 2005 the HAIRS group were informed by the VLA [Veterinary\nLaboratory Agency, Defra (UK Department for Environment, Food, and\nRural Affairs), otherwise known as 'Weybridge'. - Mod.MHJ] of an\nincrease in the detection of mycobacterial infections in domestic\ncats during 2004. The reports were predominantly _M. microti_ (10\nisolates) and _M. bovis_ (6 isolates).\n\nProcess\n-------\nThe group monitored reports over several months in 2005, and found\nthat a similar increase had also been seen in ferrets, including an\noutbreak at a ferret rescue centre. Both _Mycobacterium bovis_ and\n_M. microti_ were reported in cats and ferrets. The majority of cases\nwere in rural areas and involved the predominant spoligotypes seen in\nthe areas. Experts from Defra and VLA were consulted and it was noted\nthat the increase may partly have been due to alterations to the\ncharging arrangements for testing, which led to an increase in\nsubmissions in 2004.\n\nThe HAIRS group investigated the situation regarding _M. bovis_ and\nother potentially zoonotic mycobacteria in humans. The HAIRS group\nwere concerned over the potential for zoonotic transmission of\nmycobacteria from these spillover hosts to their owners, however\nthere was no evidence to suggest that zoonotic transmission had occurred.\n\nOutcome\n-------\nIn response to the concerns of the HAIRS group a procedure was\ninitiated whereby HPA reference laboratories send isolates of\nzoonotic mycobacteria from humans for spoligotyping at the Veterinary\nLaboratories Agency, to allow further research to be carried out and\npossible links between human and animal cases identified.\n\nIt was noted at this time that notification of TB in cats was\nnon-statutory and samples were received at VLA on an ad-hoc basis,\ntherefore identifying a trend was complicated. However _M. bovis_\nbecame notifiable in all species during 2007 and this was likely to\nimprove surveillance. The HAIRS group are continuing to monitor this issue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HAIRS is a multiagency group under the Health Protection Agency\numbrella. Two things should be noted:\n1. VLA charging arrangements changed in 2004 and there was an\nimmediate increase in submissions;\n2. _M. bovis_ infections for all species are now notifiable, that is,\ncompulsory reporting. Both factors would have increased the number of\nreported feline TB cases whether or no there was a true increase in\nincidence. Unfortunately, this 9 Oct 2008 report does not cover 2007\nfeline TB events. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\n...................................mhj/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reports were predominantly _M. microti_ (10\nisolates) and _M. bovis_ (6 isolates).\n\nProcess\n-------\nThe group monitored reports over several months in 2005, and found\nthat a similar increase had also been seen in ferrets, including an\noutbreak at a ferret rescue centre. Both _Mycobacterium bovis_ and\n_M. microti_ were reported in cats and ferrets. The majority of cases\nwere in rural areas and involved the predominant spoligotypes seen in\nthe areas. Experts from Defra and VLA were consulted and it was noted\nthat the increase may partly have been due to alterations to the\ncharging arrangements for testing, which led to an increase in\nsubmissions in 2004.\n\nThe HAIRS group investigated the situation regarding _M. bovis_ and\nother potentially zoonotic mycobacteria in humans. The HAIRS group\nwere concerned over the potential for zoonotic transmission of\nmycobacteria from these spillover hosts to their owners, however\nthere was no evidence to suggest that zoonotic transmission had occurred.\n\nOutcome\n-------\nIn response to the concerns of the HAIRS group a procedure was\ninitiated whereby HPA reference laboratories send isolates of\nzoonotic mycobacteria from humans for spoligotyping at the Veterinary\nLaboratories Agency, to allow further research to be carried out and\npossible links between human and animal cases identified.\n\nIt was noted at this time that notification of TB in cats was\nnon-statutory and samples were received at VLA on an ad-hoc basis,\ntherefore identifying a trend was complicated. However _M. bovis_\nbecame notifiable in all species during 2007 and this was likely to\nimprove surveillance. The HAIRS group are continuing to monitor this issue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HAIRS is a multiagency group under the Health Protection Agency\numbrella. Two things should be noted:\n1. VLA charging arrangements changed in 2004 and there was an\nimmediate increase in submissions;\n2. _M. bovis_ infections for all species are now notifiable, that is,\ncompulsory reporting. Both factors would have increased the number of\nreported feline TB cases whether or no there was a true increase in\nincidence. Unfortunately, this 9 Oct 2008 report does not cover 2007\nfeline TB events. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\n...................................mhj/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reports were predominantly _M. microti_ (10\nisolates) and _M. bovis_ (6 isolates).\n\nProcess\n-------\nThe group monitored reports over several months in 2005, and found\nthat a similar increase had also been seen in ferrets, including an\noutbreak at a ferret rescue centre. Both _Mycobacterium bovis_ and\n_M. microti_ were reported in cats and ferrets. The majority of cases\nwere in rural areas and involved the predominant spoligotypes seen in\nthe areas. Experts from Defra and VLA were consulted and it was noted\nthat the increase may partly have been due to alterations to the\ncharging arrangements for testing, which led to an increase in\nsubmissions in 2004.\n\nThe HAIRS group investigated the situation regarding _M. bovis_ and\nother potentially zoonotic mycobacteria in humans. The HAIRS group\nwere concerned over the potential for zoonotic transmission of\nmycobacteria from these spillover hosts to their owners, however\nthere was no evidence to suggest that zoonotic transmission had occurred.\n\nOutcome\n-------\nIn response to the concerns of the HAIRS group a procedure was\ninitiated whereby HPA reference laboratories send isolates of\nzoonotic mycobacteria from humans for spoligotyping at the Veterinary\nLaboratories Agency, to allow further research to be carried out and\npossible links between human and animal cases identified.\n\nIt was noted at this time that notification of TB in cats was\nnon-statutory and samples were received at VLA on an ad-hoc basis,\ntherefore identifying a trend was complicated. However _M. bovis_\nbecame notifiable in all species during 2007 and this was likely to\nimprove surveillance. The HAIRS group are continuing to monitor this issue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HAIRS is a multiagency group under the Health Protection Agency\numbrella. Two things should be noted:\n1. VLA charging arrangements changed in 2004 and there was an\nimmediate increase in submissions;\n2. _M. bovis_ infections for all species are now notifiable, that is,\ncompulsory reporting. Both factors would have increased the number of\nreported feline TB cases whether or no there was a true increase in\nincidence. Unfortunately, this 9 Oct 2008 report does not cover 2007\nfeline TB events. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\n...................................mhj/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Both _Mycobacterium bovis_ and\n_M. microti_ were reported in cats and ferrets. The majority of cases\nwere in rural areas and involved the predominant spoligotypes seen in\nthe areas. Experts from Defra and VLA were consulted and it was noted\nthat the increase may partly have been due to alterations to the\ncharging arrangements for testing, which led to an increase in\nsubmissions in 2004.\n\nThe HAIRS group investigated the situation regarding _M. bovis_ and\nother potentially zoonotic mycobacteria in humans. The HAIRS group\nwere concerned over the potential for zoonotic transmission of\nmycobacteria from these spillover hosts to their owners, however\nthere was no evidence to suggest that zoonotic transmission had occurred.\n\nOutcome\n-------\nIn response to the concerns of the HAIRS group a procedure was\ninitiated whereby HPA reference laboratories send isolates of\nzoonotic mycobacteria from humans for spoligotyping at the Veterinary\nLaboratories Agency, to allow further research to be carried out and\npossible links between human and animal cases identified.\n\nIt was noted at this time that notification of TB in cats was\nnon-statutory and samples were received at VLA on an ad-hoc basis,\ntherefore identifying a trend was complicated. However _M. bovis_\nbecame notifiable in all species during 2007 and this was likely to\nimprove surveillance. The HAIRS group are continuing to monitor this issue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HAIRS is a multiagency group under the Health Protection Agency\numbrella. Two things should be noted:\n1. VLA charging arrangements changed in 2004 and there was an\nimmediate increase in submissions;\n2. _M. bovis_ infections for all species are now notifiable, that is,\ncompulsory reporting. Both factors would have increased the number of\nreported feline TB cases whether or no there was a true increase in\nincidence. Unfortunately, this 9 Oct 2008 report does not cover 2007\nfeline TB events. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\n...................................mhj/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "129620", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis - UK: increased incidence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=129620", "date": "2008-11-14 17:00:36", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, DOMESTIC ANIMALS - UK (03): 2005-2006\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 9 Oct 2008 [added/updated]\nSource: The Human Animal Infections and Risk Surveillance (HAIRS)\nGroup First Report 2004-2007 [edited]\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/web/HPAwebFile/HPAweb_C/1223534078963>\n\n\nTuberculosis in cats and ferrets [2005 and 2006] (page 18)\n----------------------------------------------------------\nIncident\n--------\nin early 2005 the HAIRS group were informed by the VLA [Veterinary\nLaboratory Agency, Defra (UK Department for Environment, Food, and\nRural Affairs), otherwise known as 'Weybridge'. - Mod.MHJ] of an\nincrease in the detection of mycobacterial infections in domestic\ncats during 2004. The reports were predominantly _M. microti_ (10\nisolates) and _M. bovis_ (6 isolates).\n\nProcess\n-------\nThe group monitored reports over several months in 2005, and found\nthat a similar increase had also been seen in ferrets, including an\noutbreak at a ferret rescue centre. Both _Mycobacterium bovis_ and\n_M. microti_ were reported in cats and ferrets. The majority of cases\nwere in rural areas and involved the predominant spoligotypes seen in\nthe areas. Experts from Defra and VLA were consulted and it was noted\nthat the increase may partly have been due to alterations to the\ncharging arrangements for testing, which led to an increase in\nsubmissions in 2004.\n\nThe HAIRS group investigated the situation regarding _M. bovis_ and\nother potentially zoonotic mycobacteria in humans. The HAIRS group\nwere concerned over the potential for zoonotic transmission of\nmycobacteria from these spillover hosts to their owners, however\nthere was no evidence to suggest that zoonotic transmission had occurred.\n\nOutcome\n-------\nIn response to the concerns of the HAIRS group a procedure was\ninitiated whereby HPA reference laboratories send isolates of\nzoonotic mycobacteria from humans for spoligotyping at the Veterinary\nLaboratories Agency, to allow further research to be carried out and\npossible links between human and animal cases identified.\n\nIt was noted at this time that notification of TB in cats was\nnon-statutory and samples were received at VLA on an ad-hoc basis,\ntherefore identifying a trend was complicated. However _M. bovis_\nbecame notifiable in all species during 2007 and this was likely to\nimprove surveillance. The HAIRS group are continuing to monitor this issue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HAIRS is a multiagency group under the Health Protection Agency\numbrella. Two things should be noted:\n1. VLA charging arrangements changed in 2004 and there was an\nimmediate increase in submissions;\n2. _M. bovis_ infections for all species are now notifiable, that is,\ncompulsory reporting. Both factors would have increased the number of\nreported feline TB cases whether or no there was a true increase in\nincidence. Unfortunately, this 9 Oct 2008 report does not cover 2007\nfeline TB events. - Mod.MHJ]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02) 20081112.3565\nBovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK 20081111.3551\n...................................mhj/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Both _Mycobacterium bovis_ and\n_M. microti_ were reported in cats and ferrets. The majority of cases\nwere in rural areas and involved the predominant spoligotypes seen in\nthe areas. Experts from Defra and VLA were consulted and it was noted\nthat the increase may partly have been due to alterations to the\ncharging arrangements for testing, which led to an increase in\nsubmissions in 2004.\n\nThe HAIRS group investigated the situation regarding _M. bovis_ and\nother potentially zoonotic mycobacteria in humans. The HAIRS group are continuing to monitor this issue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HAIRS is a multiagency group under the Health Protection Agency\numbrella. "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "127142", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=127142", "date": "2008-09-09 14:00:31", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NETHERLANDS ex UNITED KINGDOM: EU CONSULTATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 2 Sep 2008\nSource: EU Directorate for Health and Consumers [edited]\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/report_working_group_bovine_tuberculosis.pdf>\n\n\nReport on the Working Group meeting on bovine tuberculosis\n----------------------------------------------------------\nFollowing the extraordinary Standing Committee for Food Chain and\nAnimal Health (SCFCAH) [meeting] of 23 Jul 2008 where the findings of\nbovine tuberculosis (TB) in young calves introduced from the United\nKingdom into the Netherlands via intra-Community trade were\ndiscussed, on 2 Sep 2008, a Working Group of experts on bovine\ntuberculosis was organised.\n\nThe Commission invited representatives of all Member States and 6\nprivate experts (Director of the Community reference laboratory on\ntuberculosis and 5 members of the Task Force Sub-group on bovine\ntuberculosis).\n\nObjective of the meeting\n------------------------\nThe purpose of the meeting was to explore with the Member States\nmeasures to prevent the spread of bovine tuberculosis [TB] from areas\nwith high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade in live\ncattle, and in particular calves under 42 days of age that are\nstatutory not subject to pre-movement testing.\n\nBackground\n----------\nIn July 2008, the Netherlands (officially bovine tuberculosis-free\nMember State), based on the epidemiological investigation followed by\nthe notification received from the United Kingdom, detected a number\nof cases of infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ in calves under 42\ndays of age coming from a single holding in the United Kingdom, that\nwent down with tuberculosis after the dispatch of the animals.\n\nDutch and Belgian farmers have self imposed a ban on British cattle\nfollowing the revelation that 12 veal calves were positive for bovine\ntuberculosis. The Dutch Agriculture Ministry has condemned this\nbreech of biosecurity, particularly as there has been no TB in the\nNetherlands since 1999.\n\nDue to the arisen situation, on 23 Jul 2008 the Commission organised\nan extraordinary SCFCAH meeting in order to clarify the TB situation\nin the UK and exchange opinion with the Member States on the measures\nto be taken in that respect.\n\nDuring the meeting the Member States agreed that at this point in\ntime immediate additional Community measures are not needed. The UK\nagreed to reinforce the controls on such movements, to ensure that\nDirective 64/432/EEC is fully applied, and that relevant information\nis transmitted to Member States of destination without delay.\n\nMember States engaged themselves to monitor the situation and to\ninform the Commission in case of new findings.\n\nMoreover, the Commission committed itself to set up in the 1st days\nof September 2008 an expert meeting to further discuss the issue and\npossible Community-wide measures.\n\nGeneral discussion and issues raised by the participants\n--------------------------------------------------------\nThe Netherlands presented the situation and the measures taken due to\nthe detection of TB positive calves below 6 weeks of age introduced\nvia intra-Community trade to the officially TB free bovine herds at\ntheir territory.\n\nThe United Kingdom updated the participants on the current situation\nas regards bovine tuberculosis on the territory of their country and\non measures taken in relation to the breakdown in an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd of origin of the calves, found later TB\npositive in the Netherlands. The UK emphasised that this isolated\nincident was due to a case of bovine tuberculosis mastitis.\n\nCertain Member States and in particular the Netherlands urged that\naction be taken at all levels and especially by the Member States not\nyet officially bovine tuberculosis-free to ensure that eradication of\nthe disease is accelerated.\n\nThe Commission gave a brief overview of the Community legislation on\nbovine tuberculosis noting that calves under 42 days of age are\nexempted for the requirement of the pre-movement testing and that in\nthis case, current EU provisions rely only on the status of the herd.\nIn addition, the Commission presented for discussion 4 possible\nalternative provisions which could be implemented, either one at a\ntime or in combination, in order to prevent the spread of TB from\nareas with high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade\nin calves under 42 days of age, and in particular apart from the\nmandatory officially tuberculosis-free herd origin:\n\n1. Pre-movement test (intradermal skin test or gamma interferon test)\nof individual animals concerned;\n2. Low prevalence region origin (below 1 or 0,5 percent or other);\n3. Recent herd test (such as, less then 6 months) with strictly\ndefined frequency of testing the herd (annual, twice a year, etc.);\n4. Channelling procedure (post-movement test at destination or\ndispatched to a holding at destination from which they can only be\nmoved directly to a slaughterhouse).\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThere was general consensus on:\n- the need to ensure that the officially bovine tuberculosis-free (TB\nOF) status is properly granted to the herds, as this is the basic\nrequirement in order to ensure safe trade;\n- the pre-movement testing is not suitable for animals younger than\n42 days of age due to the lack of sensitivity of the test when used\non these animals;\n- there is a need to have proportionate and effective measures in\norder to address the risk posed by these animals that cannot be\ntested before movement.\n\nAn acceptable regime for animals below 42 days of age would be as follows:\nBovine animals for breeding and production less than 42 days old\nshall only be dispatched to other Member States if they come from an\nofficially tuberculosis-free bovine herd as defined in Article\n2(2)(d) of Directive 64/432/EEC, and:\n\n1. The holding of origin is situated in a Member State or a region of\na Member State as defined in Article 2(2)(p) of Directive 64/432/EEC\nin which on average, determined at 31 December of each year, the\nannual percentages of bovine herds confirmed as infected with\ntuberculosis is not more than 0.5 percent of all herds within the\nMember State or region thereof, or\n2. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the routine intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B\nto Directive 64/432/EEC at an interval of more than 3 months and less\nthan 6 months during the last 12 months, or\n3. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B to\nDirective 64/432/EEC, carried out in the 30 days prior to the\nmovement, or\n4. The animals are consigned, through a channelling procedure under\nthe control of the competent authority of the place of destination,\nto a holding from where they can only be removed:\na. to be transported directly to the slaughterhouse for slaughter in\naccordance with the first indent of Article 7 of Directive\n64/432/EEC, or\nb. to be introduced not earlier than at the age of at least 42 days\ninto another herd in accordance with the procedure provided for in\npoint 1(c) of Section I of Annex A to Directive 64/432/EEC [see\ncommentary. - Mod.AS]\n\nOn 3 Sep 2008 the conclusions of the meeting were presented to the\nStanding Committee for Food Chain and Animal Health under point 4D of\nthe Committee's agenda.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Directive 64/432/EEC, point C of section I in Annex A says: \"no\nbovine animal has been introduced without a certificate from an\nofficial veterinarian showing that the animal has reacted negatively\nto an intradermal tuberculin test assessed according to the criteria\nset out in Annex B 21 (a) and that it comes from an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd\".\n\nArticle 21 (a) of Annex B says: \"the result of the intradermal\ntuberculin test must be read after 72 hours and assessed according to\nthe following method: (a) negative reaction: if only limited swelling\nis observed, with an increase of not more than 2 mm in the thickness\nof the fold of skin without clinical signs such as pasty consistency,\nexudation, necrosis, pain or inflammation of the lymphatic ducts in\nthat region and of the lymph nodes. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK 20080718.2186\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (02) 20061011.2915\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-09-02 00:00:00", "2008-07-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-07-23 00:00:00", "2008-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UNITED KINGDOM", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "126830", "headline": "PRO/AH> Bovine tuberculosis, domestic animals - UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=126830", "date": "2008-09-09 14:00:31", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NETHERLANDS ex UNITED KINGDOM: EU CONSULTATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 2 Sep 2008\nSource: EU Directorate for Health and Consumers [edited]\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/report_working_group_bovine_tuberculosis.pdf>\n\n\nReport on the Working Group meeting on bovine tuberculosis\n----------------------------------------------------------\nFollowing the extraordinary Standing Committee for Food Chain and\nAnimal Health (SCFCAH) [meeting] of 23 Jul 2008 where the findings of\nbovine tuberculosis (TB) in young calves introduced from the United\nKingdom into the Netherlands via intra-Community trade were\ndiscussed, on 2 Sep 2008, a Working Group of experts on Pre-movement test (intradermal skin test or gamma interferon test)\nof individual animals concerned;\n2. Low prevalence region origin (below 1 or 0,5 percent or other);\n3. Recent herd test (such as, less then 6 months) with strictly\ndefined frequency of testing the herd (annual, twice a year, etc.);\n4. Channelling procedure (post-movement test at destination or\ndispatched to a holding at destination from which they can only be\nmoved directly to a slaughterhouse).\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThere was general consensus on:\n- the need to ensure that the officially bovine tuberculosis-free (TB\nOF) status is properly granted to the herds, as this is the basic\nrequirement in order to ensure safe trade;\n- the pre-movement testing is not suitable for animals younger than\n42 days of age due to the lack of sensitivity of the test when used\non these animals;\n- there is a need to have proportionate and effective measures in\norder to address the risk posed by these animals that cannot be\ntested before movement.\n\nAn acceptable regime for animals below 42 days of age would be as follows:\nBovine animals for breeding and production less than 42 days old\nshall only be dispatched to other Member States if they come from an\nofficially tuberculosis-free bovine herd as defined in Article\n2(2)(d) of Directive 64/432/EEC, and:\n\n1. The holding of origin is situated in a Member State or a region of\na Member State as defined in Article 2(2)(p) of Directive 64/432/EEC\nin which on average, determined at 31 December of each year, the\nannual percentages of bovine herds confirmed as infected with\ntuberculosis is not more than 0.5 percent of all herds within the\nMember State or region thereof, or\n2. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the routine intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B\nto Directive 64/432/EEC at an interval of more than 3 months and less\nthan 6 months during the last 12 months, or\n3. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B to\nDirective 64/432/EEC, carried out in the 30 days prior to the\nmovement, or\n4. The animals are consigned, through a channelling procedure under\nthe control of the competent authority of the place of destination,\nto a holding from where they can only be removed:\na. to be transported directly to the slaughterhouse for slaughter in\naccordance with the first indent of Article 7 of Directive\n64/432/EEC, or\nb. to be introduced not earlier than at the age of at least 42 days\ninto another herd in accordance with the procedure provided for in\npoint 1(c) of Section I of Annex A to Directive 64/432/EEC [see\ncommentary. - Mod.AS]\n\nOn 3 Sep 2008 the conclusions of the meeting were presented to the\nStanding Committee for Food Chain and Animal Health under point 4D of\nthe Committee's agenda.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Directive 64/432/EEC, point C of section I in Annex A says: \"no\nbovine animal has been introduced without a certificate from an\nofficial veterinarian showing that the animal has reacted negatively\nto an intradermal tuberculin test assessed according to the criteria\nset out in Annex B 21 (a) and that it comes from an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd\".\n\nArticle 21 (a) of Annex B says: \"the result of the intradermal\ntuberculin test must be read after 72 hours and assessed according to\nthe following method: (a) negative reaction: if only limited swelling\nis observed, with an increase of not more than 2 mm in the thickness\nof the fold of skin without clinical signs such as pasty consistency,\nexudation, necrosis, pain or inflammation of the lymphatic ducts in\nthat region and of the lymph nodes. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK 20080718.2186\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (02) 20061011.2915\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-09-02 00:00:00", "2008-07-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-07-23 00:00:00", "2008-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UNITED KINGDOM", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "120440", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, cervids - USA: (NY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=120440", "date": "2008-09-09 14:00:31", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NETHERLANDS ex UNITED KINGDOM: EU CONSULTATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 2 Sep 2008\nSource: EU Directorate for Health and Consumers [edited]\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/report_working_group_bovine_tuberculosis.pdf>\n\n\nReport on the Working Group meeting on bovine tuberculosis\n----------------------------------------------------------\nFollowing the extraordinary Standing Committee for Food Chain and\nAnimal Health (SCFCAH) [meeting] of 23 Jul 2008 where the findings of\nbovine tuberculosis (TB) in young calves introduced from the United\nKingdom into the Netherlands via intra-Community trade were\ndiscussed, on 2 Sep 2008, a Working Group of experts on bovine\ntuberculosis was organised.\n\nThe Commission invited representatives of all Member States and 6\nprivate experts (Director of the Community reference laboratory on\ntuberculosis and 5 members of the Task Force Sub-group on bovine\ntuberculosis).\n\nObjective of the meeting\n------------------------\nThe purpose of the meeting was to explore with the Member States\nmeasures to prevent the spread of bovine tuberculosis [TB] from areas\nwith high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade in live\ncattle, and in particular calves under 42 days of age that are\nstatutory not subject to pre-movement testing.\n\nBackground\n----------\nIn July 2008, the Netherlands (officially bovine tuberculosis-free\nMember State), based on the epidemiological investigation followed by\nthe notification received from the United Kingdom, detected a number\nof cases of infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ in calves under 42\ndays of age coming from a single holding in the United Kingdom, that\nwent down with tuberculosis after the dispatch of the animals.\n\nDutch and Belgian farmers have self imposed a ban on British cattle\nfollowing the revelation that 12 veal calves were positive for bovine\ntuberculosis. The Dutch Agriculture Ministry has condemned this\nbreech of biosecurity, particularly as there has been no TB in the\nNetherlands since 1999.\n\nDue to the arisen situation, on 23 Jul 2008 the Commission organised\nan extraordinary SCFCAH meeting in order to clarify the TB situation\nin the UK and exchange opinion with the Member States on the measures\nto be taken in that respect.\n\nDuring the meeting the Member States agreed that at this point in\ntime immediate additional Community measures are not needed. The UK\nagreed to reinforce the controls on such movements, to ensure that\nDirective 64/432/EEC is fully applied, and that relevant information\nis transmitted to Member States of destination without delay.\n\nMember States engaged themselves to monitor the situation and to\ninform the Commission in case of new findings.\n\nMoreover, the Commission committed itself to set up in the 1st days\nof September 2008 an expert meeting to further discuss the issue and\npossible Community-wide measures.\n\nGeneral discussion and issues raised by the participants\n--------------------------------------------------------\nThe Netherlands presented the situation and the measures taken due to\nthe detection of TB positive calves below 6 weeks of age introduced\nvia intra-Community trade to the officially TB free bovine herds at\ntheir territory.\n\nThe United Kingdom updated the participants on the current situation\nas regards bovine tuberculosis on the territory of their country and\non measures taken in relation to the breakdown in an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd of origin of the calves, found later TB\npositive in the Netherlands. The UK emphasised that this isolated\nincident was due to a case of bovine tuberculosis mastitis.\n\nCertain Member States and in particular the Netherlands urged that\naction be taken at all levels and especially by the Member States not\nyet officially bovine tuberculosis-free to ensure that eradication of\nthe disease is accelerated.\n\nThe Commission gave a brief overview of the Community legislation on\nbovine tuberculosis noting that calves under 42 days of age are\nexempted for the requirement of the pre-movement testing and that in\nthis case, current EU provisions rely only on the status of the herd.\nIn addition, the Commission presented for discussion 4 possible\nalternative provisions which could be implemented, either one at a\ntime or in combination, in order to prevent the spread of TB from\nareas with high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade\nin calves under 42 days of age, and in particular apart from the\nmandatory officially tuberculosis-free herd origin:\n\n1. Pre-movement test (intradermal skin test or gamma interferon test)\nof individual animals concerned;\n2. Low prevalence region origin (below 1 or 0,5 percent or other);\n3. Recent herd test (such as, less then 6 months) with strictly\ndefined frequency of testing the herd (annual, twice a year, etc.);\n4. Channelling procedure (post-movement test at destination or\ndispatched to a holding at destination from which they can only be\nmoved directly to a slaughterhouse).\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThere was general consensus on:\n- the need to ensure that the officially bovine tuberculosis-free (TB\nOF) status is properly granted to the herds, as this is the basic\nrequirement in order to ensure safe trade;\n- the pre-movement testing is not suitable for animals younger than\n42 days of age due to the lack of sensitivity of the test when used\non these animals;\n- there is a need to have proportionate and effective measures in\norder to address the risk posed by these animals that cannot be\ntested before movement.\n\nAn acceptable regime for animals below 42 days of age would be as follows:\nBovine animals for breeding and production less than 42 days old\nshall only be dispatched to other Member States if they come from an\nofficially tuberculosis-free bovine herd as defined in Article\n2(2)(d) of Directive 64/432/EEC, and:\n\n1. The holding of origin is situated in a Member State or a region of\na Member State as defined in Article 2(2)(p) of Directive 64/432/EEC\nin which on average, determined at 31 December of each year, the\nannual percentages of bovine herds confirmed as infected with\ntuberculosis is not more than 0.5 percent of all herds within the\nMember State or region thereof, or\n2. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the routine intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B\nto Directive 64/432/EEC at an interval of more than 3 months and less\nthan 6 months during the last 12 months, or\n3. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B to\nDirective 64/432/EEC, carried out in the 30 days prior to the\nmovement, or\n4. The animals are consigned, through a channelling procedure under\nthe control of the competent authority of the place of destination,\nto a holding from where they can only be removed:\na. to be transported directly to the slaughterhouse for slaughter in\naccordance with the first indent of Article 7 of Directive\n64/432/EEC, or\nb. to be introduced not earlier than at the age of at least 42 days\ninto another herd in accordance with the procedure provided for in\npoint 1(c) of Section I of Annex A to Directive 64/432/EEC [see\ncommentary. - Mod.AS]\n\nOn 3 Sep 2008 the conclusions of the meeting were presented to the\nStanding Committee for Food Chain and Animal Health under point 4D of\nthe Committee's agenda.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Directive 64/432/EEC, point C of section I in Annex A says: \"no\nbovine animal has been introduced without a certificate from an\nofficial veterinarian showing that the animal has reacted negatively\nto an intradermal tuberculin test assessed according to the criteria\nset out in Annex B 21 (a) and that it comes from an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd\".\n\nArticle 21 (a) of Annex B says: \"the result of the intradermal\ntuberculin test must be read after 72 hours and assessed according to\nthe following method: (a) negative reaction: if only limited swelling\nis observed, with an increase of not more than 2 mm in the thickness\nof the fold of skin without clinical signs such as pasty consistency,\nexudation, necrosis, pain or inflammation of the lymphatic ducts in\nthat region and of the lymph nodes. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK 20080718.2186\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (02) 20061011.2915\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. CONSULTATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 2 Sep 2008\nSource: EU Directorate for Health and Consumers [edited]\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/report_working_group_bovine_tuberculosis.pdf>\n\n\nReport on the Working Group meeting on bovine "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=116864", "date": "2008-09-09 14:00:31", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NETHERLANDS ex UNITED KINGDOM: EU CONSULTATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 2 Sep 2008\nSource: EU Directorate for Health and Consumers [edited]\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/report_working_group_bovine_tuberculosis.pdf>\n\n\nReport on the Working Group meeting on bovine tuberculosis\n----------------------------------------------------------\nFollowing the extraordinary Standing Committee for Food Chain and\nAnimal Health (SCFCAH) [meeting] of 23 Jul 2008 where the findings of\nbovine tuberculosis (TB) in young calves introduced from the United\nKingdom into the Netherlands via intra-Community trade were\ndiscussed, on 2 Sep 2008, a Working Group of experts on bovine\ntuberculosis was organised.\n\nThe Commission invited representatives of all Member States and 6\nprivate experts (Director of the Community reference laboratory on\ntuberculosis and 5 members of the Task Force Sub-group on bovine\ntuberculosis).\n\nObjective of the meeting\n------------------------\nThe purpose of the meeting was to explore with the Member States\nmeasures to prevent the spread of bovine tuberculosis [TB] from areas\nwith high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade in live\ncattle, and in particular calves under 42 days of age that are\nstatutory not subject to pre-movement testing.\n\nBackground\n----------\nIn July 2008, the Netherlands (officially bovine tuberculosis-free\nMember State), based on the epidemiological investigation followed by\nthe notification received from the United Kingdom, detected a number\nof cases of infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ in calves under 42\ndays of age coming from a single holding in the United Kingdom, that\nwent down with tuberculosis after the dispatch of the animals.\n\nDutch and Belgian farmers have self imposed a ban on British cattle\nfollowing the revelation that 12 veal calves were positive for bovine\ntuberculosis. The Dutch Agriculture Ministry has condemned this\nbreech of biosecurity, particularly as there has been no TB in the\nNetherlands since 1999.\n\nDue to the arisen situation, on 23 Jul 2008 the Commission organised\nan extraordinary SCFCAH meeting in order to clarify the TB situation\nin the UK and exchange opinion with the Member States on the measures\nto be taken in that respect.\n\nDuring the meeting the Member States agreed that at this point in\ntime immediate additional Community measures are not needed. The UK\nagreed to reinforce the controls on such movements, to ensure that\nDirective 64/432/EEC is fully applied, and that relevant information\nis transmitted to Member States of destination without delay.\n\nMember States engaged themselves to monitor the situation and to\ninform the Commission in case of new findings.\n\nMoreover, the Commission committed itself to set up in the 1st days\nof September 2008 an expert meeting to further discuss the issue and\npossible Community-wide measures.\n\nGeneral discussion and issues raised by the participants\n--------------------------------------------------------\nThe Netherlands presented the situation and the measures taken due to\nthe detection of TB positive calves below 6 weeks of age introduced\nvia intra-Community trade to the officially TB free bovine herds at\ntheir territory.\n\nThe United Kingdom updated the participants on the current situation\nas regards bovine tuberculosis on the territory of their country and\non measures taken in relation to the breakdown in an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd of origin of the calves, found later TB\npositive in the Netherlands. The UK emphasised that this isolated\nincident was due to a case of bovine tuberculosis mastitis.\n\nCertain Member States and in particular the Netherlands urged that\naction be taken at all levels and especially by the Member States not\nyet officially bovine tuberculosis-free to ensure that eradication of\nthe disease is accelerated.\n\nThe Commission gave a brief overview of the Community legislation on\nbovine tuberculosis noting that calves under 42 days of age are\nexempted for the requirement of the pre-movement testing and that in\nthis case, current EU provisions rely only on the status of the herd.\nIn addition, the Commission presented for discussion 4 possible\nalternative provisions which could be implemented, either one at a\ntime or in combination, in order to prevent the spread of TB from\nareas with high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade\nin calves under 42 days of age, and in particular apart from the\nmandatory officially tuberculosis-free herd origin:\n\n1. Pre-movement test (intradermal skin test or gamma interferon test)\nof individual animals concerned;\n2. Low prevalence region origin (below 1 or 0,5 percent or other);\n3. Recent herd test (such as, less then 6 months) with strictly\ndefined frequency of testing the herd (annual, twice a year, etc.);\n4. Channelling procedure (post-movement test at destination or\ndispatched to a holding at destination from which they can only be\nmoved directly to a slaughterhouse).\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThere was general consensus on:\n- the need to ensure that the officially bovine tuberculosis-free (TB\nOF) status is properly granted to the herds, as this is the basic\nrequirement in order to ensure safe trade;\n- the pre-movement testing is not suitable for animals younger than\n42 days of age due to the lack of sensitivity of the test when used\non these animals;\n- there is a need to have proportionate and effective measures in\norder to address the risk posed by these animals that cannot be\ntested before movement.\n\nAn acceptable regime for animals below 42 days of age would be as follows:\nBovine animals for breeding and production less than 42 days old\nshall only be dispatched to other Member States if they come from an\nofficially tuberculosis-free bovine herd as defined in Article\n2(2)(d) of Directive 64/432/EEC, and:\n\n1. The holding of origin is situated in a Member State or a region of\na Member State as defined in Article 2(2)(p) of Directive 64/432/EEC\nin which on average, determined at 31 December of each year, the\nannual percentages of bovine herds confirmed as infected with\ntuberculosis is not more than 0.5 percent of all herds within the\nMember State or region thereof, or\n2. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the routine intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B\nto Directive 64/432/EEC at an interval of more than 3 months and less\nthan 6 months during the last 12 months, or\n3. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B to\nDirective 64/432/EEC, carried out in the 30 days prior to the\nmovement, or\n4. The animals are consigned, through a channelling procedure under\nthe control of the competent authority of the place of destination,\nto a holding from where they can only be removed:\na. to be transported directly to the slaughterhouse for slaughter in\naccordance with the first indent of Article 7 of Directive\n64/432/EEC, or\nb. to be introduced not earlier than at the age of at least 42 days\ninto another herd in accordance with the procedure provided for in\npoint 1(c) of Section I of Annex A to Directive 64/432/EEC [see\ncommentary. - Mod.AS]\n\nOn 3 Sep 2008 the conclusions of the meeting were presented to the\nStanding Committee for Food Chain and Animal Health under point 4D of\nthe Committee's agenda.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Directive 64/432/EEC, point C of section I in Annex A says: \"no\nbovine animal has been introduced without a certificate from an\nofficial veterinarian showing that the animal has reacted negatively\nto an intradermal tuberculin test assessed according to the criteria\nset out in Annex B 21 (a) and that it comes from an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd\".\n\nArticle 21 (a) of Annex B says: \"the result of the intradermal\ntuberculin test must be read after 72 hours and assessed according to\nthe following method: (a) negative reaction: if only limited swelling\nis observed, with an increase of not more than 2 mm in the thickness\nof the fold of skin without clinical signs such as pasty consistency,\nexudation, necrosis, pain or inflammation of the lymphatic ducts in\nthat region and of the lymph nodes. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK 20080718.2186\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (02) 20061011.2915\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=114829", "date": "2008-09-09 14:00:31", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NETHERLANDS ex UNITED KINGDOM: EU CONSULTATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 2 Sep 2008\nSource: EU Directorate for Health and Consumers [edited]\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/report_working_group_bovine_tuberculosis.pdf>\n\n\nReport on the Working Group meeting on bovine tuberculosis\n----------------------------------------------------------\nFollowing the extraordinary Standing Committee for Food Chain and\nAnimal Health (SCFCAH) [meeting] of 23 Jul 2008 where the findings of\nbovine tuberculosis (TB) in young calves introduced from the United\nKingdom into the Netherlands via intra-Community trade were\ndiscussed, on 2 Sep 2008, a Working Group of experts on bovine\ntuberculosis was organised.\n\nThe Commission invited representatives of all Member States and 6\nprivate experts (Director of the Community reference laboratory on\ntuberculosis and 5 members of the Task Force Sub-group on bovine\ntuberculosis).\n\nObjective of the meeting\n------------------------\nThe purpose of the meeting was to explore with the Member States\nmeasures to prevent the spread of bovine tuberculosis [TB] from areas\nwith high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade in live\ncattle, and in particular calves under 42 days of age that are\nstatutory not subject to pre-movement testing.\n\nBackground\n----------\nIn July 2008, the Netherlands (officially bovine tuberculosis-free\nMember State), based on the epidemiological investigation followed by\nthe notification received from the United Kingdom, detected a number\nof cases of infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ in calves under 42\ndays of age coming from a single holding in the United Kingdom, that\nwent down with tuberculosis after the dispatch of the animals.\n\nDutch and Belgian farmers have self imposed a ban on British cattle\nfollowing the revelation that 12 veal calves were positive for bovine\ntuberculosis. The Dutch Agriculture Ministry has condemned this\nbreech of biosecurity, particularly as there has been no TB in the\nNetherlands since 1999.\n\nDue to the arisen situation, on 23 Jul 2008 the Commission organised\nan extraordinary SCFCAH meeting in order to clarify the TB situation\nin the UK and exchange opinion with the Member States on the measures\nto be taken in that respect.\n\nDuring the meeting the Member States agreed that at this point in\ntime immediate additional Community measures are not needed. The UK\nagreed to reinforce the controls on such movements, to ensure that\nDirective 64/432/EEC is fully applied, and that relevant information\nis transmitted to Member States of destination without delay.\n\nMember States engaged themselves to monitor the situation and to\ninform the Commission in case of new findings.\n\nMoreover, the Commission committed itself to set up in the 1st days\nof September 2008 an expert meeting to further discuss the issue and\npossible Community-wide measures.\n\nGeneral discussion and issues raised by the participants\n--------------------------------------------------------\nThe Netherlands presented the situation and the measures taken due to\nthe detection of TB positive calves below 6 weeks of age introduced\nvia intra-Community trade to the officially TB free bovine herds at\ntheir territory.\n\nThe United Kingdom updated the participants on the current situation\nas regards bovine tuberculosis on the territory of their country and\non measures taken in relation to the breakdown in an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd of origin of the calves, found later TB\npositive in the Netherlands. The UK emphasised that this isolated\nincident was due to a case of bovine tuberculosis mastitis.\n\nCertain Member States and in particular the Netherlands urged that\naction be taken at all levels and especially by the Member States not\nyet officially bovine tuberculosis-free to ensure that eradication of\nthe disease is accelerated.\n\nThe Commission gave a brief overview of the Community legislation on\nbovine tuberculosis noting that calves under 42 days of age are\nexempted for the requirement of the pre-movement testing and that in\nthis case, current EU provisions rely only on the status of the herd.\nIn addition, the Commission presented for discussion 4 possible\nalternative provisions which could be implemented, either one at a\ntime or in combination, in order to prevent the spread of TB from\nareas with high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade\nin calves under 42 days of age, and in particular apart from the\nmandatory officially tuberculosis-free herd origin:\n\n1. Recent herd test (such as, less then 6 months) with strictly\ndefined frequency of testing the herd (annual, twice a year, etc.);\n4. Channelling procedure (post-movement test at destination or\ndispatched to a holding at destination from which they can only be\nmoved directly to a slaughterhouse).\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThere was general consensus on:\n- the need to ensure that the officially bovine tuberculosis-free (TB\nOF) status is properly granted to the herds, as this is the basic\nrequirement in order to ensure safe trade;\n- the pre-movement testing is not suitable for animals younger than\n42 days of age due to the lack of sensitivity of the test when used\non these animals;\n- there is a need to have proportionate and effective measures in\norder to address the risk posed by these animals that cannot be\ntested before movement.\n\nAn acceptable regime for animals below 42 days of age would be as follows:\nBovine animals for breeding and production less than 42 days old\nshall only be dispatched to other Member States if they come from an\nofficially tuberculosis-free bovine herd as defined in Article\n2(2)(d) of Directive 64/432/EEC, and:\n\n1. The holding of origin is situated in a Member State or a region of\na Member State as defined in Article 2(2)(p) of Directive 64/432/EEC\nin which on average, determined at 31 December of each year, the\nannual percentages of bovine herds confirmed as infected with\ntuberculosis is not more than 0.5 percent of all herds within the\nMember State or region thereof, or\n2. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the routine intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B\nto Directive 64/432/EEC at an interval of more than 3 months and less\nthan 6 months during the last 12 months, or\n3. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B to\nDirective 64/432/EEC, carried out in the 30 days prior to the\nmovement, or\n4. The animals are consigned, through a channelling procedure under\nthe control of the competent authority of the place of destination,\nto a holding from where they can only be removed:\na. to be transported directly to the slaughterhouse for slaughter in\naccordance with the first indent of Article 7 of Directive\n64/432/EEC, or\nb. to be introduced not earlier than at the age of at least 42 days\ninto another herd in accordance with the procedure provided for in\npoint 1(c) of Section I of Annex A to Directive 64/432/EEC [see\ncommentary. - "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=110536", "date": "2008-09-09 14:00:31", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NETHERLANDS ex UNITED KINGDOM: EU CONSULTATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 2 Sep 2008\nSource: EU Directorate for Health and Consumers [edited]\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/report_working_group_bovine_tuberculosis.pdf>\n\n\nReport on the Working Group meeting on bovine tuberculosis\n----------------------------------------------------------\nFollowing the extraordinary Standing Committee for Food Chain and\nAnimal Health (SCFCAH) [meeting] of 23 Jul 2008 where the findings of\nbovine tuberculosis (TB) in young calves introduced from the United\nKingdom into the Netherlands via intra-Community trade were\ndiscussed, on 2 Sep 2008, a Working Group of experts on bovine\ntuberculosis was organised.\n\nThe Commission invited representatives of all Member States and 6\nprivate experts (Director of the Community reference laboratory on\ntuberculosis and 5 members of the Task Force Sub-group on bovine\ntuberculosis).\n\nObjective of the meeting\n------------------------\nThe purpose of the meeting was to explore with the Member States\nmeasures to prevent the spread of bovine tuberculosis [TB] from areas\nwith high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade in live\ncattle, and in particular calves under 42 days of age that are\nstatutory not subject to pre-movement testing.\n\nBackground\n----------\nIn July 2008, the Netherlands (officially bovine tuberculosis-free\nMember State), based on the epidemiological investigation followed by\nthe notification received from the United Kingdom, detected a number\nof cases of infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ in calves under 42\ndays of age coming from a single holding in the United Kingdom, that\nwent down with tuberculosis after the dispatch of the animals.\n\nDutch and Belgian farmers have self imposed a ban on British cattle\nfollowing the revelation that 12 veal calves were positive for bovine\ntuberculosis. The Dutch Agriculture Ministry has condemned this\nbreech of biosecurity, particularly as there has been no TB in the\nNetherlands since 1999.\n\nDue to the arisen situation, on 23 Jul 2008 the Commission organised\nan extraordinary SCFCAH meeting in order to clarify the TB situation\nin the UK and exchange opinion with the Member States on the measures\nto be taken in that respect.\n\nDuring the meeting the Member States agreed that at this point in\ntime immediate additional Community measures are not needed. The UK\nagreed to reinforce the controls on such movements, to ensure that\nDirective 64/432/EEC is fully applied, and that relevant information\nis transmitted to Member States of destination without delay.\n\nMember States engaged themselves to monitor the situation and to\ninform the Commission in case of new findings.\n\nMoreover, the Commission committed itself to set up in the 1st days\nof September 2008 an expert meeting to further discuss the issue and\npossible Community-wide measures.\n\nGeneral discussion and issues raised by the participants\n--------------------------------------------------------\nThe Netherlands presented the situation and the measures taken due to\nthe detection of TB positive calves below 6 weeks of age introduced\nvia intra-Community trade to the officially TB free bovine herds at\ntheir territory.\n\nThe United Kingdom updated the participants on the current situation\nas regards bovine tuberculosis on the territory of their country and\non measures taken in relation to the breakdown in an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd of origin of the calves, found later TB\npositive in the Netherlands. Mod.AS]\n\nOn 3 Sep 2008 the conclusions of the meeting were presented to the\nStanding Committee for Food Chain and Animal Health under point 4D of\nthe Committee's agenda.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Directive 64/432/EEC, point C of section I in Annex A says: \"no\nbovine animal has been introduced without a certificate from an\nofficial veterinarian showing that the animal has reacted negatively\nto an intradermal tuberculin test assessed according to the criteria\nset out in Annex B 21 (a) and that it comes from an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd\".\n\nArticle 21 (a) of Annex B says: \"the result of the intradermal\ntuberculin test must be read after 72 hours and assessed according to\nthe following method: (a) negative reaction: if only limited swelling\nis observed, with an increase of not more than 2 mm in the thickness\nof the fold of skin without clinical signs such as pasty consistency,\nexudation, necrosis, pain or inflammation of the lymphatic ducts in\nthat region and of the lymph nodes. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK 20080718.2186\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (02) 20061011.2915\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
