owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-09-02 00:00:00", "2008-07-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-07-23 00:00:00", "2008-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UNITED KINGDOM", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "110189", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, bovine - Netherlands ex UK: EU consultation", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=110189", "date": "2008-09-09 14:00:31", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - NETHERLANDS ex UNITED KINGDOM: EU CONSULTATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 2 Sep 2008\nSource: EU Directorate for Health and Consumers [edited]\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/report_working_group_bovine_tuberculosis.pdf>\n\n\nReport on the Working Group meeting on bovine tuberculosis\n----------------------------------------------------------\nFollowing the extraordinary Standing Committee for Food Chain and\nAnimal Health (SCFCAH) [meeting] of 23 Jul 2008 where the findings of\nbovine tuberculosis (TB) in young calves introduced from the United\nKingdom into the Netherlands via intra-Community trade were\ndiscussed, on 2 Sep 2008, a Working Group of experts on bovine\ntuberculosis was organised.\n\nThe Commission invited representatives of all Member States and 6\nprivate experts (Director of the Community reference laboratory on\ntuberculosis and 5 members of the Task Force Sub-group on bovine\ntuberculosis).\n\nObjective of the meeting\n------------------------\nThe purpose of the meeting was to explore with the Member States\nmeasures to prevent the spread of bovine tuberculosis [TB] from areas\nwith high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade in live\ncattle, and in particular calves under 42 days of age that are\nstatutory not subject to pre-movement testing.\n\nBackground\n----------\nIn July 2008, the Netherlands (officially bovine tuberculosis-free\nMember State), based on the epidemiological investigation followed by\nthe notification received from the United Kingdom, detected a number\nof cases of infection with _Mycobacterium bovis_ in calves under 42\ndays of age coming from a single holding in the United Kingdom, that\nwent down with tuberculosis after the dispatch of the animals.\n\nDutch and Belgian farmers have self imposed a ban on British cattle\nfollowing the revelation that 12 veal calves were positive for bovine\ntuberculosis. The Dutch Agriculture Ministry has condemned this\nbreech of biosecurity, particularly as there has been no TB in the\nNetherlands since 1999.\n\nDue to the arisen situation, on 23 Jul 2008 the Commission organised\nan extraordinary SCFCAH meeting in order to clarify the TB situation\nin the UK and exchange opinion with the Member States on the measures\nto be taken in that respect.\n\nDuring the meeting the Member States agreed that at this point in\ntime immediate additional Community measures are not needed. The UK\nagreed to reinforce the controls on such movements, to ensure that\nDirective 64/432/EEC is fully applied, and that relevant information\nis transmitted to Member States of destination without delay.\n\nMember States engaged themselves to monitor the situation and to\ninform the Commission in case of new findings.\n\nMoreover, the Commission committed itself to set up in the 1st days\nof September 2008 an expert meeting to further discuss the issue and\npossible Community-wide measures.\n\nGeneral discussion and issues raised by the participants\n--------------------------------------------------------\nThe Netherlands presented the situation and the measures taken due to\nthe detection of TB positive calves below 6 weeks of age introduced\nvia intra-Community trade to the officially TB free bovine herds at\ntheir territory.\n\nThe United Kingdom updated the participants on the current situation\nas regards bovine tuberculosis on the territory of their country and\non measures taken in relation to the breakdown in an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd of origin of the calves, found later TB\npositive in the Netherlands. The UK emphasised that this isolated\nincident was due to a case of bovine tuberculosis mastitis.\n\nCertain Member States and in particular the Netherlands urged that\naction be taken at all levels and especially by the Member States not\nyet officially bovine tuberculosis-free to ensure that eradication of\nthe disease is accelerated.\n\nThe Commission gave a brief overview of the Community legislation on\nbovine tuberculosis noting that calves under 42 days of age are\nexempted for the requirement of the pre-movement testing and that in\nthis case, current EU provisions rely only on the status of the herd.\nIn addition, the Commission presented for discussion 4 possible\nalternative provisions which could be implemented, either one at a\ntime or in combination, in order to prevent the spread of TB from\nareas with high prevalence of the disease via intra-Community trade\nin calves under 42 days of age, and in particular apart from the\nmandatory officially tuberculosis-free herd origin:\n\n1. Pre-movement test (intradermal skin test or gamma interferon test)\nof individual animals concerned;\n2. Low prevalence region origin (below 1 or 0,5 percent or other);\n3. Recent herd test (such as, less then 6 months) with strictly\ndefined frequency of testing the herd (annual, twice a year, etc.);\n4. Channelling procedure (post-movement test at destination or\ndispatched to a holding at destination from which they can only be\nmoved directly to a slaughterhouse).\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThere was general consensus on:\n- the need to ensure that the officially bovine tuberculosis-free (TB\nOF) status is properly granted to the herds, as this is the basic\nrequirement in order to ensure safe trade;\n- the pre-movement testing is not suitable for animals younger than\n42 days of age due to the lack of sensitivity of the test when used\non these animals;\n- there is a need to have proportionate and effective measures in\norder to address the risk posed by these animals that cannot be\ntested before movement.\n\nAn acceptable regime for animals below 42 days of age would be as follows:\nBovine animals for breeding and production less than 42 days old\nshall only be dispatched to other Member States if they come from an\nofficially tuberculosis-free bovine herd as defined in Article\n2(2)(d) of Directive 64/432/EEC, and:\n\n1. The holding of origin is situated in a Member State or a region of\na Member State as defined in Article 2(2)(p) of Directive 64/432/EEC\nin which on average, determined at 31 December of each year, the\nannual percentages of bovine herds confirmed as infected with\ntuberculosis is not more than 0.5 percent of all herds within the\nMember State or region thereof, or\n2. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the routine intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B\nto Directive 64/432/EEC at an interval of more than 3 months and less\nthan 6 months during the last 12 months, or\n3. All animals in the holding of origin, with the exception of\nanimals under 6 weeks old, have been subjected with negative results\nto the intradermal tuberculin test in accordance with Annex B to\nDirective 64/432/EEC, carried out in the 30 days prior to the\nmovement, or\n4. The animals are consigned, through a channelling procedure under\nthe control of the competent authority of the place of destination,\nto a holding from where they can only be removed:\na. to be transported directly to the slaughterhouse for slaughter in\naccordance with the first indent of Article 7 of Directive\n64/432/EEC, or\nb. to be introduced not earlier than at the age of at least 42 days\ninto another herd in accordance with the procedure provided for in\npoint 1(c) of Section I of Annex A to Directive 64/432/EEC [see\ncommentary. - Mod.AS]\n\nOn 3 Sep 2008 the conclusions of the meeting were presented to the\nStanding Committee for Food Chain and Animal Health under point 4D of\nthe Committee's agenda.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Directive 64/432/EEC, point C of section I in Annex A says: \"no\nbovine animal has been introduced without a certificate from an\nofficial veterinarian showing that the animal has reacted negatively\nto an intradermal tuberculin test assessed according to the criteria\nset out in Annex B 21 (a) and that it comes from an officially\ntuberculosis-free herd\".\n\nArticle 21 (a) of Annex B says: \"the result of the intradermal\ntuberculin test must be read after 72 hours and assessed according to\nthe following method: (a) negative reaction: if only limited swelling\nis observed, with an increase of not more than 2 mm in the thickness\nof the fold of skin without clinical signs such as pasty consistency,\nexudation, necrosis, pain or inflammation of the lymphatic ducts in\nthat region and of the lymph nodes. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England) 20080903.2751\nBovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales) 20080723.2229\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK 20080718.2186\n2007\n----\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n----\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (02) 20061011.2915\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-09-02 00:00:00", "2008-07-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-07-23 00:00:00", "2008-09-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UNITED KINGDOM", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "108144", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, human, canine - UK: (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=108144", "date": "2008-07-18 16:00:28", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK, IRELAND, THE NETHERLANDS ex UK\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: The Herald [edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.uk/business/farming/display.var.2401815.0.Netherlands_ban_endangers_British_export_industry.php>\n\n\nNetherlands ban endangers British export industry\n-------------------------------------------------\nA voluntary ban by Dutch cattle importers on the live export of cattle from\nthe UK threatens to devastate the British export industry, just as it was\nrecovering from last year's [2007] foot and mouth [disease] restrictions.\n\nThe move comes after 12 calves, which were exported from a farm in England\nto 6 farms in the Netherlands had to be slaughtered after subsequent tests\non the English farm detected tuberculosis [TB] in the herd. A further 27\nfarms that have been in contact with the original 6 are now under\nrestriction and Dutch vets are testing more than 4000 cattle for the disease.\n\nUnofficially, Belgian farmers are also refusing to take British calves and\nadult cattle. Exporters fear that a complete ban on the trade of live\ncattle throughout the European Union could be in force next week. The news\nhas shocked farmers in the Netherlands, which has been free of TB since 1994.\n\nDuring 2006, the UK exported a total of 81 000 live calves. That figure\nfell to 64 000 in 2007 as a result of export restrictions due to\nfoot-and-mouth disease, but was recovering well this year [2008] and latest\nfigures to June reveal that 40 000 had crossed the English Channel.\n\nThe next 3 months is the peak period when most UK calves are selected for\nthe export trade to the Netherlands, and any disruption to this trade will\nresult in the complete collapse of export businesses that have already lost\nmillions because of last year's [2007] foot and mouth disease ban.\n\nNFU (National Farmers' Union) Scotland vice-president Nigel Miller said:\n\"This is a very worrying development at a time when Scotland's dairy\nfarmers are achieving BP 50 to BP 60 per head [USD 99.70 to 119.64] for\nexport-quality bull calves. \"We have spoken to Scotland's chief vet to\nraise our concerns while our Brussels office is in dialogue with their\nDutch union counterparts on the subject. If the Commission becomes\ninvolved, then what we would want to see is a proportionate response to\nthis issue, one which takes the wider calf trade in the EU into\nconsideration and one which stops well short of a unilateral ban on live\ncalf exports from the UK.\n\n\"Scotland has worked hard to preserve its excellent record on TB. We\nalready have low incidence status and, as an industry, we have set targets\nto further reduce the number of cases of TB seen here. Any suggestion of a\nEuropean ban on live calves affecting Scotland would be unjustified and\nunnecessary.\"\n\n[byline: Rog Wood]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2008\nSource: Wales Online, Western Mail report [edited]\n<http://www.walesonline.co.uk/countryside-farming-news/farming-news/2008/07/15/wales-will-kill-badgers-row-91466-21339761/>\n\n\nWales will kill badgers -- row\n------------------------------\nThe DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs)\nsecretary of state's decision to rule out a badger cull in England will not\naffect proposals to go ahead with one in Wales.\n\nRural Affairs minister Elin Jones said nothing had changed and plans for a\ncull in a pilot area as part of a package of measures to eradicate bTB\n[bovine tuberculosis] were proceeding as announced last April [2008]. \"It\nhas not affected my thinking at all. Various expert groups set up to advise\nare gathering information as we speak on the various factors we need to\ntake account of,\" said Ms Jones. \"Then at some point later in the year I\nwill be given advice from my officials as to what, when and where.\"\n\nAmong the issues that need to be addressed is the willingness of all\nlandowners to take part in the trial cull. This will only work if officials\nare able to slaughter all the animals within a clearly defined area in\norder to gauge whether it has any effect on the spread of the disease.\n\nA small minority of farmers opposes a badger cull, and larger numbers of\nlandowners with small acreages may try to prevent it from happening. The\nBadger Trust has already lodged an application for a judicial review of a\n\"naive and short-sighted political decision\". The trust claims the badger\nplays no role in the spread of bTB, which now affects more than 2000 farms\nin Wales. Last year [2007] nearly 8000 cattle were culled at a cost in\ncompensation to farmers of BP 15.2m [USD 30.3m].\n\n\"The harsh reality is that Wales' bovine TB problem can be easily traced to\ncattle movements and farming practices,\" says a Badger Trust report. \"There\nis a clear and known correlation between larger herd sizes and an increased\nrisk of bovine TB.\"\n\nThe National Farmers' Union has promised a legal challenge to what it calls\nthe UK environment minister Hilary Benn's \"disgraceful abdication of\nresponsibility\" in ruling out a cull. NFU president, Bedfordshire farmer\nPeter Kendall and vice president Meurig Raymond, who farms in\nPembrokeshire, led a demonstration outside the House of Parliament after Mr\nBenn's announcement. Mr Kendall said the NFU would mount a legal challenge\nand withdraw from talks on cost and responsibility sharing. The Tenant\nFarmers Association (TFA) has also pulled out of talks on sharing the costs\nand responsibilities of animal diseases, which it describes as\n\"hypocritical and damaging\" without controls of bTB in wildlife.\n\n[byline: Steve Dube]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: Business Scotsman [edited]\n<http://business.scotsman.com/fooddrinkagriculture/TB-outbreak--raises-fears.4301536.jp>\n\n\nTB outbreak raises fears of ban on UK calves\n--------------------------------------------\nThere appears to be a real possibility that the export of young bull calves\nfrom dairy herds in the UK to mainland Europe may be banned following the\ndiscovery to bovine tuberculosis on 27 farms in the Netherlands.\n\nA dairy herd in England, previously free from TB, has suffered a breakdown\nand it is believed that calves from this farm are the source of the\nproblem, which was discovered during routine testing.\n\nAbout 400 000 calves are exported at around 10 days of age from the UK for\nveal production. These must come from TB-free farms. However, there is no\nreliable test for TB in animals that are aged less than 42 days.\n\nIn certain parts of the European Union, there is a view that the UK is a\nreservoir of disease: first BSE in 1996, then the world's largest epidemic\nof foot and mouth disease in 2001 followed by a smaller outbreak of the\nsame disease last year [2007].\n\nThe vast majority of farmers and many leading scientists assert there is a\nclear link between TB and badgers, which are deemed to be the principal\nvector of this disease.\n\nThe latest forecast is that up to 40 000 cattle in England will be culled\nduring 2008. Only last week Hilary Benn, the secretary of state at DEFRA\n(UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs), ruled out a cull\nof badgers. He said that a cull of badgers \"could end up making the disease\nworse if it was not sustained over time or delivered effectively and public\nopposition, including the unwillingness of some landowners to take part,\nwould render this more difficult.\"\n\nJeff Rooker, a junior minister at DEFRA, is of a different opinion.\nSpeaking in the House of Lords he said: \"Badger-to-cattle transmission is\nheavy. It accounts for 70-80 per cent [of] cases.\"\n\n[byline: Dan Buglass]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Thu 17 Jul 2008\nSource: Farmers Weekly Interactive [edited]\n<http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2008/07/17/111222/badger-cull-has-desired-effect-in-ireland.html>\n\n\nBadger cull has desired effect in Ireland\n-----------------------------------------\nThe incidence of bovine TB in the Republic of Ireland continues to decline,\nas the department of agriculture in Dublin presses on with its cull of\ninfected badgers. A government spokeswoman explained that, even though\nthere had been a slight increase in 2007, this was because the level of\ntesting had increased substantially following the opening of a new\nlaboratory in Sligo. Slaughterhouse inspection procedures had also\nimproved. \"With TB you should never look at one year in isolation, as there\nare so many pieces that go together,\" she said. \"It's best to look at 5\nyear trends and that shows a steady fall in TB.\"\n\nFor example, in 1998 the number of TB reactors came to 45 000, but by 2003\nhad dropped to 28 000. In 2006 there was a further fall to 24 000, though\nlast year [2007] it was up to 28 000. Disease incidence stands at about 6\nper cent of herds tested, compared with 8.2 per cent in the peak year of 2000.\n\nThe Irish government is adamant that badger culling is a key factor in\ncontaining the disease. \"Elsewhere in the world, the tuberculin test\nprovides all the control necessary to get on top of TB. Only in Ireland and\nGB, where there is also a wildlife challenge, is there a problem.\"\n\nIn New Zealand, for example, TB had been contained when possums -- the\ncommon vector -- were culled, while in Australia it was wild buffalo that\nhad been taken out.\n\nBadger culling is strictly controlled in the Republic of Ireland. It is\nonly triggered where, following an outbreak, an epidemiological study\nimplicates badgers as the likely source, not cattle. The spokeswoman\ninsisted there was no plan to cull out all the badgers in an area -- merely\nto reduce the population and so reduce contact opportunities, until a\nvaccine was available. She also explained that, unlike in GB, there was no\nproblem with perturbation. \"It seems our badger populations are quite\ndifferent,\" she said. \"They have different diets, different reproduction,\nand different densities. Their social groups are smaller and they are less\nterritorial.\"\n\nThe government has a self-imposed cap of culling on just 30 per cent of the\nagricultural area. So far it has covered about 20 per cent, taking out\nabout 2 thirds of the badgers in that area. About half of these were TB\ninfected.\n\nFarmers contribute to the cost of the programme with a statutory levy on\nmilk sales, and on cattle slaughtered or exported.\n\n[byline: Philip Clarke]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional information on the recent bovine tuberculosis developments in\nEngland, which -- according to available science-based information -- is\ndirectly related to the infection in badgers, can be found at\n<http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article4340286.ece>.\n\nDEFRA's explanatory information is available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/index.htm>.\n\nThe number of new outbreaks in cattle during 2007, as reported to the OIE\n(World Organisation for Animal Health), was: England -- 3153(!); Wales --\n902; Scotland -- 58. Updated information on possible cases of human\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ infections in the various parts of the UK would be\nappreciated.\n\nAccording to OIE's WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database)\ninterface data, bovine tuberculosis was present in the Netherlands during\n2005 but no quantitative data were disclosed. Reportedly, the disease was\nabsent during the 1st half of 2006; no information is available for the 2nd\nhalf of 2006 or for 2007.\n\nOIE's WAHID data on new outbreaks in Belgium during the previous 2 years\nare the following: 2006 -- 7; 2007 -- 5. From a reliable source we have\nobtained the following unofficial information: \"A farm in Belgium, just\nacross the German border, went down with TB last month [June 2008].\nAllegedly, 22 cows out of 70 tested positive on the skin test.\"\nConfirmation (or, it is to be hoped, denial) of the information above from\nofficial sources would be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n---\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - New Zealand 20040804.2132\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England): wildlife 20040717.1941\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) (02) 20040716.1930\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20040216.0513\n2003\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20031105.2745\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20031021.2647\n2002\n---\nTuberculosis, cervids - New Zealand 20021208.6015\nTuberculosis, cattle - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sligo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NETHERLANDS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IRELAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "unofficially", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "107394", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis - South Africa (02): human to animal transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=107394", "date": "2008-07-18 16:00:28", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK, IRELAND, THE NETHERLANDS ex UK\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: The Herald [edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.uk/business/farming/display.var.2401815.0.Netherlands_ban_endangers_British_export_industry.php>\n\n\nNetherlands ban endangers British export industry\n-------------------------------------------------\nA voluntary ban by Dutch cattle importers on the live export of cattle from\nthe UK threatens to devastate the British export industry, just as it was\nrecovering from last year's [2007] foot and mouth [disease] restrictions.\n\nThe move comes after 12 calves, which were exported from a farm in England\nto 6 farms in the Netherlands had to be slaughtered after subsequent tests\non the English farm detected tuberculosis [TB] in the herd. A further 27\nfarms that have been in contact with the original 6 are now under\nrestriction and Dutch vets are testing more than 4000 cattle for the disease.\n\nUnofficially, Belgian farmers are also refusing to take British calves and\nadult cattle. Exporters fear that a complete ban on the trade of live\ncattle throughout the European Union could be in force next week. The news\nhas shocked farmers in the Netherlands, which has been free of TB since 1994.\n\nDuring 2006, the UK exported a total of 81 000 live calves. That figure\nfell to 64 000 in 2007 as a result of export restrictions due to\nfoot-and-mouth disease, but was recovering well this year [2008] and latest\nfigures to June reveal that 40 000 had crossed the English Channel.\n\nThe next 3 months is the peak period when most UK calves are selected for\nthe export trade to the Netherlands, and any disruption to this trade will\nresult in the complete collapse of export businesses that have already lost\nmillions because of last year's [2007] foot and mouth disease ban.\n\nNFU (National Farmers' Union) Scotland vice-president Nigel Miller said:\n\"This is a very worrying development at a time when Scotland's dairy\nfarmers are achieving BP 50 to BP 60 per head [USD 99.70 to 119.64] for\nexport-quality bull calves. \"We have spoken to Scotland's chief vet to\nraise our concerns while our Brussels office is in dialogue with their\nDutch union counterparts on the subject. If the Commission becomes\ninvolved, then what we would want to see is a proportionate response to\nthis issue, one which takes the wider calf trade in the EU into\nconsideration and one which stops well short of a unilateral ban on live\ncalf exports from the UK.\n\n\"Scotland has worked hard to preserve its excellent record on TB. We\nalready have low incidence status and, as an industry, we have set targets\nto further reduce the number of cases of TB seen here. Any suggestion of a\nEuropean ban on live calves affecting Scotland would be unjustified and\nunnecessary.\"\n\n[byline: Rog Wood]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2008\nSource: Wales Online, Western Mail report [edited]\n<http://www.walesonline.co.uk/countryside-farming-news/farming-news/2008/07/15/wales-will-kill-badgers-row-91466-21339761/>\n\n\nWales will kill badgers -- row\n------------------------------\nThe DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs)\nsecretary of state's decision to rule out a badger cull in England will not\naffect proposals to go ahead with one in Wales.\n\nRural Affairs minister Elin Jones said nothing had changed and plans for a\ncull in a pilot area as part of a package of measures to eradicate bTB\n[bovine tuberculosis] were proceeding as announced last April [2008]. \"It\nhas not affected my thinking at all. Various expert groups set up to advise\nare gathering information as we speak on the various factors we need to\ntake account of,\" said Ms Jones. \"Then at some point later in the year I\nwill be given advice from my officials as to what, when and where.\"\n\nAmong the issues that need to be addressed is the willingness of all\nlandowners to take part in the trial cull. This will only work if officials\nare able to slaughter all the animals within a clearly defined area in\norder to gauge whether it has any effect on the spread of the disease.\n\nA small minority of farmers opposes a badger cull, and larger numbers of\nlandowners with small acreages may try to prevent it from happening. The\nBadger Trust has already lodged an application for a judicial review of a\n\"naive and short-sighted political decision\". The trust claims the badger\nplays no role in the spread of bTB, which now affects more than 2000 farms\nin Wales. Last year [2007] nearly 8000 cattle were culled at a cost in\ncompensation to farmers of BP 15.2m [USD 30.3m].\n\n\"The harsh reality is that Wales' bovine TB problem can be easily traced to\ncattle movements and farming practices,\" says a Badger Trust report. \"There\nis a clear and known correlation between larger herd sizes and an increased\nrisk of bovine TB.\"\n\nThe National Farmers' Union has promised a legal challenge to what it calls\nthe UK environment minister Hilary Benn's \"disgraceful abdication of\nresponsibility\" in ruling out a cull. NFU president, Bedfordshire farmer\nPeter Kendall and vice president Meurig Raymond, who farms in\nPembrokeshire, led a demonstration outside the House of Parliament after Mr\nBenn's announcement. Mr Kendall said the NFU would mount a legal challenge\nand withdraw from talks on cost and responsibility sharing. The Tenant\nFarmers Association (TFA) has also pulled out of talks on sharing the costs\nand responsibilities of animal diseases, which it describes as\n\"hypocritical and damaging\" without controls of bTB in wildlife.\n\n[byline: Steve Dube]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: Business Scotsman [edited]\n<http://business.scotsman.com/fooddrinkagriculture/TB-outbreak--raises-fears.4301536.jp>\n\n\nTB outbreak raises fears of ban on UK calves\n--------------------------------------------\nThere appears to be a real possibility that the export of young bull calves\nfrom dairy herds in the UK to mainland Europe may be banned following the\ndiscovery to bovine tuberculosis on 27 farms in the Netherlands.\n\nA dairy herd in England, previously free from TB, has suffered a breakdown\nand it is believed that calves from this farm are the source of the\nproblem, which was discovered during routine testing.\n\nAbout 400 000 calves are exported at around 10 days of age from the UK for\nveal production. These must come from TB-free farms. However, there is no\nreliable test for TB in animals that are aged less than 42 days.\n\nIn certain parts of the European Union, there is a view that the UK is a\nreservoir of disease: first BSE in 1996, then the world's largest epidemic\nof foot and mouth disease in 2001 followed by a smaller outbreak of the\nsame disease last year [2007].\n\nThe vast majority of farmers and many leading scientists assert there is a\nclear link between TB and badgers, which are deemed to be the principal\nvector of this disease.\n\nThe latest forecast is that up to 40 000 cattle in England will be culled\nduring 2008. Only last week Hilary Benn, the secretary of state at DEFRA\n(UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs), ruled out a cull\nof badgers. He said that a cull of badgers \"could end up making the disease\nworse if it was not sustained over time or delivered effectively and public\nopposition, including the unwillingness of some landowners to take part,\nwould render this more difficult.\"\n\nJeff Rooker, a junior minister at DEFRA, is of a different opinion.\nSpeaking in the House of Lords he said: \"Badger-to-cattle transmission is\nheavy. It accounts for 70-80 per cent [of] cases.\"\n\n[byline: Dan Buglass]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Thu 17 Jul 2008\nSource: Farmers Weekly Interactive [edited]\n<http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2008/07/17/111222/badger-cull-has-desired-effect-in-ireland.html>\n\n\nBadger cull has desired effect in Ireland\n-----------------------------------------\nThe incidence of bovine TB in the Republic of Ireland continues to decline,\nas the department of agriculture in Dublin presses on with its cull of\ninfected badgers. A government spokeswoman explained that, even though\nthere had been a slight increase in 2007, this was because the level of\ntesting had increased substantially following the opening of a new\nlaboratory in Sligo. Slaughterhouse inspection procedures had also\nimproved. \"With TB you should never look at one year in isolation, as there\nare so many pieces that go together,\" she said. \"It's best to look at 5\nyear trends and that shows a steady fall in TB.\"\n\nFor example, in 1998 the number of TB reactors came to 45 000, but by 2003\nhad dropped to 28 000. In 2006 there was a further fall to 24 000, though\nlast year [2007] it was up to 28 000. Disease incidence stands at about 6\nper cent of herds tested, compared with 8.2 per cent in the peak year of 2000.\n\nThe Irish government is adamant that badger culling is a key factor in\ncontaining the disease. \"Elsewhere in the world, the tuberculin test\nprovides all the control necessary to get on top of TB. Only in Ireland and\nGB, where there is also a wildlife challenge, is there a problem.\"\n\nIn New Zealand, for example, TB had been contained when possums -- the\ncommon vector -- were culled, while in Australia it was wild buffalo that\nhad been taken out.\n\nBadger culling is strictly controlled in the Republic of Ireland. It is\nonly triggered where, following an outbreak, an epidemiological study\nimplicates badgers as the likely source, not cattle. The spokeswoman\ninsisted there was no plan to cull out all the badgers in an area -- merely\nto reduce the population and so reduce contact opportunities, until a\nvaccine was available. She also explained that, unlike in GB, there was no\nproblem with perturbation. \"It seems our badger populations are quite\ndifferent,\" she said. \"They have different diets, different reproduction,\nand different densities. Their social groups are smaller and they are less\nterritorial.\"\n\nThe government has a self-imposed cap of culling on just 30 per cent of the\nagricultural area. So far it has covered about 20 per cent, taking out\nabout 2 thirds of the badgers in that area. About half of these were TB\ninfected.\n\nFarmers contribute to the cost of the programme with a statutory levy on\nmilk sales, and on cattle slaughtered or exported.\n\n[byline: Philip Clarke]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional information on the recent bovine tuberculosis developments in\nEngland, which -- according to available science-based information -- is\ndirectly related to the infection in badgers, can be found at\n<http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article4340286.ece>.\n\nDEFRA's explanatory information is available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/index.htm>.\n\nThe number of new outbreaks in cattle during 2007, as reported to the OIE\n(World Organisation for Animal Health), was: England -- 3153(!); Wales --\n902; Scotland -- 58. Updated information on possible cases of human\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ infections in the various parts of the UK would be\nappreciated.\n\nAccording to OIE's WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database)\ninterface data, bovine tuberculosis was present in the Netherlands during\n2005 but no quantitative data were disclosed. Reportedly, the disease was\nabsent during the 1st half of 2006; no information is available for the 2nd\nhalf of 2006 or for 2007.\n\nOIE's WAHID data on new outbreaks in Belgium during the previous 2 years\nare the following: 2006 -- 7; 2007 -- 5. From a reliable source we have\nobtained the following unofficial information: \"A farm in Belgium, just\nacross the German border, went down with TB last month [June 2008].\nAllegedly, 22 cows out of 70 tested positive on the skin test.\"\nConfirmation (or, it is to be hoped, denial) of the information above from\nofficial sources would be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n---\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (England) 20040216.0513\n2003\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20031105.2745\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20031021.2647\n2002\n---\nTuberculosis, cervids - New Zealand 20021208.6015\nTuberculosis, cattle - UK 20020221.3599\n2000\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - Australia (Queensland) (04) 20001117.2010\n1998\n---\nMycobacterium bovis, badgers - UK (02) 19981203.2329\n1995\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - New Zealand 19950912.0817\n\n.................arn/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. South Africa: human to animal transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=106349", "date": "2008-07-18 16:00:28", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK, IRELAND, THE NETHERLANDS ex UK\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: The Herald [edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.uk/business/farming/display.var.2401815.0.Netherlands_ban_endangers_British_export_industry.php>\n\n\nNetherlands ban endangers British export industry\n-------------------------------------------------\nA voluntary ban by Dutch cattle importers on the live export of cattle from\nthe UK threatens to devastate the British export industry, just as it was\nrecovering from last year's [2007] foot and mouth [disease] restrictions.\n\nThe move comes after 12 calves, which were exported from a farm in England\nto 6 farms in the Netherlands had to be slaughtered after subsequent tests\non the English farm detected tuberculosis [TB] in the herd. A further 27\nfarms that have been in contact with the original 6 are now under\nrestriction and Dutch vets are testing more than 4000 cattle for the disease.\n\nUnofficially, Belgian farmers are also refusing to take British calves and\nadult cattle. Exporters fear that a complete ban on the trade of live\ncattle throughout the European Union could be in force next week. The news\nhas shocked farmers in the Netherlands, which has been free of TB since 1994.\n\nDuring 2006, the UK exported a total of 81 000 live calves. That figure\nfell to 64 000 in 2007 as a result of export restrictions due to\nfoot-and-mouth disease, but was recovering well this year [2008] and latest\nfigures to June reveal that 40 000 had crossed the English Channel.\n\nThe next 3 months is the peak period when most UK calves are selected for\nthe export trade to the Netherlands, and any disruption to this trade will\nresult in the complete collapse of export businesses that have already lost\nmillions because of last year's [2007] foot and mouth disease ban.\n\nNFU (National Farmers' Union) Scotland vice-president Nigel Miller said:\n\"This is a very worrying development at a time when Scotland's dairy\nfarmers are achieving BP 50 to BP 60 per head [USD 99.70 to 119.64] for\nexport-quality bull calves. \"We have spoken to Scotland's chief vet to\nraise our concerns while our Brussels office is in dialogue with their\nDutch union counterparts on the subject. If the Commission becomes\ninvolved, then what we would want to see is a proportionate response to\nthis issue, one which takes the wider calf trade in the EU into\nconsideration and one which stops well short of a unilateral ban on live\ncalf exports from the UK.\n\n\"Scotland has worked hard to preserve its excellent record on TB. We\nalready have low incidence status and, as an industry, we have set targets\nto further reduce the number of cases of TB seen here. Any suggestion of a\nEuropean ban on live calves affecting Scotland would be unjustified and\nunnecessary.\"\n\n[byline: Rog Wood]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2008\nSource: Wales Online, Western Mail report [edited]\n<http://www.walesonline.co.uk/countryside-farming-news/farming-news/2008/07/15/wales-will-kill-badgers-row-91466-21339761/>\n\n\nWales will kill badgers -- row\n------------------------------\nThe DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs)\nsecretary of state's decision to rule out a badger cull in England will not\naffect proposals to go ahead with one in Wales.\n\nRural Affairs minister Elin Jones said nothing had changed and plans for a\ncull in a pilot area as part of a package of measures to eradicate bTB\n[bovine tuberculosis] were proceeding as announced last April [2008]. \"It\nhas not affected my thinking at all. Various expert groups set up to advise\nare gathering information as we speak on the various factors we need to\ntake account of,\" said Ms Jones. \"Then at some point later in the year I\nwill be given advice from my officials as to what, when and where.\"\n\nAmong the issues that need to be addressed is the willingness of all\nlandowners to take part in the trial cull. This will only work if officials\nare able to slaughter all the animals within a clearly defined area in\norder to gauge whether it has any effect on the spread of the disease.\n\nA small minority of farmers opposes a badger cull, and larger numbers of\nlandowners with small acreages may try to prevent it from happening. The\nBadger Trust has already lodged an application for a judicial review of a\n\"naive and short-sighted political decision\". The trust claims the badger\nplays no role in the spread of bTB, which now affects more than 2000 farms\nin Wales. Last year [2007] nearly 8000 cattle were culled at a cost in\ncompensation to farmers of BP 15.2m [USD 30.3m].\n\n\"The harsh reality is that Wales' bovine TB problem can be easily traced to\ncattle movements and farming practices,\" says a Badger Trust report. \"There\nis a clear and known correlation between larger herd sizes and an increased\nrisk of bovine TB.\"\n\nThe National Farmers' Union has promised a legal challenge to what it calls\nthe UK environment minister Hilary Benn's \"disgraceful abdication of\nresponsibility\" in ruling out a cull. NFU president, Bedfordshire farmer\nPeter Kendall and vice president Meurig Raymond, who farms in\nPembrokeshire, led a demonstration outside the House of Parliament after Mr\nBenn's announcement. Mr Kendall said the NFU would mount a legal challenge\nand withdraw from talks on cost and responsibility sharing. The Tenant\nFarmers Association (TFA) has also pulled out of talks on sharing the costs\nand responsibilities of animal diseases, which it describes as\n\"hypocritical and damaging\" without controls of bTB in wildlife.\n\n[byline: Steve Dube]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: Business Scotsman [edited]\n<http://business.scotsman.com/fooddrinkagriculture/TB-outbreak--raises-fears.4301536.jp>\n\n\nTB outbreak raises fears of ban on UK calves\n--------------------------------------------\nThere appears to be a real possibility that the export of young bull calves\nfrom dairy herds in the UK to mainland Europe may be banned following the\ndiscovery to bovine tuberculosis on 27 farms in the Netherlands.\n\nA dairy herd in England, previously free from TB, has suffered a breakdown\nand it is believed that calves from this farm are the source of the\nproblem, which was discovered during routine testing.\n\nAbout 400 000 calves are exported at around 10 days of age from the UK for\nveal production. These must come from TB-free farms. However, there is no\nreliable test for TB in animals that are aged less than 42 days.\n\nIn certain parts of the European Union, there is a view that the UK is a\nreservoir of disease: first BSE in 1996, then the world's largest epidemic\nof foot and mouth disease in 2001 followed by a smaller outbreak of the\nsame disease last year [2007].\n\nThe vast majority of farmers and many leading scientists assert there is a\nclear link between TB and badgers, which are deemed to be the principal\nvector of this disease.\n\nThe latest forecast is that up to 40 000 cattle in England will be culled\nduring 2008. Only last week Hilary Benn, the secretary of state at DEFRA\n(UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs), ruled out a cull\nof badgers. He said that a cull of badgers \"could end up making the disease\nworse if it was not sustained over time or delivered effectively and public\nopposition, including the unwillingness of some landowners to take part,\nwould render this more difficult.\"\n\nJeff Rooker, a junior minister at DEFRA, is of a different opinion.\nSpeaking in the House of Lords he said: \"Badger-to-cattle transmission is\nheavy. It accounts for 70-80 per cent [of] cases.\"\n\n[byline: Dan Buglass]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Thu 17 Jul 2008\nSource: Farmers Weekly Interactive [edited]\n<http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2008/07/17/111222/badger-cull-has-desired-effect-in-ireland.html>\n\n\nBadger cull has desired effect in Ireland\n-----------------------------------------\nThe incidence of bovine TB in the Republic of Ireland continues to decline,\nas the department of agriculture in Dublin presses on with its cull of\ninfected badgers. A government spokeswoman explained that, even though\nthere had been a slight increase in 2007, this was because the level of\ntesting had increased substantially following the opening of a new\nlaboratory in Sligo. Slaughterhouse inspection procedures had also\nimproved. \"With TB you should never look at one year in isolation, as there\nare so many pieces that go together,\" she said. \"It's best to look at 5\nyear trends and that shows a steady fall in TB.\"\n\nFor example, in 1998 the number of TB reactors came to 45 000, but by 2003\nhad dropped to 28 000. In 2006 there was a further fall to 24 000, though\nlast year [2007] it was up to 28 000. Disease incidence stands at about 6\nper cent of herds tested, compared with 8.2 per cent in the peak year of 2000.\n\nThe Irish government is adamant that badger culling is a key factor in\ncontaining the disease. \"Elsewhere in the world, the tuberculin test\nprovides all the control necessary to get on top of TB. Only in Ireland and\nGB, where there is also a wildlife challenge, is there a problem.\"\n\nIn New Zealand, for example, TB had been contained when possums -- the\ncommon vector -- were culled, while in Australia it was wild buffalo that\nhad been taken out.\n\nBadger culling is strictly controlled in the Republic of Ireland. It is\nonly triggered where, following an outbreak, an epidemiological study\nimplicates badgers as the likely source, not cattle. The spokeswoman\ninsisted there was no plan to cull out all the badgers in an area -- merely\nto reduce the population and so reduce contact opportunities, until a\nvaccine was available. She also explained that, unlike in GB, there was no\nproblem with perturbation. \"It seems our badger populations are quite\ndifferent,\" she said. \"They have different diets, different reproduction,\nand different densities. Their social groups are smaller and they are less\nterritorial.\"\n\nThe government has a self-imposed cap of culling on just 30 per cent of the\nagricultural area. So far it has covered about 20 per cent, taking out\nabout 2 thirds of the badgers in that area. About half of these were TB\ninfected.\n\nFarmers contribute to the cost of the programme with a statutory levy on\nmilk sales, and on cattle slaughtered or exported.\n\n[byline: Philip Clarke]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional information on the recent bovine tuberculosis developments in\nEngland, which -- according to available science-based information -- is\ndirectly related to the infection in badgers, can be found at\n<http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article4340286.ece>.\n\nDEFRA's explanatory information is available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/index.htm>.\n\nThe number of new outbreaks in cattle during 2007, as reported to the OIE\n(World Organisation for Animal Health), was: England -- 3153(!); Wales --\n902; Scotland -- 58. Updated information on possible cases of human\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ infections in the various parts of the UK would be\nappreciated.\n\nAccording to OIE's WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database)\ninterface data, bovine tuberculosis was present in the Netherlands during\n2005 but no quantitative data were disclosed. Reportedly, the disease was\nabsent during the 1st half of 2006; no information is available for the 2nd\nhalf of 2006 or for 2007.\n\nOIE's WAHID data on new outbreaks in Belgium during the previous 2 years\nare the following: 2006 -- 7; 2007 -- 5. From a reliable source we have\nobtained the following unofficial information: \"A farm in Belgium, just\nacross the German border, went down with TB last month [June 2008].\nAllegedly, 22 cows out of 70 tested positive on the skin test.\"\nConfirmation (or, it is to be hoped, denial) of the information above from\nofficial sources would be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n---\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - New Zealand 20040804.2132\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England): wildlife 20040717.1941\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) (02) 20040716.1930\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20040216.0513\n2003\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20031105.2745\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20031021.2647\n2002\n---\nTuberculosis, cervids - New Zealand 20021208.6015\nTuberculosis, cattle - UK 20020221.3599\n2000\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - Australia (Queensland) (04) 20001117.2010\n1998\n---\nMycobacterium bovis, badgers - UK (02) 19981203.2329\n1995\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - New Zealand 19950912.0817\n\n.................arn/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sligo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NETHERLANDS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IRELAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "unofficially", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "101579", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - USA (06): (NM), loss of status", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=101579", "date": "2008-07-18 16:00:28", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK, IRELAND, THE NETHERLANDS ex UK\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: The Herald [edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.uk/business/farming/display.var.2401815.0.Netherlands_ban_endangers_British_export_industry.php>\n\n\nNetherlands ban endangers British export industry\n-------------------------------------------------\nA voluntary ban by Dutch cattle importers on the live export of cattle from\nthe UK threatens to devastate the British export industry, just as it was\nrecovering from last year's [2007] foot and mouth [disease] restrictions.\n\nThe move comes after 12 calves, which were exported from a farm in England\nto 6 farms in the Netherlands had to be slaughtered after subsequent tests\non the English farm detected tuberculosis [TB] in the herd. A further 27\nfarms that have been in contact with the original 6 are now under\nrestriction and Dutch vets are testing more than 4000 cattle for the disease.\n\nUnofficially, Belgian farmers are also refusing to take British calves and\nadult cattle. Exporters fear that a complete ban on the trade of live\ncattle throughout the European Union could be in force next week. The news\nhas shocked farmers in the Netherlands, which has been free of TB since 1994.\n\nDuring 2006, the UK exported a total of 81 000 live calves. That figure\nfell to 64 000 in 2007 as a result of export restrictions due to\nfoot-and-mouth disease, but was recovering well this year [2008] and latest\nfigures to June reveal that 40 000 had crossed the English Channel.\n\nThe next 3 months is the peak period when most UK calves are selected for\nthe export trade to the Netherlands, and any disruption to this trade will\nresult in the complete collapse of export businesses that have already lost\nmillions because of last year's [2007] foot and mouth disease ban.\n\nNFU (National Farmers' Union) Scotland vice-president Nigel Miller said:\n\"This is a very worrying development at a time when Scotland's dairy\nfarmers are achieving BP 50 to BP 60 per head [USD 99.70 to 119.64] for\nexport-quality bull calves. \"We have spoken to Scotland's chief vet to\nraise our concerns while our Brussels office is in dialogue with their\nDutch union counterparts on the subject. If the Commission becomes\ninvolved, then what we would want to see is a proportionate response to\nthis issue, one which takes the wider calf trade in the EU into\nconsideration and one which stops well short of a unilateral ban on live\ncalf exports from the UK.\n\n\"Scotland has worked hard to preserve its excellent record on TB. We\nalready have low incidence status and, as an industry, we have set targets\nto further reduce the number of cases of TB seen here. Any suggestion of a\nEuropean ban on live calves affecting Scotland would be unjustified and\nunnecessary.\"\n\n[byline: Rog Wood]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2008\nSource: Wales Online, Western Mail report [edited]\n<http://www.walesonline.co.uk/countryside-farming-news/farming-news/2008/07/15/wales-will-kill-badgers-row-91466-21339761/>\n\n\nWales will kill badgers -- row\n------------------------------\nThe DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs)\nsecretary of state's decision to rule out a badger cull in England will not\naffect proposals to go ahead with one in Wales.\n\nRural Affairs minister Elin Jones said nothing had changed and plans for a\ncull in a pilot area as part of a package of measures to eradicate bTB\n[bovine tuberculosis] were proceeding as announced last April [2008]. \"It\nhas not affected my thinking at all. Various expert groups set up to advise\nare gathering information as we speak on the various factors we need to\ntake account of,\" said Ms Jones. \"Then at some point later in the year I\nwill be given advice from my officials as to what, when and where.\"\n\nAmong the issues that need to be addressed is the willingness of all\nlandowners to take part in the trial cull. This will only work if officials\nare able to slaughter all the animals within a clearly defined area in\norder to gauge whether it has any effect on the spread of the disease.\n\nA small minority of farmers opposes a badger cull, and larger numbers of\nlandowners with small acreages may try to prevent it from happening. The\nBadger Trust has already lodged an application for a judicial review of a\n\"naive and short-sighted political decision\". The trust claims the badger\nplays no role in the spread of bTB, which now affects more than 2000 farms\nin Wales. Last year [2007] nearly 8000 cattle were culled at a cost in\ncompensation to farmers of BP 15.2m [USD 30.3m].\n\n\"The harsh reality is that Wales' bovine TB problem can be easily traced to\ncattle movements and farming practices,\" says a Badger Trust report. \"There\nis a clear and known correlation between larger herd sizes and an increased\nrisk of bovine TB.\"\n\nThe National Farmers' Union has promised a legal challenge to what it calls\nthe UK environment minister Hilary Benn's \"disgraceful abdication of\nresponsibility\" in ruling out a cull. NFU president, Bedfordshire farmer\nPeter Kendall and vice president Meurig Raymond, who farms in\nPembrokeshire, led a demonstration outside the House of Parliament after Mr\nBenn's announcement. Mr Kendall said the NFU would mount a legal challenge\nand withdraw from talks on cost and responsibility sharing. The Tenant\nFarmers Association (TFA) has also pulled out of talks on sharing the costs\nand responsibilities of animal diseases, which it describes as\n\"hypocritical and damaging\" without controls of bTB in wildlife.\n\n[byline: Steve Dube]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: Business Scotsman [edited]\n<http://business.scotsman.com/fooddrinkagriculture/TB-outbreak--raises-fears.4301536.jp>\n\n\nTB outbreak raises fears of ban on UK calves\n--------------------------------------------\nThere appears to be a real possibility that the export of young bull calves\nfrom dairy herds in the UK to mainland Europe may be banned following the\ndiscovery to bovine tuberculosis on 27 farms in the Netherlands.\n\nA dairy herd in England, previously free from TB, has suffered a breakdown\nand it is believed that calves from this farm are the source of the\nproblem, which was discovered during routine testing.\n\nAbout 400 000 calves are exported at around 10 days of age from the UK for\nveal production. These must come from TB-free farms. However, there is no\nreliable test for TB in animals that are aged less than 42 days.\n\nIn certain parts of the European Union, there is a view that the UK is a\nreservoir of disease: first BSE in 1996, then the world's largest epidemic\nof foot and mouth disease in 2001 followed by a smaller outbreak of the\nsame disease last year [2007].\n\nThe vast majority of farmers and many leading scientists assert there is a\nclear link between TB and badgers, which are deemed to be the principal\nvector of this disease.\n\nThe latest forecast is that up to 40 000 cattle in England will be culled\nduring 2008. Only last week Hilary Benn, the secretary of state at DEFRA\n(UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs), ruled out a cull\nof badgers. He said that a cull of badgers \"could end up making the disease\nworse if it was not sustained over time or delivered effectively and public\nopposition, including the unwillingness of some landowners to take part,\nwould render this more difficult.\"\n\nJeff Rooker, a junior minister at DEFRA, is of a different opinion.\nSpeaking in the House of Lords he said: \"Badger-to-cattle transmission is\nheavy. It accounts for 70-80 per cent [of] cases.\"\n\n[byline: Dan Buglass]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Thu 17 Jul 2008\nSource: Farmers Weekly Interactive [edited]\n<http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2008/07/17/111222/badger-cull-has-desired-effect-in-ireland.html>\n\n\nBadger cull has desired effect in Ireland\n-----------------------------------------\nThe incidence of bovine TB in the Republic of Ireland continues to decline,\nas the department of agriculture in Dublin presses on with its cull of\ninfected badgers. A government spokeswoman explained that, even though\nthere had been a slight increase in 2007, this was because the level of\ntesting had increased substantially following the opening of a new\nlaboratory in Sligo. Slaughterhouse inspection procedures had also\nimproved. \"With TB you should never look at one year in isolation, as there\nare so many pieces that go together,\" she said. \"It's best to look at 5\nyear trends and that shows a steady fall in TB.\"\n\nFor example, in 1998 the number of TB reactors came to 45 000, but by 2003\nhad dropped to 28 000. In 2006 there was a further fall to 24 000, though\nlast year [2007] it was up to 28 000. Disease incidence stands at about 6\nper cent of herds tested, compared with 8.2 per cent in the peak year of 2000.\n\nThe Irish government is adamant that badger culling is a key factor in\ncontaining the disease. \"Elsewhere in the world, the tuberculin test\nprovides all the control necessary to get on top of TB. Only in Ireland and\nGB, where there is also a wildlife challenge, is there a problem.\"\n\nIn New Zealand, for example, TB had been contained when possums -- the\ncommon vector -- were culled, while in Australia it was wild buffalo that\nhad been taken out.\n\nBadger culling is strictly controlled in the Republic of Ireland. It is\nonly triggered where, following an outbreak, an epidemiological study\nimplicates badgers as the likely source, not cattle. The spokeswoman\ninsisted there was no plan to cull out all the badgers in an area -- merely\nto reduce the population and so reduce contact opportunities, until a\nvaccine was available. She also explained that, unlike in GB, there was no\nproblem with perturbation. \"It seems our badger populations are quite\ndifferent,\" she said. \"They have different diets, different reproduction,\nand different densities. Their social groups are smaller and they are less\nterritorial.\"\n\nThe government has a self-imposed cap of culling on just 30 per cent of the\nagricultural area. So far it has covered about 20 per cent, taking out\nabout 2 thirds of the badgers in that area. About half of these were TB\ninfected.\n\nFarmers contribute to the cost of the programme with a statutory levy on\nmilk sales, and on cattle slaughtered or exported.\n\n[byline: Philip Clarke]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional information on the recent bovine tuberculosis developments in\nEngland, which -- according to available science-based information -- is\ndirectly related to the infection in badgers, can be found at\n<http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article4340286.ece>.\n\nDEFRA's explanatory information is available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/index.htm>.\n\nThe number of new outbreaks in cattle during 2007, as reported to the OIE\n(World Organisation for Animal Health), was: England -- 3153(!); Wales --\n902; Scotland -- 58. Updated information on possible cases of human\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ infections in the various parts of the UK would be\nappreciated.\n\nAccording to OIE's WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database)\ninterface data, bovine tuberculosis was present in the Netherlands during\n2005 but no quantitative data were disclosed. Reportedly, the disease was\nabsent during the 1st half of 2006; no information is available for the 2nd\nhalf of 2006 or for 2007.\n\nOIE's WAHID data on new outbreaks in Belgium during the previous 2 years\nare the following: 2006 -- 7; 2007 -- 5. From a reliable source we have\nobtained the following unofficial information: \"A farm in Belgium, just\nacross the German border, went down with TB last month [June 2008].\nAllegedly, 22 cows out of 70 tested positive on the skin test.\"\nConfirmation (or, it is to be hoped, denial) of the information above from\nofficial sources would be appreciated. - UK (England) 20040216.0513\n2003\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20031105.2745\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20031021.2647\n2002\n---\nTuberculosis, cervids - New Zealand 20021208.6015\nTuberculosis, cattle -
