For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sligo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NETHERLANDS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IRELAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "unofficially", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "100037", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - Austria ex Romania", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=100037", "date": "2008-07-18 16:00:28", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK, IRELAND, THE NETHERLANDS ex UK\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: The Herald [edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.uk/business/farming/display.var.2401815.0.Netherlands_ban_endangers_British_export_industry.php>\n\n\nNetherlands ban endangers British export industry\n-------------------------------------------------\nA voluntary ban by Dutch cattle importers on the live export of cattle from\nthe UK threatens to devastate the British export industry, just as it was\nrecovering from last year's [2007] foot and mouth [disease] restrictions.\n\nThe move comes after 12 calves, which were exported from a farm in England\nto 6 farms in the Netherlands had to be slaughtered after subsequent tests\non the English farm detected tuberculosis [TB] in the herd. A further 27\nfarms that have been in contact with the original 6 are now under\nrestriction and Dutch vets are testing more than 4000 cattle for the disease.\n\nUnofficially, Belgian farmers are also refusing to take British calves and\nadult cattle. Exporters fear that a complete ban on the trade of live\ncattle throughout the European Union could be in force next week. The news\nhas shocked farmers in the Netherlands, which has been free of TB since 1994.\n\nDuring 2006, the UK exported a total of 81 000 live calves. That figure\nfell to 64 000 in 2007 as a result of export restrictions due to\nfoot-and-mouth disease, but was recovering well this year [2008] and latest\nfigures to June reveal that 40 000 had crossed the English Channel.\n\nThe next 3 months is the peak period when most UK calves are selected for\nthe export trade to the Netherlands, and any disruption to this trade will\nresult in the complete collapse of export businesses that have already lost\nmillions because of last year's [2007] foot and mouth disease ban.\n\nNFU (National Farmers' Union) Scotland vice-president Nigel Miller said:\n\"This is a very worrying development at a time when Scotland's dairy\nfarmers are achieving BP 50 to BP 60 per head [USD 99.70 to 119.64] for\nexport-quality bull calves. \"We have spoken to Scotland's chief vet to\nraise our concerns while our Brussels office is in dialogue with their\nDutch union counterparts on the subject. If the Commission becomes\ninvolved, then what we would want to see is a proportionate response to\nthis issue, one which takes the wider calf trade in the EU into\nconsideration and one which stops well short of a unilateral ban on live\ncalf exports from the UK.\n\n\"Scotland has worked hard to preserve its excellent record on TB. We\nalready have low incidence status and, as an industry, we have set targets\nto further reduce the number of cases of TB seen here. Any suggestion of a\nEuropean ban on live calves affecting Scotland would be unjustified and\nunnecessary.\"\n\n[byline: Rog Wood]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2008\nSource: Wales Online, Western Mail report [edited]\n<http://www.walesonline.co.uk/countryside-farming-news/farming-news/2008/07/15/wales-will-kill-badgers-row-91466-21339761/>\n\n\nWales will kill badgers -- row\n------------------------------\nThe DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs)\nsecretary of state's decision to rule out a badger cull in England will not\naffect proposals to go ahead with one in Wales.\n\nRural Affairs minister Elin Jones said nothing had changed and plans for a\ncull in a pilot area as part of a package of measures to eradicate bTB\n[bovine tuberculosis] were proceeding as announced last April [2008]. \"It\nhas not affected my thinking at all. Various expert groups set up to advise\nare gathering information as we speak on the various factors we need to\ntake account of,\" said Ms Jones. \"Then at some point later in the year I\nwill be given advice from my officials as to what, when and where.\"\n\nAmong the issues that need to be addressed is the willingness of all\nlandowners to take part in the trial cull. This will only work if officials\nare able to slaughter all the animals within a clearly defined area in\norder to gauge whether it has any effect on the spread of the disease.\n\nA small minority of farmers opposes a badger cull, and larger numbers of\nlandowners with small acreages may try to prevent it from happening. The\nBadger Trust has already lodged an application for a judicial review of a\n\"naive and short-sighted political decision\". The trust claims the badger\nplays no role in the spread of bTB, which now affects more than 2000 farms\nin Wales. Last year [2007] nearly 8000 cattle were culled at a cost in\ncompensation to farmers of BP 15.2m [USD 30.3m].\n\n\"The harsh reality is that Wales' bovine TB problem can be easily traced to\ncattle movements and farming practices,\" says a Badger Trust report. \"There\nis a clear and known correlation between larger herd sizes and an increased\nrisk of bovine TB.\"\n\nThe National Farmers' Union has promised a legal challenge to what it calls\nthe UK environment minister Hilary Benn's \"disgraceful abdication of\nresponsibility\" in ruling out a cull. NFU president, Bedfordshire farmer\nPeter Kendall and vice president Meurig Raymond, who farms in\nPembrokeshire, led a demonstration outside the House of Parliament after Mr\nBenn's announcement. Mr Kendall said the NFU would mount a legal challenge\nand withdraw from talks on cost and responsibility sharing. The Tenant\nFarmers Association (TFA) has also pulled out of talks on sharing the costs\nand responsibilities of animal diseases, which it describes as\n\"hypocritical and damaging\" without controls of bTB in wildlife.\n\n[byline: Steve Dube]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: Business Scotsman [edited]\n<http://business.scotsman.com/fooddrinkagriculture/TB-outbreak--raises-fears.4301536.jp>\n\n\nTB outbreak raises fears of ban on UK calves\n--------------------------------------------\nThere appears to be a real possibility that the export of young bull calves\nfrom dairy herds in the UK to mainland Europe may be banned following the\ndiscovery to bovine tuberculosis on 27 farms in the Netherlands.\n\nA dairy herd in England, previously free from TB, has suffered a breakdown\nand it is believed that calves from this farm are the source of the\nproblem, which was discovered during routine testing.\n\nAbout 400 000 calves are exported at around 10 days of age from the UK for\nveal production. These must come from TB-free farms. However, there is no\nreliable test for TB in animals that are aged less than 42 days.\n\nIn certain parts of the European Union, there is a view that the UK is a\nreservoir of disease: first BSE in 1996, then the world's largest epidemic\nof foot and mouth disease in 2001 followed by a smaller outbreak of the\nsame disease last year [2007].\n\nThe vast majority of farmers and many leading scientists assert there is a\nclear link between TB and badgers, which are deemed to be the principal\nvector of this disease.\n\nThe latest forecast is that up to 40 000 cattle in England will be culled\nduring 2008. Only last week Hilary Benn, the secretary of state at DEFRA\n(UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs), ruled out a cull\nof badgers. He said that a cull of badgers \"could end up making the disease\nworse if it was not sustained over time or delivered effectively and public\nopposition, including the unwillingness of some landowners to take part,\nwould render this more difficult.\"\n\nJeff Rooker, a junior minister at DEFRA, is of a different opinion.\nSpeaking in the House of Lords he said: \"Badger-to-cattle transmission is\nheavy. It accounts for 70-80 per cent [of] cases.\"\n\n[byline: Dan Buglass]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Thu 17 Jul 2008\nSource: Farmers Weekly Interactive [edited]\n<http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2008/07/17/111222/badger-cull-has-desired-effect-in-ireland.html>\n\n\nBadger cull has desired effect in Ireland\n-----------------------------------------\nThe incidence of bovine TB in the Republic of Ireland continues to decline,\nas the department of agriculture in Dublin presses on with its cull of\ninfected badgers. A government spokeswoman explained that, even though\nthere had been a slight increase in 2007, this was because the level of\ntesting had increased substantially following the opening of a new\nlaboratory in Sligo. Slaughterhouse inspection procedures had also\nimproved. \"With TB you should never look at one year in isolation, as there\nare so many pieces that go together,\" she said. \"It's best to look at 5\nyear trends and that shows a steady fall in TB.\"\n\nFor example, in 1998 the number of TB reactors came to 45 000, but by 2003\nhad dropped to 28 000. In 2006 there was a further fall to 24 000, though\nlast year [2007] it was up to 28 000. Disease incidence stands at about 6\nper cent of herds tested, compared with 8.2 per cent in the peak year of 2000.\n\nThe Irish government is adamant that badger culling is a key factor in\ncontaining the disease. \"Elsewhere in the world, the tuberculin test\nprovides all the control necessary to get on top of TB. Only in Ireland and\nGB, where there is also a wildlife challenge, is there a problem.\"\n\nIn New Zealand, for example, TB had been contained when possums -- the\ncommon vector -- were culled, while in Australia it was wild buffalo that\nhad been taken out.\n\nBadger culling is strictly controlled in the Republic of Ireland. It is\nonly triggered where, following an outbreak, an epidemiological study\nimplicates badgers as the likely source, not cattle. The spokeswoman\ninsisted there was no plan to cull out all the badgers in an area -- merely\nto reduce the population and so reduce contact opportunities, until a\nvaccine was available. She also explained that, unlike in GB, there was no\nproblem with perturbation. \"It seems our badger populations are quite\ndifferent,\" she said. \"They have different diets, different reproduction,\nand different densities. Their social groups are smaller and they are less\nterritorial.\"\n\nThe government has a self-imposed cap of culling on just 30 per cent of the\nagricultural area. So far it has covered about 20 per cent, taking out\nabout 2 thirds of the badgers in that area. About half of these were TB\ninfected.\n\nFarmers contribute to the cost of the programme with a statutory levy on\nmilk sales, and on cattle slaughtered or exported.\n\n[byline: Philip Clarke]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional information on the recent bovine tuberculosis developments in\nEngland, which -- according to available science-based information -- is\ndirectly related to the infection in badgers, can be found at\n<http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article4340286.ece>.\n\nDEFRA's explanatory information is available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/index.htm>.\n\nThe number of new outbreaks in cattle during 2007, as reported to the OIE\n(World Organisation for Animal Health), was: England -- 3153(!); Wales --\n902; Scotland -- 58. Updated information on possible cases of human\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ infections in the various parts of the UK would be\nappreciated.\n\nAccording to OIE's WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database)\ninterface data, bovine tuberculosis was present in the Netherlands during\n2005 but no quantitative data were disclosed. Reportedly, the disease was\nabsent during the 1st half of 2006; no information is available for the 2nd\nhalf of 2006 or for 2007.\n\nOIE's WAHID data on new outbreaks in Belgium during the previous 2 years\nare the following: 2006 -- 7; 2007 -- 5. From a reliable source we have\nobtained the following unofficial information: \"A farm in Belgium, just\nacross the German border, went down with TB last month [June 2008].\nAllegedly, 22 cows out of 70 tested positive on the skin test.\"\nConfirmation (or, it is to be hoped, denial) of the information above from\nofficial sources would be appreciated. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sligo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NETHERLANDS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IRELAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "unofficially", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "97648", "headline": "PRO> Tuberculosis incidence, IMF effect - Central & E.Europe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=97648", "date": "2008-07-18 16:00:28", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK, IRELAND, THE NETHERLANDS ex UK\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: The Herald [edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.uk/business/farming/display.var.2401815.0.Netherlands_ban_endangers_British_export_industry.php>\n\n\nNetherlands ban endangers British export industry\n-------------------------------------------------\nA voluntary ban by Dutch cattle importers on the live export of cattle from\nthe UK threatens to devastate the British export industry, just as it was\nrecovering from last year's [2007] foot and mouth [disease] restrictions.\n\nThe move comes after 12 calves, which were exported from a farm in England\nto 6 farms in the Netherlands had to be slaughtered after subsequent tests\non the English farm detected tuberculosis [TB] in the herd. A further 27\nfarms that have been in contact with the original 6 are now under\nrestriction and Dutch vets are testing more than 4000 cattle for the disease.\n\nUnofficially, Belgian farmers are also refusing to take British calves and\nadult cattle. Exporters fear that a complete ban on the trade of live\ncattle throughout the European Union could be in force next week. The news\nhas shocked farmers in the Netherlands, which has been free of TB since 1994.\n\nDuring 2006, the UK exported a total of 81 000 live calves. That figure\nfell to 64 000 in 2007 as a result of export restrictions due to\nfoot-and-mouth disease, but was recovering well this year [2008] and latest\nfigures to June reveal that 40 000 had crossed the English Channel.\n\nThe next 3 months is the peak period when most UK calves are selected for\nthe export trade to the Netherlands, and any disruption to this trade will\nresult in the complete collapse of export businesses that have already lost\nmillions because of last year's [2007] foot and mouth disease ban.\n\nNFU (National Farmers' Union) Scotland vice-president Nigel Miller said:\n\"This is a very worrying development at a time when Scotland's dairy\nfarmers are achieving BP 50 to BP 60 per head [USD 99.70 to 119.64] for\nexport-quality bull calves. \"We have spoken to Scotland's chief vet to\nraise our concerns while our Brussels office is in dialogue with their\nDutch union counterparts on the subject. If the Commission becomes\ninvolved, then what we would want to see is a proportionate response to\nthis issue, one which takes the wider calf trade in the EU into\nconsideration and one which stops well short of a unilateral ban on live\ncalf exports from the UK.\n\n\"Scotland has worked hard to preserve its excellent record on TB. We\nalready have low incidence status and, as an industry, we have set targets\nto further reduce the number of cases of TB seen here. Any suggestion of a\nEuropean ban on live calves affecting Scotland would be unjustified and\nunnecessary.\"\n\n[byline: Rog Wood]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2008\nSource: Wales Online, Western Mail report [edited]\n<http://www.walesonline.co.uk/countryside-farming-news/farming-news/2008/07/15/wales-will-kill-badgers-row-91466-21339761/>\n\n\nWales will kill badgers -- row\n------------------------------\nThe DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs)\nsecretary of state's decision to rule out a badger cull in England will not\naffect proposals to go ahead with one in Wales.\n\nRural Affairs minister Elin Jones said nothing had changed and plans for a\ncull in a pilot area as part of a package of measures to eradicate bTB\n[bovine tuberculosis] were proceeding as announced last April [2008]. \"It\nhas not affected my thinking at all. Various expert groups set up to advise\nare gathering information as we speak on the various factors we need to\ntake account of,\" said Ms Jones. \"Then at some point later in the year I\nwill be given advice from my officials as to what, when and where.\"\n\nAmong the issues that need to be addressed is the willingness of all\nlandowners to take part in the trial cull. This will only work if officials\nare able to slaughter all the animals within a clearly defined area in\norder to gauge whether it has any effect on the spread of the disease.\n\nA small minority of farmers opposes a badger cull, and larger numbers of\nlandowners with small acreages may try to prevent it from happening. The\nBadger Trust has already lodged an application for a judicial review of a\n\"naive and short-sighted political decision\". The trust claims the badger\nplays no role in the spread of bTB, which now affects more than 2000 farms\nin Wales. Last year [2007] nearly 8000 cattle were culled at a cost in\ncompensation to farmers of BP 15.2m [USD 30.3m].\n\n\"The harsh reality is that Wales' bovine TB problem can be easily traced to\ncattle movements and farming practices,\" says a Badger Trust report. \"There\nis a clear and known correlation between larger herd sizes and an increased\nrisk of bovine TB.\"\n\nThe National Farmers' Union has promised a legal challenge to what it calls\nthe UK environment minister Hilary Benn's \"disgraceful abdication of\nresponsibility\" in ruling out a cull. NFU president, Bedfordshire farmer\nPeter Kendall and vice president Meurig Raymond, who farms in\nPembrokeshire, led a demonstration outside the House of Parliament after Mr\nBenn's announcement. Mr Kendall said the NFU would mount a legal challenge\nand withdraw from talks on cost and responsibility sharing. The Tenant\nFarmers Association (TFA) has also pulled out of talks on sharing the costs\nand responsibilities of animal diseases, which it describes as\n\"hypocritical and damaging\" without controls of bTB in wildlife.\n\n[byline: Steve Dube]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: Business Scotsman [edited]\n<http://business.scotsman.com/fooddrinkagriculture/TB-outbreak--raises-fears.4301536.jp>\n\n\nTB outbreak raises fears of ban on UK calves\n--------------------------------------------\nThere appears to be a real possibility that the export of young bull calves\nfrom dairy herds in the UK to mainland Europe may be banned following the\ndiscovery to bovine tuberculosis on 27 farms in the Netherlands.\n\nA dairy herd in England, previously free from TB, has suffered a breakdown\nand it is believed that calves from this farm are the source of the\nproblem, which was discovered during routine testing.\n\nAbout 400 000 calves are exported at around 10 days of age from the UK for\nveal production. These must come from TB-free farms. However, there is no\nreliable test for TB in animals that are aged less than 42 days.\n\nIn certain parts of the European Union, there is a view that the UK is a\nreservoir of disease: first BSE in 1996, then the world's largest epidemic\nof foot and mouth disease in 2001 followed by a smaller outbreak of the\nsame disease last year [2007].\n\nThe vast majority of farmers and many leading scientists assert there is a\nclear link between TB and badgers, which are deemed to be the principal\nvector of this disease.\n\nThe latest forecast is that up to 40 000 cattle in England will be culled\nduring 2008. Only last week Hilary Benn, the secretary of state at DEFRA\n(UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs), ruled out a cull\nof badgers. He said that a cull of badgers \"could end up making the disease\nworse if it was not sustained over time or delivered effectively and public\nopposition, including the unwillingness of some landowners to take part,\nwould render this more difficult.\"\n\nJeff Rooker, a junior minister at DEFRA, is of a different opinion.\nSpeaking in the House of Lords he said: \"Badger-to-cattle transmission is\nheavy. It accounts for 70-80 per cent [of] cases.\"\n\n[byline: Dan Buglass]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Thu 17 Jul 2008\nSource: Farmers Weekly Interactive [edited]\n<http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2008/07/17/111222/badger-cull-has-desired-effect-in-ireland.html>\n\n\nBadger cull has desired effect in Ireland\n-----------------------------------------\nThe incidence of bovine TB in the Republic of Ireland continues to decline,\nas the department of agriculture in Dublin presses on with its cull of\ninfected badgers. A government spokeswoman explained that, even though\nthere had been a slight increase in 2007, this was because the level of\ntesting had increased substantially following the opening of a new\nlaboratory in Sligo. Slaughterhouse inspection procedures had also\nimproved. \"With TB you should never look at one year in isolation, as there\nare so many pieces that go together,\" she said. \"It's best to look at 5\nyear trends and that shows a steady fall in TB.\"\n\nFor example, in 1998 the number of TB reactors came to 45 000, but by 2003\nhad dropped to 28 000. In 2006 there was a further fall to 24 000, though\nlast year [2007] it was up to 28 000. Disease incidence stands at about 6\nper cent of herds tested, compared with 8.2 per cent in the peak year of 2000.\n\nThe Irish government is adamant that badger culling is a key factor in\ncontaining the disease. \"Elsewhere in the world, the tuberculin test\nprovides all the control necessary to get on top of TB. Only in Ireland and\nGB, where there is also a wildlife challenge, is there a problem.\"\n\nIn New Zealand, for example, TB had been contained when possums -- the\ncommon vector -- were culled, while in Australia it was wild buffalo that\nhad been taken out.\n\nBadger culling is strictly controlled in the Republic of Ireland. It is\nonly triggered where, following an outbreak, an epidemiological study\nimplicates badgers as the likely source, not cattle. The spokeswoman\ninsisted there was no plan to cull out all the badgers in an area -- merely\nto reduce the population and so reduce contact opportunities, until a\nvaccine was available. She also explained that, unlike in GB, there was no\nproblem with perturbation. \"It seems our badger populations are quite\ndifferent,\" she said. \"They have different diets, different reproduction,\nand different densities. Their social groups are smaller and they are less\nterritorial.\"\n\nThe government has a self-imposed cap of culling on just 30 per cent of the\nagricultural area. So far it has covered about 20 per cent, taking out\nabout 2 thirds of the badgers in that area. About half of these were TB\ninfected.\n\nFarmers contribute to the cost of the programme with a statutory levy on\nmilk sales, and on cattle slaughtered or exported.\n\n[byline: Philip Clarke]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional information on the recent bovine tuberculosis developments in\nEngland, which -- according to available science-based information -- is\ndirectly related to the infection in badgers, can be found at\n<http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article4340286.ece>.\n\nDEFRA's explanatory information is available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/index.htm>.\n\nThe number of new outbreaks in cattle during 2007, as reported to the OIE\n(World Organisation for Animal Health), was: England -- 3153(!); Wales --\n902; Scotland -- 58. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1994-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-06-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sligo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NETHERLANDS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IRELAND", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "unofficially", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "97235", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, caprine - UK: (Wales)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=97235", "date": "2008-07-18 16:00:28", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK, IRELAND, THE NETHERLANDS ex UK\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: The Herald [edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.uk/business/farming/display.var.2401815.0.Netherlands_ban_endangers_British_export_industry.php>\n\n\nNetherlands ban endangers British export industry\n-------------------------------------------------\nA voluntary ban by Dutch cattle importers on the live export of cattle from\nthe UK threatens to devastate the British export industry, just as it was\nrecovering from last year's [2007] foot and mouth [disease] restrictions.\n\nThe move comes after 12 calves, which were exported from a farm in England\nto 6 farms in the Netherlands had to be slaughtered after subsequent tests\non the English farm detected tuberculosis [TB] in the herd. A further 27\nfarms that have been in contact with the original 6 are now under\nrestriction and Dutch vets are testing more than 4000 cattle for the disease.\n\nUnofficially, Belgian farmers are also refusing to take British calves and\nadult cattle. Exporters fear that a complete ban on the trade of live\ncattle throughout the European Union could be in force next week. The news\nhas shocked farmers in the Netherlands, which has been free of TB since 1994.\n\nDuring 2006, the UK exported a total of 81 000 live calves. That figure\nfell to 64 000 in 2007 as a result of export restrictions due to\nfoot-and-mouth disease, but was recovering well this year [2008] and latest\nfigures to June reveal that 40 000 had crossed the English Channel.\n\nThe next 3 months is the peak period when most UK calves are selected for\nthe export trade to the Netherlands, and any disruption to this trade will\nresult in the complete collapse of export businesses that have already lost\nmillions because of last year's [2007] foot and mouth disease ban.\n\nNFU (National Farmers' Union) Scotland vice-president Nigel Miller said:\n\"This is a very worrying development at a time when Scotland's dairy\nfarmers are achieving BP 50 to BP 60 per head [USD 99.70 to 119.64] for\nexport-quality bull calves. \"We have spoken to Scotland's chief vet to\nraise our concerns while our Brussels office is in dialogue with their\nDutch union counterparts on the subject. If the Commission becomes\ninvolved, then what we would want to see is a proportionate response to\nthis issue, one which takes the wider calf trade in the EU into\nconsideration and one which stops well short of a unilateral ban on live\ncalf exports from the UK.\n\n\"Scotland has worked hard to preserve its excellent record on TB. We\nalready have low incidence status and, as an industry, we have set targets\nto further reduce the number of cases of TB seen here. Any suggestion of a\nEuropean ban on live calves affecting Scotland would be unjustified and\nunnecessary.\"\n\n[byline: Rog Wood]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2008\nSource: Wales Online, Western Mail report [edited]\n<http://www.walesonline.co.uk/countryside-farming-news/farming-news/2008/07/15/wales-will-kill-badgers-row-91466-21339761/>\n\n\nWales will kill badgers -- row\n------------------------------\nThe DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs)\nsecretary of state's decision to rule out a badger cull in England will not\naffect proposals to go ahead with one in Wales.\n\nRural Affairs minister Elin Jones said nothing had changed and plans for a\ncull in a pilot area as part of a package of measures to eradicate bTB\n[bovine tuberculosis] were proceeding as announced last April [2008]. \"It\nhas not affected my thinking at all. Various expert groups set up to advise\nare gathering information as we speak on the various factors we need to\ntake account of,\" said Ms Jones. \"Then at some point later in the year I\nwill be given advice from my officials as to what, when and where.\"\n\nAmong the issues that need to be addressed is the willingness of all\nlandowners to take part in the trial cull. This will only work if officials\nare able to slaughter all the animals within a clearly defined area in\norder to gauge whether it has any effect on the spread of the disease.\n\nA small minority of farmers opposes a badger cull, and larger numbers of\nlandowners with small acreages may try to prevent it from happening. The\nBadger Trust has already lodged an application for a judicial review of a\n\"naive and short-sighted political decision\". The trust claims the badger\nplays no role in the spread of bTB, which now affects more than 2000 farms\nin Wales. Last year [2007] nearly 8000 cattle were culled at a cost in\ncompensation to farmers of BP 15.2m [USD 30.3m].\n\n\"The harsh reality is that Wales' bovine TB problem can be easily traced to\ncattle movements and farming practices,\" says a Badger Trust report. \"There\nis a clear and known correlation between larger herd sizes and an increased\nrisk of bovine TB.\"\n\nThe National Farmers' Union has promised a legal challenge to what it calls\nthe UK environment minister Hilary Benn's \"disgraceful abdication of\nresponsibility\" in ruling out a cull. NFU president, Bedfordshire farmer\nPeter Kendall and vice president Meurig Raymond, who farms in\nPembrokeshire, led a demonstration outside the House of Parliament after Mr\nBenn's announcement. Mr Kendall said the NFU would mount a legal challenge\nand withdraw from talks on cost and responsibility sharing. The Tenant\nFarmers Association (TFA) has also pulled out of talks on sharing the costs\nand responsibilities of animal diseases, which it describes as\n\"hypocritical and damaging\" without controls of bTB in wildlife.\n\n[byline: Steve Dube]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: Business Scotsman [edited]\n<http://business.scotsman.com/fooddrinkagriculture/TB-outbreak--raises-fears.4301536.jp>\n\n\nTB outbreak raises fears of ban on UK calves\n--------------------------------------------\nThere appears to be a real possibility that the export of young bull calves\nfrom dairy herds in the UK to mainland Europe may be banned following the\ndiscovery to bovine tuberculosis on 27 farms in the Netherlands.\n\nA dairy herd in England, previously free from TB, has suffered a breakdown\nand it is believed that calves from this farm are the source of the\nproblem, which was discovered during routine testing.\n\nAbout 400 000 calves are exported at around 10 days of age from the UK for\nveal production. These must come from TB-free farms. However, there is no\nreliable test for TB in animals that are aged less than 42 days.\n\nIn certain parts of the European Union, there is a view that the UK is a\nreservoir of disease: first BSE in 1996, then the world's largest epidemic\nof foot and mouth disease in 2001 followed by a smaller outbreak of the\nsame disease last year [2007].\n\nThe vast majority of farmers and many leading scientists assert there is a\nclear link between TB and badgers, which are deemed to be the principal\nvector of this disease.\n\nThe latest forecast is that up to 40 000 cattle in England will be culled\nduring 2008. Only last week Hilary Benn, the secretary of state at DEFRA\n(UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs), ruled out a cull\nof badgers. He said that a cull of badgers \"could end up making the disease\nworse if it was not sustained over time or delivered effectively and public\nopposition, including the unwillingness of some landowners to take part,\nwould render this more difficult.\"\n\nJeff Rooker, a junior minister at DEFRA, is of a different opinion.\nSpeaking in the House of Lords he said: \"Badger-to-cattle transmission is\nheavy. It accounts for 70-80 per cent [of] cases.\"\n\n[byline: Dan Buglass]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Thu 17 Jul 2008\nSource: Farmers Weekly Interactive [edited]\n<http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2008/07/17/111222/badger-cull-has-desired-effect-in-ireland.html>\n\n\nBadger cull has desired effect in Ireland\n-----------------------------------------\nThe incidence of bovine TB in the Republic of Ireland continues to decline,\nas the department of agriculture in Dublin presses on with its cull of\ninfected badgers. A government spokeswoman explained that, even though\nthere had been a slight increase in 2007, this was because the level of\ntesting had increased substantially following the opening of a new\nlaboratory in Sligo. Slaughterhouse inspection procedures had also\nimproved. \"With TB you should never look at one year in isolation, as there\nare so many pieces that go together,\" she said. \"It's best to look at 5\nyear trends and that shows a steady fall in TB.\"\n\nFor example, in 1998 the number of TB reactors came to 45 000, but by 2003\nhad dropped to 28 000. In 2006 there was a further fall to 24 000, though\nlast year [2007] it was up to 28 000. Disease incidence stands at about 6\nper cent of herds tested, compared with 8.2 per cent in the peak year of 2000.\n\nThe Irish government is adamant that badger culling is a key factor in\ncontaining the disease. \"Elsewhere in the world, the tuberculin test\nprovides all the control necessary to get on top of TB. Only in Ireland and\nGB, where there is also a wildlife challenge, is there a problem.\"\n\nIn New Zealand, for example, TB had been contained when possums -- the\ncommon vector -- were culled, while in Australia it was wild buffalo that\nhad been taken out.\n\nBadger culling is strictly controlled in the Republic of Ireland. It is\nonly triggered where, following an outbreak, an epidemiological study\nimplicates badgers as the likely source, not cattle. The spokeswoman\ninsisted there was no plan to cull out all the badgers in an area -- merely\nto reduce the population and so reduce contact opportunities, until a\nvaccine was available. She also explained that, unlike in GB, there was no\nproblem with perturbation. \"It seems our badger populations are quite\ndifferent,\" she said. \"They have different diets, different reproduction,\nand different densities. Their social groups are smaller and they are less\nterritorial.\"\n\nThe government has a self-imposed cap of culling on just 30 per cent of the\nagricultural area. So far it has covered about 20 per cent, taking out\nabout 2 thirds of the badgers in that area. About half of these were TB\ninfected.\n\nFarmers contribute to the cost of the programme with a statutory levy on\nmilk sales, and on cattle slaughtered or exported.\n\n[byline: Philip Clarke]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional information on the recent bovine tuberculosis developments in\nEngland, which -- according to available science-based information -- is\ndirectly related to the infection in badgers, can be found at\n<http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article4340286.ece>.\n\nDEFRA's explanatory information is available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/index.htm>.\n\nThe number of new outbreaks in cattle during 2007, as reported to the OIE\n(World Organisation for Animal Health), was: England -- 3153(!); Wales --\n902; Scotland -- 58. Updated information on possible cases of human\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ infections in the various parts of the UK would be\nappreciated.\n\nAccording to OIE's WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database)\ninterface data, bovine tuberculosis was present in the Netherlands during\n2005 but no quantitative data were disclosed. Reportedly, the disease was\nabsent during the 1st half of 2006; no information is available for the 2nd\nhalf of 2006 or for 2007.\n\nOIE's WAHID data on new outbreaks in Belgium during the previous 2 years\nare the following: 2006 -- 7; 2007 -- 5. From a reliable source we have\nobtained the following unofficial information: \"A farm in Belgium, just\nacross the German border, went down with TB last month [June 2008].\nAllegedly, 22 cows out of 70 tested positive on the skin test.\"\nConfirmation (or, it is to be hoped, denial) of the information above from\nofficial sources would be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n---\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI) 20050112.0102\n2004\n---\nTuberculosis, cervids, bovines - New Zealand 20040818.2290\nTuberculosis, cervids - New Zealand 20040804.2132\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England): wildlife 20040717.1941\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) (02) 20040716.1930\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20040216.0513\n2003\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20031105.2745\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20031021.2647\n2002\n---\nTuberculosis, cervids - New Zealand 20021208.6015\nTuberculosis, cattle - UK, Ireland, Netherlands ex UK", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=96261", "date": "2008-07-18 16:00:28", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - UK, IRELAND, THE NETHERLANDS ex UK\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\n\n[1] The Netherlands: bovine tuberculosis ex UK\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: The Herald [edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.uk/business/farming/display.var.2401815.0.Netherlands_ban_endangers_British_export_industry.php>\n\n\nNetherlands ban endangers British export industry\n-------------------------------------------------\nA voluntary ban by Dutch cattle importers on the live export of cattle from\nthe UK threatens to devastate the British export industry, just as it was\nrecovering from last year's [2007] foot and mouth [disease] restrictions.\n\nThe move comes after 12 calves, which were exported from a farm in England\nto 6 farms in the Netherlands had to be slaughtered after subsequent tests\non the English farm detected tuberculosis [TB] in the herd. A further 27\nfarms that have been in contact with the original 6 are now under\nrestriction and Dutch vets are testing more than 4000 cattle for the disease.\n\nUnofficially, Belgian farmers are also refusing to take British calves and\nadult cattle. Exporters fear that a complete ban on the trade of live\ncattle throughout the European Union could be in force next week. The news\nhas shocked farmers in the Netherlands, which has been free of TB since 1994.\n\nDuring 2006, the UK exported a total of 81 000 live calves. That figure\nfell to 64 000 in 2007 as a result of export restrictions due to\nfoot-and-mouth disease, but was recovering well this year [2008] and latest\nfigures to June reveal that 40 000 had crossed the English Channel.\n\nThe next 3 months is the peak period when most UK calves are selected for\nthe export trade to the Netherlands, and any disruption to this trade will\nresult in the complete collapse of export businesses that have already lost\nmillions because of last year's [2007] foot and mouth disease ban.\n\nNFU (National Farmers' Union) Scotland vice-president Nigel Miller said:\n\"This is a very worrying development at a time when Scotland's dairy\nfarmers are achieving BP 50 to BP 60 per head [USD 99.70 to 119.64] for\nexport-quality bull calves. \"We have spoken to Scotland's chief vet to\nraise our concerns while our Brussels office is in dialogue with their\nDutch union counterparts on the subject. If the Commission becomes\ninvolved, then what we would want to see is a proportionate response to\nthis issue, one which takes the wider calf trade in the EU into\nconsideration and one which stops well short of a unilateral ban on live\ncalf exports from the UK.\n\n\"Scotland has worked hard to preserve its excellent record on TB. We\nalready have low incidence status and, as an industry, we have set targets\nto further reduce the number of cases of TB seen here. Any suggestion of a\nEuropean ban on live calves affecting Scotland would be unjustified and\nunnecessary.\"\n\n[byline: Rog Wood]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] UK (Wales): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2008\nSource: Wales Online, Western Mail report [edited]\n<http://www.walesonline.co.uk/countryside-farming-news/farming-news/2008/07/15/wales-will-kill-badgers-row-91466-21339761/>\n\n\nWales will kill badgers -- row\n------------------------------\nThe DEFRA (UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs)\nsecretary of state's decision to rule out a badger cull in England will not\naffect proposals to go ahead with one in Wales.\n\nRural Affairs minister Elin Jones said nothing had changed and plans for a\ncull in a pilot area as part of a package of measures to eradicate bTB\n[bovine tuberculosis] were proceeding as announced last April [2008]. \"It\nhas not affected my thinking at all. Various expert groups set up to advise\nare gathering information as we speak on the various factors we need to\ntake account of,\" said Ms Jones. \"Then at some point later in the year I\nwill be given advice from my officials as to what, when and where.\"\n\nAmong the issues that need to be addressed is the willingness of all\nlandowners to take part in the trial cull. This will only work if officials\nare able to slaughter all the animals within a clearly defined area in\norder to gauge whether it has any effect on the spread of the disease.\n\nA small minority of farmers opposes a badger cull, and larger numbers of\nlandowners with small acreages may try to prevent it from happening. The\nBadger Trust has already lodged an application for a judicial review of a\n\"naive and short-sighted political decision\". The trust claims the badger\nplays no role in the spread of bTB, which now affects more than 2000 farms\nin Wales. Last year [2007] nearly 8000 cattle were culled at a cost in\ncompensation to farmers of BP 15.2m [USD 30.3m].\n\n\"The harsh reality is that Wales' bovine TB problem can be easily traced to\ncattle movements and farming practices,\" says a Badger Trust report. \"There\nis a clear and known correlation between larger herd sizes and an increased\nrisk of bovine TB.\"\n\nThe National Farmers' Union has promised a legal challenge to what it calls\nthe UK environment minister Hilary Benn's \"disgraceful abdication of\nresponsibility\" in ruling out a cull. NFU president, Bedfordshire farmer\nPeter Kendall and vice president Meurig Raymond, who farms in\nPembrokeshire, led a demonstration outside the House of Parliament after Mr\nBenn's announcement. Mr Kendall said the NFU would mount a legal challenge\nand withdraw from talks on cost and responsibility sharing. The Tenant\nFarmers Association (TFA) has also pulled out of talks on sharing the costs\nand responsibilities of animal diseases, which it describes as\n\"hypocritical and damaging\" without controls of bTB in wildlife.\n\n[byline: Steve Dube]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] UK (Scotland): badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2008\nSource: Business Scotsman [edited]\n<http://business.scotsman.com/fooddrinkagriculture/TB-outbreak--raises-fears.4301536.jp>\n\n\nTB outbreak raises fears of ban on UK calves\n--------------------------------------------\nThere appears to be a real possibility that the export of young bull calves\nfrom dairy herds in the UK to mainland Europe may be banned following the\ndiscovery to bovine tuberculosis on 27 farms in the Netherlands.\n\nA dairy herd in England, previously free from TB, has suffered a breakdown\nand it is believed that calves from this farm are the source of the\nproblem, which was discovered during routine testing.\n\nAbout 400 000 calves are exported at around 10 days of age from the UK for\nveal production. These must come from TB-free farms. However, there is no\nreliable test for TB in animals that are aged less than 42 days.\n\nIn certain parts of the European Union, there is a view that the UK is a\nreservoir of disease: first BSE in 1996, then the world's largest epidemic\nof foot and mouth disease in 2001 followed by a smaller outbreak of the\nsame disease last year [2007].\n\nThe vast majority of farmers and many leading scientists assert there is a\nclear link between TB and badgers, which are deemed to be the principal\nvector of this disease.\n\nThe latest forecast is that up to 40 000 cattle in England will be culled\nduring 2008. Only last week Hilary Benn, the secretary of state at DEFRA\n(UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs), ruled out a cull\nof badgers. He said that a cull of badgers \"could end up making the disease\nworse if it was not sustained over time or delivered effectively and public\nopposition, including the unwillingness of some landowners to take part,\nwould render this more difficult.\"\n\nJeff Rooker, a junior minister at DEFRA, is of a different opinion.\nSpeaking in the House of Lords he said: \"Badger-to-cattle transmission is\nheavy. It accounts for 70-80 per cent [of] cases.\"\n\n[byline: Dan Buglass]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Ireland: badger cull policy discussed\nDate: Thu 17 Jul 2008\nSource: Farmers Weekly Interactive [edited]\n<http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2008/07/17/111222/badger-cull-has-desired-effect-in-ireland.html>\n\n\nBadger cull has desired effect in Ireland\n-----------------------------------------\nThe incidence of bovine TB in the Republic of Ireland continues to decline,\nas the department of agriculture in Dublin presses on with its cull of\ninfected badgers. A government spokeswoman explained that, even though\nthere had been a slight increase in 2007, this was because the level of\ntesting had increased substantially following the opening of a new\nlaboratory in Sligo. Slaughterhouse inspection procedures had also\nimproved. \"With TB you should never look at one year in isolation, as there\nare so many pieces that go together,\" she said. \"It's best to look at 5\nyear trends and that shows a steady fall in TB.\"\n\nFor example, in 1998 the number of TB reactors came to 45 000, but by 2003\nhad dropped to 28 000. In 2006 there was a further fall to 24 000, though\nlast year [2007] it was up to 28 000. Disease incidence stands at about 6\nper cent of herds tested, compared with 8.2 per cent in the peak year of 2000.\n\nThe Irish government is adamant that badger culling is a key factor in\ncontaining the disease. \"Elsewhere in the world, the tuberculin test\nprovides all the control necessary to get on top of TB. Only in Ireland and\nGB, where there is also a wildlife challenge, is there a problem.\"\n\nIn New Zealand, for example, TB had been contained when possums -- the\ncommon vector -- were culled, while in Australia it was wild buffalo that\nhad been taken out.\n\nBadger culling is strictly controlled in the Republic of Ireland. It is\nonly triggered where, following an outbreak, an epidemiological study\nimplicates badgers as the likely source, not cattle. The spokeswoman\ninsisted there was no plan to cull out all the badgers in an area -- merely\nto reduce the population and so reduce contact opportunities, until a\nvaccine was available. She also explained that, unlike in GB, there was no\nproblem with perturbation. \"It seems our badger populations are quite\ndifferent,\" she said. \"They have different diets, different reproduction,\nand different densities. Their social groups are smaller and they are less\nterritorial.\"\n\nThe government has a self-imposed cap of culling on just 30 per cent of the\nagricultural area. So far it has covered about 20 per cent, taking out\nabout 2 thirds of the badgers in that area. About half of these were TB\ninfected.\n\nFarmers contribute to the cost of the programme with a statutory levy on\nmilk sales, and on cattle slaughtered or exported.\n\n[byline: Philip Clarke]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional information on the recent bovine tuberculosis developments in\nEngland, which -- according to available science-based information -- is\ndirectly related to the infection in badgers, can be found at\n<http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article4340286.ece>.\n\nDEFRA's explanatory information is available at\n<http://www.defra.gov.uk/animalh/tb/index.htm>.\n\nThe number of new outbreaks in cattle during 2007, as reported to the OIE\n(World Organisation for Animal Health), was: England -- 3153(!); Wales --\n902; Scotland -- 58. Updated information on possible cases of human\n_Mycobacterium bovis_ infections in the various parts of the UK would be\nappreciated.\n\nAccording to OIE's WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database)\ninterface data, bovine tuberculosis was present in the Netherlands during\n2005 but no quantitative data were disclosed. Reportedly, the disease was\nabsent during the 1st half of 2006; no information is available for the 2nd\nhalf of 2006 or for 2007.\n\nOIE's WAHID data on new outbreaks in Belgium during the previous 2 years\nare the following: 2006 -- 7; 2007 -- 5. From a reliable source we have\nobtained the following unofficial information: \"A farm in Belgium, just\nacross the German border, went down with TB last month [June 2008].\nAllegedly, 22 cows out of 70 tested positive on the skin test.\"\nConfirmation (or, it is to be hoped, denial) of the information above from\nofficial sources would be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nBovine tuberculosis - UK, Ireland 20070731.2473\n2006\n---\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02) 20061015.2967\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (03) 20061014.2945\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK (02) 20061011.2915\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) 20061009.2896\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20061005.2857\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK: badger vaccine trial 20060622.1724\n2005\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20051209.3549\nTuberculosis, bovine, pigs - UK (England) 20050713.1996\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI) 20050112.0102\n2004\n---\nTuberculosis, cervids, bovines - New Zealand 20040818.2290\nTuberculosis, cervids - New Zealand 20040804.2132\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England): wildlife 20040717.1941\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) (02) 20040716.1930\nBovine tuberculosis, human - UK (Gloucestershire) 20040714.1890\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (England) 20040216.0513\n2003\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, badgers - UK 20031105.2745\nTuberculosis, bovine - UK (Scotland) 20031021.2647\n2002\n---\nTuberculosis, cervids - New Zealand 20021208.6015\nTuberculosis, cattle - USA (05): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=93972", "date": "2008-04-03 15:00:19", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR - NAMIBIA\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 2 Apr 2008\nSource: AllAfrica, The Namibian (Windhoek) report [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200804020649.html>\n\n\nHealth professionals are quietly treating up to 24 confirmed cases of\nextensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB), the worst form of TB with\nseriously limited treatment options and chances of cure, in Namibian hospitals.\n\nWell-placed health sources have confirmed to The Namibian that the extreme\nform of TB is currently under control, but expressed fears that the country\ndoes not have the capacity to deal with a major outbreak of XDR-TB.\n\nThe Namibian had been aware of at least one case being treated at Walvis\nBay since December 2007, but health sources said this week that the\nsituation was worse than initially thought.\n\nOn Friday [28 Mar 2008], health minister Dr Richard Kamwi only expressed\nfears that Namibia was about to record its 1st cases of XDR-TB. \"There are\ncurrently 254 cases of multi-drug-resistant TB [resistant to the 2 best\n1st-line anti-TB drugs INH (isoniacid) and rifampin - Mod.LL] under\ntreatment throughout the country. This is a great concern and is a clear\nindication that it is only a matter of time before we will have extremely\ndrug-resistant cases, known as XDR tuberculosis, in Namibia [MDR-TB with\nadditional resistance to the oral fluoroquinolones, and at least one of the\n3 injectable anti-tuberculosis drugs capreomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin -\nMod.LL]),\" Kamwi said at the World TB Day event staged at Mariental on\nFriday [28 Mar 2008].\n\nHe said experts in the Ministry of Health were busy reviewing all TB cases\nwith drug resistance to verify the extent of the problem. \"Given the large\nnumber of cases, we may well find some XDR-TB amongst this group,\" Kamwi said.\n\nKamwi confirmed that Namibia was the country with the 2nd highest TB\nincidence in the world after Swaziland, with 15 244 cases reported in 2007\nalone.\n\nThe host region of this year's TB Day event, Hardap, had the highest\nincidence of TB in Namibia in 2007, reporting a worrying 1294 cases per 100\n000 people, Kamwi said.\n\nThe TB situation is exacerbated by the HIV-AIDS epidemic in the country.\n\"In 2007, 8186 TB patients representing 54 per cent of the total notified\npatients were tested for HIV and 59 per cent were HIV positive,\" Kamwi\nsaid. He said the impact of the dual infection of TB with HIV-AIDS was a\nmajor cause for concern, in particular as it affected the Namibian workforce.\n\n[byline: Christof Maletsky]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Namibia shares a border with South Africa the country where the XDR-TB was\ninitially discovered linked primarily to HIV co-infected individuals. The\nborder can be found on a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Namibia>.\n\nIt is not clear from the posting if the presumed XDR-TB strain(s) are\nidentical to those from South Africa or other countries with the isolates.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - UK (Scotland) ex Somalia 20080322.1094\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - South Africa 20080208.0521\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\nTuberculosis, XDR - Botswana, South Africa 20080118.0222\n2007\n---\nTuberculosis, XDR, MDR: genome sequences 20071122.3780\nTuberculosis - Uganda (02): MDR, susp. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1294-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Swaziland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Botswana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "92431", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, post cyclone - Myanmar: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=92431", "date": "2008-04-03 15:00:19", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR - NAMIBIA\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 2 Apr 2008\nSource: AllAfrica, The Namibian (Windhoek) report [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200804020649.html>\n\n\nHealth professionals are quietly treating up to 24 confirmed cases of\nextensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB), the worst form of TB with\nseriously limited treatment options and chances of cure, in Namibian hospitals.\n\nWell-placed health sources have confirmed to The Namibian that the extreme\nform of TB is currently under control, but expressed fears that the country\ndoes not have the capacity to deal with a major outbreak of XDR-TB.\n\nThe Namibian had been aware of at least one case being treated at Walvis\nBay since December 2007, but health sources said this week that the\nsituation was worse than initially thought.\n\nOn Friday [28 Mar 2008], health minister Dr Richard Kamwi only expressed\nfears that Namibia was about to record its 1st cases of XDR-TB. \"There are\ncurrently 254 cases of multi-drug-resistant TB [resistant to the 2 best\n1st-line anti-TB drugs INH (isoniacid) and rifampin - Mod.LL] under\ntreatment throughout the country. This is a great concern and is a clear\nindication that it is only a matter of time before we will have extremely\ndrug-resistant cases, known as XDR tuberculosis, in Namibia [MDR-TB with\nadditional resistance to the oral fluoroquinolones, and at least one of the\n3 injectable anti-tuberculosis drugs capreomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin -\nMod.LL]),\" Kamwi said at the World TB Day event staged at Mariental on\nFriday [28 Mar 2008].\n\nHe said experts in the Ministry of Health were busy reviewing all TB cases\nwith drug resistance to verify the extent of the problem. \"Given the large\nnumber of cases, we may well find some XDR-TB amongst this group,\" Kamwi said.\n\nKamwi confirmed that Namibia was the country with the 2nd highest TB\nincidence in the world after Swaziland, with 15 244 cases reported in 2007\nalone.\n\nThe host region of this year's TB Day event, Hardap, had the highest\nincidence of TB in Namibia in 2007, reporting a worrying 1294 cases per 100\n000 people, Kamwi said.\n\nThe TB situation is exacerbated by the HIV-AIDS epidemic in the country.\n\"In 2007, 8186 TB patients representing 54 per cent of the total notified\npatients were tested for HIV and 59 per cent were HIV positive,\" Kamwi\nsaid. He said the impact of the dual infection of TB with HIV-AIDS was a\nmajor cause for concern, in particular as it affected the Namibian workforce.\n\n[byline: Christof Maletsky]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Namibia shares a border with South Africa the country where the XDR-TB was\ninitially discovered linked primarily to HIV co-infected individuals. The\nborder can be found on a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Namibia>.\n\nIt is not clear from the posting if the presumed XDR-TB strain(s) are\nidentical to those from South Africa or other countries with the isolates.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - UK (Scotland) ex Somalia 20080322.1094\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - South Africa 20080208.0521\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\nTuberculosis, XDR - Botswana, South Africa 20080118.0222\n2007\n---\nTuberculosis, XDR, MDR: genome sequences 20071122.3780\nTuberculosis - Uganda (02): MDR, susp. Kuwait (03): Jul-Dec 2007", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=92102", "date": "2008-04-03 15:00:19", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR - NAMIBIA\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 2 Apr 2008\nSource: AllAfrica, The Namibian (Windhoek) report [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200804020649.html>\n\n\nHealth professionals are quietly treating up to 24 confirmed cases of\nextensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB), the worst form of TB with\nseriously limited treatment options and chances of cure, in Namibian hospitals.\n\nWell-placed health sources have confirmed to The Namibian that the extreme\nform of TB is currently under control, but expressed fears that the country\ndoes not have the capacity to deal with a major outbreak of XDR-TB.\n\nThe Namibian had been aware of at least one case being treated at Walvis\nBay since December 2007, but health sources said this week that the\nsituation was worse than initially thought.\n\nOn Friday [28 Mar 2008], health minister Dr Richard Kamwi only expressed\nfears that Namibia was about to record its 1st cases of XDR-TB. \"There are\ncurrently 254 cases of multi-drug-resistant TB [resistant to the 2 best\n1st-line anti-TB drugs INH (isoniacid) and rifampin - Mod.LL] under\ntreatment throughout the country. This is a great concern and is a clear\nindication that it is only a matter of time before we will have extremely\ndrug-resistant cases, known as XDR tuberculosis, in Namibia [MDR-TB with\nadditional resistance to the oral fluoroquinolones, and at least one of the\n3 injectable anti-tuberculosis drugs capreomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin -\nMod.LL]),\" Kamwi said at the World TB Day event staged at Mariental on\nFriday [28 Mar 2008].\n\nHe said experts in the Ministry of Health were busy reviewing all TB cases\nwith drug resistance to verify the extent of the problem. \"Given the large\nnumber of cases, we may well find some XDR-TB amongst this group,\" Kamwi said.\n\nKamwi confirmed that Namibia was the country with the 2nd highest TB\nincidence in the world after Swaziland, with 15 244 cases reported in 2007\nalone.\n\nThe host region of this year's TB Day event, Hardap, had the highest\nincidence of TB in Namibia in 2007, reporting a worrying 1294 cases per 100\n000 people, Kamwi said.\n\nThe TB situation is exacerbated by the HIV-AIDS epidemic in the country.\n\"In 2007, 8186 TB patients representing 54 per cent of the total notified\npatients were tested for HIV and 59 per cent were HIV positive,\" Kamwi\nsaid. He said the impact of the dual infection of TB with HIV-AIDS was a\nmajor cause for concern, in particular as it affected the Namibian workforce.\n\n[byline: Christof Maletsky]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Namibia shares a border with South Africa the country where the XDR-TB was\ninitially discovered linked primarily to HIV co-infected individuals. The\nborder can be found on a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Namibia>.\n\nIt is not clear from the posting if the presumed XDR-TB strain(s) are\nidentical to those from South Africa or other countries with the isolates.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - UK (Scotland) ex Somalia 20080322.1094\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - South Africa 20080208.0521\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\nTuberculosis, XDR - Botswana, South Africa 20080118.0222\n2007\n---\nTuberculosis, XDR, MDR: genome sequences 20071122.3780\nTuberculosis - Uganda (02): MDR, susp. RFI 20071004.3284\nTuberculosis - Uganda: deadly strain, RFI 20071002.3255\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (11): fugitives 20071002.3251\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (10): Western Cape 20070627.2071\nTuberculosis, XDR - worldwide (02) 20070623.2034\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (09): Western Cape 20070604.1805\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070601.1778\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (USA, France, Canada,\nCzech Rep.) 20070529.1738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (08): Western Cape 20070425.1349\nTuberculosis, XDR, 2003-2006 - Europe (Germany, Italy) 20070403.1132\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (07): Eastern Cape 20070326.1044\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1993-2006 - USA 20070322.1005\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (06) 20070319.0959\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1991-2003 - Spain 20070302.0738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (05) 20070228.0717\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (04) 20070220.0638\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (03) 20070209.0504\nTuberculosis, XDR - worldwide 20070205.0456\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\n\n.................sc/ll/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1294-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Swaziland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Botswana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "79932", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - Kuwait (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=79932", "date": "2008-04-03 15:00:19", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR - NAMIBIA\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 2 Apr 2008\nSource: AllAfrica, The Namibian (Windhoek) report [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200804020649.html>\n\n\nHealth professionals are quietly treating up to 24 confirmed cases of\nextensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB), the worst form of TB with\nseriously limited treatment options and chances of cure, in Namibian hospitals.\n\nWell-placed health sources have confirmed to The Namibian that the extreme\nform of TB is currently under control, but expressed fears that the country\ndoes not have the capacity to deal with a major outbreak of XDR-TB.\n\nThe Namibian had been aware of at least one case being treated at Walvis\nBay since December 2007, but health sources said this week that the\nsituation was worse than initially thought.\n\nOn Friday [28 Mar 2008], health minister Dr Richard Kamwi only expressed\nfears that Namibia was about to record its 1st cases of XDR-TB. \"There are\ncurrently 254 cases of multi-drug-resistant TB [resistant to the 2 best\n1st-line anti-TB drugs INH (isoniacid) and rifampin - Mod.LL] under\ntreatment throughout the country. This is a great concern and is a clear\nindication that it is only a matter of time before we will have extremely\ndrug-resistant cases, known as XDR tuberculosis, in Namibia [MDR-TB with\nadditional resistance to the oral fluoroquinolones, and at least one of the\n3 injectable anti-tuberculosis drugs capreomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin -\nMod.LL]),\" Kamwi said at the World TB Day event staged at Mariental on\nFriday [28 Mar 2008].\n\nHe said experts in the Ministry of Health were busy reviewing all TB cases\nwith drug resistance to verify the extent of the problem. \"Given the large\nnumber of cases, we may well find some XDR-TB amongst this group,\" Kamwi said.\n\nKamwi confirmed that Namibia was the country with the 2nd highest TB\nincidence in the world after Swaziland, with 15 244 cases reported in 2007\nalone.\n\nThe host region of this year's TB Day event, Hardap, had the highest\nincidence of TB in Namibia in 2007, reporting a worrying 1294 cases per 100\n000 people, Kamwi said.\n\nThe TB situation is exacerbated by the HIV-AIDS epidemic in the country.\n\"In 2007, 8186 TB patients representing 54 per cent of the total notified\npatients were tested for HIV and 59 per cent were HIV positive,\" Kamwi\nsaid. He said the impact of the dual infection of TB with HIV-AIDS was a\nmajor cause for concern, in particular as it affected the Namibian workforce.\n\n[byline: Christof Maletsky]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Namibia shares a border with South Africa the country where the XDR-TB was\ninitially discovered linked primarily to HIV co-infected individuals. The\nborder can be found on a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Namibia>.\n\nIt is not clear from the posting if the presumed XDR-TB strain(s) are\nidentical to those from South Africa or other countries with the isolates.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - UK (Scotland) ex Somalia 20080322.1094\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - South Africa 20080208.0521\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\nTuberculosis, XDR - Botswana, South Africa 20080118.0222\n2007\n---\nTuberculosis, XDR, MDR: genome sequences 20071122.3780\nTuberculosis - Uganda (02): MDR, susp. Mod.LL] under\ntreatment throughout the country. This is a great concern and is a clear\nindication that it is only a matter of time before we will have extremely\ndrug-resistant cases, known as XDR tuberculosis, in Namibia [MDR-TB with\nadditional resistance to the oral fluoroquinolones, and at least one of the\n3 injectable anti-tuberculosis drugs capreomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin -\nMod.LL]),\" Kamwi said at the World TB Day event staged at Mariental on\nFriday [28 Mar 2008].\n\nHe said experts in the Ministry of Health were busy reviewing all TB cases\nwith drug resistance to verify the extent of the problem. \"Given the large\nnumber of cases, we may well find some XDR-TB amongst this group,\" Kamwi said.\n\nKamwi confirmed that Namibia was the country with the 2nd highest TB\nincidence in the world after Swaziland, with 15 244 cases reported in 2007\nalone.\n\nThe host region of this year's TB Day event, Hardap, had the highest\nincidence of TB in Namibia in 2007, reporting a worrying 1294 cases per 100\n000 people, Kamwi said.\n\nThe TB situation is exacerbated by the HIV-AIDS epidemic in the country.\n\"In 2007, 8186 TB patients representing 54 per cent of the total notified\npatients were tested for HIV and 59 per cent were HIV positive,\" Kamwi\nsaid. He said the impact of the dual infection of TB with HIV-AIDS was a\nmajor cause for concern, in particular as it affected the Namibian workforce.\n\n[byline: Christof Maletsky]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Namibia shares a border with South Africa the country where the XDR-TB was\ninitially discovered linked primarily to HIV co-infected individuals. Mod.LL] under\ntreatment throughout the country. This is a great concern and is a clear\nindication that it is only a matter of time before we will have extremely\ndrug-resistant cases, known as XDR tuberculosis, in Namibia [MDR-TB with\nadditional resistance to the oral fluoroquinolones, and at least one of the\n3 injectable anti-tuberculosis drugs capreomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin -\nMod.LL]),\" Kamwi said at the World TB Day event staged at Mariental on\nFriday [28 Mar 2008].\n\nHe said experts in the Ministry of Health were busy reviewing all TB cases\nwith drug resistance to verify the extent of the problem. \"Given the large\nnumber of cases, we may well find some XDR-TB amongst this group,\" Kamwi said.\n\nKamwi confirmed that Namibia was the country with the 2nd highest TB\nincidence in the world after Swaziland, with 15 244 cases reported in 2007\nalone.\n\nThe host region of this year's TB Day event, Hardap, had the highest\nincidence of TB in Namibia in 2007, reporting a worrying 1294 cases per 100\n000 people, Kamwi said.\n\nThe TB situation is exacerbated by the HIV-AIDS epidemic in the country.\n\"In 2007, 8186 TB patients representing 54 per cent of the total notified\npatients were tested for HIV and 59 per cent were HIV positive,\" Kamwi\nsaid.
