USA (04): (MN) status downgrade", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=71259", "date": "2008-04-03 15:00:19", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR - NAMIBIA\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 2 Apr 2008\nSource: AllAfrica, The Namibian (Windhoek) report [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200804020649.html>\n\n\nHealth professionals are quietly treating up to 24 confirmed cases of\nextensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB), the worst form of TB with\nseriously limited treatment options and chances of cure, in Namibian hospitals.\n\nWell-placed health sources have confirmed to The Namibian that the extreme\nform of TB is currently under control, but expressed fears that the country\ndoes not have the capacity to deal with a major outbreak of XDR-TB.\n\nThe Namibian had been aware of at least one case being treated at Walvis\nBay since December 2007, but health sources said this week that the\nsituation was worse than initially thought.\n\nOn Friday [28 Mar 2008], health minister Dr Richard Kamwi only expressed\nfears that Namibia was about to record its 1st cases of XDR-TB. \"There are\ncurrently 254 cases of multi-drug-resistant TB [resistant to the 2 best\n1st-line anti-TB drugs INH (isoniacid) and rifampin - Mod.LL] under\ntreatment throughout the country. This is a great concern and is a clear\nindication that it is only a matter of time before we will have extremely\ndrug-resistant cases, known as XDR tuberculosis, in Namibia [MDR-TB with\nadditional resistance to the oral fluoroquinolones, and at least one of the\n3 injectable anti-tuberculosis drugs capreomycin, kanamycin, and amikacin -\nMod.LL]),\" Kamwi said at the World TB Day event staged at Mariental on\nFriday [28 Mar 2008].\n\nHe said experts in the Ministry of Health were busy reviewing all TB cases\nwith drug resistance to verify the extent of the problem. \"Given the large\nnumber of cases, we may well find some XDR-TB amongst this group,\" Kamwi said.\n\nKamwi confirmed that Namibia was the country with the 2nd highest TB\nincidence in the world after Swaziland, with 15 244 cases reported in 2007\nalone.\n\nThe host region of this year's TB Day event, Hardap, had the highest\nincidence of TB in Namibia in 2007, reporting a worrying 1294 cases per 100\n000 people, Kamwi said.\n\nThe TB situation is exacerbated by the HIV-AIDS epidemic in the country.\n\"In 2007, 8186 TB patients representing 54 per cent of the total notified\npatients were tested for HIV and 59 per cent were HIV positive,\" Kamwi\nsaid. He said the impact of the dual infection of TB with HIV-AIDS was a\nmajor cause for concern, in particular as it affected the Namibian workforce.\n\n[byline: Christof Maletsky]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Namibia shares a border with South Africa the country where the XDR-TB was\ninitially discovered linked primarily to HIV co-infected individuals. The\nborder can be found on a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Namibia>.\n\nIt is not clear from the posting if the presumed XDR-TB strain(s) are\nidentical to those from South Africa or other countries with the isolates.\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - UK (Scotland) ex Somalia 20080322.1094\nTuberculosis, MDR, XDR - Worldwide: WHO 20080228.0813\nTuberculosis, MDR - South Africa 20080208.0521\nTuberculosis, MDR - Papua New Guinea 20080206.0478\nTuberculosis, XDR - Botswana, South Africa 20080118.0222\n2007\n---\nTuberculosis, XDR, MDR: genome sequences 20071122.3780\nTuberculosis - Uganda (02): MDR, susp. The chronic\ndisease doesn't threaten the quality or safety of milk and meat produced in\nthe state because most milk is pasteurized, and raw milk is regularly\ntested for TB. Cattle processed for meat are routinely inspected for TB, too.\n\nOfficials tested for the rare disease after inspectors saw suspicious\nlesions on a cow being examined for slaughter, said California Department\nof Food and Agriculture spokesman Steve Lyle. A total of 5 cows have tested\npositive since then.\n\nState agricultural authorities are barring the farm from moving cows off\ntheir property indefinitely to prevent further spread of disease, Lyle said.\n\nThe dairy farmer is working with state and federal animal health officials\nto eradicate the disease from the herd, the department said.\n\nBovine TB was last found in California in 2003.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The State of California will be taking are hard look at where the disease\nmay have come from. They will be busy tracing animals that moved into\n(trace-ins) and animals moved out (trace-outs) of the herd and testing\nherds where those animals came from. Any others herds found to be positive\ncould put the \"free-state\" status for California in jeopardy. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2003\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20030123.0203\n2002\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) (02) 20021127.5908\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20021117.5832\n\n....................tg/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The chronic\ndisease doesn't threaten the quality or safety of milk and meat produced in\nthe state because most milk is pasteurized, and raw milk is regularly\ntested for TB. Cattle processed for meat are routinely inspected for TB, too.\n\nOfficials tested for the rare disease after inspectors saw suspicious\nlesions on a cow being examined for slaughter, said California Department\nof Food and Agriculture spokesman Steve Lyle. A total of 5 cows have tested\npositive since then.\n\nState agricultural authorities are barring the farm from moving cows off\ntheir property indefinitely to prevent further spread of disease, Lyle said.\n\nThe dairy farmer is working with state and federal animal health officials\nto eradicate the disease from the herd, the department said.\n\nBovine TB was last found in California in 2003.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The State of California will be taking are hard look at where the disease\nmay have come from. They will be busy tracing animals that moved into\n(trace-ins) and animals moved out (trace-outs) of the herd and testing\nherds where those animals came from. Any others herds found to be positive\ncould put the \"free-state\" status for California in jeopardy. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2003\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20030123.0203\n2002\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) (02) 20021127.5908\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20021117.5832\n\n....................tg/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The chronic\ndisease doesn't threaten the quality or safety of milk and meat produced in\nthe state because most milk is pasteurized, and raw milk is regularly\ntested for TB. Cattle processed for meat are routinely inspected for TB, too.\n\nOfficials tested for the rare disease after inspectors saw suspicious\nlesions on a cow being examined for slaughter, said California Department\nof Food and Agriculture spokesman Steve Lyle. A total of 5 cows have tested\npositive since then.\n\nState agricultural authorities are barring the farm from moving cows off\ntheir property indefinitely to prevent further spread of disease, Lyle said.\n\nThe dairy farmer is working with state and federal animal health officials\nto eradicate the disease from the herd, the department said.\n\nBovine TB was last found in California in 2003.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The State of California will be taking are hard look at where the disease\nmay have come from. They will be busy tracing animals that moved into\n(trace-ins) and animals moved out (trace-outs) of the herd and testing\nherds where those animals came from. Any others herds found to be positive\ncould put the \"free-state\" status for California in jeopardy. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2003\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20030123.0203\n2002\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) (02) 20021127.5908\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CA) 20021117.5832\n\n....................tg/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The chronic\ndisease doesn't threaten the quality or safety of milk and meat produced in\nthe state because most milk is pasteurized, and raw milk is regularly\ntested for TB. Cattle processed for meat are routinely inspected for TB, too.\n\nOfficials tested for the rare disease after inspectors saw suspicious\nlesions on a cow being examined for slaughter, said California Department\nof Food and Agriculture spokesman Steve Lyle. A total of 5 cows have tested\npositive since then.\n\nState agricultural authorities are barring the farm from moving cows off\ntheir property indefinitely to prevent further spread of disease, Lyle said.\n\nThe dairy farmer is working with state and federal animal health officials\nto eradicate the disease from the herd, the department said.\n\nBovine TB was last found in California in 2003.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The State of California will be taking are hard look at where the disease\nmay have come from. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2008-02-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Fresno County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "51624", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - USA: (MN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=51624", "date": "2007-10-29 21:00:09", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 25 Oct 2007\nSource: Star Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.startribune.com/462/story/1508165.html>\n\n\nA heifer from a farm in northern Minnesota's Beltrami County has tested\npositive for bovine tuberculosis (TB), dealing a disappointing setback for\nthe state's cattle industry, the Minnesota Board of Animal Health said\ntoday [25 Oct 2007]. The state has now detected bovine TB in 8 beef herds\nin Roseau and Beltrami counties. While the infections pose little risk to\nhuman health, the latest discovery slows the industry in its effort to\nregain the crucial \"TB-free\" status, the board said.\n\nThe Beltrami County herd was quarantined last year [2006] after a TB\ninvestigation revealed the owner had bought animals from a TB-infected\nfarm. The entire herd was tested at that time, and all animals tested\nnegative. But in a follow-up test this fall [2007], 2 animals tested\n\"suspect\" for bovine TB. Tissue samples were submitted to the National\nVeterinary Services Laboratory in Ames, Iowa, and bovine TB was confirmed\nin a 12 month old beef heifer Tuesday [23 Oct 2007]. The 2nd animal was\nnegative.\n\nThat herd numbered about 350. The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) is\nworking with the herd operator to have the animals put down and then\narrange compensation, the state board said.\n\nThe state's cattle herds will be declared free of TB only after 2 years\npass without a positive test. Losing the \"TB-free\" label poses a cumbersome\nfinancial burden for ranchers, who must then pay for testing if they want\nto sell their animals outside of the state.\n\nThis latest discovery means the industry must start over toward having 2\nyears of being TB-free. It had been about a year into achieving that status\nbefore this positive test, said Board of Animal Health spokeswoman Malissa\nFritz.\n\nThe state's cattle herd health status took its initial hit in January 2006,\nwhen the USDA said Minnesota cows were no longer considered free of\ntuberculosis. That decision came after the discovery of 5 infected herds in\nnorth western Minnesota.\n\nIn a statement issued today [25 Oct 2007], Dr Bill Hartmann, state\nveterinarian and Board of Animal Health executive director said: \"Finding\nanother positive herd will reset our time line for regaining status, but\nfor the sake of Minnesota's cattle industry, we cannot leave a single\ninfected herd undiscovered.\"\n\nIn addition to traces and area testing, the state is conducting TB testing\nin cattle herds statewide. This statewide surveillance began before\ndiscovery of this latest infected herd and is expected to be complete by\nthe end of the year [2007]. So far, the state has tested about 1200 herds,\nand all have tested negative for bovine TB.\n\nThe disease is of little threat to consumers. The milk from an infected\nanimal would be rendered harmless by pasteurization, and infected meat\nwould be screened out of the food chain by visual inspections conducted at\nthe slaughterhouse, according to state officials.\n\n[byline: Paul Walsh]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Minnesota has been trying to eliminate this disease from the state for\nseveral years. The elimination process proceeds. Tuberculosis is caused by\nthe bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. Although this bacterium primarily\naffects bovines, it can affect a wide range of mammals, including humans,\nswine, and deer. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Minnesota can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) (02) 20070817.2690\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) (02) 20070619.1980\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (OK) 20070501.1420\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) 20070306.0787\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) 20070206.0470\n2006\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03) 20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) (02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) 20050716.2030\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Nebraska) 20050207.0418\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI) 20050112.0102\n\n.................tg/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beltrami County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beltrami", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "50284", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - Botswana, South Africa", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=50284", "date": "2007-10-29 21:00:09", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 25 Oct 2007\nSource: Star Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.startribune.com/462/story/1508165.html>\n\n\nA heifer from a farm in northern Minnesota's Beltrami County has tested\npositive for bovine tuberculosis (TB), dealing a disappointing setback for\nthe state's cattle industry, the Minnesota Board of Animal Health said\ntoday [25 Oct 2007]. The state has now detected bovine TB in 8 beef herds\nin Roseau and Beltrami counties. While the infections pose little risk to\nhuman health, the latest discovery slows the industry in its effort to\nregain the crucial \"TB-free\" status, the board said.\n\nThe Beltrami County herd was quarantined last year [2006] after a TB\ninvestigation revealed the owner had bought animals from a TB-infected\nfarm. The 2nd animal was\nnegative.\n\nThat herd numbered about 350. The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) is\nworking with the herd operator to have the animals put down and then\narrange compensation, the state board said.\n\nThe state's cattle herds will be declared free of TB only after 2 years\npass without a positive test. Losing the \"TB-free\" label poses a cumbersome\nfinancial burden for ranchers, who must then pay for testing if they want\nto sell their animals outside of the state.\n\nThis latest discovery means the industry must start over toward having 2\nyears of being TB-free. It had been about a year into achieving that status\nbefore this positive test, said Board of Animal Health spokeswoman Malissa\nFritz.\n\nThe state's cattle herd health status took its initial hit in January 2006,\nwhen the USDA said Minnesota cows were no longer considered free of\ntuberculosis. That decision came after the discovery of 5 infected herds in\nnorth western Minnesota.\n\nIn a statement issued today [25 Oct 2007], Dr Bill Hartmann, state\nveterinarian and Board of Animal Health executive director said: \"Finding\nanother positive herd will reset our time line for regaining status, but\nfor the sake of Minnesota's cattle industry, we cannot leave a single\ninfected herd undiscovered.\"\n\nIn addition to traces and area testing, the state is conducting TB testing\nin cattle herds statewide. This statewide surveillance began before\ndiscovery of this latest infected herd and is expected to be complete by\nthe end of the year [2007]. So far, the state has tested about 1200 herds,\nand all have tested negative for bovine TB.\n\nThe disease is of little threat to consumers. The milk from an infected\nanimal would be rendered harmless by pasteurization, and infected meat\nwould be screened out of the food chain by visual inspections conducted at\nthe slaughterhouse, according to state officials.\n\n[byline: Paul Walsh]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Minnesota has been trying to eliminate this disease from the state for\nseveral years. The elimination process proceeds. Tuberculosis is caused by\nthe bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. Although this bacterium primarily\naffects bovines, it can affect a wide range of mammals, including humans,\nswine, and deer. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Minnesota can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) (02) 20070817.2690\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) (02) 20070619.1980\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (OK) 20070501.1420\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) 20070306.0787\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) 20070206.0470\n2006\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03) 20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) (02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) 20050716.2030\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Nebraska) 20050207.0418\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI) 20050112.0102\n\n.................tg/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The state has now detected bovine TB in 8 beef herds\nin Roseau and Beltrami counties. While the infections pose little risk to\nhuman health, the latest discovery slows the industry in its effort to\nregain the crucial \"TB-free\" status, the board said.\n\nThe Beltrami County herd was quarantined last year [2006] after a TB\ninvestigation revealed the owner had bought animals from a TB-infected\nfarm. The entire herd was tested at that time, and all animals tested\nnegative. But in a follow-up test this fall [2007], 2 animals tested\n\"suspect\" for bovine TB. Tissue samples were submitted to the National\nVeterinary Services Laboratory in Ames, Iowa, and bovine TB was confirmed\nin a 12 month old beef heifer Tuesday [23 Oct 2007]. The 2nd animal was\nnegative.\n\nThat herd numbered about 350. The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) is\nworking with the herd operator to have the animals put down and then\narrange compensation, the state board said.\n\nThe state's cattle herds will be declared free of TB only after 2 years\npass without a positive test. Losing the \"TB-free\" label poses a cumbersome\nfinancial burden for ranchers, who must then pay for testing if they want\nto sell their animals outside of the state.\n\nThis latest discovery means the industry must start over toward having 2\nyears of being TB-free. It had been about a year into achieving that status\nbefore this positive test, said Board of Animal Health spokeswoman Malissa\nFritz.\n\nThe state's cattle herd health status took its initial hit in January 2006,\nwhen the USDA said Minnesota cows were no longer considered free of\ntuberculosis. That decision came after the discovery of 5 infected herds in\nnorth western Minnesota.\n\nIn a statement issued today [25 Oct 2007], Dr Bill Hartmann, state\nveterinarian and Board of Animal Health executive director said: \"Finding\nanother positive herd will reset our time line for regaining status, but\nfor the sake of Minnesota's cattle industry, we cannot leave a single\ninfected herd undiscovered.\"\n\nIn addition to traces and area testing, the state is conducting TB testing\nin cattle herds statewide. This statewide surveillance began before\ndiscovery of this latest infected herd and is expected to be complete by\nthe end of the year [2007]. So far, the state has tested about 1200 herds,\nand all have tested negative for bovine TB.\n\nThe disease is of little threat to consumers. The milk from an infected\nanimal would be rendered harmless by pasteurization, and infected meat\nwould be screened out of the food chain by visual inspections conducted at\nthe slaughterhouse, according to state officials.\n\n[byline: Paul Walsh]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Minnesota has been trying to eliminate this disease from the state for\nseveral years. The elimination process proceeds. Tuberculosis is caused by\nthe bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. Although this bacterium primarily\naffects bovines, it can affect a wide range of mammals, including humans,\nswine, and deer. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Minnesota can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) (02) 20070817.2690\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) (02) 20070619.1980\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (OK) 20070501.1420\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) 20070306.0787\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) 20070206.0470\n2006\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03) 20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) (02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) 20050716.2030\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Nebraska) 20050207.0418\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI) 20050112.0102\n\n.................tg/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The state has now detected bovine TB in 8 beef herds\nin Roseau and Beltrami counties. While the infections pose little risk to\nhuman health, the latest discovery slows the industry in its effort to\nregain the crucial \"TB-free\" status, the board said.\n\nThe Beltrami County herd was quarantined last year [2006] after a TB\ninvestigation revealed the owner had bought animals from a TB-infected\nfarm. The 2nd animal was\nnegative.\n\nThat herd numbered about 350. The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) is\nworking with the herd operator to have the animals put down and then\narrange compensation, the state board said.\n\nThe state's cattle herds will be declared free of TB only after 2 years\npass without a positive test. Losing the \"TB-free\" label poses a cumbersome\nfinancial burden for ranchers, who must then pay for testing if they want\nto sell their animals outside of the state.\n\nThis latest discovery means the industry must start over toward having 2\nyears of being TB-free. It had been about a year into achieving that status\nbefore this positive test, said Board of Animal Health spokeswoman Malissa\nFritz.\n\nThe state's cattle herd health status took its initial hit in January 2006,\nwhen the USDA said Minnesota cows were no longer considered free of\ntuberculosis. That decision came after the discovery of 5 infected herds in\nnorth western Minnesota.\n\nIn a statement issued today [25 Oct 2007], Dr Bill Hartmann, state\nveterinarian and Board of Animal Health executive director said: \"Finding\nanother positive herd will reset our time line for regaining status, but\nfor the sake of Minnesota's cattle industry, we cannot leave a single\ninfected herd undiscovered.\"\n\nIn addition to traces and area testing, the state is conducting TB testing\nin cattle herds statewide. This statewide surveillance began before\ndiscovery of this latest infected herd and is expected to be complete by\nthe end of the year [2007]. So far, the state has tested about 1200 herds,\nand all have tested negative for bovine TB.\n\nThe disease is of little threat to consumers. The milk from an infected\nanimal would be rendered harmless by pasteurization, and infected meat\nwould be screened out of the food chain by visual inspections conducted at\nthe slaughterhouse, according to state officials.\n\n[byline: Paul Walsh]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Minnesota has been trying to eliminate this disease from the state for\nseveral years. This statewide surveillance began before\ndiscovery of this latest infected herd and is expected to be complete by\nthe end of the year [2007]. So far, the state has tested about 1200 herds,\nand all have tested negative for bovine TB.\n\nThe disease is of little threat to consumers. The state has now detected bovine TB in 8 beef herds\nin Roseau and Beltrami counties. While the infections pose little risk to\nhuman health, the latest discovery slows the industry in its effort to\nregain the crucial \"TB-free\" status, the board said.\n\nThe Beltrami County herd was quarantined last year [2006] after a TB\ninvestigation revealed the owner had bought animals from a TB-infected\nfarm. Losing the \"TB-free\" label poses a cumbersome\nfinancial burden for ranchers, who must then pay for testing if they want\nto sell their animals outside of the state.\n\nThis latest discovery means the industry must start over toward having 2\nyears of being TB-free. That decision came after the discovery of 5 infected herds in\nnorth western Minnesota.\n\nIn a statement issued today [25 Oct 2007], Dr Bill Hartmann, state\nveterinarian and Board of Animal Health executive director said: \"Finding\nanother positive herd will reset our time line for regaining status, but\nfor the sake of Minnesota's cattle industry, we cannot leave a single\ninfected herd undiscovered.\"\n\nIn addition to traces and area testing, the state is conducting TB testing\nin cattle herds statewide. This statewide surveillance began before\ndiscovery of this latest infected herd and is expected to be complete by\nthe end of the year [2007]. So far, the state has tested about 1200 herds,\nand all have tested negative for bovine TB.\n\nThe disease is of little threat to consumers. The milk from an infected\nanimal would be rendered harmless by pasteurization, and infected meat\nwould be screened out of the food chain by visual inspections conducted at\nthe slaughterhouse, according to state officials.\n\n[byline: Paul Walsh]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Minnesota has been trying to eliminate this disease from the state for\nseveral years. The elimination process proceeds. Tuberculosis is caused by\nthe bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. Although this bacterium primarily\naffects bovines, it can affect a wide range of mammals, including humans,\nswine, and deer. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Minnesota can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) (02) 20070817.2690\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) (02) 20070619.1980\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (OK) 20070501.1420\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) 20070306.0787\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) 20070206.0470\n2006\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03) 20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) (02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) 20050716.2030\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Nebraska) 20050207.0418\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI) 20050112.0102\n\n.................tg/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beltrami County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beltrami", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "36313", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, bovine - Canada: (BC, AB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=36313", "date": "2007-10-29 21:00:09", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - USA: (MINNESOTA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 25 Oct 2007\nSource: Star Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.startribune.com/462/story/1508165.html>\n\n\nA heifer from a farm in northern Minnesota's Beltrami County has tested\npositive for bovine tuberculosis (TB), dealing a disappointing setback for\nthe state's cattle industry, the Minnesota Board of Animal Health said\ntoday [25 Oct 2007]. The state has now detected bovine TB in 8 beef herds\nin Roseau and Beltrami counties. While the infections pose little risk to\nhuman health, the latest discovery slows the industry in its effort to\nregain the crucial \"TB-free\" status, the board said.\n\nThe Beltrami County herd was quarantined last year [2006] after a TB\ninvestigation revealed the owner had bought animals from a TB-infected\nfarm. The entire herd was tested at that time, and all animals tested\nnegative. But in a follow-up test this fall [2007], 2 animals tested\n\"suspect\" for bovine TB. Tissue samples were submitted to the National\nVeterinary Services Laboratory in Ames, Iowa, and bovine TB was confirmed\nin a 12 month old beef heifer Tuesday [23 Oct 2007]. The 2nd animal was\nnegative.\n\nThat herd numbered about 350. The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) is\nworking with the herd operator to have the animals put down and then\narrange compensation, the state board said.\n\nThe state's cattle herds will be declared free of TB only after 2 years\npass without a positive test. Losing the \"TB-free\" label poses a cumbersome\nfinancial burden for ranchers, who must then pay for testing if they want\nto sell their animals outside of the state.\n\nThis latest discovery means the industry must start over toward having 2\nyears of being TB-free. It had been about a year into achieving that status\nbefore this positive test, said Board of Animal Health spokeswoman Malissa\nFritz.\n\nThe state's cattle herd health status took its initial hit in January 2006,\nwhen the USDA said Minnesota cows were no longer considered free of\ntuberculosis. That decision came after the discovery of 5 infected herds in\nnorth western Minnesota.\n\nIn a statement issued today [25 Oct 2007], Dr Bill Hartmann, state\nveterinarian and Board of Animal Health executive director said: \"Finding\nanother positive herd will reset our time line for regaining status, but\nfor the sake of Minnesota's cattle industry, we cannot leave a single\ninfected herd undiscovered.\"\n\nIn addition to traces and area testing, the state is conducting TB testing\nin cattle herds statewide. This statewide surveillance began before\ndiscovery of this latest infected herd and is expected to be complete by\nthe end of the year [2007]. So far, the state has tested about 1200 herds,\nand all have tested negative for bovine TB.\n\nThe disease is of little threat to consumers. The milk from an infected\nanimal would be rendered harmless by pasteurization, and infected meat\nwould be screened out of the food chain by visual inspections conducted at\nthe slaughterhouse, according to state officials.\n\n[byline: Paul Walsh]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Minnesota has been trying to eliminate this disease from the state for\nseveral years. The elimination process proceeds. Tuberculosis is caused by\nthe bacterium _Mycobacterium bovis_. Although this bacterium primarily\naffects bovines, it can affect a wide range of mammals, including humans,\nswine, and deer. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Minnesota can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. - CopyEd.MJ]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) (02) 20070817.2690\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) (02) 20070619.1980\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (OK) 20070501.1420\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM) 20070306.0787\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) 20070206.0470\n2006\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN) (03) 20061101.3131\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) (02) 20060131.0310\nTuberculosis, bovine, cervid - USA (MN) 20060123.0225\n2005\n---\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) (02) 20051211.3564\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) with comment 20050716.2034\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (MN) 20050716.2030\nTuberculosis, bovine - USA (Nebraska) 20050207.0418\nTuberculosis, bovine, human ex cervid - USA (MI) 20050112.0102\n\n.................tg/mj/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beltrami County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beltrami", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "30415", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - Uganda (02): MDR, susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=30415", "date": "2007-08-31 14:00:08", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, HOSPITAL EXPOSURES - USA (WISCONSIN)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2007\nSource: Wisconsin State Journal [edited]\n<http://www.madison.com/wsj/mad/top/index.php?ntid=207698>\n\nA woman who cares for patients at UW [University of Wisconsin]\nHospital and the Veterans Hospital in Madison [Wisconsin] has\ntuberculosis [TB], which has prompted officials to test about 30 of\nher co-workers for the potentially fatal lung disease and try to\ncontact up to 150 patients who may have been exposed. The woman,\nwhose identity and job position hospital officials wouldn't provide,\nis thought to have been contagious for only a few days or not at all,\nsaid Dr. Dennis Maki, an infectious disease specialist at UW Hospital.\nThough TB can be spread through the air, it generally requires close,\nprolonged contact, Maki said. It would take about 6 months for most\npeople who were exposed to develop active disease, he said. Maki said\nit's too early to know if the woman has multidrug-resistant TB [MDR],\nwhich is more of a public health threat. Tests to determine that\ncould take another few weeks. \"The people probably at greatest risk\nare the other health-care workers she has worked closely with the\nlast 2 months,\" Maki said. Those people are getting skin tests this\nweek, he said. Any of them who test positive will be given\nantibiotics to prevent the development of active disease.\nFor patients, dozens of whom will be sought out soon by their doctors\nfor skin tests, \"I don't think there's any reason for them to be\nconcerned,\" Maki said.\nThe woman, whose routine annual skin test for TB was negative in\nNovember [2006], became ill about 3 weeks ago, he said. She didn't\nhave a cough or other respiratory symptoms typical of TB, he said.\nHer main complaint was abdominal pain, for which she underwent\nsurgery last week [20-26 Aug 2007], he said. During the surgery,\nabnormal tissue samples raised suspicion of TB, Maki said. After\nsurgery, he said, the woman was put in an isolation room, with\nnegative air pressure to contain germs and rules requiring workers to\nwear special masks. She was given antibiotics. A few days later, lab\nresults from the tissue samples were positive for TB, Maki said. The\nwoman then underwent the definitive test for TB, of her sputum. It\nwas positive. The woman returned home Tuesday [28 Aug 2007] and is\nrecovering well, Maki said. She will be on antibiotics for several months.\nMaki and other officials said they wouldn't identify her or her\nposition because of privacy laws. Because the woman didn't have the\ntypical symptoms of TB, notably a cough that could easily spread the\ndisease, she probably wasn't contagious, Maki said. \"If she was\ncontagious, it was probably only in the last days before she was\ndiagnosed,\" he said.\nSkin test results on her co-workers should come back by next week\n[3-9 Sep 2007]. If they are negative, it probably means she wasn't\ncontagious to anyone, though follow-up tests will still be performed,\nMaki said. Other co-workers who don't work with her as closely will\nbe screened for TB during this year's [2007] annual skin tests this\nfall, he said. Nearly 5000 people work at both hospitals. Letters\nwill go out next week to the primary care doctors of up to 150\npatients who may have been exposed, Maki said.\nDane County had 9 cases of active TB last year [2006], said Julie\nHalvorsen, a nursing supervisor with the Madison-Dane County Health\nDepartment. The county has had 4 cases this year [2007], including\nthe UW Hospital worker.\n[Byline: David Wahlberg]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Wisconsin can be found at\n<http://www.wistravel.com/map_of_wisconsin/>.\nMadison is the capital of the US state of Wisconsin and the county\nseat of Dane County. It is also home to the University of Wisconsin-Madison.\nTransmission of tuberculosis depends on the infectivity of the\npatient, ventilation of the space in which exposure takes place, and\nduration of exposure. Usually infectious patients have cavitary\ntuberculosis and are coughing or sneezing that generates a large\nquantity of aerosols that contain tubercle bacilli. This degree of\ninfectivity is indicated by a positive smear of sputum stained\nspecifically for mycobacteria (acid fast or AFB (acid-fast bacillus)\nsmear). Prolonged, close contact in poorly ventilated spaces enhances\ntransmission.\nTuberculosis has long been known to be a risk for health care\nworkers. Indeed, we published an extensive outbreak of latent and\nactive tuberculosis in an academic medical center in 1965 (N Engl J\nMed 1965; 275: 718-21); hospital outbreaks of TB occurred in the\n1980's among AIDS patients and healthcare workers, and hospital\noutbreaks of multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB occurred in the 1990's.\nHospital employees with patient contact are tuberculin skin tested at\nleast annually to assess recent acquisition of tuberculosis. If the\nhospital employee in the news release above was tested annually for\nmany years and the tuberculin skin test had been consistently\nnegative, followed by a positive one year later, then the positive\ntuberculin reaction would be the result of an infection acquired\nwithin the prior year. The rapid progression in hospital employee in\nthe above news release from latent infection acquired less than 6-8\nweeks before or at some time after her negative skin test in November\n2006 to extra-pulmonary disease suggests some degree of\nimmunosuppression. We are not told of any co-morbidities in this\nhospital worker.\nHowever, if she were 1st employed the prior year and had not been\ntuberculin skin tested before, an initial negative tuberculin test\nmay represent tuberculin hypersensitivity that has waned over the\nyears after latent tuberculosis that was acquired in childhood. The\ninitial tuberculin skin test, although negative at the time, can\nnevertheless stimulate the waned hypersensitivity to tuberculin. This\nboosted hypersensitivity can develop within several days of testing\nand persist. A subsequent positive tuberculin test then may be either\nthe result of a newly acquired infection or the \"booster effect\". A\nbooster effect can be assessed in someone who will undergo annual\ntesting, such as a hospital employee, by repeat testing one week\nafter an initial negative test; if the 2nd test is positive, the\nreaction is due to the booster effect.\nThe hospital worker in the news release was suspected to have\nintra-abdominal tuberculosis on visual exam of the tissues during\nabdominal surgery. The exact intra-abdominal site is not specified;\nit could be intestine, lymph node, peritoneum, or a visceral organ.\nThe lab tests, which were said to be \"positive\" a few days after\nsurgery, may have been a positive smear for acid-fast bacilli, but\nthe acid-fast organism could be _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ or\nnon-tuberculous mycobacteria. Nucleic acid amplification (NAA) tests\nare available for rapid laboratory diagnosis of _M. tuberculosis_ on\nrespiratory specimens, but I don't believe they have been as yet\nFDA-approved for non-respiratory specimens -- although some specialty\nlabs will do a NAA test on non-respiratory specimens. The news\nrelease says that the patient then had a \"definitive\" positive test\nfor TB on her sputum; a positive NAA test on sputum, although rapid,\nis only presumptive of TB\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm4926a3.htm>); the\ndefinitive test is a culture, but cultures require at least 2 weeks.\nWe are told that the hospital worker was thought to be \"contagious\nfor only a few days or not at all\" because she had no cough, but we\ndon't know her chest X-ray findings, nor do we know for sure if her\nsputum smears were positive for acid-fast bacilli. Certainly if she\nhad been coughing and producing sputum that was acid-fast bacilli\nsmear-positive with pulmonary cavities seen on chest X-ray, she would\nbe considered to be contagious.\nWe also don't know the status of her family or other household\ncontacts. If she has children who are skin test tuberculin-positive,\neither she or someone else in her household is likely contagious. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070731.2462\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070728.2430\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry 20070727.2418\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (04) 20070609.1888\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070601.1778\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070530.1752\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (USA, France,\nCanada, Czech Rep.) 20070529.1738\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA (MA) 20050616.1702\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) (03) 20050225.0602\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) 20050207.0411\n........................................ml/mj/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-11-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeist", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dane County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "30073", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - Uganda: deadly strain, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=30073", "date": "2007-08-31 14:00:08", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, HOSPITAL EXPOSURES - USA (WISCONSIN)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2007\nSource: Wisconsin State Journal [edited]\n<http://www.madison.com/wsj/mad/top/index.php?ntid=207698>\n\nA woman who cares for patients at UW [University of Wisconsin]\nHospital and the Veterans Hospital in Madison [Wisconsin] has\ntuberculosis [TB], which has prompted officials to test about 30 of\nher co-workers for the potentially fatal lung disease and try to\ncontact up to 150 patients who may have been exposed. The woman,\nwhose identity and job position hospital officials wouldn't provide,\nis thought to have been contagious for only a few days or not at all,\nsaid Dr. Dennis Maki, an infectious disease specialist at UW Hospital.\nThough TB can be spread through the air, it generally requires close,\nprolonged contact, Maki said. It would take about 6 months for most\npeople who were exposed to develop active disease, he said. Maki said\nit's too early to know if the woman has multidrug-resistant TB [MDR],\nwhich is more of a public health threat. Tests to determine that\ncould take another few weeks. \"The people probably at greatest risk\nare the other health-care workers she has worked closely with the\nlast 2 months,\" Maki said. Those people are getting skin tests this\nweek, he said. Any of them who test positive will be given\nantibiotics to prevent the development of active disease.\nFor patients, dozens of whom will be sought out soon by their doctors\nfor skin tests, \"I don't think there's any reason for them to be\nconcerned,\" Maki said.\nThe woman, whose routine annual skin test for TB was negative in\nNovember [2006], became ill about 3 weeks ago, he said. She didn't\nhave a cough or other respiratory symptoms typical of TB, he said.\nHer main complaint was abdominal pain, for which she underwent\nsurgery last week [20-26 Aug 2007], he said. During the surgery,\nabnormal tissue samples raised suspicion of TB, Maki said. After\nsurgery, he said, the woman was put in an isolation room, with\nnegative air pressure to contain germs and rules requiring workers to\nwear special masks. She was given antibiotics. A few days later, lab\nresults from the tissue samples were positive for TB, Maki said. The\nwoman then underwent the definitive test for TB, of her sputum. It\nwas positive. The woman returned home Tuesday [28 Aug 2007] and is\nrecovering well, Maki said. She will be on antibiotics for several months.\nMaki and other officials said they wouldn't identify her or her\nposition because of privacy laws. Because the woman didn't have the\ntypical symptoms of TB, notably a cough that could easily spread the\ndisease, she probably wasn't contagious, Maki said. \"If she was\ncontagious, it was probably only in the last days before she was\ndiagnosed,\" he said.\nSkin test results on her co-workers should come back by next week\n[3-9 Sep 2007]. If they are negative, it probably means she wasn't\ncontagious to anyone, though follow-up tests will still be performed,\nMaki said. Other co-workers who don't work with her as closely will\nbe screened for TB during this year's [2007] annual skin tests this\nfall, he said. Nearly 5000 people work at both hospitals. Letters\nwill go out next week to the primary care doctors of up to 150\npatients who may have been exposed, Maki said.\nDane County had 9 cases of active TB last year [2006], said Julie\nHalvorsen, a nursing supervisor with the Madison-Dane County Health\nDepartment. The county has had 4 cases this year [2007], including\nthe UW Hospital worker.\n[Byline: David Wahlberg]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Wisconsin can be found at\n<http://www.wistravel.com/map_of_wisconsin/>.\nMadison is the capital of the US state of Wisconsin and the county\nseat of Dane County. It is also home to the University of Wisconsin-Madison.\nTransmission of tuberculosis depends on the infectivity of the\npatient, ventilation of the space in which exposure takes place, and\nduration of exposure. Usually infectious patients have cavitary\ntuberculosis and are coughing or sneezing that generates a large\nquantity of aerosols that contain tubercle bacilli. This degree of\ninfectivity is indicated by a positive smear of sputum stained\nspecifically for mycobacteria (acid fast or AFB (acid-fast bacillus)\nsmear). Prolonged, close contact in poorly ventilated spaces enhances\ntransmission.\nTuberculosis has long been known to be a risk for health care\nworkers. Indeed, we published an extensive outbreak of latent and\nactive tuberculosis in an academic medical center in 1965 (N Engl J\nMed 1965; 275: 718-21); hospital outbreaks of TB occurred in the\n1980's among AIDS patients and healthcare workers, and hospital\noutbreaks of multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB occurred in the 1990's.\nHospital employees with patient contact are tuberculin skin tested at\nleast annually to assess recent acquisition of tuberculosis. If the\nhospital employee in the news release above was tested annually for\nmany years and the tuberculin skin test had been consistently\nnegative, followed by a positive one year later, then the positive\ntuberculin reaction would be the result of an infection acquired\nwithin the prior year. The rapid progression in hospital employee in\nthe above news release from latent infection acquired less than 6-8\nweeks before or at some time after her negative skin test in November\n2006 to extra-pulmonary disease suggests some degree of\nimmunosuppression. We are not told of any co-morbidities in this\nhospital worker.\nHowever, if she were 1st employed the prior year and had not been\ntuberculin skin tested before, an initial negative tuberculin test\nmay represent tuberculin hypersensitivity that has waned over the\nyears after latent tuberculosis that was acquired in childhood. The\ninitial tuberculin skin test, although negative at the time, can\nnevertheless stimulate the waned hypersensitivity to tuberculin. This\nboosted hypersensitivity can develop within several days of testing\nand persist. A subsequent positive tuberculin test then may be either\nthe result of a newly acquired infection or the \"booster effect\". A\nbooster effect can be assessed in someone who will undergo annual\ntesting, such as a hospital employee, by repeat testing one week\nafter an initial negative test; if the 2nd test is positive, the\nreaction is due to the booster effect.\nThe hospital worker in the news release was suspected to have\nintra-abdominal tuberculosis on visual exam of the tissues during\nabdominal surgery. The exact intra-abdominal site is not specified;\nit could be intestine, lymph node, peritoneum, or a visceral organ.\nThe lab tests, which were said to be \"positive\" a few days after\nsurgery, may have been a positive smear for acid-fast bacilli, but\nthe acid-fast organism could be _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ or\nnon-tuberculous mycobacteria. Nucleic acid amplification (NAA) tests\nare available for rapid laboratory diagnosis of _M. tuberculosis_ on\nrespiratory specimens, but I don't believe they have been as yet\nFDA-approved for non-respiratory specimens -- although some specialty\nlabs will do a NAA test on non-respiratory specimens. The news\nrelease says that the patient then had a \"definitive\" positive test\nfor TB on her sputum; a positive NAA test on sputum, although rapid,\nis only presumptive of TB\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm4926a3.htm>); the\ndefinitive test is a culture, but cultures require at least 2 weeks.\nWe are told that the hospital worker was thought to be \"contagious\nfor only a few days or not at all\" because she had no cough, but we\ndon't know her chest X-ray findings, nor do we know for sure if her\nsputum smears were positive for acid-fast bacilli. Certainly if she\nhad been coughing and producing sputum that was acid-fast bacilli\nsmear-positive with pulmonary cavities seen on chest X-ray, she would\nbe considered to be contagious.\nWe also don't know the status of her family or other household\ncontacts. If she has children who are skin test tuberculin-positive,\neither she or someone else in her household is likely contagious. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070731.2462\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070728.2430\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry 20070727.2418\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (04) 20070609.1888\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070601.1778\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070530.1752\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (USA, France,\nCanada, Czech Rep.) 20070529.1738\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA (MA) 20050616.1702\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) (03) 20050225.0602\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) 20050207.0411\n........................................ml/mj/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-11-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeist", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dane County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "30060", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (11): fugitives", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=30060", "date": "2007-08-31 14:00:08", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, HOSPITAL EXPOSURES - USA (WISCONSIN)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2007\nSource: Wisconsin State Journal [edited]\n<http://www.madison.com/wsj/mad/top/index.php?ntid=207698>\n\nA woman who cares for patients at UW [University of Wisconsin]\nHospital and the Veterans Hospital in Madison [Wisconsin] has\ntuberculosis [TB], which has prompted officials to test about 30 of\nher co-workers for the potentially fatal lung disease and try to\ncontact up to 150 patients who may have been exposed. The county has had 4 cases this year [2007], including\nthe UW Hospital worker.\n[Byline: David Wahlberg]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Wisconsin can be found at\n<http://www.wistravel.com/map_of_wisconsin/>.\nMadison is the capital of the US state of Wisconsin and the county\nseat of Dane County. It is also home to the University of Wisconsin-Madison.\nTransmission of tuberculosis depends on the infectivity of the\npatient, ventilation of the space in which exposure takes place, and\nduration of exposure. Usually infectious patients have cavitary\ntuberculosis and are coughing or sneezing that generates a large\nquantity of aerosols that contain tubercle bacilli. Prolonged, close contact in poorly ventilated spaces enhances\ntransmission.\nTuberculosis has long been known to be a risk for health care\nworkers. Indeed, we published an extensive outbreak of latent and\nactive tuberculosis in an academic medical center in 1965 (N Engl J\nMed 1965; 275: 718-21); hospital outbreaks of TB occurred in the\n1980's among AIDS patients and healthcare workers, and hospital\noutbreaks of multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB occurred in the 1990's.\nHospital employees with patient contact are tuberculin skin tested at\nleast annually to assess recent acquisition of tuberculosis. If the\nhospital employee in the news release above was tested annually for\nmany years and the tuberculin skin test had been consistently\nnegative, followed by a positive one year later, then the positive\ntuberculin reaction would be the result of an infection acquired\nwithin the prior year. The rapid progression in hospital employee in\nthe above news release from latent infection acquired less than 6-8\nweeks before or at some time after her negative skin test in November\n2006 to extra-pulmonary disease suggests some degree of\nimmunosuppression. We are not told of any co-morbidities in this\nhospital worker.\nHowever, if she were 1st employed the prior year and had not been\ntuberculin skin tested before, an initial negative tuberculin test\nmay represent tuberculin hypersensitivity that has waned over the\nyears after latent tuberculosis that was acquired in childhood. The\ninitial tuberculin skin test, although negative at the time, can\nnevertheless stimulate the waned hypersensitivity to tuberculin. This\nboosted hypersensitivity can develop within several days of testing\nand persist. A subsequent positive tuberculin test then may be either\nthe result of a newly acquired infection or the \"booster effect\". A\nbooster effect can be assessed in someone who will undergo annual\ntesting, such as a hospital employee, by repeat testing one week\nafter an initial negative test; if the 2nd test is positive, the\nreaction is due to the booster effect.\nThe hospital worker in the news release was suspected to have\nintra-abdominal tuberculosis on visual exam of the tissues during\nabdominal surgery. The exact intra-abdominal site is not specified;\nit could be intestine, lymph node, peritoneum, or a visceral organ.\nThe lab tests, which were said to be \"positive\" a few days after\nsurgery, may have been a positive smear for acid-fast bacilli, but\nthe acid-fast organism could be _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ or\nnon-tuberculous mycobacteria. Nucleic acid amplification (NAA) tests\nare available for rapid laboratory diagnosis of _M. tuberculosis_ on\nrespiratory specimens, but I don't believe they have been as yet\nFDA-approved for non-respiratory specimens -- although some specialty\nlabs will do a NAA test on non-respiratory specimens. The news\nrelease says that the patient then had a \"definitive\" positive test\nfor TB on her sputum; a positive NAA test on sputum, although rapid,\nis only presumptive of TB\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm4926a3.htm>); the\ndefinitive test is a culture, but cultures require at least 2 weeks.\nWe are told that the hospital worker was thought to be \"contagious\nfor only a few days or not at all\" because she had no cough, but we\ndon't know her chest X-ray findings, nor do we know for sure if her\nsputum smears were positive for acid-fast bacilli. Certainly if she\nhad been coughing and producing sputum that was acid-fast bacilli\nsmear-positive with pulmonary cavities seen on chest X-ray, she would\nbe considered to be contagious.\nWe also don't know the status of her family or other household\ncontacts. If she has children who are skin test tuberculin-positive,\neither she or someone else in her household is likely contagious. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070731.2462\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070728.2430\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry 20070727.2418\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (04) 20070609.1888\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070601.1778\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070530.1752\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (USA, France,\nCanada, Czech Rep.) 20070529.1738\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA (MA) 20050616.1702\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) (03) 20050225.0602\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) 20050207.0411\n........................................ml/mj/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-11-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeist", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dane County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "27515", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, cervids - Canada (MB) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=27515", "date": "2007-08-31 14:00:08", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, HOSPITAL EXPOSURES - USA (WISCONSIN)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2007\nSource: Wisconsin State Journal [edited]\n<http://www.madison.com/wsj/mad/top/index.php?ntid=207698>\n\nA woman who cares for patients at UW [University of Wisconsin]\nHospital and the Veterans Hospital in Madison [Wisconsin] has\ntuberculosis [TB], which has prompted officials to test about 30 of\nher co-workers for the potentially fatal lung disease and try to\ncontact up to 150 patients who may have been exposed. The woman,\nwhose identity and job position hospital officials wouldn't provide,\nis thought to have been contagious for only a few days or not at all,\nsaid Dr. Dennis Maki, an infectious disease specialist at UW Hospital.\nThough TB can be spread through the air, it generally requires close,\nprolonged contact, Maki said. It would take about 6 months for most\npeople who were exposed to develop active disease, he said. Maki said\nit's too early to know if the woman has multidrug-resistant TB [MDR],\nwhich is more of a public health threat. Tests to determine that\ncould take another few weeks. \"The people probably at greatest risk\nare the other health-care workers she has worked closely with the\nlast 2 months,\" Maki said. Those people are getting skin tests this\nweek, he said. Any of them who test positive will be given\nantibiotics to prevent the development of active disease.\nFor patients, dozens of whom will be sought out soon by their doctors\nfor skin tests, \"I don't think there's any reason for them to be\nconcerned,\" Maki said.\nThe woman, whose routine annual skin test for TB was negative in\nNovember [2006], became ill about 3 weeks ago, he said. She didn't\nhave a cough or other respiratory symptoms typical of TB, he said.\nHer main complaint was abdominal pain, for which she underwent\nsurgery last week [20-26 Aug 2007], he said. During the surgery,\nabnormal tissue samples raised suspicion of TB, Maki said. After\nsurgery, he said, the woman was put in an isolation room, with\nnegative air pressure to contain germs and rules requiring workers to\nwear special masks. She was given antibiotics. A few days later, lab\nresults from the tissue samples were positive for TB, Maki said. The\nwoman then underwent the definitive test for TB, of her sputum. It\nwas positive. The woman returned home Tuesday [28 Aug 2007] and is\nrecovering well, Maki said. She will be on antibiotics for several months.\nMaki and other officials said they wouldn't identify her or her\nposition because of privacy laws. Because the woman didn't have the\ntypical symptoms of TB, notably a cough that could easily spread the\ndisease, she probably wasn't contagious, Maki said. \"If she was\ncontagious, it was probably only in the last days before she was\ndiagnosed,\" he said.\nSkin test results on her co-workers should come back by next week\n[3-9 Sep 2007]. If they are negative, it probably means she wasn't\ncontagious to anyone, though follow-up tests will still be performed,\nMaki said. Other co-workers who don't work with her as closely will\nbe screened for TB during this year's [2007] annual skin tests this\nfall, he said. Nearly 5000 people work at both hospitals. Letters\nwill go out next week to the primary care doctors of up to 150\npatients who may have been exposed, Maki said.\nDane County had 9 cases of active TB last year [2006], said Julie\nHalvorsen, a nursing supervisor with the Madison-Dane County Health\nDepartment. The county has had 4 cases this year [2007], including\nthe UW Hospital worker.\n[Byline: David Wahlberg]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Wisconsin can be found at\n<http://www.wistravel.com/map_of_wisconsin/>.\nMadison is the capital of the US state of Wisconsin and the county\nseat of Dane County. It is also home to the University of Wisconsin-Madison.\nTransmission of tuberculosis depends on the infectivity of the\npatient, ventilation of the space in which exposure takes place, and\nduration of exposure. Usually infectious patients have cavitary\ntuberculosis and are coughing or sneezing that generates a large\nquantity of aerosols that contain tubercle bacilli. This degree of\ninfectivity is indicated by a positive smear of sputum stained\nspecifically for mycobacteria (acid fast or AFB (acid-fast bacillus)\nsmear). Prolonged, close contact in poorly ventilated spaces enhances\ntransmission.\nTuberculosis has long been known to be a risk for health care\nworkers. Indeed, we published an extensive outbreak of latent and\nactive tuberculosis in an academic medical center in 1965 (N Engl J\nMed 1965; 275: 718-21); hospital outbreaks of TB occurred in the\n1980's among AIDS patients and healthcare workers, and hospital\noutbreaks of multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB occurred in the 1990's.\nHospital employees with patient contact are tuberculin skin tested at\nleast annually to assess recent acquisition of tuberculosis. If the\nhospital employee in the news release above was tested annually for\nmany years and the tuberculin skin test had been consistently\nnegative, followed by a positive one year later, then the positive\ntuberculin reaction would be the result of an infection acquired\nwithin the prior year. The rapid progression in hospital employee in\nthe above news release from latent infection acquired less than 6-8\nweeks before or at some time after her negative skin test in November\n2006 to extra-pulmonary disease suggests some degree of\nimmunosuppression. We are not told of any co-morbidities in this\nhospital worker.\nHowever, if she were 1st employed the prior year and had not been\ntuberculin skin tested before, an initial negative tuberculin test\nmay represent tuberculin hypersensitivity that has waned over the\nyears after latent tuberculosis that was acquired in childhood. The\ninitial tuberculin skin test, although negative at the time, can\nnevertheless stimulate the waned hypersensitivity to tuberculin. This\nboosted hypersensitivity can develop within several days of testing\nand persist. A subsequent positive tuberculin test then may be either\nthe result of a newly acquired infection or the \"booster effect\". A\nbooster effect can be assessed in someone who will undergo annual\ntesting, such as a hospital employee, by repeat testing one week\nafter an initial negative test; if the 2nd test is positive, the\nreaction is due to the booster effect.\nThe hospital worker in the news release was suspected to have\nintra-abdominal tuberculosis on visual exam of the tissues during\nabdominal surgery. The exact intra-abdominal site is not specified;\nit could be intestine, lymph node, peritoneum, or a visceral organ.\nThe lab tests, which were said to be \"positive\" a few days after\nsurgery, may have been a positive smear for acid-fast bacilli, but\nthe acid-fast organism could be _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ or\nnon-tuberculous mycobacteria. Nucleic acid amplification (NAA) tests\nare available for rapid laboratory diagnosis of _M. tuberculosis_ on\nrespiratory specimens, but I don't believe they have been as yet\nFDA-approved for non-respiratory specimens -- although some specialty\nlabs will do a NAA test on non-respiratory specimens. The news\nrelease says that the patient then had a \"definitive\" positive test\nfor TB on her sputum; a positive NAA test on sputum, although rapid,\nis only presumptive of TB\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm4926a3.htm>); the\ndefinitive test is a culture, but cultures require at least 2 weeks.\nWe are told that the hospital worker was thought to be \"contagious\nfor only a few days or not at all\" because she had no cough, but we\ndon't know her chest X-ray findings, nor do we know for sure if her\nsputum smears were positive for acid-fast bacilli. Certainly if she\nhad been coughing and producing sputum that was acid-fast bacilli\nsmear-positive with pulmonary cavities seen on chest X-ray, she would\nbe considered to be contagious.\nWe also don't know the status of her family or other household\ncontacts. If she has children who are skin test tuberculin-positive,\neither she or someone else in her household is likely contagious. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070731.2462\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070728.2430\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry 20070727.2418\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (04) 20070609.1888\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070601.1778\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070530.1752\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (USA, France,\nCanada, Czech Rep.) 20070529.1738\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA (MA) 20050616.1702\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) (03) 20050225.0602\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) 20050207.0411\n........................................ml/mj/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
