For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-11-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeist", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dane County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209654", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, cervids - Canada (MB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209654", "date": "2007-08-31 14:00:08", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, HOSPITAL EXPOSURES - USA (WISCONSIN)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2007\nSource: Wisconsin State Journal [edited]\n<http://www.madison.com/wsj/mad/top/index.php?ntid=207698>\n\nA woman who cares for patients at UW [University of Wisconsin]\nHospital and the Veterans Hospital in Madison [Wisconsin] has\ntuberculosis [TB], which has prompted officials to test about 30 of\nher co-workers for the potentially fatal lung disease and try to\ncontact up to 150 patients who may have been exposed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-11-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeist", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dane County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "25526", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, hospital exposure - USA (WI) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=25526", "date": "2007-08-31 14:00:08", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, HOSPITAL EXPOSURES - USA (WISCONSIN)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2007\nSource: Wisconsin State Journal [edited]\n<http://www.madison.com/wsj/mad/top/index.php?ntid=207698>\n\nA woman who cares for patients at UW [University of Wisconsin]\nHospital and the Veterans Hospital in Madison [Wisconsin] has\ntuberculosis [TB], which has prompted officials to test about 30 of\nher co-workers for the potentially fatal lung disease and try to\ncontact up to 150 patients who may have been exposed. The woman,\nwhose identity and job position hospital officials wouldn't provide,\nis thought to have been contagious for only a few days or not at all,\nsaid Dr. Dennis Maki, an infectious disease specialist at UW Hospital.\nThough TB can be spread through the air, it generally requires close,\nprolonged contact, Maki said. It would take about 6 months for most\npeople who were exposed to develop active disease, he said. Maki said\nit's too early to know if the woman has multidrug-resistant TB [MDR],\nwhich is more of a public health threat. Tests to determine that\ncould take another few weeks. \"The people probably at greatest risk\nare the other health-care workers she has worked closely with the\nlast 2 months,\" Maki said. Those people are getting skin tests this\nweek, he said. Any of them who test positive will be given\nantibiotics to prevent the development of active disease.\nFor patients, dozens of whom will be sought out soon by their doctors\nfor skin tests, \"I don't think there's any reason for them to be\nconcerned,\" Maki said.\nThe woman, whose routine annual skin test for TB was negative in\nNovember [2006], became ill about 3 weeks ago, he said. She didn't\nhave a cough or other respiratory symptoms typical of TB, he said.\nHer main complaint was abdominal pain, for which she underwent\nsurgery last week [20-26 Aug 2007], he said. During the surgery,\nabnormal tissue samples raised suspicion of TB, Maki said. After\nsurgery, he said, the woman was put in an isolation room, with\nnegative air pressure to contain germs and rules requiring workers to\nwear special masks. She was given antibiotics. A few days later, lab\nresults from the tissue samples were positive for TB, Maki said. The\nwoman then underwent the definitive test for TB, of her sputum. It\nwas positive. The woman returned home Tuesday [28 Aug 2007] and is\nrecovering well, Maki said. She will be on antibiotics for several months.\nMaki and other officials said they wouldn't identify her or her\nposition because of privacy laws. Because the woman didn't have the\ntypical symptoms of TB, notably a cough that could easily spread the\ndisease, she probably wasn't contagious, Maki said. \"If she was\ncontagious, it was probably only in the last days before she was\ndiagnosed,\" he said.\nSkin test results on her co-workers should come back by next week\n[3-9 Sep 2007]. If they are negative, it probably means she wasn't\ncontagious to anyone, though follow-up tests will still be performed,\nMaki said. Other co-workers who don't work with her as closely will\nbe screened for TB during this year's [2007] annual skin tests this\nfall, he said. Nearly 5000 people work at both hospitals. Letters\nwill go out next week to the primary care doctors of up to 150\npatients who may have been exposed, Maki said.\nDane County had 9 cases of active TB last year [2006], said Julie\nHalvorsen, a nursing supervisor with the Madison-Dane County Health\nDepartment. The county has had 4 cases this year [2007], including\nthe UW Hospital worker.\n[Byline: David Wahlberg]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Wisconsin can be found at\n<http://www.wistravel.com/map_of_wisconsin/>.\nMadison is the capital of the US state of Wisconsin and the county\nseat of Dane County. It is also home to the University of Wisconsin-Madison.\nTransmission of tuberculosis depends on the infectivity of the\npatient, ventilation of the space in which exposure takes place, and\nduration of exposure. Usually infectious patients have cavitary\ntuberculosis and are coughing or sneezing that generates a large\nquantity of aerosols that contain tubercle bacilli. This degree of\ninfectivity is indicated by a positive smear of sputum stained\nspecifically for mycobacteria (acid fast or AFB (acid-fast bacillus)\nsmear). Prolonged, close contact in poorly ventilated spaces enhances\ntransmission.\nTuberculosis has long been known to be a risk for health care\nworkers. Indeed, we published an extensive outbreak of latent and\nactive tuberculosis in an academic medical center in 1965 (N Engl J\nMed 1965; 275: 718-21); hospital outbreaks of TB occurred in the\n1980's among AIDS patients and healthcare workers, and hospital\noutbreaks of multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB occurred in the 1990's.\nHospital employees with patient contact are tuberculin skin tested at\nleast annually to assess recent acquisition of tuberculosis. If the\nhospital employee in the news release above was tested annually for\nmany years and the tuberculin skin test had been consistently\nnegative, followed by a positive one year later, then the positive\ntuberculin reaction would be the result of an infection acquired\nwithin the prior year. The rapid progression in hospital employee in\nthe above news release from latent infection acquired less than 6-8\nweeks before or at some time after her negative skin test in November\n2006 to extra-pulmonary disease suggests some degree of\nimmunosuppression. We are not told of any co-morbidities in this\nhospital worker.\nHowever, if she were 1st employed the prior year and had not been\ntuberculin skin tested before, an initial negative tuberculin test\nmay represent tuberculin hypersensitivity that has waned over the\nyears after latent tuberculosis that was acquired in childhood. The\ninitial tuberculin skin test, although negative at the time, can\nnevertheless stimulate the waned hypersensitivity to tuberculin. This\nboosted hypersensitivity can develop within several days of testing\nand persist. A subsequent positive tuberculin test then may be either\nthe result of a newly acquired infection or the \"booster effect\". A\nbooster effect can be assessed in someone who will undergo annual\ntesting, such as a hospital employee, by repeat testing one week\nafter an initial negative test; if the 2nd test is positive, the\nreaction is due to the booster effect.\nThe hospital worker in the news release was suspected to have\nintra-abdominal tuberculosis on visual exam of the tissues during\nabdominal surgery. The exact intra-abdominal site is not specified;\nit could be intestine, lymph node, peritoneum, or a visceral organ.\nThe lab tests, which were said to be \"positive\" a few days after\nsurgery, may have been a positive smear for acid-fast bacilli, but\nthe acid-fast organism could be _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ or\nnon-tuberculous mycobacteria. Nucleic acid amplification (NAA) tests\nare available for rapid laboratory diagnosis of _M. tuberculosis_ on\nrespiratory specimens, but I don't believe they have been as yet\nFDA-approved for non-respiratory specimens -- although some specialty\nlabs will do a NAA test on non-respiratory specimens. The news\nrelease says that the patient then had a \"definitive\" positive test\nfor TB on her sputum; a positive NAA test on sputum, although rapid,\nis only presumptive of TB\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm4926a3.htm>); the\ndefinitive test is a culture, but cultures require at least 2 weeks.\nWe are told that the hospital worker was thought to be \"contagious\nfor only a few days or not at all\" because she had no cough, but we\ndon't know her chest X-ray findings, nor do we know for sure if her\nsputum smears were positive for acid-fast bacilli. Certainly if she\nhad been coughing and producing sputum that was acid-fast bacilli\nsmear-positive with pulmonary cavities seen on chest X-ray, she would\nbe considered to be contagious.\nWe also don't know the status of her family or other household\ncontacts. If she has children who are skin test tuberculin-positive,\neither she or someone else in her household is likely contagious. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070731.2462\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070728.2430\nTuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry 20070727.2418\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (04) 20070609.1888\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070601.1778\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02) 20070530.1752\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (USA, France,\nCanada, Czech Rep.) 20070529.1738\n2005\n----\nTuberculosis, hospital exposures - USA (MA) 20050616.1702\nTuberculosis - Iraq (Missan) 20050613.1652\nTuberculosis, nursery school - Spain (Catalonia) 20050523.1416\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) (03) 20050225.0602\nTuberculosis, supermarket exposure - Netherlands (Zeist) 20050207.0411\n........................................ml/mj/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-11-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeist", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dane County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "25344", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, hospital exposure - USA (WI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=25344", "date": "2007-08-31 14:00:08", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, HOSPITAL EXPOSURES - USA (WISCONSIN)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2007\nSource: Wisconsin State Journal [edited]\n<http://www.madison.com/wsj/mad/top/index.php?ntid=207698>\n\nA woman who cares for patients at UW [University of Wisconsin]\nHospital and the Veterans Hospital in Madison [Wisconsin] has\ntuberculosis [TB], which has prompted officials to test about 30 of\nher co-workers for the potentially fatal lung disease and try to\ncontact up to 150 patients who may have been exposed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-11-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zeist", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Catalonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dane County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "23260", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=23260", "date": "2007-07-02 22:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, ELEPHANTS - NEPAL (04)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 29 Jun 2007\nFrom: Susan Mikota DVM <smikota@elephantcare.org>\n[In ProMED-mail's posting \"Tuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02)\n20070620.1990,\" we included a query received from Richard I. Frankel,\nM.D., M.P.H., F.A.C.P., Emeritus Professor of Medicine, University of\nHawaii: \"It would be useful to know what is meant by the statement\n\"the elephants have tested positive for TB...\" Are these elephants\nill, and was that the reason for testing? Were they tested by skin\ntest or by some other means? Do they have latent infection or\ntuberculosis disease?\"\nThe following firsthand response has been received from Dr Susan Mikota]:\n\nIn January 2006, a study was conducted by Dr. Kamal Giri in\nfulfillment of his MvSc. degree at the Institute of Agriculture and\nAnimal Science. Dr. Giri's work was assisted by Elephant Care\nInternational and Tufts Center for Conservation Medicine. TB has been\nobserved postmortem and anecdotally reported in Nepal, India, and\nother Asian countries. This was the 1st comprehensive evaluation of\nrange country elephants for TB.\nIn addition to collecting trunk wash samples (which were cultured at\nthe National Tuberculosis Lab in Nepal and the National Veterinary\nServices Lab in the U.S.), we collected blood for several serological\nTB assays: (ELISA, Elephant TB STAT-PAK, multi-antigen print\nimmunoassay (MAPIA), and immunoblot, as well as for CBCs, serum\nchemistries, and an immune profile. The determination of which\nelephants were positive or considered to be at risk to develop active\nTB was made by evaluating all of the data with particular attention\ngiven to the ELISA, Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA tests, which we\nhave found to be useful to diagnose TB among elephants in the U.S. A\nfull report was given to the government of Nepal.\nWe do not use skin testing in elephants because it is not accurate\n(see Lewerin, S.S. et al, 2005. Outbreak of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection among captive Asian elephants in a Swedish\nzoo. Vet Rec. 156(6):171-175 and also Mikota, S.K. et al, 2001.\nEpidemiology & Diagnosis of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ in captive\nAsian elephants (_Elephas maximus_). Journal of Zoo and Wildlife\nMedicine 32(1):1-16).\nElephants that are culture positive clearly have active TB. We don't\nreally know whether elephants develop latent disease or whether we\nsimply fail to detect active disease because of the limitations of\nour diagnostic techniques. We cannot X-ray adult elephants.\nCulture has inherent limitations as a primary diagnostic technique.\nFailure to isolate the organism does not rule out infection.\nReporting time is slow (up to 8 weeks) because pathogenic\nmycobacteria may grow slowly. The trunk wash method of sample\ncollection results in variable sample quality. Overgrowth due to\ncontamination from trunk wash samples occurs and may compromise the\nreliability of culture results, especially if overgrowth is not\nreported.\nObtaining 3 samples may not be practical or affordable for screening\nlarge numbers of elephants in Asia, where surveillance is urgently\nneeded.\nSerological tests that have been under investigation in the U.S. have\nshown great promise for improving our ability to diagnose TB in\nelephants.\nThe Elephant TB STAT-PAK is a lateral-flow assay that incorporates a\nunique cocktail of mycobacterial antigens impregnated on a\nnitrocellulose membrane and placed in a plastic cassette similar to a\npregnancy test kit. Serum, plasma, or whole blood may be used and\nresults are available in 20 minutes (see Lyashchenko, K.P. et al,\n2006. Tuberculosis in elephants: antibody responses to defined\nantigens of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, potential for early\ndiagnosis, and monitoring of treatment. Clin Vaccine Immunol\n13(7):722-732, and Lyashchenko, K. et al, 2005. Application of MAPIA\n(Multiple antigen print immunoassay) and rapid lateral flow\ntechnology for tuberculosis testing of elephants. 2005 Proceedings\nAAZV, AAWV, AZA Nutrition Advisory Group, pp. 64-65).\nThe MAPIA is a laboratory procedure for antibody detection that uses\na panel of multiple purified and recombinant antigens of _M.\ntuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ that are separately applied to a\nnitrocellulose membrane using an automated printing device (see\nLyashchenko, K. et al., 2000. Multi-antigen print immunoassay for the\ndevelopment of serological diagnosis of infectious disease. Journal\nof Immunological Methods 242:91-100).\nExcluding the data from Nepal, approximately 99 Asian and 72 African\nelephants in Europe, Australia, South Africa, and the U.S. have been\ntested using the Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA, including 22\nelephants with culture-confirmed TB. Preliminary data has\ndemonstrated 100 percent sensitivity and 97 percent specificity for\nthe Elephant TB STAT-PAK and 100 percent sensitivity and 100 percent\nspecificity for the MAPIA using culture as the reference standard.\nThe TB STAT-PAK has recently completed government licensing\nprocedures in the U.S. and will likely be commercially available\nlater this year [2007].\nIf the Elephant TB STAT-PAK is used as a screening test and the MAPIA\nis sequentially applied as a confirmatory assay, the accuracy of this\ntesting algorithm is 100 percent. Seroconversion on Elephant TB\nSTAT-PAK and MAPIA has been noted in several elephants months to\nyears prior to a positive culture (Lyashchenko 2006). In one elephant\nthat was euthanized and determined to be TB positive, retrospective\nevaluation of serum indicated seroconversion 8 years [earlier].\nA study by Dr. Scott Larsen (U.C. Davis) and Dr. Mo Salman (U. of\nColorado) using a 6-antigen ELISA demonstrated an estimated\nsensitivity of 100 percent and specificity of 100 percent, on a\nsample size of 47 Asian and African elephants (7 culture positive)\n(see Larsen, R.S., et al. 2000. Evaluation of a multiple-antigen\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for detection of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection in captive elephants. Journal of Zoo and\nWildlife Medicine 31(3): 291-302).\nThe ELISA continues to be evaluated but is not available commercially.\nAn important advantage of TB serodiagnosis compared to trunk wash\nculture is that, once established, the antibody response remains\nsustained throughout infection and disease, while culture may be\nintermittently positive or negative in infected elephants. A decline\nin specific antibodies to certain antigens in MAPIA has been observed\nin 7 culture positive elephants tested to date that had undergone\ntreatment, suggesting that this technology may also be a useful for\nmonitoring response to therapy.\nRegarding clinical signs: in most cases, elephants have not shown\nclinical signs until the disease is well advanced. Elephants are\nsusceptible to both _M.tuberculosis_ and _M.bovis_.\nWhile most cases in the U.S. have been due to _M. tb_, we may find\nmore cases of _M. bovis_ in Asia, where elephants often share grazing\nland with domestic livestock.\nA brief history of elephant TB and a further description of\nserological tests can be found in the summary document of a 2005\nelephant TB research meeting (Summary - Elephant Tuberculosis\nResearch Workshop May 2005, available at\n<http://www.elephantcare.org/protodoc_files/2005/Elephant%20Tuberculosis%20Research%20Workshop%20May%2005.pdf>).\n--\nSusan Mikota DVM\nDirector of Veterinary Programs and Research\nElephant Care International\n<http://www.elephantcare.org>\n<smikota@elephantcare.org>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (03) 20070624.2039\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02) 20070620.1990\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal 20070616.1962\n....................................arn/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.K.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "R.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mikota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "K.P.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "20479", "headline": "PRO> Tuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=20479", "date": "2007-07-02 22:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, ELEPHANTS - NEPAL (04)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 29 Jun 2007\nFrom: Susan Mikota DVM <smikota@elephantcare.org>\n[In ProMED-mail's posting \"Tuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02)\n20070620.1990,\" we included a query received from Richard I. Frankel,\nM.D., M.P.H., F.A.C.P., Emeritus Professor of Medicine, University of\nHawaii: \"It would be useful to know what is meant by the statement\n\"the elephants have tested positive for TB...\" Are these elephants\nill, and was that the reason for testing? Were they tested by skin\ntest or by some other means? Do they have latent infection or\ntuberculosis disease?\"\nThe following firsthand response has been received from Dr Susan Mikota]:\n\nIn January 2006, a study was conducted by Dr. Kamal Giri in\nfulfillment of his MvSc. degree at the Institute of Agriculture and\nAnimal Science. Dr. Giri's work was assisted by Elephant Care\nInternational and Tufts Center for Conservation Medicine. TB has been\nobserved postmortem and anecdotally reported in Nepal, India, and\nother Asian countries. This was the 1st comprehensive evaluation of\nrange country elephants for TB.\nIn addition to collecting trunk wash samples (which were cultured at\nthe National Tuberculosis Lab in Nepal and the National Veterinary\nServices Lab in the U.S.), we collected blood for several serological\nTB assays: (ELISA, Elephant TB STAT-PAK, multi-antigen print\nimmunoassay (MAPIA), and immunoblot, as well as for CBCs, serum\nchemistries, and an immune profile. The determination of which\nelephants were positive or considered to be at risk to develop active\nTB was made by evaluating all of the data with particular attention\ngiven to the ELISA, Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA tests, which we\nhave found to be useful to diagnose TB among elephants in the U.S. A\nfull report was given to the government of Nepal.\nWe do not use skin testing in elephants because it is not accurate\n(see Lewerin, S.S. et al, 2005. Outbreak of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection among captive Asian elephants in a Swedish\nzoo. Vet Rec. 156(6):171-175 and also Mikota, S.K. et al, 2001.\nEpidemiology & Diagnosis of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ in captive\nAsian elephants (_Elephas maximus_). Journal of Zoo and Wildlife\nMedicine 32(1):1-16).\nElephants that are culture positive clearly have active TB. We don't\nreally know whether elephants develop latent disease or whether we\nsimply fail to detect active disease because of the limitations of\nour diagnostic techniques. We cannot X-ray adult elephants.\nCulture has inherent limitations as a primary diagnostic technique.\nFailure to isolate the organism does not rule out infection.\nReporting time is slow (up to 8 weeks) because pathogenic\nmycobacteria may grow slowly. The trunk wash method of sample\ncollection results in variable sample quality. Overgrowth due to\ncontamination from trunk wash samples occurs and may compromise the\nreliability of culture results, especially if overgrowth is not\nreported.\nObtaining 3 samples may not be practical or affordable for screening\nlarge numbers of elephants in Asia, where surveillance is urgently\nneeded.\nSerological tests that have been under investigation in the U.S. have\nshown great promise for improving our ability to diagnose TB in\nelephants.\nThe Elephant TB STAT-PAK is a lateral-flow assay that incorporates a\nunique cocktail of mycobacterial antigens impregnated on a\nnitrocellulose membrane and placed in a plastic cassette similar to a\npregnancy test kit. Serum, plasma, or whole blood may be used and\nresults are available in 20 minutes (see Lyashchenko, K.P. et al,\n2006. Tuberculosis in elephants: antibody responses to defined\nantigens of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, potential for early\ndiagnosis, and monitoring of treatment. Clin Vaccine Immunol\n13(7):722-732, and Lyashchenko, K. et al, 2005. Application of MAPIA\n(Multiple antigen print immunoassay) and rapid lateral flow\ntechnology for tuberculosis testing of elephants. 2005 Proceedings\nAAZV, AAWV, AZA Nutrition Advisory Group, pp. 64-65).\nThe MAPIA is a laboratory procedure for antibody detection that uses\na panel of multiple purified and recombinant antigens of _M.\ntuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ that are separately applied to a\nnitrocellulose membrane using an automated printing device (see\nLyashchenko, K. et al., 2000. Multi-antigen print immunoassay for the\ndevelopment of serological diagnosis of infectious disease. Journal\nof Immunological Methods 242:91-100).\nExcluding the data from Nepal, approximately 99 Asian and 72 African\nelephants in Europe, Australia, South Africa, and the U.S. have been\ntested using the Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA, including 22\nelephants with culture-confirmed TB. Preliminary data has\ndemonstrated 100 percent sensitivity and 97 percent specificity for\nthe Elephant TB STAT-PAK and 100 percent sensitivity and 100 percent\nspecificity for the MAPIA using culture as the reference standard.\nThe TB STAT-PAK has recently completed government licensing\nprocedures in the U.S. and will likely be commercially available\nlater this year [2007].\nIf the Elephant TB STAT-PAK is used as a screening test and the MAPIA\nis sequentially applied as a confirmatory assay, the accuracy of this\ntesting algorithm is 100 percent. Seroconversion on Elephant TB\nSTAT-PAK and MAPIA has been noted in several elephants months to\nyears prior to a positive culture (Lyashchenko 2006). In one elephant\nthat was euthanized and determined to be TB positive, retrospective\nevaluation of serum indicated seroconversion 8 years [earlier].\nA study by Dr. Scott Larsen (U.C. Davis) and Dr. Mo Salman (U. of\nColorado) using a 6-antigen ELISA demonstrated an estimated\nsensitivity of 100 percent and specificity of 100 percent, on a\nsample size of 47 Asian and African elephants (7 culture positive)\n(see Larsen, R.S., et al. 2000. Evaluation of a multiple-antigen\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for detection of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection in captive elephants. Journal of Zoo and\nWildlife Medicine 31(3): 291-302).\nThe ELISA continues to be evaluated but is not available commercially.\nAn important advantage of TB serodiagnosis compared to trunk wash\nculture is that, once established, the antibody response remains\nsustained throughout infection and disease, while culture may be\nintermittently positive or negative in infected elephants. A decline\nin specific antibodies to certain antigens in MAPIA has been observed\nin 7 culture positive elephants tested to date that had undergone\ntreatment, suggesting that this technology may also be a useful for\nmonitoring response to therapy.\nRegarding clinical signs: in most cases, elephants have not shown\nclinical signs until the disease is well advanced. Elephants are\nsusceptible to both _M.tuberculosis_ and _M.bovis_.\nWhile most cases in the U.S. have been due to _M. tb_, we may find\nmore cases of _M. bovis_ in Asia, where elephants often share grazing\nland with domestic livestock.\nA brief history of elephant TB and a further description of\nserological tests can be found in the summary document of a 2005\nelephant TB research meeting (Summary - Elephant Tuberculosis\nResearch Workshop May 2005, available at\n<http://www.elephantcare.org/protodoc_files/2005/Elephant%20Tuberculosis%20Research%20Workshop%20May%2005.pdf>).\n--\nSusan Mikota DVM\nDirector of Veterinary Programs and Research\nElephant Care International\n<http://www.elephantcare.org>\n<smikota@elephantcare.org>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (03) 20070624.2039\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02) 20070620.1990\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal 20070616.1962\n....................................arn/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Overgrowth due to\ncontamination from trunk wash samples occurs and may compromise the\nreliability of culture results, especially if overgrowth is not\nreported.\nObtaining 3 samples may not be practical or affordable for screening\nlarge numbers of elephants in Asia, where surveillance is urgently\nneeded.\nSerological tests that have been under investigation in the U.S. have\nshown great promise for improving our ability to diagnose TB in\nelephants.\nThe Elephant TB STAT-PAK is a lateral-flow assay that incorporates a\nunique cocktail of mycobacterial antigens impregnated on a\nnitrocellulose membrane and placed in a plastic cassette similar to a\npregnancy test kit. Clin Vaccine Immunol\n13(7):722-732, and Lyashchenko, K. et al, 2005. Application of MAPIA\n(Multiple antigen print immunoassay) and rapid lateral flow\ntechnology for tuberculosis testing of elephants. 2005 Proceedings\nAAZV, AAWV, AZA Nutrition Advisory Group, pp. 64-65).\nThe MAPIA is a laboratory procedure for antibody detection that uses\na panel of multiple purified and recombinant antigens of _M.\ntuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ that are separately applied to a\nnitrocellulose membrane using an automated printing device (see\nLyashchenko, K. et al., 2000. Evaluation of a multiple-antigen\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for detection of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection in captive elephants. Journal of Zoo and\nWildlife Medicine 31(3): 291-302).\nThe ELISA continues to be evaluated but is not available commercially.\nAn important advantage of TB serodiagnosis compared to trunk wash\nculture is that, once established, the antibody response remains\nsustained throughout infection and disease, while culture may be\nintermittently positive or negative in infected elephants. A decline\nin specific antibodies to certain antigens in MAPIA has been observed\nin 7 culture positive elephants tested to date that had undergone\ntreatment, suggesting that this technology may also be a useful for\nmonitoring response to therapy.\nRegarding clinical signs: in most cases, elephants have not shown\nclinical signs until the disease is well advanced. Elephants are\nsusceptible to both _M.tuberculosis_ and _M.bovis_.\nWhile most cases in the U.S. have been due to _M. tb_, we may find\nmore cases of _M. bovis_ in Asia, where elephants often share grazing\nland with domestic livestock.\nA brief history of elephant TB and a further description of\nserological tests can be found in the summary document of a 2005\nelephant TB research meeting (Summary - Elephant Tuberculosis\nResearch Workshop May 2005, available at\n<http://www.elephantcare.org/protodoc_files/2005/Elephant%20Tuberculosis%20Research%20Workshop%20May%2005.pdf>).\n--\nSusan Mikota DVM\nDirector of Veterinary Programs and Research\nElephant Care International\n<http://www.elephantcare.org>\n<smikota@elephantcare.org>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (03) 20070624.2039\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02) 20070620.1990\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal 20070616.1962\n....................................arn/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Frankel,\nM.D., M.P.H., F.A.C.P., Emeritus Professor of Medicine, University of\nHawaii: \"It would be useful to know what is meant by the statement\n\"the elephants have tested positive for TB...\" Are these elephants\nill, and was that the reason for testing? Vet Rec. 156(6):171-175 and also Mikota, S.K. et al, 2001.\nEpidemiology & Diagnosis of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ in captive\nAsian elephants (_Elephas maximus_). Journal of Zoo and Wildlife\nMedicine 32(1):1-16).\nElephants that are culture positive clearly have active TB. We don't\nreally know whether elephants develop latent disease or whether we\nsimply fail to detect active disease because of the limitations of\nour diagnostic techniques. We cannot X-ray adult elephants.\nCulture has inherent limitations as a primary diagnostic technique.\nFailure to isolate the organism does not rule out infection.\nReporting time is slow (up to 8 weeks) because pathogenic\nmycobacteria may grow slowly. The trunk wash method of sample\ncollection results in variable sample quality. Overgrowth due to\ncontamination from trunk wash samples occurs and may compromise the\nreliability of culture results, especially if overgrowth is not\nreported.\nObtaining 3 samples may not be practical or affordable for screening\nlarge numbers of elephants in Asia, where surveillance is urgently\nneeded.\nSerological tests that have been under investigation in the U.S. have\nshown great promise for improving our ability to diagnose TB in\nelephants.\nThe Elephant TB STAT-PAK is a lateral-flow assay that incorporates a\nunique cocktail of mycobacterial antigens impregnated on a\nnitrocellulose membrane and placed in a plastic cassette similar to a\npregnancy test kit. Serum, plasma, or whole blood may be used and\nresults are available in 20 minutes (see Lyashchenko, K.P. et al,\n2006. Tuberculosis in elephants: antibody responses to defined\nantigens of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, potential for early\ndiagnosis, and monitoring of treatment. Clin Vaccine Immunol\n13(7):722-732, and Lyashchenko, K. et al, 2005. Application of MAPIA\n(Multiple antigen print immunoassay) and rapid lateral flow\ntechnology for tuberculosis testing of elephants. 2005 Proceedings\nAAZV, AAWV, AZA Nutrition Advisory Group, pp. 64-65).\nThe MAPIA is a laboratory procedure for antibody detection that uses\na panel of multiple purified and recombinant antigens of _M.\ntuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ that are separately applied to a\nnitrocellulose membrane using an automated printing device (see\nLyashchenko, K. et al., 2000. Multi-antigen print immunoassay for the\ndevelopment of serological diagnosis of infectious disease. Journal\nof Immunological Methods 242:91-100).\nExcluding the data from Nepal, approximately 99 Asian and 72 African\nelephants in Europe, Australia, South Africa, and the U.S. have been\ntested using the Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA, including 22\nelephants with culture-confirmed TB. Preliminary data has\ndemonstrated 100 percent sensitivity and 97 percent specificity for\nthe Elephant TB STAT-PAK and 100 percent sensitivity and 100 percent\nspecificity for the MAPIA using culture as the reference standard.\nThe TB STAT-PAK has recently completed government licensing\nprocedures in the U.S. and will likely be commercially available\nlater this year [2007].\nIf the Elephant TB STAT-PAK is used as a screening test and the MAPIA\nis sequentially applied as a confirmatory assay, the accuracy of this\ntesting algorithm is 100 percent. Seroconversion on Elephant TB\nSTAT-PAK and MAPIA has been noted in several elephants months to\nyears prior to a positive culture (Lyashchenko 2006). In one elephant\nthat was euthanized and determined to be TB positive, retrospective\nevaluation of serum indicated seroconversion 8 years [earlier].\nA study by Dr. Scott Larsen (U.C. Davis) and Dr. Mo Salman (U. of\nColorado) using a 6-antigen ELISA demonstrated an estimated\nsensitivity of 100 percent and specificity of 100 percent, on a\nsample size of 47 Asian and African elephants (7 culture positive)\n(see Larsen, R.S., et al. 2000. Evaluation of a multiple-antigen\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for detection of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection in captive elephants. Journal of Zoo and\nWildlife Medicine 31(3): 291-302).\nThe ELISA continues to be evaluated but is not available commercially.\nAn important advantage of TB serodiagnosis compared to trunk wash\nculture is that, once established, the antibody response remains\nsustained throughout infection and disease, while culture may be\nintermittently positive or negative in infected elephants. A decline\nin specific antibodies to certain antigens in MAPIA has been observed\nin 7 culture positive elephants tested to date that had undergone\ntreatment, suggesting that this technology may also be a useful for\nmonitoring response to therapy.\nRegarding clinical signs: in most cases, elephants have not shown\nclinical signs until the disease is well advanced. Elephants are\nsusceptible to both _M.tuberculosis_ and _M.bovis_.\nWhile most cases in the U.S. have been due to _M. tb_, we may find\nmore cases of _M. bovis_ in Asia, where elephants often share grazing\nland with domestic livestock.\nA brief history of elephant TB and a further description of\nserological tests can be found in the summary document of a 2005\nelephant TB research meeting (Summary - Elephant Tuberculosis\nResearch Workshop May 2005, available at\n<http://www.elephantcare.org/protodoc_files/2005/Elephant%20Tuberculosis%20Research%20Workshop%20May%2005.pdf>).\n--\nSusan Mikota DVM\nDirector of Veterinary Programs and Research\nElephant Care International\n<http://www.elephantcare.org>\n<smikota@elephantcare.org>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (03) 20070624.2039\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02) 20070620.1990\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal 20070616.1962\n....................................arn/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.K.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "R.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mikota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "K.P.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "19596", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, MDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=19596", "date": "2007-07-02 22:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, ELEPHANTS - NEPAL (04)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 29 Jun 2007\nFrom: Susan Mikota DVM <smikota@elephantcare.org>\n[In ProMED-mail's posting \"Tuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02)\n20070620.1990,\" we included a query received from Richard I. Frankel,\nM.D., M.P.H., F.A.C.P., Emeritus Professor of Medicine, University of\nHawaii: \"It would be useful to know what is meant by the statement\n\"the elephants have tested positive for TB...\" Are these elephants\nill, and was that the reason for testing? Were they tested by skin\ntest or by some other means? Do they have latent infection or\ntuberculosis disease?\"\nThe following firsthand response has been received from Dr Susan Mikota]:\n\nIn January 2006, a study was conducted by Dr. Kamal Giri in\nfulfillment of his MvSc. degree at the Institute of Agriculture and\nAnimal Science. Dr. Giri's work was assisted by Elephant Care\nInternational and Tufts Center for Conservation Medicine. TB has been\nobserved postmortem and anecdotally reported in Nepal, India, and\nother Asian countries. This was the 1st comprehensive evaluation of\nrange country elephants for TB.\nIn addition to collecting trunk wash samples (which were cultured at\nthe National Tuberculosis Lab in Nepal and the National Veterinary\nServices Lab in the U.S.), we collected blood for several serological\nTB assays: (ELISA, Elephant TB STAT-PAK, multi-antigen print\nimmunoassay (MAPIA), and immunoblot, as well as for CBCs, serum\nchemistries, and an immune profile. The determination of which\nelephants were positive or considered to be at risk to develop active\nTB was made by evaluating all of the data with particular attention\ngiven to the ELISA, Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA tests, which we\nhave found to be useful to diagnose TB among elephants in the U.S. A\nfull report was given to the government of Nepal.\nWe do not use skin testing in elephants because it is not accurate\n(see Lewerin, S.S. et al, 2005. Outbreak of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection among captive Asian elephants in a Swedish\nzoo. Vet Rec. 156(6):171-175 and also Mikota, S.K. et al, 2001.\nEpidemiology & Diagnosis of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ in captive\nAsian elephants (_Elephas maximus_). Journal of Zoo and Wildlife\nMedicine 32(1):1-16).\nElephants that are culture positive clearly have active TB. We don't\nreally know whether elephants develop latent disease or whether we\nsimply fail to detect active disease because of the limitations of\nour diagnostic techniques. We cannot X-ray adult elephants.\nCulture has inherent limitations as a primary diagnostic technique.\nFailure to isolate the organism does not rule out infection.\nReporting time is slow (up to 8 weeks) because pathogenic\nmycobacteria may grow slowly. The trunk wash method of sample\ncollection results in variable sample quality. Overgrowth due to\ncontamination from trunk wash samples occurs and may compromise the\nreliability of culture results, especially if overgrowth is not\nreported.\nObtaining 3 samples may not be practical or affordable for screening\nlarge numbers of elephants in Asia, where surveillance is urgently\nneeded.\nSerological tests that have been under investigation in the U.S. have\nshown great promise for improving our ability to diagnose TB in\nelephants.\nThe Elephant TB STAT-PAK is a lateral-flow assay that incorporates a\nunique cocktail of mycobacterial antigens impregnated on a\nnitrocellulose membrane and placed in a plastic cassette similar to a\npregnancy test kit. Serum, plasma, or whole blood may be used and\nresults are available in 20 minutes (see Lyashchenko, K.P. et al,\n2006. Tuberculosis in elephants: antibody responses to defined\nantigens of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, potential for early\ndiagnosis, and monitoring of treatment. Clin Vaccine Immunol\n13(7):722-732, and Lyashchenko, K. et al, 2005. Application of MAPIA\n(Multiple antigen print immunoassay) and rapid lateral flow\ntechnology for tuberculosis testing of elephants. 2005 Proceedings\nAAZV, AAWV, AZA Nutrition Advisory Group, pp. 64-65).\nThe MAPIA is a laboratory procedure for antibody detection that uses\na panel of multiple purified and recombinant antigens of _M.\ntuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ that are separately applied to a\nnitrocellulose membrane using an automated printing device (see\nLyashchenko, K. et al., 2000. Multi-antigen print immunoassay for the\ndevelopment of serological diagnosis of infectious disease. Journal\nof Immunological Methods 242:91-100).\nExcluding the data from Nepal, approximately 99 Asian and 72 African\nelephants in Europe, Australia, South Africa, and the U.S. have been\ntested using the Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA, including 22\nelephants with culture-confirmed TB. Preliminary data has\ndemonstrated 100 percent sensitivity and 97 percent specificity for\nthe Elephant TB STAT-PAK and 100 percent sensitivity and 100 percent\nspecificity for the MAPIA using culture as the reference standard.\nThe TB STAT-PAK has recently completed government licensing\nprocedures in the U.S. and will likely be commercially available\nlater this year [2007].\nIf the Elephant TB STAT-PAK is used as a screening test and the MAPIA\nis sequentially applied as a confirmatory assay, the accuracy of this\ntesting algorithm is 100 percent. Seroconversion on Elephant TB\nSTAT-PAK and MAPIA has been noted in several elephants months to\nyears prior to a positive culture (Lyashchenko 2006). In one elephant\nthat was euthanized and determined to be TB positive, retrospective\nevaluation of serum indicated seroconversion 8 years [earlier].\nA study by Dr. Scott Larsen (U.C. Davis) and Dr. Mo Salman (U. of\nColorado) using a 6-antigen ELISA demonstrated an estimated\nsensitivity of 100 percent and specificity of 100 percent, on a\nsample size of 47 Asian and African elephants (7 culture positive)\n(see Larsen, R.S., et al. 2000. Evaluation of a multiple-antigen\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for detection of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection in captive elephants. Journal of Zoo and\nWildlife Medicine 31(3): 291-302).\nThe ELISA continues to be evaluated but is not available commercially.\nAn important advantage of TB serodiagnosis compared to trunk wash\nculture is that, once established, the antibody response remains\nsustained throughout infection and disease, while culture may be\nintermittently positive or negative in infected elephants. A decline\nin specific antibodies to certain antigens in MAPIA has been observed\nin 7 culture positive elephants tested to date that had undergone\ntreatment, suggesting that this technology may also be a useful for\nmonitoring response to therapy.\nRegarding clinical signs: in most cases, elephants have not shown\nclinical signs until the disease is well advanced. Elephants are\nsusceptible to both _M.tuberculosis_ and _M.bovis_.\nWhile most cases in the U.S. have been due to _M. tb_, we may find\nmore cases of _M. bovis_ in Asia, where elephants often share grazing\nland with domestic livestock.\nA brief history of elephant TB and a further description of\nserological tests can be found in the summary document of a 2005\nelephant TB research meeting (Summary - Elephant Tuberculosis\nResearch Workshop May 2005, available at\n<http://www.elephantcare.org/protodoc_files/2005/Elephant%20Tuberculosis%20Research%20Workshop%20May%2005.pdf>).\n--\nSusan Mikota DVM\nDirector of Veterinary Programs and Research\nElephant Care International\n<http://www.elephantcare.org>\n<smikota@elephantcare.org>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (03) 20070624.2039\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02) 20070620.1990\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal 20070616.1962\n....................................arn/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Frankel,\nM.D., M.P.H., F.A.C.P., Emeritus Professor of Medicine, University of\nHawaii: \"It would be useful to know what is meant by the statement\n\"the elephants have tested positive for TB...\" Are these elephants\nill, and was that the reason for testing? Outbreak of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection among captive Asian elephants in a Swedish\nzoo. Vet Rec. 156(6):171-175 and also Mikota, S.K. et al, 2001.\nEpidemiology & Diagnosis of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ in captive\nAsian elephants (_Elephas maximus_). Journal of Zoo and Wildlife\nMedicine 32(1):1-16).\nElephants that are culture positive clearly have active TB. We don't\nreally know whether elephants develop latent disease or whether we\nsimply fail to detect active disease because of the limitations of\nour diagnostic techniques. We cannot X-ray adult elephants.\nCulture has inherent limitations as a primary diagnostic technique.\nFailure to isolate the organism does not rule out infection.\nReporting time is slow (up to 8 weeks) because pathogenic\nmycobacteria may grow slowly. The trunk wash method of sample\ncollection results in variable sample quality. Overgrowth due to\ncontamination from trunk wash samples occurs and may compromise the\nreliability of culture results, especially if overgrowth is not\nreported.\nObtaining 3 samples may not be practical or affordable for screening\nlarge numbers of elephants in Asia, where surveillance is urgently\nneeded.\nSerological tests that have been under investigation in the U.S. have\nshown great promise for improving our ability to diagnose TB in\nelephants.\nThe Elephant TB STAT-PAK is a lateral-flow assay that incorporates a\nunique cocktail of mycobacterial antigens impregnated on a\nnitrocellulose membrane and placed in a plastic cassette similar to a\npregnancy test kit. Serum, plasma, or whole blood may be used and\nresults are available in 20 minutes (see Lyashchenko, K.P. et al,\n2006. Tuberculosis in elephants: antibody responses to defined\nantigens of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, potential for early\ndiagnosis, and monitoring of treatment. Clin Vaccine Immunol\n13(7):722-732, and Lyashchenko, K. et al, 2005. Application of MAPIA\n(Multiple antigen print immunoassay) and rapid lateral flow\ntechnology for tuberculosis testing of elephants. 2005 Proceedings\nAAZV, AAWV, AZA Nutrition Advisory Group, pp. 64-65).\nThe MAPIA is a laboratory procedure for antibody detection that uses\na panel of multiple purified and recombinant antigens of _M.\ntuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ that are separately applied to a\nnitrocellulose membrane using an automated printing device (see\nLyashchenko, K. et al., 2000. Multi-antigen print immunoassay for the\ndevelopment of serological diagnosis of infectious disease. Journal\nof Immunological Methods 242:91-100).\nExcluding the data from Nepal, approximately 99 Asian and 72 African\nelephants in Europe, Australia, South Africa, and the U.S. have been\ntested using the Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA, including 22\nelephants with culture-confirmed TB. Preliminary data has\ndemonstrated 100 percent sensitivity and 97 percent specificity for\nthe Elephant TB STAT-PAK and 100 percent sensitivity and 100 percent\nspecificity for the MAPIA using culture as the reference standard.\nThe TB STAT-PAK has recently completed government licensing\nprocedures in the U.S. and will likely be commercially available\nlater this year [2007].\nIf the Elephant TB STAT-PAK is used as a screening test and the MAPIA\nis sequentially applied as a confirmatory assay, the accuracy of this\ntesting algorithm is 100 percent. Seroconversion on Elephant TB\nSTAT-PAK and MAPIA has been noted in several elephants months to\nyears prior to a positive culture (Lyashchenko 2006). In one elephant\nthat was euthanized and determined to be TB positive, retrospective\nevaluation of serum indicated seroconversion 8 years [earlier].\nA study by Dr. Scott Larsen (U.C. Davis) and Dr. Mo Salman (U. of\nColorado) using a 6-antigen ELISA demonstrated an estimated\nsensitivity of 100 percent and specificity of 100 percent, on a\nsample size of 47 Asian and African elephants (7 culture positive)\n(see Larsen, R.S., et al. 2000. Evaluation of a multiple-antigen\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for detection of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection in captive elephants. Journal of Zoo and\nWildlife Medicine 31(3): 291-302).\nThe ELISA continues to be evaluated but is not available commercially.\nAn important advantage of TB serodiagnosis compared to trunk wash\nculture is that, once established, the antibody response remains\nsustained throughout infection and disease, while culture may be\nintermittently positive or negative in infected elephants. A decline\nin specific antibodies to certain antigens in MAPIA has been observed\nin 7 culture positive elephants tested to date that had undergone\ntreatment, suggesting that this technology may also be a useful for\nmonitoring response to therapy.\nRegarding clinical signs: in most cases, elephants have not shown\nclinical signs until the disease is well advanced. Elephants are\nsusceptible to both _M.tuberculosis_ and _M.bovis_.\nWhile most cases in the U.S. have been due to _M. tb_, we may find\nmore cases of _M. bovis_ in Asia, where elephants often share grazing\nland with domestic livestock.\nA brief history of elephant TB and a further description of\nserological tests can be found in the summary document of a 2005\nelephant TB research meeting (Summary - Elephant Tuberculosis\nResearch Workshop May 2005, available at\n<http://www.elephantcare.org/protodoc_files/2005/Elephant%20Tuberculosis%20Research%20Workshop%20May%2005.pdf>).\n--\nSusan Mikota DVM\nDirector of Veterinary Programs and Research\nElephant Care International\n<http://www.elephantcare.org>\n<smikota@elephantcare.org>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (03) 20070624.2039\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02) 20070620.1990\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal 20070616.1962\n....................................arn/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.K.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "R.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mikota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "K.P.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "15718", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=15718", "date": "2007-07-02 22:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, ELEPHANTS - NEPAL (04)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 29 Jun 2007\nFrom: Susan Mikota DVM <smikota@elephantcare.org>\n[In ProMED-mail's posting \"Tuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02)\n20070620.1990,\" we included a query received from Richard I. Frankel,\nM.D., M.P.H., F.A.C.P., Emeritus Professor of Medicine, University of\nHawaii: \"It would be useful to know what is meant by the statement\n\"the elephants have tested positive for TB...\" Are these elephants\nill, and was that the reason for testing? Were they tested by skin\ntest or by some other means? Do they have latent infection or\ntuberculosis disease?\"\nThe following firsthand response has been received from Dr Susan Mikota]:\n\nIn January 2006, a study was conducted by Dr. Kamal Giri in\nfulfillment of his MvSc. degree at the Institute of Agriculture and\nAnimal Science. Dr. Giri's work was assisted by Elephant Care\nInternational and Tufts Center for Conservation Medicine. TB has been\nobserved postmortem and anecdotally reported in Nepal, India, and\nother Asian countries. This was the 1st comprehensive evaluation of\nrange country elephants for TB.\nIn addition to collecting trunk wash samples (which were cultured at\nthe National Tuberculosis Lab in Nepal and the National Veterinary\nServices Lab in the U.S.), we collected blood for several serological\nTB assays: (ELISA, Elephant TB STAT-PAK, multi-antigen print\nimmunoassay (MAPIA), and immunoblot, as well as for CBCs, serum\nchemistries, and an immune profile. The determination of which\nelephants were positive or considered to be at risk to develop active\nTB was made by evaluating all of the data with particular attention\ngiven to the ELISA, Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA tests, which we\nhave found to be useful to diagnose TB among elephants in the U.S. A\nfull report was given to the government of Nepal.\nWe do not use skin testing in elephants because it is not accurate\n(see Lewerin, S.S. et al, 2005. Outbreak of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection among captive Asian elephants in a Swedish\nzoo. Vet Rec. 156(6):171-175 and also Mikota, S.K. et al, 2001.\nEpidemiology & Diagnosis of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ in captive\nAsian elephants (_Elephas maximus_). Journal of Zoo and Wildlife\nMedicine 32(1):1-16).\nElephants that are culture positive clearly have active TB. We don't\nreally know whether elephants develop latent disease or whether we\nsimply fail to detect active disease because of the limitations of\nour diagnostic techniques. We cannot X-ray adult elephants.\nCulture has inherent limitations as a primary diagnostic technique.\nFailure to isolate the organism does not rule out infection.\nReporting time is slow (up to 8 weeks) because pathogenic\nmycobacteria may grow slowly. The trunk wash method of sample\ncollection results in variable sample quality. Overgrowth due to\ncontamination from trunk wash samples occurs and may compromise the\nreliability of culture results, especially if overgrowth is not\nreported.\nObtaining 3 samples may not be practical or affordable for screening\nlarge numbers of elephants in Asia, where surveillance is urgently\nneeded.\nSerological tests that have been under investigation in the U.S. have\nshown great promise for improving our ability to diagnose TB in\nelephants.\nThe Elephant TB STAT-PAK is a lateral-flow assay that incorporates a\nunique cocktail of mycobacterial antigens impregnated on a\nnitrocellulose membrane and placed in a plastic cassette similar to a\npregnancy test kit. Serum, plasma, or whole blood may be used and\nresults are available in 20 minutes (see Lyashchenko, K.P. et al,\n2006. Tuberculosis in elephants: antibody responses to defined\nantigens of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, potential for early\ndiagnosis, and monitoring of treatment. Clin Vaccine Immunol\n13(7):722-732, and Lyashchenko, K. et al, 2005. Application of MAPIA\n(Multiple antigen print immunoassay) and rapid lateral flow\ntechnology for tuberculosis testing of elephants. 2005 Proceedings\nAAZV, AAWV, AZA Nutrition Advisory Group, pp. 64-65).\nThe MAPIA is a laboratory procedure for antibody detection that uses\na panel of multiple purified and recombinant antigens of _M.\ntuberculosis_ and _M. bovis_ that are separately applied to a\nnitrocellulose membrane using an automated printing device (see\nLyashchenko, K. et al., 2000. Multi-antigen print immunoassay for the\ndevelopment of serological diagnosis of infectious disease. Journal\nof Immunological Methods 242:91-100).\nExcluding the data from Nepal, approximately 99 Asian and 72 African\nelephants in Europe, Australia, South Africa, and the U.S. have been\ntested using the Elephant TB STAT-PAK and MAPIA, including 22\nelephants with culture-confirmed TB. Preliminary data has\ndemonstrated 100 percent sensitivity and 97 percent specificity for\nthe Elephant TB STAT-PAK and 100 percent sensitivity and 100 percent\nspecificity for the MAPIA using culture as the reference standard.\nThe TB STAT-PAK has recently completed government licensing\nprocedures in the U.S. and will likely be commercially available\nlater this year [2007].\nIf the Elephant TB STAT-PAK is used as a screening test and the MAPIA\nis sequentially applied as a confirmatory assay, the accuracy of this\ntesting algorithm is 100 percent. Seroconversion on Elephant TB\nSTAT-PAK and MAPIA has been noted in several elephants months to\nyears prior to a positive culture (Lyashchenko 2006). In one elephant\nthat was euthanized and determined to be TB positive, retrospective\nevaluation of serum indicated seroconversion 8 years [earlier].\nA study by Dr. Scott Larsen (U.C. Davis) and Dr. Mo Salman (U. of\nColorado) using a 6-antigen ELISA demonstrated an estimated\nsensitivity of 100 percent and specificity of 100 percent, on a\nsample size of 47 Asian and African elephants (7 culture positive)\n(see Larsen, R.S., et al. 2000. Evaluation of a multiple-antigen\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for detection of _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ infection in captive elephants. Journal of Zoo and\nWildlife Medicine 31(3): 291-302).\nThe ELISA continues to be evaluated but is not available commercially.\nAn important advantage of TB serodiagnosis compared to trunk wash\nculture is that, once established, the antibody response remains\nsustained throughout infection and disease, while culture may be\nintermittently positive or negative in infected elephants. A decline\nin specific antibodies to certain antigens in MAPIA has been observed\nin 7 culture positive elephants tested to date that had undergone\ntreatment, suggesting that this technology may also be a useful for\nmonitoring response to therapy.\nRegarding clinical signs: in most cases, elephants have not shown\nclinical signs until the disease is well advanced. Elephants are\nsusceptible to both _M.tuberculosis_ and _M.bovis_.\nWhile most cases in the U.S. have been due to _M. tb_, we may find\nmore cases of _M. bovis_ in Asia, where elephants often share grazing\nland with domestic livestock.\nA brief history of elephant TB and a further description of\nserological tests can be found in the summary document of a 2005\nelephant TB research meeting (Summary - Elephant Tuberculosis\nResearch Workshop May 2005, available at\n<http://www.elephantcare.org/protodoc_files/2005/Elephant%20Tuberculosis%20Research%20Workshop%20May%2005.pdf>).\n--\nSusan Mikota DVM\nDirector of Veterinary Programs and Research\nElephant Care International\n<http://www.elephantcare.org>\n<smikota@elephantcare.org>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (03) 20070624.2039\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal (02) 20070620.1990\nTuberculosis, elephants - Nepal 20070616.1962\n....................................arn/msp/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-05-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nepal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.K.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "S.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "R.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mikota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "K.P.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "15066", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (10): Western Cape", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=15066", "date": "2007-06-04 19:00:01", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR - SOUTH AFRICA (09): WESTERN CAPE\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 30 May 2007\nSource: Independent Online [edited]\n<http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=vn20070530113820436C553281>\n\nAn 18 year old youth has died of [extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis\n(XDR TB)], the 5th death from the deadly strain of TB in the Western Cape,\nas Brooklyn Chest Hospital runs out of space in its special isolation ward.\nThe 22 bed isolation unit, specially set up to address the rising incidence\nof XDR TB in the province, is now full, as provincial health authorities\nmove fast to identify further space to address the demand.\nThe issue of isolation of patients with XDR TB and the slightly less\ndangerous multi-drug resistant TB (MDR TB) is in the spotlight following\nnews on Mon 28 May 2007, that Delft doctors were forced to send home a\nhighly infectious female patient because of a shortage of isolation unit beds.\nThe 53 year old woman was diagnosed with MDR TB, but considering she is\nstill infectious after 18 months on alternative treatment, doctors suggest\nshe could well be another XDR TB case.\nAccording to health department spokesperson, Faiza Steyn, the woman was to\nbe admitted to Brooklyn Chest Hospital today [30 May 2007].\nSteyn said there were currently 37 confirmed XDR TB patients in the Western\nCape. The 18 year old boy, the most recent person to die of XDR TB, died at\nhis home.\nMeanwhile, to cope with the shortage of beds, both confirmed and suspected\ncases were being admitted into a side section of an isolation ward at\nBrooklyn Chest Hospital, used for MDR TB patients. Other than the stopgap\nside ward, Steyn said provincial health authorities were making plans to\nconvert an \"ordinary\" TB ward at Brooklyn Chest Hospital, which has 45\nbeds, into an XDR TB ward.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As a reminder, XDR TB is now defined as an isolate resistant to INH\n(isoniazid) and RIF (rifampicin) (MDR TB) that is also resistant to a\nfluoroquinolone and to one or more of the following 3 injectable\nanti-tuberculosis drugs: capreomycin (CM), kanamycin (KM), and amikacin (AK).\nThe number of cases of XDR TB continues to grow, especially in South\nAfrica. It is not stated in the posting how many of the total and of those\nwho died were infected with HIV as well.\nClearly, additional hospital space is needed to minimize community\ntransmission of this drug resistant pathogen.\nIn this latest reported death, the death at home occurred prior to the\nmicrobiologic confirmation of XDR TB. This has been common in South Africa,\nespecially in the HIV co-infected cohort, a measure of the rapid\nprogression of TB in and profoundly cellularly immunosuppressed population.\nThe Western Cape Province of South Africa can be found on a map of the\ncountry at <http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/southafr.pdf>.\nMost of the country's provinces have had cases of XDR TB. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (03) 20070601.1778\nTuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (USA, France, Canada,\nCzech Rep.) 20070529.1738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (08): Western Cape 20070425.1349\nTuberculosis, XDR, 2003-2006 - Europe (Germany, Italy) 20070403.1132\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (07): Eastern Cape 20070326.1044\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1993-2006 - USA 20070322.1005\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (06) 20070319.0959\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1991-2003 - Spain 20070302.0738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (05) 20070228.0717\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (04) 20070220.0638\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (03) 20070209.0504\nTuberculosis, XDR - worldwide 20070205.0456\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\n...............ll/mj/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It is not stated in the posting how many of the total and of those\nwho died were infected with HIV as well.\nClearly, additional hospital space is needed to minimize community\ntransmission of this drug resistant pathogen.\nIn this latest reported death, the death at home occurred prior to the\nmicrobiologic confirmation of XDR TB.
