For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-11-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-10-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "1665-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1176-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "1882-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sturm AW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10683", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR, airplane exposure - multicountry (USA, France, Canada, Czech Rep.)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10683", "date": "2007-03-22 16:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR, 1993-2006 - USA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2007;569(11): 250-3 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a3.htm?s_cid=mm5611a3_e>\n\nThe worldwide emergence of extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis\n(XDR TB) and a provisional definition for this form of TB were 1st\nreported in November 2005 (1,2). A more detailed description of these\nfindings and preliminary data from the USA National TB Surveillance\nSystem (NTSS) were published in 2006 (3). The USA data indicated that\n74 TB cases reported during 1993-2004 met the case definition for XDR\nTB (3). Subsequent reports suggested different definitions for XDR TB\n(4,5). In October 2006, the WHO (World Health Organization) convened\nan Emergency Global Task Force on XDR TB, which revised the case\ndefinition to specify resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampin\namong 1st line anti-TB drugs, resistance to any fluoroquinolone, and\nresistance to at least one 2nd line injectable drug (amikacin,\ncapreomycin, or kanamycin) (6).\nThis report updates the 2006 report on XDR TB in the USA, using the\nrevised case definition and provisional data for 2006. NTSS data were\nanalyzed for reported XDR TB cases during 1993-2006; a total of 49\ncases (3 percent of evaluable multidrug-resistant [MDR] TB cases) met\nthe revised case definition for XDR TB. Of these, 17 (35 percent)\nwere reported during 2000-2006. Compared with 1993-1999, cases from\n2000-2006 were more likely to be in persons who were foreign-born and\nless likely to be in persons with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.\nXDR TB presents a global threat and a challenge to TB-control\nactivities in the USA. To prevent the spread of XDR TB, renewed\nvigilance is needed through drug-susceptibility testing, case\nreporting, specialized care, infection control, and expanded capacity\nfor outbreak detection and response.\nTB cases reported to NTSS from 50 states and the District of Columbia\n(DC) were analyzed for the period 1993-2006. All culture-confirmed\ncases with initial drug-susceptibility test (DST) results reported\nfor at least isoniazid and rifampin were included in the analysis.\nBecause susceptibility testing is time consuming, especially for 2nd\nline drugs, initial DST results are reported separately to avoid\ndelaying reporting of routine TB case data. At the end of treatment,\nthe outcome is reported in a 2nd follow-up report. The HIV status of\nTB cases reported to NTSS was available through 2006, except in\nCalifornia, where only data on positive HIV test results were\navailable through 2004.\nTB cases reported during 1993-1999, a period of rapidly decreasing\nincidence of both TB and MDR TB, were compared with cases reported\nduring 2000-2006, a period of slower decline in TB and MDR TB rates.\nDuring 1993-2006, a total of 202 436 culture-confirmed TB cases were\nreported to NTSS; 190 312 of these cases had initial DST results for\nat least isoniazid and rifampin, including 2927 (2 percent) with\ninitial resistance to both drugs (that is, MDR TB). Of the 2927 MDR\nTB cases, 1665 (57 percent) had DST results reported for at least a\nfluoroquinolone and an injectable 2nd line drug. Of these, 49 cases\n(3 percent) met the revised definition of XDR TB, including 32 cases\nreported during 1993-1999 and 17 cases during 2000-2006 [Table - for\ntable, see original URL - Mod.LL].\nThe 49 XDR TB cases were reported from 9 states and one city, with\nthe largest numbers in New York City (19 cases) and California (11\ncases) [Figure - for figure, see original URL - Mod.LL]. HIV status\nwas known for 29 (59 percent) of the 49 persons with XDR TB; 16 (55\npercent) were HIV positive. During 1993-1999, a total of 19 persons\nwith XDR TB had known HIV status, of whom 14 (74 percent) were HIV\npositive; during 2000-2006, 10 persons had known HIV status, of whom\n2 (20 percent) were HIV positive. The number and percentage of\npersons with XDR TB in the group aged 25-44 years decreased from 21\n(66 percent) during 1993-1999 to 6 (35 percent) during 2000-2006.\nWhen the 2 periods were compared, the number of XDR TB cases among\nforeign-born persons did not change substantially, but the percentage\nof XDR-TB cases among foreign-born persons increased from 39 percent\n(12 cases) in 1993-1999 to 76 percent (13 cases) in 2000-2006 as the\nnumber of XDR TB cases among USA-born cases decreased. Among\nracial/ethnic populations, 9 (28 percent) of 32 XDR TB cases during\n1993-1999 were reported among non-Hispanic blacks, decreasing to 2\n(12 percent) of 17 cases during 2000-2006. Conversely, the number and\npercentage of cases among Asians increased from 3 (9 percent) during\n1993-1999 to 7 (41 percent) during 2000-2006. Sputum microscopy for\nacid-fast bacilli was positive in 27 (69 percent) of the 39 cases\nwith known results. Mortality in XDR TB cases was strongly associated\nwith HIV infection. Among 41 persons with XDR TB and known outcomes,\n12 (29 percent) persons died; 10 of those had HIV infection, and the\nother 2 did not have HIV test results reported.\n[Byline: NS Shah NS, R Pratt, S Althomsons, et al]\nMMWR Editorial note\n--------------\nAfter approximately 30 years of declining trends, a TB epidemic\noccurred in the USA during 1985-1992. From 22 201 cases in 1985 (9.3\nper 100 000 population), reported TB increased to 26 673 cases in\n1992 (10.4 per 100 000 population) (7). Although the incidence of MDR\nTB in the USA was largely unknown before 1993, the number of cases\nbegan increasing in New York City in the early 1980s (8), and\nnumerous outbreaks of MDR TB were described in the late 1980s and\nearly 1990s (9). With implementation of elements of the 1992 National\nAction Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis, reported MDR\nTB cases declined rapidly (10). TB control activities included\nimproving laboratory services for rapid, accurate culture and DST,\nimproving infection control, and strengthening NTSS to include DST\nand HIV test results beginning in 1993. The rapid decrease in MDR TB\ncases during 1993-1999 likely correlated with the 34 percent decline\nin TB cases overall in the USA to 17 501 (6.3 per 100 000) in 1999 (7).\nEffective treatment of MDR TB requires administration, for 18-24\nmonths, of 4 to 6 drugs to which the infecting organism is\nsusceptible, including multiple 2nd line drugs. Beginning in the\n1980s, the use of these drugs increased substantially as physicians\nand TB control programs treated growing numbers of MDR TB cases.\nIncreased use of these drugs resulted in MDR TB strains with\nextensive resistance to both 1st and 2nd line drugs. Thus, XDR TB in\nthe 1990s likely represented the legacy of the 1985-1992 TB epidemic\nin the USA and treatments to combat the spike in MDR TB cases.\nCharacteristics of XDR TB cases changed during 2000-2006 in parallel\nwith the changing epidemiology of TB in general and MDR TB in\nparticular. These changes included an overall decrease in the number\nof cases, a decrease in the proportion of cases in HIV-infected\npersons, an increase in the proportion of cases among foreign-born\npersons, and an increase in the proportion of Asians among persons\nwith XDR TB, compared with 1993-1999 (7).\nThe findings in this report are subject to at least 5 limitations:\n- the number of XDR TB cases is a minimum estimate because of\nincomplete DST data. Although 57 percent of MDR-TB cases had DST\nresults reported for at least a fluoroquinolone and at least one of\nthe 3 2nd-line injectable drugs, only 22 percent had DST results\nreported for all drug combinations in the definition of XDR TB,\ntaking into consideration cross-resistance among drugs and data\navailable in NTSS. Initial TB isolates with any resistance to\nrifampin or resistance to any two 1st line drugs should be tested for\nsusceptibility to a full panel of anti-TB drugs, and the results\nshould be reported accordingly.\n- Aggregate reporting of drug resistance traditionally has been based\nonly on initial DST results, not on drug resistance that develops\nduring treatment. Because of the complexity of 2nd line DST, results\ncan be delayed by several months and might not be included in the\nreport of initial DST results.\n- Approximately 20 percent of reported TB cases do not have positive\ncultures that would enable DSTs to be performed.\n- NTSS data for 2006 are provisional, and final case counts,\nincluding XDR TB cases, are subject to revision.\n- Finally, HIV test results usually are reported to NTSS after both\nTB and HIV surveillance systems have verified their annual case\ncounts. Thus, HIV test results lag behind TB case counts, and data on\nHIV status are complete through 2005 but provisional for 2006, except\nfor California, which provided data only through 2004. In addition,\nHIV test results from California are less complete.\nThe NTSS surveillance data summarized in this report represent an\nupdated measurement of XDR TB in the USA. However, surveillance data\ndo not enable a detailed understanding of how most XDR TB cases\narise. For example, the relative importance of person-to-person XDR\nTB transmission compared with the emergence of XDR TB in individual\npatients as a consequence of inadequate treatment cannot be determined.\nUse of 2nd line drugs to treat drug-resistant TB is increasing\nthroughout the world, presaging substantial increases in XDR TB\ninternationally. Accurate measures of the incidence, prevalence, and\ndeterminants of XDR TB are needed to target public health responses.\nAttention to fundamental aspects of TB control (such as,\nsurveillance, prompt culture and DST, directly observed treatment,\ncontact investigation, rapid containment of outbreaks, and infection\ncontrol) is needed to control XDR TB in the USA in the same manner\nthat MDR TB was addressed during the previous decade. The Federal TB\nTask Force is developing a domestic and international response for\nthe American government agencies regarding XDR TB. A senior-level\ninteragency meeting will be convened to formulate a comprehensive\nresponse and to assign responsibilities for a unified strategic approach.\nAdditional information regarding XDR TB is available at\n<http://www.who.int/tb/xdr/en/index.html>.\nReferences:\n1. Shah NS, Wright A, Drobniewski F, et al: Extreme drug resistance\nin tuberculosis (XDR-TB\"): global survey of supranational reference\nlaboratories for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with resistance to\nsecond-line drugs. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9(Suppl 1):S77.\n2. Holtz TH, Riekstina V, Zarovska E, et al: XDR-TB: extreme\ndrug-resistance and treatment outcome under DOTS-Plus, Latvia,\n2000-2002. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9 (Suppl 1):S258.\n3. CDC: Emergence of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with extensive\nresistance to second-line drugs-worldwide, 2000-2004. MMWR 2006;55: 301-305.\n4. Gandhi NR, Moll A, Sturm AW, et al: Extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis as a cause of death in patients co-infected with\ntuberculosis and HIV in a rural area of South Africa. Lancet 2006;368: 1575-80.\n5. Leimane V, Holtz TH: MDR-TB and XDR-TB management in Latvia.\nGlobal XDR-TB Task Force, Geneva, Switzerland; 2006. Available at\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2007/who_htm_tb_2007.375_eng.pdf>.\n6. CDC: Revised definition of extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis. MMWR 2006;55: 1176.\n7. CDC: Reported tuberculosis in the United States, 2005:\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health\nand Human Services, CDC; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/surv/surv2005/pdf/tbsurvfullreport.pdf>.\n8. Frieden TR, Sterling T, Pablos-Mendez A, et al: The emergence of\ndrug-resistant tuberculosis in New York City. N Engl J Med 1993;328: 521-56.\n9. Moore M, McCray E, Onorato I: The interaction of human\nimmunodeficiency virus and multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ [Chapter 4]. In: Bastian I, Portaels F, Eds.\nMultidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Dordrecht, the Netherlands: Kluwer\nAcademic Publishers; 2000:45-57.\n10. CDC: National Action Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant\nTuberculosis. MMWR 1992;41(No. RR-11):5-48.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Saturday, 24 Mar 2007 is World TB Day. The print copy of MMWR\ncontaining the posting above, provides this text related to the day\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a1.htm?s_cid=mm5611a1_e>\n\"World TB Day is observed on 24 March each year and commemorates the\ndate in 1882 when Dr. Robert Koch announced the discovery of\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis\n(TB). Worldwide, TB remains one of the leading causes of death from\ninfectious disease. An estimated 2 billion persons (that is, one\nthird of the world's population) are infected with _M. tuberculosis_.\nEach year, approximately 9 million persons become ill from TB; of\nthese, nearly 2 million die from the disease.\nWorld TB Day provides an opportunity for TB programs, nongovernmental\norganizations, and other partners to describe problems and solutions\nrelated to the TB pandemic and to support worldwide TB-control\nactivities. The theme for this year's observance is \"TB Elimination:\nNow is the Time!\"\nAfter approximately 30 years of decline, the number of TB cases\nreported in the USA increased 20 percent during 1985-1992. This led\nto a renewed emphasis on TB control and prevention during the 1990s.\nHowever, although the 2006 TB rate is the lowest recorded in the USA\nsince national reporting began in 1953, the average annual decline\nhas slowed since 2000. In addition, multidrug-resistant TB remains a\nthreat, extensively drug-resistant TB has become an emerging threat,\nand persons of racial/ethnic minority populations and foreign-born\npersons continue to account for a disproportionate number of TB cases.\nCDC and its partners are committed to eliminating TB in the USA. In\nmany states, education and awareness programs convened by local TB\ncoalitions will take place in commemoration of World TB Day.\nAdditional information about World TB Day and CDC TB-elimination\nactivities is available at <http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/worldtbday>.\"\nAs seen in South Africa, XDR TB in HIV infected patients can cause\ndeath before the initial cultures are positive, let alone drug\nsensitivity testing. The global community has a long way to go to\neradicate TB, especially in the HIV era. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (06) 20070319.0959\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1991-2003 - Spain 20070302.0738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (05) 20070228.0717\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (04) 20070220.0638\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (03) 20070209.0504\nTuberculosis, XDR - worldwide 20070205.0456\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) (02) 20070125.0340\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) 20070124.0318\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - Hungary 20061110.3233\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - South Africa (KN) (04): nationwide 20061019.3003\nTuberculosis, multi-drug resistant - South Africa (KN) 20060904.2514\n..................ll/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-11-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-10-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "1665-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1176-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "1882-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sturm AW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10066", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, bovine - USA (OK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10066", "date": "2007-03-22 16:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR, 1993-2006 - USA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2007;569(11): 250-3 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a3.htm?s_cid=mm5611a3_e>\n\nThe worldwide emergence of extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis\n(XDR TB) and a provisional definition for this form of TB were 1st\nreported in November 2005 (1,2). A more detailed description of these\nfindings and preliminary data from the USA National TB Surveillance\nSystem (NTSS) were published in 2006 (3). The USA data indicated that\n74 TB cases reported during 1993-2004 met the case definition for XDR\nTB (3). Subsequent reports suggested different definitions for XDR TB\n(4,5). In October 2006, the WHO (World Health Organization) convened\nan Emergency Global Task Force on XDR TB, which revised the case\ndefinition to specify resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampin\namong 1st line anti-TB drugs, resistance to any fluoroquinolone, and\nresistance to at least one 2nd line injectable drug (amikacin,\ncapreomycin, or kanamycin) (6).\nThis report updates the 2006 report on XDR TB in the USA, using the\nrevised case definition and provisional data for 2006. NTSS data were\nanalyzed for reported XDR TB cases during 1993-2006; a total of 49\ncases (3 percent of evaluable multidrug-resistant [MDR] TB cases) met\nthe revised case definition for XDR TB. Of these, 17 (35 percent)\nwere reported during 2000-2006. Compared with 1993-1999, cases from\n2000-2006 were more likely to be in persons who were foreign-born and\nless likely to be in persons with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.\nXDR TB presents a global threat and a challenge to TB-control\nactivities in the USA. To prevent the spread of XDR TB, renewed\nvigilance is needed through drug-susceptibility testing, case\nreporting, specialized care, infection control, and expanded capacity\nfor outbreak detection and response.\nTB cases reported to NTSS from 50 states and the District of Columbia\n(DC) were analyzed for the period 1993-2006. All culture-confirmed\ncases with initial drug-susceptibility test (DST) results reported\nfor at least isoniazid and rifampin were included in the analysis.\nBecause susceptibility testing is time consuming, especially for 2nd\nline drugs, initial DST results are reported separately to avoid\ndelaying reporting of routine TB case data. At the end of treatment,\nthe outcome is reported in a 2nd follow-up report. The HIV status of\nTB cases reported to NTSS was available through 2006, except in\nCalifornia, where only data on positive HIV test results were\navailable through 2004.\nTB cases reported during 1993-1999, a period of rapidly decreasing\nincidence of both TB and MDR TB, were compared with cases reported\nduring 2000-2006, a period of slower decline in TB and MDR TB rates.\nDuring 1993-2006, a total of 202 436 culture-confirmed TB cases were\nreported to NTSS; 190 312 of these cases had initial DST results for\nat least isoniazid and rifampin, including 2927 (2 percent) with\ninitial resistance to both drugs (that is, MDR TB). Of the 2927 MDR\nTB cases, 1665 (57 percent) had DST results reported for at least a\nfluoroquinolone and an injectable 2nd line drug. Of these, 49 cases\n(3 percent) met the revised definition of XDR TB, including 32 cases\nreported during 1993-1999 and 17 cases during 2000-2006 [Table - for\ntable, see original URL - Mod.LL].\nThe 49 XDR TB cases were reported from 9 states and one city, with\nthe largest numbers in New York City (19 cases) and California (11\ncases) [Figure - for figure, see original URL - Mod.LL]. HIV status\nwas known for 29 (59 percent) of the 49 persons with XDR TB; 16 (55\npercent) were HIV positive. During 1993-1999, a total of 19 persons\nwith XDR TB had known HIV status, of whom 14 (74 percent) were HIV\npositive; during 2000-2006, 10 persons had known HIV status, of whom\n2 (20 percent) were HIV positive. The number and percentage of\npersons with XDR TB in the group aged 25-44 years decreased from 21\n(66 percent) during 1993-1999 to 6 (35 percent) during 2000-2006.\nWhen the 2 periods were compared, the number of XDR TB cases among\nforeign-born persons did not change substantially, but the percentage\nof XDR-TB cases among foreign-born persons increased from 39 percent\n(12 cases) in 1993-1999 to 76 percent (13 cases) in 2000-2006 as the\nnumber of XDR TB cases among USA-born cases decreased. Among\nracial/ethnic populations, 9 (28 percent) of 32 XDR TB cases during\n1993-1999 were reported among non-Hispanic blacks, decreasing to 2\n(12 percent) of 17 cases during 2000-2006. Conversely, the number and\npercentage of cases among Asians increased from 3 (9 percent) during\n1993-1999 to 7 (41 percent) during 2000-2006. Sputum microscopy for\nacid-fast bacilli was positive in 27 (69 percent) of the 39 cases\nwith known results. Mortality in XDR TB cases was strongly associated\nwith HIV infection. Among 41 persons with XDR TB and known outcomes,\n12 (29 percent) persons died; 10 of those had HIV infection, and the\nother 2 did not have HIV test results reported.\n[Byline: NS Shah NS, R Pratt, S Althomsons, et al]\nMMWR Editorial note\n--------------\nAfter approximately 30 years of declining trends, a TB epidemic\noccurred in the USA during 1985-1992. From 22 201 cases in 1985 (9.3\nper 100 000 population), reported TB increased to 26 673 cases in\n1992 (10.4 per 100 000 population) (7). Although the incidence of MDR\nTB in the USA was largely unknown before 1993, the number of cases\nbegan increasing in New York City in the early 1980s (8), and\nnumerous outbreaks of MDR TB were described in the late 1980s and\nearly 1990s (9). With implementation of elements of the 1992 National\nAction Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis, reported MDR\nTB cases declined rapidly (10). TB control activities included\nimproving laboratory services for rapid, accurate culture and DST,\nimproving infection control, and strengthening NTSS to include DST\nand HIV test results beginning in 1993. The rapid decrease in MDR TB\ncases during 1993-1999 likely correlated with the 34 percent decline\nin TB cases overall in the USA to 17 501 (6.3 per 100 000) in 1999 (7).\nEffective treatment of MDR TB requires administration, for 18-24\nmonths, of 4 to 6 drugs to which the infecting organism is\nsusceptible, including multiple 2nd line drugs. Beginning in the\n1980s, the use of these drugs increased substantially as physicians\nand TB control programs treated growing numbers of MDR TB cases.\nIncreased use of these drugs resulted in MDR TB strains with\nextensive resistance to both 1st and 2nd line drugs. Thus, XDR TB in\nthe 1990s likely represented the legacy of the 1985-1992 TB epidemic\nin the USA and treatments to combat the spike in MDR TB cases.\nCharacteristics of XDR TB cases changed during 2000-2006 in parallel\nwith the changing epidemiology of TB in general and MDR TB in\nparticular. These changes included an overall decrease in the number\nof cases, a decrease in the proportion of cases in HIV-infected\npersons, an increase in the proportion of cases among foreign-born\npersons, and an increase in the proportion of Asians among persons\nwith XDR TB, compared with 1993-1999 (7).\nThe findings in this report are subject to at least 5 limitations:\n- the number of XDR TB cases is a minimum estimate because of\nincomplete DST data. Although 57 percent of MDR-TB cases had DST\nresults reported for at least a fluoroquinolone and at least one of\nthe 3 2nd-line injectable drugs, only 22 percent had DST results\nreported for all drug combinations in the definition of XDR TB,\ntaking into consideration cross-resistance among drugs and data\navailable in NTSS. Initial TB isolates with any resistance to\nrifampin or resistance to any two 1st line drugs should be tested for\nsusceptibility to a full panel of anti-TB drugs, and the results\nshould be reported accordingly.\n- Aggregate reporting of drug resistance traditionally has been based\nonly on initial DST results, not on drug resistance that develops\nduring treatment. Because of the complexity of 2nd line DST, results\ncan be delayed by several months and might not be included in the\nreport of initial DST results.\n- Approximately 20 percent of reported TB cases do not have positive\ncultures that would enable DSTs to be performed.\n- NTSS data for 2006 are provisional, and final case counts,\nincluding XDR TB cases, are subject to revision.\n- Finally, HIV test results usually are reported to NTSS after both\nTB and HIV surveillance systems have verified their annual case\ncounts. Thus, HIV test results lag behind TB case counts, and data on\nHIV status are complete through 2005 but provisional for 2006, except\nfor California, which provided data only through 2004. In addition,\nHIV test results from California are less complete.\nThe NTSS surveillance data summarized in this report represent an\nupdated measurement of XDR TB in the USA. However, surveillance data\ndo not enable a detailed understanding of how most XDR TB cases\narise. For example, the relative importance of person-to-person XDR\nTB transmission compared with the emergence of XDR TB in individual\npatients as a consequence of inadequate treatment cannot be determined.\nUse of 2nd line drugs to treat drug-resistant TB is increasing\nthroughout the world, presaging substantial increases in XDR TB\ninternationally. Accurate measures of the incidence, prevalence, and\ndeterminants of XDR TB are needed to target public health responses.\nAttention to fundamental aspects of TB control (such as,\nsurveillance, prompt culture and DST, directly observed treatment,\ncontact investigation, rapid containment of outbreaks, and infection\ncontrol) is needed to control XDR TB in the USA in the same manner\nthat MDR TB was addressed during the previous decade. The Federal TB\nTask Force is developing a domestic and international response for\nthe American government agencies regarding XDR TB. A senior-level\ninteragency meeting will be convened to formulate a comprehensive\nresponse and to assign responsibilities for a unified strategic approach.\nAdditional information regarding XDR TB is available at\n<http://www.who.int/tb/xdr/en/index.html>.\nReferences:\n1. Shah NS, Wright A, Drobniewski F, et al: Extreme drug resistance\nin tuberculosis (XDR-TB\"): global survey of supranational reference\nlaboratories for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with resistance to\nsecond-line drugs. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9(Suppl 1):S77.\n2. Holtz TH, Riekstina V, Zarovska E, et al: XDR-TB: extreme\ndrug-resistance and treatment outcome under DOTS-Plus, Latvia,\n2000-2002. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9 (Suppl 1):S258.\n3. CDC: Emergence of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with extensive\nresistance to second-line drugs-worldwide, 2000-2004. MMWR 2006;55: 301-305.\n4. Gandhi NR, Moll A, Sturm AW, et al: Extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis as a cause of death in patients co-infected with\ntuberculosis and HIV in a rural area of South Africa. Lancet 2006;368: 1575-80.\n5. Leimane V, Holtz TH: MDR-TB and XDR-TB management in Latvia.\nGlobal XDR-TB Task Force, Geneva, Switzerland; 2006. Available at\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2007/who_htm_tb_2007.375_eng.pdf>.\n6. CDC: Revised definition of extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis. MMWR 2006;55: 1176.\n7. CDC: Reported tuberculosis in the United States, 2005:\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health\nand Human Services, CDC; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/surv/surv2005/pdf/tbsurvfullreport.pdf>.\n8. Frieden TR, Sterling T, Pablos-Mendez A, et al: The emergence of\ndrug-resistant tuberculosis in New York City. N Engl J Med 1993;328: 521-56.\n9. Moore M, McCray E, Onorato I: The interaction of human\nimmunodeficiency virus and multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ [Chapter 4]. In: Bastian I, Portaels F, Eds.\nMultidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Dordrecht, the Netherlands: Kluwer\nAcademic Publishers; 2000:45-57.\n10. CDC: National Action Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant\nTuberculosis. MMWR 1992;41(No. RR-11):5-48.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Saturday, 24 Mar 2007 is World TB Day. The print copy of MMWR\ncontaining the posting above, provides this text related to the day\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a1.htm?s_cid=mm5611a1_e>\n\"World TB Day is observed on 24 March each year and commemorates the\ndate in 1882 when Dr. Robert Koch announced the discovery of\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis\n(TB). Worldwide, TB remains one of the leading causes of death from\ninfectious disease. An estimated 2 billion persons (that is, one\nthird of the world's population) are infected with _M. tuberculosis_.\nEach year, approximately 9 million persons become ill from TB; of\nthese, nearly 2 million die from the disease.\nWorld TB Day provides an opportunity for TB programs, nongovernmental\norganizations, and other partners to describe problems and solutions\nrelated to the TB pandemic and to support worldwide TB-control\nactivities. The theme for this year's observance is \"TB Elimination:\nNow is the Time!\"\nAfter approximately 30 years of decline, the number of TB cases\nreported in the USA increased 20 percent during 1985-1992. This led\nto a renewed emphasis on TB control and prevention during the 1990s.\nHowever, although the 2006 TB rate is the lowest recorded in the USA\nsince national reporting began in 1953, the average annual decline\nhas slowed since 2000. In addition, multidrug-resistant TB remains a\nthreat, extensively drug-resistant TB has become an emerging threat,\nand persons of racial/ethnic minority populations and foreign-born\npersons continue to account for a disproportionate number of TB cases.\nCDC and its partners are committed to eliminating TB in the USA. In\nmany states, education and awareness programs convened by local TB\ncoalitions will take place in commemoration of World TB Day.\nAdditional information about World TB Day and CDC TB-elimination\nactivities is available at <http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/worldtbday>.\"\nAs seen in South Africa, XDR TB in HIV infected patients can cause\ndeath before the initial cultures are positive, let alone drug\nsensitivity testing. The global community has a long way to go to\neradicate TB, especially in the HIV era. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (06) 20070319.0959\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1991-2003 - Spain 20070302.0738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (05) 20070228.0717\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (04) 20070220.0638\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (03) 20070209.0504\nTuberculosis, XDR - worldwide 20070205.0456\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) (02) 20070125.0340\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) 20070124.0318\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - Hungary 20061110.3233\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - South Africa (KN) (04): nationwide 20061019.3003\nTuberculosis, multi-drug resistant - South Africa (KN) 20060904.2514\n..................ll/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-11-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-10-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "1665-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1176-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "1882-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sturm AW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9940", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (08): Western Cape", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9940", "date": "2007-03-22 16:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR, 1993-2006 - USA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2007;569(11): 250-3 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a3.htm?s_cid=mm5611a3_e>\n\nThe worldwide emergence of extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis\n(XDR TB) and a provisional definition for this form of TB were 1st\nreported in November 2005 (1,2). A more detailed description of these\nfindings and preliminary data from the USA National TB Surveillance\nSystem (NTSS) were published in 2006 (3). The USA data indicated that\n74 TB cases reported during 1993-2004 met the case definition for XDR\nTB (3). Subsequent reports suggested different definitions for XDR TB\n(4,5). In October 2006, the WHO (World Health Organization) convened\nan Emergency Global Task Force on XDR TB, which revised the case\ndefinition to specify resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampin\namong 1st line anti-TB drugs, resistance to any fluoroquinolone, and\nresistance to at least one 2nd line injectable drug (amikacin,\ncapreomycin, or kanamycin) (6).\nThis report updates the 2006 report on XDR TB in the USA, using the\nrevised case definition and provisional data for 2006. NTSS data were\nanalyzed for reported XDR TB cases during 1993-2006; a total of 49\ncases (3 percent of evaluable multidrug-resistant [MDR] TB cases) met\nthe revised case definition for XDR TB. Of these, 17 (35 percent)\nwere reported during 2000-2006. Compared with 1993-1999, cases from\n2000-2006 were more likely to be in persons who were foreign-born and\nless likely to be in persons with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.\nXDR TB presents a global threat and a challenge to TB-control\nactivities in the USA. To prevent the spread of XDR TB, renewed\nvigilance is needed through drug-susceptibility testing, case\nreporting, specialized care, infection control, and expanded capacity\nfor outbreak detection and response.\nTB cases reported to NTSS from 50 states and the District of Columbia\n(DC) were analyzed for the period 1993-2006. All culture-confirmed\ncases with initial drug-susceptibility test (DST) results reported\nfor at least isoniazid and rifampin were included in the analysis.\nBecause susceptibility testing is time consuming, especially for 2nd\nline drugs, initial DST results are reported separately to avoid\ndelaying reporting of routine TB case data. At the end of treatment,\nthe outcome is reported in a 2nd follow-up report. The HIV status of\nTB cases reported to NTSS was available through 2006, except in\nCalifornia, where only data on positive HIV test results were\navailable through 2004.\nTB cases reported during 1993-1999, a period of rapidly decreasing\nincidence of both TB and MDR TB, were compared with cases reported\nduring 2000-2006, a period of slower decline in TB and MDR TB rates.\nDuring 1993-2006, a total of 202 436 culture-confirmed TB cases were\nreported to NTSS; 190 312 of these cases had initial DST results for\nat least isoniazid and rifampin, including 2927 (2 percent) with\ninitial resistance to both drugs (that is, MDR TB). Of the 2927 MDR\nTB cases, 1665 (57 percent) had DST results reported for at least a\nfluoroquinolone and an injectable 2nd line drug. Of these, 49 cases\n(3 percent) met the revised definition of XDR TB, including 32 cases\nreported during 1993-1999 and 17 cases during 2000-2006 [Table - for\ntable, see original URL - Mod.LL].\nThe 49 XDR TB cases were reported from 9 states and one city, with\nthe largest numbers in New York City (19 cases) and California (11\ncases) [Figure - for figure, see original URL - Mod.LL]. HIV status\nwas known for 29 (59 percent) of the 49 persons with XDR TB; 16 (55\npercent) were HIV positive. During 1993-1999, a total of 19 persons\nwith XDR TB had known HIV status, of whom 14 (74 percent) were HIV\npositive; during 2000-2006, 10 persons had known HIV status, of whom\n2 (20 percent) were HIV positive. The number and percentage of\npersons with XDR TB in the group aged 25-44 years decreased from 21\n(66 percent) during 1993-1999 to 6 (35 percent) during 2000-2006.\nWhen the 2 periods were compared, the number of XDR TB cases among\nforeign-born persons did not change substantially, but the percentage\nof XDR-TB cases among foreign-born persons increased from 39 percent\n(12 cases) in 1993-1999 to 76 percent (13 cases) in 2000-2006 as the\nnumber of XDR TB cases among USA-born cases decreased. Among\nracial/ethnic populations, 9 (28 percent) of 32 XDR TB cases during\n1993-1999 were reported among non-Hispanic blacks, decreasing to 2\n(12 percent) of 17 cases during 2000-2006. Conversely, the number and\npercentage of cases among Asians increased from 3 (9 percent) during\n1993-1999 to 7 (41 percent) during 2000-2006. Sputum microscopy for\nacid-fast bacilli was positive in 27 (69 percent) of the 39 cases\nwith known results. Mortality in XDR TB cases was strongly associated\nwith HIV infection. Among 41 persons with XDR TB and known outcomes,\n12 (29 percent) persons died; 10 of those had HIV infection, and the\nother 2 did not have HIV test results reported.\n[Byline: NS Shah NS, R Pratt, S Althomsons, et al]\nMMWR Editorial note\n--------------\nAfter approximately 30 years of declining trends, a TB epidemic\noccurred in the USA during 1985-1992. From 22 201 cases in 1985 (9.3\nper 100 000 population), reported TB increased to 26 673 cases in\n1992 (10.4 per 100 000 population) (7). Although the incidence of MDR\nTB in the USA was largely unknown before 1993, the number of cases\nbegan increasing in New York City in the early 1980s (8), and\nnumerous outbreaks of MDR TB were described in the late 1980s and\nearly 1990s (9). With implementation of elements of the 1992 National\nAction Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis, reported MDR\nTB cases declined rapidly (10). TB control activities included\nimproving laboratory services for rapid, accurate culture and DST,\nimproving infection control, and strengthening NTSS to include DST\nand HIV test results beginning in 1993. The rapid decrease in MDR TB\ncases during 1993-1999 likely correlated with the 34 percent decline\nin TB cases overall in the USA to 17 501 (6.3 per 100 000) in 1999 (7).\nEffective treatment of MDR TB requires administration, for 18-24\nmonths, of 4 to 6 drugs to which the infecting organism is\nsusceptible, including multiple 2nd line drugs. Beginning in the\n1980s, the use of these drugs increased substantially as physicians\nand TB control programs treated growing numbers of MDR TB cases.\nIncreased use of these drugs resulted in MDR TB strains with\nextensive resistance to both 1st and 2nd line drugs. Thus, XDR TB in\nthe 1990s likely represented the legacy of the 1985-1992 TB epidemic\nin the USA and treatments to combat the spike in MDR TB cases.\nCharacteristics of XDR TB cases changed during 2000-2006 in parallel\nwith the changing epidemiology of TB in general and MDR TB in\nparticular. These changes included an overall decrease in the number\nof cases, a decrease in the proportion of cases in HIV-infected\npersons, an increase in the proportion of cases among foreign-born\npersons, and an increase in the proportion of Asians among persons\nwith XDR TB, compared with 1993-1999 (7).\nThe findings in this report are subject to at least 5 limitations:\n- the number of XDR TB cases is a minimum estimate because of\nincomplete DST data. Although 57 percent of MDR-TB cases had DST\nresults reported for at least a fluoroquinolone and at least one of\nthe 3 2nd-line injectable drugs, only 22 percent had DST results\nreported for all drug combinations in the definition of XDR TB,\ntaking into consideration cross-resistance among drugs and data\navailable in NTSS. Initial TB isolates with any resistance to\nrifampin or resistance to any two 1st line drugs should be tested for\nsusceptibility to a full panel of anti-TB drugs, and the results\nshould be reported accordingly.\n- Aggregate reporting of drug resistance traditionally has been based\nonly on initial DST results, not on drug resistance that develops\nduring treatment. Because of the complexity of 2nd line DST, results\ncan be delayed by several months and might not be included in the\nreport of initial DST results.\n- Approximately 20 percent of reported TB cases do not have positive\ncultures that would enable DSTs to be performed.\n- NTSS data for 2006 are provisional, and final case counts,\nincluding XDR TB cases, are subject to revision.\n- Finally, HIV test results usually are reported to NTSS after both\nTB and HIV surveillance systems have verified their annual case\ncounts. Thus, HIV test results lag behind TB case counts, and data on\nHIV status are complete through 2005 but provisional for 2006, except\nfor California, which provided data only through 2004. In addition,\nHIV test results from California are less complete.\nThe NTSS surveillance data summarized in this report represent an\nupdated measurement of XDR TB in the USA. However, surveillance data\ndo not enable a detailed understanding of how most XDR TB cases\narise. For example, the relative importance of person-to-person XDR\nTB transmission compared with the emergence of XDR TB in individual\npatients as a consequence of inadequate treatment cannot be determined.\nUse of 2nd line drugs to treat drug-resistant TB is increasing\nthroughout the world, presaging substantial increases in XDR TB\ninternationally. Accurate measures of the incidence, prevalence, and\ndeterminants of XDR TB are needed to target public health responses.\nAttention to fundamental aspects of TB control (such as,\nsurveillance, prompt culture and DST, directly observed treatment,\ncontact investigation, rapid containment of outbreaks, and infection\ncontrol) is needed to control XDR TB in the USA in the same manner\nthat MDR TB was addressed during the previous decade. The Federal TB\nTask Force is developing a domestic and international response for\nthe American government agencies regarding XDR TB. A senior-level\ninteragency meeting will be convened to formulate a comprehensive\nresponse and to assign responsibilities for a unified strategic approach.\nAdditional information regarding XDR TB is available at\n<http://www.who.int/tb/xdr/en/index.html>.\nReferences:\n1. Shah NS, Wright A, Drobniewski F, et al: Extreme drug resistance\nin tuberculosis (XDR-TB\"): global survey of supranational reference\nlaboratories for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with resistance to\nsecond-line drugs. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9(Suppl 1):S77.\n2. Holtz TH, Riekstina V, Zarovska E, et al: XDR-TB: extreme\ndrug-resistance and treatment outcome under DOTS-Plus, Latvia,\n2000-2002. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9 (Suppl 1):S258.\n3. CDC: Emergence of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with extensive\nresistance to second-line drugs-worldwide, 2000-2004. MMWR 2006;55: 301-305.\n4. Gandhi NR, Moll A, Sturm AW, et al: Extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis as a cause of death in patients co-infected with\ntuberculosis and HIV in a rural area of South Africa. Lancet 2006;368: 1575-80.\n5. Leimane V, Holtz TH: MDR-TB and XDR-TB management in Latvia.\nGlobal XDR-TB Task Force, Geneva, Switzerland; 2006. Available at\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2007/who_htm_tb_2007.375_eng.pdf>.\n6. CDC: Revised definition of extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis. MMWR 2006;55: 1176.\n7. CDC: Reported tuberculosis in the United States, 2005:\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health\nand Human Services, CDC; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/surv/surv2005/pdf/tbsurvfullreport.pdf>.\n8. Frieden TR, Sterling T, Pablos-Mendez A, et al: The emergence of\ndrug-resistant tuberculosis in New York City. N Engl J Med 1993;328: 521-56.\n9. Moore M, McCray E, Onorato I: The interaction of human\nimmunodeficiency virus and multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ [Chapter 4]. In: Bastian I, Portaels F, Eds.\nMultidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Dordrecht, the Netherlands: Kluwer\nAcademic Publishers; 2000:45-57.\n10. CDC: National Action Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant\nTuberculosis. MMWR 1992;41(No. RR-11):5-48.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Saturday, 24 Mar 2007 is World TB Day. The print copy of MMWR\ncontaining the posting above, provides this text related to the day\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a1.htm?s_cid=mm5611a1_e>\n\"World TB Day is observed on 24 March each year and commemorates the\ndate in 1882 when Dr. Robert Koch announced the discovery of\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis\n(TB). Worldwide, TB remains one of the leading causes of death from\ninfectious disease. An estimated 2 billion persons (that is, one\nthird of the world's population) are infected with _M. tuberculosis_.\nEach year, approximately 9 million persons become ill from TB; of\nthese, nearly 2 million die from the disease.\nWorld TB Day provides an opportunity for TB programs, nongovernmental\norganizations, and other partners to describe problems and solutions\nrelated to the TB pandemic and to support worldwide TB-control\nactivities. The theme for this year's observance is \"TB Elimination:\nNow is the Time!\"\nAfter approximately 30 years of decline, the number of TB cases\nreported in the USA increased 20 percent during 1985-1992. This led\nto a renewed emphasis on TB control and prevention during the 1990s.\nHowever, although the 2006 TB rate is the lowest recorded in the USA\nsince national reporting began in 1953, the average annual decline\nhas slowed since 2000. In addition, multidrug-resistant TB remains a\nthreat, extensively drug-resistant TB has become an emerging threat,\nand persons of racial/ethnic minority populations and foreign-born\npersons continue to account for a disproportionate number of TB cases.\nCDC and its partners are committed to eliminating TB in the USA. In\nmany states, education and awareness programs convened by local TB\ncoalitions will take place in commemoration of World TB Day.\nAdditional information about World TB Day and CDC TB-elimination\nactivities is available at <http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/worldtbday>.\"\nAs seen in South Africa, XDR TB in HIV infected patients can cause\ndeath before the initial cultures are positive, let alone drug\nsensitivity testing. The global community has a long way to go to\neradicate TB, especially in the HIV era. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (06) 20070319.0959\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1991-2003 - Spain 20070302.0738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (05) 20070228.0717\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (04) 20070220.0638\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (03) 20070209.0504\nTuberculosis, XDR - worldwide 20070205.0456\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) (02) 20070125.0340\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) 20070124.0318\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - Hungary 20061110.3233\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - South Africa (KN) (04): nationwide 20061019.3003\nTuberculosis, multi-drug resistant - South Africa (KN) 20060904.2514\n..................ll/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-11-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-10-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "1665-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1176-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "1882-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sturm AW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9444", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR, 2003-2006 - Europe (Germany, Italy)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9444", "date": "2007-03-22 16:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR, 1993-2006 - USA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2007;569(11): 250-3 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a3.htm?s_cid=mm5611a3_e>\n\nThe worldwide emergence of extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis\n(XDR TB) and a provisional definition for this form of TB were 1st\nreported in November 2005 (1,2). A more detailed description of these\nfindings and preliminary data from the USA National TB Surveillance\nSystem (NTSS) were published in 2006 (3). The USA data indicated that\n74 TB cases reported during 1993-2004 met the case definition for XDR\nTB (3). Subsequent reports suggested different definitions for XDR TB\n(4,5). In October 2006, the WHO (World Health Organization) convened\nan Emergency Global Task Force on XDR TB, which revised the case\ndefinition to specify resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampin\namong 1st line anti-TB drugs, resistance to any fluoroquinolone, and\nresistance to at least one 2nd line injectable drug (amikacin,\ncapreomycin, or kanamycin) (6).\nThis report updates the 2006 report on XDR TB in the USA, using the\nrevised case definition and provisional data for 2006. NTSS data were\nanalyzed for reported XDR TB cases during 1993-2006; a total of 49\ncases (3 percent of evaluable multidrug-resistant [MDR] TB cases) met\nthe revised case definition for XDR TB. Of these, 17 (35 percent)\nwere reported during 2000-2006. Compared with 1993-1999, cases from\n2000-2006 were more likely to be in persons who were foreign-born and\nless likely to be in persons with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.\nXDR TB presents a global threat and a challenge to TB-control\nactivities in the USA. To prevent the spread of XDR TB, renewed\nvigilance is needed through drug-susceptibility testing, case\nreporting, specialized care, infection control, and expanded capacity\nfor outbreak detection and response.\nTB cases reported to NTSS from 50 states and the District of Columbia\n(DC) were analyzed for the period 1993-2006. All culture-confirmed\ncases with initial drug-susceptibility test (DST) results reported\nfor at least isoniazid and rifampin were included in the analysis.\nBecause susceptibility testing is time consuming, especially for 2nd\nline drugs, initial DST results are reported separately to avoid\ndelaying reporting of routine TB case data. At the end of treatment,\nthe outcome is reported in a 2nd follow-up report. The HIV status of\nTB cases reported to NTSS was available through 2006, except in\nCalifornia, where only data on positive HIV test results were\navailable through 2004.\nTB cases reported during 1993-1999, a period of rapidly decreasing\nincidence of both TB and MDR TB, were compared with cases reported\nduring 2000-2006, a period of slower decline in TB and MDR TB rates.\nDuring 1993-2006, a total of 202 436 culture-confirmed TB cases were\nreported to NTSS; 190 312 of these cases had initial DST results for\nat least isoniazid and rifampin, including 2927 (2 percent) with\ninitial resistance to both drugs (that is, MDR TB). Of the 2927 MDR\nTB cases, 1665 (57 percent) had DST results reported for at least a\nfluoroquinolone and an injectable 2nd line drug. Of these, 49 cases\n(3 percent) met the revised definition of XDR TB, including 32 cases\nreported during 1993-1999 and 17 cases during 2000-2006 [Table - for\ntable, see original URL - Mod.LL].\nThe 49 XDR TB cases were reported from 9 states and one city, with\nthe largest numbers in New York City (19 cases) and California (11\ncases) [Figure - for figure, see original URL - Mod.LL]. HIV status\nwas known for 29 (59 percent) of the 49 persons with XDR TB; 16 (55\npercent) were HIV positive. During 1993-1999, a total of 19 persons\nwith XDR TB had known HIV status, of whom 14 (74 percent) were HIV\npositive; during 2000-2006, 10 persons had known HIV status, of whom\n2 (20 percent) were HIV positive. The number and percentage of\npersons with XDR TB in the group aged 25-44 years decreased from 21\n(66 percent) during 1993-1999 to 6 (35 percent) during 2000-2006.\nWhen the 2 periods were compared, the number of XDR TB cases among\nforeign-born persons did not change substantially, but the percentage\nof XDR-TB cases among foreign-born persons increased from 39 percent\n(12 cases) in 1993-1999 to 76 percent (13 cases) in 2000-2006 as the\nnumber of XDR TB cases among USA-born cases decreased. Among\nracial/ethnic populations, 9 (28 percent) of 32 XDR TB cases during\n1993-1999 were reported among non-Hispanic blacks, decreasing to 2\n(12 percent) of 17 cases during 2000-2006. Conversely, the number and\npercentage of cases among Asians increased from 3 (9 percent) during\n1993-1999 to 7 (41 percent) during 2000-2006. Sputum microscopy for\nacid-fast bacilli was positive in 27 (69 percent) of the 39 cases\nwith known results. Mortality in XDR TB cases was strongly associated\nwith HIV infection. Among 41 persons with XDR TB and known outcomes,\n12 (29 percent) persons died; 10 of those had HIV infection, and the\nother 2 did not have HIV test results reported.\n[Byline: NS Shah NS, R Pratt, S Althomsons, et al]\nMMWR Editorial note\n--------------\nAfter approximately 30 years of declining trends, a TB epidemic\noccurred in the USA during 1985-1992. From 22 201 cases in 1985 (9.3\nper 100 000 population), reported TB increased to 26 673 cases in\n1992 (10.4 per 100 000 population) (7). Although the incidence of MDR\nTB in the USA was largely unknown before 1993, the number of cases\nbegan increasing in New York City in the early 1980s (8), and\nnumerous outbreaks of MDR TB were described in the late 1980s and\nearly 1990s (9). With implementation of elements of the 1992 National\nAction Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis, reported MDR\nTB cases declined rapidly (10). TB control activities included\nimproving laboratory services for rapid, accurate culture and DST,\nimproving infection control, and strengthening NTSS to include DST\nand HIV test results beginning in 1993. The rapid decrease in MDR TB\ncases during 1993-1999 likely correlated with the 34 percent decline\nin TB cases overall in the USA to 17 501 (6.3 per 100 000) in 1999 (7).\nEffective treatment of MDR TB requires administration, for 18-24\nmonths, of 4 to 6 drugs to which the infecting organism is\nsusceptible, including multiple 2nd line drugs. Beginning in the\n1980s, the use of these drugs increased substantially as physicians\nand TB control programs treated growing numbers of MDR TB cases.\nIncreased use of these drugs resulted in MDR TB strains with\nextensive resistance to both 1st and 2nd line drugs. Thus, XDR TB in\nthe 1990s likely represented the legacy of the 1985-1992 TB epidemic\nin the USA and treatments to combat the spike in MDR TB cases.\nCharacteristics of XDR TB cases changed during 2000-2006 in parallel\nwith the changing epidemiology of TB in general and MDR TB in\nparticular. These changes included an overall decrease in the number\nof cases, a decrease in the proportion of cases in HIV-infected\npersons, an increase in the proportion of cases among foreign-born\npersons, and an increase in the proportion of Asians among persons\nwith XDR TB, compared with 1993-1999 (7).\nThe findings in this report are subject to at least 5 limitations:\n- the number of XDR TB cases is a minimum estimate because of\nincomplete DST data. Although 57 percent of MDR-TB cases had DST\nresults reported for at least a fluoroquinolone and at least one of\nthe 3 2nd-line injectable drugs, only 22 percent had DST results\nreported for all drug combinations in the definition of XDR TB,\ntaking into consideration cross-resistance among drugs and data\navailable in NTSS. Initial TB isolates with any resistance to\nrifampin or resistance to any two 1st line drugs should be tested for\nsusceptibility to a full panel of anti-TB drugs, and the results\nshould be reported accordingly.\n- Aggregate reporting of drug resistance traditionally has been based\nonly on initial DST results, not on drug resistance that develops\nduring treatment. Because of the complexity of 2nd line DST, results\ncan be delayed by several months and might not be included in the\nreport of initial DST results.\n- Approximately 20 percent of reported TB cases do not have positive\ncultures that would enable DSTs to be performed.\n- NTSS data for 2006 are provisional, and final case counts,\nincluding XDR TB cases, are subject to revision.\n- Finally, HIV test results usually are reported to NTSS after both\nTB and HIV surveillance systems have verified their annual case\ncounts. Thus, HIV test results lag behind TB case counts, and data on\nHIV status are complete through 2005 but provisional for 2006, except\nfor California, which provided data only through 2004. In addition,\nHIV test results from California are less complete.\nThe NTSS surveillance data summarized in this report represent an\nupdated measurement of XDR TB in the USA. However, surveillance data\ndo not enable a detailed understanding of how most XDR TB cases\narise. For example, the relative importance of person-to-person XDR\nTB transmission compared with the emergence of XDR TB in individual\npatients as a consequence of inadequate treatment cannot be determined.\nUse of 2nd line drugs to treat drug-resistant TB is increasing\nthroughout the world, presaging substantial increases in XDR TB\ninternationally. Accurate measures of the incidence, prevalence, and\ndeterminants of XDR TB are needed to target public health responses.\nAttention to fundamental aspects of TB control (such as,\nsurveillance, prompt culture and DST, directly observed treatment,\ncontact investigation, rapid containment of outbreaks, and infection\ncontrol) is needed to control XDR TB in the USA in the same manner\nthat MDR TB was addressed during the previous decade. The Federal TB\nTask Force is developing a domestic and international response for\nthe American government agencies regarding XDR TB. A senior-level\ninteragency meeting will be convened to formulate a comprehensive\nresponse and to assign responsibilities for a unified strategic approach.\nAdditional information regarding XDR TB is available at\n<http://www.who.int/tb/xdr/en/index.html>.\nReferences:\n1. Shah NS, Wright A, Drobniewski F, et al: Extreme drug resistance\nin tuberculosis (XDR-TB\"): global survey of supranational reference\nlaboratories for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with resistance to\nsecond-line drugs. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9(Suppl 1):S77.\n2. Holtz TH, Riekstina V, Zarovska E, et al: XDR-TB: extreme\ndrug-resistance and treatment outcome under DOTS-Plus, Latvia,\n2000-2002. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9 (Suppl 1):S258.\n3. CDC: Emergence of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with extensive\nresistance to second-line drugs-worldwide, 2000-2004. MMWR 2006;55: 301-305.\n4. Gandhi NR, Moll A, Sturm AW, et al: Extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis as a cause of death in patients co-infected with\ntuberculosis and HIV in a rural area of South Africa. Lancet 2006;368: 1575-80.\n5. Leimane V, Holtz TH: MDR-TB and XDR-TB management in Latvia.\nGlobal XDR-TB Task Force, Geneva, Switzerland; 2006. Available at\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2007/who_htm_tb_2007.375_eng.pdf>.\n6. CDC: Revised definition of extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis. MMWR 2006;55: 1176.\n7. CDC: Reported tuberculosis in the United States, 2005:\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health\nand Human Services, CDC; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/surv/surv2005/pdf/tbsurvfullreport.pdf>.\n8. Frieden TR, Sterling T, Pablos-Mendez A, et al: The emergence of\ndrug-resistant tuberculosis in New York City. N Engl J Med 1993;328: 521-56.\n9. Moore M, McCray E, Onorato I: The interaction of human\nimmunodeficiency virus and multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ [Chapter 4]. In: Bastian I, Portaels F, Eds.\nMultidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Dordrecht, the Netherlands: Kluwer\nAcademic Publishers; 2000:45-57.\n10. CDC: National Action Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant\nTuberculosis. MMWR 1992;41(No. RR-11):5-48.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Saturday, 24 Mar 2007 is World TB Day. The print copy of MMWR\ncontaining the posting above, provides this text related to the day\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a1.htm?s_cid=mm5611a1_e>\n\"World TB Day is observed on 24 March each year and commemorates the\ndate in 1882 when Dr. Robert Koch announced the discovery of\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis\n(TB). Worldwide, TB remains one of the leading causes of death from\ninfectious disease. An estimated 2 billion persons (that is, one\nthird of the world's population) are infected with _M. tuberculosis_.\nEach year, approximately 9 million persons become ill from TB; of\nthese, nearly 2 million die from the disease.\nWorld TB Day provides an opportunity for TB programs, nongovernmental\norganizations, and other partners to describe problems and solutions\nrelated to the TB pandemic and to support worldwide TB-control\nactivities. The theme for this year's observance is \"TB Elimination:\nNow is the Time!\"\nAfter approximately 30 years of decline, the number of TB cases\nreported in the USA increased 20 percent during 1985-1992. This led\nto a renewed emphasis on TB control and prevention during the 1990s.\nHowever, although the 2006 TB rate is the lowest recorded in the USA\nsince national reporting began in 1953, the average annual decline\nhas slowed since 2000. In addition, multidrug-resistant TB remains a\nthreat, extensively drug-resistant TB has become an emerging threat,\nand persons of racial/ethnic minority populations and foreign-born\npersons continue to account for a disproportionate number of TB cases.\nCDC and its partners are committed to eliminating TB in the USA. In\nmany states, education and awareness programs convened by local TB\ncoalitions will take place in commemoration of World TB Day.\nAdditional information about World TB Day and CDC TB-elimination\nactivities is available at <http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/worldtbday>.\"\nAs seen in South Africa, XDR TB in HIV infected patients can cause\ndeath before the initial cultures are positive, let alone drug\nsensitivity testing. The global community has a long way to go to\neradicate TB, especially in the HIV era. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (06) 20070319.0959\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1991-2003 - Spain 20070302.0738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (05) 20070228.0717\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (04) 20070220.0638\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (03) 20070209.0504\nTuberculosis, XDR - worldwide 20070205.0456\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) (02) 20070125.0340\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) 20070124.0318\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - Hungary 20061110.3233\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - South Africa (KN) (04): nationwide 20061019.3003\nTuberculosis, multi-drug resistant - South Africa (KN) 20060904.2514\n..................ll/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
