If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-11-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-10-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "1665-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1176-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "1882-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sturm AW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9236", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (07): Eastern Cape", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9236", "date": "2007-03-22 16:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR, 1993-2006 - USA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2007;569(11): 250-3 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a3.htm?s_cid=mm5611a3_e>\n\nThe worldwide emergence of extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis\n(XDR TB) and a provisional definition for this form of TB were 1st\nreported in November 2005 (1,2). A more detailed description of these\nfindings and preliminary data from the USA National TB Surveillance\nSystem (NTSS) were published in 2006 (3). The USA data indicated that\n74 TB cases reported during 1993-2004 met the case definition for XDR\nTB (3). Subsequent reports suggested different definitions for XDR TB\n(4,5). In October 2006, the WHO (World Health Organization) convened\nan Emergency Global Task Force on XDR TB, which revised the case\ndefinition to specify resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampin\namong 1st line anti-TB drugs, resistance to any fluoroquinolone, and\nresistance to at least one 2nd line injectable drug (amikacin,\ncapreomycin, or kanamycin) (6).\nThis report updates the 2006 report on XDR TB in the USA, using the\nrevised case definition and provisional data for 2006. NTSS data were\nanalyzed for reported XDR TB cases during 1993-2006; a total of 49\ncases (3 percent of evaluable multidrug-resistant [MDR] TB cases) met\nthe revised case definition for XDR TB. Of these, 17 (35 percent)\nwere reported during 2000-2006. Compared with 1993-1999, cases from\n2000-2006 were more likely to be in persons who were foreign-born and\nless likely to be in persons with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.\nXDR TB presents a global threat and a challenge to TB-control\nactivities in the USA. To prevent the spread of XDR TB, renewed\nvigilance is needed through drug-susceptibility testing, case\nreporting, specialized care, infection control, and expanded capacity\nfor outbreak detection and response.\nTB cases reported to NTSS from 50 states and the District of Columbia\n(DC) were analyzed for the period 1993-2006. All culture-confirmed\ncases with initial drug-susceptibility test (DST) results reported\nfor at least isoniazid and rifampin were included in the analysis.\nBecause susceptibility testing is time consuming, especially for 2nd\nline drugs, initial DST results are reported separately to avoid\ndelaying reporting of routine TB case data. At the end of treatment,\nthe outcome is reported in a 2nd follow-up report. The HIV status of\nTB cases reported to NTSS was available through 2006, except in\nCalifornia, where only data on positive HIV test results were\navailable through 2004.\nTB cases reported during 1993-1999, a period of rapidly decreasing\nincidence of both TB and MDR TB, were compared with cases reported\nduring 2000-2006, a period of slower decline in TB and MDR TB rates.\nDuring 1993-2006, a total of 202 436 culture-confirmed TB cases were\nreported to NTSS; 190 312 of these cases had initial DST results for\nat least isoniazid and rifampin, including 2927 (2 percent) with\ninitial resistance to both drugs (that is, MDR TB). Of the 2927 MDR\nTB cases, 1665 (57 percent) had DST results reported for at least a\nfluoroquinolone and an injectable 2nd line drug. Of these, 49 cases\n(3 percent) met the revised definition of XDR TB, including 32 cases\nreported during 1993-1999 and 17 cases during 2000-2006 [Table - for\ntable, see original URL - Mod.LL].\nThe 49 XDR TB cases were reported from 9 states and one city, with\nthe largest numbers in New York City (19 cases) and California (11\ncases) [Figure - for figure, see original URL - Mod.LL]. HIV status\nwas known for 29 (59 percent) of the 49 persons with XDR TB; 16 (55\npercent) were HIV positive. During 1993-1999, a total of 19 persons\nwith XDR TB had known HIV status, of whom 14 (74 percent) were HIV\npositive; during 2000-2006, 10 persons had known HIV status, of whom\n2 (20 percent) were HIV positive. The number and percentage of\npersons with XDR TB in the group aged 25-44 years decreased from 21\n(66 percent) during 1993-1999 to 6 (35 percent) during 2000-2006.\nWhen the 2 periods were compared, the number of XDR TB cases among\nforeign-born persons did not change substantially, but the percentage\nof XDR-TB cases among foreign-born persons increased from 39 percent\n(12 cases) in 1993-1999 to 76 percent (13 cases) in 2000-2006 as the\nnumber of XDR TB cases among USA-born cases decreased. Among\nracial/ethnic populations, 9 (28 percent) of 32 XDR TB cases during\n1993-1999 were reported among non-Hispanic blacks, decreasing to 2\n(12 percent) of 17 cases during 2000-2006. Conversely, the number and\npercentage of cases among Asians increased from 3 (9 percent) during\n1993-1999 to 7 (41 percent) during 2000-2006. Sputum microscopy for\nacid-fast bacilli was positive in 27 (69 percent) of the 39 cases\nwith known results. Mortality in XDR TB cases was strongly associated\nwith HIV infection. Among 41 persons with XDR TB and known outcomes,\n12 (29 percent) persons died; 10 of those had HIV infection, and the\nother 2 did not have HIV test results reported.\n[Byline: NS Shah NS, R Pratt, S Althomsons, et al]\nMMWR Editorial note\n--------------\nAfter approximately 30 years of declining trends, a TB epidemic\noccurred in the USA during 1985-1992. From 22 201 cases in 1985 (9.3\nper 100 000 population), reported TB increased to 26 673 cases in\n1992 (10.4 per 100 000 population) (7). Although the incidence of MDR\nTB in the USA was largely unknown before 1993, the number of cases\nbegan increasing in New York City in the early 1980s (8), and\nnumerous outbreaks of MDR TB were described in the late 1980s and\nearly 1990s (9). With implementation of elements of the 1992 National\nAction Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis, reported MDR\nTB cases declined rapidly (10). TB control activities included\nimproving laboratory services for rapid, accurate culture and DST,\nimproving infection control, and strengthening NTSS to include DST\nand HIV test results beginning in 1993. The rapid decrease in MDR TB\ncases during 1993-1999 likely correlated with the 34 percent decline\nin TB cases overall in the USA to 17 501 (6.3 per 100 000) in 1999 (7).\nEffective treatment of MDR TB requires administration, for 18-24\nmonths, of 4 to 6 drugs to which the infecting organism is\nsusceptible, including multiple 2nd line drugs. Beginning in the\n1980s, the use of these drugs increased substantially as physicians\nand TB control programs treated growing numbers of MDR TB cases.\nIncreased use of these drugs resulted in MDR TB strains with\nextensive resistance to both 1st and 2nd line drugs. Thus, XDR TB in\nthe 1990s likely represented the legacy of the 1985-1992 TB epidemic\nin the USA and treatments to combat the spike in MDR TB cases.\nCharacteristics of XDR TB cases changed during 2000-2006 in parallel\nwith the changing epidemiology of TB in general and MDR TB in\nparticular. These changes included an overall decrease in the number\nof cases, a decrease in the proportion of cases in HIV-infected\npersons, an increase in the proportion of cases among foreign-born\npersons, and an increase in the proportion of Asians among persons\nwith XDR TB, compared with 1993-1999 (7).\nThe findings in this report are subject to at least 5 limitations:\n- the number of XDR TB cases is a minimum estimate because of\nincomplete DST data. Although 57 percent of MDR-TB cases had DST\nresults reported for at least a fluoroquinolone and at least one of\nthe 3 2nd-line injectable drugs, only 22 percent had DST results\nreported for all drug combinations in the definition of XDR TB,\ntaking into consideration cross-resistance among drugs and data\navailable in NTSS. Initial TB isolates with any resistance to\nrifampin or resistance to any two 1st line drugs should be tested for\nsusceptibility to a full panel of anti-TB drugs, and the results\nshould be reported accordingly.\n- Aggregate reporting of drug resistance traditionally has been based\nonly on initial DST results, not on drug resistance that develops\nduring treatment. Because of the complexity of 2nd line DST, results\ncan be delayed by several months and might not be included in the\nreport of initial DST results.\n- Approximately 20 percent of reported TB cases do not have positive\ncultures that would enable DSTs to be performed.\n- NTSS data for 2006 are provisional, and final case counts,\nincluding XDR TB cases, are subject to revision.\n- Finally, HIV test results usually are reported to NTSS after both\nTB and HIV surveillance systems have verified their annual case\ncounts. Thus, HIV test results lag behind TB case counts, and data on\nHIV status are complete through 2005 but provisional for 2006, except\nfor California, which provided data only through 2004. In addition,\nHIV test results from California are less complete.\nThe NTSS surveillance data summarized in this report represent an\nupdated measurement of XDR TB in the USA. However, surveillance data\ndo not enable a detailed understanding of how most XDR TB cases\narise. For example, the relative importance of person-to-person XDR\nTB transmission compared with the emergence of XDR TB in individual\npatients as a consequence of inadequate treatment cannot be determined.\nUse of 2nd line drugs to treat drug-resistant TB is increasing\nthroughout the world, presaging substantial increases in XDR TB\ninternationally. Accurate measures of the incidence, prevalence, and\ndeterminants of XDR TB are needed to target public health responses.\nAttention to fundamental aspects of TB control (such as,\nsurveillance, prompt culture and DST, directly observed treatment,\ncontact investigation, rapid containment of outbreaks, and infection\ncontrol) is needed to control XDR TB in the USA in the same manner\nthat MDR TB was addressed during the previous decade. The Federal TB\nTask Force is developing a domestic and international response for\nthe American government agencies regarding XDR TB. A senior-level\ninteragency meeting will be convened to formulate a comprehensive\nresponse and to assign responsibilities for a unified strategic approach.\nAdditional information regarding XDR TB is available at\n<http://www.who.int/tb/xdr/en/index.html>.\nReferences:\n1. Shah NS, Wright A, Drobniewski F, et al: Extreme drug resistance\nin tuberculosis (XDR-TB\"): global survey of supranational reference\nlaboratories for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with resistance to\nsecond-line drugs. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9(Suppl 1):S77.\n2. Holtz TH, Riekstina V, Zarovska E, et al: XDR-TB: extreme\ndrug-resistance and treatment outcome under DOTS-Plus, Latvia,\n2000-2002. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9 (Suppl 1):S258.\n3. CDC: Emergence of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with extensive\nresistance to second-line drugs-worldwide, 2000-2004. MMWR 2006;55: 301-305.\n4. Gandhi NR, Moll A, Sturm AW, et al: Extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis as a cause of death in patients co-infected with\ntuberculosis and HIV in a rural area of South Africa. Lancet 2006;368: 1575-80.\n5. Leimane V, Holtz TH: MDR-TB and XDR-TB management in Latvia.\nGlobal XDR-TB Task Force, Geneva, Switzerland; 2006. Available at\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2007/who_htm_tb_2007.375_eng.pdf>.\n6. CDC: Revised definition of extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis. MMWR 2006;55: 1176.\n7. CDC: Reported tuberculosis in the United States, 2005:\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health\nand Human Services, CDC; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/surv/surv2005/pdf/tbsurvfullreport.pdf>.\n8. Frieden TR, Sterling T, Pablos-Mendez A, et al: The emergence of\ndrug-resistant tuberculosis in New York City. N Engl J Med 1993;328: 521-56.\n9. Moore M, McCray E, Onorato I: The interaction of human\nimmunodeficiency virus and multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ [Chapter 4]. In: Bastian I, Portaels F, Eds.\nMultidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Dordrecht, the Netherlands: Kluwer\nAcademic Publishers; 2000:45-57.\n10. CDC: National Action Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant\nTuberculosis. MMWR 1992;41(No. RR-11):5-48.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Saturday, 24 Mar 2007 is World TB Day. The print copy of MMWR\ncontaining the posting above, provides this text related to the day\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a1.htm?s_cid=mm5611a1_e>\n\"World TB Day is observed on 24 March each year and commemorates the\ndate in 1882 when Dr. Robert Koch announced the discovery of\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis\n(TB). Worldwide, TB remains one of the leading causes of death from\ninfectious disease. An estimated 2 billion persons (that is, one\nthird of the world's population) are infected with _M. tuberculosis_.\nEach year, approximately 9 million persons become ill from TB; of\nthese, nearly 2 million die from the disease.\nWorld TB Day provides an opportunity for TB programs, nongovernmental\norganizations, and other partners to describe problems and solutions\nrelated to the TB pandemic and to support worldwide TB-control\nactivities. The theme for this year's observance is \"TB Elimination:\nNow is the Time!\"\nAfter approximately 30 years of decline, the number of TB cases\nreported in the USA increased 20 percent during 1985-1992. This led\nto a renewed emphasis on TB control and prevention during the 1990s.\nHowever, although the 2006 TB rate is the lowest recorded in the USA\nsince national reporting began in 1953, the average annual decline\nhas slowed since 2000. In addition, multidrug-resistant TB remains a\nthreat, extensively drug-resistant TB has become an emerging threat,\nand persons of racial/ethnic minority populations and foreign-born\npersons continue to account for a disproportionate number of TB cases.\nCDC and its partners are committed to eliminating TB in the USA. In\nmany states, education and awareness programs convened by local TB\ncoalitions will take place in commemoration of World TB Day.\nAdditional information about World TB Day and CDC TB-elimination\nactivities is available at <http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/worldtbday>.\"\nAs seen in South Africa, XDR TB in HIV infected patients can cause\ndeath before the initial cultures are positive, let alone drug\nsensitivity testing. The global community has a long way to go to\neradicate TB, especially in the HIV era. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (06) 20070319.0959\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1991-2003 - Spain 20070302.0738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (05) 20070228.0717\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (04) 20070220.0638\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (03) 20070209.0504\nTuberculosis, XDR - worldwide 20070205.0456\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) (02) 20070125.0340\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) 20070124.0318\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - Hungary 20061110.3233\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - South Africa (KN) (04): nationwide 20061019.3003\nTuberculosis, multi-drug resistant - South Africa (KN) 20060904.2514\n..................ll/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-11-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-10-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "1665-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1176-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "1882-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sturm AW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9095", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR, 1993-2006 - USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9095", "date": "2007-03-22 16:00:02", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, XDR, 1993-2006 - USA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2007;569(11): 250-3 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a3.htm?s_cid=mm5611a3_e>\n\nThe worldwide emergence of extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis\n(XDR TB) and a provisional definition for this form of TB were 1st\nreported in November 2005 (1,2). A more detailed description of these\nfindings and preliminary data from the USA National TB Surveillance\nSystem (NTSS) were published in 2006 (3). The USA data indicated that\n74 TB cases reported during 1993-2004 met the case definition for XDR\nTB (3). Subsequent reports suggested different definitions for XDR TB\n(4,5). In October 2006, the WHO (World Health Organization) convened\nan Emergency Global Task Force on XDR TB, which revised the case\ndefinition to specify resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampin\namong 1st line anti-TB drugs, resistance to any fluoroquinolone, and\nresistance to at least one 2nd line injectable drug (amikacin,\ncapreomycin, or kanamycin) (6).\nThis report updates the 2006 report on XDR TB in the USA, using the\nrevised case definition and provisional data for 2006. NTSS data were\nanalyzed for reported XDR TB cases during 1993-2006; a total of 49\ncases (3 percent of evaluable multidrug-resistant [MDR] TB cases) met\nthe revised case definition for XDR TB. Of these, 17 (35 percent)\nwere reported during 2000-2006. Compared with 1993-1999, cases from\n2000-2006 were more likely to be in persons who were foreign-born and\nless likely to be in persons with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.\nXDR TB presents a global threat and a challenge to TB-control\nactivities in the USA. To prevent the spread of XDR TB, renewed\nvigilance is needed through drug-susceptibility testing, case\nreporting, specialized care, infection control, and expanded capacity\nfor outbreak detection and response.\nTB cases reported to NTSS from 50 states and the District of Columbia\n(DC) were analyzed for the period 1993-2006. All culture-confirmed\ncases with initial drug-susceptibility test (DST) results reported\nfor at least isoniazid and rifampin were included in the analysis.\nBecause susceptibility testing is time consuming, especially for 2nd\nline drugs, initial DST results are reported separately to avoid\ndelaying reporting of routine TB case data. At the end of treatment,\nthe outcome is reported in a 2nd follow-up report. The HIV status of\nTB cases reported to NTSS was available through 2006, except in\nCalifornia, where only data on positive HIV test results were\navailable through 2004.\nTB cases reported during 1993-1999, a period of rapidly decreasing\nincidence of both TB and MDR TB, were compared with cases reported\nduring 2000-2006, a period of slower decline in TB and MDR TB rates.\nDuring 1993-2006, a total of 202 436 culture-confirmed TB cases were\nreported to NTSS; 190 312 of these cases had initial DST results for\nat least isoniazid and rifampin, including 2927 (2 percent) with\ninitial resistance to both drugs (that is, MDR TB). Of the 2927 MDR\nTB cases, 1665 (57 percent) had DST results reported for at least a\nfluoroquinolone and an injectable 2nd line drug. Of these, 49 cases\n(3 percent) met the revised definition of XDR TB, including 32 cases\nreported during 1993-1999 and 17 cases during 2000-2006 [Table - for\ntable, see original URL - Mod.LL].\nThe 49 XDR TB cases were reported from 9 states and one city, with\nthe largest numbers in New York City (19 cases) and California (11\ncases) [Figure - for figure, see original URL - Mod.LL]. HIV status\nwas known for 29 (59 percent) of the 49 persons with XDR TB; 16 (55\npercent) were HIV positive. During 1993-1999, a total of 19 persons\nwith XDR TB had known HIV status, of whom 14 (74 percent) were HIV\npositive; during 2000-2006, 10 persons had known HIV status, of whom\n2 (20 percent) were HIV positive. The number and percentage of\npersons with XDR TB in the group aged 25-44 years decreased from 21\n(66 percent) during 1993-1999 to 6 (35 percent) during 2000-2006.\nWhen the 2 periods were compared, the number of XDR TB cases among\nforeign-born persons did not change substantially, but the percentage\nof XDR-TB cases among foreign-born persons increased from 39 percent\n(12 cases) in 1993-1999 to 76 percent (13 cases) in 2000-2006 as the\nnumber of XDR TB cases among USA-born cases decreased. Among\nracial/ethnic populations, 9 (28 percent) of 32 XDR TB cases during\n1993-1999 were reported among non-Hispanic blacks, decreasing to 2\n(12 percent) of 17 cases during 2000-2006. Conversely, the number and\npercentage of cases among Asians increased from 3 (9 percent) during\n1993-1999 to 7 (41 percent) during 2000-2006. Sputum microscopy for\nacid-fast bacilli was positive in 27 (69 percent) of the 39 cases\nwith known results. Mortality in XDR TB cases was strongly associated\nwith HIV infection. Among 41 persons with XDR TB and known outcomes,\n12 (29 percent) persons died; 10 of those had HIV infection, and the\nother 2 did not have HIV test results reported.\n[Byline: NS Shah NS, R Pratt, S Althomsons, et al]\nMMWR Editorial note\n--------------\nAfter approximately 30 years of declining trends, a TB epidemic\noccurred in the USA during 1985-1992. From 22 201 cases in 1985 (9.3\nper 100 000 population), reported TB increased to 26 673 cases in\n1992 (10.4 per 100 000 population) (7). Although the incidence of MDR\nTB in the USA was largely unknown before 1993, the number of cases\nbegan increasing in New York City in the early 1980s (8), and\nnumerous outbreaks of MDR TB were described in the late 1980s and\nearly 1990s (9). With implementation of elements of the 1992 National\nAction Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis, reported MDR\nTB cases declined rapidly (10). TB control activities included\nimproving laboratory services for rapid, accurate culture and DST,\nimproving infection control, and strengthening NTSS to include DST\nand HIV test results beginning in 1993. The rapid decrease in MDR TB\ncases during 1993-1999 likely correlated with the 34 percent decline\nin TB cases overall in the USA to 17 501 (6.3 per 100 000) in 1999 (7).\nEffective treatment of MDR TB requires administration, for 18-24\nmonths, of 4 to 6 drugs to which the infecting organism is\nsusceptible, including multiple 2nd line drugs. Beginning in the\n1980s, the use of these drugs increased substantially as physicians\nand TB control programs treated growing numbers of MDR TB cases.\nIncreased use of these drugs resulted in MDR TB strains with\nextensive resistance to both 1st and 2nd line drugs. Thus, XDR TB in\nthe 1990s likely represented the legacy of the 1985-1992 TB epidemic\nin the USA and treatments to combat the spike in MDR TB cases.\nCharacteristics of XDR TB cases changed during 2000-2006 in parallel\nwith the changing epidemiology of TB in general and MDR TB in\nparticular. These changes included an overall decrease in the number\nof cases, a decrease in the proportion of cases in HIV-infected\npersons, an increase in the proportion of cases among foreign-born\npersons, and an increase in the proportion of Asians among persons\nwith XDR TB, compared with 1993-1999 (7).\nThe findings in this report are subject to at least 5 limitations:\n- the number of XDR TB cases is a minimum estimate because of\nincomplete DST data. Although 57 percent of MDR-TB cases had DST\nresults reported for at least a fluoroquinolone and at least one of\nthe 3 2nd-line injectable drugs, only 22 percent had DST results\nreported for all drug combinations in the definition of XDR TB,\ntaking into consideration cross-resistance among drugs and data\navailable in NTSS. Initial TB isolates with any resistance to\nrifampin or resistance to any two 1st line drugs should be tested for\nsusceptibility to a full panel of anti-TB drugs, and the results\nshould be reported accordingly.\n- Aggregate reporting of drug resistance traditionally has been based\nonly on initial DST results, not on drug resistance that develops\nduring treatment. Because of the complexity of 2nd line DST, results\ncan be delayed by several months and might not be included in the\nreport of initial DST results.\n- Approximately 20 percent of reported TB cases do not have positive\ncultures that would enable DSTs to be performed.\n- NTSS data for 2006 are provisional, and final case counts,\nincluding XDR TB cases, are subject to revision.\n- Finally, HIV test results usually are reported to NTSS after both\nTB and HIV surveillance systems have verified their annual case\ncounts. Thus, HIV test results lag behind TB case counts, and data on\nHIV status are complete through 2005 but provisional for 2006, except\nfor California, which provided data only through 2004. In addition,\nHIV test results from California are less complete.\nThe NTSS surveillance data summarized in this report represent an\nupdated measurement of XDR TB in the USA. However, surveillance data\ndo not enable a detailed understanding of how most XDR TB cases\narise. For example, the relative importance of person-to-person XDR\nTB transmission compared with the emergence of XDR TB in individual\npatients as a consequence of inadequate treatment cannot be determined.\nUse of 2nd line drugs to treat drug-resistant TB is increasing\nthroughout the world, presaging substantial increases in XDR TB\ninternationally. Accurate measures of the incidence, prevalence, and\ndeterminants of XDR TB are needed to target public health responses.\nAttention to fundamental aspects of TB control (such as,\nsurveillance, prompt culture and DST, directly observed treatment,\ncontact investigation, rapid containment of outbreaks, and infection\ncontrol) is needed to control XDR TB in the USA in the same manner\nthat MDR TB was addressed during the previous decade. The Federal TB\nTask Force is developing a domestic and international response for\nthe American government agencies regarding XDR TB. A senior-level\ninteragency meeting will be convened to formulate a comprehensive\nresponse and to assign responsibilities for a unified strategic approach.\nAdditional information regarding XDR TB is available at\n<http://www.who.int/tb/xdr/en/index.html>.\nReferences:\n1. Shah NS, Wright A, Drobniewski F, et al: Extreme drug resistance\nin tuberculosis (XDR-TB\"): global survey of supranational reference\nlaboratories for _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with resistance to\nsecond-line drugs. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9(Suppl 1):S77.\n2. Holtz TH, Riekstina V, Zarovska E, et al: XDR-TB: extreme\ndrug-resistance and treatment outcome under DOTS-Plus, Latvia,\n2000-2002. Int J Tuberc Lung Dis 2005;9 (Suppl 1):S258.\n3. CDC: Emergence of _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_ with extensive\nresistance to second-line drugs-worldwide, 2000-2004. MMWR 2006;55: 301-305.\n4. Gandhi NR, Moll A, Sturm AW, et al: Extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis as a cause of death in patients co-infected with\ntuberculosis and HIV in a rural area of South Africa. Lancet 2006;368: 1575-80.\n5. Leimane V, Holtz TH: MDR-TB and XDR-TB management in Latvia.\nGlobal XDR-TB Task Force, Geneva, Switzerland; 2006. Available at\n<http://whqlibdoc.who.int/hq/2007/who_htm_tb_2007.375_eng.pdf>.\n6. CDC: Revised definition of extensively drug-resistant\ntuberculosis. MMWR 2006;55: 1176.\n7. CDC: Reported tuberculosis in the United States, 2005:\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health\nand Human Services, CDC; 2006. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/surv/surv2005/pdf/tbsurvfullreport.pdf>.\n8. Frieden TR, Sterling T, Pablos-Mendez A, et al: The emergence of\ndrug-resistant tuberculosis in New York City. N Engl J Med 1993;328: 521-56.\n9. Moore M, McCray E, Onorato I: The interaction of human\nimmunodeficiency virus and multidrug-resistant _Mycobacterium\ntuberculosis_ [Chapter 4]. In: Bastian I, Portaels F, Eds.\nMultidrug-resistant tuberculosis. Dordrecht, the Netherlands: Kluwer\nAcademic Publishers; 2000:45-57.\n10. CDC: National Action Plan to Combat Multidrug-Resistant\nTuberculosis. MMWR 1992;41(No. RR-11):5-48.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Saturday, 24 Mar 2007 is World TB Day. The print copy of MMWR\ncontaining the posting above, provides this text related to the day\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5611a1.htm?s_cid=mm5611a1_e>\n\"World TB Day is observed on 24 March each year and commemorates the\ndate in 1882 when Dr. Robert Koch announced the discovery of\n_Mycobacterium tuberculosis_, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis\n(TB). Worldwide, TB remains one of the leading causes of death from\ninfectious disease. An estimated 2 billion persons (that is, one\nthird of the world's population) are infected with _M. tuberculosis_.\nEach year, approximately 9 million persons become ill from TB; of\nthese, nearly 2 million die from the disease.\nWorld TB Day provides an opportunity for TB programs, nongovernmental\norganizations, and other partners to describe problems and solutions\nrelated to the TB pandemic and to support worldwide TB-control\nactivities. The theme for this year's observance is \"TB Elimination:\nNow is the Time!\"\nAfter approximately 30 years of decline, the number of TB cases\nreported in the USA increased 20 percent during 1985-1992. This led\nto a renewed emphasis on TB control and prevention during the 1990s.\nHowever, although the 2006 TB rate is the lowest recorded in the USA\nsince national reporting began in 1953, the average annual decline\nhas slowed since 2000. In addition, multidrug-resistant TB remains a\nthreat, extensively drug-resistant TB has become an emerging threat,\nand persons of racial/ethnic minority populations and foreign-born\npersons continue to account for a disproportionate number of TB cases.\nCDC and its partners are committed to eliminating TB in the USA. In\nmany states, education and awareness programs convened by local TB\ncoalitions will take place in commemoration of World TB Day.\nAdditional information about World TB Day and CDC TB-elimination\nactivities is available at <http://www.cdc.gov/nchstp/tb/worldtbday>.\"\nAs seen in South Africa, XDR TB in HIV infected patients can cause\ndeath before the initial cultures are positive, let alone drug\nsensitivity testing. The global community has a long way to go to\neradicate TB, especially in the HIV era. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (06) 20070319.0959\nTuberculosis, XDR, 1991-2003 - Spain 20070302.0738\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (05) 20070228.0717\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (04) 20070220.0638\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (03) 20070209.0504\nTuberculosis, XDR - worldwide 20070205.0456\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (02) 20070128.0375\nTuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions 20070126.0349\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) (02) 20070125.0340\nTuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON) 20070124.0318\n2006\n----\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - Hungary 20061110.3233\nTuberculosis, multiresistant - South Africa (KN) (04): nationwide 20061019.3003\nTuberculosis, multi-drug resistant - South Africa (KN) 20060904.2514\n..................ll/mj/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-11-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-10-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "2927-03-16 00:00:00", "1665-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1176-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "1882-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "1953-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Latvia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sturm AW", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9015", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - Russia (Arkhangelsk) 2006 (02)"}, {"archive_id": "8971", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (06)"}, {"archive_id": "8961", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, bovine - Russia (Arkhangelsk) 2006"}, {"archive_id": "8659", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, bovine - USA (NM)"}, {"archive_id": "8570", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR, 1991-2003 - Spain"}, {"archive_id": "8456", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (05)"}, {"archive_id": "8227", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (04)"}, {"archive_id": "7555", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, students - USA (FL)"}, {"archive_id": "7552", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (03)"}, {"archive_id": "7389", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, bovine - USA (CO)"}, {"archive_id": "7370", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - worldwide"}, {"archive_id": "7061", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa (02)"}, {"archive_id": "7018", "headline": "PRO> Tuberculosis, XDR - South Africa: interventions"}, {"archive_id": "7004", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON)(02)"}, {"archive_id": "6933", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, extensively drug-resistant - Canada (ON)"}, {"archive_id": "4464", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, multiresistant - Hungary"}, {"archive_id": "4204", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, bovine, cervids - USA (MN)(03)"}, {"archive_id": "3722", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, multiresistant - South Africa (KN)(04):nationwide", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3722", "date": "2006-09-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - CANADA (MANITOBA)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Sep 2006\nFrom: Sylvia MacBean <s.macbean@sasktel.net>\nSource: CFIA [edited]\n<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/corpaffr/newcom/2006/20060919e.shtml>\n\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) has\ndeclared livestock in the area around Manitoba's\nRiding Mountain National Park free of bovine\ntuberculosis (TB). The region, referred to as the\nRiding Mountain TB Eradication Area, had been the\nonly part of Canada without TB-free status.\n\nThe new designation is based on a sustained and\naggressive surveillance program that has found no\ncases of bovine TB in livestock in the area since\nApril 2003. The CFIA\ufffds enhanced surveillance\nprogram began in 2002 and has closely monitored\nthe health of all area cattle and farmed bison\nherds through approximately 142 000 TB tests.\n\nArea producers are no longer required to obtain\nCFIA movement permits for cattle and farmed\nbison. This measure effectively contained the\nspread of the disease by ensuring that only\nanimals from herds testing negative for bovine TB\nwere allowed to leave the area.\n\nThe Parks Canada Agency and the Province of\nManitoba have maintained efforts to address the\nbovine TB problem in wild elk and deer in and\naround the park since 2000. These initiatives\nlimited opportunities for potential bovine TB\ntransmission between wildlife and livestock, and\nplayed a significant role in restoring the area\ufffds\nTB-free status as quickly as possible. In\naddition, the strong support and cooperation of\nlivestock industry groups and individual\nproducers in the area enhanced the CFIA\ufffds bovine TB management activities.\n\nBovine TB is a reportable disease under the\nHealth of Animals Act. The CFIA follows a strict\nsurveillance and eradication program to detect\nand respond to bovine TB in cattle, farmed bison\nand farmed cervids. Whenever an infected herd is\nfound, the CFIA institutes measures to contain\nand eradicate the outbreak. All infected animals\nand any exposed susceptible animals are\nimmediately and humanely destroyed, and compensation is paid to the owners.\n\nFor information see the main TB page\n<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/heasan/disemala/tuber/tubere.shtml>\n\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nMedia Relations: (613) 228-6682\nParks Canada Agency\nMedia Relations: (204)848-7240\n\n--\nSylvia MacBean\n<s.macbean@sasktel.net>\n\n[The Riding Mountain National Forest area has\nbeen of high concern to the producers as well as\nto the regulatory agencies of Canada for many\nyears. This is indeed a testament to their\ndiligent efforts at tracking, tracing, and\nclean-up, not easy tasks, especially in such a\nlarge area. We celebrate with the Canadians this successful effort. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Man.) 20040324.0819\n2003\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (04) 20031208.3018\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (03) 20031207.3007\nTuberculosis, bovine, elk - Canada (Manitoba) (02) 20030724.1808\nPRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) 20030206.0317\n..............tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-04-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3615", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine tuberculosis, human - UK (England) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3615", "date": "2006-09-25 00:00:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - CANADA (MANITOBA)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Sep 2006\nFrom: Sylvia MacBean <s.macbean@sasktel.net>\nSource: CFIA [edited]\n<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/corpaffr/newcom/2006/20060919e.shtml>\n\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) has\ndeclared livestock in the area around Manitoba's\nRiding Mountain National Park free of bovine\ntuberculosis (TB). The region, referred to as the\nRiding Mountain TB Eradication Area, had been the\nonly part of Canada without TB-free status.\n\nThe new designation is based on a sustained and\naggressive surveillance program that has found no\ncases of bovine TB in livestock in the area since\nApril 2003. The CFIA\ufffds enhanced surveillance\nprogram began in 2002 and has closely monitored\nthe health of all area cattle and farmed bison\nherds through approximately 142 000 TB tests.\n\nArea producers are no longer required to obtain\nCFIA movement permits for cattle and farmed\nbison. This measure effectively contained the\nspread of the disease by ensuring that only\nanimals from herds testing negative for bovine TB\nwere allowed to leave the area.\n\nThe Parks Canada Agency and the Province of\nManitoba have maintained efforts to address the\nbovine TB problem in wild elk and deer in and\naround the park since 2000. These initiatives\nlimited opportunities for potential bovine TB\ntransmission between wildlife and livestock, and\nplayed a significant role in restoring the area\ufffds\nTB-free status as quickly as possible. In\naddition, the strong support and cooperation of\nlivestock industry groups and individual\nproducers in the area enhanced the CFIA\ufffds bovine TB management activities.\n\nBovine TB is a reportable disease under the\nHealth of Animals Act. The CFIA follows a strict\nsurveillance and eradication program to detect\nand respond to bovine TB in cattle, farmed bison\nand farmed cervids. Whenever an infected herd is\nfound, the CFIA institutes measures to contain\nand eradicate the outbreak. All infected animals\nand any exposed susceptible animals are\nimmediately and humanely destroyed, and compensation is paid to the owners.\n\nFor information see the main TB page\n<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/heasan/disemala/tuber/tubere.shtml>\n\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nMedia Relations: (613) 228-6682\nParks Canada Agency\nMedia Relations: (204)848-7240\n\n--\nSylvia MacBean\n<s.macbean@sasktel.net>\n\n[The Riding Mountain National Forest area has\nbeen of high concern to the producers as well as\nto the regulatory agencies of Canada for many\nyears. This is indeed a testament to their\ndiligent efforts at tracking, tracing, and\nclean-up, not easy tasks, especially in such a\nlarge area. We celebrate with the Canadians this successful effort. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Man.) 20040324.0819\n2003\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (04) 20031208.3018\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (03) 20031207.3007\nTuberculosis, bovine, elk - Canada (Manitoba) (02) 20030724.1808\nPRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) 20030206.0317\n..............tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The region, referred to as the\nRiding Mountain TB Eradication Area, had been the\nonly part of Canada without TB-free status.\n\nThe new designation is based on a sustained and\naggressive surveillance program that has found no\ncases of bovine TB in livestock in the area since\nApril 2003. The CFIA\ufffds enhanced surveillance\nprogram began in 2002 and has closely monitored\nthe health of all area cattle and farmed bison\nherds through approximately 142 000 TB tests.\n\nArea producers are no longer required to obtain\nCFIA movement permits for cattle and farmed\nbison. This measure effectively contained the\nspread of the disease by ensuring that only\nanimals from herds testing negative for bovine TB\nwere allowed to leave the area.\n\nThe Parks Canada Agency and the Province of\nManitoba have maintained efforts to address the\nbovine TB problem in wild elk and deer in and\naround the park since 2000. These initiatives\nlimited opportunities for potential bovine TB\ntransmission between wildlife and livestock, and\nplayed a significant role in restoring the area\ufffds\nTB-free status as quickly as possible. In\naddition, the strong support and cooperation of\nlivestock industry groups and individual\nproducers in the area enhanced the CFIA\ufffds bovine TB management activities.\n\nBovine TB is a reportable disease under the\nHealth of Animals Act. The CFIA follows a strict\nsurveillance and eradication program to detect\nand respond to bovine TB in cattle, farmed bison\nand farmed cervids. Whenever an infected herd is\nfound, the CFIA institutes measures to contain\nand eradicate the outbreak. All infected animals\nand any exposed susceptible animals are\nimmediately and humanely destroyed, and compensation is paid to the owners.\n\nFor information see the main TB page\n<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/heasan/disemala/tuber/tubere.shtml>\n\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nMedia Relations: (613) 228-6682\nParks Canada Agency\nMedia Relations: (204)848-7240\n\n--\nSylvia MacBean\n<s.macbean@sasktel.net>\n\n[The Riding Mountain National Forest area has\nbeen of high concern to the producers as well as\nto the regulatory agencies of Canada for many\nyears. This is indeed a testament to their\ndiligent efforts at tracking, tracing, and\nclean-up, not easy tasks, especially in such a\nlarge area. We celebrate with the Canadians this successful effort. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Man.) 20040324.0819\n2003\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (04) 20031208.3018\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (03) 20031207.3007\nTuberculosis, bovine, elk - Canada (Manitoba) (02) 20030724.1808\nPRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) 20030206.0317\n..............tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The region, referred to as the\nRiding Mountain TB Eradication Area, had been the\nonly part of Canada without TB-free status.\n\nThe new designation is based on a sustained and\naggressive surveillance program that has found no\ncases of bovine TB in livestock in the area since\nApril 2003. The CFIA\ufffds enhanced surveillance\nprogram began in 2002 and has closely monitored\nthe health of all area cattle and farmed bison\nherds through approximately 142 000 TB tests.\n\nArea producers are no longer required to obtain\nCFIA movement permits for cattle and farmed\nbison. These initiatives\nlimited opportunities for potential bovine TB\ntransmission between wildlife and livestock, and\nplayed a significant role in restoring the area\ufffds\nTB-free status as quickly as possible. In\naddition, the strong support and cooperation of\nlivestock industry groups and individual\nproducers in the area enhanced the CFIA\ufffds bovine TB management activities.\n\nBovine TB is a reportable disease under the\nHealth of Animals Act. The CFIA follows a strict\nsurveillance and eradication program to detect\nand respond to bovine TB in cattle, farmed bison\nand farmed cervids. Whenever an infected herd is\nfound, the CFIA institutes measures to contain\nand eradicate the outbreak. All infected animals\nand any exposed susceptible animals are\nimmediately and humanely destroyed, and compensation is paid to the owners.\n\nFor information see the main TB page\n<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/heasan/disemala/tuber/tubere.shtml>\n\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nMedia Relations: (613) 228-6682\nParks Canada Agency\nMedia Relations: (204)848-7240\n\n--\nSylvia MacBean\n<s.macbean@sasktel.net>\n\n[The Riding Mountain National Forest area has\nbeen of high concern to the producers as well as\nto the regulatory agencies of Canada for many\nyears. The region, referred to as the\nRiding Mountain TB Eradication Area, had been the\nonly part of Canada without TB-free status.\n\nThe new designation is based on a sustained and\naggressive surveillance program that has found no\ncases of bovine TB in livestock in the area since\nApril 2003. The CFIA\ufffds enhanced surveillance\nprogram began in 2002 and has closely monitored\nthe health of all area cattle and farmed bison\nherds through approximately 142 000 TB tests.\n\nArea producers are no longer required to obtain\nCFIA movement permits for cattle and farmed\nbison. This measure effectively contained the\nspread of the disease by ensuring that only\nanimals from herds testing negative for bovine TB\nwere allowed to leave the area.\n\nThe Parks Canada Agency and the Province of\nManitoba have maintained efforts to address the\nbovine TB problem in wild elk and deer in and\naround the park since 2000. These initiatives\nlimited opportunities for potential bovine TB\ntransmission between wildlife and livestock, and\nplayed a significant role in restoring the area\ufffds\nTB-free status as quickly as possible. In\naddition, the strong support and cooperation of\nlivestock industry groups and individual\nproducers in the area enhanced the CFIA\ufffds bovine TB management activities.\n\nBovine TB is a reportable disease under the\nHealth of Animals Act. The CFIA follows a strict\nsurveillance and eradication program to detect\nand respond to bovine TB in cattle, farmed bison\nand farmed cervids. Whenever an infected herd is\nfound, the CFIA institutes measures to contain\nand eradicate the outbreak. All infected animals\nand any exposed susceptible animals are\nimmediately and humanely destroyed, and compensation is paid to the owners.\n\nFor information see the main TB page\n<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/heasan/disemala/tuber/tubere.shtml>\n\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nMedia Relations: (613) 228-6682\nParks Canada Agency\nMedia Relations: (204)848-7240\n\n--\nSylvia MacBean\n<s.macbean@sasktel.net>\n\n[The Riding Mountain National Forest area has\nbeen of high concern to the producers as well as\nto the regulatory agencies of Canada for many\nyears. This is indeed a testament to their\ndiligent efforts at tracking, tracing, and\nclean-up, not easy tasks, especially in such a\nlarge area. We celebrate with the Canadians this successful effort. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Man.) 20040324.0819\n2003\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (04) 20031208.3018\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (03) 20031207.3007\nTuberculosis, bovine, elk - Canada (Manitoba) (02) 20030724.1808\nPRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) 20030206.0317\n..............tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-04-16 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3392", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, bovine - Canada (MB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3392", "date": "2006-09-25 00:00:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE - CANADA (MANITOBA)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Sep 2006\nFrom: Sylvia MacBean <s.macbean@sasktel.net>\nSource: CFIA [edited]\n<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/corpaffr/newcom/2006/20060919e.shtml>\n\n\nThe Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) has\ndeclared livestock in the area around Manitoba's\nRiding Mountain National Park free of bovine\ntuberculosis (TB). The region, referred to as the\nRiding Mountain TB Eradication Area, had been the\nonly part of Canada without TB-free status.\n\nThe new designation is based on a sustained and\naggressive surveillance program that has found no\ncases of bovine TB in livestock in the area since\nApril 2003. The CFIA\ufffds enhanced surveillance\nprogram began in 2002 and has closely monitored\nthe health of all area cattle and farmed bison\nherds through approximately 142 000 TB tests.\n\nArea producers are no longer required to obtain\nCFIA movement permits for cattle and farmed\nbison. This measure effectively contained the\nspread of the disease by ensuring that only\nanimals from herds testing negative for bovine TB\nwere allowed to leave the area.\n\nThe Parks Canada Agency and the Province of\nManitoba have maintained efforts to address the\nbovine TB problem in wild elk and deer in and\naround the park since 2000. These initiatives\nlimited opportunities for potential bovine TB\ntransmission between wildlife and livestock, and\nplayed a significant role in restoring the area\ufffds\nTB-free status as quickly as possible. In\naddition, the strong support and cooperation of\nlivestock industry groups and individual\nproducers in the area enhanced the CFIA\ufffds bovine TB management activities.\n\nBovine TB is a reportable disease under the\nHealth of Animals Act. The CFIA follows a strict\nsurveillance and eradication program to detect\nand respond to bovine TB in cattle, farmed bison\nand farmed cervids. Whenever an infected herd is\nfound, the CFIA institutes measures to contain\nand eradicate the outbreak. All infected animals\nand any exposed susceptible animals are\nimmediately and humanely destroyed, and compensation is paid to the owners.\n\nFor information see the main TB page\n<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/heasan/disemala/tuber/tubere.shtml>\n\nCanadian Food Inspection Agency\nMedia Relations: (613) 228-6682\nParks Canada Agency\nMedia Relations: (204)848-7240\n\n--\nSylvia MacBean\n<s.macbean@sasktel.net>\n\n[The Riding Mountain National Forest area has\nbeen of high concern to the producers as well as\nto the regulatory agencies of Canada for many\nyears. This is indeed a testament to their\ndiligent efforts at tracking, tracing, and\nclean-up, not easy tasks, especially in such a\nlarge area. We celebrate with the Canadians this successful effort. - Mod.TG]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Man.) 20040324.0819\n2003\n----\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (04) 20031208.3018\nTuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) (03) 20031207.3007\nTuberculosis, bovine, elk - Canada (Manitoba) (02) 20030724.1808\nPRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine - Canada (Manitoba) 20030206.0317\n..............tg/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (Michigan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198721", "date": "2000-03-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, MULTIDRUG-RESISTANT - CENTRAL ASIA\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, multidrug-resistance spreading 20000326194537\nDate: Tue, 28 Mar 2000 23:23:11 -0500\nFrom: Flewelling, Ty <FLEWELLING@tashkentb.us-state.gov>\n\nAs you so appropriately noted, the spread of MDR TB in the world is quite\nworrisome. You noted that you do not routinely post info on the rates of TB\nor it's spread. I would like to request that you reconsider this position.\nMDR TB is growing at an increasingly alarming rate. Monitoring the rate\nand spread of this disease could help project trends in the future. Like\nthe rest of the former Soviet Union, Uzbekistan also has a growing TB\nproblem. In the Region of Karakalpakistan, (western Uzbekistan) MDR TB is\nthe primary form of the disease affecting over 1 000 000 people.\nThe current environmental disaster affecting the Aral sea region is also\ncontributing to the spread on MDR TB in Central Asia. A recent study by MSF\nin Karakalpakistan randomly surveyed 881 people over the age of 18 years\nasked the question of whether they would consider moving. 75% of the\nrespondents related that they have considered moving from the region. The\nmigration of ill individuals throughout Central Asia is a major concern for\nhealth care providers in this part of the world. I believe that the\nmovement of other ill populations from one area to another will also affect\nother populations and providers in the future.\n--\nTy Flewelling, PA-C\nMedical Attache\nUS Embassy - Tashkent\ne-mail: FLEWELLING@tashkentb.us-state.gov\n[We bow to the man on the spot in temporarily lifting our embargo on\nMDR-TB. We would hope other Medical Attaches would consider sending us\nemerging disease information from their regions. A recent study by MSF\nin Karakalpakistan randomly surveyed 881 people over the age of 18 years\nasked the question of whether they would consider moving. 75% of the\nrespondents related that they have considered moving from the region. The\nmigration of ill individuals throughout Central Asia is a major concern for\nhealth care providers in this part of the world. I believe that the\nmovement of other ill populations from one area to another will also affect\nother populations and providers in the future.\n--\nTy Flewelling, PA-C\nMedical Attache\nUS Embassy - Tashkent\ne-mail: FLEWELLING@tashkentb.us-state.gov\n[We bow to the man on the spot in temporarily lifting our embargo on\nMDR-TB. We would hope other Medical Attaches would consider sending us\nemerging disease information from their regions. Reports from all sources\nare welcome. - Mod.JW\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You noted that you do not routinely post info on the rates of TB\nor it's spread. I would like to request that you reconsider this position.\nMDR TB is growing at an increasingly alarming rate. Monitoring the rate\nand spread of this disease could help project trends in the future. Like\nthe rest of the former Soviet Union, Uzbekistan also has a growing TB\nproblem. In the Region of Karakalpakistan, (western Uzbekistan) MDR TB is\nthe primary form of the disease affecting over 1 000 000 people.\nThe current environmental disaster affecting the Aral sea region is also\ncontributing to the spread on MDR TB in Central Asia. A recent study by MSF\nin Karakalpakistan randomly surveyed 881 people over the age of 18 years\nasked the question of whether they would consider moving. 75% of the\nrespondents related that they have considered moving from the region. There\nwere 31 reactors based on compartive cervical reactions. The North Dakota\nAgriculture Department (ND Ag Dept) is waiting on confirmation by culture\nand PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). These cattle also had positive\nhistopatological lesions. There are some families that reportedly drank\nraw milk and are being tested. The ND Ag Dept has established a 5mile radius\naround the dairy where they will test cattle at dairies and trace animals\nthat may have been sold or relocated.\n--\nDA Meier\n<meierda@hotmail.com>\n[_Mycobacterium bovis_ can cause progressive disease in most warm-blooded\nvertebrates, including man. TB can spread to man via ingestion, inhalation\nand occupational exposure. It can be spread through milk. Furthermore, with\na number of reactors in a dairy it seems possible that other animals may\nhave had the disease and been sold or traded, consequently putting other\ndairies at risk of the disease. In turn, this may put other people at risk\nfrom occupational exposure and consumption of unpasteurized milk - Mod.TG]\n...................................tg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The ND Ag Dept has established a 5mile radius\naround the dairy where they will test cattle at dairies and trace animals\nthat may have been sold or relocated.\n--\nDA Meier\n<meierda@hotmail.com>\n[_Mycobacterium bovis_ can cause progressive disease in most warm-blooded\nvertebrates, including man. TB can spread to man via ingestion, inhalation\nand occupational exposure. It can be spread through milk. Furthermore, with\na number of reactors in a dairy it seems possible that other animals may\nhave had the disease and been sold or traded, consequently putting other\ndairies at risk of the disease. In turn, this may put other people at risk\nfrom occupational exposure and consumption of unpasteurized milk - Mod.TG]\n...................................tg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. There\nwere 31 reactors based on compartive cervical reactions. The North Dakota\nAgriculture Department (ND Ag Dept) is waiting on confirmation by culture\nand PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). These cattle also had positive\nhistopatological lesions. There are some families that reportedly drank\nraw milk and are being tested. The ND Ag Dept has established a 5mile radius\naround the dairy where they will test cattle at dairies and trace animals\nthat may have been sold or relocated.\n--\nDA Meier\n<meierda@hotmail.com>\n[_Mycobacterium bovis_ can cause progressive disease in most warm-blooded\nvertebrates, including man. TB can spread to man via ingestion, inhalation\nand occupational exposure. It can be spread through milk. Furthermore, with\na number of reactors in a dairy it seems possible that other animals may\nhave had the disease and been sold or traded, consequently putting other\ndairies at risk of the disease. In turn, this may put other people at risk\nfrom occupational exposure and consumption of unpasteurized milk - Mod.TG]\n...................................tg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. There\nwere 31 reactors based on compartive cervical reactions. The North Dakota\nAgriculture Department (ND Ag Dept) is waiting on confirmation by culture\nand PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). These cattle also had positive\nhistopatological lesions. There are some families that reportedly drank\nraw milk and are being tested. The ND Ag Dept has established a 5mile radius\naround the dairy where they will test cattle at dairies and trace animals\nthat may have been sold or relocated.\n--\nDA Meier\n<meierda@hotmail.com>\n[_Mycobacterium bovis_ can cause progressive disease in most warm-blooded\nvertebrates, including man. TB can spread to man via ingestion, inhalation\nand occupational exposure. It can be spread through milk. Furthermore, with\na number of reactors in a dairy it seems possible that other animals may\nhave had the disease and been sold or traded, consequently putting other\ndairies at risk of the disease. In turn, this may put other people at risk\nfrom occupational exposure and consumption of unpasteurized milk - Mod.TG]\n...................................tg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Morton County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194915", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tuberculosis, bovine - USA (Michigan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194915", "date": "1998-10-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE, WILDLIFE - SOUTH AFRICA\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/promed>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, bovine, lions - South Africa 980721211750\nTuberculosis, bovine, lions - South Africa (02) 980728184646\n\nSource: Electronic Mail&Guardian, Johannesburg, by Eddie Koch,\n1 Sep 1998, edited\nAt a recent symposium, comprising some of the country's top ecologists and\nveterinarians, organised jointly by the South African National Parks, the\nMpumalanga Directorate of Veterinary Services and the Mpumalanga Parks\nBoard. Scientists from the Kruger Park noted that although many buffalo die\nof the disease it was not yet killing off massive numbers of these animals.\nBut other species, especially lion, appear to be suffering more heavily in\nthe short term. A number of recent cases have been established of lions\ndying from TB in both Kruger and Hluhluwe whereas it is possible buffalo can\ncarry the disease with them for life.\nIt is possible that lions are being badly affected as in Kruger many\nof the [big cats have FIV [feline immunodeficiency virus while\nthose in Hluhluwe have compromised immune systems because of heavy\ninbreeding.\nDewalt Keet, senior veterinarian in the Kruger Park's Directorate of Animal\nHealth at Skukuza, says the park management will spend the next 12 months\nconducting intensive research to establish more precisely what impact the\ndisease is having on the mortality of various species in the park. Kruger\nauthorities will then consider shooting out the most heavily infected herds.\nThe Mpumalanga Parks Board is preparing to either eliminate the entire\nherd of 350 to 400 buffalo in its Mthethomusha Game Reserve that abuts on\nthe south-western border of Kruger or to shoot the most heavily infected herds.\nBoth the Kruger and Mpumalanga park authorities have set up sterilised bomas\n[corrals where they will place pregnant buffalo cows in quarantine-like\nconditions so that they can breed a reservoir of TB-free buffalo to\nrepopulate areas where heavy culling might have to occur. The consequences\nof the epidemic are potentially critical for conservation and the protection\nof biodiversity in South Africa. Other game reserves are indicating a\nreluctance to purchase wild-caught game from Kruger and Hluhluwe, fearing\nthey may be contaminated. This is likely to cause revenue problems for\nreserves that rely on sale of wild game to bolster their conservation work.\nPlans to create large transfrontier conservation areas, popularly known as\npeace parks, between South Africa, Mozambique and Zimbabwe are in jeopardy\nas neighbouring states are reluctant to drop their game fences and run the\nrisk of their animals becoming infected. \"Practically, tuberculosis may move\nacross the borders of infected premises in either direction, and infected\nanimals on either side may thus remain a persistent source of infection that\nwill serve to maintain the infection and serve as sources of re-infection,\"\nsays Kriek. There are also fears that, although cattle from ranches abutting\nKruger's southern borders first introduced the disease to buffalo, now there\nis a reverse danger of buffalo and other smaller species re-infecting\ndomestic livestock.\nMore serious is the fact that humans can contract TB from the bovine strain.\nResidents of villages living on the borders of the parks are particularly at\nrisk because many of them poach illegally for subsistence purposes and can\ncontract the disease from undercooked meat of infected animals. By extension\nit was even possible that visitors to game parks who eat contaminated meat\nmight contract this form of tuberculosis.\nScientists at the symposium acknowledged that drastic action was now\nrequired to contain the epidemic of the late 1990s but admitted that they\nwere hamstrung by a lack of knowledge about the disease and how to cure it\nin animals, especially as there is no effective vaccine for animals. In\naddition, there is no reliable ante-mortem diagnostic way of testing live\nanimals for possible infection except in the case of buffaloes. This\nprevents veterinarians in the park from establishing infection rates in most\nspecies except when carcasses are obtained for post-mortems.\nA serious consequence is that most animals for trans-location cannot be\ntested, raising the prospect of spreading the disease from one reserve to\nanother.\nPrevalence in Kuger's herds range from\nfive percent to 90 percent with herds south of the Sabi River being most\nheavily affected. The prevalence rate declines northwards and veterinarians\nin the park believe the disease has reached to somewhere between the\nOlifants and Luvuvhu Rivers. There is also concern that smaller species\nmight contract, host, and spread the TB bacteria.\nScientific research conducted at the Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute,\nprimarily by Anita Michel, indicates that there are 17 strain of bovine\ntuberculosis in the Kruger Park. Tests indicate that the bacteria can\nsurvive in the environment in faeces, contaminated flesh, or even in sputum\nleft on leaves and other debris for up to eight weeks in winter and four\nweeks in summer.\n..............................mhj/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Zimbabwe", "country": "Zimbabwe"}, {"location": "Kruger", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the Kruger Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Hluhluwe", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Mpumalanga", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the Kruger Park 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuger", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194894", "headline": "PRO> Tuberculosis advisory, air travel (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194894", "date": "1998-10-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE, WILDLIFE - SOUTH AFRICA\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/promed>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, bovine, lions - South Africa 980721211750\nTuberculosis, bovine, lions - South Africa (02) 980728184646\n\nSource: Electronic Mail&Guardian, Johannesburg, by Eddie Koch,\n1 Sep 1998, edited\nAt a recent symposium, comprising some of the country's top ecologists and\nveterinarians, organised jointly by the South African National Parks, the\nMpumalanga Directorate of Veterinary Services and the Mpumalanga Parks\nBoard. By extension\nit was even possible that visitors to game parks who eat contaminated meat\nmight contract this form of tuberculosis.\nScientists at the symposium acknowledged that drastic action was now\nrequired to contain the epidemic of the late 1990s but admitted that they\nwere hamstrung by a lack of knowledge about the disease and how to cure it\nin animals, especially as there is no effective vaccine for animals. In\naddition, there is no reliable ante-mortem diagnostic way of testing live\nanimals for possible infection except in the case of buffaloes. This\nprevents veterinarians in the park from establishing infection rates in most\nspecies except when carcasses are obtained for post-mortems.\nA serious consequence is that most animals for trans-location cannot be\ntested, raising the prospect of spreading the disease from one reserve to\nanother.\nPrevalence in Kuger's herds range from\nfive percent to 90 percent with herds south of the Sabi River being most\nheavily affected. The prevalence rate declines northwards and veterinarians\nin the park believe the disease has reached to somewhere between the\nOlifants and Luvuvhu Rivers. There is also concern that smaller species\nmight contract, host, and spread the TB bacteria.\nScientific research conducted at the Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute,\nprimarily by Anita Michel, indicates that there are 17 strain of bovine\ntuberculosis in the Kruger Park. Tests indicate that the bacteria can\nsurvive in the environment in faeces, contaminated flesh, or even in sputum\nleft on leaves and other debris for up to eight weeks in winter and four\nweeks in summer.\n..............................mhj/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
