For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Zimbabwe", "country": "Zimbabwe"}, {"location": "Kruger", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the Kruger Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Hluhluwe", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Mpumalanga", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the Kruger Park 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuger", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194498", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine, wildlife - South Africa (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194498", "date": "1998-10-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE, WILDLIFE - SOUTH AFRICA\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/promed>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, bovine, lions - South Africa 980721211750\nTuberculosis, bovine, lions - South Africa (02) 980728184646\n\nSource: Electronic Mail&Guardian, Johannesburg, by Eddie Koch,\n1 Sep 1998, edited\nAt a recent symposium, comprising some of the country's top ecologists and\nveterinarians, organised jointly by the South African National Parks, the\nMpumalanga Directorate of Veterinary Services and the Mpumalanga Parks\nBoard. Scientists from the Kruger Park noted that although many buffalo die\nof the disease it was not yet killing off massive numbers of these animals.\nBut other species, especially lion, appear to be suffering more heavily in\nthe short term. A number of recent cases have been established of lions\ndying from TB in both Kruger and Hluhluwe whereas it is possible buffalo can\ncarry the disease with them for life.\nIt is possible that lions are being badly affected as in Kruger many\nof the [big cats have FIV [feline immunodeficiency virus while\nthose in Hluhluwe have compromised immune systems because of heavy\ninbreeding.\nDewalt Keet, senior veterinarian in the Kruger Park's Directorate of Animal\nHealth at Skukuza, says the park management will spend the next 12 months\nconducting intensive research to establish more precisely what impact the\ndisease is having on the mortality of various species in the park. Kruger\nauthorities will then consider shooting out the most heavily infected herds.\nThe Mpumalanga Parks Board is preparing to either eliminate the entire\nherd of 350 to 400 buffalo in its Mthethomusha Game Reserve that abuts on\nthe south-western border of Kruger or to shoot the most heavily infected herds.\nBoth the Kruger and Mpumalanga park authorities have set up sterilised bomas\n[corrals where they will place pregnant buffalo cows in quarantine-like\nconditions so that they can breed a reservoir of TB-free buffalo to\nrepopulate areas where heavy culling might have to occur. The consequences\nof the epidemic are potentially critical for conservation and the protection\nof biodiversity in South Africa. Other game reserves are indicating a\nreluctance to purchase wild-caught game from Kruger and Hluhluwe, fearing\nthey may be contaminated. This is likely to cause revenue problems for\nreserves that rely on sale of wild game to bolster their conservation work.\nPlans to create large transfrontier conservation areas, popularly known as\npeace parks, between South Africa, Mozambique and Zimbabwe are in jeopardy\nas neighbouring states are reluctant to drop their game fences and run the\nrisk of their animals becoming infected. \"Practically, tuberculosis may move\nacross the borders of infected premises in either direction, and infected\nanimals on either side may thus remain a persistent source of infection that\nwill serve to maintain the infection and serve as sources of re-infection,\"\nsays Kriek. There are also fears that, although cattle from ranches abutting\nKruger's southern borders first introduced the disease to buffalo, now there\nis a reverse danger of buffalo and other smaller species re-infecting\ndomestic livestock.\nMore serious is the fact that humans can contract TB from the bovine strain.\nResidents of villages living on the borders of the parks are particularly at\nrisk because many of them poach illegally for subsistence purposes and can\ncontract the disease from undercooked meat of infected animals. By extension\nit was even possible that visitors to game parks who eat contaminated meat\nmight contract this form of tuberculosis.\nScientists at the symposium acknowledged that drastic action was now\nrequired to contain the epidemic of the late 1990s but admitted that they\nwere hamstrung by a lack of knowledge about the disease and how to cure it\nin animals, especially as there is no effective vaccine for animals. In\naddition, there is no reliable ante-mortem diagnostic way of testing live\nanimals for possible infection except in the case of buffaloes. This\nprevents veterinarians in the park from establishing infection rates in most\nspecies except when carcasses are obtained for post-mortems.\nA serious consequence is that most animals for trans-location cannot be\ntested, raising the prospect of spreading the disease from one reserve to\nanother.\nPrevalence in Kuger's herds range from\nfive percent to 90 percent with herds south of the Sabi River being most\nheavily affected. The prevalence rate declines northwards and veterinarians\nin the park believe the disease has reached to somewhere between the\nOlifants and Luvuvhu Rivers. There is also concern that smaller species\nmight contract, host, and spread the TB bacteria.\nScientific research conducted at the Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute,\nprimarily by Anita Michel, indicates that there are 17 strain of bovine\ntuberculosis in the Kruger Park. Tests indicate that the bacteria can\nsurvive in the environment in faeces, contaminated flesh, or even in sputum\nleft on leaves and other debris for up to eight weeks in winter and four\nweeks in summer.\n..............................mhj/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Zimbabwe", "country": "Zimbabwe"}, {"location": "Kruger", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the Kruger Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Hluhluwe", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Mpumalanga", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the Kruger Park 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuger", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2194489", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis, bovine, wildlife - South Africa (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194489", "date": "1998-10-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, BOVINE, WILDLIFE - SOUTH AFRICA\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/promed>\nSee Also\nTuberculosis, bovine, lions - South Africa 980721211750\nTuberculosis, bovine, lions - South Africa (02) 980728184646\n\nSource: Electronic Mail&Guardian, Johannesburg, by Eddie Koch,\n1 Sep 1998, edited\nAt a recent symposium, comprising some of the country's top ecologists and\nveterinarians, organised jointly by the South African National Parks, the\nMpumalanga Directorate of Veterinary Services and the Mpumalanga Parks\nBoard. The consequences\nof the epidemic are potentially critical for conservation and the protection\nof biodiversity in South Africa. By extension\nit was even possible that visitors to game parks who eat contaminated meat\nmight contract this form of tuberculosis.\nScientists at the symposium acknowledged that drastic action was now\nrequired to contain the epidemic of the late 1990s but admitted that they\nwere hamstrung by a lack of knowledge about the disease and how to cure it\nin animals, especially as there is no effective vaccine for animals. In\naddition, there is no reliable ante-mortem diagnostic way of testing live\nanimals for possible infection except in the case of buffaloes. This\nprevents veterinarians in the park from establishing infection rates in most\nspecies except when carcasses are obtained for post-mortems.\nA serious consequence is that most animals for trans-location cannot be\ntested, raising the prospect of spreading the disease from one reserve to\nanother.\nPrevalence in Kuger's herds range from\nfive percent to 90 percent with herds south of the Sabi River being most\nheavily affected. The prevalence rate declines northwards and veterinarians\nin the park believe the disease has reached to somewhere between the\nOlifants and Luvuvhu Rivers. There is also concern that smaller species\nmight contract, host, and spread the TB bacteria.\nScientific research conducted at the Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute,\nprimarily by Anita Michel, indicates that there are 17 strain of bovine\ntuberculosis in the Kruger Park. Tests indicate that the bacteria can\nsurvive in the environment in faeces, contaminated flesh, or even in sputum\nleft on leaves and other debris for up to eight weeks in winter and four\nweeks in summer.\n..............................mhj/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Scientists from the Kruger Park noted that although many buffalo die\nof the disease it was not yet killing off massive numbers of these animals.\nBut other species, especially lion, appear to be suffering more heavily in\nthe short term. A number of recent cases have been established of lions\ndying from TB in both Kruger and Hluhluwe whereas it is possible buffalo can\ncarry the disease with them for life.\nIt is possible that lions are being badly affected as in Kruger many\nof the [big cats have FIV [feline immunodeficiency virus while\nthose in Hluhluwe have compromised immune systems because of heavy\ninbreeding.\nDewalt Keet, senior veterinarian in the Kruger Park's Directorate of Animal\nHealth at Skukuza, says the park management will spend the next 12 months\nconducting intensive research to establish more precisely what impact the\ndisease is having on the mortality of various species in the park. Kruger\nauthorities will then consider shooting out the most heavily infected herds.\nThe Mpumalanga Parks Board is preparing to either eliminate the entire\nherd of 350 to 400 buffalo in its Mthethomusha Game Reserve that abuts on\nthe south-western border of Kruger or to shoot the most heavily infected herds.\nBoth the Kruger and Mpumalanga park authorities have set up sterilised bomas\n[corrals where they will place pregnant buffalo cows in quarantine-like\nconditions so that they can breed a reservoir of TB-free buffalo to\nrepopulate areas where heavy culling might have to occur. The consequences\nof the epidemic are potentially critical for conservation and the protection\nof biodiversity in South Africa. Other game reserves are indicating a\nreluctance to purchase wild-caught game from Kruger and Hluhluwe, fearing\nthey may be contaminated. This is likely to cause revenue problems for\nreserves that rely on sale of wild game to bolster their conservation work.\nPlans to create large transfrontier conservation areas, popularly known as\npeace parks, between South Africa, Mozambique and Zimbabwe are in jeopardy\nas neighbouring states are reluctant to drop their game fences and run the\nrisk of their animals becoming infected. \"Practically, tuberculosis may move\nacross the borders of infected premises in either direction, and infected\nanimals on either side may thus remain a persistent source of infection that\nwill serve to maintain the infection and serve as sources of re-infection,\"\nsays Kriek. There are also fears that, although cattle from ranches abutting\nKruger's southern borders first introduced the disease to buffalo, now there\nis a reverse danger of buffalo and other smaller species re-infecting\ndomestic livestock.\nMore serious is the fact that humans can contract TB from the bovine strain.\nResidents of villages living on the borders of the parks are particularly at\nrisk because many of them poach illegally for subsistence purposes and can\ncontract the disease from undercooked meat of infected animals. By extension\nit was even possible that visitors to game parks who eat contaminated meat\nmight contract this form of tuberculosis.\nScientists at the symposium acknowledged that drastic action was now\nrequired to contain the epidemic of the late 1990s but admitted that they\nwere hamstrung by a lack of knowledge about the disease and how to cure it\nin animals, especially as there is no effective vaccine for animals. In\naddition, there is no reliable ante-mortem diagnostic way of testing live\nanimals for possible infection except in the case of buffaloes. This\nprevents veterinarians in the park from establishing infection rates in most\nspecies except when carcasses are obtained for post-mortems.\nA serious consequence is that most animals for trans-location cannot be\ntested, raising the prospect of spreading the disease from one reserve to\nanother.\nPrevalence in Kuger's herds range from\nfive percent to 90 percent with herds south of the Sabi River being most\nheavily affected. The prevalence rate declines northwards and veterinarians\nin the park believe the disease has reached to somewhere between the\nOlifants and Luvuvhu Rivers. There is also concern that smaller species\nmight contract, host, and spread the TB bacteria.\nScientific research conducted at the Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute,\nprimarily by Anita Michel, indicates that there are 17 strain of bovine\ntuberculosis in the Kruger Park. Tests indicate that the bacteria can\nsurvive in the environment in faeces, contaminated flesh, or even in sputum\nleft on leaves and other debris for up to eight weeks in winter and four\nweeks in summer.\n..............................mhj/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: ANIMALNET\n\nLIVESTOCK OFFICIALS TRACKING DOWN POSSIBLE DISEASE\nApr. 9/98\nManitoba Co-operator\nNorth Dakota government release\nBismarck, North Dakota State and federal officials have notified two North\nDakota livestock operations that their cattle may have been exposed to a\nserious disease threat. Dr. Larry Schuler, North Dakota state veterinarian,\nsaid seven heifers formerly held in North Dakota came from a Rossburn,\nManitoba, herd that was diagnosed with bovine tuberculosis. The Manitoba\nherd was recently destroyed. \"Canadian officials have informed us that\nseven cattle from that herd were sold earlier as part of a group of 82 head\nto North Dakota buyers last May,\" Schuler said. \"These buyers' ranches are\nnow quarantined and the operators are co-operating with us to determine if\nother animals may have been exposed.\" It is not yet known if any of the\nseven heifers from the Manitoba herd were in fact infected with TB, but\nSchuler said that when the Rossburn herd was destroyed, more than 50 per\ncent of the animals were found to have lung lesions caused by TB.\nThe TB outbreak was initially detected at a Long Prairie, Manitoba,\nslaughter plant when lung lesions were spotted on carcasses, which were\nthen traced back to Rossburn. Dr. Anne Scully, Bottineau, a veterinarian\nwith the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService, has completed an epidemiological study of the two North Dakota\nranches and has determined that no livestock in the surrounding area have\nbeen exposed.\nThe two North Dakota buyers later sold the 82 head of cattle, including the\nseven heifers from the affected herd, at a South Dakota auction market on\nSeptember 23, 1997. The auction house is currently reviewing its records to\nlocate the buyers and South Dakota officials have been informed of the\nsituation. Schuler said it is important to trace all contacts that the\nseven heifers may have had with other animals to ensure the disease has not\nentered the state. \"North Dakota has enjoyed a tuberculosis-free status\nsince the early 1980s,\" he said. \"We are working to maintain this status\nwhich saves our livestock producers thousands of dollars annually in\ntesting costs and paperwork.\"\nBovine tuberculosis is a respiratory disease, causing lung lesions, wasting\nand eventual death of infected animals. Schuler said the disease poses a\nvery minimal risk to humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-09-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "North Dakota State", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2193282", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tuberculosis in zoos & circuses: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2193282", "date": "1998-04-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "BOVINE TUBERCULOSIS, IMPORTED - USA EX CANADA\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Wed, 15 Apr 1998 05:08:35 -0400\nFrom: Robert A. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: ANIMALNET\n\nLIVESTOCK OFFICIALS TRACKING DOWN POSSIBLE DISEASE\nApr. 9/98\nManitoba Co-operator\nNorth Dakota government release\nBismarck, North Dakota State and federal officials have notified two North\nDakota livestock operations that their cattle may have been exposed to a\nserious disease threat. Dr. Larry Schuler, North Dakota state veterinarian,\nsaid seven heifers formerly held in North Dakota came from a Rossburn,\nManitoba, herd that was diagnosed with bovine tuberculosis. The Manitoba\nherd was recently destroyed. \"Canadian officials have informed us that\nseven cattle from that herd were sold earlier as part of a group of 82 head\nto North Dakota buyers last May,\" Schuler said. \"These buyers' ranches are\nnow quarantined and the operators are co-operating with us to determine if\nother animals may have been exposed.\" It is not yet known if any of the\nseven heifers from the Manitoba herd were in fact infected with TB, but\nSchuler said that when the Rossburn herd was destroyed, more than 50 per\ncent of the animals were found to have lung lesions caused by TB.\nThe TB outbreak was initially detected at a Long Prairie, Manitoba,\nslaughter plant when lung lesions were spotted on carcasses, which were\nthen traced back to Rossburn. Dr. Anne Scully, Bottineau, a veterinarian\nwith the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService, has completed an epidemiological study of the two North Dakota\nranches and has determined that no livestock in the surrounding area have\nbeen exposed.\nThe two North Dakota buyers later sold the 82 head of cattle, including the\nseven heifers from the affected herd, at a South Dakota auction market on\nSeptember 23, 1997. The auction house is currently reviewing its records to\nlocate the buyers and South Dakota officials have been informed of the\nsituation. Schuler said it is important to trace all contacts that the\nseven heifers may have had with other animals to ensure the disease has not\nentered the state. \"North Dakota has enjoyed a tuberculosis-free status\nsince the early 1980s,\" he said. \"We are working to maintain this status\nwhich saves our livestock producers thousands of dollars annually in\ntesting costs and paperwork.\"\nBovine tuberculosis is a respiratory disease, causing lung lesions, wasting\nand eventual death of infected animals. Schuler said the disease poses a\nvery minimal risk to humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: ANIMALNET\n\nLIVESTOCK OFFICIALS TRACKING DOWN POSSIBLE DISEASE\nApr. 9/98\nManitoba Co-operator\nNorth Dakota government release\nBismarck, North Dakota State and federal officials have notified two North\nDakota livestock operations that their cattle may have been exposed to a\nserious disease threat. Dr. Larry Schuler, North Dakota state veterinarian,\nsaid seven heifers formerly held in North Dakota came from a Rossburn,\nManitoba, herd that was diagnosed with bovine tuberculosis. The Manitoba\nherd was recently destroyed. \"Canadian officials have informed us that\nseven cattle from that herd were sold earlier as part of a group of 82 head\nto North Dakota buyers last May,\" Schuler said. \"These buyers' ranches are\nnow quarantined and the operators are co-operating with us to determine if\nother animals may have been exposed.\" It is not yet known if any of the\nseven heifers from the Manitoba herd were in fact infected with TB, but\nSchuler said that when the Rossburn herd was destroyed, more than 50 per\ncent of the animals were found to have lung lesions caused by TB.\nThe TB outbreak was initially detected at a Long Prairie, Manitoba,\nslaughter plant when lung lesions were spotted on carcasses, which were\nthen traced back to Rossburn. Dr. Anne Scully, Bottineau, a veterinarian\nwith the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService, has completed an epidemiological study of the two North Dakota\nranches and has determined that no livestock in the surrounding area have\nbeen exposed.\nThe two North Dakota buyers later sold the 82 head of cattle, including the\nseven heifers from the affected herd, at a South Dakota auction market on\nSeptember 23, 1997. The auction house is currently reviewing its records to\nlocate the buyers and South Dakota officials have been informed of the\nsituation. Schuler said it is important to trace all contacts that the\nseven heifers may have had with other animals to ensure the disease has not\nentered the state. \"North Dakota has enjoyed a tuberculosis-free status\nsince the early 1980s,\" he said. \"We are working to maintain this status\nwhich saves our livestock producers thousands of dollars annually in\ntesting costs and paperwork.\"\nBovine tuberculosis is a respiratory disease, causing lung lesions, wasting\nand eventual death of infected animals. Schuler said the disease poses a\nvery minimal risk to humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: ANIMALNET\n\nLIVESTOCK OFFICIALS TRACKING DOWN POSSIBLE DISEASE\nApr. 9/98\nManitoba Co-operator\nNorth Dakota government release\nBismarck, North Dakota State and federal officials have notified two North\nDakota livestock operations that their cattle may have been exposed to a\nserious disease threat. Dr. Larry Schuler, North Dakota state veterinarian,\nsaid seven heifers formerly held in North Dakota came from a Rossburn,\nManitoba, herd that was diagnosed with bovine tuberculosis. The Manitoba\nherd was recently destroyed. \"Canadian officials have informed us that\nseven cattle from that herd were sold earlier as part of a group of 82 head\nto North Dakota buyers last May,\" Schuler said. \"These buyers' ranches are\nnow quarantined and the operators are co-operating with us to determine if\nother animals may have been exposed.\" It is not yet known if any of the\nseven heifers from the Manitoba herd were in fact infected with TB, but\nSchuler said that when the Rossburn herd was destroyed, more than 50 per\ncent of the animals were found to have lung lesions caused by TB.\nThe TB outbreak was initially detected at a Long Prairie, Manitoba,\nslaughter plant when lung lesions were spotted on carcasses, which were\nthen traced back to Rossburn. Dr. Anne Scully, Bottineau, a veterinarian\nwith the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService, has completed an epidemiological study of the two North Dakota\nranches and has determined that no livestock in the surrounding area have\nbeen exposed.\nThe two North Dakota buyers later sold the 82 head of cattle, including the\nseven heifers from the affected herd, at a South Dakota auction market on\nSeptember 23, 1997. The auction house is currently reviewing its records to\nlocate the buyers and South Dakota officials have been informed of the\nsituation. Schuler said it is important to trace all contacts that the\nseven heifers may have had with other animals to ensure the disease has not\nentered the state. \"North Dakota has enjoyed a tuberculosis-free status\nsince the early 1980s,\" he said. \"We are working to maintain this status\nwhich saves our livestock producers thousands of dollars annually in\ntesting costs and paperwork.\"\nBovine tuberculosis is a respiratory disease, causing lung lesions, wasting\nand eventual death of infected animals. Schuler said the disease poses a\nvery minimal risk to humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: ANIMALNET\n\nLIVESTOCK OFFICIALS TRACKING DOWN POSSIBLE DISEASE\nApr. 9/98\nManitoba Co-operator\nNorth Dakota government release\nBismarck, North Dakota State and federal officials have notified two North\nDakota livestock operations that their cattle may have been exposed to a\nserious disease threat. Dr. Larry Schuler, North Dakota state veterinarian,\nsaid seven heifers formerly held in North Dakota came from a Rossburn,\nManitoba, herd that was diagnosed with bovine tuberculosis. The Manitoba\nherd was recently destroyed. \"Canadian officials have informed us that\nseven cattle from that herd were sold earlier as part of a group of 82 head\nto North Dakota buyers last May,\" Schuler said. \"These buyers' ranches are\nnow quarantined and the operators are co-operating with us to determine if\nother animals may have been exposed.\" It is not yet known if any of the\nseven heifers from the Manitoba herd were in fact infected with TB, but\nSchuler said that when the Rossburn herd was destroyed, more than 50 per\ncent of the animals were found to have lung lesions caused by TB.\nThe TB outbreak was initially detected at a Long Prairie, Manitoba,\nslaughter plant when lung lesions were spotted on carcasses, which were\nthen traced back to Rossburn. Dr. Anne Scully, Bottineau, a veterinarian\nwith the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService, has completed an epidemiological study of the two North Dakota\nranches and has determined that no livestock in the surrounding area have\nbeen exposed.\nThe two North Dakota buyers later sold the 82 head of cattle, including the\nseven heifers from the affected herd, at a South Dakota auction market on\nSeptember 23, 1997. The auction house is currently reviewing its records to\nlocate the buyers and South Dakota officials have been informed of the\nsituation. Schuler said it is important to trace all contacts that the\nseven heifers may have had with other animals to ensure the disease has not\nentered the state. \"North Dakota has enjoyed a tuberculosis-free status\nsince the early 1980s,\" he said. \"We are working to maintain this status\nwhich saves our livestock producers thousands of dollars annually in\ntesting costs and paperwork.\"\nBovine tuberculosis is a respiratory disease, causing lung lesions, wasting\nand eventual death of infected animals. Schuler said the disease poses a\nvery minimal risk to humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: ANIMALNET\n\nLIVESTOCK OFFICIALS TRACKING DOWN POSSIBLE DISEASE\nApr. 9/98\nManitoba Co-operator\nNorth Dakota government release\nBismarck, North Dakota State and federal officials have notified two North\nDakota livestock operations that their cattle may have been exposed to a\nserious disease threat. Dr. Larry Schuler, North Dakota state veterinarian,\nsaid seven heifers formerly held in North Dakota came from a Rossburn,\nManitoba, herd that was diagnosed with bovine tuberculosis. The Manitoba\nherd was recently destroyed. \"Canadian officials have informed us that\nseven cattle from that herd were sold earlier as part of a group of 82 head\nto North Dakota buyers last May,\" Schuler said. \"These buyers' ranches are\nnow quarantined and the operators are co-operating with us to determine if\nother animals may have been exposed.\" It is not yet known if any of the\nseven heifers from the Manitoba herd were in fact infected with TB, but\nSchuler said that when the Rossburn herd was destroyed, more than 50 per\ncent of the animals were found to have lung lesions caused by TB.\nThe TB outbreak was initially detected at a Long Prairie, Manitoba,\nslaughter plant when lung lesions were spotted on carcasses, which were\nthen traced back to Rossburn. Dr. Anne Scully, Bottineau, a veterinarian\nwith the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService, has completed an epidemiological study of the two North Dakota\nranches and has determined that no livestock in the surrounding area have\nbeen exposed.\nThe two North Dakota buyers later sold the 82 head of cattle, including the\nseven heifers from the affected herd, at a South Dakota auction market on\nSeptember 23, 1997. The auction house is currently reviewing its records to\nlocate the buyers and South Dakota officials have been informed of the\nsituation. Schuler said it is important to trace all contacts that the\nseven heifers may have had with other animals to ensure the disease has not\nentered the state. \"North Dakota has enjoyed a tuberculosis-free status\nsince the early 1980s,\" he said. \"We are working to maintain this status\nwhich saves our livestock producers thousands of dollars annually in\ntesting costs and paperwork.\"\nBovine tuberculosis is a respiratory disease, causing lung lesions, wasting\nand eventual death of infected animals. Schuler said the disease poses a\nvery minimal risk to humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: ANIMALNET\n\nLIVESTOCK OFFICIALS TRACKING DOWN POSSIBLE DISEASE\nApr. 9/98\nManitoba Co-operator\nNorth Dakota government release\nBismarck, North Dakota State and federal officials have notified two North\nDakota livestock operations that their cattle may have been exposed to a\nserious disease threat. Dr. Larry Schuler, North Dakota state veterinarian,\nsaid seven heifers formerly held in North Dakota came from a Rossburn,\nManitoba, herd that was diagnosed with bovine tuberculosis. The Manitoba\nherd was recently destroyed. \"Canadian officials have informed us that\nseven cattle from that herd were sold earlier as part of a group of 82 head\nto North Dakota buyers last May,\" Schuler said. \"These buyers' ranches are\nnow quarantined and the operators are co-operating with us to determine if\nother animals may have been exposed.\" It is not yet known if any of the\nseven heifers from the Manitoba herd were in fact infected with TB, but\nSchuler said that when the Rossburn herd was destroyed, more than 50 per\ncent of the animals were found to have lung lesions caused by TB.\nThe TB outbreak was initially detected at a Long Prairie, Manitoba,\nslaughter plant when lung lesions were spotted on carcasses, which were\nthen traced back to Rossburn. Dr. Anne Scully, Bottineau, a veterinarian\nwith the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService, has completed an epidemiological study of the two North Dakota\nranches and has determined that no livestock in the surrounding area have\nbeen exposed.\nThe two North Dakota buyers later sold the 82 head of cattle, including the\nseven heifers from the affected herd, at a South Dakota auction market on\nSeptember 23, 1997. The auction house is currently reviewing its records to\nlocate the buyers and South Dakota officials have been informed of the\nsituation. Schuler said it is important to trace all contacts that the\nseven heifers may have had with other animals to ensure the disease has not\nentered the state. \"North Dakota has enjoyed a tuberculosis-free status\nsince the early 1980s,\" he said. \"We are working to maintain this status\nwhich saves our livestock producers thousands of dollars annually in\ntesting costs and paperwork.\"\nBovine tuberculosis is a respiratory disease, causing lung lesions, wasting\nand eventual death of infected animals. Schuler said the disease poses a\nvery minimal risk to humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. LaBudde <ral@lcfltd.com>\nSource: ANIMALNET\n\nLIVESTOCK OFFICIALS TRACKING DOWN POSSIBLE DISEASE\nApr. 9/98\nManitoba Co-operator\nNorth Dakota government release\nBismarck, North Dakota State and federal officials have notified two North\nDakota livestock operations that their cattle may have been exposed to a\nserious disease threat. Dr. Larry Schuler, North Dakota state veterinarian,\nsaid seven heifers formerly held in North Dakota came from a Rossburn,\nManitoba, herd that was diagnosed with bovine tuberculosis. The Manitoba\nherd was recently destroyed. \"Canadian officials have informed us that\nseven cattle from that herd were sold earlier as part of a group of 82 head\nto North Dakota buyers last May,\" Schuler said. \"These buyers' ranches are\nnow quarantined and the operators are co-operating with us to determine if\nother animals may have been exposed.\" It is not yet known if any of the\nseven heifers from the Manitoba herd were in fact infected with TB, but\nSchuler said that when the Rossburn herd was destroyed, more than 50 per\ncent of the animals were found to have lung lesions caused by TB.\nThe TB outbreak was initially detected at a Long Prairie, Manitoba,\nslaughter plant when lung lesions were spotted on carcasses, which were\nthen traced back to Rossburn. Dr. Anne Scully, Bottineau, a veterinarian\nwith the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService, has completed an epidemiological study of the two North Dakota\nranches and has determined that no livestock in the surrounding area have\nbeen exposed.\nThe two North Dakota buyers later sold the 82 head of cattle, including the\nseven heifers from the affected herd, at a South Dakota auction market on\nSeptember 23, 1997. The auction house is currently reviewing its records to\nlocate the buyers and South Dakota officials have been informed of the\nsituation. Schuler said it is important to trace all contacts that the\nseven heifers may have had with other animals to ensure the disease has not\nentered the state. \"North Dakota has enjoyed a tuberculosis-free status\nsince the early 1980s,\" he said. \"We are working to maintain this status\nwhich saves our livestock producers thousands of dollars annually in\ntesting costs and paperwork.\"\nBovine tuberculosis is a respiratory disease, causing lung lesions, wasting\nand eventual death of infected animals. Schuler said the disease poses a\nvery minimal risk to humans.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................mhj/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. While most of the attention given to El Nino\nSouthern Oscillation is its eastern Pacific impact on South, Central, and\nNorth America, let it be known that the \"flip side\" of ENSO is drought in\nthe western Pacific. We should not overlook the concurrent impacts of this\nmajor influencing environmental force.\n--\nHal B. Nash\nAssistant Professor of Biology\nWestern Wyoming College\nRock Springs, WY 82902\nhnash@wwcc.cc.wy.us\n\n[2\nDate: Thu, 20 Nov 1997 17:14:48 -0500\nFrom: DAN JORGENSEN <JORGENSEN@SSCL.UWO.CA>\n\nI wonder about the reporting on locations and numbers. The Lake Sentani,\nTanah Merah,\nMerauke, and Mamberamo areas are all quite distant from one another;\nSentani is right next door to the provincial capital of Jayapura.\n--\nDan Jorgensen\ne-mail: JORGENSEN@SSCL.UWO.CA\n\n[3\nDate: Sat, 22 Nov 1997 07:44:37 +0700 (JVT)\nFrom: Dr. Bachti Alisjahbana <bachti@melsa.net.id>\n\n[Adding to the comments of Mr. Stuart Kirsch about tuberculosis in Irian\nJaya, I\nhave worked in Irian Jaya (in the Wamena Region, central highlands) during\n1991-1993. I have seen that tuberculosis is now widely spread in the\nshorelines, or all the regions on the shore.\nI can't see how we would know where tuberculosis started in Irian Jaya\nbecause before the Dutch occupation, I am sure that people in the northern\nshore had been trading with other Islands of the Indonesian Archipelago.\nIn the central highlands which is isolated from surface access,\ntuberculosis is not [seen as much. In the Capital of the central\nhighlands, Wamena, we [see a few [cases, but in the sub district\n[surrounding area ? I found very few [cases of\ntuberculosis (1-2 cases per /12,000 inhabitants). [The cases that I have\nobserved are mostly newcomers from the shore or [those who have close\ncontact to people from\nshore.\nA tuberculosis program has been running for more than 7 years now, which\n[provides free medication for patients with positive sputum [smears for\nacid-fast bacilli (AFB). Despite this, compliance of patients are poor.\nThe main issue is how to spread the program, how to detect [infected\npersons, and do\n[epidemiological surveillance. We have enough medicine [to expand the\nprogram, but we don't have enough training and people to do surveillance\nand lab work.\n--\nDr. Bachti Alisjahbana\nResident in Internal Medicine,\nMedical Faculty, University Of Padjadjaran Bandung\nJl, Sulanjana 11A, Bandung, 40116, Indonesia\n[Thanks to all who have contributed to the discussion of this situation,\nand especially to Dr. Alisjahbana for offering the perspective of the\npracticing physician in Indonesia. It would appear that there is ample\nwork to be done here for those who wish to contribute to the advancement of\nhealth care delivery in the developing world. While most of the attention given to El Nino\nSouthern Oscillation is its eastern Pacific impact on South, Central, and\nNorth America, let it be known that the \"flip side\" of ENSO is drought in\nthe western Pacific. We should not overlook the concurrent impacts of this\nmajor influencing environmental force.\n--\nHal B. Nash\nAssistant Professor of Biology\nWestern Wyoming College\nRock Springs, WY 82902\nhnash@wwcc.cc.wy.us\n\n[2\nDate: Thu, 20 Nov 1997 17:14:48 -0500\nFrom: DAN JORGENSEN <JORGENSEN@SSCL.UWO.CA>\n\nI wonder about the reporting on locations and numbers. The Lake Sentani,\nTanah Merah,\nMerauke, and Mamberamo areas are all quite distant from one another;\nSentani is right next door to the provincial capital of Jayapura.\n--\nDan Jorgensen\ne-mail: JORGENSEN@SSCL.UWO.CA\n\n[3\nDate: Sat, 22 Nov 1997 07:44:37 +0700 (JVT)\nFrom: Dr. Bachti Alisjahbana <bachti@melsa.net.id>\n\n[Adding to the comments of Mr. Stuart Kirsch about tuberculosis in Irian\nJaya, I\nhave worked in Irian Jaya (in the Wamena Region, central highlands) during\n1991-1993. I have seen that tuberculosis is now widely spread in the\nshorelines, or all the regions on the shore.\nI can't see how we would know where tuberculosis started in Irian Jaya\nbecause before the Dutch occupation, I am sure that people in the northern\nshore had been trading with other Islands of the Indonesian Archipelago.\nIn the central highlands which is isolated from surface access,\ntuberculosis is not [seen as much. In the Capital of the central\nhighlands, Wamena, we [see a few [cases, but in the sub district\n[surrounding area ? I found very few [cases of\ntuberculosis (1-2 cases per /12,000 inhabitants). [The cases that I have\nobserved are mostly newcomers from the shore or [those who have close\ncontact to people from\nshore.\nA tuberculosis program has been running for more than 7 years now, which\n[provides free medication for patients with positive sputum [smears for\nacid-fast bacilli (AFB). Despite this, compliance of patients are poor.\nThe main issue is how to spread the program, how to detect [infected\npersons, and do\n[epidemiological surveillance. We have enough medicine [to expand the\nprogram, but we don't have enough training and people to do surveillance\nand lab work.\n--\nDr. Bachti Alisjahbana\nResident in Internal Medicine,\nMedical Faculty, University Of Padjadjaran Bandung\nJl, Sulanjana 11A, Bandung, 40116, Indonesia\n[Thanks to all who have contributed to the discussion of this situation,\nand especially to Dr. Alisjahbana for offering the perspective of the\npracticing physician in Indonesia. It would appear that there is ample\nwork to be done here for those who wish to contribute to the advancement of\nhealth care delivery in the developing world. The Lake Sentani,\nTanah Merah,\nMerauke, and Mamberamo areas are all quite distant from one another;\nSentani is right next door to the provincial capital of Jayapura.\n--\nDan Jorgensen\ne-mail: JORGENSEN@SSCL.UWO.CA\n\n[3\nDate: Sat, 22 Nov 1997 07:44:37 +0700 (JVT)\nFrom: Dr. Bachti Alisjahbana <bachti@melsa.net.id>\n\n[Adding to the comments of Mr. Stuart Kirsch about tuberculosis in Irian\nJaya, I\nhave worked in Irian Jaya (in the Wamena Region, central highlands) during\n1991-1993. I have seen that tuberculosis is now widely spread in the\nshorelines, or all the regions on the shore.\nI can't see how we would know where tuberculosis started in Irian Jaya\nbecause before the Dutch occupation, I am sure that people in the northern\nshore had been trading with other Islands of the Indonesian Archipelago.\nIn the central highlands which is isolated from surface access,\ntuberculosis is not [seen as much. In the Capital of the central\nhighlands, Wamena, we [see a few [cases, but in the sub district\n[surrounding area ? I found very few [cases of\ntuberculosis (1-2 cases per /12,000 inhabitants). [The cases that I have\nobserved are mostly newcomers from the shore or [those who have close\ncontact to people from\nshore.\nA tuberculosis program has been running for more than 7 years now, which\n[provides free medication for patients with positive sputum [smears for\nacid-fast bacilli (AFB). Despite this, compliance of patients are poor.\nThe main issue is how to spread the program, how to detect [infected\npersons, and do\n[epidemiological surveillance. We have enough medicine [to expand the\nprogram, but we don't have enough training and people to do surveillance\nand lab work.\n--\nDr. Bachti Alisjahbana\nResident in Internal Medicine,\nMedical Faculty, University Of Padjadjaran Bandung\nJl, Sulanjana 11A, Bandung, 40116, Indonesia\n[Thanks to all who have contributed to the discussion of this situation,\nand especially to Dr. Alisjahbana for offering the perspective of the\npracticing physician in Indonesia. It would appear that there is ample\nwork to be done here for those who wish to contribute to the advancement of\nhealth care delivery in the developing world. In the Capital of the central\nhighlands, Wamena, we [see a few [cases, but in the sub district\n[surrounding area ? I found very few [cases of\ntuberculosis (1-2 cases per /12,000 inhabitants). [The cases that I have\nobserved are mostly newcomers from the shore or [those who have close\ncontact to people from\nshore.\nA tuberculosis program has been running for more than 7 years now, which\n[provides free medication for patients with positive sputum [smears for\nacid-fast bacilli (AFB). Despite this, compliance of patients are poor.\nThe main issue is how to spread the program, how to detect [infected\npersons, and do\n[epidemiological surveillance. We have enough medicine [to expand the\nprogram, but we don't have enough training and people to do surveillance\nand lab work.\n--\nDr. Bachti Alisjahbana\nResident in Internal Medicine,\nMedical Faculty, University Of Padjadjaran Bandung\nJl, Sulanjana 11A, Bandung, 40116, Indonesia\n[Thanks to all who have contributed to the discussion of this situation,\nand especially to Dr. Alisjahbana for offering the perspective of the\npracticing physician in Indonesia. Despite this, compliance of patients are poor.\nThe main issue is how to spread the program, how to detect [infected\npersons, and do\n[epidemiological surveillance. We should not overlook the concurrent impacts of this\nmajor influencing environmental force.\n--\nHal B. The Lake Sentani,\nTanah Merah,\nMerauke, and Mamberamo areas are all quite distant from one another;\nSentani is right next door to the provincial capital of Jayapura.\n--\nDan Jorgensen\ne-mail: JORGENSEN@SSCL.UWO.CA\n\n[3\nDate: Sat, 22 Nov 1997 07:44:37 +0700 (JVT)\nFrom: Dr. Bachti Alisjahbana <bachti@melsa.net.id>\n\n[Adding to the comments of Mr. Stuart Kirsch about tuberculosis in Irian\nJaya, I\nhave worked in Irian Jaya (in the Wamena Region, central highlands) during\n1991-1993. I have seen that tuberculosis is now widely spread in the\nshorelines, or all the regions on the shore.\nI can't see how we would know where tuberculosis started in Irian Jaya\nbecause before the Dutch occupation, I am sure that people in the northern\nshore had been trading with other Islands of the Indonesian Archipelago.\nIn the central highlands which is isolated from surface access,\ntuberculosis is not [seen as much. In the Capital of the central\nhighlands, Wamena, we [see a few [cases, but in the sub district\n[surrounding area ? I found very few [cases of\ntuberculosis (1-2 cases per /12,000 inhabitants). [The cases that I have\nobserved are mostly newcomers from the shore or [those who have close\ncontact to people from\nshore.\nA tuberculosis program has been running for more than 7 years now, which\n[provides free medication for patients with positive sputum [smears for\nacid-fast bacilli (AFB). Despite this, compliance of patients are poor.\nThe main issue is how to spread the program, how to detect [infected\npersons, and do\n[epidemiological surveillance. We have enough medicine [to expand the\nprogram, but we don't have enough training and people to do surveillance\nand lab work.\n--\nDr. Bachti Alisjahbana\nResident in Internal Medicine,\nMedical Faculty, University Of Padjadjaran Bandung\nJl, Sulanjana 11A, Bandung, 40116, Indonesia\n[Thanks to all who have contributed to the discussion of this situation,\nand especially to Dr. Alisjahbana for offering the perspective of the\npracticing physician in Indonesia. It would appear that there is ample\nwork to be done here for those who wish to contribute to the advancement of\nhealth care delivery in the developing world. While most of the attention given to El Nino\nSouthern Oscillation is its eastern Pacific impact on South, Central, and\nNorth America, let it be known that the \"flip side\" of ENSO is drought in\nthe western Pacific. We should not overlook the concurrent impacts of this\nmajor influencing environmental force.\n--\nHal B. Nash\nAssistant Professor of Biology\nWestern Wyoming College\nRock Springs, WY 82902\nhnash@wwcc.cc.wy.us\n\n[2\nDate: Thu, 20 Nov 1997 17:14:48 -0500\nFrom: DAN JORGENSEN <JORGENSEN@SSCL.UWO.CA>\n\nI wonder about the reporting on locations and numbers. I have seen that tuberculosis is now widely spread in the\nshorelines, or all the regions on the shore.\nI can't see how we would know where tuberculosis started in Irian Jaya\nbecause before the Dutch occupation, I am sure that people in the northern\nshore had been trading with other Islands of the Indonesian Archipelago.\nIn the central highlands which is isolated from surface access,\ntuberculosis is not [seen as much. In the Capital of the central\nhighlands, Wamena, we [see a few [cases, but in the sub district\n[surrounding area ? I found very few [cases of\ntuberculosis (1-2 cases per /12,000 inhabitants). [The cases that I have\nobserved are mostly newcomers from the shore or [those who have close\ncontact to people from\nshore.\nA tuberculosis program has been running for more than 7 years now, which\n[provides free medication for patients with positive sputum [smears for\nacid-fast bacilli (AFB). Despite this, compliance of patients are poor.\nThe main issue is how to spread the program, how to detect [infected\npersons, and do\n[epidemiological surveillance. We have enough medicine [to expand the\nprogram, but we don't have enough training and people to do surveillance\nand lab work.\n--\nDr. Bachti Alisjahbana\nResident in Internal Medicine,\nMedical Faculty, University Of Padjadjaran Bandung\nJl, Sulanjana 11A, Bandung, 40116, Indonesia\n[Thanks to all who have contributed to the discussion of this situation,\nand especially to Dr. Alisjahbana for offering the perspective of the\npracticing physician in Indonesia. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-11-20 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jayapura", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Mamberamo", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Sulanjana", "country": "Indonesia"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "Indonesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192249", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis - Indonesia (Irian Jaya) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192249", "date": "1997-07-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS IN BUFFALO - SOUTH AFRICA\n**************************************\n[see: Tuberculosis, warthogs - Uganda: human to animal transmission\n970609150546]\nDate: Mon, 07 Jul 1997\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\nVia: Luiz Jacintho da Silva <luisjs@guttenberg.correionet.com.br>\nSource: Mail & Guardian Web, Johannesburg, South Africa, July 4, 1997\n\nBovine tuberculosis (_Mycobacterium bovis_) has infected over half of\nthe buffalo herds in Kruger National Park in South Africa, concentrated in\nthe south part of this 2 million hectare park. The original source of the\ninfection may have been a 1960's outbreak on a cattle farm in the\nsouthwest corner of the park. The Park was unfenced at that time\nwhich allowed the buffalo access to the infected cattle through farm\nfences.\nThe TB was detected in 1990 when a young buffalo was shot due to\nillness. The autopsy showed the TB. Since then, surveys done during\nthe annual cull have shown very high infection rates, up to 85% in one\nherd. A small number of animals of other species have also been found\ninfected: 3 lions, 6 kudu, 2 cheetah and a baboon troop.\nA study group has been set up to develop a strategies for control. One\nplan was to establish a buffalo-free zone to separate the uninfected\nherds in the north from infected herds in the south of the Park. Then the\ninfected animals south of the zone would be slaughtered. This plan was\ndropped when TB was also discovered in the north part of the Park. At\nthis time, Park officials are trying to contain the disease within the Park\nthrough fencing. They are especially concerned with the infection\nspreading to valuable export species such as white rhinoceros. [I hope\nthey are talking about zoological park use - Mod.MDM]\nPark veterinarians are searching for better methods to diagnose TB in the\nvarious species. At this time, they can only test bovids and primates\nwithout resorting to autopsy.\nUntil more research is done, Park officials will have to rely on monitoring\nto follow the disease. There appears to be little spread into other\nspecies. Most of the infected buffalo appear perfectly healthy. It is\nunknown whether the disease will have any adverse affect on the\nbuffalo populations.\n[This situation reminds me of current problems with _M. bovis_ in captive\nherds of deer in the United States. The animals appear healthy and the\ndisease is not discovered until slaughter or autopsy.\nSee also:\nTuberculosis in deer?:rfi - Argentina (Patagonia) 970527175354\nTuberculosis in deer - Argentina (Patagonia) (02) 970531234559\n_M. bovis_ has been almost completely eradicated from US cattle herds\nexcept for a few herds in Texas and California. Animal health officials\nare very concerned about the escape of TB from the infected deer herds into\nthe wild deer populations - Mod.MDM]\n............................................................jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). The original source of the\ninfection may have been a 1960's outbreak on a cattle farm in the\nsouthwest corner of the park. The Park was unfenced at that time\nwhich allowed the buffalo access to the infected cattle through farm\nfences.\nThe TB was detected in 1990 when a young buffalo was shot due to\nillness. The autopsy showed the TB. Since then, surveys done during\nthe annual cull have shown very high infection rates, up to 85% in one\nherd. A small number of animals of other species have also been found\ninfected: 3 lions, 6 kudu, 2 cheetah and a baboon troop.\nA study group has been set up to develop a strategies for control. One\nplan was to establish a buffalo-free zone to separate the uninfected\nherds in the north from infected herds in the south of the Park. Then the\ninfected animals south of the zone would be slaughtered. This plan was\ndropped when TB was also discovered in the north part of the Park. At\nthis time, Park officials are trying to contain the disease within the Park\nthrough fencing. They are especially concerned with the infection\nspreading to valuable export species such as white rhinoceros. [I hope\nthey are talking about zoological park use - Mod.MDM]\nPark veterinarians are searching for better methods to diagnose TB in the\nvarious species. At this time, they can only test bovids and primates\nwithout resorting to autopsy.\nUntil more research is done, Park officials will have to rely on monitoring\nto follow the disease. There appears to be little spread into other\nspecies. Most of the infected buffalo appear perfectly healthy. It is\nunknown whether the disease will have any adverse affect on the\nbuffalo populations.\n[This situation reminds me of current problems with _M. bovis_ in captive\nherds of deer in the United States. The animals appear healthy and the\ndisease is not discovered until slaughter or autopsy.\nSee also:\nTuberculosis in deer?:rfi - Argentina (Patagonia) 970527175354\nTuberculosis in deer - Argentina (Patagonia) (02) 970531234559\n_M. bovis_ has been almost completely eradicated from US cattle herds\nexcept for a few herds in Texas and California. Animal health officials\nare very concerned about the escape of TB from the infected deer herds into\nthe wild deer populations - Mod.MDM]\n............................................................jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The original source of the\ninfection may have been a 1960's outbreak on a cattle farm in the\nsouthwest corner of the park. The Park was unfenced at that time\nwhich allowed the buffalo access to the infected cattle through farm\nfences.\nThe TB was detected in 1990 when a young buffalo was shot due to\nillness. The autopsy showed the TB. Since then, surveys done during\nthe annual cull have shown very high infection rates, up to 85% in one\nherd. A small number of animals of other species have also been found\ninfected: 3 lions, 6 kudu, 2 cheetah and a baboon troop.\nA study group has been set up to develop a strategies for control. One\nplan was to establish a buffalo-free zone to separate the uninfected\nherds in the north from infected herds in the south of the Park. Then the\ninfected animals south of the zone would be slaughtered. This plan was\ndropped when TB was also discovered in the north part of the Park. At\nthis time, Park officials are trying to contain the disease within the Park\nthrough fencing. They are especially concerned with the infection\nspreading to valuable export species such as white rhinoceros. [I hope\nthey are talking about zoological park use - Mod.MDM]\nPark veterinarians are searching for better methods to diagnose TB in the\nvarious species. At this time, they can only test bovids and primates\nwithout resorting to autopsy.\nUntil more research is done, Park officials will have to rely on monitoring\nto follow the disease. There appears to be little spread into other\nspecies. Most of the infected buffalo appear perfectly healthy. It is\nunknown whether the disease will have any adverse affect on the\nbuffalo populations.\n[This situation reminds me of current problems with _M. bovis_ in captive\nherds of deer in the United States. The animals appear healthy and the\ndisease is not discovered until slaughter or autopsy.\nSee also:\nTuberculosis in deer?:rfi - Argentina (Patagonia) 970527175354\nTuberculosis in deer - Argentina (Patagonia) (02) 970531234559\n_M. bovis_ has been almost completely eradicated from US cattle herds\nexcept for a few herds in Texas and California. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-07-07 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-07-04 00:00:00", "1960-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Patagonia", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Park", "country": "St Vincent and Grenadines"}, {"location": "Johannesburg", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192005", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Tuberculosis, contaminated instruments", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192005", "date": "1997-07-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS IN BUFFALO - SOUTH AFRICA\n**************************************\n[see: Tuberculosis, warthogs - Uganda: human to animal transmission\n970609150546]\nDate: Mon, 07 Jul 1997\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\nVia: Luiz Jacintho da Silva <luisjs@guttenberg.correionet.com.br>\nSource: Mail & Guardian Web, Johannesburg, South Africa, July 4, 1997\n\nBovine tuberculosis (_Mycobacterium bovis_) has infected over half of\nthe buffalo herds in Kruger National Park in South Africa, concentrated in\nthe south part of this 2 million hectare park. The original source of the\ninfection may have been a 1960's outbreak on a cattle farm in the\nsouthwest corner of the park. The Park was unfenced at that time\nwhich allowed the buffalo access to the infected cattle through farm\nfences.\nThe TB was detected in 1990 when a young buffalo was shot due to\nillness. The autopsy showed the TB. Since then, surveys done during\nthe annual cull have shown very high infection rates, up to 85% in one\nherd. A small number of animals of other species have also been found\ninfected: 3 lions, 6 kudu, 2 cheetah and a baboon troop.\nA study group has been set up to develop a strategies for control. One\nplan was to establish a buffalo-free zone to separate the uninfected\nherds in the north from infected herds in the south of the Park. Then the\ninfected animals south of the zone would be slaughtered. This plan was\ndropped when TB was also discovered in the north part of the Park. At\nthis time, Park officials are trying to contain the disease within the Park\nthrough fencing. They are especially concerned with the infection\nspreading to valuable export species such as white rhinoceros. [I hope\nthey are talking about zoological park use - Mod.MDM]\nPark veterinarians are searching for better methods to diagnose TB in the\nvarious species. At this time, they can only test bovids and primates\nwithout resorting to autopsy.\nUntil more research is done, Park officials will have to rely on monitoring\nto follow the disease. There appears to be little spread into other\nspecies. Most of the infected buffalo appear perfectly healthy. It is\nunknown whether the disease will have any adverse affect on the\nbuffalo populations.\n[This situation reminds me of current problems with _M. bovis_ in captive\nherds of deer in the United States. The animals appear healthy and the\ndisease is not discovered until slaughter or autopsy.\nSee also:\nTuberculosis in deer?:rfi - Argentina (Patagonia) 970527175354\nTuberculosis in deer - Argentina (Patagonia) (02) 970531234559\n_M. bovis_ has been almost completely eradicated from US cattle herds\nexcept for a few herds in Texas and California. Animal health officials\nare very concerned about the escape of TB from the infected deer herds into\nthe wild deer populations - Mod.MDM]\n............................................................jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The original source of the\ninfection may have been a 1960's outbreak on a cattle farm in the\nsouthwest corner of the park. The Park was unfenced at that time\nwhich allowed the buffalo access to the infected cattle through farm\nfences.\nThe TB was detected in 1990 when a young buffalo was shot due to\nillness. The autopsy showed the TB. Since then, surveys done during\nthe annual cull have shown very high infection rates, up to 85% in one\nherd. A small number of animals of other species have also been found\ninfected: 3 lions, 6 kudu, 2 cheetah and a baboon troop.\nA study group has been set up to develop a strategies for control. One\nplan was to establish a buffalo-free zone to separate the uninfected\nherds in the north from infected herds in the south of the Park. Then the\ninfected animals south of the zone would be slaughtered. This plan was\ndropped when TB was also discovered in the north part of the Park. At\nthis time, Park officials are trying to contain the disease within the Park\nthrough fencing. They are especially concerned with the infection\nspreading to valuable export species such as white rhinoceros. [I hope\nthey are talking about zoological park use - Mod.MDM]\nPark veterinarians are searching for better methods to diagnose TB in the\nvarious species. At this time, they can only test bovids and primates\nwithout resorting to autopsy.\nUntil more research is done, Park officials will have to rely on monitoring\nto follow the disease. There appears to be little spread into other\nspecies. Most of the infected buffalo appear perfectly healthy. It is\nunknown whether the disease will have any adverse affect on the\nbuffalo populations.\n[This situation reminds me of current problems with _M. bovis_ in captive\nherds of deer in the United States. The animals appear healthy and the\ndisease is not discovered until slaughter or autopsy.\nSee also:\nTuberculosis in deer?:rfi - Argentina (Patagonia) 970527175354\nTuberculosis in deer - Argentina (Patagonia) (02) 970531234559\n_M. bovis_ has been almost completely eradicated from US cattle herds\nexcept for a few herds in Texas and California. Animal health officials\nare very concerned about the escape of TB from the infected deer herds into\nthe wild deer populations - Mod.MDM]\n............................................................jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Park was unfenced at that time\nwhich allowed the buffalo access to the infected cattle through farm\nfences.\nThe TB was detected in 1990 when a young buffalo was shot due to\nillness. Then the\ninfected animals south of the zone would be slaughtered. This plan was\ndropped when TB was also discovered in the north part of the Park. At\nthis time, Park officials are trying to contain the disease within the Park\nthrough fencing. They are especially concerned with the infection\nspreading to valuable export species such as white rhinoceros. [I hope\nthey are talking about zoological park use - Mod.MDM]\nPark veterinarians are searching for better methods to diagnose TB in the\nvarious species. At this time, they can only test bovids and primates\nwithout resorting to autopsy.\nUntil more research is done, Park officials will have to rely on monitoring\nto follow the disease. There appears to be little spread into other\nspecies. Most of the infected buffalo appear perfectly healthy. It is\nunknown whether the disease will have any adverse affect on the\nbuffalo populations.\n[This situation reminds me of current problems with _M. bovis_ in captive\nherds of deer in the United States. At\nthis time, Park officials are trying to contain the disease within the Park\nthrough fencing. They are especially concerned with the infection\nspreading to valuable export species such as white rhinoceros. [I hope\nthey are talking about zoological park use - Mod.MDM]\nPark veterinarians are searching for better methods to diagnose TB in the\nvarious species. At this time, they can only test bovids and primates\nwithout resorting to autopsy.\nUntil more research is done, Park officials will have to rely on monitoring\nto follow the disease. The original source of the\ninfection may have been a 1960's outbreak on a cattle farm in the\nsouthwest corner of the park. The Park was unfenced at that time\nwhich allowed the buffalo access to the infected cattle through farm\nfences.\nThe TB was detected in 1990 when a young buffalo was shot due to\nillness. The autopsy showed the TB. Since then, surveys done during\nthe annual cull have shown very high infection rates, up to 85% in one\nherd. A small number of animals of other species have also been found\ninfected: 3 lions, 6 kudu, 2 cheetah and a baboon troop.\nA study group has been set up to develop a strategies for control. One\nplan was to establish a buffalo-free zone to separate the uninfected\nherds in the north from infected herds in the south of the Park. Then the\ninfected animals south of the zone would be slaughtered. This plan was\ndropped when TB was also discovered in the north part of the Park. At\nthis time, Park officials are trying to contain the disease within the Park\nthrough fencing. They are especially concerned with the infection\nspreading to valuable export species such as white rhinoceros. [I hope\nthey are talking about zoological park use - Mod.MDM]\nPark veterinarians are searching for better methods to diagnose TB in the\nvarious species. At this time, they can only test bovids and primates\nwithout resorting to autopsy.\nUntil more research is done, Park officials will have to rely on monitoring\nto follow the disease. There appears to be little spread into other\nspecies. Most of the infected buffalo appear perfectly healthy. It is\nunknown whether the disease will have any adverse affect on the\nbuffalo populations.\n[This situation reminds me of current problems with _M. bovis_ in captive\nherds of deer in the United States. The animals appear healthy and the\ndisease is not discovered until slaughter or autopsy.\nSee also:\nTuberculosis in deer?:rfi - Argentina (Patagonia) 970527175354\nTuberculosis in deer - Argentina (Patagonia) (02) 970531234559\n_M. bovis_ has been almost completely eradicated from US cattle herds\nexcept for a few herds in Texas and California. USA (California) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2191370", "date": "1996-06-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "TUBERCULOSIS, PREVENTION & CONTROL IN PRISONS: GUIDELINES\n==========================================================\nDate: Fri, 7 Jun 1996 09:20:06 -0500\nFrom: owner-mmwr-toc@list.cdc.gov\nSubject: June 7, 1996 CDC Recommendations and Reports\nThe June 7, 1996 edition of CDC Recommendations\nand Reports is now available in Adobe Acrobat format on the Internet.\nJune 7, 1996/Vol. 45/No. RR-8\n* Prevention and Control of Tuberculosis in Correctional Facilities\nRecommendations of the Advisory Council for the Elimination of\nTuberculosis\nTo access the MMWR via the MMWR web page:\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/\nGo to: \"Publications, Products, and Subscription Services,\" then\n\"Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR)\" to find the MMWR.\n-OR-\nVia anonymous FTP:\nftp.cdc.gov in directory pub/Publications/mmwr/rr/rr4508.pdf\nIf you do not have access to either FTP or the WWW, you may retrieve the\nMMWR via e-mail from the FTP mail server. This process is much slower and\nmore complex than either anonymous FTP or the World Wide Web.\nCopy the following script, and paste it into an e-mail message addressed\nto lists@list.cdc.gov\nget mmwr mmwr.archive.960607\nFTP mail will send the file uuencoded. Depending on your e-mail system,\nsome sites may have to process the received mail with a uudecode utility\nto create an acceptable binary file readable by Acrobat. If the e-mail\nsystem does not have uudecode, contact your e-mail administrator.\nUudecode software is available free of charge at many FTP sites on the\nInternet.\nIf you need further instructions about FTP mail send an e-mail message to\nftpmail@crawford.com. The subject line should remain blank, and the body of\nthe message should read:\nhelp\nThe FTP mail server will send you a detailed help file with further\ninstructions and commands.\nIf you have other problems or questions, send e-mail to\nmmwr-questions@list.cdc.gov\n........................................................................MHJ\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
